articles.title: ‘Naked imperialism’: how Trump intervention in Venezuela is a return to form for the US
articles.trailText: Most of the Americas have suffered from interference from their powerful northern neighbour – and are usually the worse off for it
articles.summary: Donald Trump ordered the US bombardment of Venezuela and capture of President Nicolás Maduro, marking the first direct US military attack on a South American country and signaling a return to Monroe doctrine–style “naked imperialism.” Citing a new national security strategy that calls for an expanded military presence, Trump declared “American dominance” in the hemisphere unassailable. This unprecedented operation echoes earlier interventions—from the 1847 US invasion of Mexico, the 1898 Cuba occupation, 1915 Haiti invasion, Cold War–era coups and Operation Condor, to the 1989 Panama Noriega seizure—and raises doubts about long-term stability or democracy in Venezuela.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: outcry and questions after US attack on Venezuela
articles.trailText: With Nicolás Maduro in US custody, Donald Trump says ‘we will run’ Venezuela until ‘a safe, proper and judicious transition’ can be made – key US politics stories from 3 January 2026
articles.summary: In a surprise US special forces raid that knocked out power in parts of Caracas, President Trump seized long-time Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, vowing the US will “run” Venezuela until a “safe, proper and judicious” transition. Republicans hailed enforcement of a 2020 narco-trafficking indictment; Democrats and global powers—including France, China and Russia—condemned the operation as illegal imperialism evoking Iraq. Analysts warn of a “Putinization” of US foreign policy, while major oil firms stay silent on rebuilding the Venezuelan petroleum sector.

articles.title: Maduro’s capture had the world’s ear – but Trump returned to petty gripes
articles.trailText: Though he also discussed plans to ‘run’ Venezuela, the US president could not resist upending his moment of glory
articles.summary: At Mar-a-Lago, Trump hailed the daring US military operation that toppled Venezuelan strongman Nicolás Maduro, floated vaguely running Venezuela, yet quickly derailed his Churchillian moment by airing grievances—against city mayors, state governors, past generals, Congress “leakers,” and Joe Biden. Praising current commanders but dismissing predecessors, he boasted of US crime-fighting help in Chicago, Memphis, New Orleans and LA. Pressed on his secretive planning and the Honduras pardon, Trump blamed Biden’s administration for unfair persecution. Despite a world-shifting raid, he remained fixated on personal slights.

articles.title: Four sisters from LA’s Watts nurture families from the same blocks: ‘They stand in the gap’
articles.trailText: The Sisters of Watts have served families for a decade, providing food, fitness, money and after-school programs
articles.summary: Since 2016, four siblings who grew up in 2.2 sq miles of Watts – Keisha, Robin, Jessica and Penny Daniels – and their extended network have led the Sisters of Watts, a nonprofit delivering food giveaways, fitness, tutoring, after-school programs, housing aid and re-entry support. Through signature events such as Thanksgiving meals for 100+ families and back-to-school drives drawing nearly 4,000 people, they have fostered community bonds, empowered entrepreneurs like ex-inmate Izell Leonard Sr. and opened a neighborhood safe house. Operating largely on small grants, donations and a $100K LAPD safety partnership grant, they face financial precarity but continuously leverage partnerships to sustain and expand services.

articles.title: Epstein disclosures raise key question: why wasn’t he stopped earlier?
articles.trailText: New documents reveal numerous missed opportunities as experts and victims condemn US authorities’ failures
articles.summary: Documents released under the Epstein Files Transparency Act detail repeated missed opportunities to prosecute Jeffrey Epstein’s abuse from a 1996 FBI report by Maria Farmer through a 2004 taxi-driver tip, a 2008 lenient state plea deal and an unpursued 2011 FBI interview with Virginia Giuffre. Experts cite local-federal communication gaps, prosecutors’ risk aversion in ‘he said, she said’ sex-crime cases and Epstein’s powerful network. Analogies to 9/11 intelligence failures underscore fragmented data. Only after a 2019 Miami Herald exposé was Epstein arrested; he died by suicide and Ghislaine Maxwell was later convicted.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Nicolás Maduro wants to have ‘serious talks’ with Trump
articles.trailText: Venezuelan leader calls for ‘dialogue and diplomacy’ between Washington and Caracas following US claims of airstrike
articles.summary: Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has called on Donald Trump to abandon “illegal warmongering” and initiate “serious talks” amid ambiguity over a purported pre-Christmas CIA airstrike—the first on Venezuelan soil since Trump’s five-month military pressure campaign involving naval deployments, drug-trafficking airstrikes, oil tanker blockades and vessel seizures. Maduro rejects US narco-terrorism accusations as a pretext to seize Venezuela’s oil, gold and rare-earth metals and demands dialogue and diplomacy. The digest also highlights Trump’s Iran warnings, DHS artwork controversy, NASA’s Artemis 2 agenda, domestic political shifts and security incidents.

articles.title: California ban on openly carrying guns is unconstitutional, court rules
articles.trailText: Ninth circuit sides with gun owner that ban in counties with more than 200,000 people violates second amendment
articles.summary: A 2-1 Ninth Circuit panel ruled California’s ban on openly carrying firearms in counties over 200,000 residents unconstitutional under the Supreme Court’s 2022 Bruen test. Judges VanDyke and a fellow Trump appointee found open carry part of America’s historical tradition predating the Bill of Rights, citing the 1967 Mulford Act’s racially motivated response to Black Panther patrols. The court partially reversed a 2023 lower-court decision in favor of gun owner Mark Baird, while upholding licensing rules in smaller counties. Senior Judge N. Randy Smith dissented. The decision fuels nationwide Bruen challenges ahead of March’s US v Hemani argument.

articles.title: US woman charged with fetal homicide after allegedly inducing own abortion
articles.trailText: Kentucky woman reportedly ordered medication to end her pregnancy and buried remains in her yard
articles.summary: Melinda S. Spencer, 35, is charged with first-degree fetal homicide, abuse of a corpse and evidence tampering after allegedly ordering abortion pills online and burying a “developed” fetus in her Kentucky backyard. Kentucky bans post-conception abortions by doctors but not self-managed ones, and medical experts deem first-trimester pill abortions safe. Since Roe’s fall, online mail-order abortions rose to 25% of U.S. procedures by 2024, yet 412 pregnancy-related prosecutions occurred in two years, including 16 homicide charges, reflecting a push for fetal personhood often sparked by clinical staff reports.

articles.title: US’s first registry of domestic abusers takes effect in Tennessee
articles.trailText: ‘Savanna’s law’ named after woman killed by ex-boyfriend, who had extensive record of domestic violence allegations
articles.summary: Tennessee’s new “Savanna’s law,” named for 22-year-old deputy Savanna Puckett—killed by ex-boyfriend James Conn in 2022—establishes the US’s first public registry of domestic violence offenders. Effective Jan. 1, it records individuals with two-plus convictions or guilty pleas for domestic abuse, listing name, birth date, photo and conviction locations (excluding addresses) for up to 20 years. Advocated by Puckett’s mother, the non-retroactive database seeks to prevent repeat violence. One in four US women face severe domestic violence, and nearly 70% of mass shootings involve abusers.

articles.title: College freshman identified as one of three hikers found dead on California’s Mount Baldy
articles.trailText: Marcus Alexander Muench Casanova, 19, died on the Devil’s Backbone trail after reportedly falling 500ft
articles.summary: Marcus Alexander Muench Casanova, a 19-year-old freshman at Santa Clara University, was identified as one of three hikers found dead Monday on the Devil’s Backbone trail of California’s Mount Baldy after reportedly falling about 500ft. Rescue crews were hampered by severe winds, and two other victims remain unidentified pending coroner’s reports. His family, describing him as an avid sailor and outdoorsman, asked for privacy. In response, the US Forest Service has closed seven trails, including Devil’s Backbone, through next Wednesday. Mount Baldy, east of Los Angeles, is notorious for winter hazards, with past fatalities like actor Julian Sands.

articles.title: DC pipe bomb suspect must remain in jail before trial, judge rules
articles.trailText: Brian Cole, accused of planting bombs before Capitol attack, presents ‘intolerable risk of danger’, court finds
articles.summary: Federal magistrate judge ordered Brian Cole Jr., 30, of Woodbridge, Virginia, held without bail pending trial after finding he poses an "intolerable risk" to community safety. Cole is accused of constructing, transporting and attempting to detonate two pipe bombs outside Democratic and Republican headquarters on January 5, 2021. Neither device exploded. He faces federal charges of interstate transportation of explosives and malicious attempted destruction, carrying up to 20 years in prison. Investigators cite cell-tower pings, license-plate data, bomb parts seized at his home, purchase records spanning 2019–22 and his partial admission. Defense cited his autism diagnosis and clean record in seeking home detention.

articles.title: US homeland security condemned for using Japanese artist’s work without consent
articles.trailText: Hiroshi Nagai, in a post on X, has objected to his artwork being used by the agency to promote its deportation agenda
articles.summary: Hiroshi Nagai, a 78-year-old Japanese graphic designer known for his 1950s Americana dreamscapes, objected on X after the US Department of Homeland Security used his palm-tree beach image without permission to promote “America after 100 million deportations” and tout “the peace of a nation no longer besieged by the third world.” DHS defended its action, saying it’ll “use every tool at its disposal” to inform the public. This incident follows similar unauthorized uses of Thomas Kinkade’s suburban painting (“Protect the homeland”) and pop stars’ music—Olivia Rodrigo’s “all-american bitch” and Sabrina Carpenter’s “Juno”—in immigration campaigns, all condemned by rights holders.

articles.title: FBI says it thwarted planned New Year’s Eve terrorist attack in North Carolina
articles.trailText: FBI says teen was planning Islamic State-inspired hammer and knife attack on Jews, Christians and LGBTQ+ people
articles.summary: An 18-year-old North Carolina resident, Christian Sturdivant, was arrested December 31 after the FBI thwarted his year-long, Islamic State-inspired plot to attack a grocery store and restaurant on New Year’s Eve in Mint Hill. Charged with providing material support to a foreign terrorist organization, prosecutors say a search of his home uncovered knives, hammers and detailed notes targeting Jews, Christians and LGBTQ+ people, and he pledged allegiance online—unwittingly to an undercover NYPD agent. Known to the FBI since age 14 for earlier extremist contacts, Sturdivant faces up to 20 years in prison.

articles.title: Growing number of California sheriffs no longer respond to mental health calls
articles.trailText: A shift away from police-led responses spreads, but gaps in crisis teams leave some communities exposed
articles.summary: Over the past year, several California sheriff’s offices—including Sacramento and El Cajon—have stopped answering 911 mental-health crisis calls unless a crime is in progress or someone faces imminent danger, a move spurred by a 2024 Ninth Circuit ruling holding officers liable for excessive force. Between 2015 and 2024, US police killed 2,057 people in mental-health crises (274 in California). Authorities now steer callers to 988 and local hotlines or co-response teams like San Diego’s PERT, which de-escalates over 90% of cases. Advocates warn that uneven funding, training and call-center integration leave gaps in community safety and call for shifting police budgets toward health-focused responders.

articles.title: Israel accuses Mamdani of antisemitism on first day as New York mayor
articles.trailText: Foreign ministry says mayor has poured ‘antisemitic gasoline on an open fire’ by scrapping IHRA definition
articles.summary: On his first day in office New York Mayor Zohran Mamdani rescinded the outgoing administration’s adoption of the IHRA definition of antisemitism and lifted restrictions on boycotting Israel, prompting Israel’s foreign ministry to accuse him of “pouring antisemitic gasoline on an open fire.” Mamdani pledged to protect Jewish New Yorkers, fund hate-crime prevention, and fight all forms of hate in a “politics of universality.” The New York chapter of CAIR welcomed overturning what it called an overly broad definition, while Jewish leaders warned the move could weaken efforts to combat antisemitism.

articles.title: Colorado authorities suspect mountain lion attack after woman found dead near trail
articles.trailText: Other hikers had reported seeing the animal near the body and scared it away ‘by throwing rocks’ at it
articles.summary: Colorado Parks and Wildlife investigating suspected mountain lion attack after a woman was found dead near Crosier Mountain trail in unincorporated Larimer County around 12:15 pm Thursday. Hikers scared off a lion by throwing rocks but found no pulse. CPW, sheriff deputies and firefighters euthanized two lions found on scene per policy; necropsies will check for diseases. Mountain lion attacks are rare—28 since 1990, last fatality in 1999—and Colorado's cougar population is estimated at 3,800–4,400.

articles.title: ‘It’s our turn’: gun-safety advocates are riding a ‘seismic’ wave to US legislatures
articles.trailText: A once-toxic topic is helping survivors and relatives of victims get elected to enact the laws they helped draft
articles.summary: Armed with personal loss and community ties, a new generation of mostly Democratic legislators—like Tennessee’s Justin Pearson, Gen Z representative Maxwell Frost and former activists Lucy McBath and Abigail Spanberger—are leveraging firsthand experiences with gun violence to win state and federal races. Their candidacies reflect a decade-long shift that’s turned gun safety from a political taboo into a winning platform, driven by survivors’ networks such as March for Our Lives and Moms Demand Action. Expelled for protest, Pearson champions red flag laws, waiting periods and holistic approaches linking gun violence to mental health, poverty and housing—seeking federal reforms amid exhausted voters ready for change.

articles.title: Mamdani pledges ‘new era’ for New York and vows to govern ‘audaciously’
articles.trailText: New mayor gives speech at inauguration and rescinds all orders signed by Eric Adams after corruption indictment
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani, 34-year-old democratic socialist, was sworn in as New York’s first Muslim, south Asian, Africa-born mayor using the Qur’an, pledging a “new era” and to govern “expansively and audaciously” without lowering expectations. He rescinded all executive orders by Eric Adams post-indictment, plans to reissue key directives, and outlined populist promises—free childcare and buses, rent freeze for 1m households, city-run grocery pilot—funded by taxing the wealthy. Introduced by Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and sworn in by Bernie Sanders, Mamdani faces state-level tax constraints, Trump’s “communist” jeers, Jewish community concerns over his Israel stance, and service delivery challenges.

articles.title: 2025 was a big year for climate in the US courts - these were the wins and losses
articles.trailText: Americans are increasingly turning to courts to hold big oil accountable. Here are major trends that emerged last year
articles.summary: In 2025, more than 70 US states, cities and local governments pressed climate liability claims against major oil firms, scoring wins as courts—up to the Supreme Court—rejected attempts to dismiss cases like Honolulu’s, though Puerto Rico and Charleston voluntarily dropped suits. A pending high-court review of Boulder’s lawsuit could set a national precedent. Novel filings, including a wrongful-death claim after a heat wave and a homeowners’ insurance class action, broke new ground. Meanwhile, fossil fuel interests, backed by Trump’s executive order and lobbying for a federal liability shield, are racing to insulate themselves. In 2026, cases targeting plastic pollution and extreme-weather attribution are on the rise.

articles.title: Donald Trump wants the US back on the moon before his term ends. Can it happen?
articles.trailText: After losing a year to havoc and job-slashing at Nasa, the pressure is on billionaire administrator Jared Isaacman
articles.summary: New NASA administrator Jared Isaacman, an ally of Elon Musk, faces Trump’s mandate to plant an American flag on the moon before his term concludes. With Artemis 2 planned for spring 2026 and a crewed Artemis 3 lunar landing targeted by mid-2027, Isaacman must navigate past budget cuts, job purges and delayed SLS rockets. Experts urge phasing out SLS for commercial heavy-lift services, leasing private orbital stations by 2028, and leveraging SpaceX and Blue Origin to outpace China’s 2030 lunar ambitions.

articles.title: Italian pasta makers win reprieve from Trump tariffs
articles.trailText: US cuts proposed levies to between 2% and 14% despite accusing Italian producers of selling at unfairly low prices
articles.summary: After threatened 92% duties, US Department of Commerce cut proposed tariffs on 13 Italian pasta producers (Barilla, La Molisana, Pastificio Lucio Garofalo etc.) to 2%-14%, atop the existing 15% EU goods duty. Italy supplies about $770m of pasta annually to the US, with targeted firms accounting for roughly 16% of imports. The preliminary analysis, published early January, found producers addressed US concerns; final duty rates will be set on March 12. Italy’s agribusiness group Coldiretti warned of a “fatal blow” had rates stayed high, while the EU Commission stands ready to intervene. This follows US delays of hikes on furniture and cabinets.

articles.title: Swiss investigators race to identify victims after 40 killed in resort bar fire | First Thing
articles.trailText: Blaze that swept through crowded New Year’s Eve bar in Crans-Montana also injured 115 people. Plus, the politicians and advocates making climate policy part of the affordability agenda
articles.summary: Swiss investigators are hastening the identification of around 40 people killed and 115 injured in a New Year’s Eve blaze at Le Constellation bar in Crans-Montana, a ski resort. President Guy Parmelin declared five days of national mourning, calling the tragedy “a drama of an unknown scale” and mourning the loss of youthful ambitions. Investigators are probing whether celebratory sparklers triggered the fire at 1:30 am. DNA and forensic work may take days or weeks. Italy’s Emanuele Galeppini emerged as the first named victim. He vowed safety reforms to prevent similar disasters.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president denies falling asleep in public meetings as he defends ‘perfect’ health
articles.trailText: In an interview with The Wall Street Journal, Trump robustly defended his health after the first year of his second term in office raised growing questions. Key US politics stories from 1 January 2026
articles.summary: In a WSJ interview, 79-year-old President Trump dismisses concerns over his health, calling it “perfect,” denies sleeping in meetings—blaming “blinks”—and defends his daily high-dose aspirin habit. At his Mar-a-Lago New Year’s Eve party, he auctioned a Jesus portrait for $2.75 million. The State Dept’s $2 billion aid pledge demands UN reforms, while polling suggests abortion rights may lose traction in 2026 midterms. South Park writer registered trumpkennedycenter.org amid a court battle over renaming the Kennedy Center, and federal gender-affirming care coverage is cut under new policy as NYC’s new mayor vows a “new era.”

articles.title: South Park writer buys ‘Trump Kennedy Center’ domain name
articles.trailText: Toby Morton now owns trumpkennedycenter.org, which advertises new year performance by the ‘Epstein dancers’
articles.summary: South Park writer-producer Toby Morton purchased trumpkennedycenter.org after predicting President Trump’s renaming of the John F. Kennedy Center into the “Trump Kennedy Center” and installed a satirical webpage advertising an “Epstein dancers” show instead of the classical lineup. Morton, known for snapping up domains tied to authoritarian figures, calls it “performance art” to expose political power’s absurdity. The real Kennedy Center has seen performer walkouts and legal challenges over the rebranding. A British comedy troupe similarly grabbed trump-kennedycenter.org, reflecting how satire has become a key counter to political theatre.

articles.title: Trump says he takes more aspirin than recommended but his ‘health is perfect’
articles.trailText: President tells Wall Street Journal in interview that his doctors encouraged him to take lower dose but he declined
articles.summary: President Trump tells the Wall Street Journal he’s taken high-dose aspirin daily for 25 years despite doctors’ advice to reduce it, insisting his health is "perfect" and preferring "thin blood." Under scrutiny after makeup and drowsiness sightings, he outlined an early-morning White House routine with streamlined meetings, a two-week Mar-a-Lago break, and staff tips to stay alert. He regretted a CT/MRI scan that fueled speculation, while Navy Capt. Sean Barbabella rates his health "exceptional" with a cardiac age of 65. Trump dismissed compression socks and treadmill workouts, crediting strong genetics and enough energy for golf.

articles.title: ‘Their first instinct was to loot’: how Trump’s acolytes are plundering the Kennedy Center
articles.trailText: Sheldon Whitehouse, an ex officio member of the Kennedy Center board, remains undeterred and determined to press on with his investigation
articles.summary: After Trump allies seized control of the Kennedy Center board in February—ousting Biden appointees, appointing Ric Grenell, and unilaterally renaming it to the Donald J. Trump Kennedy Center—Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse has launched a Senate EPW investigation into alleged cronyism, mismanagement and slush-fund spending. Whitehouse cites waived fees for MAGA events and FIFA, no-bid contracts to Trump allies, luxury Watergate stays and multimillion-dollar losses. Grenell insists donations cover costs but has provided no documentation. The probe continues amid family objections that a name change needs Congress.

articles.title: Trump rings in 2026 at Mar-a-Lago with $2.75m auction of Jesus painting
articles.trailText: President auctioned off freshly painted portrait and said his new year’s resolution was ‘peace on Earth’
articles.summary: Donald Trump rang in 2026 with a New Year’s Eve gala at Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, auctioning a live-painted Jesus portrait by Vanessa Horabuena for $2.75 million, with proceeds split between St. Jude’s Children’s Hospital and the local sheriff’s department. Accompanied by a slow “Hallelujah” performance, the event drew figures including Rudy Giuliani, Kristi Noem, Benjamin and Sara Netanyahu, Emirati billionaire Hussain Sajwani, and Tom Emmer. Trump toasted “peace on Earth” while amid pre–midnight social media attacks labeling Democrats “cheaters and thieves” and targeting governors Jared Polis and Tim Walz.

articles.title: From rent to utility bills: the politicians and advocates making climate policy part of the affordability agenda
articles.trailText: As the Trump administration derides climate policy as a ‘scam’, emissions-cutting measures are gaining popularity
articles.summary: Progressive politicians and advocates are recasting climate action as economic populism, arguing that extreme weather, inefficient homes and fossil-fuel pollution drive up utility bills, healthcare costs and rents. Sunrise Movement’s Stevie O’Hanlon and others link emissions cuts to lower living expenses. Officials from NYC mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani’s free buses and school retrofits to Seattle’s Katie Wilson’s green social housing and right-to-repair laws in Nebraska reflect affordability-first policies. Teachers and labor unions secure solar panels, unionized clean-energy jobs and tenant protections. Campaigns for public power utilities and “climate superfund” laws in Vermont and New York push polluter accountability. Opinion polls show voters support measures that address both climate and pocketbook concerns.

articles.title: ‘I don’t think we should have billionaires’: mayor Zohran Mamdani in his own words
articles.trailText: Democratic socialist mayor led historic push to lead New York, speaking on immigration, Trump and subway burritos
articles.summary: New York City’s first democratic socialist mayor Zohran Mamdani used his campaign and victory speeches to champion immigrant contributions, reject Islamophobia, and challenge billionaire inequality. He sparred with Andrew Cuomo, defended affordable transit via a viral “cyclist” rebuke, and joked about subway burritos. Mamdani vowed to protect immigrant communities from ICE, raise taxes on the wealthy, and oppose Trump’s agenda. His direct address to Trump—“turn the volume up”—underscored his goal to dismantle conditions enabling authoritarianism.

articles.title: How to talk dating like gen Z: 51 (hyperspecific) terms for love, sex and bad behavior
articles.trailText: As young people take on a messy dating landscape, they’ve created their own lexicon to match. Here’s like what phrases ‘bird theory’ and ‘monkey branching’ mean
articles.summary: Gen Z has crafted an ever-expanding, meme-infused lexicon to navigate romance, from “ghostlighting” (returning after ghosting) and “monkey branching” (lining up a rebound) to green/beige/red flags and “bird theory” tests of curiosity. The guide covers archetypes (black cat girlfriend, golden retriever boyfriend), budget-friendly “choremance,” modern consent (“emotional vibe coding”), microcheating, polyamory, and app behaviors (“wokefishing,” phubbing, X-ing). It illustrates how social media, economic pressures, and identity politics shape 51 hyper-specific dating phenomena.

articles.title: Zohran Mamdani is now mayor of New York City. Here’s what he campaigned on
articles.trailText: From freezing rents to free buses and municipal grocery stores – a recap of the policies that won Mamdani the office
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani, NYC’s 111th mayor and first Muslim democratic socialist Democrat, was sworn in at a repurposed subway station. His platform aims to freeze rent hikes by reforming the rent guidelines board, build 200,000 affordable units, eliminate bus fares, launch municipal grocery stores at wholesale prices, create a Community Safety department with a public-health model, provide free childcare for ages 0–5, expand K–12 services and raise the minimum wage to $30 by 2030. He’ll fund $10 billion by hiking corporate tax to 11.5% and the top income rate by 2%, and bolster sanctuary city protections by removing ICE from city facilities.

articles.title: Zohran Mamdani sworn in as mayor of New York City
articles.trailText: New mayor, 34, was sworn in by state attorney general Letitia James in old beaux-arts city hall subway station
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani, 34, was sworn in at midnight as New York City’s new mayor in a private ceremony at the old beaux-arts City Hall subway station, officiated by NY Attorney General Letitia James using two Qur’ans. Family and cultural figures attended as Mamdani highlighted the vital role of public transit and appointed veteran planner Mike Flynn as transportation commissioner. The working-people–themed inauguration precedes a public swearing-in with Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Bernie Sanders. A democratic socialist, Mamdani built a grassroots campaign to win November’s election with 50.8% on a platform of affordability, rent freezes, free transit and community safety.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: the end of some national guard efforts and all childcare payments
articles.trailText: Trump abruptly announced attempts to impose troops in some cities, while reportedly freezing childcare payments to all states – key US politics stories from 31 December at a glance
articles.summary: On 31 December 2025 the Trump administration abruptly halted planned federal troop deployments in Los Angeles, Chicago and Portland after months of friction with local officials. Simultaneously, HHS froze all state childcare funding pending proof of legitimate use. A federal appeals court permitted the White House to end Medicaid coverage for Planned Parenthood clinics in 22 states and DC. A West Health-Gallup poll found a record 23% of Americans view the US healthcare system as in crisis. The Kennedy Center revised bylaws to restrict votes to Trump-appointed trustees amid plans to bear his name, while Wall Street closed the year near record highs.

articles.title: Lauren Boebert claims Trump’s veto of safe drinking water bill is retaliation
articles.trailText: Colorado lawmaker, who pushed for Epstein files release, points to bill’s unanimous passage through US House and Senate
articles.summary: Colorado Republican Rep. Lauren Boebert accused former President Donald Trump of political retaliation after he vetoed a unanimously passed bill funding a decades-long project to deliver safe drinking water to 39 eastern plains communities plagued by high salt and radioactive groundwater. Trump branded it an expensive taxpayer handout in his veto letter as part of a fiscal sanity push. Boebert linked the veto to her efforts to release Jeffrey Epstein files and to Colorado’s refusal to pardon election conspirator Tina Peters, warning it denies clean water to 50,000 rural residents. He also vetoed a $14m Everglades project for the Miccosukee Tribe.

articles.title: Trump administration reportedly freezes all childcare payments to all states
articles.trailText: Trump official says funds will be released ‘only when states prove they are being spent legitimately’
articles.summary: The Department of Health and Human Services has frozen all federal childcare payments to every state, mandating detailed documentation—justification, receipts or photo evidence, attendance logs, licensing, inspection and monitoring reports—before releasing funds. Announced by HHS deputy secretary Jim O’Neill and assistant secretary Alex Adams, the move responds to a viral video alleging fraud at Somali American daycare centers in Minneapolis. Minnesota Governor Tim Walz denounced the nationwide freeze as a politically motivated, xenophobic tactic.

articles.title: Jack Smith told House committee he had ‘proof beyond reasonable doubt’ in cases against Trump
articles.trailText: Ex-special counsel testified in front of judiciary committee about aborted federal prosecution of Donald Trump
articles.summary: Former special counsel Jack Smith told the Republican-led House Judiciary Committee in a private deposition that he never consulted President Biden or AG Garland on the classified-documents and election-interference cases against Trump, asserting he had “proof beyond a reasonable doubt.” He cautioned that unpunished election meddling would be “catastrophic” for democracy, defended the lawful phone-data subpoenas, and said he’d prosecute any president on identical facts. Both federal indictments were later dropped after Trump’s 2024 victory following Supreme Court and Judge Cannon rulings.

articles.title: Trump backs away from deploying national guard in Los Angeles, Chicago and Portland
articles.trailText: Decision comes after DoJ stopped contesting California court’s ruling to return control of guard to state’s governor
articles.summary: Trump abruptly halted federal National Guard deployments in Los Angeles, Chicago and Portland after the Justice Department dropped its appeal of a California court’s order restoring Governor Gavin Newsom’s command and the Supreme Court rebuked efforts to federalize troops in Illinois. Newsom ordered state guards home, denouncing the move as illegal intimidation. On Truth Social, Trump vowed a stronger redeployment when crime rises. The climbdown follows legal setbacks over his use of guard units to enforce immigration policies and clouds plans for forces in DC and New Orleans.

articles.title: ICE plans $100m yearlong ‘wartime recruitment’ media blitz to attract new agents
articles.trailText: Campaign will target rightwing ideologues to fill ranks to meet Trump deportation goals in 2026
articles.summary: ICE has unveiled a $100 million, year-long “wartime recruitment” media blitz aimed at right-wing audiences—MAGA radio listeners, gun enthusiasts, military affairs and men’s lifestyle followers—using geofencing at bases, races, trade shows and campuses. The agency plans to spend over $8 million on fitness, military and tactical influencers, deploy patriotic ads and offer up to $50 000 bonuses and $60 000 in loan repayment. With $77 billion in new enforcement funding, ICE has fielded 220 000 applications and made 18 000 offers, gearing up for an “explosion” of arrests in 2026.

articles.title: End of an era as New York City transit retires three-decade-old MetroCard
articles.trailText: Resisted at first, the replacement for the subway token became an indelible symbol of the city
articles.summary: On Jan 1, as newly elected mayor Zohran Mamdani takes office, NYC's three-decade-old MetroCard is retired and sales cease, replaced by OMNY contactless taps. Introduced in 1994 after tokens phased out, MetroCard's magnetic-stripe passes and unlimited 30-day option transformed commuting but suffered swipe failures. Jodi Shapiro of the Transit Museum calls it revolutionary; its special swipe technique, commemorative designs from Bowie to Seinfeld, and Hillary Clinton's five-swipe Bronx struggle cemented its cultural status. A Washington Square Park funeral and fare-gifting tradition underscore mixed nostalgia, as MetroCards remain valid until 2026.

articles.title: ‘It’s not a coincidence’: journalists of color on being laid off amid Trump’s anti-DEI push
articles.trailText: Black and brown former employees from CBS, NBC and Teen Vogue talk about the effects of being let go
articles.summary: Black and brown journalists at CBS, NBC and Teen Vogue say they were disproportionately laid off amid corporate restructurings and Trump’s anti-DEI directives. At CBS News, four producers of color lost jobs while five white colleagues were reassigned after its Skydance–Paramount merger, a disparity spotlighted in a viral TikTok. NBC dismantled its dedicated Black, Latino, Asian American and LGBTQ+ vertical teams, folding their work into the broader newsroom. Teen Vogue’s integration into Vogue led to the exit of most women of color on staff. These cuts align with FCC moves to de-prioritize DEI and have spurred plans for a Black Media Caucus to launch new outlets.

articles.title: Trump attacks Walz and Omar after freezing Minnesota childcare funding
articles.trailText: US president goes on racist tirade against lawmaker and Somali Americans, alleging fraud in industry
articles.summary: President Donald Trump froze federal Minnesota childcare funding, citing alleged rampant fraud—up to 90% he attributed to Somali immigrants—while launching racist attacks on Gov. Tim Walz (calling him “Crooked Governor”) and Rep. Ilhan Omar (accusing her of scamming, calling for deportations). The move follows YouTuber Nick Shirley’s viral but disputed videos on fraud at Somali American daycare centers. Walz and Omar condemned the politicization of anti-fraud efforts, noting prosecutions of 98 individuals and disputing Trump’s broader smears against their state and community.

articles.title: US justice department reportedly reviewing more than 5m pages of Epstein files
articles.trailText: Figure represents significant expansion on earlier estimates as Democrats accuse Trump officials of ‘hiding something’
articles.summary: NYT reports the DOJ is reviewing over 5 million pages of FBI files on Jeffrey Epstein—an expansion beyond the 300 GB estimate—that is diverting national security and criminal case resources. Deputy AG Todd Blanche has enlisted around 400 lawyers to work through the holidays, aiming for a Jan 20 completion. Senate Democrats led by Chuck Schumer accuse the DOJ of releasing fewer than 40,000 pages (0.01%) and hiding materials. A Christmas Eve DOJ post pledges compliance with the Epstein Files Transparency Act and Trump’s release order. Early disclosures show FBI alerts a decade earlier and some inauthentic documents.

articles.title: Court allows White House to end Medicaid funding for Planned Parenthood in 22 states
articles.trailText: Appeals court reversed injunction blocking Trump administration’s defunding of reproductive healthcare giant
articles.summary: An appeals panel of the 1st US Circuit Court on Tuesday lifted Judge Indira Talwani’s injunction, allowing the Trump administration to end Medicaid reimbursements for Planned Parenthood health centers in 22 states plus DC. The move enforces a GOP ‘One Big Beautiful Bill Act’ provision barring Medicaid funding to tax-exempt reproductive providers performing abortions who received over $800,000 in reimbursements. California AG Rob Bonta and other Democratic attorneys general argue the law imposes an unconstitutional retroactive condition and risks closing scores of clinics—jeopardizing STI tests, cancer screenings and contraception for more than 1.5 million Medicaid visits in 2024.

articles.title: Kennedy Center reportedly changed rules before vote to add Trump’s name
articles.trailText: Bylaws that would limit voting to Trump-appointed trustees appears to reveal long-held renaming plan
articles.summary: In May, the Kennedy Center quietly revised bylaws to bar ex-officio board members (Congressional appointees) from voting or forming a quorum. This change enabled a unanimous December 18 vote—restricted to Trump-appointed trustees—to rename the venue the Donald J. Trump and John F. Kennedy Memorial Center for the Performing Arts. Artists and lawmakers have protested, with some bookings canceled and Rep. Joyce Beatty suing to restore Congressional authorization. Critics argue the move violates the center’s charter; audience ratings for Trump-hosted Honors awards also plunged.

articles.title: ‘Heartbreaking’: Florida wildlife groups decry state-sanctioned bear hunt
articles.trailText: Fifty-two black bears were killed in three-week hunt state officials said was necessary to reduce ursine population
articles.summary: Florida’s Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission (FWC) reported killing 52 black bears in a Dec 6-28 hunt—its first since a 2015 event was halted after nearly 300 bears, many pregnant or with cubs, were killed. Aimed at controlling a rebound from hundreds in the 1970s to over 4,000 bears today, the FWC issued 172 single-take permits across four high-density zones, barred dog packs initially, and plans to phase them in later. Officials hailed the hunt as science-based and conservative. Wildlife groups, citing an 81% public opposition poll, condemned bait traps, archery and “trophy hunter” displays as barbaric, promising continued legal fights. Full harvest data is pending.

articles.title: ‘A state of crisis’: record number of Americans are pessimistic about US healthcare system
articles.trailText: Costs, insurance delays and difficult-to-obtain mental health treatment plague the US health system
articles.summary: Poll by West Health-Gallup finds a record 23% of Americans see US healthcare as in crisis and 47% cite major problems, with 29% naming cost as the top concern. Critics cite insurance delays, rising drug prices and leadership under Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. as driving distrust. KFF analyst Emma Wager says aging demographics and inflation make care costs unpredictable. West Health's Timothy Lash warns high prices drive stress, worsen health and force patients to skip treatments – a trend Gallup shows peaks in Mississippi. Experts highlight mental health carve-out copays, calling for integration into primary care to lower expenses and improve outcomes.

articles.title: ‘Not my first rodeo’: meet the 21-year-old serving as Georgia’s youngest state legislator
articles.trailText: Democrat Muhammad Akbar Ali joins the Georgia state house as a legislator representing an Atlanta suburb
articles.summary: 21-year-old Democrat Muhammad Akbar Ali won a runoff for Georgia’s 107th House District in Snellville, becoming the youngest state legislator. A former legislative aide and longtime Gwinnett activist, he emphasizes bipartisan relationships and grassroots outreach in a 70% nonwhite, immigrant-rich district. His coalition spanned DSA to ex-governor Roy Barnes. Campaign themes included Medicaid expansion, affordable housing, lower property taxes, school safety and small-business relief. Ali vows to boost youth turnout and cross the aisle effectively.

articles.title: How the climate crisis showed up in Americans’ lives this year: ‘The shift has been swift and stark’
articles.trailText: Guardian US readers share how global heating and biodiversity loss affected their lives in ways that don’t always make the headlines
articles.summary: In a year of record heat and storms, Guardian US readers recount swift, stark shifts: a Pacific Northwest father laments snow’s disappearance for his children as regional temps rise; an Appalachian Trail hiker confronts dried streams and mosquito plagues post-Hurricane Helene; a Sacramento gardener struggles with a shrinking growing season, abandoning crops and pivoting to drought-tolerant legumes; and a retired naturalist mourns dwindling butterflies and birds even as he fights for conservation. These personal accounts underscore the intimate impacts of biodiversity loss and global heating and the urgent need to adapt local practices to a rapidly changing climate.

articles.title: ‘She has no expertise’: the US medical community girds for Tracy Beth Høeg’s tenure at the FDA
articles.trailText: The Danish American who doubted Covid shots is meant to lead drug regulation – but has focused on vaccines
articles.summary: Tracy Beth Høeg, a sports physician and Covid-vaccine skeptic, has been named acting director of the FDA’s Center for Drug Evaluation and Research (CDER). Lacking drug-development or regulatory leadership experience, she has pushed for a Denmark-style childhood schedule, questioned aluminium adjuvant and myocarditis data, and proposed excluding young men from Covid shots. Her appointment—after collaboration with vaccines chief Vinay Prasad—and oversight of a fast-track drug voucher program alarm former CDER directors, who warn of reduced transparency, scientific rigor and a push to dismantle approved vaccines.

articles.title: Trump family business delays launch of $499 gold smartphone
articles.trailText: US-made device planned by end of year hit by recent government shutdown affecting shipments
articles.summary: Trump Mobile has postponed the December launch of its $499 gold-coloured T1 smartphone—marketed as a US-made rival to Apple and Samsung—after the recent government shutdown disrupted shipments. Customers paid $100 deposits despite unclear domestic manufacturing capacity. Led by Donald Jr. and Eric Trump under a Trump Organization licensing deal, the venture also offers a $47.45/month service plan and refurbished iPhones and Samsungs at mixed prices. Having generated over $8 million in licensing revenue in 2024, the telecom expansion raises potential conflict-of-interest concerns under federal regulation.

articles.title: US executions surged in 2025 to highest level in 16 years
articles.trailText: Forty-seven men killed by states operating death penalty – almost double last year’s number
articles.summary: In 2025 US states carrying out capital punishment executed 47 men, nearly double 2024 and the highest annual total since 2009. Driven by President Trump’s Jan. 20 executive order “Restoring the death penalty” and DOJ new federal prosecutions, Florida’s executions jumped from one to 19, making it the leading state alongside Texas, Alabama and South Carolina, which collectively accounted for about 75% of all executions. Twelve states resumed or ramped up use—Louisiana with nitrogen gas, South Carolina with firing squad—while the Supreme Court denied every stay, even as public support fell to a 50-year low of 52%.

articles.title: Trump administration freezes childcare funding to Minnesota in wake of fraud scheme allegations
articles.trailText: Officials claim to find ‘rampant fraud’ in childcare funding, but prosecutions began in Biden era and Tim Walz says ‘we’ve spent years cracking down on it’
articles.summary: The Trump administration has halted federal childcare funding in Minnesota, citing “rampant fraud” uncovered in programs dating back to Biden-era prosecutions. HHS deputy Jim O’Neill announced new nationwide requirements for receipts, photos and justifications, plus a fraud hotline, and demanded Governor Tim Walz conduct an audit of attendance, licenses and investigations. Conservatives, led by influencer Nick Shirley, focused on Somali American operators in Minneapolis, despite indictments since 2022 that convicted 57 people in a $250m child nutrition scheme. Walz insists his administration has long cracked down on fraud and accuses Trump of politicizing vital support programs.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president’s Kennedy Center name change is a sour note for these artists
articles.trailText: More musical acts pull out of performances after Trump slaps his name on the building – key US politics stories from 30 December at a glance
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s renaming of DC’s Kennedy Center to the “Trump-Kennedy Center” has prompted jazz septet the Cookers, drummer Chuck Redd and folk singer Kristy Lee to cancel scheduled gigs, condemning the decision as politically motivated. In other stories, a federal judge orders continued funding for the CFPB, halts the end of South Sudanese TPS, and Israel’s presidential office denies Trump’s claim of a Netanyahu pardon. Iran urges renewed nuclear talks, Trump downplays China’s Taiwan drills, and updates include a DC pipe bomber hearing, JFK’s granddaughter’s death, Musk’s Doge transparency questions, citizenship exclusions, and New York’s incoming mayor swearing in underground.

articles.title: Tilting at windmills: Trump laments death of bald eagle in the US … which was really a falcon in Israel
articles.trailText: A pity that Trump, or one of the 18 intelligence agencies reporting to him, did not trace the image back to its source
articles.summary: Donald Trump, while on holiday in Florida, posted on X an image claiming windmills were killing bald eagles, a message amplified by a White House account. The photo actually shows a falcon killed at an Israeli wind farm in 2017—captured by Hedy Ben Eliahou for Israel’s Nature and Parks Authority and first published by Haaretz. Visual clues like Hebrew lettering and the bird’s markings were overlooked by Trump and his 18 intelligence agencies. Haaretz noted Israeli turbines kill about two dozen birds annually, spurring campaigns against new Golan Heights wind farms.

articles.title: California snowpack gets a boost from series of December downpours
articles.trailText: Water stored as snow during the winter months feeds waterways in the summer and supplies cities and farms
articles.summary: After a series of December storms fueled by an atmospheric river, California’s first snowpack survey at the Phillips station in the Sierra Nevada recorded 24 in depth, raising statewide snowpack to 71% of average. The snowpack, which melts into rivers and groundwater to supply about a third of the state’s annual water, currently holds 50% of its typical water content for late December and 21% of the April 1 average. While reservoirs stand at 123% of norm, officials warn that continued winter storms will be crucial to secure water for California’s 39 million residents and agriculture.

articles.title: Three hikers found dead on southern California’s Mount Baldy
articles.trailText: One person had made an emergency call after companion fell 500ft, but rescue copter couldn’t land due to high winds
articles.summary: Three hikers were found dead Monday evening along Mount Baldy’s 10,000 ft Devil’s Backbone trail after high winds thwarted two helicopter landing attempts. A caller with GPS coordinates reported at 11:30 am that a 19-year-old companion had tumbled 500 ft down a remote mountainside. A medic hoisted in by 7:30 pm discovered all three unresponsive; identities and causes remain unconfirmed. Earlier that day, two other hikers (ages 18 and 31) were rescued from a different Mount Baldy trail after a 100 ft fall.

articles.title: Suspected DC pipe bomber appears at detention hearing after alleged confession
articles.trailText: Lawyers for Brian Cole argue he should be released ahead of trial for allegedly planting devices in DC in 2021
articles.summary: Brian Cole Jr appeared at a federal detention hearing after his arrest for allegedly planting pipe bombs at the DNC and RNC HQs in DC on Jan. 5, 2021. His lawyers argue he should be released pending trial under GPS home detention, citing his autism, OCD and lack of criminal history and noting no devices exploded. Prosecutors counter that Cole confessed in detail to constructing and planting the bombs—motivated by anger over the 2020 election and inspired by Northern Ireland’s Troubles—and pose he remains dangerous, facing up to 20 years in prison. Judge Sharbaugh will issue a ruling soon.

articles.title: Tatiana Schlossberg, granddaughter of JFK, dies after rare leukemia diagnosis
articles.trailText: Schlossberg, 35, revealed in November diagnosis of mutation of cancer of blood and bone marrow
articles.summary: Tatiana Schlossberg, 35-year-old granddaughter of John F. Kennedy, died after revealing in November a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia with a rare mutation. Announced by the JFK Presidential Library, her passing follows treatment begun shortly after the May 2024 birth of her second child. A Yale and Oxford alumna, she was a New York Times climate reporter and contributor to The Atlantic, Washington Post and Vanity Fair. In a New Yorker essay, she criticized cousin Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s cuts to vaccine and NIH funding. She leaves two young children.

articles.title: Judge says Trump administration must continue funding consumer watchdog
articles.trailText: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is at risk after Donald Trump vowed to shutter it since his return to office
articles.summary: A federal judge in DC, Amy Berman Jackson, ruled that the Trump administration must maintain CFPB funding, rejecting acting director Russell Vought’s argument that Federal Reserve losses cut off its revenue stream. Jackson deemed the starve-the-agency tactic, based on an OLC memo, invalid and noted the CFPB has been financed seamlessly since its 2011 inception, even amid Fed expense shortfalls. The DC Circuit will hear a broader appeal in February 2026. Senate Banking Committee Democrat Elizabeth Warren praised the decision, which protects the watchdog days before its funding lapsed and highlights its $21 billion returned to consumers.

articles.title: Mamdani to be sworn in as New York mayor in abandoned subway station
articles.trailText: Mamdani to take oath of office on New Year’s Eve in gilded age subway station beneath city hall
articles.summary: New York’s mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani will take his oath on New Year’s Eve in a decommissioned gilded-age subway station beneath City Hall, symbolizing a ‘new era’ and the city’s working-class roots. The 1904 station, landmarked in 1979, will host a private midnight ceremony led by AG Letitia James, followed by a public swearing-in by Senator Bernie Sanders on the steps of City Hall and a post-inauguration block party on Broadway. Mayor Eric Adams’s attendance is uncertain; tech billionaire Elon Musk criticized Mamdani’s FDNY pick, EMS veteran Lillian Bonsignore, prompting Mamdani to highlight her 30-year record.

articles.title: More musicians drop out of Kennedy Center shows after Trump name change
articles.trailText: The Cookers on Monday pulled out of a New Year’s Eve jazz gig at the controversially renamed ‘Trump-Kennedy’ center
articles.summary: The Cookers, a Grammy-nominated septet of veteran post-bop musicians, withdrew two days before their New Year’s Eve gig at the newly renamed Trump-Kennedy Center, joining drummer Chuck Redd, folk singer Kristy Lee and Doug Varone & Dancers in boycotting what they call an act of ‘intolerance’ and ‘erasure.’ Citing jazz’s roots in freedom and resistance, saxophonist Billy Harper denounced the center’s renaming as racist and an affront to Black culture. Kennedy Center president Richard Grenell threatened lawsuits and accused opponents of ‘boycotting the arts’ for political reasons.

articles.title: Despair for would-be US citizens as American dream blocked by Trump
articles.trailText: Aspirant Americans tell of exclusions from ceremonies by sudden policy introduced on ‘security’ grounds
articles.summary: At Boston's Faneuil Hall and over 16 US cities, a December 5 USCIS memo halted green-card and naturalization interviews and canceled oath ceremonies for nationals of 19 'high-risk' countries—including Haiti, Sudan, Venezuela and Afghanistan—citing security after a DC shooting. Long-term residents, like a 50-year-old Haitian assistant, were barred despite years of vetting, triggering distress and mass cancellations by email. Immigration advocates warn this abrupt policy, coupled with a push to file thousands of denaturalization cases, signals an authoritarian expansion of Trump's immigration crackdown.

articles.title: Shawn Harris was ready to defeat Marjorie Taylor Greene. Now he awaits Republicans’ next move
articles.trailText: After the far-right US representative’s resignation, Harris wonders who his opponent for Georgia’s 14th district will be
articles.summary: Retired brigadier general and rancher Shawn Harris, who won a record 135,000 votes and outperformed Trump by three points in GA-14’s R+19 district, had geared up to face far-right Marjorie Taylor Greene before her sudden resignation. Now he’s bracing for Republicans to nominate either an extremist or a center-right contender. Harris positions himself as a centrist with military oversight credentials—calling for congressional war declarations and criticizing Pentagon leadership—while emphasizing cost-of-living relief, rural homelessness solutions, and agriculture support. He runs canned goods drives and urges Congress to lower grocery prices amid an agriculture recession.

articles.title: US military says two were killed in strike on suspected drug vessel in Pacific
articles.trailText: Two men killed in Hegseth-led attack on boat suspected of carrying drugs in international waters, Pentagon says
articles.summary: On Dec. 29, the Pentagon confirmed a lethal kinetic strike in international waters of the eastern Pacific killed two men aboard a suspected drug-smuggling vessel, marking the 30th US naval attack on narco-traffickers since September and raising the death toll to at least 107. The operation, ordered by Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth per US Southern Command, targeted a boat on known trafficking routes; no US forces were harmed. President Trump has justified these strikes—falsely claiming each shipment would kill 25,000 Americans—and asserted, without evidence, an undisclosed Venezuelan port strike over the weekend.

articles.title: Pardons and prizes: five key takeaways from Trump’s meeting with Netanyahu
articles.trailText: US president hosted Israeli prime minister to discuss stalled Gaza peace plan, Iran and an award for Trump
articles.summary: At Mar-a-Lago, Trump and Netanyahu agreed on pushing Gaza ceasefire terms: Hamas must disarm within a short timeframe or face harsh reprisals, possibly from unnamed states. Trump signaled support for Israeli strikes on Iran over its missile and nuclear programs, warning of immediate US action. He acknowledged but declined to detail disagreements over West Bank status, hinting at forthcoming decisions. Trump also repeated his claim that Israeli President Herzog assured him of a pardon for Netanyahu—a claim Jerusalem denied. Finally, Netanyahu announced Trump would be the first non-Israeli to receive the Israel Prize for pro-Israel policies and hostage-release efforts.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president greets Netanyahu, warns Hamas, threatens to sue Jerome Powell
articles.trailText: Israeli prime minister’s Florida trip included announcement that he will award Trump with Israel prize
articles.summary: At Mar-a-Lago, President Trump warned Hamas would pay a steep price if it fails to disarm, offered full support to Israeli PM Netanyahu—who announced he’ll award Trump Israel’s highest civilian prize—and assailed Fed Chair Jerome Powell as a “fool,” threatening to sue over renovation costs. He claimed an undisclosed US strike on a “big facility” in Venezuela, boasted of economic strength despite nearly half of Americans feeling less secure, backed a $2 billion UN aid mechanism, and faced critiques from Marjorie Taylor Greene, Nancy Pelosi and environmental watchdogs amid fresh climate denial.

articles.title: Beyoncé is now the fifth billionaire musician, Forbes reports
articles.trailText: Grammy-winning artist joins husband Jay-Z and artists like Taylor Swift following the success of Cowboy Carter tour
articles.summary: Beyoncé, 44, has joined Forbes’ billionaire list as the fifth musician after grossing over $400 million in ticket sales and $50 million in merchandise on her Cowboy Carter tour, plus $579 million from Renaissance. Following Jay-Z (2019), Rihanna, Springsteen and Taylor Swift, her wealth chiefly stems from music royalties, global tours and her Parkwood Entertainment empire. Ventures include Cécred, SirDavis whiskey and Ivy Park. Her 2024 album won a Grammy and spawned 2025’s highest-grossing tour with 350 crew, 100 trucks and eight 747s. She also earned $50 million for an NFL halftime show and $10 million from Levi’s.

articles.title: Authorities identify the two victims of New Jersey helicopter crash: ‘They were always together’
articles.trailText: Kenneth Kirsch, 65, and Michael Greenberg, 71, died after the Sunday middair collision near Hammonton airport
articles.summary: Authorities identified the pilots killed in Sunday’s midair collision near Hammonton municipal airport, NJ, as Kenneth Kirsch, 65, of Carney’s Point, and Michael Greenberg, 71, of Sewell. Both private pilots since 2014, they often shared breakfast at the Apron Cafe before flying their Enstrom F-28A and 280C in tandem. Witnesses saw the helicopters fly close together before colliding over a farm field 35 miles southeast of Philadelphia, leaving a 100-yard debris trail. NTSB investigators are on site, with a preliminary report expected in 30 days. The FAA confirms only the two pilots were aboard. Senators Booker and Kim offered condolences.

articles.title: Case dropped against TikTok streamer who was shot by US immigration agents
articles.trailText: Carlitos Ricardo Parias, who livestreams LA breaking news, was accused of ramming car into federal officers’ vehicles
articles.summary: US District Judge Fernando Olguin dismissed with prejudice the indictment against Los Angeles TikTok news streamer Carlitos Ricardo Parias, who was shot in the elbow by an ICE agent during an October enforcement operation. Parias faced assault charges for allegedly ramming his car into agents’ vehicles, but bodycam footage shows his car was stationary and a ricochet also wounded a deputy marshal. Olguin ruled ICE violated Parias’s constitutional rights by detaining him at Adelanto processing center after bond release, obstructing attorney visits, and missing discovery deadlines, including late release of bodycam video. The US attorney’s office disputes the ruling and is considering an appeal. Parias, an undocumented Mexican national, remains in ICE custody as his immigration case proceeds.

articles.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene says she was ‘naive’ for believing Trump is man of the people
articles.trailText: Greene gave lengthy interview with New York Times days before stepping down as congresswoman for Georgia
articles.summary: In a New York Times interview days before resigning her Georgia House seat, third-term Congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene said she was “naive” to believe Donald Trump was a man of the people. She said her break with him crystallized when, at Charlie Kirk’s memorial, Trump boasted “I hate my opponent,” clashing with her Christian faith and Erika Kirk’s forgiveness. Greene has since defied MAGA norms—apologizing, citing Gaza as genocide, pushing release of Epstein files, and criticizing GOP economic and foreign-policy stances—earning her status as a self-described political outcast amid White House dismissals.

articles.title: Body of triathlete apparently killed by shark found on California beach
articles.trailText: Erica Fox’s remains were found after nearly weeklong search, marking a rare shark-related fatality for California
articles.summary: Rescuers recovered the body of 55-year-old triathlete Erica Fox on Dec. 28 at Davenport Beach, north of Santa Cruz, nearly a week after she disappeared during a group swim from Monterey’s Lovers Point. Witnesses reported seeing a shark carrying human remains. Fox’s husband Jean-François Vanreusel and swim-club members held a memorial walk; her father praised her kindness and passion for ocean swimming. A multi-agency search—including Coast Guard, fire and police—had been suspended after covering 84 nautical miles. The Santa Cruz County Sheriff’s Office is investigating. Fox competed in triathlons including Escape From Alcatraz, marking California’s 16th shark-related fatality in 75 years.

articles.title: FBI deploys more resources to Minnesota amid Trump’s targeting of state
articles.trailText: Kash Patel claims $250m Covid aid fraud scheme is ‘tip of iceberg’ and blames state’s Somali population
articles.summary: The FBI has sent extra agents to Minnesota to combat large-scale fraud exploiting federal aid, particularly a $250m Covid-era food assistance scheme tied to 78 indictments and 57 convictions. Director Kash Patel warns it’s “the tip of the iceberg” and may trigger denaturalization or deportation. Prosecutors estimate up to $9bn stolen in schemes linked to the state’s Somali community. An unverified $4m empty daycare claim drew a gubernatorial denial. Amid Trump’s targeting of Somali Americans with racist rhetoric, Rep. Ilhan Omar decries a white supremacist crackdown even as questions swirl around her family’s Rose Lake Capital wealth surge.

articles.title: US struck ‘big facility’ in Venezuela, Trump claimed without offering details
articles.trailText: Trump alleged that US forces hit ‘very hard’ in what would mark his team’s first land strike on Venezuela if confirmed
articles.summary: President Trump asserted that US forces struck a “big facility” in Venezuela’s dock area where drugs are loaded onto boats, causing a major explosion, but offered no specifics and the White House declined to comment. Unverified video from Zulia state surfaced online. This would be his administration’s first confirmed land strike in Venezuela amid a regional military buildup—authorized covert CIA operations and a 15,000-strong maritime “quarantine” with a carrier strike group, F-35s and Coast Guard cutters—to counter Maduro-linked drug trafficking and disrupt oil exports via a global shadow fleet. Independent verification and Venezuelan response remain absent.

articles.title: Hundreds of Detroit home demolition sites may have been filled with toxic dirt
articles.trailText: Toxic chemicals like lead and asbestos are likely in dirt used to backfill demolished structures in city, experts say
articles.summary: Detroit faces an unfolding public health crisis after independent and regulatory testing flagged that backfill at roughly 424 demolished home sites—part of the city’s massive blight elimination program—likely contains industrial slag and debris from Northland Mall, with lead, mercury, cadmium, PAHs and asbestos detected in 42 of 47 samples above regional background. Critics say Mayor Duggan skipped 2018 protocols requiring universal soil tests to maintain demolition speed, leaving neighborhoods exposed to toxic dust; remediation could cost $18,000 per lot. EGLE probes possible enforcement actions as Duggan exits office.

articles.title: Two half-brothers, in prison for killing a priest, tell a story of abuse in New Orleans
articles.trailText: Father Patrick McCarthy was brutally murdered in 1988. The two half-brothers in prison for the killing say he sexually abused them for years
articles.summary: Half-brothers Bernard Joseph and Marcus Hamilton, serving life terms in Louisiana’s Angola penitentiary for the 1988 murder of Josephite priest Patrick McCarthy, allege they endured years of sexual abuse first by Josephite Father Paul Oberg and later by McCarthy. Their detailed affidavits, newly surfaced in the archdiocese of New Orleans’s bankruptcy (with over 600 claimants) and in Hamilton’s death-penalty appeal, chronicle grooming at shuttered orphanages, family trauma, mental‐health crises and forensic psychiatric findings. Despite voluminous evidence and Oberg’s transfers, the archdiocese and Josephites have not publicly recognized him. This marks the first full public account linking systemic clerical abuse to the brothers’ crime.

articles.title: ‘Just like so many families’: US parents of addicted kids relate to the Reiners – but fear stigma
articles.trailText: The challenges of drug and alcohol addiction are familiar, but violence against others is highly unusual, parents say
articles.summary: US parents of addicted children empathize with the Reiner family after the alleged violence by Nick Reiner, but worry media focus on rare violence will fuel stigma around addiction and mental illness. Ron and Darlene Grover compare their son’s opioid-to-heroin journey and seven years of rehab and jail to Nick’s, while Greg of Families Anonymous warns addiction is a ‘family disease.’ Experts note two-thirds of Americans know someone with SUD, violence is highly unusual, and relapse often leads to self-harm. Parents face fear, guilt, boundary-setting, and isolation—but three in four recover with ongoing support.

articles.title: From ‘global cooling’ to ‘beautiful coal’: Trump’s startling climate claims of 2025
articles.trailText: Trump ratcheted up his often questionable claims about the environment and how to deal, if at all, with the threats to it
articles.summary: After January’s return, Trump ordered water diverted from the endangered delta smelt to farmers and firefighting. He accused offshore wind turbines of driving whales ashore, halted wind and solar projects calling wind “the most expensive energy,” and at the UN rebranded coal as “clean, beautiful coal,” denounced climate change as the “greatest con job,” and mischaracterized past warnings of global cooling and warming. He then launched investigations into unnamed climate “conspirators,” targeting scientists, insurers and officials. Experts say all claims are baseless amid overwhelming evidence of rapid global heating and ecosystem threats.

articles.title: Working Families bet on 2026 as the right time for a third US party after a wave of wins
articles.trailText: The progressive party is now active in 18 states and much of its expansion happened in the past five years
articles.summary: Working Families party, founded in 1998, now active in 18 states with 600,000+ members and 100 staff, leveraged 2025 victories—Zohran Mamdani’s upset NYC mayoral win on its ballot line, abolition of New Jersey’s party “line,” wins in Dayton and Buffalo—to argue 2026 is ripe for a genuine third party. It endorses hundreds, mainly in Democratic primaries, champions working-class affordability, workers’ rights and electoral reform, uses fusion voting and cultural outreach (Real Housewives of Politics, Dungeons & Dragons). Eyeing state legislature flips and congressional challenges in North Carolina, California and New York, WFP aims to dismantle structural barriers and convert Democratic disaffection into an orange wave in the midterms.

articles.title: Donald Trump in his own words – the year in racism and misogyny
articles.trailText: The president has increased the amount of invective he’s spewed against women and people of color
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s second-term first year saw a sweeping rollback of DEI and affirmative action via executive orders, a ban on gender-affirming care for under-19s, directives halting racial exhibits at the Smithsonian and renaming Denali to Mount McKinley, alongside mass deportations. Throughout the year he unleashed racist, xenophobic and sexist remarks—targeting Palestinians for displacement, denigrating Somali immigrants and Rep. Ilhan Omar, invoking antisemitic "shylock" slurs, and hurling misogynistic insults at women and journalists.

articles.title: Nancy Pelosi predicts Democrats will retake US House in 2026 midterms
articles.trailText: Former House speaker on ABC News also said congressional Republicans have ceded almost all their power to Trump
articles.summary: Nancy Pelosi predicts Democrats will reclaim the House majority in the 2026 midterms, expressing 'none' doubts that Hakeem Jeffries—whom she calls an eloquent unifier—will secure the speaker’s gavel. On ABC’s This Week, she accused Republicans of having 'abolished the Congress' by ceding power to Trump and vowed Democrats would restore legislative authority once in control. Pelosi’s forecast ties to Trump’s 36% approval rating, historic midterm losses for the president’s party, multiple GOP retirements (McConnell, Tillis, Ernst, Tuberville) and her own planned 2027 retirement after 20 terms.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: progress but no breakthrough in Ukraine peace talks
articles.trailText: Donald Trump says ‘one or two tough’ issues could lead to negotiations breaking down – key US politics stories from 28 December at a glance
articles.summary: President Trump says Ukraine and Russia are ‘closer than ever’ to a peace deal after a Florida meeting with President Zelenskyy, but 'one or two tough' disputes over territory and war termination remain; he also held an 'excellent' call with Putin and claims the draft agreement is 95% complete. Other updates: mixed US economic data on jobs and inflation; strikes in Nigeria and Syria targeting IS; FBI action on a $250m Minnesota food-aid fraud; a powerful winter storm sweeping the US; uneven opioid overdose declines; record silver prices raising cost concerns; and Bernie Sanders urging an AI datacenter moratorium.

articles.title: Bernie Sanders criticizes AI as ‘the most consequential technology in humanity’
articles.trailText: Republican senator Katie Britt also proposes AI companies be criminally liable if they expose minors to harmful ideas
articles.summary: Sen. Bernie Sanders warned on CNN’s State of the Union that AI—driven by billionaires like Musk, Zuckerberg, Bezos and Thiel—poses unprecedented risks to jobs, incomes and mental health, calling AI “the most consequential technology” and urging Congress to study its social impacts and consider a moratorium on new datacenters. Meanwhile, Sen. Katie Britt proposed the Guard Act to criminalize AI companions that expose minors to sexual content or self-harm, mandate non-human disclaimers and impose guardrails to protect children’s well-being, marking rare bipartisan momentum on AI oversight.

articles.title: US strikes on Nigeria and Syria are ‘consistent’ with policy to combat IS, Republican says
articles.trailText: House armed services committee’s Mike Turner denied that military strikes showed new Trump approach to US forces
articles.summary: Senior Republican Mike Turner, of the House Armed Services Committee, defended US military strikes on IS camps in Syria and Nigeria as a continuation of long-standing policy under President Trump, not a new second-term doctrine. Speaking on ABC’s This Week, he emphasized that defeating Islamic State “around the world”—from Iraq and Syria to Nigeria—remains a core objective alongside allies. Trump hailed the Nigeria cruise missile strike as a “Christmas present” for IS “butchers,” prompting Defense Sec. Pete Hegseth to vow action against violence targeting Christians. Turner also cited the consistency of US stance in supporting Ukraine against Russia’s Christmas strikes.

articles.title: Oklahoma man doing target practice in back yard charged in fatal shooting of neighbor
articles.trailText: Cody Adams, 33, charged with manslaughter after neighbor blocks away was killed as he was firing at a drink can
articles.summary: On Christmas Day in Stephens County, Oklahoma, 33-year-old Cody Wayne Adams used a handgun he’d received as a gift to shoot at a Red Bull can in his backyard, which lacked a protective backstop. A stray bullet traveled several blocks and killed Sandra Phelps as she sat on her porch holding a child. Investigators matched the bullet’s trajectory to Adams’s shooting position. He was arrested on first-degree manslaughter and released on a $100,000 bond. The case underscores risks of unsafe backyard target practice in a country where unintentional firearm deaths are four times higher than in peer nations.

articles.title: For this Catholic bishop, protecting immigrants is personal
articles.trailText: Michael Pham fled communist Vietnam by boat as a child. Now, as bishop of San Diego, he is putting faith into action
articles.summary: Bishop Michael Pham, a Vietnamese refugee who crossed the Pacific at 13, now leads the San Diego diocese and founded Faith (Faithful Accompaniment in Trust and Hope), mobilizing around 500 volunteers from 17 faiths to accompany immigrants at federal court, offering spiritual support and deterring ICE arrests. As the first Vietnamese American diocesan bishop appointed by Pope Leo XIV, he confronts both rising deportations and his diocese’s sex-abuse legacy. Pham invokes the gospel call to “welcome the stranger,” uniting polarized Catholics through listening, prayer, and direct action amid heated local immigration debates.

articles.title: Texas father rescues kidnapped 15-year-old daughter after tracking her phone’s location
articles.trailText: Authorities say they arrested a man, 23, for kidnapping teen in a Houston suburb as she walked her dog on Christmas
articles.summary: Texas father rescues 15-year-old daughter kidnapped at knifepoint on Christmas in Porter, Texas by tracking her cell phone via parental controls. She was walking her dog when abducted by 23-year-old Giovanni Rosales Espinoza; witnesses described the vehicle. Her father located her phone two miles away in a wooded area of Harris County, found his daughter and her dog in a pickup with the suspect and helped her escape. Rosales was arrested by Montgomery County deputies, charged with aggravated kidnapping and indecency with a child. He remains held without bail, faces prison time and sex offender registration. Sheriff Wesley Doolittle praised deputies’ swift action.

articles.title: ‘You know what I like’: Epstein files reveal disgraced financier’s routine abuse of girls
articles.trailText: Released documents detail the assembly line-like process with which Jeffrey Epstein procured underage victims
articles.summary: Newly released DOJ files expose an "assembly line" operation led by Jeffrey Epstein and associates like Ghislaine Maxwell to procure dozens of underage girls, some as young as 14, under the guise of massage work from 2002–2005. Maxwell recruited students, victims were coerced to lure peers, and Epstein insisted on "young petite" minors, verifying ages with IDs. Investigator notes from 2019 show Epstein's network scrambling for fresh victims, while grand jury exhibits reveal coerced victim recruitment and communications on co-conspirators. Documents implicate figures like Jean-Luc Brunel, detail sharing of child abuse imagery, and highlight law enforcement lapses.

articles.title: ‘We became famous, but at what cost?’: after the horrors of Cecot, the search for a normal life
articles.trailText: After months of torture in the Salvadorian prison, the men deported from the US reunite with families in Venezuela
articles.summary: After US authorities accused 252 Venezuelan men—many asylum seekers without criminal records—of Tren de Aragua affiliation and deported them to El Salvador’s Cecot mega-prison, detainees endured routine beatings, sexual abuse and systemic torture. Abruptly released in July under a diplomatic swap, they reunited with families in Venezuela, celebrating traditions yet grappling with PTSD, economic precarity and stigma as alleged gang members. They support each other—especially makeup artist Andry Hernández Romero—while facing job discrimination, political exploitation and pursuing justice, reintegration and advocacy for LGBTQ+ and torture survivors.

articles.title: The little-known program contributing to a decline in overdose deaths in the US
articles.trailText: Crisis intervention training helps police recognize substance use disorders and connect people with treatment
articles.summary: Since fall 2023, US overdose deaths have fallen unevenly across states, with West Virginia among those posting the steepest declines—an effect experts link in part to expanded crisis intervention training (CIT) for police. Initially designed in the late 1980s to help officers identify mental health crises, modern CIT teaches them to recognize substance use disorders, engage empathetically, avoid arrest, and arrange ‘warm handoffs’ to treatment rather than jail. Advocates like Wheeling’s CIT supervisor Yolandah Mwikisa and Brookings fellow Richard Frank say this approach not only reduces fatal overdoses and crime drivers but also lowers liability for departments, challenging skeptics who favor incarceration over treatment.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Republican turns ‘lowlife’ taunt back on president to raise campaign funds
articles.trailText: Thomas Massie, who co-authored Epstein files act, says president attacked him for keeping commitment to ‘help victims’. Key US politics stories from 27 December at a glance
articles.summary: Kentucky GOP Rep. Thomas Massie, singled out by Trump as a “lowlife” for co-authoring the Epstein Files Transparency Act, turned the insult into a fundraising pitch on X, raising nearly $3,000 in two hours for his 2026 reelection bid. Meanwhile, signs point to a Republican midterm backlash: multiple GOP senators are retiring, Trump’s approval has slumped to 36%, and young and Latino voters are drifting away.
