In other developments, Kennedy Center president Richard Grenell is seeking $1 million in damages from jazz musician Chuck Redd for canceling a holiday show over Trump’s renaming, and the former president is pressing Senate Republicans to scrap the filibuster to fast-track his agenda.

articles.title: Southern California cleans up after the wettest recent Christmas season
articles.trailText: More than 17in of rain fell in Ventura county, with trees felled and hundreds of car crashes throughout the region
articles.summary: An atmospheric river dumped record rainfall across Southern California over Christmas Eve and Day—5.91in at Santa Barbara and over 17in in Ventura County—triggering hydroclimate whiplash. The deluge felled trees, cut power, caused hundreds of crashes, mudflows into homes and spawned an EF-0 tornado in Boyle Heights that damaged a house and strip mall. Mayor Bass and Gov. Newsom declared emergencies in multiple counties as L.A. firefighters rescued over 100 people. With flash-flood and mudslide risks persisting, forecasters predict a dry weekend before renewed rain and Sierra Nevada snowfall around New Year’s.

articles.title: A vineyard manager’s deportation shattered an Oregon town. Now his daughter is carrying on his legacy
articles.trailText: Alondra Sotelo Garcia took over her father’s business when he was deported to Mexico after three decades in the US
articles.summary: After vineyard manager Moises Sotelo was detained by ICE in June and deported in July, his daughter Alondra Sotelo Garcia quit her shipping logistics job and moved back to Newberg to run the family’s vineyard‐management company. With her mother, Irma, joining Moises in Mexico, Alondra took charge of staff, navigated a downturn in the global wine market, and organized GoFundMe proceeds to secure housing and support her parents’ resettlement. Balancing seasonal vineyard tasks and mounting bills, she marshals community ties to keep the business afloat. Her story highlights the human, economic and agricultural fallout of aggressive deportation policies in rural Oregon.

articles.title: Trump urges Republicans to ditch filibuster rule in US Senate
articles.trailText: Rule allows minority party to block legislation, but GOP is reluctant to scrap it as they could lose majority
articles.summary: In a December 27 Politico interview, former President Donald Trump urged Senate Republicans to eliminate the filibuster—the procedural tool allowing a minority of senators to block bills—arguing it hampers GOP priorities and risks another government shutdown. With a narrow 53–47 majority, Trump said scrapping the rule would pave the way for healthcare reform, voter ID requirements and other agenda items ahead of the 2026 midterms. He reprised an October call to end the filibuster to reopen the government and framed upcoming campaigns around “pricing” amid signs of cooling inflation, contrasting it with Democrats’ “affordability” messaging.

articles.title: FBI to move out of brutalist J Edgar Hoover building in Washington DC
articles.trailText: Iconic building, called ‘greatest monstrosity ever constructed’ by Hoover himself, to be closed down
articles.summary: The FBI plans to permanently close its aging, brutalist J Edgar Hoover building in Washington DC after two decades of failed relocation efforts. Director Kash Patel announced the agency will move personnel into existing offices at the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center, utilizing vacated USAID spaces. He emphasized modern facilities, resource savings, and enhanced national security capabilities. The decision follows a Maryland lawsuit over scrapped congressional-funded relocation plans and revives debate over the building’s controversial 1960s design—once dubbed “the greatest monstrosity ever constructed” by its namesake.

articles.title: California woman delivers healthy baby after ‘essentially unheard of’ ectopic pregnancy
articles.trailText: Suze Lopez found out she was pregnant only days before giving birth, due to fetus hiding behind 22lb ovarian cyst
articles.summary: Suze Lopez, a 41-year-old ER nurse from Bakersfield, delivered baby Ryu in August via emergency surgery after doctors discovered an advanced abdominal ectopic pregnancy hidden behind a 22-lb ovarian cyst. Occurring in 1 in 30,000 pregnancies—and full-term in fewer than 1 in a million—Ryu’s development went unnoticed until days before birth. A 30-physician team at Cedars-Sinai removed both the cyst and the baby in a single operation. Lopez, who’s had ovarian cysts for years, initially attributed symptoms to her cyst. Both mother and Ryu have fully recovered, and Cedars-Sinai plans to document this unprecedented case in medical literature.

articles.title: Clergy abuse survivors frustrated by New Orleans archdiocese’s protracted bankruptcy
articles.trailText: Long-winded legal wrangling and recalcitrant Catholic church leadership thwarted hopes for timely settlement
articles.summary: Since May 2020 the New Orleans archdiocese’s Chapter 11 filing stalled abuse claims by 310 alleged clerical predators (the church lists just 79), frustrating survivors like ex-CCF president James Adams. Judge Grabill’s secrecy orders forestalled depositions, purged victims’ reps from the creditors’ committee and fined lawyers for leaks. After five years of slow negotiations and contested discovery, a $305 million settlement won approval in December 2025, but survivors lament the emotional toll of protracted legal wrangling and church opacity.

articles.title: Inflatable frogs and ice scrapers: nine innovative ways Americans protested against Trump in 2025
articles.trailText: Historically, when organizers have used tactical innovation, movement activity has peaked
articles.summary: Americans deployed nine novel nonviolent tactics to resist Trump’s 2025 policies nationwide: from symbolic ice-scraper buy-ins at Home Depot and whimsical inflatable-frog demonstrations (“tactical frivolity”) at ICE facilities, to “No Sleep for ICE” hotel noise campaigns, #TeslaTakedown boycotts, mass unsubscribes from Disney+, high-pitch whistle alerts in Chicago, nightly cacerolazo pot-banging in DC, pop-up block parties for votes in Memphis, and a Women’s March Win ad urging ICE staff to “walk away.” These innovations echo civil rights-era strategy, broadening grassroots engagement across LA, Portland, Chicago, DC, Memphis and beyond.

articles.title: Epstein texts and yelling at Trump: US House’s year of censures
articles.trailText: Lawmakers spent much of 2025 seeking to reprimand each other – here’s a look back at what sparked such outrage
articles.summary: In a record-breaking year for the House, lawmakers introduced at least 17 censure or disapproval resolutions over insults to Elon Musk, Al Green’s shouting at Trump, racial slurs, mocking Governor Abbott’s wheelchair, confrontations at ICE facilities, and texts with Jeffrey Epstein. Only one—against Green—passed, prompting bipartisan bids to tighten censure rules. Other targets included Boebert, Crockett, Ogles, Omar, Garcia, Plaskett and Mills, amid accusations of back-room deals to shield allies. Though censures carry no formal penalties beyond public rebuke, the spree underscored deep partisan rancor and calls to curb procedural abuse.

articles.title: Republican behind Epstein files act responds to Trump ‘lowlife’ taunt
articles.trailText: Kentucky’s Thomas Massie used the president’s insult to raise funds to run against a Trump-endorsed candidate
articles.summary: Rep. Thomas Massie, co-author of the bipartisan Epstein Files Transparency Act, was derided by Donald Trump as a “lowlife Republican” on Truth Social after pushing for release of Jeffrey Epstein documents to aid victims. Massie seized the insult in an X post to solicit campaign donations ahead of his 2026 primary challenge against Trump-endorsed Ed Gallrein, raising $3,000 from 40 donors within two hours. The spat underscores a growing rift: Trump’s Justice Department missed the Act’s December 19 deadline, though it released some files and uncovered over a million additional documents pending review.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Nigeria says it provided intelligence for US airstrikes as Hegseth warns of more attacks
articles.trailText: Country’s foreign minister says his president signed off on US air attack – key US politics stories from 26 December at a glance
articles.summary: On Dec 26, Nigeria’s foreign minister Yusuf Tuggar confirmed President Tinubu green-lit U.S. Christmas Day strikes on Islamic State camps in northwest Nigeria, supplying “extensive” intelligence in calls with U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio. Tuggar said operations target militants, not religion, and future coordinated raids are possible. U.S. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth warned more strikes are coming. Trump supporters celebrated the action, while other briefs note Volodymyr Zelenskiy’s planned Mar-a-Lago talks, a UK anti-disinformation campaigner facing U.S. removal, craftivist protests, Trump’s staffing shift toward loyalty, and Bari Weiss’s pulled 60 Minutes episode.

articles.title: Mudslides bury cars and homes up to their windows in California town
articles.trailText: At least three people killed across state since atmospheric river storms began earlier this week
articles.summary: Mudslides triggered by an atmospheric river dumped up to 12 inches of rain on Wrightwood, California, on Christmas, burying cars and homes to window height and prompting evacuation orders for the 5,000-resident town northeast of Los Angeles. San Bernardino County firefighters rescued over 100 people, while LA County handled more than 350 collisions. It was downtown LA’s wettest Christmas in 54 years. Since the storms began, three have died: a motorist in Redding, a Sacramento sheriff’s deputy and a man in San Diego felled by a tree. More flash flooding, wind-driven debris flows and heavy Sierra Nevada snowfall are forecast, with flood watches statewide and a weekend Northeast winter storm looming.

articles.title: Three men who escaped Georgia jail hijacked Lyft to Florida, records show
articles.trailText: Stevenson Charles, Yusuf Minor and Naod Yohannes, all incarcerated for murder, recaptured on Tuesday
articles.summary: Stevenson Charles (24), Yusuf Minor (31) and Naod Yohannes (25) escaped DeKalb County jail near Atlanta on Dec 22, hijacked a Lyft ride to Miramar, Florida under a fake female name—assisted by Minor’s girlfriend—attacked the driver, threatened rape and murder during the 10-hour trip, and used her credit cards to rent a property and borrow the car. Tracking via license-plate readers led to their arrest on Dec 24. Minor and Yohannes face life sentences for murder; Charles is charged with murder and armed robbery. Jail officials are reinforcing outdated facilities after the breach; phone records showed external coordination.

articles.title: Trump supporters hail US strikes in Nigeria as ‘amazing Christmas present’
articles.trailText: Some even celebrated ‘mass killing’ and the president’s ‘resolve’ in attacking Islamic State targets
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s Christmas Day cruise-missile strikes on Islamic State camps in Nigeria drew effusive praise from his supporters and aligned Republicans, who hailed the attacks as a justified “mass killing” to avenge Christians. Far-right activist Laura Loomer and Florida congressman Randy Fine called it an “amazing Christmas present,” while senators Tom Cotton, Ted Budd and others emphasized defending religious minorities. The response contrasts with caution over strikes on Venezuela. Pressure had mounted since July from US religious-freedom watchdogs and congressional resolutions. Trump even postponed the operation for symbolic holiday timing.

articles.title: The protesters showing up every week to shut down ‘Alligator Alcatraz’: ‘We will end this’
articles.trailText: Every Sunday, protesters from Florida and beyond go to the notorious immigration jail and advocate for its closure
articles.summary: Every Sunday since August, convoys of activists from Florida and beyond travel to the remote “Alligator Alcatraz” ICE camp in the Everglades to demand its closure. They protest alleged human rights abuses—denial of insulin, violence and forced deportations without due process—after a federal judge ordered its shutdown and an appeals court reversed. Families, clergy, veterans, civil rights elders and grassroots organizers have built a diverse alliance, vowing to sustain weekly vigils until the facility and its detention network end.

articles.title: Kentucky plane crash death toll rises to 15 after injured man died on Christmas
articles.trailText: Alain Rodriguez Colina was working at a scrapyard that the UPS cargo plane crashed into on 4 November
articles.summary: After 4 November’s UPS Flight 2976 MD-11 crash at Louisville, Kentucky, where its left engine detached on take-off and the fully fuelled jet collided with a scrapyard and nearby businesses, the ground death toll rose to 15 when scrapyard worker Alain Rodriguez Colina succumbed to injuries on Christmas Day. Colina, one of four employees of Grade A Auto Parts & Recycling killed, had been at the site since 2023. Three crew members also died. NTSB investigators detected cracks at the engine-wing connection. The FAA grounded all MD-11s days later. UPS and GE face wrongful-death suits alleging maintenance lapses, both citing safety priorities amid ongoing probes.

articles.title: ‘Weapons of mass construction’: the US ‘craftivists’ using yarn to fight back against Trump
articles.trailText: Fiber artists across the US are using their craft to protest against everything from national guard deployments to rollbacks on abortion rights
articles.summary: In Portland, knitters led by Tracy Wright have staged weekly “knit-ins” at ICE facilities as “weapons of mass construction” to protest Trump’s national guard deployment, forming “Knitters Against Fascism” to show solidarity with immigrants. Designer Michele Lee Bernstein’s frog-hat pattern raised hundreds for local food banks. Rooted in the craftivism coined in 2003, the movement spans embroidered guns by Shannon Downey to pussyhat campaigns, leveraging fiber arts to forge community bonds, raise funds for causes like LGBTQ+ youth, Gaza relief and reproductive rights, and sustain political activism through shared joy.

articles.title: Conservative and Christian? US right champions psychedelic drugs
articles.trailText: Texas governor among those to call for expanded access to ibogaine, said to help with treating veterans with PTSD
articles.summary: Evangelical Christians, Republican governors and veterans advocacy groups are championing ibogaine, an intense African psychedelic, as a 'divine technology' to treat PTSD, TBI and depression. After FDA rejected MDMA, Texas Gov. Abbott allocated $50M for ibogaine research; Colorado moving toward legal treatments; Ohio in reform talks. Stanford veterans reported breakthroughs with single-dose ibogaine. Big-tech donors (e.g. Sergey Brin’s $15M) and figures like Musk, McGregor and GOP lawmakers back access despite risks of cardiac arrest, urging medical oversight and destigmatization.

articles.title: ‘Loyalty over all’: Trump was once known for constantly switching out his staff. Not any more
articles.trailText: The president’s professed satisfaction with his cabinet may reflect how hard it would be to get a replacement confirmed
articles.summary: After a first term marked by record-high cabinet turnover and public firings, President Trump’s second administration has remained remarkably stable, retaining figures like Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, DHS chief Kristi Noem, DNI Tulsi Gabbard and FBI Director Kash Patel. Driven by an ethos of “loyalty über alles,” Trump rewards personal allegiance over institutional independence, limiting dismissals amid tougher Senate confirmation odds. Critics warn this sycophantic court prioritizes obedience over competence and sidesteps accountability, though purges continue among federal advisory councils and career prosecutors.

articles.title: US voters linking climate crisis to rising bills despite Trump’s ‘green scam’ claims
articles.trailText: New polling shows 65% of registered US voters believe global heating is affecting cost of living
articles.summary: A Yale University poll finds 65% of US registered voters link global heating to higher food, electricity and home insurance costs via extreme weather, droughts and grid strain. Nearly 80% oppose the Trump administration’s cuts to climate research, removal of climate data, FEMA cuts and bans on new offshore windfarms, despite White House labeling renewables a “scam.” Local backlash has also targeted power-hungry data centres. Overall, 59% favor candidates backing climate action, but only 21% of conservative Republicans do, underscoring persistent partisan divides.

articles.title: ‘Not the charmed industry it once was’: can Hollywood find its comeback story?
articles.trailText: After the writers’ and actors’ strikes, the pandemic, and structural shifts in technology, LA’s trying to find its footing in a changed industry
articles.summary: Veteran cinematographer Bruce McCleery’s return to LA on Fallout season two—backed by $25 m in state incentives (and $166 m for season three)—illustrates California’s bid to reverse “runaway” shoots migrating to Atlanta, Toronto and beyond after 2023’s writers’ and actors’ strikes and COVID. Yet LA lost over 20 % of filming days, saw pension contributions plunge one-third, and witnessed closures from costume warehouses to rental houses. Tech advances, streaming wars and underused sound stages have reshaped production globally. Gov. Newsom’s plan to boost incentives to $750 m divides insiders, many calling for stronger IP protections.

articles.title: How an ex-US marine became vital in the fight against Trump’s aggressive immigration enforcement
articles.trailText: When Trump began deploying troops to US cities, Janessa Goldbeck’s Vet Voice Foundation was ready – now they’re preparing for what may be next
articles.summary: Marine vet Janessa Goldbeck, CEO of Vet Voice Foundation, predicted and prepared for President Trump’s use of the National Guard for immigration enforcement, war-gaming coup scenarios and advising local leaders. Her group supports litigation to curb guard deployments in Democratic cities, clarifies guard versus ICE roles, and warns of safety risks (including a fatal ambush near the White House) and authoritarian threats to elections. Goldbeck joined the Marines, left in 2019 over Trump’s agenda, and now mobilizes millions of veterans to defend democracy, nonpartisan military norms, and resist Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth’s anti-woke, anti-women in combat rhetoric.

articles.title: US judge blocks Trump administration from deporting UK anti-disinformation campaigner
articles.trailText: Imran Ahmed of Center for Countering Digital Hate files complaint against senior Trump allies
articles.summary: A US judge in the Southern District of New York granted UK anti-disinformation campaigner Imran Ahmed, CEO of the Center for Countering Digital Hate, a temporary restraining order blocking his detention or deportation under a Trump administration sanction campaign targeting five Europeans. Ahmed sued senior officials including Secretary of State Marco Rubio and AG Pam Bondi, alleging unconstitutional removal. A DC resident with his American wife and daughter, he has clashed with Elon Musk over X content moderation. The state department claims they coercively push US platforms to censor American viewpoints; the UK government defends internet freedom.

articles.title: Brown shooting suspect: gruelling academic climate may have taken mental toll, say ex-classmates
articles.trailText: Cláudio Valente and one of victims, Nuno FG Loureiro, both studied at notoriously challenging Técnico in Lisbon
articles.summary: Investigators probing Cláudio Valente’s killing of two Brown University students and an MIT professor are tracing possible roots to his and victim Nuno FG Loureiro���s time at Lisbon’s Técnico, known for its emotionally gruelling engineering program. Classmates recall Valente’s brilliance and competitiveness but say his abrupt exit from Brown’s physics PhD and the hyper-competitive academic culture exacerbated mental distress. After Valente returned to the US on a diversity visa and obtained a green card, homeland security secretary Kristi Noem paused the lottery—a move peers argue misplaces blame on immigration rather than addressing pressure and mental-health gaps in academia.

articles.title: Trump news briefing: President praises military after launching Christmas Day strikes on IS in Nigeria
articles.trailText: Trump also wishes ‘merry Christmas to all, including the dead terrorists’, after strikes. Key US politics stories from Thursday 25 December
articles.summary: On Christmas Day, President Trump ordered “powerful and deadly” US Africa Command strikes on Islamic State militants in Sokoto state, Nigeria—the first under his administration—citing prior warnings against the slaughter of Christians. Confirmed by Nigeria’s foreign ministry, the strikes underscore Trump’s religious framing amid local pushback against claims of Christian persecution. Other key developments: AFL-CIO officials vow to challenge his “Billionaire First” agenda in 2026; British campaigner Imran Ahmed sues to halt a deportation threat; and insider fallout over chief of staff Susie Wiles.

articles.title: Southern California sees third death from atmospheric river storm drenching region
articles.trailText: Some parts of LA saw more than 11in of rain, with flooding, road closures and debris flows reported across the region
articles.summary: An atmospheric river storm triggered historic rainfall—over 11 in in parts of L.A. County—killing three, including a man crushed by a fallen tree in San Diego. Gov. Newsom declared a state of emergency in Los Angeles and surrounding counties; LA Mayor Bass issued a local emergency. Flood watches and evacuation orders cover mountain communities and 130 vulnerable Pacific Palisades homes as burn scars fuel debris flows. Widespread road closures (Angeles Crest Hwy), 102,900 power outages (peak in Monterey), flight delays, rare east LA tornado warning, and multiple rescues (a woman swept 9 mi down San Jose Creek). A second storm wave is due through Saturday.

articles.title: US carries out strikes on Nigeria targeting Islamic State militants, Trump says
articles.trailText: President claims strikes targeted militants in country’s north-west, accusing group of attacking Christian communities
articles.summary: Donald Trump announced US airstrikes against Islamic State Sahel Province militants in Sokoto state, Nigeria, targeting groups accused of killing Christians in north-west Nigeria. He said the strikes, directed by him as Commander-in-Chief and executed by AFRICOM in coordination with Nigerian authorities, delivered “powerful and deadly” precision hits following weeks of IS attacks. Nigeria’s foreign ministry confirmed ongoing intelligence-sharing and strategic cooperation. Analysts note complex local drivers—herder-farmer clashes, criminal kidnappings—and warn against framing solely as religious persecution. The strikes come after a Christmas Eve mosque bombing in Borno blamed on Boko Haram.

articles.title: Maga’s guilt, frank nonsense and mirth | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Donald Trump | Engels’ festive spirit | Gordon Bennett news | Unseen radio plays | Habits of tech users | Stages of life
articles.summary: Seven readers weigh in on festive themes: Anthony Bron (Oxford) contrasts the biblical Magi’s gifts with the MAGA campaign’s misguided leader, lampooning his ‘frank nonsense’; Keith Flett (Tottenham) quotes Friedrich Engels’s 1868 letter on holiday overindulgence and ill temper; Simon Chapman (Marseille) celebrates the unveiling of an unseen Tennessee Williams radio play; Joanna Rimmer (Newcastle) confesses reflexively pinching print to zoom photos; David Joss Buckley (London) worries about the Gordon Bennett after a canal embankment collapse; Kenneth Brown (Harrogate) and Moira Robinson (Kidlington) reflect on the ‘fourth age’ and ‘decrepitude’ in later life. Readers are invited to submit letters.

articles.title: ‘Not an enabler’? A glimpse behind the curtain at Trump’s chief of staff, Susie Wiles
articles.trailText: Are her recent candid remarks about Trump an attempt to distance herself from an increasingly unpopular president?
articles.summary: In a 9,500-word Vanity Fair profile, Trump’s White House chief of staff Susie Wiles—first woman in that role—described him as having “an alcoholic’s personality,” labelled VP JD Vance “a conspiracy theorist” and Elon Musk “odd,” raising questions over her motives and whether she’s distancing herself ahead of an inevitable departure. A seasoned operative who steered Trump’s Florida campaigns since 2016, Wiles insists she’s “not an enabler,” but critics call her remarks a plea bargain with history as her future remains uncertain.

articles.title: How effective is protesting? According to historians and political scientists: very
articles.trailText: From emancipation to women’s suffrage, civil rights and BLM, mass movement has shaped the arc of US history
articles.summary: Historians and political scientists argue US protests have been highly effective: from emancipation, women’s suffrage and civil rights to Black Lives Matter. Mass marches (2017 Women’s March, No Kings) increased voter turnout, shifted county votes toward Democrats, spurred a surge in women and minority candidates, and mirror Tea Party effects in 2010. The 3.5% rule suggests nonviolent campaigns’ peak participation can topple regimes. Protesting fosters lifelong civic engagement, coalition-building and emotional wellbeing. Nonviolence remains key: disciplined tactics attract public sympathy and policy shifts, while violent or destructive acts undermine support. Impact often unfolds gradually over decades.

articles.title: US labor unions gear up to fight against Trump’s ‘Billionaire First’ agenda
articles.trailText: AFL-CIO president Liz Shuler says union ready to stand up for struggling Americans: ‘Which side are you on?’
articles.summary: Facing Trump’s “biggest attack on unions,” AFL-CIO president Liz Shuler says the federation will mobilize against his “Billionaire First” agenda by pushing a December 11 House–passed bill to restore collective bargaining for over 1M federal workers in a January Senate fight, filing lawsuits, and organizing nationwide canvasses. Shuler accuses Trump of broken job and cost promises and dismissing affordability as a “hoax.” As threat of a late-January government shutdown and ACA-subsidy clash looms, unions leverage 68% public support, rising trust in labor, and high-profile strikes like Starbucks to shape 2026 midterms on healthcare, housing, affordability, and AI guardrails.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: EU could respond to ‘unjustified’ US visa bans, official says
articles.trailText: European leaders including Emmanuel Macron accused Washington of ‘coercion and intimidation’. Key US politics stories from Wednesday 24 December
articles.summary: The European Commission vows swift countermeasures after the Trump administration barred visas for five Europeans—including former EU commissioner Thierry Breton and anti-disinformation campaigners—citing alleged ’extraterritorial censorship.’ Emmanuel Macron, along with German, Spanish and UK leaders, condemned the move as coercion. Secretary of State Marco Rubio defended it as a stand against European tech regulation. Elsewhere, the DOJ says it needs weeks to process 1m+ new Epstein documents; a federal judge blocks homeland security funding cuts tied to immigration compliance; 350 National Guard troops deploy to New Orleans; Palau agrees to take 75 US migrants; Rep. Joyce Beatty sues to remove Trump’s name from the Kennedy Center.

articles.title: US justice department says it may need ‘a few more weeks’ to process 1m more Epstein documents for release
articles.trailText: DoJ says more documents have been uncovered amid criticisms for missing 19 December deadline for full release
articles.summary: The Justice Department has announced discovery of over one million additional Epstein-related records from the SDNY and FBI, delaying full release by 'a few more weeks' for legally required redactions. Critics, victims and lawmakers like Ro Khanna, Thomas Massie and Chuck Schumer have threatened contempt actions over missing the 19 December deadline. Approximately 750,000 documents are reviewed, with many duplicates. Recent releases included 30,000 files with more mentions of Donald Trump’s flights, and fake letters and videos produced under court order. FBI emails named ten potential co-conspirators, only Maxwell, Brunel and Wexner unredacted; Wexner denies any involvement. Transparency demands escalate.

articles.title: Democratic lawmaker sues Trump over Kennedy Center’s name change
articles.trailText: Joyce Beatty seeks to remove the president’s name from the newly minted ‘Trump-Kennedy Center’
articles.summary: Ohio Representative Joyce Beatty sued President Trump to remove his name from the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, challenging its renaming to “Trump-Kennedy Center” as an illegal act requiring congressional approval. Beatty, an ex-officio trustee, alleges the board vote violated federal law and silenced her input by muting her during the video call. Represented by Washington Litigation Group and Democracy Defenders Action, she asserts the center must remain a memorial to JFK. White House spokespeople defend the change, while critics including Joe Kennedy III also question its legality amid Trump’s broader overhaul of the center.

articles.title: Federal judge blocks White House’s reductions of homeland security funding to states
articles.trailText: Judge said cuts were ‘another example’ of Trump administration tying state assistance to its immigration crackdown
articles.summary: US District Judge Mary McElroy, a 2018 Trump appointee, enjoined the Trump administration’s withholding of over $230 million in DHS and FEMA counterterrorism grants from Connecticut, Delaware, Minnesota, Massachusetts, New York, Rhode Island, Vermont and DC for non-compliance with federal immigration enforcement. These funds are part of $1 billion in annual counterterrorism and emergency disaster support. In a scathing 48-page opinion, McElroy decried the “wanton abuse” of grant administration, citing the Brown University mass shooting response as illustrative of these programs’ critical role. A coalition of 12 state attorneys general, led by NY AG Letitia James, celebrated the ruling. DHS plans to appeal.

articles.title: North Carolina Christmas tree farmers are optimistic after Hurricane Helene
articles.trailText: More than a year after storm ripped apart families and farms, growers are bullish about strength of their industry
articles.summary: After October 2024’s Category 4 Hurricane Helene killed 95+, caused $125 million in nursery and tree losses, western North Carolina Christmas tree farmers are rebuilding and optimistic. Hickory Creek Farm reports strong sales; Avery Farms replanted 20,000 trees this spring, doubled wreath output and restored family homes; C&G Nursery and Cartner’s repaired roads, bridges and culverts. Despite reduced inventory, 2025 sales remain buoyant thanks to ample rainfall. North Carolina—second in US Fraser fir production at 4 million trees—leans on long harvest cycles (6–12 yrs), community support and climate adaptation research.

articles.title: The 12 days of Trump-mas
articles.trailText: What has Donald Trump given us in his second term? We look at some of the numbers
articles.summary: Adapting the ‘12 Days’ motif into his second term’s stats, the Trump White House logs claim 12-hour workdays and 11 months of unprecedented change, he’s suing the BBC for $10bn over a ‘doctored’ Capitol speech, touts a future $400m ballroom seating about 99 guests, denies an 8-line Epstein note, polls show just 7% find living costs unaffordable, he’s labeled 6 Democrats seditious, sent federal troops to 5 cities, US unemployment stands at 4.6%—a 4-year high, he’s nodded off publicly 3 times, remains the only twice-impeached president, and his team insists he’s America’s No.1 chief executive despite historians ranking him 43rd.

articles.title: Republicans aim to exempt major polluters from Pfas cleanup costs
articles.trailText: Water treatment and landfill companies given chance to make case that EPA rules should not apply to them
articles.summary: Republicans on the House energy committee are pushing legislation to shield water treatment plants, landfills and other major polluters from paying cleanup costs for PFOA and PFOS “forever chemicals” under EPA’s Superfund rules. Industry groups argue they merely handle contaminated waste and cannot absorb compliance expenses without burdening ratepayers or diverting funds from infrastructure. Opponents say exemptions would weaken the 2024 hazardous substance designation, remove incentives for polluters to curb discharges and undermine public health protections for water systems nationwide.

articles.title: Fresh ‘manty’ and cheap figs: a post-Soviet supermarket becomes a must-visit spot in NYC
articles.trailText: Tashkent Supermarket’s new West Village location offers staples like plov and samsas hot and fresh – a taste of Central Asia for everyone
articles.summary: Tashkent Supermarket, founded by Uzbek immigrant Odiljon Tursunov's family in 2012, opened a West Village outpost in March, bringing hot Central Asian staples—plov, samsas and manty—to Manhattan. Already a Brighton Beach pilgrimage site for 1.2M post-Soviet immigrants, the new location draws influencers, food bloggers and curious locals attracted by fresh dumplings, cheap figs and smoked fish. Despite Manhattan's high rents and congestion pricing hikes adding $1 to hot bar items, shoppers still flock. Sourcing breads from Ukraine, cheeses from Georgia and spices from Uzbekistan, Tashkent showcases Silk Road-meets-Soviet-era flavors while expanding to five NYC sites.

articles.title: Trump’s claims to Venezuelan oil are part of broader ‘resource imperialism’, experts say
articles.trailText: Critics compare offensive to Iraq war, citing familiar mix of regime-change rhetoric, security pretexts and oil interests
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s push to seize Venezuelan oil from intercepted tankers exemplifies a broader right-wing “resource imperialism,” say experts. Framing regime-change rhetoric and security pretexts—labeling Venezuelan fentanyl a WMD—his administration has openly argued the US can claim foreign resources as assets, echoing his calls to grab Iraqi and Syrian oil, enforce secondary sanctions on Iran, and secure Arctic minerals in Greenland. Analysts warn his “most-of-the-above” energy strategy, driven by fossil fuel dominance and geopolitical leverage, mirrors past administrations’ extractive playbooks but disregards climate norms and risks heightening US-China competition.

articles.title: Is Trump mentally OK? A look back at the president’s unusual behavior in 2025
articles.trailText: Trump has shown erratic and bizarre behavior throughout the year, leading to questions about his mental acuity
articles.summary: In 2025 Trump’s second term featured erratic behavior raising mental‐fitness concerns: he napped in meetings, veered off-topic into decor, whales, windmills killing birds, and fabricated Unabomber anecdotes. He bungled MRI details, mixed up Albania/Armenia, and rambled about stairs and autism. Critics cite these incidents and his shorter days (noon–5 pm, 39% fewer events) to question his acuity. The White House and allies insist he’s in “excellent overall health” and tout a dementia test pass. Democrats aim to spotlight his age and alleged decline ahead of midterms, while public trust in news dips to record lows.

articles.title: Throwing out flame-retardant furniture can reduce toxic chemicals in blood, study finds
articles.trailText: Flame retardants commonly used in furniture are linked to serious health issues, including cancer and thyroid disease
articles.summary: California’s decade-long peer-reviewed study finds that removing foam furniture made with flame retardants (1975–2015) cuts blood levels of these toxic chemicals by half in 1.4 years—four times faster than in people who kept old sofas. Flame retardants, long used to meet 1970s flammability laws, are linked to cancer, thyroid disease, neurotoxicity, fertility issues and lower IQ in children. After California dropped chemical requirements in 2015 and later bans at state and federal levels, most manufacturers have abandoned these additives. Experts advise swapping dated furniture, replacing cushion foam or increasing dust control with HEPA vacuums.

articles.title: Woman deported before she could see dying husband in ICE custody: ‘I never saw him again’
articles.trailText: Francisco Gaspar-Andrés died in El Paso hospital after being detained at Fort Bliss – his wife was deported to Guatemala without a chance to see him
articles.summary: Francisco Gaspar-Andrés, 48, became the first person to die in ICE custody at Fort Bliss on December 3, succumbing to complications of alcoholic cirrhosis and kidney failure after ten weeks detained. His wife, Lucía Pedro Juan, was deported to Guatemala on November 28 without seeing him again, despite both being arrested in Florida and held at Camp East Montana. Democratic Rep. Veronica Escobar and ACLU lawyers accuse the facility of inhumane conditions and medical neglect, demanding its closure, while DHS and ICE deny mistreatment citing continuous medical care.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: President claims tariffs behind unexpected growth, but consumer confidence falls
articles.trailText: The surprisingly strong growth ‘reflected increases in consumer spending, exports and government spending’, according to officials. Key US politics stories from Tuesday 23 December
articles.summary: Q3 US GDP jumped 4.3% annualized, driven by consumer spending, exports and government outlays, surprising officials. President Trump credited tariffs via Truth Social as key driver, while consumer sentiment slid for a fifth straight month, the longest since 2008, complicating the Fed’s rate policy amid its third cut this year. Meanwhile, SCOTUS weighs tariff challenges, blocks Trump’s bid to deploy National Guard in Chicago; newly released Epstein files reference Trump; the VA abortion ban kicks in; ex-senator Ben Sasse reveals terminal cancer; journalist attacks surge under Trump’s tenure.

articles.title: American woman accused of killing her two children extradited to US from UK
articles.trailText: Kimberlee Singler was arrested in London in 2023, a week after her daughter, 9, and son, 7, found dead in Colorado
articles.summary: Kimberlee Singler, 37, was extradited from London to Colorado after allegedly killing her nine-year-old daughter and seven-year-old son and seriously injuring her 11-year-old daughter in Colorado Springs. Arrested in Chelsea days after the bodies were found in December 2023, she claimed an intruder attacked the family and later said “God made me do it.” Singler fought extradition on human-rights grounds, arguing a life-without-parole sentence for first-degree murder violates European law, but UK courts rejected her appeal. Colorado prosecutors have charged her with two counts of first-degree murder, attempted murder, child abuse and assault amid a custody dispute with her ex-husband.

articles.title: At least two people dead in Philadelphia nursing home explosion
articles.trailText: Five additional people unaccounted for after partial building collapse at Silver Lake center in Bristol Township
articles.summary: A suspected gas explosion at Silver Lake Healthcare Center—a 174-bed nursing home in Bristol Township, PA—partially collapsed the building, killing at least two and leaving five unaccounted. Peco crews, responding to reports of a gas odor at 2pm, shut off utilities as black smoke billowed. Police declared a mass casualty incident; EMS and fire units statewide responded. Survivors were sent to a reunification center at Truman High School. Governor Josh Shapiro urged prayers. The cause awaits confirmation. The facility, which passed a Sept 2024 fire review, holds a "much below average" Medicare rating.

articles.title: TikToker who allegedly hit and killed man while livestreaming is arrested
articles.trailText: Known as Tea Tyme, Tynesha McCarty-Wroten arrested over 3 November death of Darren Lucas in Zion, Illinois
articles.summary: Tynesha McCarty-Wroten, aka Tea Tyme, 43-year-old TikTok livestreamer, was arrested after video and traffic camera evidence contradicted her claim of a green light when she fatally struck 59-year-old Darren Lucas on 3 November in Zion, Illinois. Prosecutors charged her with felony reckless homicide and aggravated use of a communications device resulting in death. Forensic analysis confirmed she was livestreaming at the crash moment. She stayed at the scene but initially declined to surrender her phone. Amid public outrage, she later solicited donations online. Lucas’s family set up a GoFundMe for his widow. TikTok prohibits live streaming while driving.

articles.title: US supreme court blocks Trump bid to deploy national guard to Chicago
articles.trailText: In a 6-3 decision, the high court sided with a lower court ruling that blocked deployment of troops to the Illinois city
articles.summary: The Supreme Court denied the Justice Department’s emergency request to deploy hundreds of National Guard troops to the Chicago area for immigration enforcement amid protests at the Broadview ICE facility. In a 6-3 decision, the majority upheld District Judge April Perry’s October order blocking the deployment, ruling the government had not shown authority to use military forces for domestic law enforcement. Justices Alito, Thomas and Gorsuch dissented. The ruling curbs Trump’s domestic troop deployments and may guide related challenges in DC, Oregon, California and Tennessee.

articles.title: Newly released Epstein files include references to Donald Trump
articles.trailText: Files also include details about Epstein’s relationship with Larry Summers and apparently fake letter to Larry Nassar
articles.summary: Justice Department released nearly 30,000 pages of Epstein files, including a January 2020 SDNY email claiming that Donald Trump flew on Epstein’s private jet at least eight times between 1993 and 1996—once alone with Epstein and a 20-year-old woman and four times when Ghislaine Maxwell was aboard. No evidence suggests criminal wrongdoing. Files also document Epstein’s ties to former Treasury secretary Larry Summers, a bogus letter to Larry Nassar, references to Prince Andrew and a fake Saudi passport, allegations involving David Copperfield and FBI raids, and a Senate call for DOJ transparency over unnamed co-conspirators.

articles.title: DoJ says Jeffrey Epstein letter to Larry Nassar referencing Trump is fake
articles.trailText: Justice department says FBI confirmed letter is fake and lists why it was not deemed genuine by authorities
articles.summary: DoJ announced an alleged 2019 letter from Jeffrey Epstein to Larry Nassar referencing President Trump’s fondness for ‘young, nubile girls’ is a forgery. The FBI authenticated the document as fake and the DoJ cited signature, postmark and provenance discrepancies. First reported by the AP in 2023 amid 4,000 Bureau of Prisons pages, the letter—postmarked three days after Epstein’s 2019 custodial death—was returned to sender from an Arizona prison. Nassar, serving decades for sexual-abuse convictions, has no known link to Epstein. DoJ stressed that releasing documents under transparency laws doesn’t imply accuracy and rejected other unverified pre-election Trump allegations.

articles.title: Trump administration bans US veterans agency from providing abortions
articles.trailText: Department of Veterans Affairs says justice department found procedure not to be legally sound
articles.summary: The Department of Veterans Affairs, following a Department of Justice memo deeming it “not legally authorized” to provide abortions, has immediately banned all abortion services for veterans—including in rape or incest cases—overturning a Biden-era policy that had allowed counseling and procedures in such circumstances or when pregnancy threatened a veteran’s health. The 1,300-facility VA network treating nearly 10 million veterans annually is processing rollback paperwork filed in August now in the rule-making process. Internal VA guidance preserves only life-saving interventions (e.g., ectopic pregnancies). Democracy Forward condemned the ban as callous. Over half of female veterans live in states that ban abortion.

articles.title: Epstein files appear to show Andrew asking Ghislaine Maxwell for ‘inappropriate friends’
articles.trailText: Documents give further insight into former royal’s ties to sex offender and raise fresh questions for Donald Trump
articles.summary: Newly released DOJ files reveal emails from 2001–02 in which Prince Andrew (signed “A” from Balmoral) asks Ghislaine Maxwell to arrange meetings with “inappropriate friends” and discreet young women via fixer Juan Esteban Ganoza. The tranche also shows FBI interest in Andrew’s links to Epstein and Peter Nygard, US lawyers disputing inaccuracies in his statements, references to Donald Trump on flights with Epstein, and recoverable redactions. Under growing pressure and stripped of titles, Andrew denies wrongdoing while UK and US leaders urge his cooperation in investigations.

articles.title: The valet, the burnt toast, and the trip to Peru: evidence that suggests Andrew link to Ghislaine Maxwell emails
articles.trailText: Documents released in relation to Jeffrey Epstein contain emails between Maxwell and an individual signing off as ‘A’ and ‘The Invisible Man’
articles.summary: Documents from the DOJ reveal 2001–02 emails between Ghislaine Maxwell and a correspondent signing as “A” or “The Invisible Man,” whose references—to ‘inappropriate friends’, Balmoral’s burnt-toast fire scare, valet Michael Perry’s death and a Peru trip to the Nazca Lines—match Prince Andrew’s itinerary. Maxwell names him directly and forwards contacts for “Andrew” in Lima. Andrew has denied all accusations, but these exchanges deepen scrutiny of his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein’s circle.

articles.title: Some Epstein file redactions are being undone with hacks
articles.trailText: Un-redacted text from released documents began circulating on social media on Monday evening
articles.summary: Independent analysts found that redactions in DOJ-released Jeffrey Epstein documents can be undone via Photoshop layer adjustments or text highlighting, and unredacted allegations began circulating on social media December 23. The exhibit from a Virgin Islands civil suit against estate executors Darren K. Indyke and Richard D. Kahn reveals schemes to funnel over $400,000 to underage models, conceal sex-trafficking crimes with hush payments, threats and evidence destruction. The 2022 settlement totaled $105 million plus island‐sale proceeds. The new Epstein Files Transparency Act allows DOJ redactions, but unanswered inquiries question consistency with the law.

articles.title: Washington state officials warn of toilet rats after floods: ‘Try to stay calm’
articles.trailText: Tips include flushing rat, squirt soap into toilet or if the rat is too large close toilet lid and call pest control
articles.summary: Following record December floodwaters that inundated homes, washed away roads and forced thousands to evacuate, Seattle and King County Public Health warned rodents may surface in toilets. In a Facebook post they advised residents to stay calm; flush small rats or add dish soap to grease their path; and if a rat is too large, close the lid and call pest control. Strong swimmers with slender bodies, rats exploit dilapidated pipes in older buildings during heavy rainfall.

articles.title: Ben Sasse, ex-Republican senator, says he has terminal pancreatic cancer
articles.trailText: Sasse, who is 53 and voted to impeach Trump, says he has ‘metastasized, stage-four pancreatic cancer’
articles.summary: Ben Sasse, 53, former Republican senator from Nebraska (2015–23) and one of seven GOP members who voted to impeach Donald Trump in 2021, announced on X that he’s been diagnosed with metastatic, stage-four pancreatic cancer, calling it a “death sentence.” A Harvard, Oxford and Yale PhD in history, Sasse warned of the impact on his wife and three children. In his farewell Senate speech he criticized political extremes on both left and right. As a Christian, he framed the news in the Advent season. Pancreatic cancer strikes 67,000 Americans yearly, killing about 51,000.

articles.title: Jes Staley and Larry Summers made executors of Jeffrey Epstein’s estate, files reveal
articles.trailText: Former Barclays boss and ex-US Treasury secretary named in versions of will of convicted child sex offender
articles.summary: Newly released DOJ filings show former Barclays CEO Jes Staley and ex-Treasury Secretary Larry Summers were named executors in earlier versions of Jeffrey Epstein’s will: Staley as successor executor in 2012 and full executor in 2013–14, Summers as successor executor in 2014. Neither appears in the 2019 will. Epstein died awaiting trial in August 2019. Both men deny active involvement—Staley says he refused the role, Summers claims he was unaware of his inclusion. The revelations intensify scrutiny: Staley was banned from UK banking in 2023 after stepping down in 2021; Summers left Harvard in 2024 after document leaks.

articles.title: Once hailed as heroes, Afghans fear deportation under Trump
articles.trailText: The very same immigrants welcomed to the US after risking their lives to fight the Taliban now fear detention or worse
articles.summary: Afghan pilot Ali, who fled Kabul on a US C-17 and now works as an Uber driver in Idaho, and thousands of other evacuees brought by Operation Allies Welcome face abrupt Trump administration measures pausing asylum and green-card processes, suspending special immigrant visas and expanding travel bans. Advocates warn these policies punish all Afghans for isolated acts, erode trust in US wartime commitments, expose families to ICE raids and undermine America’s promise to allies. Ali, granted asylum and awaiting a green card, fears deportation and separation from relatives still under Taliban rule, highlighting a betrayal of those who served America.

articles.title: Email from ‘A’ at Balmoral urged Ghislaine Maxwell to find ‘inappropriate friends’
articles.trailText: Epstein files reveal messages between his accomplice and a man who appears to be Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor
articles.summary: Newly released 2001–02 emails show Ghislaine Maxwell exchanging messages with “A,” writing from Balmoral—widely presumed to be Prince Andrew—urging her to find “inappropriate friends” after his Royal Navy departure. In August 2001, “A” complains of exhaustion at Balmoral Summer Camp and teases Maxwell for only locating “appropriate” companions. A 2002 thread forwards correspondence about a Peru trip organized by Maxwell and Juan Esteban Ganoza, including setting up meetings with girls and sharing Andrew’s phone number. Subsequent documents reveal US lawyers highlighting inaccuracies in Andrew’s Epstein accounts, a public dispute over his DOJ cooperation, and a Metropolitan Police inquiry to the FBI on alleged efforts to dig up dirt on Virginia Giuffre. There is no suggestion that mere mention constitutes wrongdoing.

articles.title: ‘Rare’ squirrels set free together after bonding at Florida wildlife hospital
articles.trailText: Big Cypress fox squirrels released as a pair to reduce stress and support natural behaviors during return to the wild
articles.summary: Two juvenile Big Cypress fox squirrels, a threatened species unseen by the Conservancy of Southwest Florida in over a decade, fell from nests and spent 56 and 74 days at von Arx wildlife hospital. Under associate director Lauren Barkley, they bonded, received special diets, and practiced climbing, foraging and nut-cracking in an outdoor enclosure. Released together into prime pine-cypress habitat near their natal nest to reduce stress and bolster wild behaviors, one displays a rare melanistic black-and-white coat.

articles.title: Mauritanian immigrants in Ohio face deportations home, where abuses persist
articles.trailText: A growing group has found community around Cincinnati. Trump’s ICE crackdown threatens to send them back to Mauritania, rife with human rights problems
articles.summary: Mauritanian asylum seekers, including musician Khalidou Sy, have formed a growing community in Lockland, Ohio, after perilous 15-day journeys via Central America. Fleeing a segregated, Arab-Berber–ruled Mauritania—last to abolish slavery with 149,000 still held and rising Fulani persecution—they face deportations under Trump’s ICE expansion, with 19,000 cases pending and at least 90 returned since 2021. Strained local housing, jobs and services and right-wing backlash contrast with rising work-permit use, car ownership and volunteer aid from groups like Queen City Bike. Families await asylum decisions amid fear of check-ins, detentions and forced repatriation.

articles.title: ‘An air of repression’: Cop City case hangs over heads of 61 defendants
articles.trailText: US government continues holding on to huge amounts of seized personal property, from diaries to cellphones
articles.summary: Georgia’s unprecedented RICO case against 61 protesters opposing the $109m Cop City police training center remains unresolved three years on after a judge failed to file a written ruling dismissing felony conspiracy charges. Meanwhile the state continues to hold over 100 devices—cellphones, laptops, hard drives—plus diaries, letters, health records and bail-fund receipts, including the diary of slain activist Manuel “Tortuguita” Paez Terán and intimate materials from the Atlanta Solidarity Fund. Defendants’ lawyers condemn this mass seizure as government overreach and an “air of repression.”

articles.title: ‘Gunboat diplomacy on steroids’: US signs security deals across Latin America
articles.trailText: Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro warns Trump administration may ‘destabilise the entire region’ amid rising tensions
articles.summary: While ramping up a military campaign against Venezuela, the Trump administration has quietly inked security pacts this week with Paraguay, Ecuador, Peru and Trinidad and Tobago—granting airport access, US radar installations and temporary troop deployments under a “war on drugs” pretext. Observers see these moves, alongside deals with Guyana, the Dominican Republic and Panama and US bases in Puerto Rico, Honduras and Cuba, as part of a new “Trump Corollary” to the Monroe Doctrine aimed at securing energy reserves and positioning forces. Caracas denounces this “gunboat diplomacy on steroids,” warning that expanded US footprints risk destabilizing the entire region.

articles.title: ‘It’s sad we have to do this’: the US citizens carrying passports out of fear
articles.trailText: Across the US, people have been carrying their passports amid reports of ICE detaining citizens. Five people explain what living this reality is like
articles.summary: Amid nationwide ICE raids under the second Trump administration, US citizens across ethnic communities now carry passports daily to prove citizenship and avoid wrongful detention. In Minneapolis, Somali-American nurse Munira Maalimisaq began holding her passport at her clinic to reassure patients; in Kenner, Louisiana, landscaper Walter Cruz Perez stashes his in a weatherproof phone case; educator Carola Lopez, a Puerto Rican-American,’s long-held practice of keeping her passport continues; Los Angeles maintenance worker Miguel Rios carries copies after colleagues’ detentions; and in Southern California, teacher Ana follows a high-profile ICE kidnapping of a citizen. All report heightened anxiety, disrupted routines and activism to defend civil rights.

articles.title: First Thing: Number of people in ICE detention hits record high
articles.trailText: Administration has arrested 328,000 and deported 327,000 people. Plus, Bethlehem in the Israeli-occupied West Bank celebrates Christmas again
articles.summary: ICE’s biweekly data published Dec. 14 shows 68,400 immigrants in US detention—a new all-time high, surpassing the early-December record. Since inauguration, the administration has arrested over 328,000 people and deported nearly 327,000, yet migrants with no criminal convictions—who face only civil infractions for undocumented status—now constitute the largest detained group, contradicting vows to target “the worst” offenders. As detention capacity strains, grassroots coalitions in multiple states are organizing mutual-aid networks, staging blockade actions to thwart raids and distributing emergency groceries to affected families. Civil rights groups warn the surge violates due process and are mounting legal challenges against expanded detention policies.

articles.title: US sees surge in violence against journalists under Trump, report says
articles.trailText: The US press have suffered about as many assaults this year as in the previous three years combined
articles.summary: Since Trump’s return to office, verified assaults on US journalists have spiked: 170 attacks by law enforcement at immigration protests as of mid-December 2025—nearly equalling the 175 incidents from 2022–24 combined. Freedom of the Press Foundation attributes the rise to both increased civil unrest coverage and anti-media presidential rhetoric that frames reporters as combatants. Notable episodes include 34 assaults during “Operation Midway Blitz” in Chicago and multiple lawsuits over baton strikes, pepper balls, and explosive munitions injuring freelance photographers and staff. Advocates warn this pattern normalises aggression against news gatherers.

articles.title: Trump complains Epstein files are damaging people who ‘innocently met’ him
articles.trailText: In his first comments since the release, the president expressed sympathy for high-profile figures, including Bill Clinton, who have come under scrutiny
articles.summary: At Mar-a-Lago, President Trump criticized the Justice Department’s partial release of Jeffrey Epstein files, claiming publicly distributed photos unfairly tarnish those who “innocently met” Epstein—citing Bill Clinton, Harvard’s Larry Summers and unnamed bankers and lawyers. He blamed Democrats for pushing the disclosures, framed them as a GOP distraction, and dismissed the files as a “hoax.” Mandated by the nearly unanimous Epstein Files Transparency Act, only one batch has emerged, prompting survivor and congressional outcry. Clinton spokesperson Angel Urena accused the DOJ of selective leaks implying wrongdoing and demanded full release of all Clinton-related documents and images.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president breaks with convention to name new battleships after himself
articles.trailText: Donald Trump is on a naming spree; Schumer asks Senate to back legal action over partial Epstein files release – key US politics stories from Monday 22 December at a glance
articles.summary: President Trump broke naming convention by ordering a “Trump-class” fleet of 20–25 next-generation battleships—bigger, faster, 100× more powerful, including two USS Defiant ships hailed by Navy secretary John Phelan as ensuring American victory at sea. Developments: Senate leader Schumer plans a resolution to force DOJ to release full Epstein files; the administration recalled ~30 ambassadors to install loyalists; CBS pulled a 60 Minutes probe on El Salvador’s Cecot prison; DOI halted five offshore wind projects over military radar risks; ICE detention hit a record 68,400; DOJ paused $90 million in anti-trafficking grants.

articles.title: Trump administration plans to promote loyal diplomats after recall of 30 ambassadors, sources say
articles.trailText: Move comes as union representing US diplomats said it was ‘deeply concerned’ by the process, which could ‘politicise’ foreign service
articles.summary: The Trump administration quietly recalled nearly 30 career ambassadors and senior diplomats—primarily in Africa (including Niger, Uganda, Senegal, Somalia, Côte d’Ivoire, Mauritius, Nigeria, Gabon, Congo, Burundi, Cameroon, Rwanda), plus posts in Egypt, Algeria, Slovakia, Montenegro, Armenia and North Macedonia—and plans to reassign them while promoting officials loyal to its “America First” agenda. The American Foreign Service Association and affected officers warn the unprecedented purge and revised promotion criteria politicize an apolitical foreign service, penalize dedicated career staff and risk undermining U.S. diplomatic leadership amid soaring vacancies.

articles.title: Trump announces plans for new navy warships to be known as ‘Trump-class’
articles.trailText: President says the ships will be bigger, faster and a hundred times more powerful than any previous US-built warship
articles.summary: At Mar-a-Lago on Dec 22, President Trump unveiled plans for a “Trump-class” battleship series—two initial vessels, eventually 20–25—boasting bigger size, faster speed and 100× more firepower than any previous US warship, led by the prototype USS Defiant. Navy secretary John Phelan highlighted hypersonic weapons, high-power lasers and nuclear-armed sea-launched cruise missiles, declaring American victory at sea inevitable. Critics decry this naming and recent renamings of federal institutions as part of a broader narcissistic spree.

articles.title: One dead in California floods as state braces for brutal week of Christmas storms
articles.trailText: An atmospheric river is forecast to drive storms across the state this week, bringing rain, high winds and risk of floods
articles.summary: One motorist died in Redding after becoming trapped in floodwaters as California braces for a brutal week of Christmas storms driven by the Pineapple Express atmospheric river. Officials warn 4–8 inches of rain along the southern coast and 8–12 inches in foothills from Tuesday through Saturday, with high winds, flash flooding and mudslide risks in burn-scarred zones. Los Angeles has issued a flash flood warning, mobilizing first responders, public works crews and homeless services to pre-deploy supplies and hotel vouchers. This surge follows an unusually wet winter that has caused levee breaches and power outages across Oregon and Washington.

articles.title: Schumer to ask Senate to back legal action over partial Epstein files release
articles.trailText: Top Democrat to introduce resolution after Department of Justice misses deadline for all files linked to sex offender
articles.summary: Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer will introduce a resolution to authorize legal action against the DOJ for missing the Dec. 19 deadline under the Epstein Files Transparency Act to release all Jeffrey Epstein documents. Instead, DOJ released only 7,700 partial files, calling it a “first phase” to protect victims. The partial dump—briefly omitting a Trump photo—sparked criticism from Clinton’s spokesperson and lawmakers Ro Khanna, AOC and Thomas Massie, who warn of contempt, a court lawsuit or even impeachment if the full records, including grand jury transcripts and photos, aren’t turned over.

articles.title: New York school board investigates wooden ‘timeout’ box allegations
articles.trailText: Governor calls accusations that students with disabilities may have been confined in boxes ‘highly disturbing’
articles.summary: Salmon River central school district in upstate New York is investigating after images of small wooden "timeout" boxes—resembling padded seclusion cells—surfaced, prompting accusations that disabled elementary students were confined inside. Three boxes were installed at two schools; no official confirmation that any child was locked in. The board has placed three staff and the superintendent on leave, is aiding a state probe and apologized. Parents, amid a student body over 60% Native American, fear echoes of abusive US residential schools. Gov. Hochul calls the allegations "highly disturbing."

articles.title: Number of people in ICE detention hits record high, data shows
articles.trailText: ICE held more than 68,400 people as of 14 December, breaking previous high set at beginning of December
articles.summary: ICE held over 68,400 people as of December 14, 2025, breaking an early-December record, according to biweekly ICE data tracked by the Guardian. The figure covers detentions from October 1 through December 14 and contributes to a total of more than 328,000 arrests and nearly 327,000 deportations since January 2025. Despite promises to focus on “the worst of the worst,” non-criminal, undocumented immigrants remain the largest group in detention. At the same time, the administration has moved to invalidate legal protections for many migrants residing in the US legally.

articles.title: Betty Reid Soskin, who became a park ranger at 85, dies aged 104
articles.trailText: During her time as a ranger Soskin sought to shed light on experiences of women of color during the second world war
articles.summary: Betty Reid Soskin, National Park Service’s oldest active ranger, died aged 104 in Richmond, California on December 22, 2025. Appointed at 85 to the Rosie the Riveter/WWII Home Front National Historical Park, she drew on her past as a segregated-union file clerk to illuminate the wartime contributions of women of color. Retiring at 100 in 2022, Soskin championed inclusive historical narratives and featured in The Guardian’s “A New Start After 60,” inspiring cross-generational dialogue on race, labor and memory.

articles.title: Yellowstone hot spring spews forth spectacular muddy plumes
articles.trailText: Black Diamond Pool eruption provides dramatic footage after being captured on official camera
articles.summary: Over the weekend, Yellowstone’s Black Diamond Pool in Biscuit Basin sporadically erupted spectacular muddy plumes reaching 40 feet high, captured on a newly installed USGS camera and monitored by seismic and acoustic sensors. The footage, taken under bright winter skies at 9:23 am local time, marks the first clear visual record of these "dirty eruptions" since a July 2024 hydrothermal blast that damaged a nearby boardwalk. Situated midway between Old Faithful and the Grand Prismatic Spring, Black Diamond’s mud and rock expulsions underscore the park’s dynamic geothermal activity, one of over 10,000 hydrothermal features amid its bison, bears, and moose.

articles.title: Trump officials halt offshore wind-farm projects over ‘national security risks’
articles.trailText: Interior department move affects five projects under construction in latest blow to industry targeted by Trump
articles.summary: The Trump administration’s Interior Department has paused leases for five under-construction offshore wind farms—Vineyard Wind 1, Sunrise Wind, Empire Wind, Revolution Wind and Coastal Virginia Offshore Wind—citing potential radar interference and ‘national security risks.’ All projects were approved under Biden after Pentagon assessments found no DoD mission impacts. Developers warn the halt threatens billions in investment, thousands of jobs and new clean power amid surging electricity demand. The move escalates Trump’s campaign against wind energy despite a federal judge striking down an earlier permit ban.

articles.title: ‘I want that escape route’: Americans seek dual citizenships under Trump
articles.trailText: Some US citizens, grappling with issues from LGBTQ+ rights to the economy, are looking to the countries their families once left behind
articles.summary: As political upheaval, rights rollbacks and economic anxiety intensified under a likely second Trump term, growing numbers of Americans are reclaiming citizenship by descent. New York tenor Daniel Kamalić is applying for Croatian nationality after rising antisemitism, Medicaid cuts and immigration raids shook his faith in US protections. Sales executive Hollis Rutledge used Mexican lineage for cost-of-living relief and to safeguard his trans child’s rights. Teen Kyla Shannon tapped German ancestry for EU opportunities. Experts report a 500% spike in US descent-based citizenship claims since 2023 as dual passports become ‘Plan B’ insurance.

articles.title: Neo-Nazi terror group steps up US operations as FBI pulls back
articles.trailText: Online activity shows the Base, headed by alleged Russian asset Rinaldo Nazzaro, sees US and Ukraine as key centers
articles.summary: Designated neo-Nazi terror group the Base, led by alleged Russian asset and ex-Pentagon contractor Rinaldo Nazzaro, has reactivated US cells as the FBI under the second Trump administration diverts resources from far-right threats. Recent online footage shows Appalachian, mid-Atlantic and Midwestern members in military drills and sieg heil salutes. Meanwhile, its Spanish cell was raided and its Ukrainian wing claimed a Kyiv assassination. Nazzaro’s December audio urges ‘acceleration teams’ to target US infrastructure, echoing al-Qaida tactics, and seeks a white insurgent homeland. European arrests in Spain, the Netherlands, Belgium and the UK and the EU’s terrorist designation have raised global alarm.

articles.title: James Ransone, US actor known for The Wire, dies aged 46
articles.trailText: LA medical examiner reports Ransone, who played Chester ‘Ziggy’ Sobotka in the HBO crime drama, died by suicide
articles.summary: James Ransone, 46, best known as Ziggy Sobotka in HBO’s The Wire, died by suicide in Los Angeles, the city medical examiner confirmed. He also starred in Generation Kill and It Chapter Two. Ransone’s death prompted tributes from Wendell Pierce, Spike Lee, Larry Clark and Sean Baker. His widow, Jamie McPhee, mourned their two young children, Jack and Violet. Baltimore-born in 1979, Ransone trained at Towson’s Carver Center, debuted in Ken Park (2002) and later revealed he survived childhood sexual abuse and overcame addiction.

articles.title: ‘It’s made things worse for everyone’: Philadelphia grapples with rise of new street drug
articles.trailText: Medetomidine has extreme and fast-acting withdrawal symptoms – and the detox centers that help patients are struggling with how best to cope
articles.summary: In Philadelphia’s Kensington open drug scene, medetomidine – a potent veterinary sedative (“rhino tranq”) – now taints roughly 70% of fentanyl stamps, triggering extreme, rapid-onset withdrawal, organ failure and prolonged unconsciousness even after Narcan reversal. Sunshine House staff reverse overdoses daily, while Penn Presbyterian reports 25% of ICU beds occupied by medetomidine detox patients for whom no treatment protocols or diagnosis codes exist. Pennsylvania’s xylazine ban spurred this switch. Mayor Parker’s policing and diversion programs face criticism as activists call for safe supply and rapid innovation in detox services.

articles.title: Epstein files shed light on Ghislaine Maxwell’s tactics for luring teenagers  | First Thing
articles.trailText: Documents allege Epstein’s accomplice and ex-girlfriend ‘normalized’ his grooming and ‘directed’ girls on what to do. Plus, was 2025 the year that business retreated from net zero?
articles.summary: Newly released grand jury documents in Manhattan federal court detail how Ghislaine Maxwell ‘normalized’ grooming tactics and ‘directed’ vulnerable teenage girls into Jeffrey Epstein’s sex-trafficking network, fueling her appeal and transfer to a minimum-security prison. The news roundup covers Congress probing DOJ noncompliance, CBS delaying a 60 Minutes exposé on El Salvador’s Cecot megaprison, the assassination of Lt Gen Fanil Sarvarov in Moscow, actor James Ransone’s suicide, Trump’s recall of nearly 30 career diplomats, updates on an alleged Bondi beach terror plot, rising white-collar pardons under Trump, infighting at the MAGA AmericaFest, and corporate rollbacks on net-zero climate pledges.

articles.title: One twin is a Democratic politician, the other supports Trump. They’ve learned to bridge the divide
articles.trailText: Despite the fact that they disagree on everything when it comes to politics, Nick and Nathan Roberts make it a point to be kind to each other
articles.summary: Identical twins Nick and Nathan Roberts of Indiana—Nick, a 25-year-old Democratic Indianapolis city council member, and Nathan, a Trump-aligned Republican running anti-immigration group Save Heritage Indiana—went viral after Nick’s video clarified which twin wears a MAGA hat. Amid high-stakes redistricting debates, they avoid political arguments by prioritizing civility, kindness and honest dialogue, citing their grandmother’s adage on family unity. Nick faced bomb threats and a swatting attempt during the acrimonious debate. Their viral story underscores potential paths to bridge America’s political divide through empathy and mutual respect.

articles.title: Files release illuminates Maxwell’s tactics to lure teens into Epstein’s orbit
articles.trailText: Documents allege Epstein’s accomplice and ex-girlfriend ‘normalized’ his grooming and ‘directed’ girls on what to do
articles.summary: Newly released grand jury transcripts in Manhattan detail how Ghislaine Maxwell psychologically groomed and normalized Jeffrey Epstein’s sexual abuse of teenage girls, using a sisterly façade—joking, listening and directing victims to perform foot and breast massages as part of group encounters. Multiple anonymous witnesses recount her casual demeanor during abuse, from joking at the movies to sending lingerie, mirroring trial testimony from survivors like ‘Jane’. The disclosures coincide with Maxwell’s appeal of her 20-year sentence and transfer to a minimum-security camp, prompting skepticism from her brother about the one-sided nature of the filings.

articles.title: US Coast Guard pursuing another oil tanker off coast of Venezuela
articles.trailText: Official indicates vessel is subject to sanctions after Trump’s ‘blockade’ on sanctioned tankers in and out of Venezuela
articles.summary: US Coast Guard launched an active pursuit of the Bella 1, a US-sanctioned tanker under judicial seizure and flying a false flag, in international waters near Venezuela. This marks the second interception over the weekend and third this month under President Trump’s blockade on sanctioned Venezuelan oil shipments. Officials allege ties to Iran. The vessel refused boarding. U.S. military strikes and a beefed-up naval presence—alongside prior seizures on 10 December—aim to choke Maduro’s oil revenue. White House’s Kevin Hassett downplays price impacts; traders foresee upward pressure. Senate Republicans like James Lankford back regime change. Maduro decries U.S. actions as piracy as Trump keeps military options open.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: justice department restores Epstein files image featuring Trump after outcry
articles.trailText: Todd Blanche says removal of images has ‘nothing to do’ with the president, and removal of 16 photos came at request of victim advocacy groups – key US politics stories from Sunday 21 December at a glance
articles.summary: Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche said the DOJ restored an image from the Jeffrey Epstein files that included Donald Trump after removing 16 photos at the request of victim-advocacy groups, not to shield the president. The unexplained Saturday takedown had sparked Democratic accusations of political interference. DOJ concluded the Trump photo posed no harm to survivors and may repost other images after review. Victims’ rights advocates, led by Gloria Allred, criticized under-redaction of names and unclothed photos during the ongoing investigation.

articles.title: Louisiana nursing student speaks out during her six-month ICE detention
articles.trailText: Vilma Palacios, 22, tells local outlet ‘I want my freedom back’ as she may be forced to return to Honduras
articles.summary: Vilma Palacios, 22, an LSU Health New Orleans nursing graduate, has spent six months in ICE’s Basile, LA processing center after her June 26 arrest during a routine vehicle inspection. With no criminal record and an active asylum claim filed in childhood, Palacios was denied bond and faces potential voluntary return to Honduras. She describes despair over the controlled dormitory, lack of personal items and delays accessing hygiene products. DHS asserts her detention is lawful and disputes facility complaints. Family and advocacy groups protest, highlighting her community role amid nursing shortages.

articles.title: US justice department restores photo featuring Trump from Epstein files
articles.trailText: Department says image was flagged by prosecutors before determining it posed no risk to survivors of late sex offender
articles.summary: The DOJ briefly removed then restored a photograph showing Donald Trump from its Jeffrey Epstein investigative file release after New York prosecutors flagged it for possible victim exposure. Democrats accused the department of political interference, while Deputy AG Todd Blanche insisted the pull-down—one of 16—was driven by victim advocacy concerns and that files will return once redaction needs are assessed. Survivor rights attorney Gloria Allred lamented under-redaction of names and images, and a victim’s letter highlighted inconsistencies in identity protections. House Democrats, led by Hakeem Jeffries, argued the partial dump violated the Epstein Files Transparency Act, while Republicans countered that prior releases had been politicized. The dispute over redactions and selective disclosures underscores ongoing partisan battles over full public access to Epstein’s records.

articles.title: Gripes and infighting on display as Maga stars gather at Turning Point conference
articles.trailText: Figures at event include Tucker Carlson, Steve Bannon and Trump Jr as cohesion of political right shows signs of stress
articles.summary: At AmericaFest, a four-day Turning Point USA conference in Phoenix—the first since founder Charlie Kirk’s assassination—right-wing figures from Megyn Kelly to Tucker Carlson, Steve Bannon, Donald Trump Jr., Vivek Ramaswamy, Ben Shapiro and Glenn Beck gathered amid rising infighting. Shapiro blasted Carlson’s hosting of white nationalist Nick Fuentes, sparking backlash from Carlson. Fractures over Israel, “heritage” conservatism and purity tests surfaced. Speakers including Speaker Mike Johnson, Ramaswamy, Kirk’s widow Erika and JD Vance (endorsed for 2028) urged unity over drone-like partisanship. Nicki Minaj made a surprise pro-Trump cameo.

articles.title: The DoJ failed to comply with Epstein files law – can Congress do anything?
articles.trailText: Lawmakers threatening legal action face major obstacle: those with legal power in this case are the ones accused of failing to follow the law
articles.summary: After the DoJ missed a statutory deadline to release all Jeffrey Epstein documents, bipartisan lawmakers led by Reps. Ro Khanna and Thomas Massie threatened contempt citations, court actions to compel disclosure, criminal referrals, and even impeachment against AG Pam Bondi or Deputy Todd Blanche. Legal experts Neama Rahmani and Eric Faddis say Congress could sue and hold officials in contempt, but enforcement depends on a DoJ unwilling to prosecute itself.
