Former prosecutor John Day warns the Transparency Act lacks built-in penalties. The partial release omitted allegedly missing files amid victim-protection claims, fueling bipartisan outrage.

articles.title: Mass power outages black out large parts of San Francisco and disrupt traffic
articles.trailText: Traffic signals failed in large portions of the California city while Waymo robotaxis stopped in streets and intersections
articles.summary: On Dec. 21, a widespread Pacific Gas & Electric blackout plunged about 30% of San Francisco—and roughly 130,000 homes and businesses—into darkness, disabling traffic signals citywide. Waymo confirmed it halted its 2,500-vehicle driverless taxi fleet after videos showed robotaxis frozen at intersections, blocking streets and creating hazards. Mayor Daniel Lurie urged residents to stay off roads while police directed traffic. The incident underscored autonomous vehicles’ dependency on intact infrastructure, revealing how grid failures outside their control can paralyze operations. Waymo, the only paid US robotaxi service without onboard safety drivers, has faced federal scrutiny over unpredictable behavior since launching paid rides in Phoenix in 2020.

articles.title: ‘He shouldn’t be allowed to hide’: the Golden State Killer’s prosecutor on the relentless search for the mass murderer
articles.trailText: Thien Ho considers his book The People vs the Golden State Killer part of a ‘trilogy’ after two books by different authors
articles.summary: In his new book The People vs the Golden State Killer, Sacramento county district attorney Thien Ho recounts the decades-long hunt, capture and 2020 prosecution of Joseph DeAngelo – the former police officer and navy veteran who admitted to 100+ burglaries, 51 rapes and 13 murders across California. Ho details the breakthrough investigative genetic genealogy that led to DeAngelo’s 2018 arrest, his demand to unmask the killer at sentencing, and the emotional testimonies of survivors like Phyllis Henneman, highlighting persistence of law enforcement and victims’ resilience.

articles.title: Ira ‘Ike’ Schab, one of last remaining Pearl Harbor survivors, dies aged 105
articles.trailText: Schab was a 21-year-old navy musician aboard USS Dobbin when Japan carried out surprise attack in 1941
articles.summary: Ira 'Ike' Schab, a Chicago native and one of the last survivors of the 1941 Pearl Harbor attack, died aged 105 at his Oregon home, peacefully listening to swing music. As a 21-year-old Navy musician aboard USS Dobbin, he loaded ammunition for anti-aircraft gunners during Japan’s surprise strike that killed over 2,400 U.S. personnel. After serving across the Pacific, including Vanuatu, the Marianas and Okinawa, he became an electrical engineer on NASA’s Apollo moon missions. Schab attended annual observances to honor fallen shipmates; his son later retired as a Navy commander.

articles.title: Trump does presidency via Truth Social – what are Americans missing out on?
articles.trailText: Since just 3% of Americans use platform Trump owns, public may be unaware of his mental state and performance
articles.summary: On Truth Social, used by only 3% of Americans, President Trump posts frequent policy declarations and erratic content revealing confusion and potential cognitive decline. In early December he posted 158 times in three hours and mistook AI videos as real, e.g., “med bed hospitals.” He spread racist tropes against Somali Americans as “inbred savages” unnoticed by media and launched a widely reported rant about filmmaker Rob Reiner’s death. He misreported the Brown University shooting suspect as in custody then corrected himself. His rants and odd posts, sometimes amplified by mainstream outlets, raise questions about his performance and mental fitness ahead of crucial midterms.

articles.title: Sister of Epstein victim reported him in 1996, but FBI failed to investigate, files reveal
articles.trailText: Maria Farmer, whose sister Annie was abused by Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, says Epstein ‘stole’ nude images
articles.summary: Maria Farmer filed an FBI complaint in 1996 saying Jeffrey Epstein stole nude photos she took of her 12- and 16-year-old sisters, including Annie, and threatened to burn down her house if she spoke out. The newly released file reveals the bureau never acted. Annie Farmer later detailed how Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell groomed and abused her at 16 in New Mexico. Maria, now suing the federal government, says earlier action could have spared hundreds of victims decades of trauma. The FBI declined to comment.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Anger grows about redactions, apparent removal of Epstein files from DoJ website
articles.trailText: Justice department hit with legal threats after authorities release limited, heavily redacted trove of files in apparent violation of Epstein Transparency Act. Key US politics stories from 20 December 2025
articles.summary: Trump’s DOJ faced legal threats after releasing a limited, heavily redacted trove of Jeffrey Epstein files in apparent violation of the Epstein Transparency Act by Khanna and Massie, who warn of impeachment, contempt findings and prosecutions. At least 16 documents were removed from the DOJ site, including one photo of Trump with Epstein, Melania and Maxwell. In related news, US forces intercepted a second oil tanker off Venezuela, Bill Clinton’s team decried scapegoating, and the promised 'golden age' economy shows sluggish jobs growth and rising unemployment.

articles.title: Bill Clinton spokesperson says White House is using him as scapegoat after Epstein files release
articles.trailText: Angel Ureña said ex-president, pictured in some photos released by justice department, cut ties with Epstein in 2005
articles.summary: Bill Clinton’s spokesperson Angel Ureña accused the White House of using Clinton as a scapegoat by releasing DOJ photos of him with Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell—they were cut ties in 2005 before Epstein’s 2008 conviction, she stressed. The grainy images, including Clinton poolside with Maxwell and a dinner with Mick Jagger, were mocked online by White House staff. Epstein visited the White House 17 times under Clinton and flew him post-presidency. Trump allies demand a probe, and Bill and Hillary face House Oversight depositions on January 13–14 or risk contempt.

articles.title: US intercepts second merchant vessel off coast of Venezuela in international waters
articles.trailText: Vessel does not appear to be on list of US-sanctioned vessels, which would represent escalation in blockade
articles.summary: On 20 December, US forces seized a second merchant tanker, the Panama-flagged Centuries, carrying 1.8 million barrels of Venezuelan Merey crude east of Barbados in international waters, despite it not being on the US sanctions list. Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem said the action demonstrates an expanded blockade against oil shipments funding regional narco-terrorism. The move follows a prior Dec.10 seizure of a sanctioned tanker, Donald Trump’s “total and complete” embargo, and refusal to rule out military conflict. Caracas decries “piracy,” Mexico urges UN intervention, while China persists as Venezuela’s top oil buyer.

articles.title: Luigi Mangione lawyers fight death penalty, saying Pam Bondi is biased
articles.trailText: Lawyers also attempting to throw out two federal charges, saying US attorney general has ties to UnitedHealth Group
articles.summary: Lawyers for Luigi Mangione, accused of killing UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson in December 2024, asked an SDNY court on Jan 9 to bar the death penalty and dismiss two federal counts, arguing AG Pam Bondi’s prior lobbying at Ballard Partners—representing UnitedHealth Group—creates a conflict of interest. They highlight her politically charged comments directing DOJ to seek execution and seek to probe her ties to the firm. Prosecutors call the motion repackaged meritless arguments; a state evidentiary ruling is due in May.

articles.title: Brown University shooting suspect died two days before body discovered, autopsy shows
articles.trailText: Suspect’s body was discovered after he allegedly killed an MIT professor and two Brown University students
articles.summary: Autopsy: Claudio Manuel Neves Valente, 48, Portuguese ex-Brown doctoral student accused of killing MIT nuclear physicist Nuno Loureiro and two Brown students, Ella Cook and Mukhammad Aziz Umurzokov, and injuring nine others, died by suicide on Dec 16—two days before his body was found in a Salem, NH, storage locker. A Reddit tip plus matching rental-car sightings in Rhode Island (Florida plates) and Massachusetts (Maine plates) tied him to the shootings. Valente, who studied with Loureiro at Portugal’s Instituto Superior Técnico, had voiced disdain for Brown. His motive remains unclear. The case prompted a US suspension of the green card lottery amid visa disputes.

articles.title: From praise to rage: conservative response to Epstein release is mixed
articles.trailText: Republicans such as Thomas Massie and Marjorie Taylor Greene slam redactions, but others express satisfaction
articles.summary: Conservatives are split over the partial release of Jeffrey Epstein case documents, lauding DOJ transparency while decrying heavy redactions. Marjorie Taylor Greene and Thomas Massie condemned opaque blackouts they say violate Trump’s 30-day deadline, even threatening AG Pam Bondi’s impeachment. Trump loyalists like Laura Loomer and Rogan O’Handley seized on unredacted photos of Bill Clinton, Michael Jackson and Noam Chomsky to weaponize Clinton-Epstein ties. DOJ deputy AG Todd Blanche defended the process as unprecedented openness. Clinton’s spokesperson dismissed blackmail claims, and overall right-wing commentary was more muted than earlier demands for full disclosure.

articles.title: ‘Am I Next?’ protest art in downtown LA boldly asks who’s safe from ICE
articles.trailText: Public exhibition, featuring billboard-sized portraits projected onto buildings, calls attention to Trump administration’s attacks on civil liberties
articles.summary: Am I Next? is a protest art project launched Nov. 6 in downtown Los Angeles by California Community Foundation, LA Plaza Cultura y Artes and the Japanese American National Museum. Each evening, billboard-size black-and-white portraits of Angelenos – including US citizens, immigrant workers and figures like Edward James Olmos, George Takei and Mayor Karen Bass – appear on building facades with stories of those “Taken” by ICE amid a 65,000-person detention surge (74% without convictions). Paralleling Japanese American wartime internment, it invites public submissions and runs indefinitely to expose civil-rights violations.

articles.title: Dollar General agrees to pay $15m to settle price-gouging claims
articles.trailText: Company settles allegations it failed to honor shelf prices in multiple states, and customers anywhere in US may be eligible for repayments
articles.summary: Retailer Dollar General will pay at least $15 million to resolve lawsuits in New Jersey, New York, Oklahoma and South Carolina alleging it charged higher register prices than posted shelf prices at its 20 000 US stores. A concurrent $1.55 million settlement in Pennsylvania follows a probe and a Guardian report revealing over 4 300 failed price-accuracy inspections across 23 states. Pending court approval, nationwide shoppers who document overcharges can claim refunds (starting at $10) or a $3 discount. Dollar General will fund external audits, hire pricing monitors and, if needed, donate excess settlement funds to food banks.

articles.title: Epstein files: which royals, politicians, musicians and actors are in the photos?
articles.trailText: Released images illustrate relationships Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell forged with significant figures
articles.summary: The US Justice Department released thousands of documents and photographs revealing Jeffrey Epstein and accomplice Ghislaine Maxwell alongside high-profile figures. Maxwell, serving 20 years for child sex trafficking, and Epstein, who died awaiting trial, appear with: Prince Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor at Sandringham, Ascot and Balmoral; former president Bill Clinton in a hot tub and pool with Maxwell, Michael Jackson, Diana Ross and Mick Jagger in the late 1990s; ex-ambassador Peter Mandelson celebrating Epstein’s 50th birthday and retaining ties post-2008 conviction; Michael Jackson beside Epstein; Mick Jagger in cocktail attire; and Kevin Spacey in Churchill’s war rooms in 2002. None face allegations.

articles.title: ‘The biggest transformation in a century’: how California remade itself as a clean energy powerhouse
articles.trailText: The Golden State’s clean energy use hit new highs in 2025. As the Trump administration abandons US climate initiatives, can California fill the void?
articles.summary: At COP30, Gov. Newsom positioned California as a global climate leader, touting its grid running on 67% clean energy in 2025 and world-leading battery capacity. Since 2019 the state added 30,800 MW of solar, wind and storage, boosting battery capacity from 771 MW to nearly 17,000 MW to smooth intermittent output. California targets 60% zero-carbon by 2030 and 100% by 2045, with renewables (solar, wind, hydro, geothermal, biomass) and nuclear supplying peaks while natural gas—still 35% of generation—fell 8% in 2024. Facing federal rollbacks under Trump, the state is suing to defend its clean-energy agenda and plans to expand rooftop solar and phase out gas plants.

articles.title: Merry boycotting: US shoppers avoid Trump-aligned businesses amid holiday season
articles.trailText: People are supporting economic boycotts to show discontent with businesses capitulating to Trump’s agenda
articles.summary: In Trump’s second term first holiday season, consumers are targeting businesses seen as capitulating to his anti-DEI and anti-immigration agenda. The No Kings protests coalition’s “We Ain’t Buying It” Black Friday campaign united 220+ groups and drew over 40,000 pledges to skip Target, Home Depot and Amazon. Visits to Little Blue Cart, a progressive small-business directory, hit record highs as shoppers divert spending to local, immigrant-owned or thrift outlets. Parallel boycotts focus on Spotify (ICE ads), Tesla (federal agency cuts) and Starbucks (union disputes). Organizers urge conscious spending via small, local, reused or thrifted purchases and support for institutions resisting administration policies.

articles.title: Outrage and legal threats: Trump justice department slammed after limited Epstein files release
articles.trailText: Lawmakers voice frustration over heavy redactions and the apparent removal of files from government website
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s Justice Department issued a limited, heavily redacted release of Jeffrey Epstein files by the December 19 deadline under the Epstein Files Transparency Act, drawing ire from lawmakers including Reps. Ro Khanna and Thomas Massie, who threaten contempt, impeachment or prosecution. Democrats from AOC to Chuck Schumer and Robert Garcia denounced missing documents—at least 16 files and a Trump photo—calling it a cover-up. DOJ defends its pace and redactions as needed to protect investigations and victims.

articles.title: A new pope, a mayoral victory and a drunk raccoon: Guardian US readers on their favorite news moments of 2025
articles.trailText: There were some bright spots in a year of dark news stories – here are the ones that brought readers the most joy
articles.summary: In a year marked by wildfires, mass layoffs and political turmoil, Guardian US readers celebrated four uplifting moments of 2025: the election of Pope Leo XIV, lauded for his first Sunday plea for peace in Ukraine and Gaza and his migrant-rights critique; the Oscar win for Latvian animated feature Flow—about a flood-stranded cat—that beat major studio blockbusters; Zohran Mamdani’s idealistic New York City mayoral victory; and the viral "drunk raccoon" in a Virginia liquor store, whose Trashed Panda merchandise raised $250,000 for Hanover animal shelter.

articles.title: Caviar bumps, cost jumps: US consumers on how they’re dining in Trump’s economy
articles.trailText: Georgia residents are shopping vastly differently – from food pantries to $300 steak dinners
articles.summary: Eleven months into Trump’s second term, food costs have surged 30%+ across Atlanta, straining low-income families who now double pantry visits amid SNAP cuts, while mid-income residents juggle $200–$500 weekly grocery bills and cautious dining. Refugee entrepreneurs like chef Nizakat Noori are thriving in catering programs but face ingredient inflation and deportation fears. Casual eateries such as Fork in the Road raise prices minimally to stay competitive, while high-end steakhouses and importers of wagyu and caviar report successive markups to offset tariffs. Despite broader belt-tightening, Atlanta’s top 1% continue splurging on luxury dining trends like caviar bumps.

articles.title: ‘We spent $10,000 in four months’: how an emergency car repair can gut a US family’s finances
articles.trailText: A $1,000 fix is out of reach for many Americans – and so is good public transportation
articles.summary: Emergency car repairs costing thousands have left US families teetering: parents in a Guardian-linked WhatsApp group report spending $1,500–$10,000 this year on fixes—from Gabriela Rangel’s flood-ruined engine to Rene Williams’s $10K transmission saga—decimating savings in areas without reliable transit. AAA data show drivers average $1,400 annually, with 64 million Americans going into debt. Strained budgets mean scaled-back holidays, delayed travel and sacrifices to keep cars running.

articles.title: Photos of Andrew reveal how ex-prince gave Jeffrey Epstein access to British high society
articles.trailText: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor reclines across five people in one photo watched by Ghislaine Maxwell at Sandringham
articles.summary: Newly released US DOJ photos from the Epstein files depict Prince Andrew hosting Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell at key British sites—Balmoral, Ascot’s royal box, Sandringham (him reclining across five people’s laps under Maxwell’s gaze), and outside Downing Street—revealing how he facilitated their entrée into high society. Uploaded under the Epstein Files Transparency Act alongside redacted documents, the trove also features Bill Clinton and others. Andrew’s ties to Epstein prompted his 2019 royal exit, loss of titles and a multi-million pound settlement with Virginia Giuffre; Maxwell is serving 20 years and Epstein died in custody.

articles.title: US launches airstrikes against dozens of Islamic State targets in Syria
articles.trailText: Attacks come after two US soldiers and interpreter killed as Trump says US inflicting ‘very serious retaliation’
articles.summary: US military launched Operation Hawkeye Strike—airstrikes on over 70 Islamic State targets across central Syria with Jordanian jet support—after a suspected IS attacker killed two Iowa National Guard soldiers and a civilian interpreter near Palmyra. President Trump hailed “very serious retaliation,” while Syria’s foreign ministry said the strikes were coordinated and urged coalition backing. Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth vowed continued vengeance. The action follows US troops’ 1,000-strong mission, IS’s uptick in attacks and Syria’s recent US-sanction repeal under new rebel-led government.

articles.title: Trickle release of Epstein files on a Friday signals move to bury Trump ties
articles.trailText: The justice department is using a variety of tactics to try to obfuscate the US president’s connection to the sex offender
articles.summary: The Justice Department met a Friday deadline by dumping a few thousand heavily redacted Epstein documents—far fewer than the “hundreds of thousands” promised—burying potentially damaging Trump references. Deputy AG Todd Blanche said more files will trickle out over the holidays, betting public interest will wane. Republicans decried noncompliance with the Epstein Files Transparency Act, while the White House highlighted photos of Bill Clinton and other celebrities to deflect scrutiny. Democrats, including Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, called it a cover-up and urged AG Pam Bondi’s resignation.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Department of Justice releases heavily redacted cache of Epstein files
articles.trailText: Long-awaited tranche of documents is heavily redacted but viewable files include images of Epstein with figures such as Bill Clinton and Michael Jackson – key US politics stories from 19 December 2025
articles.summary: On 19 December 2025, the Department of Justice published a heavily redacted 2006 Epstein investigation cache showing images of him with Bill Clinton, Michael Jackson, Ghislaine Maxwell and royalty, prompting Democratic complaints over withheld victim identities under the Epstein Files Transparency Act. Other updates include US airstrikes on ISIS in Syria, FBI domestic terrorism probes into anti-ICE activists, a Trump-brokered drugmaker deal to cut Medicaid drug prices, migrant child deportation pressures, Venezuela war threats, a TikTok-Oracle joint venture, Kennedy Center renaming, RFK Jr’s anti-vaccine group defense, Alliance Defending Freedom’s global litigation push and a new Hispanic bishop in Florida.

articles.title: US justice department releases heavily redacted cache of Jeffrey Epstein files
articles.trailText: Photos included in tranche of documents as Democrats accuse Trump officials of failing to comply with law
articles.summary: DoJ released redacted files on 2006 Epstein investigations, including photos of him with celebrities Michael Jackson, Diana Ross, Richard Branson, Bill Clinton in a pool with Ghislaine Maxwell, and British royal Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor. Deputy AG Todd Blanche says more documents will roll out; redactions shield identities of over 1,200 victims. Democrats Khanna and Schumer, and GOP Rep. Massie claim noncompliance with the Epstein Files Transparency Act’s mandate to publish all unclassified records. The White House says the release shows Trump’s transparency. Exemptions cover active investigations; a detailed redaction report is due within 15 days.

articles.title: Survivors of Epstein’s abuse condemn justice department for only partly releasing files
articles.trailText: Lawyers for victims say they have been ‘repeatedly denied justice’ while deputy attorney general says more files will be released
articles.summary: Survivors of Jeffrey Epstein’s abuse and their lawyers condemned the DOJ’s partial release of investigative files under the Epstein Files Transparency Act, calling it a continuation of years-long delays and obfuscations. Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche said additional documents will follow, while lawmakers threaten legal action over alleged violations of federal law. Attorneys Spencer Kuvin and Gloria Allred decried possible cover-ups protecting powerful enablers. Epstein survivor Maria Farmer hailed confirmation of her 1996 FBI complaint as both redemption and a tragedy for victims denied timely justice.

articles.title: Trump over-promises and under-delivers with heavily redacted Epstein cache
articles.trailText: ‘Most transparent’ administration has slow-walked and stonewalled – the incomplete release smells of a cover-up
articles.summary: After global anticipation, the DOJ under Trump released ‘The Epstein Files: Phase 1’—hundreds of thousands of pages but mostly blacked out, offering no new details on Trump despite his well-known ties, while featuring photos of Bill Clinton. Critics from Norm Eisen to Senators Schumer and Merkley call it over-redacted, legally noncompliant and a cover-up. The administration missed its own deadline, promising additional documents later, and Trump refused on-the-spot questions. The slow-walk undermines his ‘most transparent’ claim, fuels conspiracy theories and draws only 44% GOP approval.

articles.title: FBI notes detail grim demands Epstein made for procurement of underage girls
articles.trailText: Interview from 2019 reveals specific preferences for recruitment, including age and race
articles.summary: DoJ released FBI evidence cover sheet EFTA00004179 and 13 pages of May 2 2019 interview notes revealing Jeffrey Epstein’s demands for underage girls under the guise of “massages.” The redacted witness describes his precise preferences—girls aged 14–17 by race (“dark-skinned Dominican” but “not Spanish or dark”), ID checks to confirm under 18 and “rough” sexual encounters. Photos depict minors in bikinis near NYC and Rochester sites. Notes align with known Brazilian victims like Marina Lacerda. These documents from the Trump DOJ follow Epstein’s 2019 jail death and precede related arrests including Jean-Luc Brunel’s 2022 suicide in Paris.

articles.title: Elise Stefanik ends bid for New York governor and plans to leave Congress
articles.trailText: Trump-allied Republican said attempting to unseat Democrat Kathy Hochul ‘is not an effective use of our time’
articles.summary: Rep. Elise Stefanik, a Trump-aligned ultra-MAGA Republican, has ended her New York governor campaign and will not seek reelection to Congress, citing the futility of a drawn-out primary and daunting Democratic majority in the state. Once a GOP gubernatorial frontrunner, her bid was complicated by Nassau County exec Bruce Blakeman’s entry; party chair Ed Cox endorsed Blakeman. Stefanik will complete her term in the House, where she frequently clashed with Speaker Mike Johnson. Earlier this year, her UN ambassadorship nomination was suspended amid concerns over the chamber’s narrow GOP majority.

articles.title: US legislators say justice department is violating law by not releasing all Epstein files
articles.trailText: Todd Blanche, deputy attorney general, says release of files won’t include full set, prompting outrage from lawmakers
articles.summary: DOJ released some but not all files on Jeffrey Epstein, drawing swift rebuke from lawmakers. Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche said hundreds of thousands of documents—photos and investigative materials—were released Friday, with similar batches to follow to protect victims. Top legislators, including Reps. Robert Garcia, Jamie Raskin and Thomas Massie, and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, threatened legal action under the Epstein Files Transparency Act, which mandated all unclassified records within 30 days. Survivor counsel Jennifer Freeman criticized the partial release and urged complete disclosure. Legal scholar Ryan Goodman also called it a violation. Freeman noted survivors like Maria Farmer have waited decades for their records.

articles.title: Investigators seek motive for shootings of MIT professor and Brown students
articles.trailText: Suspect Claudio Manuel Neves Valente was found dead in New Hampshire storage facility after five-day manhunt
articles.summary: Investigators are probing the motive behind the killings of two Brown engineering students and MIT physics professor Nuno FG Loureiro by Claudio Manuel Neves Valente, 48, a Portuguese ex-Brown grad student. After a December 14 mass shooting at Brown’s Barus and Holley building (2 dead, 9 wounded), Neves Valente drove to Brookline and fatally shot Loureiro, his former classmate from Portugal’s Instituto Superior Técnico. Found dead in a New Hampshire storage unit with a rental Nissan and weapons, authorities credit a Reddit tipster for tracing his vehicle and still seek a clear motive.

articles.title: Congress members demand answers on price disparities at dollar-store chains
articles.trailText: A letter from 30 lawmakers criticizes recurring overcharges at Dollar General and Family Dollar stores – questioning ‘how seriously’ the companies prioritize ethics and affordability
articles.summary: Thirty Democrats led by Rep. Nikki Budzinski wrote to Dollar General and Family Dollar CEOs demanding four years of internal documents after The Guardian found over 6,400 price-accuracy violations across 28,000 US stores since 2022. They highlight systemic shelf-register price disparities—like $10.99 paper towels rang up at $15.50—amid an affordability crisis. The letter also challenges forced arbitration clauses in apps and seeks revenue data from overcharges and restitution plans. Budzinski warns rural shoppers have no alternative retailers. The lawmakers suggest federal enforcement to standardize price-accuracy protections. Both chains have yet to fully respond.

articles.title: Trump and top aides refuse to rule out war with Venezuela
articles.trailText: President Nicolás Maduro orders Venezuelan navy to escort oil tankers after seizure by US forces
articles.summary: President Trump told NBC he won’t rule out war with Venezuela as Nicolás Maduro orders his navy to escort oil tankers amid the largest US fleet in decades. At the State Department, Senator Marco Rubio affirmed the right to use “every element of national power” to defend US interests, hinting at regime change. US forces recently seized a sanctioned tanker, disrupting Maduro’s “dark fleet”—many vessels are now diverting to the Indian Ocean or trapped in blockade zones, cutting key oil revenues. Experts say the blockade raises prospects of unseating Maduro by starving his government.

articles.title: Judge accused of helping immigrant dodge ICE agents found guilty of obstruction
articles.trailText: Wisconsin judge Hannah Dugan was arrested by the FBI and charged in April amid Trump’s immigration crackdown
articles.summary: Milwaukee County circuit judge Hannah Dugan was convicted of felony obstruction for misleading federal agents and guiding Mexican national Eduardo Flores Ruiz through a private exit to avoid an April ICE arrest at her courthouse. Acquitted of a related misdemeanor, she faces up to five years and plans to appeal. Flores Ruiz was deported after serving time for illegal entry. The trial highlighted Trump’s immigration policies, spurred advocacy groups’ constitutional concerns, and led to calls for her impeachment under Wisconsin law.

articles.title: Unaccompanied children being pressed to return to their countries by US border officials
articles.trailText: Exclusive: federal document reveals children arriving as undocumented immigrants being threatened with detention
articles.summary: A newly disclosed CBP “advisal” warns unaccompanied children that seeking an immigration hearing or expressing fear of return will lead to prolonged detention, sponsor arrest or deportation, and ICE custody if they turn 18 in government custody. It dangling a “voluntary return” option with no administrative penalty but falsely promising future visa eligibility. Senator Ron Wyden condemns the coercive policy as exploiting vulnerable minors; the National Immigrant Justice Center and allied groups have sued DHS over child detention practices.

articles.title: Tipster hailed for helping authorities identify suspect in Brown shooting
articles.trailText: Man known as ‘John’ expected to be eligible for $50,000 reward from FBI for providing details on the suspect
articles.summary: Authorities praised a tipster known as “John,” a Brown graduate, for providing key details—via Reddit and by alerting police (“I think you are looking for me”)—that led to identifying suspect Claudio Neves Valente. John’s observations of Valente’s odd behavior around a rented gray Nissan with Florida plates helped corroborate disparate clues. Providence Mayor Brett Smiley called his cooperation a “critical turning point,” enabling investigators to link Valente to the Brown University mass shooting and the MIT professor’s killing. Now eligible for the FBI’s $50,000 reward, John risked personal safety after surveillance images were released.

articles.title: Epstein files to be released after months of delays from Trump officials
articles.trailText: Huge archive – set to shed fresh light on Epstein’s misdeeds – legally obliged to be released before midnight deadline
articles.summary: By midnight Friday, per the Epstein Files Transparency Act passed over White House objections, the DOJ must publish all unclassified records related to Epstein and his network. After months of MAGA fracturing over Trump’s prior refusal, the president signed the act into law. Deputy AG Todd Blanche said today’s initial release will comprise several hundred thousand documents—photos, files from federal probes—with similar volumes to follow. Sponsors Ro Khanna and Thomas Massie warn that Pam Bondi or any official who redacts, withholds or tampers faces prosecution or contempt. Oversight Democrats published 68 estate images, raising concerns over completeness and redactions of victim identities and classified materials.

articles.title: Conservative legal group aims to export its rightwing Christian mission beyond US borders
articles.trailText: Alliance Defending Freedom has ramped up its global spending on litigation and other campaigns to push its ultra-conservative Christian values
articles.summary: Alliance Defending Freedom and ADF International boosted global legal spending to $10.9m in 2024 (70% rise in Europe) to export ultra-conservative Christian values. Led by Kristen Waggoner, they claim 39 ECHR and 282 national court victories, backing cases from Finnish MP Päivi Räsänen’s LGBT-speech trial to Nigeria’s blasphemy defendant and UK anti-abortion buffer-zone protests. Critics warn ADF weaponizes religious freedom to curb women’s, LGBTQ+ rights and influence elections, urging restrictions on foreign funding and judicial integrity.

articles.title: Trump’s EPA wants to weaken formaldehyde protections – this is what it could mean
articles.trailText: EPA proposed undoing Biden-era policy on exposure to carcinogenic toxin in latest push to weaken toxin standards
articles.summary: Trump’s EPA aims to raise allowable formaldehyde exposure limits, reversing Biden-era findings that even minimal exposure poses cancer and other health risks. Led by industry appointees from the American Chemistry Council, the proposal rescinds risk determinations in five scenarios, weakens restrictions in 53 more, and adopts a threshold-based cancer assessment favored by chemical manufacturers. Critics warn that higher “safe” levels will prolong exposure from everyday products—furniture, textiles, cosmetics—undermining safeguards against a known carcinogen. Environmental groups say the rollback could increase cancer, respiratory and reproductive harms by ignoring cumulative exposures from consumer and workplace sources.

articles.title: Revealed: how Toyota uses retro-style games and prizes to urge US workers to lobby politicians
articles.trailText: Games such as Dragon Quest used to mobilize workers to back corporate goals including relaxing environmental rules
articles.summary: The Guardian reveals Toyota’s internal platform, Toyota Policy Drivers, uses retro‐style games (Star Quest, Adventure Quest, Dragon Quest, Monster Mansion) to reward US employees across manufacturing, finance and sales for lobbying federal and state lawmakers. Staff earn points by listening to pro-Toyota policy briefings, taking quizzes, sending scripted letters to Congress and opposing Biden‐era tailpipe rules or California’s 2035 gas-car ban. Rewards range from stickers and T-shirts to trips. Critics call the gamified program “Orwellian” greenwashing, noting Toyota’s heavy diesel and hybrid lobbying, $1 million Trump inauguration gift and status as a top climate policy adversary despite pledges to reach net-zero by 2050.

articles.title: First Thing: Brown University shooting suspect died from self-inflicted gunshot wound, officials say
articles.trailText: Claudio Neves Valente, who was found dead in a storage facility, also killed an MIT professor. Plus, what will your life look like in 2035?
articles.summary: Claudio Neves Valente, 48, a former Brown University student, killed two and wounded nine on campus, then fatally shot MIT physics professor Nuno F.G. Loureiro in his home. Providence police found Valente dead of a self-inflicted gunshot in a New Hampshire storage unit; investigators believe he acted alone. Homeland Security suspended the green card lottery at President Trump’s direction, citing Valente’s entry route. Elsewhere, EU leaders approved a €90 billion loan to Ukraine, the US prepares to release long-delayed Jeffrey Epstein files, and TikTok agreed to sell its US business to Oracle, Silver Lake and MGX.

articles.title: Revealed: FBI opened domestic terrorism investigations into anti-ICE activity across US
articles.trailText: Internal report shared with Guardian shows FBI has launched cases in 23 regions, some linked to Trump memo on thwarting ‘terroristic activities’
articles.summary: An internal FBI report dated November 14 discloses that the bureau has opened criminal and domestic terrorism investigations into anti-ICE threats across 23 field office regions, linking some cases to Trump’s September NSPM-7 memo on countering domestic terrorism. The report highlights an escalation from property damage to violent attacks—citing Texas ICE facility bombings, fireworks assaults and a Dallas office shooting—flags indicators like arms stockpiling, encrypted communications and First Amendment–protected research, and warns broader civil liberties risks as rights advocates decry the memo’s vague language.

articles.title: Why did Donald Trump Jr turn up in a tiny British enclave looking for money?
articles.trailText: Meetings in Gibraltar are the latest twist in worldwide campaign that is enriching the US president’s family
articles.summary: In November, Donald Trump Jr. flew to Gibraltar—home to an AI data-centre and crypto firms—to pitch investment in the Trump family’s ventures, including the Maga-aligned 1789 Capital ‘patriotic capitalism’ fund. Meeting at top law firm Hassans with local powerbroker James Levy and Chief Minister Fabian Picardo, Don Jr. solicited funds for real-estate and tech deals, part of a global moneymaking tour that critics say blurs his father’s public duties with private profit and risks conflicts of interest.

articles.title: Trump suspends US green card lottery in wake of Brown University and MIT shootings
articles.trailText: Homeland security secretary Kristi Noem pauses high-profile visa program, saying shooting suspect Claudio Neves Valente gained green card in 2017
articles.summary: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem, at Trump’s direction, suspended the DV-1 green card lottery, blaming it for allowing Brown University/MIT shooting suspect Claudio Neves Valente—who entered on a student visa in 2000 and secured a 2017 diversity visa—to gain residency. Valente died by suicide after the December attacks. Trump, a longtime lottery opponent, framed the move as part of tougher immigration policy, mirroring past responses to isolated crimes. The program had offered up to 50,000 annual visas from roughly 20 million applicants, with nearly 131,000 selections including spouses, all subject to vetting.

articles.title: Brown University shooting suspect died from self-inflicted gunshot wound, officials say
articles.trailText: Claudio Neves Valente, who was found dead in storage facility, also killed MIT professor at his Boston-area home
articles.summary: Claudio Neves Valente, 48, a Portuguese former Brown physics graduate student, died by a self-inflicted gunshot in a New Hampshire storage facility on Thursday, ending the three-day manhunt. Valente is accused of Saturday’s Brown University shooting that killed two—sophomore Ella Cook and first-year MukhammadAziz Umurzokov—and injured nine, and of fatally shooting MIT physics professor Nuno F.G. Loureiro at his Boston-area home on Monday. Investigators, led by Providence PD Chief Oscar Perez and RI AG Peter Neronha, traced Valente via a tipster, rental records and swapped license plates. No accomplices have been identified.

articles.title: Noise machines installed by LA Home Depot ‘torture’ for day laborers, advocates say
articles.trailText: Advocates call for removal of machines and demand that company speak out against ICE raids in parking lots
articles.summary: At its Cypress Park, Los Angeles store, Home Depot installed three high-frequency noise machines under a highway overpass on Caltrans land allegedly to deter day laborers from seeking work, causing headaches and nausea. Advocates from IDEPSCA and Councilwoman Eunisses Hernandez denounce the devices as torture, demand their removal and for Home Depot to oppose ICE raids in parking lots, where agents have detained about 50 workers this year and once removed a toddler. Home Depot calls the machines a ‘safety initiative’ to curb illegal overnight parking and denies involvement with immigration enforcement.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: anticipation high as clock ticks on release of all Epstein files
articles.trailText: Latest batch includes photos of famous people in Epstein’s orbit, copies of foreign passports and screenshot of text messages – key US politics stories from 18 December 2025
articles.summary: On Dec 19, DOJ must publish all Jeffrey Epstein investigation files by Friday; House Democrats released photos linking Epstein to figures including Bill Gates and Noam Chomsky. Meanwhile, the Kennedy Center board is weighing renaming to the Trump-Kennedy Center. Federal CPI rose 2.7% year-on-year versus Trump’s claims. HHS/Medicare to ban gender-affirming care for minors. The $1,776 “warrior dividend” for troops stems from housing aid. Trump reclassified marijuana out of Schedule I. Trump Media plans a $6bn merger with fusion firm TAE; an Oracle-led group will take over TikTok US. White House dismisses talk of a constitutionally barred third Trump term.

articles.title: Democrats release new Epstein photos ahead of DoJ transparency deadline
articles.trailText: Images, undated and uncaptioned, include lines from Lolita written on woman’s body and show Bill Gates and Noam Chomsky
articles.summary: House oversight Democrats released an uncaptioned batch of undated photos from Jeffrey Epstein’s estate—Lolita passages written on women’s bodies, images of Bill Gates, Noam Chomsky, Woody Allen, Steve Bannon and David Brooks, redacted passports and texts about sourcing women—to ratchet up pressure on DOJ as the November-signed Epstein Files Transparency Act demands file release within 48 hours. Justice Department lawyers, given only four pages of redaction guidance, are racing to process thousands of documents, raising over-redaction concerns. Meanwhile, Ghislaine Maxwell filed a pro se habeas petition citing newly disclosed evidence to challenge her conviction.

articles.title: Kennedy Center board votes to add Trump’s name to DC arts institution
articles.trailText: Joe Kennedy III, JFK’s grandnephew, said he doubted the Trump-Kennedy Center name change was legal
articles.summary: The Kennedy Center’s board of trustees, now chaired by Donald Trump following a board purge, voted unanimously to rename the institution the Trump-Kennedy Center, crediting Trump with rescuing it financially and structurally. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt hailed Trump’s “unbelievable work” rebuilding and funding the landmark arts venue. Joe Kennedy III argued the change may violate federal law designating the center as a memorial to JFK, and ex-officio board member Rep. Joyce Beatty said she was muted and barred from objecting. Critics note a statute forbids new memorials while the administration advances further renamings and cultural overhauls.

articles.title: Trump’s $1,776 ‘warrior dividend’ repurposed from military housing aid
articles.trailText: President claims bonus the result of tariff revenue but stipend had already been approved in tax-and-spend bill
articles.summary: President Trump’s promised $1,776 “warrior dividend” for 1.45m military personnel—heralded as tariff-funded—will actually draw on repurposed military housing aid approved in the One Big Beautiful Bill Act. Trump misattributes the payout to record 16.8% average tariffs (hitting households about $1,700). The $2.5bn bonus’s timing, taxable status, eligibility (active duty vs guard/reserves) and pay impact remain uncertain as the Supreme Court weighs tariff refunds. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth says it’s tax-free and incoming.

articles.title: ICE meets snow as midwesterners fight back against Trump immigration raids
articles.trailText: Videos show people in Minnesota and Illinois throwing snowballs at federal agents trying to arrest residents
articles.summary: Amid a surge of ICE immigration raids in Minnesota and Illinois, neighbors have begun pelleting federal agents with snowballs to disrupt arrests, according to videos from Minneapolis and Elgin. In one clip, agents dragging a partially handcuffed woman through a snowbank faced a barrage of snow and car-horn protests before responding with pepper spray and a Taser. Minneapolis Police Chief Brian O’Hara criticized ICE’s tactics as overly aggressive, and the ACLU of Minnesota has sued DHS for rights violations. Legal experts warn snowball-throwing at officers can constitute a federal felony, exposing participants to steep penalties.

articles.title: Trump signs order reclassifying marijuana as less dangerous
articles.trailText: Change will loosen limits on research and certain regulations but stops short of making marijuana legal
articles.summary: President Trump signed an executive order downgrading cannabis from Schedule I to Schedule III, citing medical benefits and easing research constraints. The move allows DEA rulemaking, a Medicare reimbursement pilot for CBD products, reduced federal tax penalties for hemp companies, and better banking access, but stops short of legalizing recreational use or changing arrest procedures. The order tasks HHS with real-world studies on long-term health effects and directs collaboration with Congress to broaden access to full-spectrum CBD while curbing unapproved risky products. Critics applaud medical validation but warn it falls short of full reform.

articles.title: Pope’s naming of New York archbishop signals continued challenge to Trump on immigration
articles.trailText: Ronald Hicks, who endorsed message condemning ICE raids, to lead one of biggest US archdioceses
articles.summary: Pope Leo XIV has tapped 58-year-old Ronald Hicks, currently bishop of Joliet, Illinois, to succeed Cardinal Timothy Dolan as archbishop of New York, overseeing 2.5 million Catholics in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island. A Chicago native with missionary stints in Peru and a five-year term running an orphanage in El Salvador, Hicks recently backed a US bishops’ statement condemning Trump administration ICE raids and criticizing immigration policies as “inhuman.” At his introductory news conference he emphasized preventing abuse and supporting survivors alongside advancing church accountability, transparency and healing. The appointment signals continuity in the Vatican’s challenge to Washington on immigration.

articles.title: Deadline nears for release of Epstein files – what we know so far
articles.trailText: Justice department must release most documents by the end of Friday, and failure to do so would provoke a firestorm
articles.summary: Less than 48 hours remain for the DOJ to comply with the Epstein Files Transparency Act, passed by Congress and signed by President Trump on November 19. By Dec. 19, the department must disclose most records on Jeffrey Epstein—civil litigation papers, grand jury testimony, flight logs, victims’ statements and associates’ names—unless they imperil ongoing investigations, national security or victim privacy. After months of silence from AG Pam Bondi and a failed 2025 DOJ memo denying a client list, lawmakers threaten to block nominees if the deadline is missed, risking a political firestorm.

articles.title: New York Times columnist David Brooks appears in latest Epstein photos
articles.trailText: Brooks, who dismissed Epstein scandal as ‘stupid story’, wrote column expressing lack of interest in developments
articles.summary: Photos released by the House Oversight Committee show New York Times columnist David Brooks at a 2011 dinner at Jeffrey Epstein’s estate, seated beside Google co-founder Sergey Brin. Brooks, who in November dismissed the scandal as a “stupid story” and compared public fixation on Epstein to QAnon conspiracies, did not disclose his attendance when criticizing the coverage. The Times says this was his only contact with Epstein. The committee also published images of Bill Gates, Woody Allen and Noam Chomsky, prompting questions about transparency given Brooks’s earlier columns.

articles.title: Trump administration unveils plans to end gender-affirming care for minors
articles.trailText: Proposal would ban use of Medicaid funds to cover puberty blockers, hormone treatments or surgical procedures
articles.summary: On Dec 18, HHS Secretary RFK Jr announced a proposal blocking Medicare/Medicaid hospitals from providing puberty blockers, hormone therapy or surgery to minors and banning Medicaid/CHIP coverage for gender-affirming care, labeling it “sex-rejecting procedures.” FDA will warn 12 breast binder manufacturers. HHS seeks to remove gender dysphoria as a disability under Sec.504 and cut AAP grants. Medical groups, LGBTQ+ advocates and Democratic AG James condemn the move. House also passed GOP bills to criminalize or defund care; Senate approval unlikely.

articles.title: Trump critics praise Vanity Fair article for its scrutiny of his officials – and unsparing photos
articles.trailText: Susie Wiles spoke candidly about Trump’s inner circle and the piece made even bigger waves for its photos
articles.summary: Vanity Fair’s deep-dive with White House chief of staff Susie Wiles combined candid criticism of Trump’s inner circle—calling the president “an alcoholic,” VP JD Vance a “conspiracy theorist” and budget director Russell Vought a “right-wing zealot”—with dramatic, unretouched portraits by Christopher Anderson. Advocates praised the overdue scrutiny and raw visuals; Trump allies decried a “hit piece” and photo manipulation. Anderson and VF countered that no blemishes were airbrushed, insisting the images truthfully captured their subjects. Social media reactions ranged from admiration for the photographer’s bold style to accusations of a smear campaign.

articles.title: Democrats won’t release 2024 election loss ‘autopsy’, DNC chair says
articles.trailText: Report on Kamala Harris’s loss to Trump would be a ‘distraction’ as party is ‘putting our learnings into motion’
articles.summary: Ken Martin, DNC chair, says the 2024 election autopsy—an internal review interviewing stakeholders across all 50 states on presidential and down-ballot races—is complete but won’t be released publicly to avoid distracting from 2025 midterm efforts. The report identifies lessons in organizing, communications, fundraising and spending—Democrats outspent Republicans at every level—but strategic focus will shift to implementation rather than commentary. Speculation that it sidestepped questions about Biden’s candidacy and Harris’s role contrasts with RootsAction’s autopsy, which argued Harris prioritized moderates over mobilizing the progressive base.

articles.title: ‘They tricked me’: Migrants were promised $1,000 to voluntarily leave the US. Some never received it
articles.trailText: People who signed up for a US ‘self-deportation’ scheme say their payoffs were delayed, misdirected or never arrived – leaving them empty-handed in their home countries
articles.summary: Germán Pineda and dozens of migrants across Honduras, Nicaragua, El Salvador and Peru signed voluntary departure forms under DHS’s Trump-era Project Homecoming, lured by free flights and a $1,000 exit bonus. Many endured months in ICE custody, then never received payments due to wire errors, ineligibility misclassification or administrative chaos. Managed by Soterex Financial Services and funded from a repurposed $250 million refugee pot, the scheme offers no guaranteed legal return and imposes multi-year bans, raising coercion, transparency and contract-award concerns.

articles.title: White House says US would be ‘lucky’ if Trump stayed for third term
articles.trailText: Comments follow reports that US president discussed idea with constitutional scholar Alan Dershowitz
articles.summary: White House spokeswoman Abigail Jackson said America would be ‘lucky’ if Donald Trump served a constitutionally banned third term, responding to Alan Dershowitz’s claim that the 22nd Amendment is ‘not clear.’ In his forthcoming book, Dershowitz explores electoral-college abstention or House selection as loopholes. Trump finds the idea intellectually intriguing but likely won’t run. Despite plunging approval, mixed signals persist: allies Mike Johnson and Susie Wiles dismiss a third bid, while billionaire donors like Miriam Adelson and Trump’s 2028 merchandise keep the prospect alive.

articles.title: Man sues Tennessee county after he was jailed over meme related to Charlie Kirk killing
articles.trailText: Lawsuit alleges that Larry Bushart’s first amendment rights were violated when he was arrested and jailed for 37 days
articles.summary: Former Perry County, Tennessee, officer Larry Bushart, 61, spent 37 days jailed on a $2 million bond after sharing on Facebook a meme linking Trump’s “we have to get over it” remark on the 2024 Iowa school shooting to a Charlie Kirk vigil. Authorities misinterpreted it as a threat to Perry County High School; charges were dropped in October. With help from FIRE, Bushart is suing the sheriff, county and investigator for First and Fourth Amendment violations, seeking compensatory and punitive damages and lost wages.

articles.title: Inside DoJ’s controversial prosecution of a Texas ‘antifa cell’ charged with terrorism
articles.trailText: DoJ says a group of protesters at an ICE detention center was part of a terror cell; legal experts say case is an effort to crack down on leftwing groups and deter protesters
articles.summary: Following Trump’s vow to crack down on leftwing protesters, the DOJ in October brought unprecedented terrorism charges against 18 Texas activists labeled a ‘North Texas antifa cell’ after a July 4 noise demonstration at the Prairieland ICE detention center. Prosecutors allege they plotted an attack—citing all-black gear, encrypted Signal chats, zines and site scouting—and say two ICE officers and a police officer were shot. Fifteen face material support for terrorism plus rioting, explosives, firearms and attempted murder counts. Legal experts and defense lawyers warn this marks a dangerous expansion of domestic terrorism statutes to silence dissent.

articles.title: Ordinary Americans are fighting back against ICE: ‘We’re going to outlast them’
articles.trailText: As Trump carries out his mass deportation operation, residents are banding together to block raids and distribute groceries
articles.summary: Under Trump’s mass deportation drive—300,000 removed, 65,000 detained—communities from Chicago to Los Angeles have banded together to counter ICE raids. Chicago’s Protect Rogers Park rapid responders chase agents by bike and sound whistles; a local fetish shop donated 400 whistles. In LA, public health student Miguel Montes delivered groceries to 1,500 families via Raíces Con Voz. Maryland parents run “walking school buses” to escort Latino children. In New York, Mi Tlalli court watchers provide mutual aid, sending $50 weekly to 300 detainees and supporting 3,000 contacts. Organizers use encrypted Signal chats, trainings and assemblies to build solidarity and “outlast” ICE.

articles.title: CDC officials urge US flu vaccination after record child deaths last year
articles.trailText: Americans told ‘time to get vaccinated is now’ as concerning mutation of influenza virus circulates in US
articles.summary: CDC urges immediate flu vaccination and antiviral treatment as US influenza activity rises and a concerning H3N2 subclade K circulates. Last season saw record 288 pediatric deaths, 610K–1.3M hospitalizations, and 109 encephalopathy cases (74% ICU, 19% fatal) amid only 16% vaccination among eligible children. Officials removed thimerosal from endorsed flu shots, face FDA approval changes potentially limiting annual vaccine trials, and combat misinformation from HHS leadership. Early UK data show 70–75% vaccine effectiveness in children, 30–40% in adults, underscoring vaccines’ role in preventing hospitalization and death.

articles.title: ‘We wanted to take action’: US toy company fights back over Trump tariffs
articles.trailText: Learning Resources is suing the administration, claiming the president’s tariffs are illegal ��� and millions of dollars are on the line
articles.summary: Learning Resources, a family-owned educational toy maker with 500 employees and a 364,000 sq ft warehouse outside Chicago, is suing the Trump administration (Learning Resources v. Trump) in the Supreme Court, challenging IEEPA-based tariffs. The company paid $2 m in 2024 and faces $14 m in new levies this year, disrupted supply chains—eg, moving BubblePlush production to India only to incur an extra $50 k when rates spiked. Seeking refunds, it argues only Congress can levy taxes. Tariff volatility has forced hiring freezes, product delays and pre-buys, underscoring the high cost of reshoring.

articles.title: This student group agrees US universities are too elitist – but aims to transform, not destroy them
articles.trailText: Class Action, a grassroots network formed after the affirmative action ruling, seeks to be critical of universities in their current form
articles.summary: Class Action, a grassroots student network founded in 2023 after the Supreme Court’s affirmative action ruling, critiques the elitism of US universities and seeks transformative reform rather than dismantling them. Spearheaded by Yale senior Emily Hettinger and Stanford alumnus Ryan Cieslikowski with adviser Evan Mandery, it has held a Yale conference of 300 students, conducted a nationwide listening tour, and is drafting an “academic social contract” to realign university wealth, governance and mission with the public good. Campaign victories include California’s ban on legacy admissions, and on 76 campuses members push to diversify career services and steer graduates toward public-interest roles. Class Action now builds formal chapters to defend academic freedom, expand student representation on boards, and foster inclusive coalitions that bridge societal divides.

articles.title: ‘Uniquely evil’: Michigan residents fight against huge datacenter backed by top tycoons
articles.trailText: Locals band together in David v Goliath fight against facility they say would jack up bills, increase pollution and destroy area’s character
articles.summary: In rural Saline Township, Michigan, a broad coalition of residents has mobilized against the $7 billion, 1.4 GW “Stargate” datacenter backed by Donald Trump, Sam Altman, Larry Ellison, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, DTE Energy and developer Related Co. Locals warn the facility would hike energy bills, pollute groundwater, erode the township’s bucolic character and undermine state renewable targets. After trustees initially rejected the plan, Related Digital sued and the board reversed. Opponents, joined by the Michigan attorney general, Sierra Club and former legislator Yousef Rabhi, are pressing the MPSC to require a full contested review of costs and environmental risks.

articles.title: First Thing: US military announces strike on Pacific boat that kills four, taking death toll to 99
articles.trailText: UN condemns strikes as extrajudicial executions. Plus, Trump’s end-of-year ‘Bah! Humbug!’ address
articles.summary: US defense secretary Pete Hegseth announced another lethal strike on an alleged drug-trafficking vessel in the eastern Pacific, killing four and raising the campaign’s death toll to 99 since September. Critics, including the UN, Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch, condemn the strikes as extrajudicial executions, citing no public evidence and a Colombian family’s petition to the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights over a September bombing. Elsewhere, Donald Trump’s frosty end-of-year “Bah! Humbug!” address blamed Biden, trade deals and immigrants as his approval slides.

articles.title: Americans’ view on their mental health at record low, according to new poll
articles.trailText: Drop is cause for public health concern, but news isn’t all bad as acknowledging struggles is ‘a good sign’, experts say
articles.summary: A West Health–Gallup poll finds just under 30% of Americans now rate their mental health “excellent,” and 72% rate it “good” or “excellent,” both record lows since the Covid-19 era (pre-2020 levels were 42% “excellent”). Experts attribute the drop partly to increased openness about psychiatric struggles—diagnoses of anxiety, depression, bipolar disorder and ADHD have surged since 2019 (Fair Health data)—and partly to pandemic trauma, political/economic uncertainty and social disconnection. Self-ratings fell most sharply among college graduates and Republicans, narrowing historical gaps and signaling broad, shared distress alongside growing willingness to acknowledge mental health issues.

articles.title: Trump’s ‘Bah! Humbug!’ address suggests he is feeling the chill of opinion polls
articles.trailText: Primetime speech – delivered with shouty spirit but no cheer – betrayed a figure dogged by a cost of living crisis and the looming release of the Epstein files
articles.summary: Surrounded by Christmas decorations in a 20-minute “Bah! Humbug!” primetime address, Trump channeled Ebenezer Scrooge, railing against Biden, immigrants and “woke radicals” amid a cost-of-living crisis and looming Epstein files. He falsely claimed 48-year high inflation under Biden, touted a sharp drop in gas prices, and announced a $1,776 “warrior dividend” for service members funded by tariffs. Monotone and shouty, he blamed trade deals and a “corrupt system,” revealing desperation over 33% economic approval, Republican dissent and the search for new political foes.

articles.title: US strike on alleged drug boat in Pacific kills four, as Trump accuses Venezuela of taking ‘our oil’
articles.trailText: Hegseth announcement comes day after Trump blockades all sanctioned oil tankers entering and leaving Venezuela
articles.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced a lethal strike on a suspected narco-trafficking vessel in the eastern Pacific, killing four and bringing the campaign’s death toll to 99 since September. The action follows President Trump’s blockade of sanctioned Venezuelan oil tankers, accusing Caracas of seizing US oil to fund drug operations. Venezuela, backed by China, insists exports continue despite threats of regime change. House Republicans blocked measures to require congressional approval for strikes, while Mexico’s president and UN chief António Guterres face pressure to prevent regional escalation amid accusations that Trump’s true goal is ousting Maduro for oil interests.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Dan Bongino ‘wants to go back to his show’ says president, as deputy FBI director resigns
articles.trailText: Bongino, a former Secret Service agent turned podcaster, will step down in January. Key US politics stories from Wednesday 17 December at a glance
articles.summary: FBI deputy director Dan Bongino, a former Secret Service agent turned podcaster, will step down in January, thanking Trump, FBI director Kash Patel and former AG Pam Bondi, with the president quipping he “wants to go back to his show.” Elsewhere, Trump’s White House updates presidential portraits to denounce Biden; four Republicans join Democrats to force a vote extending Obamacare subsidies; the administration plans to dismantle Colorado’s NCAR climate center; FCC chair questions agency independence; Congress advances a $901bn defense bill including aid for Ukraine; plus key moves on Venezuela, HHS grants, NASA leadership and federal workforce layoffs blocked by a judge.

articles.title: House passes bill criminalising gender-affirming care and eyes Medicaid ban
articles.trailText: Two bills mark first time Congress votes over national care bans and escalation of anti-trans rhetoric
articles.summary: On Dec. 17 the House passed Greene’s bill, 216-211, to criminalize gender-affirming care for under-18s—punishable by up to 10 years—marking Congress’s first vote on national care bans. A second Crenshaw bill would bar Medicaid from covering puberty blockers, hormones or surgeries for minors. Advocates warn these measures fuel anti-trans rhetoric, exacerbate high suicide rates among trans youth, and mirror broad collateral harms seen in state abortion bans. Opponents, including Rep. Sarah McBride, decry federal overreach into medical decisions, argue open-access care reduces mental health crises and question prioritizing these bans over healthcare funding lapses.

articles.title: Washington state flooding damage profound but unclear, governor warns
articles.trailText: Record rains have forced hundreds of rescues, swamped communities and left rivers high, with more storms forecast
articles.summary: Gov. Bob Ferguson warns that after more than a week of Pacific storms dumping 0.6m of rain across western Washington, the extent of flooding damage remains unclear. Rising rivers triggered over 629 rescues and 572 assisted evacuations across 10 counties, leaving more than 100,000 under evacuation orders. High winds downed trees and powerlines, cutting electricity for 400,000 in Washington and Oregon. Mudslides, washed-out highways—State Route 2 may stay closed for months—and levee breaches persist under flood and wind watches. One fatality has occurred. The state has authorized millions in aid while crews await receding waters to assess damages and federal assistance.

articles.title: FBI deputy director Dan Bongino to step down in January
articles.trailText: Former podcaster Bongino confirms departure after Trump tells reporters ‘I think he wants to go back to his show’
articles.summary: FBI deputy director Dan Bongino confirmed he will resign in January, thanking Trump, director Kash Patel and AG Pam Bondi, with whom he'd clashed over Epstein files. Trump said Bongino "wants to go back" to his talk show. MS Now reported he told confidants he won’t return to bureau HQ this month. A former Secret Service agent and podcaster, Bongino has hosted shows like The Dan Bongino Show after stints on Hannity and Levin’s programs. His tenure saw emotional Fox News remarks about personal sacrifices and controversial theories about a "deep state," calls to jail Obama and Clinton, and claims of a 2021 bomb-plot cover-up. The FBI declined to comment.

articles.title: Heart attacks increased after Los Angeles wildfires, study finds
articles.trailText: Researchers at Cedars-Sinai say rates of heart attack and respiratory illness ‘matched worst years of Covid’
articles.summary: A Cedars-Sinai study in the Journal of the American College of Cardiology reports a 46% rise in ER visits for heart-attack symptoms and a 24% uptick in respiratory illness in the 90 days after January’s Palisades and Eaton wildfires, which destroyed over 16,200 structures and killed 31 residents. Adjacent zip codes saw a 118% surge in subtle blood-test abnormalities. Located 10–20 miles from the fire epicenters, researchers link wildland-urban interface smoke to acute biochemical stress across cardiac, pulmonary and metabolic systems, raising concerns about long-term health impacts.

articles.title: US Senate confirms billionaire Musk ally Jared Isaacman as Nasa chief
articles.trailText: Vote on Isaacman, private astronaut and Mars missions advocate, passes 67-30 for him to be agency’s 15th leader
articles.summary: On December 17, the Senate confirmed billionaire private astronaut and SpaceX ally Jared Isaacman as NASA’s 15th administrator in a 67-30 vote. A Trump nominee and Shift4 founder, Isaacman pledged to accelerate lunar missions to outpace China. His appointment blocked acting chief Sean Duffy’s bid to fold NASA into the Transportation Department—a conflict fueled by Duffy’s criticism of SpaceX and shift toward Blue Origin. Isaacman, who self-funded two all-civilian SpaceX flights including a 2024 private spacewalk, revived his candidacy after a May withdrawal amid Trump-Musk disputes.

articles.title: American Academy of Pediatrics loses government funding after criticizing RFK Jr
articles.trailText: Cuts, which affect projects focused on issues including early identification of autism, made without prior notice to AAP
articles.summary: The US Department of Health and Human Services abruptly terminated seven multimillion-dollar grants to the American Academy of Pediatrics after AAP criticized Health Secretary RFK Jr’s diverging Covid-19 vaccine guidance and used identity-based language. The cuts hit projects on fetal alcohol spectrum disorders, early autism screening, SIDS reduction, rural healthcare, mental health and birth defects. HHS said the grant materials misaligned with departmental priorities. AAP CEO Mark Del Monte decried harm to children and families and plans legal action. AAP and other medical groups have sued HHS over RFK Jr’s vaccine policy changes, citing wider public health impacts.

articles.title: Fani Willis defends Trump prosecution at contentious Georgia hearing
articles.trailText: Fulton county DA hits back at Republican opponents who investigated her over relationship with special prosecutor
articles.summary: At a Georgia state senate investigative hearing, Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis defended her racketeering prosecution of Donald Trump amid accusations of impropriety over her romantic relationship with special prosecutor Nathan Wade. Republicans, led by Sen. Greg Dolezal, pressed whether Wade was improperly paid with forfeiture or federal grant funds and if Willis coordinated with the January 6 committee. Willis rejected the inquiry as political, citing harassment and threats against her, and insisted hiring outside counsel was necessary to manage the extensive Trump case workload.

articles.title: Trump attacks Democratic foes in White House presidential portraits
articles.trailText: New plaques on ‘Presidential Walk of Fame’ scorn ‘divisive’ Obama and ‘by far the worst’ Biden – but Reagan is praised
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s White House unveiled a revamped “Presidential Walk of Fame” outside the West Wing, featuring new plaques under former presidents’ portraits that echo his social-media tirades. Joe Biden is denounced as “the worst president in American history,” his portrait swapped for an autopen; Barack Obama is labeled “one of the most divisive political figures” who lost Congress with the “Unaffordable Care Act”; Bill Clinton’s record is minimized; and Ronald Reagan is extolled as “The Great Communicator” and Trump admirer. The display debuts as Trump’s approval rating slips to 39% amid policy and personal controversies.

articles.title: FCC chair suggests agency is not independent amid fears of Trump power-grab
articles.trailText: Brendan Carr’s declaration raises concerns amid Trump efforts to exert greater control over independent agencies
articles.summary: FCC chair Brendan Carr told senators the FCC “is not an independent agency” after scrubbing that term from its online mission statement, sparking fears of a Trump power grab. A vocal Trump supporter, Carr has threatened broadcasters—most notably ABC over Jimmy Kimmel’s criticism of the president—citing vague public-interest rules. Democrats including Amy Klobuchar, Ed Markey and Tammy Baldwin accused him of politicizing the FCC, undermining its autonomy and policing speech under a decades-old standard.

articles.title: FDA recalls salad dressing after ‘plastic material’ found in ingredients
articles.trailText: More than 3,500 cases of dressing, including Hidden Valley Ranch, recalled after ‘foreign objects’ were discovered
articles.summary: Ventura Foods recalled over 3,500 one-gallon and deli-size salad dressings—including Hidden Valley Buttermilk Ranch, Italian, Creamy Poblano Avocado Ranch, Ventura and Pepper Mill Caesars—after FDA found black plastic planting material in granulated onion. Classified Class II on Dec. 4, signaling possible temporary, reversible health effects, the recall covers shipments to seven retailers across 42 locations in 26 US states plus one in Costa Rica. Retail Hidden Valley Ranch sold to consumers is unaffected. Customers should return purchases for a full refund.

articles.title: Four Republicans join Democrats to force vote on bill that would extend Obamacare subsidies
articles.trailText: Major setback for Mike Johnson as rebellion underscores GOP anxiety over rise in healthcare costs before midterms
articles.summary: In a blow to Speaker Mike Johnson, four Republican moderates—Brian Fitzpatrick, Robert Bresnahan, Ryan Mackenzie and Mike Lawler—joined Democrats via Hakeem Jeffries’ discharge petition to force a House vote on extending ACA premium tax credits for three years. Reaching the required 218 signatures underscores GOP unrest over rising healthcare costs ahead of the 2026 midterms. Johnson maintains control as the House will likely vote in January, while Republicans press their own Lower Health Care Premiums Act. Senate prospects remain uncertain. GOP plans also include association health plans and employer-sponsored coverage measures.

articles.title: Nick Reiner appears in court on murder charges in killing of parents
articles.trailText: Son of Rob Reiner and Michele Singer Reiner being held without bail after his parents were found dead in their home
articles.summary: Nick Reiner, son of director Rob Reiner and photographer Michele Singer Reiner, made a first court appearance Wednesday after being charged with two counts of first-degree murder, special circumstances of multiple killings and using a deadly weapon in his parents’ deaths. Held without bail, he did not plead, and arraignment is set for January. Authorities say their daughter discovered the bodies in the Brentwood home. Siblings Romy and Jake praised public support and called for privacy. Defense counsel urged caution pending evidence. Nick’s history of addiction and mental-health struggles is noted. His next hearing is January 7.

articles.title: Susie Wiles interview might be a useful distraction from how poorly things are going for Americans
articles.trailText: The incendiary quotes don’t disguise how dissatisfied people are about jobs, inflation or the cost of living
articles.summary: In a candid Vanity Fair interview, White House chief of staff Susie Wiles labeled Trump’s cabinet “bonkers,” branding JD Vance a decade-long conspiracy theorist, Elon Musk “an odd duck,” OMB head Russell Vought “a right-wing zealot,” Pam Bondi’s Epstein handling a “whiff,” and Trump himself as having an “alcoholic’s personality.” Wiles dismissed criticism as a “disingenuous hit piece.” Her salvo may deflect from a weakening economy: 41,000 jobs lost, 4.6% unemployment, expiring health subsidies, surging inflation, and Trump’s approval dropping to 43%, fueling public discontent.

articles.title: In Durham, North Carolina, neighbors are protecting neighbors from ICE: ‘We care for each other’
articles.trailText: Community members have stepped up with carpools, food deliveries, school patrols and policy advocacy
articles.summary: After a surge in statewide ICE raids and doubled arrests to 3,400 this year, Durham, NC parents, students and volunteers have formed watch groups around schools, organizing carpools, food deliveries and policy advocacy to protect predominantly Latino families (35% of students) from enforcement. Led by PTA president Norma Portillo and grassroots group Durham Public School Strong, they deploy whistles, 3D-printed gear and coordinated rideshares. This effort builds on decades of local immigrant organizing and a City Council “Fourth Amendment workplace” resolution, demanding clearer district policies to shield schools from ICE intrusion.

articles.title: Trump administration to dismantle key climate research center in Colorado
articles.trailText: Governor Jared Polis warned that breaking up Boulder’s NCAR would put ‘public safety at risk’
articles.summary: The Trump admin will dismantle Boulder-based NCAR, accusing it of spreading ‘climate alarmism’ and reallocating its weather work under an NSF review. The Mesa Lab closure threatens 830 staff, two research aircraft and a Wyoming supercomputer. Gov. Jared Polis warns the move endangers public safety by undermining data for fires, floods and cyclones. OMB director Russell Vought led the action, calling some programs wasteful including an Indigenous sciences initiative. Critics say shuttering NCAR undermines U.S. leadership in atmospheric science. It follows broader Trump scepticism, including proposed 30% NOAA climate cuts.

articles.title: Executives of bankrupt subprime auto lender Tricolor Holdings charged with fraud
articles.trailText: Daniel Chu, company’s founder, charged with directing multiple executives since 2018 to defraud investors
articles.summary: Executives at bankrupt subprime auto lender Tricolor Holdings, led by founder and ex-CEO Daniel Chu, were indicted for orchestrating a systematic fraud scheme since 2018. Prosecutors say Chu directed subordinates to falsify auto-loan data, double-pledge collateral and conceal losses, leading to over $900 million owed and a Chapter 7 collapse. The indictment alleges Chu personally extracted $6.25 million—some used to buy a Beverly Hills property—and misled banks and investors, inflicting billion-dollar losses on creditors, employees and customers.

articles.title: Congress member who faces charges for visiting ICE facility says Trump is ‘using me as an example’
articles.trailText: The New Jersey Democrat was charged with interfering with an immigration arrest while conducting her oversight duties
articles.summary: LaMonica McIver, a first-term New Jersey Democrat and homeland security committee member, was indicted for allegedly interfering with an ICE arrest during a May 9 oversight visit to Delaney Hall, Newark. She claims the charges—brought by acting US attorney Alina Habba—are political retaliation by Trump to deter congressional oversight, and notes pardons for Jan. 6 defendants under similar statutes. McIver, pleading not guilty, argues she was fulfilling her duties amid reports of unsafe conditions and is fighting selective prosecution despite a potential 17-year sentence.

articles.title: Trump’s tariffs are choking small US manufacturers – even those making music magic
articles.trailText: EarthQuaker Devices has served Smashing Pumpkins, PJ Harvey and Radiohead but says tariffs add costs up to 30%
articles.summary: EarthQuaker Devices in Akron makes handmade guitar pedals for Smashing Pumpkins, Radiohead and PJ Harvey, selling over 67,000 Plumes. Trump’s tariffs on 1,000+ imported components from China and Vietnam have added up to 30% in extra costs, forcing the company to absorb expenses, freeze new hires and lose a $50,000 state grant. A report shows one-third of northeast Ohio manufacturers face tariff-related losses averaging 16% versus 9% gains, delaying R&D, pausing expansions and cutting jobs. Cleveland port cargo is down 15–20%, prompting firms to use foreign trade zones; yet two-thirds still expect growth in 2026.

articles.title: First Thing: Trump orders blockade of oil tankers under sanctions from entering and leaving Venezuela
