articles.trailText: Move comes amid escalating campaign against Maduro as Venezuelan government condemns ‘grotesque threat’. Plus, how to plan a polyamorous wedding
articles.summary: Donald Trump has ordered a total blockade of all oil tankers under US sanctions from entering or leaving Venezuela, intensifying his campaign against Nicolás Maduro. The move follows a surge in US military presence in the region, over two dozen strikes on vessels in the Caribbean and Pacific that killed dozens, and last week’s seizure of a tanker with 2m barrels of heavy crude. Trump accused Caracas of using oil to fund drug trafficking and vowed further escalation, while Venezuela condemned the blockade as “an act of international piracy,” heightening bilateral tensions.

articles.title: Maga loyalist expands investigation into intelligence officials who angered Trump
articles.trailText: Experts decry Jason Reding Quiñones’s ‘fishing expedition’ as subpoenas reportedly issued to John Brennan and others
articles.summary: In Miami, US attorney Jason Reding Quiñones—confirmed in August with backing from Trump allies—has expanded a grand jury inquiry into former FBI and intelligence officials including John Brennan, James Clapper, Peter Strzok and Lisa Page. Having issued roughly two dozen subpoenas, the probe, backed by right-wing lawyer Mike Davis, seeks conspiracy charges despite exonerations by two special counsels and a Senate panel. Former prosecutors decry it as a politically driven “fishing expedition” that violates DOJ standards, forced two junior attorneys to resign and risks weaponizing justice for political revenge.

articles.title: From ‘odd’ Musk to ‘painful’ tariffs: key takeaways from interviews with Trump’s chief of staff
articles.trailText: Susie Wiles has spoken to Vanity Fair magazine in a series of 11 interviews that she has since dismissed as a ‘hit piece’
articles.summary: In 11 Vanity Fair interviews, Trump’s chief of staff Susie Wiles offers unfiltered takes on the administration: calls VP J.D. Vance a long-time conspiracy theorist turned MAGA recruit; criticizes Elon Musk’s USAID purge as “odd”; dubs Robert Kennedy Jr. “quirky Bobby” yet valuable for pushing hardliners; labels Trump’s broad-stroke style “an alcoholic’s personality”; admits his tariffs (April’s “Liberation Day”) proved “more painful than expected”; condemns Pam Bondi’s mishandling of the Epstein probe; defends Trump’s revenge tour as self-preservation; and outlines a “boat-striking” campaign to oust Nicolás Maduro. She called the VF piece a 'hit piece' but has not disputed its quotes.

articles.title: Elon Musk’s X wins appeal to lift block on Australians seeing Charlie Kirk shooting footage
articles.trailText: In successful challenge, X argued the video wasn’t excessively offensive and was an objective record of a ‘public event of historical and political significance’
articles.summary: X overturned an Australian board’s ‘refused classification’ rulings on social media clips of conservative influencer Charlie Kirk’s fatal 10 September shooting at Utah Valley University and a separate Charlotte train assault on Iryna Zarutska. X argued both grainy, weapon-free videos were neutral records of public events, not gratuitous violence, likening the Kirk footage to the Zapruder JFK film. The board’s majority reclassified them as R18+ (minority dissented), mandating under-18 safeguards. X touted a free-speech win; the eSafety commissioner hailed the outcome but emphasized R18+ obligations. Bondi terror attack clips remain unblocked with sensitive-content labels required.

articles.title: Trump orders blockade of sanctioned oil tankers entering and leaving Venezuela
articles.trailText: Move comes amid escalating campaign against Maduro as Venezuelan government condemns ‘grotesque threat’
articles.summary: Donald Trump has ordered a “total and complete” naval blockade of all sanctioned oil tankers entering or leaving Venezuela, citing allegations that Maduro uses oil revenue for drug trafficking. The move follows US forces’ recent seizure of a vessel carrying about 2 million barrels of crude and over 20 military strikes that have killed nearly 95 people. Venezuelan authorities denounce the blockade as piracy; Democratic Congressman Joaquin Castro calls it an unauthorized act of war. Market reaction has pushed oil prices higher amid supply concerns worsened by a cyberattack on PDVSA’s systems. Enforcement details remain unclear.

articles.title: CDC ends recommendation for all US newborns to receive hepatitis B vaccine
articles.trailText: Change marks an abrupt end to 30 years of established medical guidance. and follows vote earlier this month
articles.summary: The CDC under acting director Jim O’Neill, following a vote by health secretary RFK Jr.’s vaccine advisory panel, ended its 30-year universal hepatitis B birth-dose recommendation, advising vaccination only for infants of HBsAg-positive or status-unknown mothers and directing parents of hepatitis B-negative mothers to consult providers or delay to two months. Critics warn this individual-based approach risks rising pediatric infections, undermines science-based policy, and jeopardizes the 90% decline in hepatitis B incidence since 1982. Experts fear parents will lose trust and face access barriers under this shift.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president ratchets up pressure on Maduro with oil tanker blockade
articles.trailText: Trump said US armada ‘will only get bigger’ until Venezuela returns ‘all of the oil, land, and other assets that they previously stole from us’ – key US politics stories from 16 December 2025
articles.summary: On 16 Dec, President Trump ordered a “total and complete” naval blockade of all sanctioned oil tankers entering or leaving Venezuela, deploying the largest US armada in South America—including a supercarrier—to force Nicolás Maduro to return alleged stolen US oil, land and assets and cut revenues funding drug trafficking. Last week, US forces seized a Venezuelan crude tanker. Other US updates: the Pentagon won’t release full video of a deadly Caribbean strike; Rep. Ilhan Omar warned Trump’s rhetoric fuels political violence; Trump further restricted entry for nationals from 17 countries; and the BBC vowed to fight his $10 billion defamation suit amid GOP calls for a Muslim ban and disputes over White House ballroom construction.

articles.title: Man found dead in submerged car in first reported death in Washington floods
articles.trailText: Swimmers find driver, believed to be 33-year-old man, and vehicle in about 6ft of water in ditch in Snohomish area
articles.summary: A 33-year-old man became the first reported fatality in Washington’s record flooding after driving past warnings and ending up in six feet of water in a Snohomish County ditch. A week of Pacific storms has dumped nearly two feet of rain in the Cascades, swollen rivers, triggered mudslides and levee breaches, and prompted over 600 rescues and 572 assisted evacuations across ten counties. In Pacific, 220 homes were evacuated after a levee breach along the White River. Governor Bob Ferguson warned residents to heed evacuation orders as high water, landslides and power outages persist into next week, with state and expected federal aid mobilising for relief.

articles.title: Police release new video in hunt for Brown University shooting suspect
articles.trailText: Providence police say video shows person of interest ‘casing the area’ before attack in which two people were killed
articles.summary: Providence police have released East Side video of the masked individual they believe cased the area two hours before Saturday’s Brown University shooting, which killed two and wounded nine during finals. The suspect—wearing a black beanie, green jacket and gloves—was captured walking near Waterman Avenue and Hope Street. Police chief Oscar L. Perez said they’ve collected nearly 200 actionable tips and are seeking any resident or vehicle footage dating back a week. Rhode Island AG Peter Neronha affirmed progress; Brown’s president pledged community safety. The FBI has offered a $50,000 reward.

articles.title: Democrats to block Senate nominations over Bondi’s ‘failure’ on Epstein files
articles.trailText: Senate duo condemn Trump administration and say ‘there can be no business as usual until justice is delivered’
articles.summary: Senators Jeff Merkley and Ben Ray Luján will block all pending civilian nominations until Florida Attorney General Pam Bondi provides a briefing on the Justice Department’s compliance with the Epstein Files Transparency Act. Passed mid-November, the law mandates release of all unclassified records, documents, communications and investigative materials related to Jeffrey Epstein by December 19. The pair says Bondi failed to deliver requested bipartisan briefings on new evidence or procedural issues. Without full transparency and accountability, they argue, the Senate cannot proceed with any nominations.

articles.title: Trump signs order to further restrict entry of foreign nationals to US
articles.trailText: US imposes restrictions on Burkina Faso, Mali, Niger, South Sudan and Syria, in addition to initial list of 12 countries
articles.summary: President Trump on Dec. 16 issued a proclamation imposing full US entry bans on Burkina Faso, Mali, Niger, South Sudan, Syria and Palestinian Authority–document holders (adding to an earlier 12-country list), plus partial restrictions on 15 more nations (Angola, Nigeria, Tanzania, etc.). Citing the November DC National Guard shooting by an Afghan asylum recipient and recent IS-linked US fatalities in Syria, and following DHS Secretary Kristi Noem’s plan to expand the list, the White House argues vetting gaps necessitate tighter border controls under national security grounds.

articles.title: Nick Reiner to be charged with first-degree murder of his parents, Rob and Michele Reiner
articles.trailText: LA district attorney says charges could carry the death penalty, after Nick Reiner arrested in murder of his parents
articles.summary: Nick Reiner, 32, faces two counts of first-degree murder for allegedly killing his parents, director-actor Rob Reiner and Michele Singer Reiner, in their Brentwood home on Dec. 14. LA District Attorney Nathan Hochman announced possible death-penalty charges, citing special circumstances of multiple murders and deadly-weapon use. LAPD homicide detectives booked Nick without bail after responding at 3:40 PM and arresting him at 9:15 PM. Arraignment awaits medical clearance. Defense attorney Alan Jackson notes Nick’s recent mental-health concerns; DA must file formal counts by Dec. 18. Evidence will be presented in court to prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt.

articles.title: Democratic senators investigate data centers’ effects on electricity prices
articles.trailText: Elizabeth Warren, Richard Blumenthal and Chris Van Hollen demand answers from tech firms including Google and Amazon
articles.summary: Democratic Senators Elizabeth Warren, Richard Blumenthal and Chris Van Hollen are probing whether data centers run by Google, Microsoft, Amazon, CoreWeave, Digital Realty and Equinix are shifting utility costs onto US households. In letters demanding detailed energy-usage data and tax incentives by Jan. 12, they cite regions with 267% bill hikes over five years and a 7% national increase. They urge tech firms to cover their share of infrastructure costs as data centers could consume 12% of US power by 2028. Critics warn of water use and emissions; local campaigns have stalled $64 billion in projects amid utility contracts confidentiality.

articles.title: Trump’s chief of staff says he believes ‘there’s nothing he can’t do’ as president
articles.trailText: Susie Wiles gives strikingly unguarded comments in 11 interviews, starting before election, with Vanity Fair
articles.summary: In a series of 11 Vanity Fair interviews, White House chief of staff Susie Wiles reveals Trump believes “there’s nothing he can’t do,” likening his possessive personality to that of a high-functioning alcoholic. She says a “loose agreement” to settle political scores within 90 days went off track amid ongoing retribution indictments. Wiles claims she curbed planned Jan 6 pardons after praising the FBI’s casework, blasts Elon Musk’s USAID cuts and drug-tinged posts, and faults Pam Bondi over mishandled Epstein files. She warns the deportation process needs reform and hails Trump’s “world-class disruptor” cabinet while criticizing VP Vance and OMB director Russ Vought as ideological extremes.

articles.title: Donald Trump and the Goldwater rule | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: There’s a difference between armchair diagnosis and legitimate observation, and we must allow medical expertise to inform public discourse, writes Robert Krasner
articles.summary: Physician Robert Krasner argues the Goldwater rule—originally crafted in 1964 to curb irresponsible “armchair diagnosis”—need not bar ethical professional commentary on publicly documented behaviors of political figures. Prompted by President Trump’s rambling Pennsylvania speech marked by affordability ‘hoax’ claims and racist attacks, Krasner cites psychiatrist Dr. Allen Dyer’s October 2024 clarification that the rule was never an absolute gag order. He maintains that responsible, evidence-based observations of a public figure’s conduct, when extensively documented, can and should inform public discourse without violating medical ethics.

articles.title: FBI offers $50,000 reward as Brown University shooter still at large
articles.trailText: Two students were killed and nine wounded as hunt for unknown suspect enters fourth day, amid growing frustration
articles.summary: Entering its fourth day, the FBI has offered a $50,000 reward for information on the “stocky-built” suspect who killed two students and wounded nine with a 9mm handgun in Brown University’s Barus & Holley building. One person of interest was briefly detained and released amid criticism of FBI director Kash Patel’s premature resolution claims. Rhode Island authorities and Providence police are appealing to student witnesses and canvassing local footage amid frustration over limited campus surveillance. The slain include second-year Ella Cook and freshman Mukhammad Aziz Umurzokov.

articles.title: ‘You don’t have to do it alone’: how US cities are helping each other resist ICE
articles.trailText: From LA to Charlotte, organizers are learning from others’ strategies to protect residents amid federal crackdowns
articles.summary: Grassroots groups in US cities are sharing tactics to resist ICE raids: LA activists pioneered patrols at Home Depot lots to warn day laborers, distributing whistles and 'know your rights' flyers; Chicago adopted the tactic, while New Yorkers and Charlotte residents likewise used whistles to alert neighbors. Through DSA and Indivisible, Chicago organizers shipped whistle kits to New Orleans and led remote trainings for 800 people. ACLU branches relay legal updates statewide, while street vendor networks circulate protocols to distinguish local police from ICE. Decentralized neighborhood cells coordinate via secure channels to document raids, alert communities and disrupt arrests, forging cross-city solidarity.

articles.title: First Thing: Donald Trump sues BBC for up to $10bn over January 6 speech edit
articles.trailText: President accuses broadcaster of ‘deceptive’ editing. Plus, music labels embrace AI despite artists’ concerns
articles.summary: Former US president Donald Trump has filed a $10bn lawsuit against the BBC, claiming its Panorama episode maliciously and deceptively edited his Jan 6, 2021 speech to imply he urged supporters to ‘fight like hell’ at the Capitol. He seeks $5bn each for defamation and breach of Florida’s Deceptive and Unfair Trade Practices Act. The BBC has apologised for the editing error, insisted the claim is baseless and vowed to defend itself, with UK ministers publicly backing its integrity. Separately, major record labels are embracing AI music tools despite artists warning they could dilute creativity and undermine livelihoods.

articles.title: Ilhan Omar says Trump’s repeated attacks fuel climate of political violence
articles.trailText: The US House member says president’s rhetoric about her and Somali Americans could have dangerous consequences
articles.summary: Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-MN) warns that President Trump’s repeated personal attacks and dehumanizing rhetoric—like calling for her deportation, pushing baseless conspiracies about her Somali heritage, and labeling Somalis “garbage”—fuel a climate of political violence and endanger Somali-American communities. She cites prosecuted death threats, a past plot requiring a six-person security detail, and a record 9,474 threat investigations by Capitol Police in 2024. Threats fell to near zero under Biden but soared under Trump. Omar calls for stronger institutional guardrails and will focus on healthcare, affordability, climate policy and defending democracy in next year’s elections.

articles.title: ‘It’s terrifying, but not surprising’: a Brown University student on surviving her second school shooting
articles.trailText: Mia Tretta has advocated for gun-violence prevention since being shot as a high school student in California in 2019
articles.summary: Mia Tretta, a 21-year-old Brown junior and 2019 Saugus high school shooting survivor, endured her second mass shooting when an active shooter killed two students and injured nine on campus. Text alerts and a “Run, hide, fight” lockdown followed. She recently performed a song at Washington DC’s national gun violence vigil. Tretta, now a gun violence prevention advocate, has campaigned against untraceable ghost guns since her first shooting. She warns politicians failing to ensure safe schools amid nearly 400 multi-victim shootings in 2025. Tretta’s story underscores U.S. gun violence’s indiscriminate nature and calls for federal reforms.

articles.title: Nearly 90 flights linked to Epstein ‘came to or from UK airports’
articles.trailText: Flight logs reveal three British women onboard who were allegedly trafficked by convicted sex offender, according to BBC
articles.summary: BBC analysis of Epstein estate court records reveals 87 flights between the early 1990s and 2018 linked to Jeffrey Epstein landed at or departed UK airports, including 15 after his 2008 sex-offender conviction. Logs name three British women allegedly trafficked and list unidentified female passengers. Testimony from one victim helped convict Ghislaine Maxwell in 2021, yet UK police say no new evidence warrants reopening investigations. Meanwhile, US lawmakers passed a bill to force release of all government files by December 19, and a judge cleared publication of Maxwell case materials.

articles.title: Merch commemorating drunk Virginia raccoon raises over $250,000 for animal shelter
articles.trailText: Staff at the Ashland animal shelter sold merch of raccoon they cared for after he was found passed out in a liquor store
articles.summary: Merch commemorating a Virginia raccoon that broke into an Ashland ABC liquor store on Black Friday, smashed whisky bottles and passed out, has raised over $254,000 for the Hanover County Animal Protection Shelter via Bonfire. Limited-edition “Trashed Panda” shirts, sweatshirts, cups and stickers are within 250 sales of a 19,000-item goal; proceeds fund shelter animal care and enrichment. The viral incident followed prior raccoon break-ins at a DMV and karate studio. Officials released the creature locally after he sobered, citing relocation as a death sentence. A recent study on urban raccoon domestication added context to the stunt.

articles.title: US military says eight killed in strikes on three boats in eastern Pacific
articles.trailText: US Southern Command says boats were ‘engaged in narco-trafficking’
articles.summary: US Southern Command conducted strikes in international waters of the Eastern Pacific on three vessels suspected of narco-trafficking, killing eight individuals. Shared footage shows vessels moving along known trafficking routes before being destroyed. This operation, part of President Trump’s intensified anti-drug campaign, brings total vessel strikes to over 20 and at least 90 suspected smugglers killed across the Pacific and Caribbean. The Pentagon claims these actions comply with US and international law, but legal experts warn of potential extrajudicial killings. The strikes follow Trump’s designation of fentanyl as a “weapon of mass destruction.”

articles.title: Donald Trump sues BBC for up to $10bn over edit of January 6 speech
articles.trailText: President accuses corporation of ‘intentionally, maliciously and deceptively’ editing speech in Panorama broadcast
articles.summary: President Donald Trump has sued the BBC in Florida federal court seeking up to $10bn in damages, alleging the broadcaster “intentionally, maliciously and deceptively” edited his January 6, 2021 rally speech in a Panorama episode to imply he incited the Capitol attack. Trump filed two counts—defamation and violation of Florida’s Deceptive Trade Practices Act—each seeking $5bn. The BBC apologized for the editing error but denies legal liability. The lawsuit follows the resignations of the BBC’s director general and news chief amid broader coverage criticisms, extending Trump’s global campaign to hold media outlets legally accountable.

articles.title: Trump brands fentanyl a ‘weapon of mass destruction’ in drug war escalation
articles.trailText: Order classifies opioid as potential chemical weapon amid administration’s attempts to combat drug smuggling
articles.summary: Former President Donald Trump signed an executive order classifying fentanyl as a 'weapon of mass destruction', labeling it a potential chemical weapon and directing the Pentagon and DOJ to intensify anti-smuggling operations. The move escalates militaristic tactics—over 20 naval strikes so far—following his prior designation of cartels as foreign terrorist organizations. Critics and drug policy experts question the WMD comparison, noting no evidence of fentanyl use in terror attacks. The order aligns with Trump's broader hemispheric dominance strategy, ties to tougher immigration and trade policies with Mexico and China, and draws concerns about neglecting domestic addiction treatment and harm reduction funding.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: US president condemned over comments about Rob Reiner
articles.trailText: Lawmakers from both sides criticize ‘petty’ posts; Trump seeking $10bn in damages from BBC – key US politics stories from 15 December 2025
articles.summary: President Trump drew bipartisan ire after blaming Rob Reiner’s death on “Trump derangement syndrome,” calling the late director “paranoid” and “tortured,” triggering “vile” backlash from celebrities and lawmakers. He also sued the BBC for $10 billion over an edited January 6 Panorama segment. Other key developments: a Massachusetts green-card holder sues ICE over a “violent” detention; FBI director Kash Patel criticized for premature case claims; The Heritage Foundation hires Christian nationalist Scott Yenor; DOJ lawyers allege political pressure in UC antisemitism probe; Gov. Newsom appoints ex-CDC officials to lead California’s new public health network.

articles.title: Washington state orders immediate evacuations in three Seattle suburbs
articles.trailText: Orders come after a levee is breached following a week of heavy rain amid a flash-flood warning
articles.summary: King County ordered immediate evacuations in Kent, Auburn and Tukwila east of the Green River after the Desimone levee breached Monday amid record rains and an NWS flash-flood warning for 47,000 residents. A car-sized section of the 2020-damaged levee collapsed under floodwaters fueled by an atmospheric river. Crews have dropped sandbags and National Guard troops are en route while long-term repairs aren’t expected until 2031. In Sumas, USCG helicopters rescued people stranded on second floors. Researchers link more intense atmospheric rivers in the Pacific Northwest to ocean-warming climate change.

articles.title: Rhode Island governor says officials working hard to catch Brown shooter
articles.trailText: Manhunt continues for killer of two students on campus Saturday, with suspect considered armed and dangerous
articles.summary: Rhode Island Gov. Daniel McKee said authorities are sparing no effort to apprehend the armed suspect in Saturday’s Brown University classroom shooting that killed students Ella Cook and MukhammadAziz Umurzokov and wounded nine others during finals week. Providence police released video clips of a winter-clad person of interest and noted the use of a 9mm handgun. The FBI has offered a $50,000 reward, and officials warn the public to stay vigilant amid an ongoing manhunt.

articles.title: Newsom appoints ex-CDC officials to lead California’s new public health network
articles.trailText: Dr Susan Monarez to head PHNIX, a response to Trump administration’s dismantling of public health safeguards
articles.summary: Gavin Newsom named former CDC director Dr Susan Monarez and ex-CDC chief medical officer Dr Debra Houry to lead California’s new Public Health Network Innovation Exchange (PHNIX), a state response to the Trump administration’s dismantling of public health safeguards and rise in vaccine skepticism. Monarez, fired after clashing with HHS secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. over vaccine policy, and Houry, who resigned in protest, both testified before Congress in September. PHNIX will modernize the state’s public health infrastructure—focusing on technology development, data systems and funding frameworks—where Monarez serves as strategic health technology and funding adviser and Houry as senior regional and global medical adviser.

articles.title: From Hollywood to Brentwood, LA mourns beloved director Rob Reiner
articles.trailText: Fans pay tribute to When Harry Met Sally and The Princess Bride film-maker and his wife after apparent homicide
articles.summary: Los Angeles is reeling after director Rob Reiner and his wife, photographer-producer Michele Singer Reiner, were found dead in their Brentwood home and their son arrested on suspicion of homicide. Fans gathered at Reiner’s Hollywood Walk of Fame star to honor the maker of When Harry Met Sally, The Princess Bride, Stand By Me and This Is Spinal Tap, and to remember his activism—co-founding the Prop 8 legal challenge, leading marriage equality efforts and speaking out against Trump—and his I Am Your Child initiative on early childhood development.

articles.title: Lawyers accuse DoJ of political pressure in University of California antisemitism investigation
articles.trailText: Attorneys who eventually quit tell LA Times they were pushed to conclude university system had violated law
articles.summary: Nine DOJ attorneys told the LA Times they were pushed by Trump-appointed political leadership to find the University of California system liable for antisemitic discrimination at pro-Palestinian protests before investigating facts, calling the probe a 'hit job.' All eventually resigned. The case sought a $1 billion fine at UCLA and risked withholding $500 million in research grants, but a federal judge blocked funding cuts, citing ideological coercion. DOJ’s civil rights division had earlier found UCLA liable, prompting a $6.5 million settlement with Jewish claimants. Critics called the inquiry rushed, politically driven and legally flawed.

articles.title: Trump’s post on Rob Reiner sparks outrage from lawmakers and celebrities
articles.trailText: President’s statement blaming acclaimed director’s death on his dislike of him described as ‘disgusting’ and ‘vile’
articles.summary: After the murders of director Rob Reiner, 78, and his wife Michele, 68, in Brentwood, President Trump on Truth Social blamed Reiner’s “massive, unyielding…TRUMP DERANGEMENT SYNDROME” for the deaths, then lauded his own “Golden Age of America.” He later doubled down, mocking Reiner’s past critiques. Bipartisan outrage ensued: Patrick Schwarzenegger and Whoopi Goldberg called his post “vile,” while Governor Newsom, Senators Murphy, Representatives Frost, Lofgren and Greene condemned the attack. GOP’s Greene and Thomas Massie urged empathy for the family. Police arrested their son Nick, 32, on murder charges, bail set at $4 million.

articles.title: People in the US: what news story brought you hope or happiness in 2025?
articles.trailText: We want to hear from people about the news moments that were a ray of light in among the more difficult headlines and bad news stories
articles.summary: The Guardian invites US readers to share the news stories or moments in 2025 that uplifted them, offering a ray of hope amid challenging headlines. They ask: What positive news story stood out for you this year? Submissions can highlight moments of happiness, resilience, scientific breakthroughs, community solidarity or other uplifting events. Instructions to submit via online form are provided, with links to terms of service and privacy policy. This participatory feature seeks firsthand accounts of optimism to counterbalance difficult coverage.

articles.title: US green card holder sues ICE over claims of ‘violent assault’
articles.trailText: Hilda Ramirez Sanan and her two US citizen children were ‘illegally and forcefully detained’, the lawsuit alleges
articles.summary: Hilda Ramirez Sanan, a green-card holder of 20+ years and her two US-citizen children, were allegedly “illegally and forcefully detained” by unmarked ICE agents outside a Chelsea, Massachusetts courthouse on 26 September. Officers smashed her car windows, struck her and her brother-in-law with glass, twisted her arms, kicked her, and yanked her autistic 13-year-old son from his seat. All were hospitalized; Ramirez Sanan suffered a concussion, bruising and nerve palsy. The family, now seeking $1m in damages via Lawyers for Civil Rights, accuses ICE of violent, unlawful assault.

articles.title: Kash Patel faces criticism for touting FBI’s work tracking down suspect prematurely
articles.trailText: FBI director said his agency helped detain ‘person of interest’ in Brown shooting – who was released hours later
articles.summary: Kash Patel, the FBI director, prematurely touted detaining a person of interest in the Brown University shooting based on a Providence police tip; the 24-year-old was released hours later and the actual shooter remains at large. Rhode Island AG Peter Neronha said only a “quantum of evidence” justified the brief detention. Critics from across the spectrum condemned Patel’s social media announcements and questioned his leadership, citing previous misstatements, internal reports of low morale and an underperforming, ‘rudderless’ agency.

articles.title: Democrat on ousting Republican in Pennsylvania’s ’swingiest’ county: ‘Partnering with ICE is a losing proposition’
articles.trailText: Danny Ceisler’s defeat in sheriff’s race of incumbent who had signed an agreement to work with ICE sends a message on US’s contentious debate around immigration policy
articles.summary: In swingiest Bucks County, PA, Democrat Danny Ceisler unseated 30-year veteran Sheriff Frederick Harran by 11% (23,000 votes), campaigning to terminate Harran’s 287(g) ICE Task Force Model pact that allowed deputies to question immigration status and make arrests. Ceisler, a 33-year-old Army veteran and former Shapiro aide, argued that ICE cooperation erodes public safety by deterring crime reporting in a county of 500,000 (70k foreign-born). His victory, alongside wins for DA and school board, signals voter rejection of local immigration enforcement partnerships.

articles.title: Looming federal cuts could devastate Alaska’s fight against overdose deaths
articles.trailText: Law enforcement and public health experts worry that potential cuts to resources that save lives and stop the flow of drugs into the state could raise overdose deaths
articles.summary: Looming 35% cut (~$100 m) to Alaska’s HIDTA funding in the proposed FY2026 budget threatens drug interdiction in a state with rising overdose deaths, driven by fentanyl. Alaska relies on HIDTA for coordination, training and arrests across its vast, remote terrain. Simultaneous Medicaid cuts under the “big, beautiful bill” could strip exemptions and work requirements for 211 000 Alaska enrollees, endangering substance-use treatment, inpatient bed expansions and provider reimbursements. Law enforcement leaders and bereaved families warn these cuts could reverse recent gains and fuel overdose fatalities.

articles.title: Congresswoman Ilhan Omar says ICE agents pulled over her son in Minnesota
articles.trailText: Representative says her son was let go once he showed ID as Trump ramps up operation targeting Somali population in Minneapolis
articles.summary: Congresswoman Ilhan Omar said ICE agents pulled over her son after he left a Target store in Minneapolis and released him once he showed his passport. She recounted that agents earlier entered the mosque where he was praying and departed without incident. Omar warned that Operation Metro Surge—President Trump’s directive to target Somali and Latino residents—relies on racial profiling of young men who look Somali. In a letter to DHS Secretary Kristi Noem and ICE Acting Director Todd Lyons, she condemned the enforcement as excessively forceful and performative for social media.

articles.title: Brown University shooting: what we know so far about the attack in Providence, Rhode Island
articles.trailText: A person who was taken into custody after two people were killed and several more critically injured was later released
articles.summary: On Dec. 13, a shooter dressed in black opened fire in Brown University’s Barus and Holley engineering building during finals, killing two students—Ella Cook, 2nd-year College Republicans VP, and Uzbek freshman MukhammadAziz Umurzokov—and wounding nine others; eight were hospitalized in critical but stable condition. A person in their 20s was arrested at a Coventry hotel after cellphone data led FBI agents there; authorities later released them without charge as evidence pointed elsewhere. Classes and exams were canceled for the semester. Two handguns were recovered in the hotel. Providence Mayor Brett Smiley and President Trump publicly paid tribute to victims.

articles.title: ‘Just disgraceful’: outcry as Heritage thinktank appoints far-right figure to key post
articles.trailText: Scott Yenor, who has offered views on women, marriage and LGBTQ+ rights, helped to found secretive fraternal order
articles.summary: The Heritage Foundation has appointed Scott Yenor—co-founder of a secretive, all-male Christian nationalist lodge network—as director of its B. Kenneth Simon Center for American Studies, sparking outcry. Yenor has publicly called for outlawing homosexuality, adultery, no-fault divorce and abortion under a ‘soft patriarchy,’ linking homosexuality to pedophilia and urging rollback of workplace sex-discrimination protections. Critics from both the left and right, including extremism expert Heidi Beirich and conservative Henry Olsen, condemn Heritage’s choice as evidence of its radical shift despite its stated nondiscrimination policy.

articles.title: ‘Virality, rumors and lies’: US federal agencies mimic Trump on social media
articles.trailText: Variety of agencies now deliberately provocative on social media, further inflaming discourse on serious issues
articles.summary: Since Trump’s second term, federal agencies like ICE, DHS and Defense have adopted his confrontational social media tone, using memes, mockery and “rage bait” to promote deportations (“YOU’RE GOING HO HO HOME”), tout arrests as “worst of the worst” despite most detainees lacking criminal records, and post ASMR chains-of-custody videos. Experts warn this propagandistic style exploits algorithms, psychological targeting and inflammatory content to polarize audiences, echoing authoritarian regimes’ dehumanizing tactics. Critics decry co-opting Christmas imagery for anti-immigrant rhetoric. EU and Germany’s tougher digital laws underscore contrast with US agencies’ aggressive online playbook.

articles.title: Brown University shooting: authorities say they released sole person of interest
articles.trailText: At least two people were killed and nine others injured in Saturday attack that occurred in engineering building on Providence, Rhode Island campus
articles.summary: Brown University mass shooting in an engineering building during finals left two students dead and nine wounded. Authorities detained a person of interest 17 miles from campus but released him after finding no basis for suspicion. The FBI deployed cellular analysis to aid geolocation as investigators scour surveillance footage. Classes and exams were canceled for the semester; shelter-in-place orders were lifted but campus access remains restricted. Victims include recent graduate Kendall Turner and first-year Spencer Yang. The community is shaken, and officials pledge an intensified search for the shooter amid renewed calls for stricter US gun control.

articles.title: US librarians tackle ‘manufactured crisis’ of book bans to protect LGBTQ+ rights
articles.trailText: In at least half a dozen states, librarians have joined forces with civil rights groups to oppose book bans, often facing personal and professional repercussions
articles.summary: Across at least six states, public librarians are suing and winning settlements after refusing to remove or segregate LGBTQ+ titles under conservative mandates. In Texas, Rhea Young lost her job for protecting books like It’s Perfectly Normal; in Wyoming, Terri Lesley secured a $700 K payout over bans on queer-inclusive sex-ed works. Backed by civil-rights groups and ACLU attorneys, they’ve challenged over 130 anti-library bills and 821 ban attempts in 2024, countering a “manufactured crisis” driven by groups like Moms for Liberty and fortifying grassroots legal resistance.

articles.title: A hurricane destroyed their homes in Jamaica. Now they fear losing the jobs they rely on in the US
articles.trailText: Thousands of Jamaican workers who come to the US on an H-2A visa say they aren’t sure if they’ll be able to return from one year to the next
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa, a record category-5 storm, obliterated roofs and inflamed material costs in Jamaica’s Black River region, imperiling homes of thousands. Some 5,000 Jamaican H-2A farmworkers in New York—like Owen Salmon and Damian—returned to devastation and allege employers threatened non-return if productivity lagged. Wafler Farms denies refusing recalls and points to U.S. recruitment mandates. After unionizing with United Farm Workers and winning New York certification, workers began bargaining over wages and conditions. Price gouging on staples and delayed aid hamper recovery as visa-tied labor and immigration status hang in the balance.

articles.title: Father and son allegedly used licensed firearms in Bondi beach terror attack | First Thing
articles.trailText: One alleged shooter was known previously to security agencies, the Australian PM said. Plus, what we know about the Assad family’s new life after fleeing Syria last year
articles.summary: Police allege a father and son used legally obtained firearms to kill 15 and injure dozens during a Hanukkah gathering at Bondi Beach. Naveed Akram, 24, wounded critically, was arrested; his 50-year-old father was shot dead by officers. PM Albanese revealed Naveed was monitored by security agencies in 2019 but insisted they weren’t linked to any wider cell. NSW Premier Minns signalled imminent gun-law reforms as authorities review licensing failures in this evolving terror probe.

articles.title: Nancy Pelosi calls female US president in her lifetime unlikely: ‘Marble ceiling’
articles.trailText: Former House speaker, 85, expects woman to assume Oval Office this generation but concedes she may not live to see it
articles.summary: Nancy Pelosi, 85, says a woman president is unlikely in her lifetime, citing a “marble ceiling.” She reflects on the defeats of Hillary Clinton in 2016 and Kamala Harris in 2024, yet predicts a female Oval Office occupant within the next generation. Echoing Michelle Obama’s “we’re not ready” remark, Pelosi revisits her historic tenure as the first woman House speaker since 2007, her congressional career beginning in 1988, and recent estrangement from Joe Biden after urging him to end his 2024 campaign. Grateful for his praise on her retirement, she explains stepping down in 2027 as a matter of timing and age.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president pays tribute to Brown University shooting victims amid calls for gun control
articles.trailText: Donald Trump addressed shooting as politicians urged action to improve gun controls – key US politics stories from Sunday at a glance
articles.summary: At a White House holiday reception, President Trump paid respects to two killed and nine injured in a Brown University shooting—his remarks came as the 389th US mass shooting this year reignited calls for stricter gun control. Authorities have detained a person of interest in their 20s. Other top stories: Trump’s “big, beautiful” bill ties federal funding to AI integration in healthcare; ex-Senator Manchin urged politicians to de-escalate amid political violence; Trump’s domestic policy chief prioritizes a DC triumphal arch amid affordability woes; immigrant teens assume caregiver roles after parental detentions; the NLRB lost its quorum after key firings; journalists of color face layoffs amid DEI rollbacks.

articles.title: Trump says building DC triumphal arch is domestic policy chief’s ‘primary thing’
articles.trailText: Trump praises Vince Haley, his ex-speechwriter tasked with creating Arc de Triomphe knockoff amid affordability crisis
articles.summary: Trump revealed at a White House party that his domestic policy chief, ex-speechwriter Vince Haley, is focused on building a Paris-style triumphal arch near the Arlington Bridge opposite the Lincoln Memorial. Praising Haley’s enthusiasm, Trump claimed the new monument would surpass Paris’s Arc de Triomphe. Critics note the project’s prominence contrasts with growing affordability concerns—tariffs driving up consumer costs and looming spikes in health insurance premiums for over 20 million Americans.

articles.title: Republican says ‘deal can be had’ on healthcare as subsidies set to expire
articles.trailText: Senator Bill Cassidy urges collaboration between Democrats and his party after Senate rejected dual healthcare bills
articles.summary: Senator Bill Cassidy, chair of the Senate healthcare committee, said bipartisan cooperation remains possible after senators rejected both Democratic and Republican cost-containment bills and as soon-to-expire ACA premium tax credits threaten 22 million Americans. Democrats sought a three-year renewal; Cassidy’s GOP plan would deposit $1,000 in HSAs for ACA bronze or catastrophic enrollees (plus $500 for ages 50–64), with limits on abortion and gender-affirming care. He’s open to a short-term tax-credit extension if lawmakers agree to address high $6,000 deductibles, signaling hope for a compromise.

articles.title: Manchin urges lawmakers to stop acting in ‘attack mode’ amid political violence
articles.trailText: Former senator’s comments echo recent call from Erika Kirk that ‘everyone has responsibility’ to tone down hatred
articles.summary: Former senator Joe Manchin on WABC called on lawmakers to abandon “attack mode,” urging Democrats and Republicans to cool rhetoric and form a “sensible majority” free of far-left and far-right influences. His appeal echoes Erika Kirk’s town-hall plea after her husband Charlie Kirk’s September killing. Manchin stressed civil disagreement—“you are not the enemy”—and warned that intense partisanship risks fueling recent political violence in the US, which has included two assassination attempts on Donald Trump, a firebombing at Gov. Josh Shapiro��s residence and the murders of Charlie Kirk and ex-Minnesota speaker Melissa Hortman. Republican Sen. Rand Paul also cautioned that aggressive redistricting could heighten tensions before 2026.

articles.title: Obamacare expiration will have ‘death spiral’ effect on US healthcare – experts
articles.trailText: End of subsidies after failed legislation will have serious and damaging impact on entire sector, policy experts say
articles.summary: With ACA subsidies set to expire after a failed Senate vote, average marketplace premiums could more than double from $888 to $1,904 in 2026, prompting a third of enrollees to shift to lower-premium, high-deductible plans and a quarter to drop coverage. Experts warn this adverse selection will trigger a “death spiral,” raising costs further as healthier consumers exit. Rural hospitals, already reliant on ACA patients, face rising uncompensated care and potential closures or price hikes affecting employer-insured Americans. Despite 5.7 million sign-ups to date, analysts caution the true impact will emerge after Jan. 15 when first premiums are due.

articles.title: ‘I’m going to be heartbroken. This is a landmark’: cherished Times Square dive bar faces eviction
articles.trailText: With cheap drinks and friendly locals, Jimmy’s Corner is a New York institution. But a real-estate developer has ordered its closure – can it survive?
articles.summary: Founded in 1971 by former boxer Jimmy Glenn, Jimmy’s Corner in Times Square has defied gentrification with $3 pints, vintage décor and locals-plus-tourists drawn to its intimate, wifi-free dive atmosphere. After Jimmy’s 2020 death, landlord Durst Organization invoked a contested lease clause to evict owner Adam Glenn, who has filed suit alleging the terms were exploitative. Regulars warn losing this “landmark” means erasing New York history. Glenn aims to reopen elsewhere, preserving the bar’s low prices and community spirit if forced out.

articles.title: A prolific true crime producer was truly a criminal the whole time, the FBI says
articles.trailText: Agency added Mary Carole McDonnell to Most Wanted list for loan fraud tied to phony heiress story
articles.summary: Mary Carole McDonnell, 73, former Bellum Entertainment founder and prolific true-crime TV producer responsible for 50-plus episodes of Murderous Affairs, was added to the FBI’s Most Wanted list for federal bank fraud and identity theft. Posing as a McDonnell Aircraft heiress with false documents—$28m deposit, $80m trust—she secured a $15m bridge loan from Banc of California, defaulting and allegedly scamming nearly $30m total from multiple banks. Indicted in 2018, believed hiding in Dubai, she left staff like showrunner Nigel Bellis and office manager Stephanie Manos with half-million-dollar claims, unpaid back pay and ruined careers. FBI urges public tips for extradition and asset recovery.

articles.title: ‘It feels endless’: despite misplaced fanfare about a model home, LA struggles to rebuild
articles.trailText: As LA’s mayor touted a developer’s model home, residents of Altadena and Pacific Palisades wrangle for insurance payouts
articles.summary: It feels endless: despite Mayor Bass heralding a newly built 4,000 sq ft Thomas James Homes model as the first post-wildfire recovery milestone, Pacific Palisades and Altadena survivors say it’s not a true fire rebuild. Nearly a year after blazes leveled 7,000 structures and killed 31 people, residents still wrestle with stalled insurance payouts, complex permits and expiring relief. While 340 homes are under construction and 750 rebuild plans approved, advocacy group Pali Builds and UCLA urban planners call for a dedicated rebuilding authority and resilient planning, warning full community restoration could take decades.

articles.title: Experts urge caution as Trump’s big bill incentivizes AI in healthcare
articles.trailText: Analysts say benefits could be felt in under-resourced rural hospitals but warn against AI as a cost-cutting measure
articles.summary: Under the Trump administration’s “big bill,” states can tap a $50 bn Rural Health Transformation Fund over five years by meeting criteria such as integrating AI in healthcare. Experts say AI could ease staffing and administrative burdens in under-resourced rural hospitals—e.g., automating patient notes and remote monitoring—but warn the funding barely offsets $911 bn in projected Medicaid cuts. They urge balanced implementation, stronger regulation for diagnostic and note-taking tools, cybersecurity safeguards, and workforce upskilling to prevent cost-cutting compromises.

articles.title: ‘They’re trying to get rich off it’: US contractors vie to rebuild Gaza, with ‘Alligator Alcatraz’ team in the lead
articles.trailText: Exclusive: group behind notorious Florida immigration detention center created bid for reconstruction deal
articles.summary: Trump-endorsed Board of Peace and a parallel White House Gaza taskforce led by Jared Kushner, Steve Witkoff and Aryeh Lightstone are jockeying to award lucrative reconstruction contracts in Gaza. Two former Doge officials have circulated a “Gaza Supply System Logistics Architecture” proposing a $1.7 billion-a-year “master contractor” model charging fees of $2,000 per humanitarian truck and $12,000 per commercial load. Politically connected Gothams LLC—operator of Florida’s “Alligator Alcatraz” detention center—emerged as frontrunner but has since pulled out after scrutiny.

articles.title: ‘A very hostile climate for workers’: US labor movement struggles under Trump
articles.trailText: National Labor Relations Board, the federal watchdog for workers’ rights, has been rendered toothless as employees grapple with corporations
articles.summary: Philadelphia Whole Foods workers won a union vote but can’t be certified after Trump fired an NLRB member, knocking out the board’s quorum. The NLRB under Trump has issued just six rulings in 11 months vs 150 in 2024, demoralizing staff and delaying cases. An appeals court has blocked enforcement in a SpaceX challenge. Trump’s nominees could restore quorum, but the administration has rescinded Biden-era pro-labor policies. States like California and New York are stepping in. The supreme court is poised to decide on the NLRB’s independence.

articles.title: Two survivors of Brown University attack escaped other school shootings
articles.trailText: Mia Tretta was shot in the abdomen in 2019 at a school near LA and Zoe Weissman witnessed a Florida shooting in 2018
articles.summary: During a Dec. 14 shooting at Brown University that killed two and wounded nine, students Mia Tretta, 21, and Zoe Weissman, 20, found themselves reliving past traumas: Tretta had been shot in the abdomen in the 2019 Saugus High School attack that killed two, including her best friend, and Weissman witnessed the 2018 Parkland shooting at her middle-high school in Florida that left 17 dead. Both, caught off-guard in their dorms, expressed anger and disbelief that they had survived two campus shootings. Their experiences underscore mounting calls for stricter U.S. gun laws amid 389 mass shootings so far this year.

articles.title: DoorDasher in Indiana arrested for allegedly pepper-spraying delivery
articles.trailText: Kourtney Stevenson was allegedly caught on camera spraying meal with chemical that later sickened customers
articles.summary: Kourtney Stevenson, 29, a DoorDash driver in Indiana, was arrested for allegedly pepper-spraying a customer’s meal in view of a doorbell camera, sickening a married couple who later vomited and experienced burning sensations. Charged with felony battery and consumer product tampering, Stevenson claimed she targeted a spider—not food—though investigators noted 35°F would immobilize spiders. DoorDash permanently banned her and is cooperating with authorities. Sheriff’s investigators, aided by DoorDash records, obtained a warrant, and Stevenson is held without bail awaiting extradition.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: US seizure of Venezuela oil tanker an act of ‘maritime terrorism’, says Cuba
articles.trailText: Cuban officials denounce the US seizure of the Skipper oil tanker off Venezuela’s coast. Key US politics stories from 13 December 2025
articles.summary: After Washington seized the Skipper oil tanker off Venezuela’s coast—loaded with nearly 2m barrels of PDVSA heavy crude and bound for Cuba’s Matanzas but redirected to Galveston, Texas, after off-loading some 50,000 barrels—Cuban officials condemned the action as “piracy and maritime terrorism” and a breach of international law aimed at economic pressure. In US politics, senior Democrats call for probes into a $12m share-buying spree by Trump-aligned LNG magnates; Gavin Newsom slams Trump’s AI directive; Afghan advocates denounce immigration crackdowns; Trump jabs Biden on “Sleepy Joe” amid his own dozing incidents.

articles.title: Two people dead and nine wounded in mass shooting at Brown University, as suspect remains at large
articles.trailText: Mayor of Providence, Rhode Island, says ‘shooter’ still at large, as officials embark on widespread manhunt
articles.summary: At Brown University in Providence, Rhode Island, a shooter killed two students and critically injured nine others on Saturday afternoon in the Barus and Holley engineering and physics building. Witnesses described a man in black, possibly wearing a camouflage mask, fleeing the scene onto nearby Hope Street. Authorities launched a multi-agency manhunt across campus and surrounding neighborhoods, releasing surveillance footage. University officials locked down buildings, mobilized victim support, and urged holiday crowds to remain vigilant. Investigation ongoing; suspect remains at large.

articles.title: Kansas Native American tribe in turmoil over deal to design ICE facilities
articles.trailText: Prairie Band Potawatomi Nation signed deal in October, but president says tribe is now trying to exit contract
articles.summary: Prairie Band Potawatomi Nation’s development arm, KPB Services, signed a $29.9m sole‐source DHS contract in October to design ICE detention centers, prompting backlash from tribal members and other Native groups. Chair Joseph “Zeke” Rupnick publicly apologized, announced plans to exit the agreement, and fired the brokers. Critics highlight historical trauma—reservations as first US detention sites—and question sole‐source award practices. The dispute underscores tensions between economic pressures facing tribes amid funding cuts and cultural values, while other Native entities also hold government detention contracts. Future engagements now must align with the nation’s principles.

articles.title: Atmospheric rivers – what to know about the storms inundating the Pacific north-west
articles.trailText: This week’s weather system dumped 5tn gallons of rain on Washington state – and another one is threatening Canada
articles.summary: An intense atmospheric river dumped over a foot of rain—roughly 5tn gallons—over western Washington this week, triggering record floodwaters, mudslides washed away homes and stranded families on rooftops, and widespread evacuations extending into British Columbia. A second system threatens to swell the Nooksack and Sumas rivers again, prompting 500 Abbotsford property evacuations and renewed calls for U.S. investment in transboundary flood infrastructure. Scientists link the surge in moisture—fed by tropical and western Pacific warming—to human-driven climate change, and Washington’s governor warned the deluge is potentially historic.

articles.title: Death on high-speed roller coaster in Florida deemed accidental
articles.trailText: Kevin Rodriguez Zavala died from blunt-impact trauma on ride at Universal’s Epic Universe theme park
articles.summary: Orange County sheriff’s investigators concluded 32-year-old Kevin Rodriguez Zavala’s Sept. 17 death on Epic Universe’s 62 mph dual-launch roller coaster was accidental. Medical examiners cited blunt-impact trauma—deep forehead laceration, orbital ridge fracture, skull bleeding, broken nose, fractured thigh and bruising—caused when a malfunctioning lap bar trapped and flung Zavala, who had spinal rods, during multiple high-speed drops. Universal staff followed protocols; ride warnings flagged sudden forces and advised guests with preexisting back or neck conditions not to ride. His death follows Florida’s 2022 amusement-ride safety reforms.

articles.title: Washington state flood waters receding after days of rescues and evacuations
articles.trailText: No fatalities reported in flooding, which prompted Trump to approve emergency declaration request from governor
articles.summary: Record-breaking flood waters in western Washington have begun to recede after days of historic inundation, emergency rescues and evacuations. Governor Bob Ferguson confirmed President Trump approved an emergency declaration following an atmospheric river that dumped over 30 cm of rain, swelling the Skagit and Nooksack rivers. No fatalities have been reported. Tens of thousands, including roughly 1,000 Burlington residents north of Seattle, were evacuated; a 2018 flood wall protected downtown Burlington as Mount Vernon’s Skagit River peaked at 11 m. Landslides, debris-clogged highways and BC’s Fraser Valley flooding persist, with more rain forecast and flash-flood risks ongoing.

articles.title: Cuba denounces US seizure of oil tanker off Venezuela’s coast as ‘piracy’
articles.trailText: Cuban foreign ministry called US military action ‘maritime terrorism’ under a policy of ‘economic suffocation’
articles.summary: Cuba’s foreign ministry denounced the US Navy’s seizure of the VLCC Skipper off Venezuela’s coast as "piracy" and "maritime terrorism," accusing Washington of violating international law and intensifying "economic suffocation." The tanker, carrying nearly 2m barrels of Venezuelan crude bound for Matanzas, off-loaded 50,000 barrels to an intermediary ship before US forces intercepted it en route to Galveston. The action coincides with new Treasury sanctions on shipping firms, Maduro’s circle and a broker tied to Iran-linked terror networks, plus a US military buildup in the Caribbean. A DC federal warrant cites terrorism-financing ties to Hezbollah and Iran’s IRGC-QF, highlighting efforts to choke Venezuelan oil revenues.

articles.title: ‘Not a gift-giving year’: student loan debt upends US borrowers’ holiday spending
articles.trailText: After Trump ended key repayment plan, 40% of borrowers say their student loans make it harder to cover essentials
articles.summary: After the Trump administration scrapped the Biden-era Save income-driven repayment plan—arguing it exceeded federal authority—and halted new enrollments, 40% of US student loan borrowers say loans hinder covering essentials like food, housing and healthcare, per TICAS/Data for Progress. Biotech professional Ben L pays $1,850 monthly on $95,000 in private loans, lives paycheck-to-paycheck and skips holiday gifts. Forty-five percent report delayed housing plans; 52% can’t save for retirement. Nonprofit worker Erin O expects her Save payments to double, forcing a lean Christmas.

articles.title: The Katie Miller Podcast: an aggressively vibeless curriculum for the Maga mom
articles.trailText: The wife of the Trump adviser aims to entice conservative women into Maga – but like much of the rest of the movement, her sales pitch is fundamentally lacking
articles.summary: Katie Miller’s eponymous podcast positions itself as a soft-entry point for conservative women into MAGA culture, blending family, faith and anti-establishment talking points—seed oils, anti-Trump protesters and transgender “ideology”—with instructions on motherhood. Guests like Pete Hegseth, JD Vance and Kellyanne Conway face softball queries on godly conduct and domestic routines, while vaccine skepticism and anti–birth-control rhetoric underscore a “womanosphere” ethos. Despite high-profile access, Miller’s lack of chemistry and overly polished, generic interviews render the show vibeless and ineffective at authenticating or expanding Trump’s appeal among female audiences.

articles.title: ‘They fought for American values’: Afghan immigrants and advocates push back against Trump crackdown
articles.trailText: The US has been punishing ‘an entire group’ since the arrest of an Afghan in the shooting of two national guard troops
articles.summary: After an Afghan man’s arrest in the Washington DC shooting of two National Guard soldiers, the Trump administration froze USCIS asylum decisions, paused Afghan and 18 other travel-ban nationals’ visa and green-card applications, re-investigated past grants and reduced work-permit validity. ICE raids have intensified. Afghan advocates like Yahya Haqiqi in Oregon and Shir Agha Safi in Iowa warn 80,000 under Operation Allies Welcome and over 200,000 total face fear, uncertainty and indefinite limbo. Critics say the broad measures punish those who fought for US values, while officials defend enhanced vetting for security.

articles.title: You and me against the world: who was behind Trump’s anti-Europe foreign policy?
articles.trailText: The US’s national security strategy, shared last week, claims European immigration will cause ‘civilisational erasure’
articles.summary: Behind Trump’s new National Security Strategy is Michael Anton, ex-State Department policy planner, whose draft frames European immigration as “civilizational erasure,” revives the Monroe Doctrine, downgrades China/Russia competition and courts illiberal EU partners. Surviving a bruising interagency process, the document reflects MAGA ideologues like JD Vance, Stephen Miller and Secretary of State Marco Rubio. Though nonbinding and likely unread by Trump, its anti-immigrant, anti-EU tenor aligns with his instincts. US embassies now gather immigrant crime data, the EU is recast as a rival, and human rights reports tilt toward allies. Critics warn this NSS serves as a blueprint to upend postwar policy.

articles.title: Top Democrats call for investigation into share-buying spree by Trump allies
articles.trailText: Fossil fuel execs Robert Pender and Michael Sabel deny wrongdoing after report on potential conflict of interest
articles.summary: Senate Democrats Ron Wyden and Chris Van Hollen, joined by Jeff Merkley and Ro Khanna, demand an investigation into a March share purchase—over one million Venture Global LNG shares worth ~$12 million each—by founders Robert Pender and Michael Sabel days after meeting Trump officials who granted a crucial export permit. Critics allege pay-to-play and insider trading reminiscent of past Trump energy scandals, citing record fossil fuel lobbying and donations to Trump’s inauguration. Venture Global and the White House deny misconduct amid Trump’s rollback of climate rules, rising gas prices and extreme weather impacts.

articles.title: Trump attacks old foe Biden – but presidential parallels hard to avoid
articles.trailText: US president finds himself shouldering same burdens of affordability crisis and the inexorable march of time
articles.summary: At a Pennsylvania rally, Trump mocked Biden as “Sleepy” and “Crooked Joe” while launching a roadshow to tout the economy, echoing Biden’s Bidenomics tour. Both septuagenarian presidents shoulder an affordability crisis, high inflation and scrutiny over age and health. Trump’s medical check-up, MRI, leg swelling, bandaged hand and on-camera nodding off mirror past concerns about Biden’s fitness. With unemployment rising, cost-of-living approval at 31% and voters skeptical, analysts warn Trump risks repeating Biden’s messaging mistakes ahead of crucial midterms.

articles.title: Cruise-ship stowaway owls set for US return after living it up at Spanish resort
articles.trailText: Burrowing owls, who boarded cruise ship in Miami, to be returned to US next month after long spell in quarantine
articles.summary: Two threatened burrowing owls stowed away on Royal Caribbean’s Allure of the Seas in Miami and survived a transatlantic voyage to Cartagena by sheltering in the ship’s Central Park. Spotted early in the 14-day cruise, they were netted by crew, handed to Spanish authorities and quarantined since spring at a CITES rescue center near Murcia. Florida Fish and Wildlife biologists say the ground-dwelling pair may have been lured by onboard greenery and will return to Florida by air in mid-January for health checks and release into urban habitats familiar to them.

articles.title: ‘He’s living his best life’: drunk raccoon hit DMV for snacks before liquor store
articles.trailText: Officials say raccoon that broke into Virginia liquor store on 29 November had previously hit DMV and karate studio
articles.summary: In Hanover County, Virginia, a clever raccoon staged at least three break-ins on one block—helping itself to snacks at the DMV, ransacking a karate studio, then smashing bottles and downing liquor at the Ashland ABC store on November 29 before passing out in its bathroom. Animal protection officer Samantha Martin said the critter “knows how to get back in” and, after sobering up in a shelter, was released nearby rather than relocated. Officials joked it might face a hangover and “learn a lesson,” while a recent study linking urban raccoons’ shorter snouts and curlier tails to domestication highlights their adaptation to city life.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: More Epstein estate photos released as White House decries ‘Democrat hoax’
articles.trailText: Trump is featured in three images, while others feature Epstein with Bill Clinton, Steve Bannon and Woody Allen
articles.summary: House Democrats published 90 photos from Epstein’s estate including Trump in three images, drawing White House claims of ‘Democrat hoax.’ The oversight committee is probing Epstein’s network. Meanwhile, House Republicans unveiled a last-minute ACA healthcare plan that won’t extend Obamacare tax credits. US churches are using nativity scenes to protest ICE policies; lawmakers challenge the VA’s non-citizen database; a judge paused the re-detention of Kilmar Ábrego García; preservationists sued over Trump’s White House ballroom expansion. Catastrophic floods hit the Pacific Northwest; Trump urged the Fed to heed him; TPS for Ethiopians ends; Denmark accuses the US of economic coercion; Venezuelan opposition deems Maduro’s fall inevitable.

articles.title: 81 women file civil suit against army gynecologist already charged criminally
articles.trailText: Blaine McGraw is accused of inappropriately touching and secretly filming patients during appointments on base
articles.summary: Eighty-one women have expanded a November civil suit against Army Major and gynecologist Blaine McGraw of Fort Hood, Texas, alleging invasive, unnecessary and degrading touching, covert filming and voyeurism during on-base exams. McGraw, criminally charged days earlier with 54 counts of indecent visual recording involving 44 identified victims, now faces civil claims of assault, sexual assault and battery under Texas law. Plaintiffs cite secret photography during rape-kit exams and missing medical documentation that undermined survivors’ criminal cases. Legal observers say the case could test recent Pentagon reforms aimed at preventing military sexual misconduct and better supporting survivors.

articles.title: House Democrats release Epstein photos with Trump, Bannon, Clinton and others
articles.trailText: Notable figures in batch of images include Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, Woody Allen and Bill Gates
articles.summary: House Democrats published an initial batch of 19 ‘disturbing’ photographs from Jeffrey Epstein’s estate—among nearly 100,000 images obtained by a House oversight probe—showing Donald Trump, Bill Clinton, ex-royal Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, Woody Allen, Bill Gates, Richard Branson and Steve Bannon in social settings. The uncaptioned release, followed by 70 more photos of Epstein properties and novelty ‘Trumpkin’ items, prompted Democrats to demand transparency and justice for survivors, while White House and GOP critics accused them of cherry-picking images to score political points. A bill to free all Epstein records is pending compliance.

articles.title: Ancient lake reappears in Death Valley after record-breaking rains
articles.trailText: Repeated fall storms led to the temporary lake, known as Lake Manly, appearing in basin 282ft beneath sea level
articles.summary: After record rains from September to November—2.41 in total vs annual norm, November’s 1.76 in broke a 1923 record—Death Valley’s Badwater Basin (–282 ft) briefly refilled to create a thin Lake Manly. Smaller than the 2023 hurricane-fueled event that allowed kayaking, this ephemeral lake recalls the original pluvial body from 128,000–186,000 years ago when Sierra Nevada glacial melt filled a 100-mile lake. Amid rising extremes—recent 128 °F highs, 2023 floods and superblooms—experts warn of risks to desert flora, fauna and heat-tourism impacts.

articles.title: Trump sued by preservation group over $300m White House ballroom project
articles.trailText: National Trust looks to halt construction, claiming Trump tore down historic East Wing without needed permission
articles.summary: On Dec. 12, the National Trust for Historic Preservation sued President Trump and administration officials in US District Court (D.C.) to stop work on his $300 million, 90,000 sq ft White House ballroom addition. The group alleges Trump illegally demolished part of the historic East Wing in October without NEPA reviews, National Capital Planning Act approval or congressional consent, violating the Constitution’s property clause. They seek a temporary restraining order. A prior Voorhees suit was dismissed. Polls show 56–61% public opposition. Funded by donors like Meta, Microsoft, Amazon and Lockheed, with many contributions anonymous.

articles.title: House Democrats to ask for release of Jack Smith classified documents report
articles.trailText: Judiciary panel Democrats ask Aileen Cannon ahead of special counsel’s deposition next week
articles.summary: House Judiciary Committee Democrats will ask Judge Aileen Cannon to unseal the classified-document section of Special Counsel Jack Smith’s report on Donald Trump’s alleged mishandling of classified materials, arguing that charges against co-defendants have been dropped and courtroom rationale no longer applies. Smith is set for a closed-door deposition next week with the committee. Republicans led by Jim Jordan have subpoenaed him, while AG Pam Bondi and Cannon have withheld the report. Democrats warn that refusing disclosure undermines oversight and could face renewed subpoenas if they retake the House.

articles.title: Louisiana pastor convicted of abusing teenage congregant
articles.trailText: Milton Otto Martin III, who has been accused by several alleged victims of assault, convicted of indecent behavior
articles.summary: Milton Otto Martin III, 58, pastor of First Pentecostal Church in Chalmette, Louisiana, was convicted of indecent behavior with a juvenile but acquitted of statutory rape after a three-day trial. He faces up to seven years in prison, must register as a sex offender, and is due to be sentenced on January 15. The jury heard testimony from one victim who said Martin abused her between ages 15 and 17 during four-wheeler rides; other accusers have since come forward. A civil lawsuit against Martin and the church institutions is still pending.

articles.title: Indiana’s rejection of new voting map shows Trump’s might is not unlimited
articles.trailText: Defeat complicates the picture for Republicans across the US as they seek to redraw districts in an increasingly messy battle
articles.summary: Indiana’s GOP-controlled legislature rejected a Trump-backed congressional map that would have added two Republican seats, marking a rare defeat for the former president’s aggressive pressure campaign, which included personal appeals by JD Vance and threats from Heritage Action to withhold federal funding. Deterred by heavy-handed tactics and threats against lawmakers, senators voted the proposal down. The setback complicates national redistricting efforts as both parties vie for seats—Texas, North Carolina, California, Virginia, Florida—and underscores looming uncertainty over a Supreme Court ruling that could weaken key Voting Rights Act protections before next year’s midterms.

articles.title: Flooding remains threat in Pacific north-west as Washington declares emergency
articles.trailText: Torrential rain has caused mudslides, washed out roads and submerged vehicles with more deluges expected on Sunday
articles.summary: An atmospheric river dumped historic rainfall across the Pacific Northwest this week, triggering record flooding, mudslides and levee threats from Oregon through Washington into British Columbia. Washington governor Bob Ferguson declared a state emergency Wednesday; President Trump approved a federal disaster Friday. Over 100,000 residents faced evacuation orders, with National Guard, California rescue teams and local responders conducting dozens of water rescues. Major highways, rail lines and bridges were washed out or closed. Rivers remain near record crests and more rain is forecast, keeping flood risks high.

articles.title: ‘The holy family is in hiding’: nativity scenes at US churches push back on ICE
articles.trailText: Displays include handcuffed baby Jesus and Mary wearing a gas mask in wake of Trump’s immigration crackdown
articles.summary: Churches across the US have unveiled satirical nativity scenes criticizing Trump’s immigration enforcement, casting baby Jesus and his parents as ICE detainees. At Lake Street Church in Evanston, a zip-tied Jesus wrapped in a foil blanket lies in a manger while Mary wears a gas mask, flanked by ‘ICE’-vested Roman soldiers. Chicago’s Urban Village replaced holy figures with a sign ‘Due to ICE activity…the Holy Family is in hiding.’ Similar displays at St Susanna in Massachusetts removed Christ entirely under a sign ‘ICE was here.’ Faith leaders argue these protest art pieces draw direct parallels between the Holy Family’s refugee status and modern migrant experiences.

articles.title: ‘They attacked my religion, my faith’: Muslim photojournalist detained by ICE speaks out
articles.trailText: Ya’akub Vijandre, held in ICE detention in Georgia, tells Guardian he is concerned for safety of family and friends
articles.summary: Ya’akub Vijandre, a 38-year-old Muslim photojournalist and DACA recipient held at Georgia’s Folkston ICE facility since October, says he was detained and had his status revoked over social media posts the government deemed “glorifying terrorism.” He and his lawyers argue his posts on political prisoners and faith are protected speech and seize on religious bias. Vijandre describes harsh treatment by guards and fears for his family’s safety amid rising Islamophobia. His habeas corpus bid and bond request were denied, and his team warns the case tests the limits of executive detention powers.

articles.title: Judge issues temporary order to block officials from detaining Kilmar Ábrego García
articles.trailText: Ábrego was freed from immigration detention facility in Pennsylvania after federal judge ordered his release
articles.summary: Federal judge Paula Xinis issued a temporary restraining order barring ICE from re-detaining Kilmar Ábrego García until a full hearing, after he was freed from Pennsylvania custody following a Maryland court’s release order. Citing strong merits, the judge said upholding due process is vital. Ábrego, deported earlier to an El Salvador prison under Trump’s aggressive immigration policy, returned to Maryland where he lives with his US wife and child. He vowed to keep fighting additional deportation attempts and criminal charges while supporters rallied behind him. He also faces human smuggling charges in Tennessee.

articles.title: US agents increasingly arresting Afghan asylum seekers, lawyers say: ‘A huge chilling effect’
articles.trailText: Lawyers say people ‘don’t feel safe to leave their home’ as officials target recent arrivals and those awaiting hearings
articles.summary: Immigration agents across Indiana, New York and California have increasingly arrested Afghan asylum seekers—mostly men awaiting court hearings—despite many holding humanitarian parole or complying with ICE check-ins and electronic monitoring. Cases include Amir in Bloomington, cuffed without explanation, and another detainee in NYC. Lawyers warn of a “huge chilling effect,” as clients fear leaving home, exploring flight to Canada. These detentions follow policy shifts pausing asylum processing for 1.5 million people and halting green-card and citizenship applications for nationals of 19 countries. Attorneys say legal pathways remain unclear, immigration courts are strained, and Afghans face heightened uncertainty and peril.

articles.title: First Thing: Indiana Republicans reject effort to redraw voting maps in rebuke to Trump
articles.trailText: Measure to add two GOP-friendly seats failed 19-31 after 21 Republicans joined 10 Democrats. Plus, how the Paris climate treaty changed the world
articles.summary: Indiana’s Republican-controlled Senate voted down a GOP redistricting proposal 31-19 after 21 Republicans joined all 10 Democrats, refusing to add two new GOP-leaning seats and delivering a rare rebuke to former President Trump and JD Vance. Sen. Greg Goode led holdouts, citing constituent will, while Heritage Action threatened to strip federal funding, close guard bases and halt infrastructure projects if the map failed. The defeat spotlights intra-party resistance to Trump’s pressure tactics. Democrats have since countered Texas’s gerrymander push by unveiling new congressional maps in California.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president ‘sick of meetings’ as Ukraine-Russia peace deal talks drag on
articles.trailText: Trump’s press secretary suggested Trump was growing weary of process as Ukraine’s president under immense pressure to sign US deal – key US politics stories from 11 December 2025
articles.summary: White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt says President Trump is “sick of meetings” on Ukraine–Russia peace talks, urging Zelenskyy to endorse a plan that would create a Donbas “free economic zone” and require Ukrainian troop withdrawals without Russian advances. In other US political developments, senior lawmakers across parties criticize Trump’s seizure of a Venezuelan oil tanker; Indiana Republicans reject his proposed redistricting maps; the Senate spurns competing Obamacare subsidy extensions; protesters interrupt DHS chief Kristi Noem’s hearing; a grand jury again declines to indict a Trump critic; civil liberties groups blast a plan to vet visa applicants’ social media; and news emerges of a South Carolina measles outbreak, the release of an immigration detainee, growing ideological divisions in the military, expanded border militarization and election conspiracist Mike Lindell’s Minnesota gubernatorial bid.

articles.title: Trump signs executive order aimed at preventing states from regulating AI
articles.trailText: Order, which lacks the force of law, also creates taskforce whose ‘sole responsibility’ will be challenging states’ AI laws
articles.summary: Donald Trump issued an executive order to block state AI regulations and establish an AI Litigation Task Force at DOJ to challenge existing laws. The nonbinding measure revives a moratorium effort rejected by Congress and centralizes oversight to prevent 50-state approval processes.
