It instructs reviews of state rules on safety disclosures and bias risk assessments in jurisdictions like California and Colorado. Industry-backed, it drew criticism from governors and civil rights groups fearing unchecked Big Tech power and harm to vulnerable communities.

articles.title: Indiana Republicans reject effort to redraw voting maps in rebuke to Trump
articles.trailText: Measure to redistrict, which would add two GOP-friendly seats, failed 19-31 after 21 Republicans joined 10 Democrats
articles.summary: Indiana Senate rejected a Trump-backed GOP redistricting plan 19-31 after 21 Republicans joined 10 Democrats, thwarting a map that would have carved Indianapolis into four districts and split the northwest seat to add two GOP-friendly districts. Republicans currently hold seven of nine seats. Key holdout Sen. Greg Goode opposed the proposal on constituent and moral grounds. The vote marks a rebuke to Trump and JD Vance and follows nationwide GOP efforts, pressure campaigns, threats and Heritage Action warnings of federal funding cuts.

articles.title: Kilmar Ábrego García released from ICE custody in fight over Trump immigration
articles.trailText: Ábrego plans return to Maryland as DHS pledges to appeal judge’s decision, calling ruling ‘naked judicial activism’
articles.summary: Kilmar Ábrego García, a Salvadoran national and Maryland construction worker, was freed from ICE custody after Judge Paula Xinis ruled his detention unlawful without a final removal order. Ábrego, wrongfully deported in March to an El Salvador prison under Trump’s hardline immigration policy—where he endured beatings and torture—was returned to face human-smuggling charges in Tennessee. DHS, calling the decision “naked judicial activism,” plans to appeal as Ábrego prepares to reunite with his US-citizen wife and child in Maryland.

articles.title: Gas explosion in San Francisco Bay Area injures at least six people
articles.trailText: Explosion led to three-alarm blaze in Hayward, California, neighborhood after construction crew damaged a gas pipe
articles.summary: An explosion erupted around 9:30 am local time in Hayward when a third-party contractor working on a bike-lane and sidewalk expansion on Lewelling Boulevard struck a PG&E gas line at about 7:30 am. PG&E isolated the leak by 9:25 am, but at 9:35 am the line exploded into a three-alarm blaze that deployed eight engines and two trucks, injuring six people whose conditions are unknown. Flames and falling debris heavily damaged three buildings and caused minor to major damage to others. Residents shared dramatic doorbell-cam footage.

articles.title: Woman extradited to US to face charges immediately detained by ICE in ‘Kafkaesque’ twist
articles.trailText: Prosecutors had worked to secure extradition of Yana Leonova, but efforts unraveled when immigration officials issued order to deport her
articles.summary: Belarusian logistics manager Yana Leonova, indicted for smuggling $2m in US aircraft parts to Russia via Armenia, was extradited last month to face fraud, conspiracy and money laundering charges. Soon after, ICE issued a deportation order—her US stay authorization lapsed two weeks post-arrival—sparking a “Kafkaesque” standoff as prosecutors seek trial while DHS pushes removal. Magistrate Zia M Faruqui blasted the government for prioritizing deportation stats over criminal prosecution. Leonova, held in DC custody, has been in legal limbo since her arrest in France in September 2024.

articles.title: Grand jury again declines to indict Letitia James on mortgage fraud charges
articles.trailText: New York attorney general dodges indictment for second time in a week as Trump’s justice department seeks retribution
articles.summary: Federal grand jurors in Norfolk, Virginia, for the second time in a week declined to indict New York Attorney General Letitia James on 2020 mortgage fraud charges, marking an embarrassment for the Trump administration’s Justice Department. After a November ruling voided the initial indictment—filed under improperly appointed U.S. Attorney Lindsey Halligan—career prosecutors, recently ousted for resisting, balked at refiled charges alleging she mischaracterized a rented Norfolk home as a second residence. James denies wrongdoing and her attorney Abbe Lowell called further attempts a politicized mockery; prosecutors may still seek a third grand jury.

articles.title: Trump administration creates new militarized zone in California along southern US border
articles.trailText: Trump hands 760 acres of California public land to the navy for a new defense zone, deepening border militarization
articles.summary: Trump’s administration has transferred jurisdiction over 760 acres of public land in San Diego and Imperial counties to the US Navy for three years, creating a National Defense Area to bolster southern border security. The zone, spanning from Otay Mountain Wilderness to a mile west of the California–Arizona line, targets a high-traffic smuggling corridor, allows military to detain migrants and expand criminal charges, and complements over 7,000 service members and surveillance deployments. Critics note border arrests hit six-decade lows, while courts block some domestic troop deployments, ruling the administration exceeded legal authority.

articles.title: Mike Lindell, Trump ally and MyPillow founder, running for Minnesota governor
articles.trailText: Lindell, an election conspiracist who still maintains the 2020 election was stolen, joins a crowded Republican field
articles.summary: Mike Lindell, MyPillow CEO and election conspiracist, announced his Republican bid for Minnesota governor, joining a packed primary in the Democratic-leaning state. A prominent Trump ally, Lindell persists in false claims that 2020 was 'stolen,' facing multimillion-dollar defamation judgments and dire finances he dubs 'lawfare.' He’s backed by Rudy Giuliani’s advice and eyes a potential Trump endorsement to break through a field including state House Speaker Lisa Demuth and former candidate Scott Jensen. Incumbent Democrat Tim Walz seeks an unprecedented third term amid criticism over state fraud mishandling. Dems warn Lindell’s extremism jeopardizes Minnesotans’ priorities.

articles.title: US’s polarization affecting military ability to remain apolitical, says former joint chiefs chair
articles.trailText: Retired Adm Mike Mullen said political environment facing officers is difficult as ‘we have gotten so much more divided’
articles.summary: Retired Adm. Mike Mullen, speaking at an Aspen Institute forum, warned that the US military’s traditional apolitical stance is under unprecedented strain as deep ideological polarization now reaches junior officers. He cited recent purges of senior leaders—such as Gen. C.Q. Brown and Adm. Lisa Franchetti—and the Trump administration’s use of National Guard troops in domestic law-and-order roles as signs of politicization. Mullen cautioned that a broader pool of politically inexperienced officers fears costly missteps and criticized both a video by ex-service Democrat lawmakers urging resistance to unlawful orders and past abuses of military force against protesters.

articles.title: What we know about the oil tanker seized by the US off the Venezuela coast
articles.trailText: The Skipper, a tanker sanctioned by the US in 2022, is thought to have been carrying 1.1m barrels of Venezuelan oil
articles.summary: The US Coast Guard seized the Skipper, a 1.1m-barrel very large crude carrier (VLCC) off Venezuela’s coast under a judicial warrant, accusing it of operating as a sanctioned “shadow vessel” for Iran’s IRGC. Previously sanctioned in 2022 as Adisa, the tanker flew a false Guyana flag and is owned by US-sanctioned Triton Navigation. Loaded in Jose, it carried Venezuelan and Cuban state oil. The dramatic helicopter-borne raid, part of Operation Southern Spear, underscores US pressure on Maduro’s regime, will trigger forfeiture proceedings, and could drive up costs in the shadow tanker market.

articles.title: FDA to update regulations after unconfirmed claims of Covid vaccine-linked death
articles.trailText: Announcement, and lack of details in the weeks following, represents major departure from previous FDA priorities
articles.summary: FDA’s top vaccine official Vinay Prasad, under HHS Sec. Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s push, said he’s investigating unverified reports of 10 child Covid vaccine deaths and adult fatalities, promising regulatory overhaul soon. Experts including former CDC officer Debra Houry and Yale’s Jason Schwartz questioned the lack of evidence, transparency and advisory review. An FDA panel heard of new safety frameworks widening outcome nets and requiring randomized trials for groups like pregnant women and children. Critics warn this departure may hamper established vaccines, from flu to MMR.

articles.title: Senate rejects dual healthcare bills as Obamacare tax credits expiration nears
articles.trailText: Votes came as premium tax credits for estimated 21.8 million enrollees of plans set to expire at end of month
articles.summary: On December 11, the Senate rejected both a Democratic-backed three-year extension of ACA premium tax credits (51–48) and a GOP plan to deposit up to $1,000 in health savings accounts for enrollees. Without renewal, subsidies covering 21.8 million will expire at month’s end, risking a KFF-projected doubling of premiums. GOP Leader John Thune and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer traded barbs over Obamacare’s costs, while Donald Trump backed the HSA scheme. Similar bipartisan tax-credit and cap proposals are pending in the GOP-controlled House.

articles.title: Protesters interrupt Noem hearing with Exorcist line: ‘The power of Christ compels you!’
articles.trailText: Two protesters disrupted House panel hearing, with one yelling line made famous in 1973 horror film
articles.summary: Two protesters disrupted homeland security secretary Kristi Noem’s House committee hearing, invoking 'The power of Christ compels you' from The Exorcist while demanding end to ICE raids and deportations. They held 'Stop ICE raids,' 'Codepink,' 'No ICE, no troops' signs; were escorted out by Capitol police. Rep. Bennie Thompson called on Noem to resign over Trump-era immigration crackdowns. Noem defended DHS’s mission to 'make America safe,' noting family presence. The hearing unfolded amid public outrage over militarized immigration tactics—flash-bangs, armored vehicles, smartwatch tracking of pregnant migrants—and DHS’s new six-Boeing-737 deportation fleet contract under the largest deportation operation pledge.

articles.title: Why my letters would fail the Trump visa test | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: US visa edict | 1 No Trump | Flu advice | Costly candles | Christmas spirit
articles.summary: Letters to the Guardian critique four topics: Trump’s new US visa rule demanding five years of social media logs would bar anyone who ever bid “1 No Trump” in bridge; an NHS flu advisory should tell symptomatic patients to stay home rather than just wear masks; a £28 scented candle is luxuriously priced, not affordable for many; and Christmas spirit for one reader starts when milk’s “best before” dates roll into January.

articles.title: US lawmakers condemn seizure of Venezuelan oil tanker: ‘Trump is sleepwalking us into a war’
articles.trailText: Unease grows in Washington, including among some Republicans, over Trump administration’s escalating military posture in the Caribbean
articles.summary: Senior Democratic lawmakers and at least one Republican criticized Trump’s seizure of a Venezuelan oil tanker as evidence of an aggressive military posture aimed at regime change, warning he’s ‘sleepwalking us into a war.’ Senators Van Hollen, Paul, Coons and Warner decried the operation’s pretext of drug interdiction and its inconsistent priorities, while Schumer lamented Trump’s erratic messaging. Attorney General Bondi defended the seizure as targeting oil shipments fueling terrorism. Venezuela denounced it as piracy. A bipartisan war powers resolution to curb unauthorized military action is pending.

articles.title: ‘Censorship pure and simple’: critics hit out at Trump plan to vet visitors’ social media
articles.trailText: Some warn proposal will decimate US tourism industry as free speech advocates say it will lead to people self-censoring
articles.summary: President Trump’s DHS plans require ESTA tourists from 42 countries, including the UK, EU, Australia and Japan, to disclose five years of social media posts, phone numbers and ten years of email history before entry. Free speech groups and human rights advocates decry it as "censorship pure and simple," likening it to China, warning it will chill criticism, prompt self-censorship and devastate US tourism and the 2026 World Cup. Index on Censorship, Amnesty International UK, Big Brother Watch and HRW call it a breach of civil liberties. EU officials and ex-campaigners fear overreach, while Trump insists it’s about security.

articles.title: South Carolina officials report ‘accelerating’ measles outbreak
articles.trailText: Thanksgiving travel and low vaccination rates have contributed to 27 new cases in state during past week
articles.summary: South Carolina’s measles outbreak in Spartanburg county has “accelerated” post-Thanksgiving, with 111 confirmed cases—105 unvaccinated and three partially vaccinated—centered on a church and several schools. Health officials reported 27 new cases since Friday, 254 people quarantined and 16 in isolation. State vaccination coverage has dropped from 96% in 2020 to 93.5% in 2025; twenty cases involve children under five. The state surge adds to 1,912 national cases across 47 outbreaks, jeopardizing the US measles-elimination status. Officials blame low MMR uptake, underused mobile clinics and mixed federal vaccine messaging, and expect transmission to continue for weeks.

articles.title: First Thing: Venezuela decries ‘act of piracy’ after US forces seize oil tanker off country’s coast
articles.trailText: The move marks a major escalation of Trump’s pressure campaign against Nicolás Maduro. Plus, how Hasan Piker became one of the biggest voices on the US left
articles.summary: US forces have seized a crude oil tanker off Venezuela’s coast used to transport sanctioned Venezuelan and Iranian oil, marking an escalation of President Trump’s four-month pressure campaign on Nicolás Maduro’s regime. Trump and AG Pam Bondi confirmed the operation, executed by the FBI, Homeland Security Investigations, Coast Guard and Defense Department under a seizure warrant. Caracas denounced the move as a “blatant theft” and “act of international piracy” aimed at its natural resources. Exiled opposition leader María Corina Machado, in Oslo after months in hiding, endorsed the seizure as key to confronting Maduro’s alleged criminal government.

articles.title: ‘Somalis are the scapegoat’: fear rises as Trump targets Minneapolis community
articles.trailText: Residents have had to adjust how they’re living – staying home, carrying passports – since Trump launched his attack
articles.summary: After Trump branded Minneapolis’s Somali community “garbage” and launched DHS’s Operation Metro Surge to deport alleged “criminal illegal aliens,” the normally busy Karmel Mall has fallen silent. Somali Americans—84,000 mostly citizens or legal residents—now stay home, carry passports, skip appointments and set up volunteer block watches to film ICE. Local leaders, from Democratic Mayor Jacob Frey to GOP Senator Jim Abeler, condemn the scapegoating fueled by right-wing media coverage of fraud cases. Reports of US citizens detained overnight and mass cancellations of clinic visits have spurred telehealth and rapid-response medical rides, underscoring deep fear and community solidarity.

articles.title: ‘Human trafficking behind prison walls’: women jailed in Texas allege rampant sexual abuse
articles.trailText: Women at FMC Carswell – long a focus of sexual abuse investigations – say prison officials have turned a blind eye
articles.summary: Eleven women at FMC Carswell, a federal medical prison in Fort Worth, Texas, have filed lawsuits in DC since May accusing six staff members—including a doctor, chaplain and officers—of sexual assault, negligence, trafficking and battery over the past seven years. Carswell, with 13 staff convictions since 1997 and a 2022 Senate report naming it the most abusive federal women’s prison, faces fresh allegations of systemic inaction as internal records show few investigations lead to discipline. Plaintiffs highlight a culture of impunity, vulnerable inmates and stalled PREA enforcement amid DOJ funding shifts.

articles.title: ‘I love when my enemies hate me’: how Hasan Piker became one of the biggest voices on the US left
articles.trailText: Every day he broadcasts a marathon Twitch stream, airing his views to his three million followers. It has led to fame – and some fear – in a country ever more politically divided
articles.summary: Hasan Piker, a 34-year-old Turkish-American, has built a 3 million-follower Twitch audience through daily seven-hour livestreams blending politics, gaming and memes. Emerging from The Young Turks, he’s become an outspoken social democrat and vocal critic of Trump, Israel and US foreign policy, while leveraging his physique to defy left-wing stereotypes. Frequent controversies—from a “9/11” remark and dog-collar conspiracy to China praise—have triggered suspensions, online harassment and border detentions. Embracing the backlash, Piker stresses the online/offline divide, urges real-world organizing over parasociality, and plans to stay on Twitch rather than enter traditional media.

articles.title: Venezuela decries ‘act of piracy’ after US forces seize oil tanker off country’s coast
articles.trailText: Footage uploaded to X by US attorney general shows its forces landing on the tanker in major escalation of Trump’s pressure campaign
articles.summary: US forces seized a crude oil tanker off Venezuela’s coast, marking a significant escalation of Donald Trump’s four-month pressure campaign against Nicolás Maduro. Footage shared by AG Pam Bondi shows a helicopter boarding; the vessel was sanctioned for transporting Venezuelan and Iranian oil to fund terrorist networks. Venezuela’s government denounced the action as piracy. Since 2019 US sanctions on Venezuelan oil have deepened, including a $50m bounty on Maduro and the largest Caribbean naval deployment since the Cuban Missile Crisis. Opposition leader María Corina Machado received the Nobel Peace Prize amid talks of a possible oil blockade.

articles.title: Immigrant students experience more bullying as ICE raids cause ‘culture of fear’, says survey
articles.trailText: In survey, US school principals describe ‘climate of distress’ and declines in student attendance amid crackdowns
articles.summary: Nationally representative survey of 600+ US high school principals by UCLA’s IDEA reveals ICE raids have created a ‘culture of fear’ driving bullying, anxiety and learning losses among immigrant students. Seventy percent reported students expressing concern for family safety, 58% saw parents relocate, 64% linked absences to immigration rhetoric and over a third documented harassment; some principals were unsure of missing students’ whereabouts. Seventy-eight percent of schools have federal-agent response plans and half prepare for guardian deportations. DHS labels the study ‘fear-mongering.’

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Seizure of oil tanker marks new level of tensions between US and Venezuela
articles.trailText: Trump also said Colombia’s president ‘will be next’ as he announced major escalation in US pressure on Nicolás Maduro
articles.summary: US forces seized a crude-oil tanker off Venezuela’s coast under a warrant targeting sanctioned Venezuelan and Iranian oil, escalating Trump’s campaign against Nicolás Maduro. Trump unveiled a $1m golden visa program with a $5m tier; Fed cut rates by 25 bps amid FOMC split; Dem senator opened an insider-trading probe into Trump donors; DHS contracted ~$140m Boeing 737 deportation fleet; CBP to vet five years of visitor social media; judge blocked federal Guard deployment in LA; Germany’s AfD backs nationalist revival; plus emergency in Washington, FDA RSV shot review, abortion-pill lawsuits, RFK Jr impeachment and NASA Mars orbiter contact loss.

articles.title: US House passes bill authorizing $900bn for military programs
articles.trailText: Legislation includes pay increase for troops and a demand for more information about boat strikes in the Caribbean
articles.summary: House approved 312–112 a $900 billion defense policy bill (NDAA) authorizing a 3.8 percent military pay raise, housing and facility upgrades, procurement reform, and congressional oversight of lethal boat strikes in the Caribbean—tying travel funds cuts to release of video footage. It allocates $400 million annually for Ukraine weapons aid, mandates at least 76,000 troops in Europe and 28,500 in Korea, trims $1.6 billion climate and $40 million DEI funds, repeals the 2003 Iraq War AUMF, ends Syria sanctions, and removes IVF coverage expansion. Now moves to the Senate.

articles.title: US House passes bill to bolster Europe’s defence, in apparent rebuke to Trump’s foreign policy strategy
articles.trailText: The 2026 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) carries $8bn more than the funding Trump requested in May
articles.summary: The US House approved the 2026 National Defense Authorization Act, boosting European defense amid backlash to Trump’s foreign policy and adding $8bn above his request. The bill bars troop levels in Europe from falling below 76,000 for more than 45 days, prohibits major equipment removals, secures $400m in baseline Ukraine aid, and strengthens NATO’s northeastern flank and Baltic states. It also limits cuts to US forces in South Korea and targets diversity and inclusion programs. The 3,086-page measure now goes to the Senate; Trump has signaled he will sign it.

articles.title: Washington state governor declares emergency amid heavy rains and floods
articles.trailText: Bob Ferguson says he has also activated the state’s national guard to respond to the flooding
articles.summary: After an AR5 atmospheric river dumped heavy rain across Washington state, Governor Bob Ferguson declared a statewide emergency, activated up to 300 National Guard troops and sought expedited federal aid to cover mudslide damage, washed-out roads and rising rivers—including the Carbon, Cedar and Snohomish. Farmers near the Snoqualmie reported unprecedented barn flooding. The storm, one of the strongest since 1959, could drop up to 4″ at low elevations and 10″ in the Cascades, hampering travel, prompting evacuations along I-5 and mobile-home parks, and heightening flood and debris-flow risk in fire-scarred slopes.

articles.title: No arrests or suspects in mass shooting at toddler’s birthday party in California
articles.trailText: Stockton officials predict months-long investigation into 29 November killing of four people, including three children
articles.summary: Stockton, CA officials report no arrests or suspects a week after the Nov. 29 mass shooting at a toddler’s birthday party that killed four, including three children, and injured 17. Investigators have recovered 50 shell casings and believe five guns were used, but motives remain unknown and probes may take months. Victims’ families and local leaders decry media focus on alleged gang ties over the losses of eight-year-olds Journey Rose Reotutar Guerrero and Maya Lupian, 14-year-old Amari Peterson and 21-year-old Susano Archuleta. Stockton vice-mayor Jason Lee blasts underfunded violence-prevention efforts amid calls for greater state support.

articles.title: Montana youth activists who won landmark climate case push for court enforcement
articles.trailText: In 2023, court ruled in favor of 16 plaintiffs that officials violated their constitutional right by promoting fossil fuels
articles.summary: Thirteen of the original 16 youth plaintiffs from Held v. Montana petitioned the state supreme court to enforce their August 2023 victory, which ruled unconstitutional state laws barring climate impacts from environmental reviews. They challenge 2025 legislation that caps state air quality standards at federal levels, limits greenhouse gas inventories to six gases, excludes upstream/downstream emissions and forbids agencies from using emission data to deny permits. Backed by Our Children’s Trust, they argue these measures violate Montana’s constitutional right to a clean environment and seek to strike down the new laws to empower agencies to condition or deny fossil fuel projects.

articles.title: Trump launches $1m ‘gold card’ visa scheme amid immigration crackdown
articles.trailText: Wealthy immigrants will be able to buy residency, and $5m ‘platinum card’ will exempt holders from some US taxes
articles.summary: Donald Trump unveiled a “Gold Card” scheme allowing wealthy foreigners to secure US residency for $1 million plus a $15 000 DHS processing fee and vetting; companies sponsoring employees pay $2 million upfront, a 1% annual maintenance fee and a 5% transfer fee. A $5 million “Platinum Card,” granting up to 270 days in the US without US tax on non-US income, is slated to follow. Launched by executive order amid aggressive immigration enforcement, the program—discounted from an initial $5 million—faces criticism for favoring the wealthy but aims to boost US talent and generate billions for national projects.

articles.title: US signs nearly $140m deal to purchase six Boeing 737s for use in deportations
articles.trailText: Funds for contract signed with Daedalus Aviation will come from $170bn allocated for Trump’s border policy
articles.summary: The DHS has inked a $140m contract with Virginia-based Daedalus Aviation to acquire six Boeing 737s for deportation operations, funded from the $170bn Trump administration border policy allocation. DHS claims $279m in taxpayer savings via efficient flight patterns. This follows a shelved bid for Spirit Airlines jets and aligns with record deportation metrics—1,701 flights to 77 countries and 500,000 removals—and has drawn scrutiny over detainee profiles and data transparency.

articles.title: Trump continues to sow chaos and division after winning Fifa peace prize
articles.trailText: The US president praised an autocrat, said Europe should ‘send back’ asylum seekers and compared Ukraine’s leader to a conman
articles.summary: After receiving FIFA’s inaugural peace prize from ally Gianni Infantino, President Trump used a Politico interview to sow division: praising autocrats Viktor Orbán and Javier Milei, urging Europe to ‘send back’ Congolese asylum seekers, mocking London mayor Sadiq Khan as ‘vicious’, launching racist attacks on Somali migrants and Ilhan Omar, bungling Crimea’s geography, likening Zelenskyy to P.T. Barnum, rambling “I have eyes. I have ears,” and even deriding birthright citizenship while dog-whistling about “Barack Hussein Obama,” a performance critics say undermines any peace credentials.

articles.title: Tourists to US would have to reveal five years of social media activity under new Trump plan
articles.trailText: Plan would apply to countries not currently required to get visas to the US, including Britain and France
articles.summary: Under a new Trump administration rule, tourists from the 42 visa-exempt countries—including Britain, France, Australia, Germany and Japan—would have to disclose five years of social media posts, phone numbers, ten years of emails and submit biometrics (face, fingerprint, DNA, iris) plus family details before obtaining ESTA. Framed as ensuring visitors lack "hostile attitudes," the measure follows broader visa crackdowns—on student, H-1B and journalist applicants—and adds $100 per-day park fees. With US tourism already slumping and the 2026 World Cup looming, critics warn of chilling free speech, privacy invasions and travel deterrence. A two-month public comment window is now open.

articles.title: Judge blocks Trump administration’s deployment of national guard troops in Los Angeles
articles.trailText: Judge ordered the guard, deployed to the city in June, returned to the control of the California governor
articles.summary: US District Judge Charles Breyer blocked the Trump administration’s federalization of California’s National Guard in Los Angeles, ordering roughly 100 remaining troops returned to Gov. Gavin Newsom’s control. The court rejected federal claims that late protests against immigration enforcement constituted a rebellion justifying continued federal command. Breyer had earlier deemed the June deployment illegal and granted a preliminary injunction—paused until Monday—against the administration’s extension through February. White House and state officials dispute the move’s legality, echoing reversals in other cities.

articles.title: Brad Lander to challenge Dan Goldman for New York congressional seat
articles.trailText: Outgoing comptroller and progressive ally of Zohran Mamdani launches primary bid for Congress
articles.summary: Brad Lander, outgoing NYC comptroller and former mayoral candidate, is challenging Democratic Rep. Dan Goldman in the Manhattan–northwest Brooklyn primary. Endorsed by mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani and Sen. Bernie Sanders, Lander pledges to fight economic inequality, corporate influence and defend immigrants after his arrest by ICE at an immigration hearing. Goldman, a two-term congressman who led Trump’s first impeachment defense, supports higher taxes on the wealthy, immigrant-court protections and the Green New Deal. The race highlights a progressive-versus-moderate tug within New York Democrats.

articles.title: A Democratic mayor for Miami is not just Trump backlash – it’s a seismic shift
articles.trailText: Eileen Higgins’s win has reset the city’s political landscape in some ways not seen in 28 years, and in others not at all
articles.summary: Democrat Eileen Higgins ended 28 years of GOP rule as Miami’s mayor, winning the runoff with nearly 60% over Trump-backed Emilio González. She’s the city’s first woman, first Democrat since 1997 and first non-Hispanic mayor in decades. Her victory in a majority-foreign-born city signals backlash against Trump and DeSantis’s tough immigration agenda (TPS cuts, Everglades detentions) and suggests Hispanic voters may swing away from Republicans ahead of the 2026 midterms.

articles.title: Michigan Democrat moves to impeach RFK Jr, alleging ‘abuse of authority’
articles.trailText: Haley Stevens accuses health secretary of undermining public health, but Republican-run House is unlikely to act
articles.summary: Michigan Rep. Haley Stevens filed articles of impeachment against Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., accusing him of abusing authority, undermining science and public health by spreading conspiracies, hiking costs, restricting vaccines and slashing research funding. With Republicans controlling the House and Democratic leaders withholding support, the measure faces slim prospects. HHS spokesman says Kennedy remains focused on lowering costs and improving health, while critics including six former U.S. surgeons general warn his policies sow vaccine distrust, erode scientific institutions and jeopardize national health security.

articles.title: US health officials re-examine RSV shots despite documented safety and efficacy
articles.trailText: The FDA is reviewing RSV vaccines, which have drastically lowered infant hospitalizations, a spokesperson confirmed
articles.summary: Under HHS Secretary RFK Jr, the FDA has launched a safety review of three RSV vaccines for infants and maternal shots despite no new safety concerns and evidence showing 55–83% efficacy in preventing hospitalizations. Critics warn this re-examination—prompted by anti-vaccine activists—risks limiting access to shots that cut infant RSV admissions by two-thirds, undermining hard-won public trust and progress against the leading cause of infant respiratory illness. New vaccine advisers replaced previous ACIP experts, halting maternal working groups despite reassurances from former advisers that trial data showed no pre-term birth risks.

articles.title: Zelenskyy ‘ready for elections’ after Trump questions Ukrainian democracy | First Thing
articles.trailText: Ukraine’s president to look at holding wartime vote. Plus, the hidden life of Matthew Perry
articles.summary: Ukraine’s president Volodymyr Zelenskyy said he is ready to hold a wartime national election within the next three months if Ukraine’s parliament and foreign allies agree, responding to Donald Trump’s recent allegation in a Politico interview that Zelenskyy is clinging to power and eroding Ukrainian democracy. Zelenskyy’s five-year term expired last May, but the constitution bars elections during active conflict. Despite his irritation at Trump’s intervention, Zelenskyy pledged to explore all legal, security and diplomatic avenues for a vote while the war goes on.

articles.title: Wrong voters, wrong message: progressives’ autopsy lays bare Kamala Harris failures
articles.trailText: RootsAction report finds Harris courted moderates instead of working-class Democrats – and Gaza stance did not help
articles.summary: RootsAction’s autopsy blames Harris’s loss on courting moderate Republicans over working-class, young and progressive Democrats, driving turnout down: she received 6.8 m fewer votes than Biden in 2020, while Trump gained 2.8 m. With just 107 days to run, “joyful” Bidenomics messaging, failure to break from Biden on Gaza and corporate-influenced advisers further alienated core voters. Mirroring 2016 Clinton missteps, the report urges Democrats to embrace bold economic populism, curb corporate contributions and realign foreign policy on Israel.

articles.title: Oklahoma man allegedly holds up liquor store with ‘old timey musket’
articles.trailText: Local police say Dyllon Redfern, 24, brandished a derringer from the 19th century after being asked for his ID
articles.summary: Tulsa police say 24-year-old Dyllon Redfern went to Primo’s Wine and Spirits on Dec. 5, was refused service for lack of ID, then returned in pajamas wielding a single-shot, percussion-style derringer—an 1850s “muff” pocket pistol—and demanded cash and IDs. Officers later found him in a nearby QuikTrip garage with stolen money, a customer’s ID and the antique firearm, which experts call rare and valuable. Redfern faces first-degree robbery charges and at least 10 years in prison.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president hints at abandoning Ukraine, rambles about ‘weak’ Europe
articles.trailText: Trump’s sometimes incoherent Politico interview featured recycled far-right tropes about European immigration
articles.summary: In a rambling, sometimes incoherent Politico interview transcript released Tuesday, President Trump hinted he may walk away from supporting Ukraine, misnaming cities beyond Kyiv and misrepresenting the conflict’s trajectory. He lambasted a “weak, decaying” Europe as “destroying itself” through a “disaster” immigration policy echoing far-right “great replacement” tropes—warned some nations “won’t be viable”—and urged Zelenskyy to cede territory to Russia, claiming Moscow holds the “upper hand” and Ukraine must “play ball.”

articles.title: Trump rails on affordability ‘hoax’ and flings racist attacks in rally-style speech
articles.trailText: President sought to rehab image after criticism of being out of touch, but speech aimed at midterms took different turn
articles.summary: At a rally-style event at Mount Pocono casino in NE Pennsylvania, Trump sought to reclaim the economic narrative, denouncing affordability concerns as a ‘hoax’ and blaming Democrats for high prices. In a 90-minute freewheeling address, he mixed policy posturing—boasting of tariffs, claiming trillions in tariff revenue and new auto and AI plant investments, a $12bn farm bailout and ‘reverse migration’—with racist attacks, targeting Ilhan Omar with baseless brother-marriage claims and revisiting his ‘shithole countries’ slur. Trump gave the economy an ‘A++++,’ despite 33% approval ratings, as he pivots to a midterms campaign blending economic populism and xenophobia.

articles.title: Fact check: Trump’s racist and false claims on immigration and cost of living
articles.trailText: US president’s speech veered into baseless attacks on inflation, migrants and Ilhan Omar as he revived grievances
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s speech in Pennsylvania, billed as an affordability address, devolved into baseless inflation boasts and xenophobic attacks. He wrongly said prices “way down,” mischaracterized turkey costs, boasted crushing inflation and claimed he inherited worst inflation ever. He repeated racist lies about Ilhan Omar’s refugee status and marriage, disparaged Somalia, and spouted false stats on immigrants taking all new jobs and Venezuelan/Congolese prisoners flooding the US. He defended unverified boat strikes, made absurd transgender and Black voter claims, and peddled 2020 election fraud myths.

articles.title: Two US fighter jets circle Gulf of Venezuela in escalation of hostilities
articles.trailText: Trump had further said Nicolás Maduro’s ‘days are numbered’ as military has targeted alleged drug boats
articles.summary: Two US F/A-18 Super Hornets and two EA-18G Growler electronic warfare jets circled the Gulf of Venezuela for 40 minutes north of Maracaibo on Dec. 9, tracked in real time by FlightRadar24 as the site’s most-watched flights. Venezuela asserts the gulf falls within its territorial waters, but the Pentagon labels the mission a “routine, lawful” operation in international airspace. The patrol coincides with rising tensions over the Trump administration’s drug-war rebranding of traffickers as enemy combatants—87 killed to date—and congressional outcry over potential extrajudicial killings. President Trump reiterated Maduro’s “days are numbered” and promised land strikes against narcotraffickers.

articles.title: Eileen Higgins becomes Miami’s first Democratic mayor in 30 years
articles.trailText: In stunning upset victory, Higgins also becomes first woman in post and first non-Hispanic candidate since 90s
articles.summary: Democrat Eileen Higgins, 61, a former county commissioner, won Miami’s mayoral run-off, becoming the city’s first Democratic mayor since 1997, first woman, and first non-Hispanic in decades. Higgins defeated Republican ex-city manager Emilio González by about 19 points, reversing Miami-Dade’s swing to Trump in 2024. Her campaign framed the race as a referendum on federal immigration policies and garnered strong grassroots support—over 300,000 phone calls—highlighting local concerns over deportations, housing and insurance costs. National and local Democrats view her upset victory as a sign of growing resistance to Trump-era agendas and a bellwether for future elections.

articles.title: Powerful storms dump heavy rain and swell rivers across US Pacific north-west
articles.trailText: Crews conduct high-water rescues in Washington, and flood watches put in effect along coast down to Oregon
articles.summary: An atmospheric river unleashed heavy rain across western Washington and NW Oregon, swelling rivers, flooding roads and stranding vehicles, while over a foot of snow fell in the northern Rockies and NW Wyoming. Crews used inflatable kayaks near Seattle to rescue drivers and a hiker trapped by rising water. Power outages and school closures spread as forecasters warned major rivers will crest later this week and another storm will arrive Sunday, extending an unsettled pattern through the holidays. Meanwhile, an Arctic blast in southeast Alaska threatens wind chills near –50°F, and a fast-moving system brings freezing rain, heavy snow and high winds across the upper Midwest, triggering no-travel advisories.

articles.title: ‘We call him ... unbearable’: California homeowner laments uninvited beast
articles.trailText: The 550lb bear living under Ken Johnson’s home for two weeks is unmoved by ‘lure’, with caramel and cherry smells
articles.summary: A 550 lb black bear, tagged “2120,” has lived for over two weeks in the crawl space of Ken Johnson’s Altadena home, impervious to sweet caramel-and-cherry lures and ammonia-soaked towels. Displaced wildlife have sought refuge in the community since the January Eaton wildfire that scorched the Angeles National Forest. California Fish and Wildlife biologists set up remote cameras and scent baits to coax 2120 into a transport cart for relocation about 10 miles away. Though black bears rarely harm humans, Johnson, a 63-year-old photographer, worries about nightly growls and unseen damage beneath his floorboards, reflecting a rise in bear sightings across LA’s foothill neighborhoods.

articles.title: Trump officials move to scrap Biden student-loan repayment plan
articles.trailText: Education department announces plans to halt ‘illegal’ Save program as critics call news ‘devastating’ for borrowers
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s education department reached a settlement with seven GOP-led states to end President Biden’s “illegal” Save program, halting new enrollments, denying pending applications and shifting more than seven million borrowers into alternative repayment plans if approved by a Missouri federal court. Save cut payments to as low as $0, halved undergraduate payments and promised early forgiveness. Education Under-Secretary Nicholas Kent called Save a taxpayer burden, while Missouri AG Catherine Hanaway praised Trump’s “real solutions.” Advocates Persis Yu and Natalie Abrams warned the move is “devastating,” stripping affordable terms, prolonging borrower confusion and inflating financial strain amid the $1.6 trillion student-debt crisis.

articles.title: Officers at Texas immigration detention facility accused of beatings and sexual abuse
articles.trailText: Civil rights coalition calls for immediate closure of camp, where more than 2,700 detainees are being held
articles.summary: A coalition of eight civil-rights groups (including the ACLU, HRW and Texas Civil Rights Project) alleges systemic abuse at ICE’s Camp East Montana on Fort Bliss, Texas: officers beat and sexually assault detainees, deny medical care and use failing tent housing for 2,700+ migrants. Non-Mexican asylum seekers from Cuba and Guatemala report masked agents shackling them, then driving them to Santa Teresa to “jump” the US-Mexico border wall under threat of imprisonment, bypassing due-process. The groups demand immediate closure; DHS and ICE deny all claims, insisting conditions meet standards.

articles.title: This swine life: pig named Six Seven pardoned by Miami-Dade mayor
articles.trailText: Daniella Levine Cava wished the piglet ‘a long happy life’ in speech alluding to the several pardons issued by Trump
articles.summary: Daniella Levine Cava, Miami-Dade’s mayor, ceremonially pardoned Six Seven, a piglet at Little Havana’s Latin Cafe 2000, in a playful nod to presidential pardon rituals and alluding to Trump’s prolific clemencies. Donated by a Coral Gables firefighter and named after a viral slang term, the pig—blameless except for eating “six or seven apples” daily—will retire to a rural sanctuary. The holiday event, featuring vegetarian spinach croquetas and cafecito, blends cultural traditions, community spirit and commentary on pardon excess amid Miami’s diverse festive season.

articles.title: Organizers submit enough signatures to block gerrymandered Missouri map
articles.trailText: More than 300,000 signatures delivered to secretary of state to force referendum on Republican-drawn map
articles.summary: People Not Politicians delivered over 300,000 signatures—nearly three times the Missouri constitutional threshold—to Secretary of State Denny Hoskins, seeking to block a newly approved Republican-drawn congressional map and force a referendum. The map, passed in September, eliminates Democrat Emanuel Cleaver’s Kansas City district in favor of a GOP seat, part of a broader Trump-led effort to redraw battleground districts ahead of midterms. Hoskins is reviewing and may discard about 100,000 signatures as prematurely collected; verification could take eight to ten weeks or extend into summer, during which the new map remains paused. Meanwhile, Attorney General Catherine Hanaway has filed legal challenges to halt the referendum process.

articles.title: New Trump doctrine identifies ‘weak’ Europe’s problem: not enough racism
articles.trailText: A new US national security strategy represents one of the most profound crises for the Atlantic alliance since 1945
articles.summary: In his new US National Security Strategy and Politico interview, Donald Trump portrays Europe as culturally diluted and weak, blaming immigration and multiculturalism, and advocating support for far-right parties. His racist worldview now frames the Atlantic alliance as undeserving partners. By refusing to pay lip service to European security and denying responsibility, Trump aids Russia’s strategy to destabilize NATO amid the Ukraine war and rising Russian provocations. European leaders, from Germany’s Friedrich Merz to the UK, face mounting pressure to confront rather than appease his transactional diplomacy. The era of dismissing Trump’s rhetoric as mere bluster is over.

articles.title: New York archdiocese seeks $300m to settle claims by clergy abuse survivors
articles.trailText: Largest US Catholic archdiocese is raising funds, selling assets and cutting costs to compensate about 1,300 victims
articles.summary: The New York archdiocese is raising a $300m settlement fund for about 1,300 clergy abuse survivors, trimming its budget by 10%, laying off staff and selling over $100m in Manhattan real estate. It’s engaging retired judge Daniel J. Buckley as mediator ahead of a 2026 civil trial, while attorney Jeff Anderson—representing 300 survivors—demands full disclosure and abuse-prevention measures. Cardinal Timothy Dolan issued a formal apology. The move parallels a $305m New Orleans settlement. Unlike Los Angeles’s record $880m accord, New York hasn’t filed for bankruptcy and is contesting Chubb insurers’ refusal to cover longstanding claims.

articles.title: Trump had two mortgages he claimed were primary dwellings, records show
articles.trailText: President did same thing his administration is now calling ‘mortgage fraud’ in case against Fed governor Lisa Cook
articles.summary: ProPublica records show that in late 1993 and early 1994, Donald Trump took out mortgages on two adjacent Palm Beach homes, each sworn as his principal residence but rented out instead while he remained at Trump Tower, only formally relocating to Florida in 2019. His administration now calls identical dual‐primary‐residence loans “mortgage fraud” in cases against Fed governor Lisa Cook and others. Trump defends the 1990s Merrill Lynch‐financed loans—$525,000 and $1.2 m subject to occupancy rules—saying no laws were broken; both mortgages are long paid off and beyond fraud statutes.

articles.title: Nancy Mace escalated airport incident into ‘spectacle’, police investigation says
articles.trailText: Republican congresswoman berated TSA personnel in October with profanity and insults, leaving facility employees ‘visibly upset’
articles.summary: An internal Charleston airport police probe found South Carolina Republican congresswoman Nancy Mace turned a minor miscommunication about her car color into a "spectacle" on October 30. Mace reportedly berated TSA and airport officers with profanity—calling them "fucking idiots" and declaring "I’m sick of your shit"—and left staff "visibly upset." The report notes prior clashes over procedure and says poor communication and staff turnover partly contributed. Mace’s office called it a "full exoneration." Running for governor in 2026, she has threatened to sue over the incident, citing personal safety concerns.

articles.title: Trump lambasts ‘weak’ and ‘decaying’ Europe and hints at walking away from Ukraine
articles.trailText: US president recycles far-right tropes on European immigration and presses Zelenskyy to accept his peace plan
articles.summary: In a wide-ranging Politico interview, President Trump derided Europe as "weak" and "decaying," recycled "great replacement" immigration tropes, and hinted he may pull US backing from Ukraine unless President Zelenskyy accepts his proposal to cede territory to Russia in exchange for vague US security guarantees by Christmas. Struggling to name Ukrainian cities beyond Kyiv, Trump also refused to rule out sending troops to Venezuela and praised Hungary’s Viktor Orbán. His blistering remarks prompted German Chancellor Friedrich Merz, EU foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas and European Council President António Costa to condemn US interference, while Pope Leo XIV warned these policies threaten the transatlantic alliance.

articles.title: Over 200 ex-staffers decry destruction of DoJ civil rights arm: ‘America deserves better’
articles.trailText: Former employees from justice department’s civil rights division accuse Trump administration of purging experts
articles.summary: Over 200 former DOJ civil rights division employees signed a letter condemning the Trump administration’s purge of career experts, warning that political appointees under Harmeet Dhillon displaced or detailed attorneys, dropped enforcement of voting rights, migrant child abuse and police consent decrees, and refocused the division on rare voter fraud and antisemitism probes. By May, 70% of attorneys had left. Released by Justice Connection on its 68th anniversary, the letter urges Americans to demand the Division’s return to core civil rights enforcement.

articles.title: Man dies of rabies after kidney transplant from donor who saved kitten from skunk
articles.trailText: Michigan man received kidney transplant from donor who had fought off a skunk and was later found unresponsive
articles.summary: CDC reports a Michigan man died of rabies five weeks after receiving a kidney transplant in December 2024 from an Idaho donor who’d been scratched by a skunk while defending a kitten. The recipient’s post-transplant symptoms—tremors, lower extremity weakness, confusion and incontinence—led to postmortem rabies confirmation. Initial donor tests were negative, but kidney biopsies revealed a silver-haired bat–related strain, indicating a bat-to-skunk-to-donor-to-recipient transmission chain. This marks the fourth US transplant-transmitted rabies case since 1978. Three cornea recipients received PEP and remain asymptomatic. CDC underscores the rarity and diagnostic challenges of donor rabies screening.

articles.title: Florida declares US Muslim civil rights group a foreign terrorist organization
articles.trailText: Ron DeSantis’s legally dubious order designating Cair – and Muslim Brotherhood – follows similar move by Texas
articles.summary: Florida governor Ron DeSantis has issued an executive order designating the Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR) and the Muslim Brotherhood as foreign terrorist organizations, a power reserved for the federal government. Mirroring a November decree by Texas governor Greg Abbott, DeSantis alleges CAIR’s founders have ties to the Muslim Brotherhood and Hamas. CAIR’s chapters condemn the order as Islamophobic, defamatory, and unconstitutional, vow to sue, and highlight decades of civil rights advocacy. The order directs state agencies to deny privileges or material support, while state legislators consider anti-Sharia law measures.

articles.title: He was called one of the most violent prison guards in America. He got promoted
articles.trailText: Roderick Gadson showed no remorse after beating a man to death. A new film, The Alabama Solution, shows how the case lays bare a culture of violence the state has long failed to control
articles.summary: Alabama corrections lieutenant Roderick Gadson, long accused of excessive force in at least 26 civil suits, was promoted twice after a 2019 beating that killed prisoner Steven Davis. Despite DOJ findings of systemic brutality and internal reviews clearing him, Gadson now features prominently in HBO’s The Alabama Solution, which exposes pervasive violence and a culture of impunity across the state’s overcrowded, understaffed prisons. Lawmakers like Rep. Chris England and advocacy groups demand his firing, citing half-million-dollar settlements and racial disparities in inmate deaths. Gadson’s defenders cite security challenges, but critics say his unchecked record symbolizes Alabama’s failure to reform corrections.

articles.title: Abbott moves to bring Charlie Kirk’s Turning Point USA into Texas schools
articles.trailText: The governor touts ‘urgency and a need’ for Club America chapters amid criticism of influence on students
articles.summary: Texas governor Greg Abbott and lieutenant governor Dan Patrick announced plans to establish Turning Point USA and its high-school arm Club America chapters in more than 500 Texas high schools, citing an “urgency” to counter perceived left-wing indoctrination. TPUSA, founded by the late Charlie Kirk, reported 54,000 inquiries post-shooting and aims for 20,000 chapters nationwide. Abbott warned schools blocking clubs will face discipline and TEA reports. Critics—teachers, parents and legal foes—decry TPUSA’s anti-LGBTQ+, racist, sexist stances and challenge use of public resources for partisan programming.

articles.title: Cheryl Hines says Robert F Kennedy Jr won’t run for president in 2028
articles.trailText: The actor’s remark comes amid renewed news coverage and commentary about her husband’s 2024 presidential bid
articles.summary: Actor Cheryl Hines told NewsNation’s Elizabeth Vargas she doesn’t expect husband Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to mount a 2028 presidential campaign, despite his previous political pivots—from Democratic hopeful to independent to endorsing Donald Trump after losing in 2024. Appointed by Trump as health secretary, Kennedy backed CDC advisers’ controversial decision to narrow hepatitis B vaccine guidelines for newborns, reversing a policy credited with a 99% drop in pediatric cases since 1990. His allegiances put him among possible GOP successors alongside VP JD Vance and Sec. of State Marco Rubio.

articles.title: New York City braces for new casinos as gambling surge in US worries experts
articles.trailText: Three proposed casinos approved as researchers say they take money from businesses and increase addiction
articles.summary: New York City’s gaming facility location board approved three commercial casinos—Hard Rock Met Park by Citi Field, Resorts World expansion in Queens, and Bally’s Bronx resort—projected to open within five years, generating $7 billion in tax revenue and thousands of jobs. Proponents cite union construction and service positions plus community benefits like parks and subway upgrades. Critics, including gambling researchers and residents, warn casinos often recirculate local spending, fuel addiction—searches for which rose 23% since 2018’s sports‐betting ruling—and deliver few sustainable high‐wage jobs, prompting calls for robust problem‐gambling interventions.

articles.title: US civic health rating downgraded after year of ‘restrictive‘ Trump actions | First Thing
articles.trailText: Civicus, a nonprofit that monitors global civic freedoms, moved the US from the ‘narrowed’ to ‘obstructed’ category. Plus, the ‘gay wool’ taking over a New York catwalk
articles.summary: Civicus downgraded the US civic health rating from 'narrowed' to 'obstructed' after a year of sweeping executive actions, restrictive laws and aggressive crackdowns on free speech and dissent under the Trump administration. In its latest report on civic freedoms in 198 countries, the nonprofit cited a sharp deterioration of fundamental rights, moving the US one step down in its five-tier scale of open, narrowed, obstructed, repressed and closed. The ‘obstructed’ label denotes a heavily contested civic space where NGOs endure illegal surveillance, bureaucratic harassment and public disparagement by state authorities.

articles.title: We asked critics from authoritarian regimes what they wish they’d known sooner. Here’s what they said
articles.trailText: Critics from Hungary, El Salvador and Turkey offer advice to the US about what they’ve learned about authoritarians
articles.summary: Critics from Hungary, Turkey and El Salvador—veterans of Viktor Orbán’s, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan’s and Nayib Bukele’s regimes—warn Americans to avoid copying authoritarian playbooks. They urge dropping arrogance and exceptionalism, listening to social frustrations and addressing concrete pocketbook issues, securing private-sector resilience against political pressure, and combining street mobilization with party politics. They emphasize a long-term fight for democratic institutions, crafting citizen-centered narratives, active local engagement and unwavering defense of checks and balances against rapid power grabs.

articles.title: US civic health rating downgraded after year of ‘restrictive‘ Trump actions
articles.trailText: Civicus, a non-profit that monitors global civic freedoms, moved the US from the ‘narrowed’ to ‘obstructed’ category
articles.summary: Civicus downgraded the US from “narrowed” to “obstructed” status, citing a sharp deterioration in civic freedoms after a year of sweeping Trump-era executive orders, restrictive laws and crackdowns. The report details militarized protest responses—National Guard deployments, ICE presence—and frequent use of excessive force, illegal surveillance, bureaucratic harassment and demeaning public statements. It flags campus speech bans targeting pro-Palestinian activism, vague “material support” probes against student groups and threats to foreign-born academics. Press freedoms eroded through FCC license threats, lawsuits, NPR/PBS defunding and a pro-administration outlet. Civicus warns the US now joins 39 “obstructed” countries and urges a course correction ahead of its 250th anniversary.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: US supreme court appears set to back Trump’s power to fire independent board members
articles.trailText: Court appears to be split down partisan lines in favor of historic expansion of executive power – key US politics stories from 8 December 2025
articles.summary: US politics roundup: The Supreme Court, split along partisan lines including Justice Coney Barrett, seems set to uphold President Trump’s power to remove independent FTC commissioner Rebecca Slaughter, risking overturn of the 1935 Humphrey’s Executor precedent. Other key stories: Israeli agents reportedly surveiled US forces at a Gaza-aid hub; Pete Hegseth’s 2016 call for troops to defy unlawful Trump orders resurfaces; Brazil warns a US attack on Venezuela could spark a ‘Vietnam-style’ conflict; Trump flags antitrust concerns over Netflix’s $83bn Warner Bros deal. Media bids, church abuse settlement, police shake-ups, Texas Senate bid, park fee changes, Gaza lines and Blair’s exclusion.

articles.title: US supreme court appears set to back Trump on FTC firing in major expansion of power
articles.trailText: Conservative justices seem to signal support for president over move to fire Democrat Rebecca Slaughter in March
articles.summary: The US Supreme Court signaled a conservative majority likely to uphold Trump’s authority to fire FTC commissioner Rebecca Slaughter, challenging nearly century-old protections for independent agencies. In arguments split along ideological lines, justices debated overruling the New Deal–era Humphrey’s Executor precedent that shields agency heads from at-will removal. Advocates of the “unitary executive” argued agency leaders are unaccountable “headless” branches; liberals warned that unchecked presidential power risks politicizing experts and eroding separation of powers. The ruling, due by June, could reshape governance across two dozen independent bodies, including the Federal Reserve.

articles.title: ‘Very unfair’: Trump threatens extra 5% tariff on Mexico over water dispute
articles.trailText: President accuses neighbor of violating treaty governing water-sharing and urges water to be released ‘immediately’
articles.summary: President Trump warned Mexico of a new 5% tariff unless it immediately delivers 200k acre-feet of Rio Grande water it owes under the 1944 US–Mexico water-sharing treaty, claiming an 800k-acre-feet shortfall over five years is harming Texas agriculture. Mexico, facing climate-driven drought and local water stress, has disputed its capacity to meet shipments. The dispute echoes earlier congressional threats to withhold funds in 2024. Simultaneously, the administration unveiled a $12 bn farm relief package—mostly via USDA’s Farmer Bridge Assistance—to offset trade-war losses and stabilize row-crop markets. Under the treaty, Mexico must deliver 1.75 m acre-feet every five years while the US sends 1.5 m to Mexico annually from the Colorado River.

articles.title: Community outraged after California high schoolers form a human swastika
articles.trailText: A student at a San Jose high school posted a photo of eight students lying in the shape of a swastika on a football field
articles.summary: At San Jose’s Branham High, eight students formed a human swastika on the football field, posting a photo on Instagram on Dec 3 with an antisemitic Hitler quote. The image sparked outrage in the Bay Area Jewish community after circulating on Reddit. The school and CUHSD condemned the act, withheld student identities per federal law, and pledged to address hate alongside the Bay Area Jewish Coalition, the Anti-Defamation League and the Jewish Community Relations Council. BAJC leaders blamed gaps in Holocaust education and urged stronger anti-hate curricula to prevent future incidents.

articles.title: Trump unveils $12bn aid package for US farmers amid tariff fallout
articles.trailText: President says money will come from tariff revenues and promises trade policies will make farmers ‘so strong’
articles.summary: President Trump unveiled a $12bn tariff-funded relief package for US farmers to offset trade-dispute fallout, pledging a “golden age” for agriculture. Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins said $11bn will arrive as one-time bridge payments for row crops by Feb 28, with remaining funds allocated to specialty crops under a later plan; applications and individual payment rates will be announced in the coming weeks. The move responds to Chinese and other import barriers, a Supreme Court review of Trump’s tariff authority and farmers’ calls for a level playing field. Trump also criticized farm-equipment complexity, Congress and “fake-news” media. The plan echoes Trump’s $12bn 2018 bailout.

articles.title: Texas Democrat Jasmine Crockett launches bid for US Senate seat
articles.trailText: The two-term Texas congresswoman seeks to flip seat held by Republican John Cornyn in the GOP-dominated state
articles.summary: Two-term Dallas congresswoman Jasmine Crockett filed Monday to challenge Republican Sen. John Cornyn in Texas’s March 3 primary, aiming to flip a GOP stronghold and help Democrats reclaim a Senate majority. Known as an outspoken progressive and frequent GOP target, Crockett enters a field including state rep. James Talarico—whose viral posts criticize vouchers and classroom religion mandates. Her bid follows former candidate Colin Allred’s withdrawal and hinges on polling showing a viable general-election path.

articles.title: Ex-Trump lawyer Alina Habba quits as top federal prosecutor in New Jersey
articles.trailText: Resignation comes despite administration’s efforts to keep her in place after courts found she was serving unlawfully
articles.summary: Former Trump attorney Alina Habba has resigned as acting US attorney for New Jersey after district and appellate courts ruled her interim appointment unlawful due to lack of Senate confirmation. Trump’s administration had attempted to bypass the expired 120-day term by reappointing her as a “special attorney” following the firing of first assistant Desiree Grace, whom judges had installed. Habba, appointed nine months earlier, will serve as senior adviser to AG Pam Bondi and could return if rulings are reversed. Trump decried the breakdown of the bipartisan “blue slip” tradition.

articles.title: Clerk in Murdaugh murder case pleads guilty over graphic crime-scene photos
articles.trailText: Becky Hill sentenced to probation after admitting to showing photos to photographer and lying about it in court
articles.summary: Former Colleton County court clerk Becky Hill pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice, perjury and misconduct in office after admitting she showed sealed crime-scene photos from the Alex Murdaugh double-murder trial to a photographer and lied about it in court. She was sentenced to three years’ probation. Hill also admitted to misusing federal child-support funds and promoting her book through her office. Judge Heath Taylor noted a harsher penalty would have followed proven jury tampering allegations, which prosecutors ultimately deemed unsubstantiated. Hill expressed remorse, saying she will carry the shame of her actions.

articles.title: Drinking water contaminated with Pfas probably increases risk of infant mortality, study finds
articles.trailText: Study of 11,000 births in New Hampshire shows residents’ reproductive outcomes near contaminated sites
articles.summary: A University of Arizona study of 11,000 New Hampshire births finds that residents drinking well water down gradient from 41 Pfoa/Pfos-contaminated sites experience a 191% rise in infant mortality, a 20% increase in preterm birth and 43% more low-weight births, with extremely premature and extremely low-weight births up 168% and 180%. Using groundwater flow data for causal inference, researchers estimate a $8 billion annual societal burden versus $3.8 billion in cleanup costs, bolstering calls for stricter Pfas regulation and filtration systems.

articles.title: New Orleans Catholic clergy abuse survivors in line to collectively be paid $305m
articles.trailText: Attorneys for the victims struck deal with the church’s largest insurer to increase $230m settlement approved earlier
articles.summary: Roughly 600 survivors of New Orleans Catholic clergy abuse may receive $305 million after Travelers, the archdiocese’s primary insurer, agreed to add $75 million to a previously approved $230 million settlement in its May 2020 bankruptcy. Pending separate court sign-off, the deal spares Travelers from tens-of-millions in lawsuits. It follows Louisiana’s 2021 repeal of a law barring decades-old abuse claims. Survivors overwhelmingly ratified the original offer, which also mandates reforms on abuse disclosures and child protection. Archbishop James Checchio, named by Pope Leo XIV, will soon succeed Gregory Aymond.

articles.title: New Orleans Catholic archdiocese gains approval to pay $230m to sexual abuse survivors
articles.trailText: Settlement also includes major changes to how church identifies and discloses past claims of abuse by clergy
articles.summary: After five years of litigation, a federal bankruptcy judge approved the Roman Catholic archdiocese of New Orleans’ $230 million settlement for roughly 600 clergy sexual-abuse survivors, plus an in-principle $75 million insurer contribution pending separate approval. The deal, resolving a 2020 Chapter 11 filing, mandates enhanced abuse-disclosure procedures, independent investigations and new child-protection safeguards. Judge Meredith Grabill, moved by survivors’ emotional testimony, confirmed a December 26 trust funding deadline and a points-based compensation formula amid critiques of past screening failures.

articles.title: Family of student deported to Honduras say they were targeted by ICE agents
articles.trailText: Father of student detained at Boston airport on her way to visit family in Austin, says agents showed up at Texas home
articles.summary: Any Lucia López Belloza, a 19-year-old Babson College student, was detained at Boston Logan on November 20 en route to surprise her family in Austin for Thanksgiving and deported to Honduras within 48 hours. On December 8, ICE Enforcement and Removal Operations agents in three unmarked vehicles stormed her father’s yard in Austin without a warrant, then left after two hours without speaking to the family. Lawyers say no valid removal order existed and that a federal stay barring her deportation was ignored. Democratic Rep. Greg Casar alleges the Trump administration is retaliating against López Belloza for speaking out. She remains with her grandparents in Honduras, seeking to continue her studies and reunite with her family.

articles.title: Mother of Karoline Leavitt’s nephew rejects White House portrayal of her after ICE arrest
articles.trailText: Bruna Ferreira, who was released from ICE custody Monday on bond, denies claims that she’s an absentee parent
articles.summary: Bruna Ferreira (33), mother of White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt’s 11-year-old nephew, was detained by ICE in November during a Massachusetts traffic stop, held in Louisiana, and released on a $1,500 bond. Ferreira disputes the White House’s claim she’s an absentee parent—detailing daily care, attending sports and events, inviting Karoline to be her son’s godmother, and arranging his presence at Karoline’s wedding and the White House Easter egg hunt. DHS confirmed she overstayed a 1999 tourist visa; Ferreira and her lawyer reject allegations of a prior battery arrest, citing a dismissed juvenile case. She also alleges her son’s father threatened to have her deported, a claim he denies.

articles.title: Mike Johnson strips military IVF coverage from defense bill – report
articles.trailText: House speaker worked behind the scenes to strip provision after it was added as an amendment earlier this year
articles.summary: House Speaker Mike Johnson quietly stripped a bipartisan amendment from the FY26 National Defense Authorization Act that would have provided in vitro fertilization coverage to active-duty service members. Despite earlier approval by both chambers, Johnson’s anti-abortion stance led to its removal, drawing criticism from Resolve’s CEO and ASRM’s Sean Tipton, who note military infertility rates are high. Johnson praised the NDAA’s conservative cultural agenda. Congress may vote on the bill this week, while Trump’s IVF access promises remain unfulfilled.

articles.title: Hegseth said US military should refuse ‘unlawful’ Trump orders in unearthed 2016 interview
articles.trailText: Defense secretary’s comments recirculating amid dispute over US strikes on alleged drug boats in Caribbean
articles.summary: Unearthed by CNN from March 2016, Fox News clips show Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, then a contributor, repeatedly arguing US troops must refuse “unlawful” orders from candidate Donald Trump—the same stance he now calls “despicable” when Democrats urge disobedience amid a political firestorm over 20 US strikes on alleged drug-smuggling boats in the Caribbean, including a Sept. 2nd strike that killed two survivors, which critics deem extrajudicial and say have killed over 80 people. Hegseth labels smugglers “narco-terrorists,” attacked the “Seditious Six,” defended Trump’s war powers, and backed Pentagon probes of Sen. Mark Kelly.

articles.title: Trump appears not to know the difference between making a deal and making peace
articles.trailText: US president’s efforts under harsh spotlight as Rwanda-DRC deal and Thailand-Cambodia mediations waver
articles.summary: Trump’s self-styled role as a global peacemaker faces scrutiny as his touted Rwanda-DRC agreement, Thailand–Cambodia border mediation and Gaza ceasefire unravel. Experts cite Johan Galtung’s concept of “negative” versus “positive” peace: Trump’s transactional, zero-sum dealmaking yields fragile truces rather than durable, justice-driven resolutions. His performative, win-oriented approach—evident in renaming the US Institute of Peace after himself and pressuring Ukraine to cede territory—fails to address structural grievances, undermines trust and turns negotiations into exercises in bad faith.

articles.title: Washington DC police chief resigns after less than two years
articles.trailText: Pamela Smith, first Black woman to lead the department, quits amid battle with Trump over control of police
articles.summary: Pamela Smith, the first Black woman to serve as Washington DC police chief, announced her resignation effective December 31 after less than two years amid disputes with President Trump over federalizing the Metropolitan Police Department. Mayor Muriel Bowser lauded Smith’s tenure, noting a 35% drop in violent crime and the lowest homicide rate in over 30 years, and credited her with restoring safety. Smith cited family commitments—missing celebrations since her mother’s death—rather than federal pressure. Her departure follows Bowser’s announcement she won’t seek reelection and comes amid ongoing national guard deployments and a DOJ-House probe into alleged MPD crime-stat manipulation. No successor has been named.

articles.title: ‘We’ll need to see a warrant’: the group teaching businesses a vital tool to fight ICE raids
articles.trailText: Siembra in North Carolina gives owners fourth amendment rights trainings should federal agents show up at their door
articles.summary: North Carolina immigrant-rights group Siembra has launched a Fourth Amendment strategy teaching business owners their rights if ICE agents show up unannounced. Posters declaring “private area” and “we’ll need a warrant” adorn windows at over 250 stores and restaurants. Siembra provides a free workbook, printable signage, trainings and a pledge, plus volunteer canvassers. Participants like Angela Salamanca and Scuppernong Books cite community defense and solidarity. Responses vary—from fear to indifference—until ICE arrests spur signups. Siembra now targets municipalities such as Durham, Carrboro and Chapel Hill, seeking statewide expansion and inspiring similar efforts nationwide.

articles.title: First Thing: Zelenskyy to meet European leaders in London for talks on ending Ukraine war
articles.trailText: Ukrainian president says latest discussions with US were ‘constructive, although not easy’. Plus, the autism advocates fighting RFK Jr’s barrage of misinformation
articles.summary: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy meets UK, French and German leaders in London to advance a US-authored peace plan following “constructive, although not easy” talks in Washington. Trump claims Zelenskyy hasn’t read but likes the proposal. Elsewhere, Israeli operatives face scrutiny for covert surveillance at a Gaza-aid coordination base; internal GOP figures mocked Trump before rallying behind him, while autism campaigners counter RFK Jr’s vaccine-autism claims. Brief updates cover Thailand–Cambodia border strikes, Japan–China air tensions, South Yemen’s bid for independence, wildfire rebuilding in LA and Perry’s public romance with Trudeau.

articles.title: Ex-Honduran president thanks God – and Trump – for drug-trafficking pardon
articles.trailText: Juan Orlando Hernández thanked the Lord for being ‘a free man’ and then Trump for ‘changing my life’
articles.summary: Former Honduran president Juan Orlando Hernández released a social media video praising God and thanking Donald Trump for his December 1 pardon of a March 2024 US drug-trafficking conviction. Hernández, in office from 2014 to 2022, was convicted for accepting $1 million from El Chapo and running Honduras as a cocaine “superhighway.” He decried a Biden deep-state conspiracy, restricted X replies to Trump allies, and hailed Trump’s courage. The pardon—amid US “war on drugs,” election interference and a judge’s block of DOJ probes—drew bipartisan criticism. Critics like Sen. Chris Coons called it the wrong message to narco-traffickers.

articles.title: Ignorance is BS: speaker’s stock answer on Trump’s misdeeds is ‘I don’t know’
articles.trailText: Mike Johnson’s denials of knowledge of presidential scandals strain credulity – but may be an effective tactic
articles.summary: House Speaker Mike Johnson repeatedly claims ignorance of controversies involving former President Donald Trump—over 14 instances ranging from a US military strike that may be a war crime and presidential pardons to a $400m Qatar jet gift—saying “I don’t know” or “it’s not my lane.” Experts deem this an abdication of the speakership’s constitutional oversight role and break from precedent. Johnson’s tactic shields him politically, preserves a slim GOP majority and allegiance to Trump by exploiting the fast-moving news cycle, despite criticism that his denials strain credulity.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Key Republican backs release of video of strike on alleged drug boat
articles.trailText: Democrats are pushing the Trump administration to release the video of a second strike on the drug boat which was incapacitated in the Caribbean. Key US politics stories from 7 December 2025
articles.summary: Democrats and GOP Sen. Tom Cotton pressed the Pentagon to declassify video of a Sept. 2 strike on an alleged drug boat in the Caribbean that killed two survivors amid war-crime allegations, even as officials cite security concerns. Elsewhere, the Kremlin applauded Trump’s new national security strategy; Donald Trump Jr. floated ending US support for Ukraine; the president criticized Rep. Henry Cuellar’s post-pardon party loyalty; Ilhan Omar decried Trump’s anti-Somali slur; a judge limited evidence access in the Comey case; the Biden administration weighs a Gaza ceasefire draft; and advocates urge protections for a deportation-threatened Army veteran.

articles.title: More than 200 environmental groups demand halt to new US datacenters
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Congress urged to act against energy-hungry facilities blamed for increasing bills and worsening climate crisis
articles.summary: A coalition of over 230 environmental groups including Greenpeace, Friends of the Earth and Food & Water Watch has called on Congress to impose a moratorium on new US datacenters, citing soaring electricity bills, water shortages and rising greenhouse gas emissions driven by AI and crypto demand. Local opposition has already stalled or blocked 16 projects worth $64bn. Campaigners credit the backlash with influencing recent elections in Virginia, New Jersey and Georgia. They warn datacenters could triple power demand by 2035 and add 44m tonnes of CO2, urging a pause until federal regulations curb their climate and affordability impacts.

articles.title: Trump claims rave reviews for hosting Kennedy Center Honors – before ceremony even ends
articles.trailText: President refers jokingly to renamed ‘Trump-Kennedy Center’ at celebration of stars from music and film
articles.summary: President Trump served as host of the Kennedy Center Honors Dec 7 in Washington, marking the first time a sitting president chaired the lifetime achievement awards. Trump jokingly rebranded the venue “Trump-Kennedy Center,” claimed pre-emptive “rave reviews” and scored partisan jabs. He personally curated honorees—Stallone (Rocky), Crawford (Phantom of the Opera), Strait, Gaynor, Kiss—and introduced them via Oval Office videos. His presence underscores his post-2025 push to reshape the “woke” arts center amid staff shake-ups under new appointee Ric Grenell and dwindling diversity and ticket sales.

articles.title: Republicans in Congress mocked Trump privately, Marjorie Taylor Greene says
