articles.trailText: Georgia lawmaker says colleagues who made fun of president before 2024 win now support him out of fear
articles.summary: Marjorie Taylor Greene, outgoing GOP representative from Georgia, revealed on 60 Minutes that many House Republicans privately mocked Donald Trump’s speech and her loyalty until he clinched the 2024 nomination, then publicly backed him to avoid his wrath. Once a staunch Trump ally turned “traitor,” Greene reported hundreds of threats to Capitol Police—initially from left-wing critics, then from Trump loyalists after she challenged his handling of Jeffrey Epstein files. She says colleagues stay silent out of fear of harsh Truth Social reprisals by Trump.

articles.title: Ilhan Omar calls Trump’s anti-Somali tirade ‘completely disgusting’
articles.trailText: Minnesota congresswoman says ‘hateful rhetoric’ can lead to ‘dangerous actions by people who listen to the president’
articles.summary: Somalia-born Congresswoman Ilhan Omar condemned President Trump’s recent description of Minnesota’s Somali community as “garbage,” calling it “completely disgusting” and warning that dehumanizing rhetoric can spark violence. On CBS’s Face the Nation, she defended her constituents, criticized Trump’s push to send Somali Americans back to Somalia and blasted his administration’s immigration restrictions. Omar highlighted Minneapolis’s mayoral order barring federal enforcement on city property, wrote a New York Times op-ed accusing Trump of stoking bigotry to distract from broken promises, and called for full accountability in the state’s Somali fraud cases while rejecting claims that stolen funds went to terrorism.

articles.title: Democrats urge Pentagon to release video of strike on alleged drug boat
articles.trailText: Trump team faces mounting pressure as members of Congress allege that the deadly attack was unlawful
articles.summary: Democrats in Congress are pressing the Pentagon to release footage of a second September strike on an alleged drug vessel in the Caribbean that killed 11 people, including two survivors clinging to a capsized hull. Allegations of unlawful killing and war crimes rose after reports SecDef Pete Hegseth ordered “kill them all.” Adm. Frank Bradley and the Pentagon defend the attack’s legality but offer no video. Sens. Adam Schiff, Reps. Jim Himes and Adam Smith demand public scrutiny. President Trump has no objection, but Hegseth cites security concerns. Sen. Tom Cotton says he’d trust the Pentagon’s declassification.

articles.title: Detained Georgia veteran deserves to stay in US after serving country, fiancee says
articles.trailText: Godfrey Wade’s case is emblematic of rising number of non-US citizen veterans swept up by ICE under Trump’s immigration policies
articles.summary: Jamaican-born, decorated US Army veteran Godfrey Wade, 65, has been in ICE custody since September at Stewart detention center in Georgia after being arrested for driving without a license. His fiancée and six children are fundraising via GoFundMe and lobbying Congress—inquiring DOJ and DHS—urging restoration of former-veteran deportation protections Trump rescinded. Wade’s case highlights reports that over 10,000 non-U.S. citizen vets have been deported, and that VA internal data-sharing may expose thousands more.

articles.title: Hegseth gives defiant speech defending ‘drug boat’ strikes amid scrutiny
articles.trailText: At event in California, US defense secretary says Trump has power to take military action ‘as he sees fit’
articles.summary: US defense secretary Pete Hegseth defended military strikes on alleged drug cartel boats in the Caribbean at a Reagan library event, arguing President Trump can act “as he sees fit.” The attacks, which have killed over 80 people since September, are justified to protect Americans, he said, likening smugglers to terrorists. Legal experts and some Republicans dispute the strikes’ legality, noting suspects lack court convictions and the US isn’t at war in the Caribbean. A Washington Post report claiming a second strike on survivors followed Hegseth’s “kill everybody” order drew his denial. Democrats, led by the New Democrat Coalition, demand his resignation as scrutiny intensifies.

articles.title: Trump slams ‘lack of loyalty’ after pardoned Democrat says he won’t change party
articles.trailText: Henry Cuellar launched House re-election bid as Democrat days after Trump pardoned him over bribery charges
articles.summary: After pardoning Texas Congressmember Henry Cuellar and his wife on bribery charges tied to Azerbaijan and a Mexican bank, former President Donald Trump criticized Cuellar on Truth Social for running for re-election as a Democrat and accused him of disloyalty. He blasted Cuellar’s 'lack of LOYALTY' and warned 'no more Mr. Nice guy!' Cuellar, one of the most conservative House Democrats, promptly filed as a Democrat, saying he won’t switch parties. His south Texas district was redrawn by Republicans ahead of the 2026 midterms, a map recently cleared by SCOTUS, raising GOP hopes of flipping the seat.

articles.title: Judge blocks Trump prosecutors from accessing key evidence in Comey case
articles.trailText: Setback for government after judge said it probably violated Comey ally’s protections from unreasonable searches
articles.summary: On Dec. 7, federal judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly temporarily barred prosecutors from accessing computer materials seized from Daniel Richman – James Comey’s friend and legal adviser – after finding the government likely conducted an unconstitutional, warrantless search of files previously obtained under expired warrants. Richman sued in November, asserting Fourth Amendment and attorney–client privilege violations as prosecutors pursue Comey on charges of lying to Congress about authorized leaks. The order, in effect until Dec. 12, compounds setbacks for the Eastern District of Virginia, whose recent grand jury declined to indict NY Attorney General Letitia James.

articles.title: LA wildfire survivors rebuild holiday traditions after year of devastation
articles.trailText: After losing homes, heirlooms and decades of memories, Angelenos are piecing together new rituals this season
articles.summary: After January’s Pacific Palisades and Eaton fires—LA’s deadliest blaze (6,800 structures, 12 dead; 9,400 destroyed in Altadena/Pasadena, half of Black households hit)—survivors are forging new holiday rituals. Altadena couple Michael Holland (64) and Anne Bannon (67) lost 27 years of ornaments, opting for a small tree and icicle lights in their Pasadena apartment. Recent arrivals Jodie Ludwin’s family returned to the UK, refocusing on family traditions. LA’s first rebuilt Palisades home marks hope; Altadena mother Melissa Merritt, recovering from cancer, treasures rescued heirlooms and a tabletop tree before celebrating resilience in England.

articles.title: Maha v Maga: feud grows as Trump EPA rolls back rules on toxic chemicals
articles.trailText: ‘Make America healthy again’ leaders call for Lee Zeldin to quit for favoring chemical companies over US families
articles.summary: Leaders of the ‘Make America Healthy Again’ (Maha) movement, led by RFK Jr. and supported by influencers Zen Honeycutt, Kelly Ryerson and Vani Hari, petition Trump to dismiss EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin for prioritizing chemical and pesticide industry interests over US public health. Since January Zeldin has rolled back oversight on toxic chemicals, fast-tracked dicamba and PFAS pesticide approvals, and reduced scrutiny of existing compounds, while appointing industry executives to agency posts. EPA defends its actions as aligned with Trump-Kennedy policies, but Maha warns rollback risks higher disease rates and medical costs.

articles.title: US may end support for Ukraine war effort, says Donald Trump Jr
articles.trailText: Eldest son of Donald Trump makes speculative comments during tirade against Volodymyr Zelenskyy and EU
articles.summary: At a Middle East forum, Donald Trump Jr warned his father may withdraw US military support for Ukraine, arguing Kyiv’s “corrupt” elites fled abroad and left “peasants” to fight while looting funds. He criticized President Zelenskyy for prolonging the war to win re-election, branded EU sanctions “no plan” for merely hiking oil prices, and singled out EU foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas. He claimed only three voters in his 2022 canvass named the Ukraine war a top-10 issue and asserted Venezuelan fentanyl poses a greater threat. His remarks echo MAGA pressure on the Trump team to demand territorial concessions from Kyiv.

articles.title: No, New York City’s wealthiest are not fleeing the city after Mamdani’s win
articles.trailText: Conservatives warned of a mass exodus if the democratic socialist won, but experts, and property data, paint a very different picture
articles.summary: Despite conservative warnings that Zohran Mamdani’s modest tax-hike plan would trigger a millionaire exodus, November data show rising signed contracts for Manhattan homes over $4 million and a 16% drop in luxury inventory. Cornell sociologist Cristobal Young and EU Tax Observatory’s Quentin Parrinello cite historically low migration among high earners—tied to family, cultural and business networks and immovable assets—and studies from New Jersey to France confirm limited millionaire flight, meaning roughly 98% of wealthy New Yorkers remain and will boost city revenues.

articles.title: Luigi Mangione court hearings gave a preview of gripping trial to come
articles.trailText: Last week’s proceedings in murder case of Brian Thompson showed a mix of politics, social comment and drama
articles.summary: At contested preliminary hearings in NYC, prosecutors and defense clashed over seized evidence in the Luigi Mangione murder case, previewing a trial steeped in politics, social commentary and conspiracy. Mangione is charged with fatally shooting United Healthcare exec Brian Thompson with a ghost gun, igniting public outrage over for-profit healthcare, inequality and gun violence. Testimony ranged from a McDonald’s tipster suspicious of a mask-wearing suspect to a guard invoking Epstein-style precautions, and culminated in the forcible ejection of a reporter challenging sealed evidence. Mangione, pleading not guilty, contests warrantless searches and Miranda issues, underscoring America’s adversarial system.

articles.title: An animal rights activist was on the FBI’s Most Wanted list for 15 years. Will he be returned to the US?
articles.trailText: Daniel Andreas San Diego, now 47, is fighting extradition from the UK amid accusations he set off three pipe bombs in 2003
articles.summary: Daniel Andreas San Diego, 47, the FBI’s most-wanted suspect in 2003 pipe bomb attacks on Chiron and Shaklee HQs to protest animal testing, is fighting extradition from the UK. Vanishing after a traffic stop in 2003, he lived under alias “Danny Stephen Webb” in northern Wales until his November 2024 arrest. If returned and convicted, he faces up to 90 years in prison. His UK barristers argue he’ll be denied a fair, apolitical trial in the US under Trump, highlighting risks of stacked charges, harsh sentencing and prison violence. A Westminster court verdict is due January 2026.

articles.title: Trump vows to slam America’s doors shut as he heaps scorn on immigrants
articles.trailText: National guard shooting prompts extraordinary outburst and targeting of people from startling range of countries
articles.summary: After a West Virginia guardwoman’s fatal shooting by Afghan asylum-seeker Rahmanullah Lakanwal on 26 Nov, Trump blamed immigrants, promising on Thanksgiving to pause migration from "all Third World countries," terminate Biden-era admissions, denaturalize "non-assets" and deport those "undermining domestic tranquility." Aided by Stephen Miller, he broadened attacks, then at a cabinet meeting called Somali Minnesotans and Rep. Ilhan Omar "garbage." ICE launched Operation Catahoula Crunch, targeting 5,000 arrests in New Orleans and Minnesota, while DHS chief Kristi Noem proposed bans on 32 unnamed nations, canceling some green-card appointments.

articles.title: Alabama: Woman who alleged priest paid her for sex beginning at 17 says there’s ‘no real winner’ after his resignation
articles.trailText: Heather Jones, now 33, went public with allegations after Robert Sullivan continued to work with children
articles.summary: Heather Jones, now 33, alleges that from age 17 she exchanged sex and private companionship for financial support with longtime Homewood, Alabama priest Robert “Bob” Sullivan, who paid her hundreds of thousands over several years. After Jones’s formal complaint spurred a Birmingham diocese review and Vatican referral, Sullivan asked Pope Leo XIV to dispense him from priestly obligations and resigned on Nov. 22. Jones says there’s “no real winner” but hopes for healing, accountability and stronger protections for minors; she faces a misdemeanor she calls retaliatory.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Hegseth faces most serious crisis of tenure
articles.trailText: US defense secretary Pete Hegseth under siege over mishandling of classified military intelligence and Caribbean boat attacks. Key US politics stories from 6 December 2025
articles.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, backed by Trump, faces calls to resign after an inspector general found he mishandled classified intelligence via Signal ahead of Yemen strikes and lawmakers allege his Caribbean ‘double-tap’ boat attacks killed survivors. In other developments: Trump escalated anti-immigrant rhetoric after a DC National Guard shooting; Pentagon press credentials shifted to pro-Trump pundits; a wounded Guard member slowly recovers; Trump hosted Kennedy Center honorees amid board shake-ups; Sen. Patty Murray condemned an ICE dog mauling; the administration waived Southwest’s $11 m fine; ex‐Sen. Bob Menendez was disqualified from office; Biden attacked GOP on trans rights; vaccine guidelines face scrutiny; and a judge questioned federal command of deployed Guard troops.

articles.title: Trump hosts Kennedy Center honorees and teases hosting skills: ‘I’m sure they’ll give me great reviews’
articles.trailText: George Strait, ‘Sly’ Stallone and Kiss accept medals from president, who says he was ‘98% involved’ in choosing them
articles.summary: On Dec. 6, 2025 President Trump hosted the four Kennedy Center honorees—George Strait, Michael Crawford, Sylvester Stallone and rock band Kiss—in the Oval Office, presenting redesigned Tiffany & Co. medals alongside center president Richard Grenell, a Trump appointee and special envoy to Latin America. Trump, who skipped the awards in his first term, has ousted its board for supporters and vowed a full renovation. Claiming “98% involvement” in honoree selection, he’ll become the first president to host the honors broadcast, predicting record ratings and quipping he’ll outshine Jimmy Kimmel.

articles.title: Senator says ICE ‘attack dog’ caused ‘horrific’ injuries to unresisting man as he was detained
articles.trailText: Patty Murray of Washington state said ICE agents lied to Wilmer Toledo-Martinez to lure him outside before dog attacked him
articles.summary: Senator Patty Murray (D-WA) alleges that in November ICE agents deceived undocumented immigrant Wilmer Toledo-Martinez, lured outside under the guise of a car accident inquiry, then released an “attack dog” that mauled him despite nonresistance. Photos show deep side lacerations requiring hospital stitches; he was denied prompt antibiotic and injury care, left shaking and briefly blinded. Detained at NW ICE Processing Center, Toledo-Martinez—brought to the US at 15—was seized before his US-citizen wife and two young children. Murray demands his immediate release and accountability. DHS has yet to comment. Related ICE use-of-force probes include a Vancouver arrest car-foot collision and a Tucson protest chemical spray.

articles.title: National guard member wounded in DC attack is ‘slowly healing’, says West Virginia governor
articles.trailText: Andrew Wolfe was shot in the head on 26 November, while Sarah Beckstrom died from her injuries
articles.summary: West Virginia National Guard soldier Andrew Wolfe, 24, shot in the head while patrolling Washington DC under the Trump administration’s “crime emergency” deployment, is “slowly healing” and will remain in acute care 2–3 more weeks, Gov. Patrick Morrisey said. Fellow guard member Sarah Beckstrom, 20, died of her injuries. Suspect Rahmanullah Lakanwal, an Afghan asylum-seeker and former CIA-affiliated “Zero Unit” operative, faces first-degree murder and other federal charges, with the US attorney general weighing the death penalty. His next court date is Jan. 14. The shooting prompted restrictive immigration policies and criticism over the deployment’s political motives amid low DC crime rates.

articles.title: Joe Biden slams Republicans for turning transgender rights into ‘political football’
articles.trailText: Former president gave a speech expressing support for LGBTQ+ rights at an LGBTQ+ leaders conference on Friday
articles.summary: At the International LGBTQ+ Leaders Conference in Washington, former president Joe Biden condemned Republicans for weaponizing transgender rights as a "political football" under Donald Trump’s prospective return. While accepting a lifetime achievement award, he highlighted signing the Respect for Marriage Act and his personal evolution from opposing same-sex unions in the 1990s to championing LGBTQ+ equality. Biden urged isolated LGBTQ+ youth to "get up and fight back" for basic decency, dignity and respect, even as he addressed his prostate cancer and health-related verbal slip.

articles.title: Former senator Bob Menendez banned from holding public office in New Jersey
articles.trailText: State court made ruling against ex-lawmaker now serving 11-year sentence for bribery and acting as an agent of Egypt
articles.summary: New Jersey superior court judge Robert Lougy permanently barred former US Senator Bob Menendez from seeking or holding state and local public office after his 2024 bribery conviction, which saw him start an 11-year sentence in June for accepting cash, gold bars and acting as an agent of Egypt. Violating the ban incurs a contempt charge. Menendez, dubbed “Gold Bar Bob,” resigned in August 2024. Prosecutors found $480,000 in cash and $150,000 in gold at his home; his wife Nadine received 4.5 years for related influence-peddling. Menendez maintains his innocence and seeks a Trump pardon.

articles.title: Drag queen Pattie Gonia completes 100-mile trek raising $1m to make outdoors more ‘equitable’
articles.trailText: Drag queen, environmentalist, diversity and inclusion advocate and social media star arrives in San Francisco
articles.summary: Drag queen and environmentalist Pattie Gonia completed a 100-mile trek in full drag from Point Reyes to San Francisco’s Golden Gate Bridge, raising over $1m via GoFundMe from nearly 35,000 donors. She urged followers: “Don’t let anyone ever tell you that you can’t make a difference,” reflecting on skepticism she overcame since launching her activist persona seven years ago. The campaign supports eight nonprofits working to expand access and equity in outdoor spaces. She has staged high-profile actions—like flying a Trans pride flag at Yosemite—to amplify LGBTQ+ presence in nature.

articles.title: From ‘criminals’ to ‘garbage’, Trump is ramping up anti-immigrant language
articles.trailText: The US president has seized on the dehumanizing tactic since an Afghan man shot two national guard troops
articles.summary: Following a DC shooting by an Afghan asylum-seeker, President Trump and administration officials have intensified dehumanizing rhetoric against immigrants, labeling Afghans “criminals” and Somalis “garbage,” and urging re-examination of Afghan arrivals, blanket bans on “Islamic immigrants,” and immediate deportations. USCIS suspended Afghan visa and asylum applications, while GOP lawmakers called for Sharia bans. Critics condemned the remarks as vile and warned they fuel xenophobic violence. Community organizers report heightened fear among Somali and Afghan residents as ICE operations surge.

articles.title: ‘Mouthpieces for Trump’: inside the rightwing takeover of the Pentagon press corps
articles.trailText: Pentagon press passes once held by credentialed journalists are now in the hands of rightwing pundits and Trump allies
articles.summary: The Pentagon’s once-mainstream press corps has been replaced by over 70 rightwing pundits and Trump allies—Laura Loomer, Mike Lindell’s LindellTV, Matt Gaetz, Turning Point USA, Gateway Pundit—after legacy outlets relinquished their passes in October rather than accept a 21-page policy effectively barring unauthorized reporting. Critics, including journalism scholars and the New York Times (now suing), warn the new corps will merely parrot official lines, undermining First Amendment press independence at a time when scandals—from Pentagon IG findings on Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s operational leaks to questions over a Caribbean double strike—demand rigorous scrutiny.

articles.title: Pressure grows on ‘reckless’ Hegseth as twin scandals engulf Pentagon chief
articles.trailText: Defense secretary defiant but allegations of war crimes and blistering watchdog report increase calls for him to go
articles.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, a Trump appointee, faces bipartisan calls to resign after an inspector general found he leaked classified Yemeni strike plans on Signal, violating record-keeping rules and endangering pilots, and revelations that survivors of a September Caribbean narco-boat strike were killed in an unlawful “double-tap.” Democratic senators and the New Democrat Coalition label him reckless, while legal experts dispute the administration’s drug-war framing. Despite mounting pressure, Hegseth retains White House support and refuses to step down.

articles.title: Experts fear for US childhood vaccine schedule after hepatitis B guideline change
articles.trailText: Pediatricians say panel’s decision will create confusion and access issues, and condemn ‘parody of public health’
articles.summary: After Robert F. Kennedy Jr. overhauled the CDC’s Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, inserting longtime vaccine skeptics, the panel voted to alter the hepatitis B recommendation. Critics warn this sets a precedent to scrutinize the entire childhood immunization schedule, sowing confusion among parents and insurers and jeopardizing coverage and access. Experts cite no safety data justifying new restrictions, fear rising outbreaks amid the worst US measles surge in 30 years, and warn vulnerable, immunocompromised children face increased risk as public trust erodes.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: list of countries under US travel ban set to grow
articles.trailText: US Department of Homeland Security secretary Kristi Noem says list will expand to more than 30 countries
articles.summary: Trump administration to expand travel bans to over 30 countries affecting immigrants and visitors; civil rights groups vow legal challenges. SCOTUS will review his birthright citizenship rollback. Survivors of a US airstrike in the Caribbean were later killed. National Security Strategy backs European far right. CDC panel recommends limiting newborn hepatitis B shots. Judge orders release of Jeffrey Epstein grand-jury files. State Dept. to deny visas to fact-checkers. Ilhan Omar condemns Trump’s anti-Somali remarks. Also: Netflix-Warner deal, LA guard lawsuit and new immigration actions.

articles.title: CDC advisory panel votes to limit hepatitis B vaccines for newborns
articles.trailText: Move from CDC advisers mirrors Trump team’s regressive approach to longstanding vaccine guidance
articles.summary: At a December 5 meeting, CDC’s ACIP advisers, appointed by Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., voted 8–3 to remove the longstanding universal newborn hepatitis B vaccine recommendation and replace it with a “shared clinical decision-making” approach for infants of hepatitis B-negative mothers. Backed by the Trump administration, the change could sow confusion, limit access for low-income families and prompt insurers to drop coverage. Modeling predicts delays will cause 1,400 infections, 300 liver cancers and 480 deaths annually. Independent bodies still urge birth-dose vaccination. The nonbinding vote now goes to acting CDC director Jim O’Neill.

articles.title: Arizona congresswoman says she was ‘pepper sprayed’ at protest against ICE
articles.trailText: Adelita Grijalva, a Democratic representative, said she was ‘sprayed in the face’ at demonstration outside a restaurant
articles.summary: Democratic Rep Adelita Grijalva said she was pepper sprayed while joining protesters blocking ICE agents executing an immigration raid at Tucson’s Taco Giro. In video, she coughs after an agent fires an orange chemical and pushes her aside when she identified herself. DHS denies targeting her, saying she was near those obstructing enforcement; two officers were injured. ICE says it executed 16 search warrants across southern Arizona, detaining multiple individuals. Local officials and Democrats, including Sen. Ruben Gallego, condemned the force, warning the incident illustrates how vulnerable community members are treated during aggressive immigration operations.

articles.title: ‘Cultivate resistance’: policy paper lays bare Trump support for Europe’s far right
articles.trailText: Text signed by president seems to echo ‘great replacement�� theory, saying Europe faces ‘civilisational erasure’
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s signed US National Security Strategy warns Europe faces ��civilisational erasure” within 20 years from migration, EU integration and loss of national identity, echoing the racist “great replacement” theory. It explicitly urges Washington to “cultivate resistance” by backing nationalist far-right parties, opening European markets to US goods and shifting defence burdens onto EU states. The paper criticizes EU censorship and regulatory “suffocation,” calls for an end to the Ukraine war favouring Russia, and celebrates rising patriotic parties like Germany’s AfD. Germany’s foreign minister rebuffs US interference, while Democrats denounce contradictions and pro-Russia leanings.

articles.title: Judge challenges rationale for Trump’s control over national guard in California
articles.trailText: Judge seems skeptical of administration’s case and whether any crisis justifying deployment still exists in Los Angeles
articles.summary: Judge Charles Breyer challenged the Trump administration’s authority to indefinitely federalize roughly 4,000 California National Guard troops it sent to Los Angeles in June to shield immigration agents and federal property after protests and two incendiary devices were thrown. In a Dec. 5 hearing, he noted conditions in L.A. have since improved, questioned why state forces couldn’t secure federal sites, and recalled his earlier ruling deeming the activation illegal. California Governor Newsom’s suit seeks a preliminary injunction to return control of the guard, but an appeals panel has stayed Breyer’s order. DOJ attorney Eric Hamilton argued presidential power permits extended command while a crisis persists. This unprecedented deployment tests limits on domestic military use.

articles.title: US Capitol pipe bomb suspect says he believed Trump’s 2020 election lie
articles.trailText: Brian Cole Jr makes first court appearance charged with planting two devices on 5 January 2021 in Washington
articles.summary: Brian Cole Jr., 30, appeared in federal court Dec 5 in Washington DC charged with placing two pipe bombs outside the Democratic and Republican party headquarters on Jan 5, 2021, a day before the Capitol siege. He faces explosives charges carrying up to 20 years. FBI traced his pipe, timer and battery purchases plus cellphone and license-plate data. Cole confessed, saying he believed Trump’s stolen-election conspiracy. Magistrate Judge Moxila Upadhyaya set a detention hearing for Dec 15; the devices were found and defused Jan 6 without casualties.

articles.title: DoJ moves to eliminate sexual abuse protections for LGBTQ+ people in prisons
articles.trailText: Memo says the policy shift, which advocates call ‘reckless’, was designed to align with one of Trump’s anti-trans orders
articles.summary: The Justice Department has terminated enforcement of LGBTQ+ sexual abuse safeguards under the Prison Rape Elimination Act, effective immediately, according to a memo from Tammie Gregg. Auditors are instructed to cease reviewing housing, screening and search protocols designed to protect trans, intersex and gender-nonconforming inmates. The directive, intended to mirror Trump’s anti-trans “biological truth” order, drops requirements for harassment investigations and respectful communication. The DOJ says formal Prea updates are planned. Civil rights groups including JDI and the ACLU warn it will sow confusion, increase assaults and carry legal liability for violations.

articles.title: US supreme court to decide on legality of Trump birthright citizenship order
articles.trailText: Justices to take up case amid legal fight over order to heavily restrict right to birthright citizenship in US
articles.summary: The US Supreme Court has agreed to hear Trump v. Barbara in spring to resolve whether President Trump’s January executive order—blocked by multiple federal judges and lower courts—violates the 14th Amendment and federal statute by denying birthright citizenship to children born on US soil to noncitizen parents. The case tests an anti-immigration legal theory challenging a century-old interpretation of the citizenship clause. Lower courts, including a New Hampshire judge in an ACLU-led class-action suit, have unanimously found the ban contrary to the constitution, Supreme Court precedent, and federal law. A ruling is expected early summer.

articles.title: US citizen chased by federal agents in New Orleans says she was targeted because ‘I’m brown’
articles.trailText: Home security videos shows Jacelynn Guzman, 23, telling masked officers following her to ‘leave me alone’
articles.summary: During a Trump administration immigration sweep in Marrero, Louisiana, 23-year-old US citizen Jacelynn Guzman, a Hispanic woman, was chased by masked, unmarked federal agents after they alleged she matched a deportation target. Home security footage shows her pleading, “Leave me alone!” as she ran home. Agents later confirmed she was not the person sought and left. Guzman, who has no criminal record, believes she was targeted because of her race—“I’m brown”—and her family fears racial profiling. The incident, part of a New Orleans-area operation aiming for 5,000 arrests, underscores immigrant communities’ growing anxiety over aggressive enforcement tactics.

articles.title: Trump wins his peace prize from Fifa – any chance of a VAR review?
articles.trailText: At a gaudy and gauche World Cup draw, Gianni Infantino went all out to flatter the world’s most precious ego
articles.summary: At a gaudy Washington ceremony to draw the 2026 World Cup groups, FIFA president Gianni Infantino theatrically awarded Donald Trump an inaugural ‘peace prize’ — a gold globe trophy and medal — explicitly designed to flatter him. The spectacle, featuring Bocelli performance, celebrity hosts and a promotional video touting eight conflicts allegedly resolved by Trump, echoed Mussolini’s politicized 1934 draw. It underscored Infantino’s commercial pursuit of US markets, cozy ties with the president and FIFA’s new Trump Tower office, while ignoring controversies from extrajudicial killings to Putin flattery. Critics derided the dubious honor and called for a VAR-style review.

articles.title: US federal judge orders release of Epstein grand jury materials
articles.trailText: Ruling compels unsealing of documents from 2006-2007 federal investigation into Epstein in Florida
articles.summary: A Florida federal judge, Rodney Smith, ordered the unsealing of 2006–07 grand jury transcripts from the Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell sex-trafficking investigation under the newly enacted Epstein Files Transparency Act. This marks the first successful release of Epstein-related materials since the law, passed 427–1 in the House and by unanimous Senate consent and signed by Donald Trump last month, overrode traditional secrecy rules. The DOJ’s request was approved in Florida, and New York courts face a Monday deadline on similar unsealing petitions. The Act mandates disclosure of unclassified records by December 19, with narrow exceptions for active investigations and victims’ personal data.

articles.title: Who’s allowed to get the hepatitis B vaccine in the US now?
articles.trailText: Advisers for the CDC voted to limit the vaccines – here’s what happened and why the vote is so significant
articles.summary: In an unprecedented decision, CDC’s vaccine advisory panel voted to make the universal newborn hepatitis B shot subject to 'shared clinical decision-making' rather than routine, requiring parents to consult a physician and potentially delaying vaccination until two months. This marks the first limitation on a long-standing infant vaccine—raised by the Trump administration—despite three decades of proven safety and a 99% drop in pediatric cases. Hospitals may stock fewer doses, insurers’ coverage unclear pre-two months, and experts warn it could sow broader vaccine doubt.

articles.title: Science journal retracts study on safety of Monsanto’s Roundup: ‘Serious ethical concerns’
articles.trailText: Paper published in 2000 found glyphosate was not harmful, while internal emails later revealed company’s influence
articles.summary: Regulatory Toxicology and Pharmacology has retracted a 2000 paper by Williams, Kroes and Munro that defended Monsanto’s glyphosate herbicide Roundup as non-carcinogenic after internal emails revealed Monsanto scientists ghostwrote and guided the research under a “Freedom to Operate” strategy. Editor Martin van den Berg cited “serious ethical concerns” over misrepresented authorship, undisclosed conflicts and reliance on unpublished Monsanto studies. The move follows lawsuits that awarded plaintiffs billions in damages and fresh scrutiny of industry influence. Bayer and the EPA say they rely on independent, weight-of-evidence reviews and will update glyphosate assessments by 2026.

articles.title: Trump administration moves to deny visas to factcheckers and content moderators
articles.trailText: Action detailed in a state department memo directs officials to deny visas to any applicant engaging in ‘censorship’
articles.summary: State Dept. memo orders visa denials for applicants involved in 'censorship' of US speech, including fact-checkers, content moderators, trust & safety staff, misinformation/disinformation analysts. Applies to H-1B and all visas, with enhanced vetting via social media, LinkedIn and media mentions. Follows Trump's immigration tightening, Rubio's vow to bar 'speech suppressors.' Critics warn conflating trust & safety with censorship endangers child safety and invites brain drain. State Dept. defends move as protecting Americans' free expression. First flagged by Reuters and NPR, the directive stems from a memo leaked to overseas missions. It follows Trump's September imposition of a $100K fee on H-1B applicants and his reprisals against tech platforms after the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.

articles.title: Pam Bondi tells law enforcement agencies to investigate antifa groups for ‘tax crimes’
articles.trailText: Move is part of Trump’s broader crackdown on leftwing groups, including designation of antifa as ‘domestic terrorism’ group
articles.summary: US AG Pam Bondi ordered federal and local law enforcement to investigate antifa and other leftwing groups for possible tax crimes, part of Trump’s drive to designate antifa as a domestic terror organization. Her memo, first reported by Reuters and Bloomberg, directs agencies to review records, hand over intelligence to the FBI within 14 days, list domestic terror groups, and consider revoking tax-exempt status of liberal nonprofits. It also urges DOJ to prioritize anti-terrorism grants to states. The move builds on recent antifa terror charges in Texas and Rubio’s EU designations, prompting legal experts to decry executive overreach.

articles.title: Tenured US professor fired over pro-Palestinian protests contests dismissal
articles.trailText: Sang Hea Kil is first tenured faculty member fired from a public university in connection to the protests
articles.summary: Sang Hea Kil, a tenured justice studies professor and Students for Justice in Palestine adviser at San José State University, was fired for participating in a February pro-Palestinian protest and student encampment, accused of disrupting university operations and encouraging policy violations. The first tenured public-university faculty member dismissed over Gaza protests since 2014, she is contesting termination through arbitration backed by the California Faculty Association, citing infringements on free speech and academic freedom. Despite a faculty review deeming dismissal disproportionate, university president Cynthia Teniente-Matson upheld the decision. Kil vows legal action if arbitration fails.

articles.title: Ilhan Omar says Trump made racist anti-Somali tirade because he ‘knows he is failing’
articles.trailText: The congresswoman from Minnesota responded to Trump’s dismissal of Somali Americans as ‘garbage’
articles.summary: In a New York Times essay, Somali-born Rep. Ilhan Omar says President Trump’s latest racist tirades—calling Somali Americans “garbage” and demanding she be “thrown out”—reflect a desperate diversion from his failing domestic agenda. She highlights his long record of anti-immigrant, anti-Black and anti-Muslim attacks—from the Muslim travel ban to his “shithole countries” remark—and condemns planned federal immigration raids in Minnesota. Praising Somali American resilience and noting some constituents voted for Trump, Omar warns of the chilling effect on Black, Muslim, immigrant communities but vows: “We will not let him intimidate us.”

articles.title: ‘Don’t normalize this’: after deadly gunfire at children’s party, advocates urge focus on violence tearing US apart
articles.trailText: Community fears shooting will be written off as gang violence and says examination of complex factors such as online feuds is required
articles.summary: In Stockton, California, masked gunmen opened fire at a toddler’s birthday party in a banquet hall, killing two eight-year-olds, a 14-year-old and a 21-year-old, and wounding over a dozen guests. Community organizers like Tashante McCoy and Cymone Reyes warn this gang-related mass shooting reflects a dangerous shift in “diss the dead” rap-fueled feuds and lack of 'no‐shoot' norms. They decry authorities’ tendency to write off such violence, urging equal investigative resources, sustained youth development, mental-health outreach and nonprofit intervention rather than treating it as inevitable urban crime.

articles.title: Homeland security head reveals plans to widen US travel ban to more than 30 countries
articles.trailText: Kristi Noem said the list of countries from which travel to the US is prohibited will increase to an unspecified number
articles.summary: DHS Sec. Kristi Noem told Fox News the US will expand its travel ban to "over 30" countries, though she wouldn’t specify which, as the president continues evaluating unstable nations lacking vetting capacity. Trump’s June proclamation already barred citizens from 12 nations and restricted travel from 7 others to guard against “foreign terrorists.” Reuters reports 36 more countries under consideration. The announcement follows a DC National Guard shooting by an Afghan resettlement entrant and Trump’s vow to pause migration from unspecified “third world” states. Critics say the policy halts asylum reviews, cancels naturalizations and widens Biden-era migration curbs.

articles.title: California pesticide agency could loosen restrictions on most toxic rat poisons
articles.trailText: The anti-coagulant rodenticides also unintentionally harm wildlife across the state, including endangered species
articles.summary: California’s pesticide regulator, under Governor Gavin Newsom, is proposing to roll back strict limits on second-generation anticoagulant rodenticides despite a 2024 law that tied their use to wildlife recovery data. A new state wildlife report documents widespread poisoning of mountain lions, bobcats, hawks, owls, bears, river otters and endangered California condors and bald eagles. The proposal would open over 100,000 new sites—grocery stores, highways, parks—to the most toxic formulations. Critics warn these bioaccumulative poisons cause prolonged internal bleeding, disorientation and impaired survival, and urge lawmakers to close loopholes and preserve the 2024 restrictions.

articles.title: US airstrike survivors clung to boat wreckage for an hour before second deadly attack, video shows
articles.trailText: Footage seen by US senators shows two unarmed, shirtless men struggling to stay afloat before they were killed, sources say
articles.summary: Video seen by US senators shows two unarmed, shirtless survivors of a 2 September US airstrike on a suspected drug-smuggling vessel clinging to wreckage for an hour before a second strike killed them. The Pentagon, calling such operations legal under its narcotics-war rationale, has now conducted 22 maritime strikes, killing at least 87. Democrats described the follow-up as a potential war crime under the laws prohibiting attacks on incapacitated, shipwrecked persons, while Republicans defended the campaign’s legality.

articles.title: US supreme court approves redrawn Texas congressional maps | First Thing
articles.trailText: Major win for Trump as majority rejects lower-court ruling that found maps had been racially gerrymandered. Plus, the story of Mr DeepFakes – the world’s most notorious AI porn site
articles.summary: In a 6-3 conservative-majority order, the US Supreme Court lifted a lower court’s block on Texas’s newly redrawn congressional map—adding up to five Republican-favored seats—after that court had found likely racial gerrymandering. The three liberal justices dissented, warning it upset the federal-state balance in election law. Also featured: the rise of Mr DeepFakes, the notorious AI porn site hosting non-consensual deepfake videos of famous and private individuals via custom commissions.

articles.title: US leader of global neo-Nazi terrorist group signals retribution for arrests
articles.trailText: Rinaldo Nazzaro says detention of suspected Base members in Spain justifies ‘resistance … by any means necessary’
articles.summary: In December 2025, Spanish police and Europol arrested a self-proclaimed neo-Nazi Base cell in Castellón that openly shared weapons training, Kaczynski idolization and calls for a white ethnostate on Telegram. US-born leader Rinaldo Nazzaro, based in St. Petersburg and suspected Kremlin asset, denounced the arrests as political persecution and promised retributive violence. Experts highlight the cell’s sophisticated arsenal and paramilitary drills as echoing past US plots, including a 2020 Virginia attack, and warn its global terror claims in Ukraine and deprioritization by US agencies amplify Europe’s rightwing extremist threat.

articles.title: Key US panel to vote on changing infant hepatitis B vaccine recommendation
articles.trailText: ACIP vote follows two postponements and contentious meeting and comes as RFK Jr pushes for vaccine delay
articles.summary: On Dec. 5, the CDC’s vaccine advisory panel (ACIP) is poised to vote on altering its decades-old recommendation that all newborns receive the hepatitis B vaccine within 24 hours of birth. The decision, delayed twice after a heated, evidence-light debate in Atlanta and influenced by RFK Jr.’s push for postponement, signals the sway of newly appointed vaccine skeptics—hand-picked by Robert F. Kennedy Jr.—including autism-linked theorist Mark Blaxill. Critics warn any schedule change could jeopardize established infant protection against serious liver disease. Final guidance awaits CDC acting director Jim O’Neill.

articles.title: Greg Abbott’s Cair ‘terror’ label stokes legal fight in Texas’s long struggle with Islamophobia
articles.trailText: The civil liberties group argues the Texas governor’s proclamation exceeds his authority and deepens fears
articles.summary: Texas governor Greg Abbott’s November proclamation labeling the Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR) and the Muslim Brotherhood as terrorist organizations, unauthorized at the state level, has prompted CAIR’s Texas chapters to sue Abbott and AG Ken Paxton, alleging violations of free speech, due process and property rights. CAIR, which has won prior suits defending pro-Palestinian speech, calls the move fearmongering amid a surge in anti-Muslim violence and rhetoric—including high-profile incidents like an attempted drowning in Euless—and broader Islamophobic targets such as the Epic City development. Critics from civil rights lawyers to Imam Omar Suleiman deem Abbott’s actions unconstitutional political theater.

articles.title: Nancy Reagan’s rehearsal dinners and Bush Sr’s overfed dog: chief usher’s White House memories
articles.trailText: Gary Walters managed the president’s official residence for 37 years – now he’s sharing his most vivid recollections
articles.summary: Gary Walters, chief usher 1970–2007, recalls 37 years overseeing White House operations under seven presidents. He details Nancy Reagan’s state-dinner rehearsals, the West Wing expansion, Gorbachev’s INF Treaty thaw in the East Room, Clinton’s secure jogging track, Bush Sr.’s overfed dog Ranger, live baseball feeds for George W., and scrambling logistics on 9/11. Walters also initiated gifting presidents their first-and-last-day flags and shares ghost- and burn-mark stories in the Lincoln Bedroom. His new memoir, White House Memories 1970–2007, spans diplomatic renovations, staff anecdotes, and the behind-the-scenes challenges of presidential security and hospitality.

articles.title: Pentagon announces it has killed four men in another boat strike in Pacific
articles.trailText: Strike comes amid congressional turmoil over legality of US attacks on suspected drug smugglers
articles.summary: Pentagon on Dec. 4 announced a lethal strike by Joint Task Force Southern Spear, directed by Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, on a suspected narcotics boat in international waters of the eastern Pacific, killing four alleged narco-terrorists. Video from US Southern Command shows the vessel engulfed in flames. It was the 22nd such operation since September, raising the campaign’s death toll to at least 87. The strikes face growing congressional scrutiny over their legal basis—including an impeachment resolution against Hegseth—and experts reject classifying shipborne drug smugglers as lawful combatants under international law.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: US supreme court gives Texas win in national redistricting battle
articles.trailText: State is key in president’s effort to secure Republicans’ fragile House majority for second half of his term
articles.summary: The US Supreme Court’s 6-3 conservative majority lifted a lower court ban on Texas’s new map, allowing up to five GOP-friendly districts and delivering a major victory for Trump’s bid to bolster Republicans’ fragile House majority before the midterms, over liberal dissents led by Justice Kagan. Other updates: Pentagon boat strike kills four; Trump replaces White House ballroom architect; grand jury spares NY AG Letitia James; arrest in Capitol pipe bomb plot; DC appeals court extends Guard deployment; ICE deports student to Honduras; Amnesty slams Alligator Alcatraz detentions; NYT sues Pentagon over press limits.

articles.title: Court releases audio of 911 call that led to Luigi Mangione’s arrest
articles.trailText: Judge allows call from manager of Pennsylvania McDonald’s to be made public after press urged its release
articles.summary: An Altoona McDonald’s manager’s 911 call, in which she reported a customer she suspected was Brian Thompson’s alleged killer—citing a black jacket, mask and khaki beanie—was released after press advocacy and played in Manhattan state court. The call prompted police to arrest Luigi Mangione, who faces state and federal counts and has pleaded not guilty. Judge Gregory Carro unsealed some exhibits following a press outcry (a reporter was ejected), noting they would be posted on the DA’s Dropbox; additional materials remain under seal.

articles.title: US student who took four chickens after breaking into slaughterhouse sentenced to 90 days in jail
articles.trailText: Zoe Rosenberg, 23, studying at UC Berkeley, had said it was a ‘rescue’ and ‘will not apologize’ for her actions
articles.summary: UC Berkeley student Zoe Rosenberg, 23, has been sentenced to 90 days in jail (60 days potentially as house arrest) and ordered to pay over $100,000 in restitution after pleading guilty to felony conspiracy and three misdemeanors for breaking into a Petaluma Perdue Farms slaughterhouse in 2023 and rescuing four chickens. Convicted by a judge, she must report to Sonoma County jail on December 10. Her act, part of Direct Action Everywhere’s “right to rescue” campaign, ignited legal debate over animal welfare and drew support from actor Joaquin Phoenix.

articles.title: US supreme court approves redrawn Texas congressional maps
articles.trailText: Major win for Trump as majority rejects lower-court ruling that found maps had been racially gerrymandered
articles.summary: The US Supreme Court’s 6–3 conservative majority has cleared Texas’s mid-cycle congressional maps, which add up to five Republican-leaning districts, overturning a lower court’s racial gerrymandering ruling. The unsigned order lifts a stay that would have forced Texas to use post-2020 census lines in next year’s midterms. Justice Elena Kagan’s dissent, joined by Justices Sotomayor and Jackson, warns the decision entrenches racial sorting and undercuts factual findings. Republicans, including AG Ken Paxton and Trump allies, hailed the victory; House Democrats and the DCCC called it an extreme partisan power grab.

articles.title: Grand jury declines to re-indict Letitia James after judge dismissed first case
articles.trailText: Decision comes less than two weeks after judge ruled similar case against New York attorney general unlawful
articles.summary: After a judge last month tossed a mortgage fraud case against New York AG Letitia James, a federal grand jury again declined Thursday to indict her. Originally charged in October with bank fraud and false statements over a 2020 Norfolk, VA, rental-home mortgage—allegedly saving $18,933 by mislabeling it a second home—James argued the US attorney who filed charges was unlawfully appointed. Experts and career prosecutors deemed the case weak. Attorney Abbe Lowell warned further pursuit would undermine rule of law.

articles.title: Court hears Maurene Comey was fired as retaliation against ex-FBI chief father
articles.trailText: Daughter of James Comey was dismissed by Trump justice department from job as prosecutor in New York
articles.summary: Maurene Comey, who led prosecutions of Jeffrey Epstein, Ghislaine Maxwell and Sean “Diddy” Combs, sued the Trump Justice Department in Manhattan federal court, claiming her July 2025 firing was political retaliation against her father, ex‐FBI director James Comey. Despite an exemplary performance review weeks earlier, DOJ abruptly dismissed her via email citing only the Constitution. At a procedural hearing, the judge weighed deferring discovery to an arbitration board; Comey seeks reinstatement, back pay and a declaration that her termination violated separation of powers and her constitutional rights.

articles.title: Several people arrested in New Orleans amid ICE ‘siege’: ‘It’s racial profiling’
articles.trailText: Communities remain terrified as Trump administration’s crackdown on another Democratic-led city enters day two
articles.summary: In New Orleans, ICE’s Operation Catahoula Crunch has detained dozens—often in public areas such as Home Depot parking lots, bus stops and hardware stores—sparking fears among immigrant communities. Multiple US citizens were briefly held. Advocates describe the raids as racial profiling and “psychological warfare.” Protests at city council disrupted calls for ICE-free zones and stronger local protections; an online portal was launched for reporting federal misconduct. Families fear job loss and deportation, leaving kids home for Christmas, while solidarity networks organize legal and logistical support.

articles.title: Trump replaces architect overseeing $300m gilded ballroom project
articles.trailText: President and James McCrery II disagreed over expanding ballroom’s size, but change prompted by firm’s limited staff
articles.summary: President Trump has removed James McCrery II and his boutique firm from overseeing the $300 million, 90,000-sq-ft gilded White House ballroom—citing missed deadlines and limited staff despite occasional disputes over expansion plans—and appointed veteran federal architect Shalom Baranes in his place. The White House confirmed Baranes, noted for projects like the Treasury building, will drive development into its next phase, while McCrery stays on as a consultant. The change follows criticism over East Wing demolition and Trump’s earlier ousting of the Commission of Fine Arts.

articles.title: RoboCop statue rises in Detroit: ‘Big, beautiful, bronze piece of art’
articles.trailText: A 15-year quest ends with a monument, drawing crowds and nostalgia as Detroit embraces its cult-film past
articles.summary: An 11-foot, 3,500-pound bronze statue of RoboCop now stands guard near Detroit's Eastern Market, capping a 15-year journey that began with a 2010 tweet and a 2012 Kickstarter that raised $67,000. Sculpted by Giorgio Gikas in 2017 but mired in storage and a canceled Michigan Science Center exhibit, it was finally installed at Free Age film company in December 2025. Drawing selfie-minded crowds even during snowstorms, the monument channels nostalgia for the 1987 cult film and symbolizes Detroit's declining crime rates and civic rebirth. Early backer James Campbell, who contributed $100, joked he owns 0.038% of this cinematic landmark.

articles.title: Experts urge release of boat strike video as US admiral denies ‘kill them all’ order
articles.trailText: Democrat Jim Himes calls footage ‘one of the most troubling scenes’ he’s observed in public service
articles.summary: After a deadly double airstrike on a vessel alleged to carry drugs off Trinidad—killing 11—Congressional leaders debated whether Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth ordered commanders to “kill survivors.” In a classified briefing, Admiral Frank Bradley denied a “no quarter” directive. Top Democrat Jim Himes labeled the footage “troubling” and pressed for full video release, while GOP Sen. Tom Cotton called the strikes “righteous.” Trump and Hegseth deny wrongdoing. Human rights groups warn the campaign—83 boat strikes since September—may violate war‐crimes law, prompting calls for a War Powers resolution and transparency.

articles.title: New York mayor issues order targeting Israel divestment weeks before Mamdani takes office
articles.trailText: Eric Adams signed orders on boycott, divestment and sanctions movement, and protests near houses of worship
articles.summary: In late 2025 Mayor Eric Adams issued two executive orders to counter antisemitism and BDS: prohibiting city agencies and pension officials from boycotting or divesting from Israel or associated individuals, and directing the NYPD to tighten protest rules near houses of worship after synagogue protests. With $300 m of $250 bn pensions in Israeli assets, Adams framed the measures as safeguarding Jewish New Yorkers’ rights. The orders, seen as a preemptive curb on incoming mayor Zohran Mamdani—an outspoken Israel critic—risk reversal and stoke debate over where criticism of Israel becomes antisemitic.

articles.title: Suspect arrested and named in case of pipe bombs planted on eve of January 6
articles.trailText: Bombs were placed near Republican and Democratic party HQs in Washington night before US Capitol attack
articles.summary: On Dec 4 2025 US DOJ named Brian Cole, 30, of Woodbridge VA, as the suspect who planted pipe bombs outside the RNC and DNC HQs near the Capitol on Jan 5 2021. Using re-examined forensic evidence—including surveillance video, distinctive Nike shoes, license-plate readers, cell-tower links—and following a $500,000 reward offered in 2023, authorities charged Cole with interstate transport of explosive devices and attempted malicious destruction. Cole, who works for a bail bond firm and lived with his parents, remains under investigation with no motive disclosed.

articles.title: Hegseth broke rules in sharing Yemen strike details on Signal, report finds
articles.trailText: An investigation found defense secretary put US forces at risk, triggering fresh demands for his resignation
articles.summary: An unclassified DoD inspector general report found defense secretary Pete Hegseth violated protocol by using his personal phone to share secret operational details of the 15 March Yemen airstrike in a ‘Houthi PC Small Group’ Signal chat, mirroring a CENTCOM-secured email. The breach risked US personnel and mission security, prompting Senate Intelligence vice-chair Mark Warner to call for Hegseth’s resignation. Hegseth countered on X that no classified material was leaked and he had declassified general details to provide an unclassified summary. Partial auto-deletion of messages forced the IG to rely on The Atlantic’s transcript to assess the full scope.

articles.title: CDC advisers delay vote on restricting infant hepatitis B vaccinations in tense meeting
articles.trailText: From 1990 to 2019, reported cases of acute hepatitis B among kids declined by 99% due to infant immunization
articles.summary: At a contentious CDC ACIP meeting, advisers voted 6–3 to delay until Friday a decision on restricting infant hepatitis B vaccination despite no new safety concerns. Handpicked anti-vaccine advocates led by RFK Jr appointees questioned the birth dose—currently credited with a 99% drop in pediatric acute hepatitis B cases since 1990—but offered only speculative harm data. Modelling warns delaying to two months could cause 1,400 infections, 300 liver cancers, 480 deaths and $222m extra costs annually. Experts warn such debates may erode public trust, worsen falling immunization rates, and jeopardize gains against measles and other vaccine-preventable diseases.

articles.title: Trump lashes out at Somalis again as Minneapolis stands behind community
articles.trailText: Activists prepare for more targeting of Somali residents by ICE as Trump renews racist tirade
articles.summary: Donald Trump renewed racist attacks on Minneapolis Somalis, calling their nation “garbage,” urging deportations, and targeting US Rep. Ilhan Omar. His administration plans a surge of ICE agents to enforce deportation orders. Minneapolis leaders, including Mayor Jacob Frey, passed an order barring use of city lots for federal operations, and activists organized rights trainings, ICE-watch volunteer networks, and legal clinics. Neighbors and businesses distributed whistles and signage to deter ICE. Community groups highlight that most Somalis are US citizens or refugees and counter right-wing fraud claims. The city stands firmly behind its 84,000-strong Somali population.

articles.title: Inside the climate group working everywhere but DC: ‘You can still have huge wins’
articles.trailText: Climate Cabinet supports candidates in state and city races as the federal government ignores the climate crisis
articles.summary: With federal inaction under Trump, analysts estimate 75% of US Paris climate pledges are achievable at state and local levels. Caroline Spears founded Climate Cabinet in 2020 to use data science across 500,000+ public offices, identifying and funding 500+ pro-climate candidates with a 75%+ win rate (42/45 in 2025), now overseeing policies cutting 813 MtCO2e annually. Highlights include Naperville council member Ian Holzhauer’s re-election stalling a coal contract despite billionaire-backed attacks, and support for Juan de Jesus Sanchez for New Mexico Land Commissioner (9 M acres, boosting renewables). By targeting under-the-radar races costing <$400 K, leveraging small donations, and endorsing on voting records, they flipped chambers in Minnesota, Michigan and Virginia to pass 100% clean energy mandates.

articles.title: US schools face big price swings for basics under Amazon’s ‘dynamic pricing’, report claims
articles.trailText: Amazon calls the report ‘flawed and misleading’ and says it offers lower prices than competitors
articles.summary: Non-profit ILSR analysis of government procurement data finds US schools and municipalities overpay for basics under Amazon’s dynamic pricing: identical orders varied up to 30%, costing Denver Public Schools an estimated $1m in 2023. Across 23 entities and 55,000 purchases, buyers could have saved 17% by locking in Amazon’s lowest rates. The report urges bans on algorithmic pricing and prioritizing local vendors. Amazon disputes the findings, citing everyday low prices, price ceilings, local-supplier tools and efficiency gains on its Business portal.

articles.title: Student describes ‘horror show’ ICE deportation to Honduras at Thanksgiving
articles.trailText: Any Lucia López Belloza, 19, was detained at Boston airport while on the way to see family in Austin for a surprise trip
articles.summary: Any Lucia López Belloza, a 19-year-old Babson College student, was detained by ICE at Boston Logan airport while boarding a Thanksgiving flight to Austin, then shackled and deported to Honduras within 48 hours despite a judge’s 72-hour emergency stay. With no criminal record, she received no removal order or hearing, and her lawyers argue her rights were violated. In Honduras, where gang violence and political strife are rampant, López hopes to resume her studies and legally fight to return.

articles.title: Trump’s sweeping changes to US immigration policy – here’s what to know
articles.trailText: President orders pause on asylum claims and extra scrutiny of migrants from 19 countries after Washington shooting
articles.summary: Following a deadly Washington shooting, Trump ordered USCIS to suspend consideration of approximately 1.5 million pending asylum applications, while leaving court proceedings intact. A memo also halts work authorizations, green-card, naturalization and family-sponsorship petitions for nationals of 19 “high-risk” countries (including Afghanistan, Iran, Venezuela, Yemen and others) and mandates a comprehensive re-review of approvals since January 2021, potentially requiring new interviews and security checks. DHS Secretary Kristi Noem urged expanding the list to around 30 countries. Legal experts predict federal court challenges that could pause enforcement but lengthen the asylum backlog and worsen humanitarian impacts.

articles.title: Trump has granted clemency to more than 1,800 people – and some have been arrested again
articles.trailText: President did not follow the usual review process, experts say, making it more likely they would commit other crimes
articles.summary: Trump has issued over 1,800 pardons and commutations since 2016 — many without Justice Department review — and at least a dozen recipients have since been arrested for new alleged offenses. Among them: January 6 rioters like Andrew Taake, who attacked police then fled; Daniel Ball, charged with illegal gun possession; David Daniel, found with child pornography; and fraud convicts Jonathan Braun and Eliyahu Weinstein, both reoffending post-commutation. Critics warn unchecked clemency undermines rule of law by signaling impunity.

articles.title: ‘Alligator Alcatraz’ detainees face human rights violations, report alleges | First Thing
articles.trailText: Amnesty finds detainees at Florida facility were shackled and left outside in metal cage. Plus, how the dollar-store industry overcharges consumers
articles.summary: Amnesty International alleges detainees at Florida’s Everglades “Alligator Alcatraz” and Miami’s Krome processing center were subjected to cruel treatment—including being shackled in 2-ft-high metal cages under sweltering sun for up to 24 hours without water—used arbitrarily to punish minor or fabricated offenses. Interviews and site visits documented inhuman conditions raising torture concerns. A federal judge ordered the Everglades facility closed in August, but it reopened after appeals. Florida officials, led by Gov. DeSantis, dismiss the findings as politically motivated fabrications.

articles.title: Killing of survivors sparks outrage – but entire US ‘drug boat’ war is legally shaky
articles.trailText: Pentagon’s Law of War manual clearly prohibits attack, but justification for whole campaign also faces tough questions
articles.summary: Since September the Trump administration has launched over 20 ‘drug boat’ strikes in the Caribbean and Pacific, killing at least 81 people. A Washington Post exposé revealed that on September 2 a follow-up strike—allegedly ordered by Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth to “kill everybody”—targeted two survivors clinging to a disabled Venezuelan vessel. Legal scholars contend the US is not in armed conflict with traffickers, making the attacks on hors de combat individuals a clear violation of the Pentagon’s Law of War manual, international law and US military justice. Republican-led congressional committees have opened investigations into the orders, targeting rationale and failure to rescue survivors.

articles.title: New Texas law allows residents to sue those suspected of providing access to abortion pills
articles.trailText: Abortion providers, and even manufacturers, will be liable for penalties over pills mailed into the state
articles.summary: The Texas law enables any resident to sue individuals or firms suspected of manufacturing, distributing or mailing abortion pills across state lines—apart from the pill-taker—and imposes minimum $100K penalties on providers and manufacturers. It directly challenges blue-state “shield laws” that protect telemedicine abortions, prompting threats of Supreme Court standoffs after Texas AG’s failed lawsuits against out-of-state doctors. Despite risks, providers vow to keep shipping pills. Critics warn it endangers patients and may drive care away from Texas.

articles.title: ‘Never seen anything like this’: alarm at memo from top US vaccine official
articles.trailText: Vinay Prasad memo said at least 10 children had died from Covid vaccination – but offered scant evidence for claim
articles.summary: FDA biologics chief Vinay Prasad’s internal memo asserts, without sourcing, that at least 10 children aged 7–16 died post–Covid vaccination according to VAERS reports. He vows to overhaul vaccine regulation—limiting external advisory input, requiring outcome-based trials for flu, Covid, MMR and simultaneous shots—yet cites no data. Experts warn this unprecedented top-down shift risks undermining public trust, delaying annual flu and other vaccines, and increasing preventable illness. Infectious-disease specialists and former CDC leaders urge transparent evidence and fear fewer vaccines will mean more outbreaks and deaths.

articles.title: RFK Jr’s vaccine advisory panel to weigh delaying hepatitis B shots for newborns
articles.trailText: Experts say any change to the hepatitis B schedule could have significant and far-reaching consequences
articles.summary: RFK Jr convenes an HHS-appointed panel Thursday to consider delaying the newborn hepatitis B vaccine, reversing decades-old US policy credited with a 99% drop in acute pediatric cases since 1990. After firing 17 CDC advisory members, he installed vaccine skeptics, including Dr Martin Kulldorff’s successor Dr Kirk Milhoan, a Covid-vaccine critic. The panel has already endorsed thimerosal-free flu shots and split the MMRV vaccine, and voted against Covid-19 jabs. The advisory recommendations go to acting CDC director Jim O’Neill after Susan Monarez’s ouster; experts warn any schedule shift could reverse gains and exacerbate outbreaks.

articles.title: Detainees at ‘Alligator Alcatraz’ facing ‘harrowing human right violations’, new report alleges
articles.trailText: Amnesty International finds immigrants at Florida facility were shackled and left outside in metal cage for up to a day
articles.summary: Amnesty International report alleges migrants at Florida’s state-run “Alligator Alcatraz” and Miami’s private Krome center face “cruel, inhuman and degrading” treatment: detainees shackled in 2ft-high metal cages (“the box”) under south Florida sun for up to 24 hours, exposed to unsanitary conditions, insect-infested cells, medical neglect, 24-hour lighting and arbitrary punishment. Despite a federal judge ordering Alligator Alcatraz closed, it reopened under an appeals stay. Amnesty calls for ending state–federal immigration agreements and halting mass detention.

articles.title: New England warming faster than most places on Earth, study finds
articles.trailText: Pace of area’s temperature rise, outpaced in US only by Alaskan Arctic, apparently increased in past five years
articles.summary: New England is warming faster than almost anywhere globally except Alaska’s Arctic, with a 2.5 °C average rise since 1900—nearly double the global 1.3 °C—particularly accelerating over the past five years. Researchers Stephen and Joshua Young found winter and nighttime temperatures increasing fastest, cutting snow cover by 18% since 2000, especially in southern states. A slowed Gulf Stream driven by Greenland meltwater has concentrated ocean heat along the coast. This rapid warming threatens maple syrup harvests, ice-based sports and ski seasons. Published in Climate journal, the study signals a fast-climbing climate crisis in the region.

articles.title: Trump pardons entertainment exec indicted by his own justice department
articles.trailText: Tim Leiweke was accused of ‘orchestrating a conspiracy to rig the bidding process for an arena at a public university’
articles.summary: President Trump quietly granted a full and unconditional pardon Tuesday to sports and entertainment executive Tim Leiweke, co-founder of Oak View Group, who was indicted by his own Justice Department in July for allegedly orchestrating a conspiracy to rig bidding on a public university arena in Austin, Texas. Leiweke, who pleaded not guilty and awaited trial, is the fifth high-profile pardon this week, announced without White House explanation. DOJ antitrust officials said his scheme deprived the university and taxpayers of fair competition. Leiweke, expressing profound gratitude, called the pardon a 'new lease on life' for his family.

articles.title: Safety volunteer charged in fatal shooting of ‘No Kings’ protester in Utah
articles.trailText: Protest guard fired at armed man he mistakenly believed to be threat to protesters but accidentally killed a bystander
articles.summary: A Salt Lake City safety volunteer, Matthew Scott Alder, 43, was charged with manslaughter for accidentally killing protester Arthur “Afa” Ah Loo on June 14. Alder fired three shots at armed marcher Arturo Gamboa, mistakenly believing he planned a mass shooting; Gamboa’s rifle was unloaded and legally carried. Gamboa was briefly jailed without charges under state gun laws. Alder’s bullet missed Gamboa, struck Ah Loo as he filmed. District Attorney Sim Gill labeled the act reckless. Alder faces up to 15 years in prison and a $10,000 fine.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Hegseth remains in hot seat over Signal chat leak, boat strikes
articles.trailText: Pentagon report concludes defense secretary endangered troops as some Republican lawmakers scrutinize Caribbean operations – key US politics stories from 3 December 2025
articles.summary: An inspector general’s long-awaited Pentagon report finds Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth violated policy and risked US troops by sharing classified Yemen airstrike plans in a Signal chat with JD Vance, CIA director John Ratcliffe and ex-NSA Mike Waltz. Hegseth refused questioning, claiming declassification authority; an unclassified version is due soon. Meanwhile, Republican senators led by Rand Paul question the administration’s rationale for dual Caribbean drug-boat strikes. Other key developments: new images of Epstein’s Caribbean island released; ICE raids in New Orleans; Trump pardons Rep. Henry Cuellar; Colombia warns Trump over drug threats; Biden-era fuel standards repealed and some travel bans paused.

articles.title: Trump officials say second strike aimed to destroy suspected drug boat instead of crew
articles.trailText: Officials hew closely to secret memo which gives legal cover to firing on boats even if it would kill people on board
articles.summary: Trump administration officials defended a second strike on a suspected drug boat on 2 September, saying Adm. Frank Bradley aimed to destroy the vessel under a secret OLC memo authorising lethal force against unflagged cocaine traffickers as part of collective self-defense. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth emphasised the order was legally grounded in a classified intelligence annex and a July NSPM. The OLC opinion holds that civilian casualties are permissible if targeting the boat, a view critics say lacks public evidence of cartels’ armed-conflict status. Bradley is set to testify on Thursday.

articles.title: Federal agents launch immigration crackdown in New Orleans
articles.trailText: Gregory Bovino, border patrol chief and face of Trump’s mass deportation efforts, seen patrolling French Quarter
articles.summary: Federal agents under “Operation Catahoula Crunch,” led by border patrol chief Gregory Bovino, launched a sweeping immigration crackdown in New Orleans and suburbs aiming to net up to 5,000 arrests of immigrants released after criminal charges. About 250 agents, masked and in marked/unmarked vehicles, made arrests outside hardware stores and patrolled the French Quarter. Community organizers, local businesses and the mayor-elect raised profiling and due-process concerns amid protests and staff shortages. Louisiana’s GOP governor praised the operation and announced National Guard deployment, while local police refused to enforce federal immigration law, creating tensions over jurisdiction.

articles.title: Pentagon report concludes Hegseth put troops in danger with Signal chat
articles.trailText: Report says defense secretary violated policies in sharing secret information in March on planned airstrike in Yemen
articles.summary: An internal DoD IG report concluded Defense Sec. Pete Hegseth breached protocols by sharing secret March Yemen airstrike plans targeting Houthis in an unapproved Signal group chat that included Vance, CIA Dir. Ratcliffe, NSC’s Waltz and an Atlantic reporter—risking US pilots if intercepted. Though Hegseth claims declassification power and denies wrongdoing on X, he refused an IG interview. The report flagged other insecure chats as a pattern. Sen. Mark Warner demanded his resignation. Congress received the findings and an unclassified version is due this week.

articles.title: $700 for a bed? San Francisco startup plots ‘sleeping pod’ expansion
articles.trailText: Brownstone firm buys building with plan for 400 pods in city where median apartment rent tops $3,000 a month
articles.summary: Brownstone Shared Housing purchased a six-story downtown San Francisco building at 1049 Market to install up to 400 stacked, twin-size sleeping pods at $700/month—versus the city’s $3,065 median rent. The startup, which already operates about two dozen pods at 12 Mint Plaza with shared kitchens, bathrooms and workspaces, saw an eviction suit over $150,000 in back rent dismissed. CEO James Stallworth plans to maintain both sites after receiving hundreds of applications. The expansion underscores rising demand for micro-living as SF rents surge 12.2% year-over-year amid an AI-driven wealth influx that squeezes middle-class workers out of traditional housing.

articles.title: Lawmakers decry Trump’s immigration halt for 19 countries: ‘scapegoating entire nationalities’
articles.trailText: Crackdown on applications from countries also under travel restrictions comes after shooting of two national guards
articles.summary: President Trump has ordered an immediate adjudicative hold on immigration and asylum applications from 19 high-risk countries already under US travel restrictions—including Afghanistan, Burma, Cuba, Iran, Venezuela, Yemen and others—while reviewing all entrants since January 2021. The decision, prompted by last week’s DC shooting of two National Guard members by an Afghan asylum recipient, also halts naturalization ceremonies for affected nationals. Human Rights Watch, Human Rights First, the National Immigrant Justice Center and the National Iranian American Council decry the measure as racist scapegoating that tears families apart, undermines due process and damages US human-rights credibility. Congressional critics like Rep. Ilhan Omar and Minnesota Secretary of State Steve Simon warn it fuels xenophobia and bigotry.

articles.title: Trump says he will repeal Biden-era fuel efficiency standards for cars and trucks
articles.trailText: Move marks president’s latest effort to dismantle pollution regulations and support for cleaner-running vehicles
articles.summary: President Trump announced repeal of Biden-era Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) standards, scrapping the planned 50 mpg requirement for cars and light trucks by 2031 and replacing it with a 34 mpg target. Flanked by CEOs of Ford and Stellantis, he argued the rollback will lower vehicle costs, support automaker jobs and ease ‘burdensome’ regulations. The move also undoes tailpipe emissions rules and electric-vehicle tax credits. Environmental groups, including the Sierra Club and Center for Biological Diversity, warn this will boost gasoline consumption, increase greenhouse gas emissions and weaken US clean-tech competitiveness.

articles.title: Judge blocks widespread immigration arrests in DC made without warrants or probable cause
articles.trailText: Injunction was sought by civil liberties groups in lawsuit against Department of Homeland Security
articles.summary: A federal judge in Washington, D.C., granted a preliminary injunction blocking the Department of Homeland Security from conducting widespread immigration arrests without warrants or probable cause of imminent flight risk. The ACLU, Casa and Amica Center sued after reporting indiscriminate stops and arrests in Latino neighborhoods since an emergency declaration in August, fueling fear and hindering daily life. Judge Beryl Howell requires agents to document specific flight-risk facts and share records, mirroring similar rulings in Colorado and California.

articles.title: Republican lawmakers scrutinize Trump administration over ‘drug boat’ strikes
articles.trailText: US House and Senate lawmakers to meet with top admiral on Thursday about double strike on boats from Venezuela
