articles.summary: Senate and House Republicans will interview Navy Admiral Frank Bradley Thursday over two US naval strikes on suspected Venezuelan drug boats on Sept. 2, notably a controversial second attack that killed survivors. The key issue is whether Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth ordered the follow-up — a claim he denies — amid shifting White House explanations. Karoline Leavitt defends Bradley’s actions. Lawmakers from Rand Paul to Jim Justice and Thom Tillis demand accountability or release of video footage; Armed Services Chair Roger Wicker promises vigorous oversight, while Roger Marshall calls the strikes necessary to stem lethal drug flows.

articles.title: House Democrats release new images of Epstein’s private Caribbean island
articles.trailText: Images and videos taken in 2020, a year after he died in jail, show the late sex offender’s home
articles.summary: House Democrats on Dec. 3 published 2020 law-enforcement photos and walkthrough videos of Jeffrey Epstein’s private Little St. James island in the USVI, revealing bedrooms, an office/library with a chalkboard inscribed ‘fin,’ ‘intellectual,’ ‘deception,’ ‘power,’ and a room with a dentist chair and masks. These materials, released by USVI authorities, follow a $100 million settlement with Epstein’s estate over alleged trafficking and abuse of minors. A bipartisan House group led by Rep. Robert Garcia also sought a status update from AG Pam Bondi, citing more forthcoming financial records from JPMorgan and Deutsche Bank ahead of a Dec. 19 DOJ deadline.

articles.title: Trump administration pauses all immigration applications from 19 non-European countries
articles.trailText: Pause, including Afghanistan and Somalia, indicates plan to tie US security to increased focus on legal immigration
articles.summary: USCIS has indefinitely paused visa, green card and asylum applications from 19 non-European nations on Trump’s travel ban list – including Afghanistan, Somalia and Iran – citing national security after a Thanksgiving shooting by an Afghan asylum grantee. A policy memo orders holds on all asylum petitions, a review of entries since Jan 20, 2021, and within 90 days a prioritized roster for possible enforcement or law-enforcement referral. It extends June’s ban on 12 countries plus partial sanctions on seven, affects those already in the US, and adds new interviews and vetting.

articles.title: FDA drug chief signals possible exit as agency turmoil deepens
articles.trailText: Richard Pazdur’s potential retirement weeks into the role adds to upheaval at the FDA amid political pressure
articles.summary: FDA drug regulator Richard Pazdur filed retirement papers just weeks after accepting the CDER directorship, intensifying leadership churn at the agency. He would be the fourth CDER chief this year following George Tidmarsh’s departure amid a retaliation lawsuit, and replaces a brief vacancy caused by Vinay Prasad’s clashes over regulatory reforms. Pazdur was tasked with piloting a rapid-approval “National Priority Voucher” program likened to a regulatory “Shark Tank,” but lack of planning and one-day decision panels fuel concern. Experts warn the exit threatens drug approval stability, industry predictability and public trust.

articles.title: ‘I’ve held this in my whole life’: ex-Big Brother contestant testifies about childhood sexual abuse by New Orleans priest
articles.trailText: Renny Martyn revealed in archdiocese bankruptcy proceedings that priest abused her at school when she was six years old
articles.summary: Renny Martyn, 71, known from Big Brother 10, testified in December 3 US bankruptcy proceedings against the New Orleans archdiocese, revealing she was molested at age six by priest Hubert Broussard at St. Mary Magdalen school in Metairie. Martyn described lifelong emotional scars and highlighted that Broussard isn’t on the church’s list of 80 credibly accused clergy. Her testimony came during a fairness trial for a proposed $230 million settlement funding hundreds of abuse survivors. Martyn called speaking out “liberating,” and Judge Grabill praised her courage.

articles.title: Drunk raccoon found passed out in Virginia liquor store
articles.trailText: Store employee found masked bandit sleeping off a bender after invading booze store and tippling a tad too much
articles.summary: Virginia liquor store employee discovered a raccoon passed out in the bathroom amid smashed whisky bottles after it fell through the ceiling and gorged itself. Animal control cited no injuries beyond a hangover and released the animal back into the wild. The incident underscores raccoons’ urban adaptation and potential domestication traits – shorter snouts, smaller brains and teeth – linked to scavenging human refuse. Researchers note frequent alcohol consumption across species, citing similar incidents: a beer-bingeing pig in Australia and a honey-intoxicated bear cub in Turkey. In Toronto, an overabundant raccoon population has even spawned a 'Raccoons v Toronto' T-shirt trend.

articles.title: Family of victim of Trump boat airstrikes files complaint against ‘extrajudicial killing’ | First Thing
articles.trailText: Alejandro Carranza Medina’s relatives say he was a fisher, not a drug trafficker. Plus, Putin says Russia ‘ready’ for war with Europe as Ukraine talks stall
articles.summary: Colombian fisher Alejandro Carranza Medina’s family petitioned the Washington-based Inter-American Commission on Human Rights, accusing a September 15 US airstrike under Trump’s anti-drug-boat campaign of extrajudicial killing. They insist Carranza was hunting tuna and marlin, not trafficking. UN agencies say at least 83 people died in over 20 US strikes in the Caribbean and Pacific in three months. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, accused of ordering “kill everybody,” denies the claim, and the US has yet to formally respond.

articles.title: ‘The Mamdani effect’: wealthy New Yorkers show renewed interest in Miami’s Billionaire’s Beach
articles.trailText: Sales spike at the Ritz-Carlton, Four Seasons and Cipriani as luxury buyers weigh moves from Manhattan
articles.summary: Wealthy New Yorkers, fearing Mayor Zohran Mamdani’s democratic socialist policies, are driving an “exponential” surge in inquiries and sales at Miami’s Billionaire’s Beach, from the Ritz-Carlton Residences’ 166% jump in New York interest to Four Seasons Coconut Grove’s 10–15% uptick. Projects like Perigon, with two-bedroom units from $12.5 m and an exclusive chef-run speakeasy, and the 80-story Cipriani tower, where one-beds start near $2 m, tout opulent finishes, ocean views and full-service amenities. Developers see a “thoughtful exodus” of second-home buyers weighing seasonal retreats and tax advantages.

articles.title: Trump ally admits goal of eliminating same-day registration in federal voting rights trial
articles.trailText: Cleta Mitchell was compelled to testify in North Carolina over a recent law that hiked up requirements
articles.summary: In a federal trial over N.C.’s SB 747, Trump ally Cleta Mitchell and activist Jim Womack admitted they urged GOP lawmakers to end same-day registration—used by about half of college voters—by requiring extra proof-of-residence (e.g. utility bills) and discarding ballots if notice letters go unreturned. Mitchell labeled same-day registration a fraud favoring Democrats; plaintiffs contend the activists drafted discriminatory language targeting students under the 26th Amendment. Judge Schroeder will rule on whether the law unlawfully burdens young voters.

articles.title: How the dollar-store industry overcharges cash-strapped customers while promising low prices
articles.trailText: A Guardian investigation reveals Dollar General and Family Dollar stores often fail to honor their shelf prices – charging more at checkout for everything from frying pans to Frosted Flakes
articles.summary: A Guardian investigation shows Dollar General and Family Dollar chains frequently charge customers more at checkout than shelf prices indicate, with average overcharge rates around 30% in failed inspections across 23 and 20 states respectively. Regulatory fines capped at $5,000 per violation provide little incentive to fix errors rooted in understaffing and outdated shelf tags. Low-income shoppers often overlook small discrepancies, cumulatively draining tight budgets. Despite multi-state settlements exceeding $3m and corporate promises to improve pricing accuracy, enforcement gaps and minimal state inspections allow overcharging to persist, exacerbating economic hardship for vulnerable communities.

articles.title: Revealed: US veterans affairs to share immigration data about non-citizen workers with ‘appropriate agencies’
articles.trailText: Exclusive: The move prompts fears the data will be sent to ICE to further the Trump administration’s immigration crackdown
articles.summary: Leaked memo shows the VA is building by Dec 30 a comprehensive internal database of non-US-citizen employees, contractors, trainees and volunteers, to share ‘adverse findings’ with ‘appropriate agencies,’ likely including ICE. Officials justify it under federal vetting laws but exclude US citizens. Critics warn permanent residents and veteran staff face deportation risks, undermining workforce morale and patient safety. Illinois Rep. Delia Ramirez labels it an authoritarian list-making tactic. The move echoes Trump’s expanded interagency data-sharing push and fuels fears of intimidation of legally present workers.

articles.title: Republican Matt Van Epps wins closely watched Tennessee special election
articles.trailText: Race called with Van Epps holding a 52% lead over Aftyn Behn’s 46% in normally reliable Republican territory
articles.summary: Republican Matt Van Epps won Tennessee’s 7th district special election 52%-46% over Democrat Aftyn Behn in a typically safe GOP seat (Trump +15 in 2020; +22 in 2024), prompting warnings of a narrowing Republican base ahead of the midterms. Van Epps credited Trump’s virtual endorsement, while Behn’s campaign—backed by Democrats on cost-of-living issues—exceeded expectations in a Trump +22 district. Cook Political Report downgraded the seat to “leans Republican.” The open seat arose after Mark Green’s July resignation; House Republicans now lead 219-213.

articles.title: Trump claims to void all documents signed by Biden, citing autopen use
articles.trailText: Presidents of both major parties have used the device and experts called into question legality of Trump’s move
articles.summary: After claiming Biden used an autopen to sign various documents, Trump on Truth Social declared all such pardons and other acts “terminated” and of no legal effect. Experts say federal law and the Constitution don’t require a bare-hand signature, there’s no mechanism to reverse prior pardons and it’s unclear Biden even autopen-signed them; Trump’s bid won’t affect Hunter Biden’s pardon, reportedly pen-signed. Biden had granted clemencies to family members and high-profile figures from Fauci to Jan. 6 lawmakers; Trump’s unprecedented move is likely to face court challenges.

articles.title: ‘Iconic swamp king’: San Francisco’s beloved albino alligator dies aged 30
articles.trailText: Claude, the de facto mascot for a local museum, was the subject of a children’s book and regularly received fan mail
articles.summary: Claude, a 30-year-old albino alligator and beloved mascot of San Francisco’s California Academy of Sciences, died after treatment for a suspected infection. Hatched in Louisiana in 1995, the rare white-scaled reptile—one of fewer than 200 albinos worldwide—spent 13 years in a Florida zoo before arriving in 2008. Decorated in a children’s book, celebrated with fan mail, a 30th-birthday festival and a 24/7 livestream, Claude’s passing will be examined via necropsy at UC Davis and honored with a public memorial.

articles.title: San Francisco sues food giants over ultra-processed products
articles.trailText: City argues corporations profit while communities bear the cost of diseases linked to ultra-processed foods
articles.summary: San Francisco filed the first US government lawsuit against manufacturers of ultra-processed foods (UPFs)—industrial products with additives that constitute over 70% of the US supply and 60% of children’s calories—arguing that treating related diseases burdens local budgets. The Superior Court suit on behalf of California names 10 companies—Coca-Cola, PepsiCo, Kraft Heinz, Post, Mondelez, General Mills, Nestlé, Kellogg’s, Mars and ConAgra—for unfair, deceptive marketing of items from frozen pizzas to “healthy” bars. It cites a review linking UPFs to cancer, diabetes, heart disease and seeks damages under state unfair competition and public nuisance laws.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Hegseth scrutinized over boat strikes as first formal complaint filed by victim’s family
articles.trailText: Trump says any country he believes is making drugs destined illegally for the US is vulnerable to military attack – key US politics stories from Tuesday, 2 December 2025
articles.summary: A bipartisan outcry has erupted over a US double-tap strike on an alleged drug vessel that killed survivors of an earlier attack, raising war-crime questions. The Pentagon and Trump team have shifted blame onto Adm. Frank M. Bradley—authorized by Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth—while insisting the mission was lawful. In a Cabinet meeting, Trump threatened military action against any country he deems a drug source. The first formal complaint, filed with the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights by the Colombian family of victim Alejandro Carranza Medina, accuses the administration of illegal killings.

articles.title: Trump officials threaten to withhold Snap funds from Democratic-led states
articles.trailText: Agriculture secretary Brooke Rollins threatens to pull funds unless states turn over recipient data to US government
articles.summary: The Trump administration’s USDA Sec. Brooke Rollins has threatened to withhold SNAP administrative funds from 21 Democratic-led states—including CA, NY and MN—unless they hand over beneficiary data (immigration status, SSNs) to “root out fraud.” While 29 Republican states complied, Rollins warns stopping transfers next week if blue states resist. Over a dozen Senate Democrats have labelled the demands an unlawful privacy violation, and New York Gov. Kathy Hochul and House agriculture Democrats decry this as illegal weaponization of hunger. USDA data show SNAP serves 42M monthly with one of the lowest fraud rates.

articles.title: Police were skeptical about tip that led to arrest of UnitedHealthcare CEO shooting suspect
articles.trailText: Officers joked about tip that Luigi Mangione was at a Pennsylvania McDonald’s, where they arrested him in the killing of Brian Thompson
articles.summary: Officers skeptical of a tip that Luigi Mangione, accused of fatally shooting UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson in NYC on Dec. 4, 2024, was hiding at a Pennsylvania McDonald’s joked in texts about earning a hoagie reward. Within an hour, Altoona police confirmed the tip and arrested Mangione on Dec. 9, 2024. Now charged in both state and federal court, Mangione has pleaded not guilty. During hearings on potential evidence suppression, prosecutors detailed the low-priority dispatch, body-cam footage of the mask-clad suspect calmly identified, and defense challenges over Miranda warnings and officers’ positioning.

articles.title: How do ‘Trump accounts’ work – and who will benefit?
articles.trailText: Donation of $6.25bn for children’s investment accounts prompts wave of questions – but details remain scarce
articles.summary: Tech billionaire Michael Dell and his wife will donate $6.25 billion to the new “Trump accounts”—tax-advantaged, state-managed investment vehicles created by Donald Trump’s 2025 tax bill—to seed 25 million children’s accounts with about $250 each in qualifying low-income ZIP codes. Every child born 2025–28 gets a $1,000 federal deposit; families, friends and employers may add up to $5,000/year, and philanthropy is unlimited. Funds vest at 18, invest in a low-cost stock index and incur retirement-style withdrawal penalties, with exceptions for education and first homes. Critics say they benefit the wealthy and don’t offset deep cuts to safety-net programs.

articles.title: Family members identify victims of shooting at toddler’s birthday party in California
articles.trailText: Dead included children, aged eight, nine and 14, and a 21-year-old man who were shot at a banquet hall
articles.summary: Over the weekend, a shooting at a toddler’s birthday party in Stockton, California, left four people dead—including 8-year-old Maya Lupian, 14-year-old Amari Peterson and 21-year-old Susano Archuleta—and at least 11 others injured. Family members confirmed the victims in GoFundMe posts, describing Maya as an outgoing third grader, Amari as a promising athlete with no gang ties, and Archuleta as “full of life.” Investigators suspect multiple shooters in what may have been a targeted, gang-related attack at a Central Valley banquet hall hosting around 100 guests. The San Joaquin County sheriff’s office is seeking any tips as city leaders mourn amid Stockton’s ongoing violence concerns.

articles.title: Trump administration is ‘selling out’ admiral to shield Hegseth over boat strikes, officials say
articles.trailText: White House names Adm Frank M Bradley as officer who ‘directed the engagement’, distancing Hegseth from accountability
articles.summary: The Pentagon pinned responsibility on Adm. Frank M. Bradley for a Sept. 2 double-tap strike on an alleged drug-smuggling vessel that killed survivors, as lawmakers investigate potential war crimes. White House and Pentagon spokespeople affirmed Bradley acted within legal authorities and distanced Pentagon Secretary Pete Hegseth, who had been accused of ordering the follow-up strike. Bradley will deliver a classified briefing to Congress. Bipartisan armed services panels have opened probes into the operation’s legality and the Trump administration’s broader Caribbean naval campaign.

articles.title: Trump calls Somali immigrants ‘garbage’ as US reportedly targets Minnesota community
articles.trailText: US president’s xenophobic rant comes amid reports of ramped-up deportation efforts in Ilhan Omar’s district
articles.summary: In a December 2 cabinet meeting, President Trump denounced Somali immigrants in Minnesota as “garbage,” urged their deportation and slurred Rep. Ilhan Omar’s heritage. His remarks coincide with reports that ICE will deploy about 100 agents to step up removals of Somalis with final orders in the Minneapolis–St. Paul metro—home to roughly 80,000 mostly citizen or legal Somalis. Officials cite alleged fraud and a probe into Al-Shabaab funding to justify the operation. Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey condemned the plan, vowed due process and affirmed city support for the Somali community.

articles.title: Survivors of New Orleans clergy abuse weigh forgiveness in court: ‘It destroyed my faith in God’
articles.trailText: Victims share painful memories in trial aiming to determine fairness of archdiocese’s $230m settlement proposal
articles.summary: About 20 survivors testified in federal court over three weeks to judge Meredith Grabill, weighing the fairness of the New Orleans archdiocese’s $230 m bankruptcy settlement covering roughly 600 clergy abuse claims. Witnesses described decades-long trauma—rape by priests Lawrence Hecker (who died days after his life sentence), Gerard Howell (whose living costs the archdiocese covered post-conviction), deacon George Brignac, and abuse at Madonna Manor. They detailed lasting impacts—flashbacks, addiction, broken marriages and lost faith—and divided over forgiveness: some, like Kathleen Austin and Neil Duhon, still struggle, while others, including Billy Cheramie and Ted Posner, offered absolution. Archbishop Gregory Aymond apologized; ruling expected in December as Archbishop-elect James Checchio transitions in.

articles.title: Trump threatens strikes on any country he claims makes drugs for US
articles.trailText: Trump signals imminent land strikes in Venezuela, blaming a navy admiral for a deadly September attack
articles.summary: At a White House Q&A on Tuesday, President Donald Trump warned he will order military strikes—“land is much easier”—against any country he suspects of producing drugs for the US, extending beyond Venezuela to nations like Colombia. He accused Venezuela of narco-terrorism and said land attacks would start soon, citing intelligence on trafficking routes and suspects. The remarks followed a cabinet meeting where Trump and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth blamed Navy Admiral Frank M. “Mitch” Bradley for an extrajudicial double strike in September that killed two alleged drug-boat survivors. Bradley is set to brief congressional investigators this week.

articles.title: Michael and Susan Dell donate $6.25bn to encourage families to claim ‘Trump accounts’
articles.trailText: Billionaires contribute to new investment accounts for children created as part of Trump legislation
articles.summary: Michael and Susan Dell pledged $6.25 billion to deposit $250 each into the new “Trump accounts” for 25 million US children under ten, part of Donald Trump’s 2025 tax-and-spending law. The program, launching July 4, 2026, will automatically seed $1,000 for children born 2025–28, invest all funds in market index funds, and allow withdrawals at age 18 for education, housing or business. The Dells’ gift targets families in ZIP codes with median incomes ≤ $150,000 to spur additional contributions and commemorate the 250th anniversary of US independence.

articles.title: Trump administration puts Fema workers back on administrative leave
articles.trailText: Fourteen workers who signed a petition that warned cuts put the US at risk were initially suspended in August
articles.summary: In December 2025, the Trump administration reversed the brief reinstatement of 14 FEMA employees who’d been on leave since August after signing a 'Katrina declaration' petition warning budget cuts risk a repeat of New Orleans post-Katrina failures. Within hours of restoring access, senior officials re-suspended them, blaming unauthorized bureaucrats. Legal counsel affirmed their actions are protected under the Whistleblower Protection Act and First Amendment. After CNN broke the story, DHS labeled the reinstatement unauthorized and vowed to punish 'rogue conduct.' Advocates denounce the move as unlawful retaliation amid sweeping federal workforce purges and plans to overhaul or even scrap FEMA.

articles.title: Eric Trump’s cryptocurrency firm tumbles nearly 40% amid ‘crypto winter’
articles.trailText: American Bitcoin Corp’s shares fell from $2.39 to $1.90 after closing in what some are calling ‘crypto winter’
articles.summary: American Bitcoin Corp shares plunged 38.8% to $1.90 on Dec 2 after a 30% dip in Bitcoin triggered heavy sell-off and repeated trading halts, erasing about $1 billion in market value. ABTC had peaked at $9.31 in September before this crash, with volume surging to 40× average. Eric Trump, who claims his Texas firm mines 2% of global bitcoin, blamed profit-taking and vowed to hold all shares and “lead the industry.” The sell-off reflects a broader “crypto winter,” as bitcoin is down 30% since October and Trump-linked ventures WLFI and $Trump token have also fallen, trimming the family’s fortune by $1 billion to $6.7 billion.

articles.title: Pentagon says every national guard soldier deployed in Washington DC ‘is now armed’
articles.trailText: Move to arm all 2,375 estimated troops marks shift in rules of engagement for domestic military deployments
articles.summary: The Pentagon confirmed all 2,375 DC National Guard troops (plus 500 added) are now armed with live weapons and conducting joint patrols with the MPD after an ambush near the White House killed one member and critically wounded another. The Trump administration, appealing a court’s ruling that the deployment is unlawful, cites an “urgent threat” and standardized combat training for expanded domestic missions declared under August’s “crime emergency.” Critics warn that varied unit readiness and new engagement rules risk escalation, while DHS has suspended Afghan immigration processing and broadened its asylum review.

articles.title: New York City bill aims to ban toxic ‘forever chemicals’ in firefighting gear
articles.trailText: Approval of legislation to ban Pfas would be major win for advocates pushing for safer gear alternatives across US
articles.summary: New York City’s council is set to ban PFAS-treated “turnout gear”—jackets, pants, boots and gloves used by its 11,000 firefighters—by 2028 to reduce occupational cancers linked to these “forever chemicals.” Following bans in Massachusetts, Connecticut and Illinois, the bill mandates firehouse water testing and voluntary firefighter blood screenings. Authored by bipartisan Council Minority Leader Joann Ariola and backed by the Uniformed Firefighters Association, it faces pushback from the American Chemistry Council but gains momentum from the NFPA’s new PFAS-free gear standard.

articles.title: Federal panel could call for scrapping of infant hepatitis B vaccines this week
articles.trailText: Two-day meeting under new, RFK Jr-appointed chair could see radical overhaul of US childhood immunizations policy
articles.summary: Kirk Milhoan, chair of the federal vaccine advisory committee appointed by Health Secretary RFK Jr., will vote this week on scrapping the newborn hepatitis B mandate and potentially delaying early childhood shots amid concerns they contribute to allergies, asthma and autoimmune disorders. The panel, which recently led the CDC to downplay decades of vaccine–autism science, has also advised doctor consultation before COVID boosters and postponing MMRV. Eliminating the hepatitis B dose—linked to a 99% drop in pediatric cases since 1991—would mark a radical shift; measures go to acting CDC director Jim O’Neill.

articles.title: Costco sues Trump administration over sweeping emergency tariff powers
articles.trailText: The wholesale giant claims the White House misused emergency authority and warns importers could lose refunds even if duties are ruled unlawful
articles.summary: Costco filed suit in the US Court of International Trade on Dec. 2, 2025, accusing the Trump administration of overstepping its powers under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act by imposing sweeping emergency tariffs. The retailer argues IEEPA doesn’t authorize tariffs and demands a ruling that Trump’s duties are unlawful, an injunction against ongoing collections, and refunds for any improperly paid tariffs. It warns that Customs’ 314-day liquidation process may bar repayment even if the Supreme Court strikes down the tariffs. Costco, with one-third of US sales in imports, seeks to protect its refund rights.

articles.title: Publisher condemns ‘violent’ use of Franklin the Turtle after Hegseth’s boat strike post
articles.trailText: US defense secretary posted meme depicting beloved children’s character aiming rocket launcher at set of boats
articles.summary: Defense Sec. Pete Hegseth’s social-media post recast Franklin the Turtle as a helmeted, rocket-launching soldier firing at drug boats, drawing condemnation from publisher Kids Can Press for unauthorized, violent misuse of a character synonymous with kindness and inclusivity. His post spawned covers questioning the 2020 election and “Franklin Goes to the Hague.” The meme coincides with outrage over US strikes in the Caribbean and Pacific that have killed 80 people—an operation reportedly involving orders to “kill everybody” on a vessel. Critics cited the Pentagon’s war manual barring attacks on shipwrecked people; the White House insisted the strikes were lawful.

articles.title: What Trump’s asylum ‘pause’ means – and what it doesn’t
articles.trailText: The US president has halted decisions on many asylum claims, but the scope, legality and real-world effects of the pause remain unclear
articles.summary: President Trump ordered an open-ended “pause” on decisions for asylum claims processed by USCIS—about 1.5 million pending cases—following the shooting of two National Guard members by an Afghan national previously granted parole and asylum. The directive excludes roughly 2.4 million cases in immigration courts, introduces unclear legal authority and duration, and reverses Trump’s earlier rapid adjudication and rising denial rates. Observers predict swift litigation challenging the sweeping move, which may serve as a prelude to broader procedural or policy changes amid ongoing battles over the administration’s immigration overhaul. Officials say its purpose and length remain unclear, suggesting a review of asylum protocols.

articles.title: Trump’s night of 160 posts on Truth Social fuels debate about US president’s stamina
articles.trailText: The 79-year-old president’s social media blitz included conspiracies, attacks on political foes and self-praise
articles.summary: On 2 December, 79-year-old President Trump unleashed 160 posts on Truth Social over five hours, averaging one per minute. His barrage combined conspiracy-laden claims—crediting Elon Musk with thwarting vote fraud in Serbia, alleging Tulsi Gabbard held Russiagate-exposing documents, repeating false mass immigrant voting allegations, and sharing Alex Jones’s unsubstantiated Obama-autopen pardoning theory—with customary self-praise and holiday cheer (“Christmas is officially great again”). He singled out opponents from Mark Kelly to Nancy Pelosi, Biden and Obama, Gavin Newsom, Ilhan Omar, Tim Walz, James Comey and Eric Holder. Notably, Trump repeatedly reposted content, often embellishing with added commentary. After finally sleeping past midnight, he resumed his social media offensive next morning, backing GOP candidates in Georgia and Tennessee.

articles.title: Kristi Noem urges sweeping new US travel ban after fatal DC shooting
articles.trailText: Homeland security secretary backs broad restrictions after guard member’s killing, echoing Trump’s hardline stance
articles.summary: Homeland security secretary Kristi Noem, after an Afghan national killed a DC National Guard member, urged President Trump to impose a full travel ban on unspecified “killer, leech, entitlement” countries flooding the U.S., echoing his 2017 Muslim ban. She posted on X that she and Trump discussed halting migrants from third-world states, with DHS promising to list targeted nations soon. Trump last week paused migration from third-world countries and halted Afghan visas. The suspect, Rahmanullah Lakanwal, was resettled in 2021 under a Biden-era evacuation and granted asylum in April under Trump-era rules. Noem’s push expands his crackdown, pending legal challenges under civil rights groups.

articles.title: Asylum seekers across US in limbo over Trump’s policy reversals: ‘devastating’
articles.trailText: US paused asylum decisions, halted Afghan visas, and will review green card requests after national guard shooting
articles.summary: After an Afghan national shot two National Guard soldiers in DC, the administration announced a permanent pause on all affirmative asylum decisions, halted visas for Afghans who aided U.S. forces, and ordered reviews of green card applications from designated 'countries of concern'. That order affects roughly 1.5 million pending asylum cases, deepens USCIS backlogs and drives thousands of Afghans including Hazara refugees into legal limbo and psychological distress. Immigration legal aid groups such as Raíces and Immigrant Defenders Law Center are bracing for court battles and working to reassure clients as uncertainty over deportation risks and process timelines mounts.

articles.title: Revealed: Mexico’s industrial boomtown is making goods for the US. Residents say they’re ‘breathing poison’
articles.trailText: Polluting facilities in Monterrey, which has close ties to the US, are pumping toxic heavy metals into the city’s air and threatening residents’ health
articles.summary: Research by the Guardian and Quinto Elemento Lab finds Monterrey’s industrial boom—dominated by factories making goods for the US and recycling US waste—has driven fine-particulate air pollution and heavy-metal emissions (lead, cadmium, arsenic) higher than many US metros, with CO2 output rivaling some countries. Daily PM2.5 levels are twice those in Los Angeles, causing thousands of annual deaths, respiratory, neurological disorders and developmental defects in children. Despite resident protests (“We want to breathe”) and government pledges to tighten emissions standards, activists warn public health costs will outweigh economic gains unless factories are moved or upgraded.

articles.title: ‘A terror inflicted on our communities’: why ICE is targeting car washes in LA
articles.trailText: Andrea Gonzalez and Norma Fajardo of Clean Carwash Worker Center, an advocacy group, describe ICE’s ‘psychological warfare’ as car wash workers are disappeared
articles.summary: Under Trump, ICE has conducted at least 101 raids on Los Angeles car washes, arresting 346 Latino workers—citizens and undocumented alike—and swiftly deporting many without due process. Targeting small, visible, isolated businesses, agents have waged ‘psychological warfare,’ forcing workers to choose between deportation or lost wages. The Clean Carwash Worker Center, founded in 2007 with steelworkers’ union support, has shifted from labor rights advocacy to providing legal aid, bond funds and mutual aid, securing bond release for 20 detainees. Collaborating with legal and community partners, Clean combats coercive voluntary departures and trauma while reinforcing worker solidarity and human rights.

articles.title: Pete Hegseth told US soldiers in Iraq to ignore legal advice on rules of engagement
articles.trailText: Defense secretary shares anecdote in The War on Warriors and rails against ‘rules and regulations’ governing war
articles.summary: Pete Hegseth, US defense secretary and author of The War on Warriors, recounts in his book how he told his Iraq platoon to ignore JAG rules of engagement—calling them “bullshit”—and to “engage and destroy” any perceived threat, promising his backing. He rails against Geneva conventions, praises commanders who incentivize body counts and demands soldiers fight without legal constraints. Under scrutiny for a Caribbean strike alleged to have killed survivors on his “kill everybody” order, he maintains Trump’s backing despite some senators suggesting war crime charges.

articles.title: EU foreign policy chief warns US-Russia talks may pressure Kyiv to make concessions | First Thing
articles.trailText: Kaja Kallas voices concern as Steve Witkoff is due to meet Vladimir Putin in Moscow. Plus, a new book highlights the forgotten builders of the Empire State Building
articles.summary: Kaja Kallas, the EU’s foreign policy chief, warned that US envoy Steve Witkoff’s talks with Vladimir Putin risk pressuring Ukraine into concessions, such as ceding eastern territories, limiting its army and abandoning NATO aspirations. Witkoff, a property developer turned envoy who coached Russian officials on courting Trump’s favor, is in Moscow after leading US-Ukraine talks. European leaders decry a US blueprint seen as tilted toward Russia. President Zelenskyy, meanwhile, presses on his European tour, having visited France and arriving in Ireland.

articles.title: ‘We’re not going anywhere’: how unionization ‘whirlwind’ set stage for historic Starbucks strike
articles.trailText: Four years after workers at a Starbucks store in upstate New York became the first to unionize, hundreds of outlets followed – defying intense resistance from the coffee chain. What happened next?
articles.summary: Since the first union victory at Buffalo in December 2021, Starbucks baristas nationwide have organized under Starbucks Workers United. Facing alleged union-busting by management and years of stalled contract talks, about 2,500 workers at 120 stores in 85 cities have struck this holiday season, urging customers to avoid the chain. They demand a first collective bargaining agreement, improved staffing and secured benefits. Starbucks downplays the impact, but mounting political and grassroots support pressures CEO Brian Niccol to return to the table.

articles.title: Radar revelation stokes fears Caribbean could be drawn into US-Venezuela crisis
articles.trailText: Trinidad PM rejects claims installation is in support of US campaign but opposition says ‘they have sold soul of nation’
articles.summary: Trinidad and Tobago approved a US AN/TPS-80 G/ATOR radar installation and deployment of over 100 US marines in Tobago, just seven miles from Venezuela, sparking fears the Caribbean is being drawn into the US-Venezuela crisis. PM Kamla Persad-Bissessar initially claimed a US C-17 landed for road construction and that no marines remained, then said the radar served counter-narcotics aims and withheld details for security. Opposition MPs accused her of misleading the nation and selling out sovereignty, warning this militarization risks regional Cold War–style tensions, damages tourism, and compromises Trinidad’s neutrality amid US pressure on Venezuela.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: tensions with Venezuela rise after president’s reported ultimatum to Maduro
articles.trailText: Trump reportedly had a ‘blunt message’ for Venezuelan president: leave power and your country immediately
articles.summary: President Trump gave Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro an ultimatum to immediately resign and leave Venezuela, offering safe passage only if he stepped down. Maduro refused, demanding global immunity and control of the armed forces. The ultimatum follows a four-month US pressure campaign—including a major naval deployment off Venezuela’s northern coast—and high-level national security discussions. Trump later met with his top advisers to discuss Venezuela, but details remain undisclosed, and both governments have offered few comments on their highly unusual 21 November call.

articles.title: US north-east braces for ‘significant’ snowfall after storm hits midwest
articles.trailText: Prediction for New England area comes after travelers experienced disruption over Thanksgiving holiday weekend
articles.summary: Forecasters warn a winter storm will slam the US north-east Monday night into Tuesday, bringing rain, ice and 5–10 in of snow from the Poconos to eastern Maine and over a foot in high-elevation New England. Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Vermont and coastal Maine are under winter storm warnings—Maine’s until Wednesday, with travel discouraged. The storm follows Thanksgiving weekend disruptions in the midwest and Great Lakes, including a record 8.4 in at Chicago O’Hare. Pennsylvania Turnpike crews are pre-treating roads, interstates will restrict vehicles, and New Hampshire launched its name-a-plow contest.

articles.title: Luigi Mangione under ‘constant watch’ in prison to prevent ‘Epstein-style situation’
articles.trailText: Corrections officer testifies that Mangione had constant watch to prevent him from dying in custody like Epstein
articles.summary: During opening of a Manhattan state court hearing on evidence from his December 2024 Altoona McDonald’s arrest, corrections officer Tomas Rivers testified that Luigi Mangione was held at SCI Huntingdon under constant watch—ostensibly to prevent an “Epstein-style” death—rather than in a local jail. Mangione, charged with murdering UnitedHealthcare executive Brian Thompson, faces both state and federal counts. His defense seeks to suppress his statements and a warrantless backpack search. Earlier this year, Judge Gregory Carro dismissed terrorism-related murder charges for insufficient evidence. The prosecution also played a 911 call from the restaurant manager.

articles.title: Republican whose child has Down syndrome opposes redistricting after Trump’s ableist slur
articles.trailText: Michael Bohacek, an Indiana state senator, says US president’s ‘choices of words have consequences’
articles.summary: Indiana state senator Michael Bohacek, a Republican whose daughter has Down syndrome, announced he will vote “no” on a planned congressional redistricting measure after former President Donald Trump used an ableist slur against Gov. Tim Walz. On Facebook, Bohacek—an advocate for people with intellectual disabilities—warned that “choices of words have consequences,” defying Trump’s Truth Social call for primary challenges against dissenting GOP senators. Since Trump’s post, at least nine Republican lawmakers in Indiana faced swatting or bomb threats; Gov. Mike Braun also reported threats, urging an end to intimidation. Indiana’s legislature debates the map in December amid broader partisan redistricting battles.

articles.title: California police plead for details on shooting at child’s party with suspect unknown
articles.trailText: Search continues after four people, including three children, were killed and 11 were injured in Stockton
articles.summary: Stockton police continue hunting suspects after a deadly Saturday shooting at a toddler’s birthday party in a banquet hall killed four—including three children aged 8, 9, and 14—and wounded 11. Authorities, calling it a “targeted incident” possibly involving multiple shooters inside and outside the hall, urged witnesses to share tips. The tragedy deepens concern over Stockton’s rising homicide rate—54 in 2024 and 34 in 2025—despite past violence-prevention efforts. Five arrests on weapons and gang charges were unconnected, officials say. Mayor Fugazi announced school counselors and lamented the senseless loss of young lives.

articles.title: White House insists Trump’s recent physical shows ‘perfectly normal’ health
articles.trailText: US president, who is 79, had October exam amid concerns over his cognitive abilities and mental fitness
articles.summary: In October President Trump, 79, underwent an MRI as part of his semiannual executive physical. White House physician Capt. Sean Barbabella reported ‘perfectly normal’ cardiovascular and abdominal imaging with no arterial narrowing, structural heart or vessel issues, inflammation or chronic concerns, deeming his overall health ‘excellent.’ The detailed assessment, standard for his age, came amid renewed scrutiny of his cognitive fitness after Trump admitted uncertainty about the MRI’s focus and touted acing a cognitive test while critics, including Gov. Tim Walz, questioned his mental capacity.

articles.title: Several protesters arrested after ICE raid thwarted in New York City
articles.trailText: Demonstrators blocked the exit of ICE vehicles from a parking lot using garbage bags and metal barriers
articles.summary: About 200 activists blocked an ICE/DHS/CBP parking garage in Manhattan’s Chinatown on December 1, thwarting a federal immigration raid tied to Trump’s second presidency. Protesters used garbage bags and metal barriers, scuffled with NYPD and chased ICE vehicles along Canal Street, hurling planters and claiming chemical irritant exposure. Several demonstrators were arrested. Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani’s transition team condemned the operation as “cruel and inhumane,” pledging sanctuary protections. DHS accused masked agitators of violent obstruction; critics cited NYPD’s SRG involvement as unlawful under city sanctuary laws. Commissioner Tisch called the raid “unacceptable” for endangering New Yorkers.

articles.title: FBI under Kash Patel has become ‘internally paralyzed by fear’, new report reveals
articles.trailText: Leaked assessment based on confidential accounts from 24 FBI sources describes organization as a ‘rudderless ship’
articles.summary: Leaked 115-page FBI internal assessment by 24 agents and analysts criticizes Director Kash Patel’s first six months, describing the bureau as a “rudderless ship” paralyzed by fear, low morale and risk-averse managers awaiting orders. Sources say Patel, lacking FBI experience, politicized leadership with public “deep state” claims, bungled high-profile probes and focused on social media. Incidents include tirades over raid jackets and punitive polygraphs. Allies worry about damaged cooperation. Some praise immigration enforcement and rollbacks of DEI, but call reforms insufficient.

articles.title: Trump move to pardon Honduras’s ex-president shows counter-drug effort is ‘based on lies and hypocrisy’
articles.trailText: Why has Trump blown up alleged narco boats in the Caribbean and at the same time decided to let a big-time trafficker off the hook?
articles.summary: Trump announced a pardon for former Honduran president Juan Orlando Hernández—sentenced to 45 years in a Manhattan court for masterminding a ‘cocaine superhighway’ to the US—while simultaneously blowing up alleged narco boats and targeting Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro as a ‘narco-terrorist’. Critics label the move hypocritical, pointing to Hernández’s conviction for colluding with major cartels, overseeing coca production labs in Honduras and accepting $1m from El Chapo. Observers say pardoning a right-wing ally while pursuing an ideological adversary undercuts any coherent US counter-drug strategy.

articles.title: How progressives are taking over swing states – and driving fear into Democratic elites
articles.trailText: Left-leaning challengers in the Rust belt are throwing chaos into a divided party struggling to rebuild after Trump’s win
articles.summary: In the Rust Belt’s swing states, left-leaning insurgents—from Shenise Turner-Sloss’s upset in Dayton to Jaime Arroyo’s historic election in Lancaster and Shaundel Washington-Spivey in La Crosse—are toppling establishment Democrats in mayoral, council and school board races. Backed by groups like the Working Families party, they run on affordability, housing and transit, seizing on voter discontent over party elites’ stances on Gaza, health subsidies, and generational change. While some campaigns falter, this ‘Liberal Tea Party’ revolt highlights deep divisions and poses both an opportunity and risk for Democrats facing tight midterm and 2028 battleground contests.

articles.title: California dreaming: who is running to succeed Gavin Newsom as governor?
articles.trailText: More than 95 candidates have submitted paperwork but here are the early frontrunners for next year’s election
articles.summary: More than 95 have filed to succeed Gov. Newsom, with filings opening Feb. 9 and a single June 2 nonpartisan primary leading the general between the top two. With no clear frontrunner and 49% undecided per UC Berkeley, big names Harris, Padilla and Kounalakis bowed out. Leading Democrats include consumer advocate Katie Porter (amid campaign stumbles), ex-AG/HHS Sec. Xavier Becerra (affordability pitch, aide embezzlement scandal), ex-LA Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa, Rep. Eric Swalwell (Trump impeachment), Tom Steyer, Betty Yee, Tony Thurmond and Ian Calderon. On the right, MAGA sheriff Chad Bianco and ex-Fox host Steve Hilton vie.

articles.title: Flight of woman in Slender Man case casts spotlight on system that failed her
articles.trailText: Morgan Geyser, who stabbed a classmate as a 12-year-old, fled after a decade being raised by state institutions
articles.summary: Morgan Geyser, who at 12 stabbed a classmate 19 times in 2014 to appease the fictional Slender Man, was found not guilty by reason of mental defect due to undiagnosed schizophrenia, autism and PTSD. Sent to a 40-year psychiatric commitment, she was conditionally released this summer to a Wisconsin group home. She cut off her ankle monitor and fled with friend Chad “Charley” Mecca to Illinois, fearing loss of visitation. Advocates say her lifelong institutionalization stunted her development and exemplifies systemic failures in juvenile prosecutions.

articles.title: Democrats hope for off-year House upset in Tennessee Maga stronghold
articles.trailText: Even a close second could be a bellwether of Republican loss of control of House of Representatives in midterms
articles.summary: In Tennessee’s middle congressional district—spanning rural counties, parts of Nashville and swing-area Clarksville—a Dec. 3 special election pits Republican Matt Van Epps against Democrat state Rep. Aftyn Behn to replace GOP Rep. Mark Green. Historically Trump-leaning (+22 points in 2024), the seat is now a dead heat: Emerson shows Van Epps at 48% vs. Behn at 46%. Democrats, buoyed by recent off-year upsets, have plowed millions via the DNC, House Majority PAC and Kamala Harris, aiming to flip the seat. Republicans counter with Trump’s endorsement, MAGA Inc and Club for Growth ads. A Behn victory—or narrow GOP hold—carries major House control implications ahead of 2026.

articles.title: Cooking with gas gets more expensive as Americans face rising prices into 2026
articles.trailText: Trump promised to cut consumers’ energy costs within his first year in office but gas price is up 4% on average
articles.summary: Despite Trump’s pledge to halve energy costs in his first term and congressional vows to curb inflation, US residential gas bills are up 4% on average in 2025 vs 2024, with piped-gas costs rising 11.7% in September year-on-year, the EIA reports. Extreme weather, Ukraine war spillovers and supply-chain pressures have driven prices higher. Trump’s repeal of Biden’s LNG export restrictions—four new terminals enabling a 25% export increase—will fuel further hikes, pushing wholesale gas up 16% in 2026 and saddling lower-income households with volatile, elevated bills.

articles.title: Death toll passes 1,000 in devastating floods across Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Malaysia and Thailand | First Thing
articles.trailText: Hundreds remain missing in Indonesia and Sri Lanka as rescue efforts continue. Plus, law changes could bring cheap balcony solar to millions of Americans
articles.summary: Monsoon rains and tropical cyclones have killed over 1,030 people across Southeast Asia—502 in Indonesia (508 missing), 355 in Sri Lanka (366 missing), 170 in Thailand and 3 in Malaysia—with militaries deployed as rescue operations intensify amid the region’s worst flooding since 2004 (Sri Lanka) and 2018 (Indonesia). Meanwhile in the US, New York and Pennsylvania lawmakers have introduced bills to legalize plug-in balcony solar panels, aiming to expand affordable rooftop photovoltaics to millions of households.

articles.title: Aipac over affordability: Democratic candidates come under fire for support of Israel
articles.trailText: Democrats like congressman Ritchie Torres face backlash for pro-Israel stances as Americans’ views of Israel sour
articles.summary: In New York’s poorest congressional district, incumbent Democrat Ritchie Torres—one of Congress’s staunchest pro-Israel voices with over $1.6m in Aipac funding—faces five primary challengers accusing him of prioritizing Israel’s Gaza war over Bronx affordability. Contestants, inspired by Zohran Mamdani’s insurgent, pro-Palestinian success, link the $21bn US aid since October 2023 to local hardships, denounce Israeli actions as "genocide," and argue voters want material relief alongside moral leadership. While Torres retains strong name recognition and funding, his adversaries bet that shifting public opinion on Israel and cost-of-living pressures can upend reflexive pro-Israel support.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president says freeze on asylum decisions will last ’a long time’
articles.trailText: Response to national guard shooting has ‘no time limit’; gutting of DHS watchdog could pave way for abuse – key US politics stories from 30 November at a glance
articles.summary: President Trump announced an indefinite pause on asylum decisions—linked to 19 countries already travel-restricted—after an Afghan national’s shooting of two National Guard members near the White House, killing Specialist Sarah Beckstrom and wounding Staff Sgt Andrew Wolfe, whose families he invited to the White House. DHS Sec Kristi Noem called the suspect “radicalized” domestically despite asylum granted under Trump. The president also granted clemency to ex-GPB Capital CEO David Gentile, faced criticism over gutting DHS watchdogs that experts warn invites rights abuses, threatened to cut aid to Honduras during its tight election, and spoke with Nicolás Maduro amid global outreach efforts, including FIFA’s Infantino.

articles.title: Trump invites families of national guard members who were shot to White House
articles.trailText: President plans to honor Sarah Beckstrom, who was fatally shot, as well as Andrew Wolfe, who is in critical condition
articles.summary: Donald Trump invited the families of West Virginia National Guard members shot in DC to the White House, offering to honor the late Specialist Sarah Beckstrom, 20, and support critically wounded Staff Sgt. Andrew Wolfe, 24. Beckstrom was killed on November 27; Wolfe remains hospitalized. Vigils were held in their hometowns, and both served under Trump’s federal policing initiative. Authorities charged a 29-year-old Afghan national with murder and assault. The administration has paused Afghan asylum and visa processing in response.

articles.title: Clean-slate laws could give former prisoners in Florida a real second chance | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Erica Averion responds to a report about Floridians being stuck in temporary jobs because of their criminal records
articles.summary: Erica Averion, executive director of the Florida Foundation for Correctional Excellence, calls on Florida’s legislature to implement automated clean-slate laws to seal eligible arrest and conviction records. She argues that Florida’s current expungement process is prohibitively costly and slow, trapping over 6.2 million adults in stigmatizing records and pushing many into exploitative temp agencies. Thirteen states and DC already use automated record sealing to expand employment access. Averion highlights Rep. Laurel Lee’s bipartisan bill to tie state reforms to federal infrastructure grants, emphasizing that those who turn their lives around deserve a genuine second chance.

articles.title: Winter storm brings foot of snow to midwest over busiest US travel weekend
articles.trailText: Plane skidded off runway and 45 cars were piled up as 53 million were under winter weather alerts over Thanksgiving
articles.summary: A Thanksgiving weekend storm dumped over a foot of snow and winds across the Midwest, triggering weather alerts for 53 million from South Dakota to New York. Des Moines saw 10.9in (highest since Jan 2024) and Chicago O’Hare 8.4in (snowiest November day), causing a 45-car pile-up on I-78 and a Delta plane skid during landing; no serious injuries. Flights within or to the US faced 4,600 delays and 576 cancellations—25% at O’Hare—while nearly 500 crashes (66 injuries) hit the Chicago area. Cold rain and travel impacts will spread across the East Coast from Cleveland to Atlanta.

articles.title: Kristi Noem claims suspect in national guard shooting was ‘radicalized’ in US
articles.trailText: Homeland security secretary also blamed ‘activist’ judges for defying court order to halt deportation flights
articles.summary: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem argued that 29-year-old Rahmanullah Lakanwal—resettled under Trump’s April 2024 asylum policy and brought via Operation Allies Welcome after serving with CIA-backed Afghan units—was “radicalized” domestically, blaming the Biden administration for abandoning vetting she says originated under it. She made the claims on NBC’s Meet the Press and reiterated them on ABC’s This Week. Noem also defended her unilateral order to continue deportation flights of Venezuelan migrants to El Salvador despite US District Judge James Boasberg’s March injunction, labeling opposing jurists “activist judges,” a move DOJ contends didn’t breach the court’s ruling. Former President Trump echoed calls for extended asylum pauses.

articles.title: A teenager redrew the Alabama voting map – and it’s now state law
articles.trailText: Daniel DiDonato, 18, drafted new state senate districts at home on free software – and a judge picked his map ahead of professionals’ efforts to remedy voting rights violations
articles.summary: Alabama University of Alabama freshman Daniel DiDonato, 18, anonymously submitted six redistricting proposals online using free software to remedy a Section 2 Voting Rights Act violation. Federal judge Anna Manasco selected his plan over two from a court-appointed special master because it changed only two senate districts while restoring Black voters’ fair representation near Montgomery. DiDonato’s grassroots effort highlights the democratization of mapmaking via tools like Dave’s Redistricting App and Election Twitter, and underscores the ongoing struggle to enforce the Voting Rights Act in states with histories of disenfranchisement.

articles.title: Trump grants clemency to executive convicted in fraud scheme – report
articles.trailText: David Gentile had just begun to serve a seven-year sentence for role in $1.6bn scheme that defrauded thousands
articles.summary: Donald Trump commuted the sentence of David Gentile, 59, founder and former CEO of GPB Capital, convicted in May for orchestrating a $1.6 billion fraud scheme that defrauded thousands of investors. Gentile, who began serving a seven-year term on November 14, was released on November 26. Prosecutors highlighted lavish personal expenses—private jets with a $90,000-a-year flight attendant, ATV rentals, a $29,000 birthday party and a $355,000 Ferrari. New York AG Letitia James filed a 2021 lawsuit seeking $1.8 billion in investor restitution. Department of Justice has yet to publish commutation details.

articles.title: Virginia Democrat flips seat in state legislature by taking on datacenters
articles.trailText: John McAuliff won against a Republican by focusing on something affecting all his constituents: the cost of energy
articles.summary: John McAuliff, a 33-year-old small-business owner, flipped Virginia’s 30th House district by zeroing in on the local costs of sprawling datacenters. Running in a historically Republican exurban‐rural seat, he knocked on doors—sometimes on an electric scooter—arguing that datacenters’ energy demands drive up rates and infrastructure charges for ratepayers. Backed by a $3 million campaign, McAuliff narrowly defeated GOP incumbent Geary Higgins 50.9% to 49%, while also supporting abortion codification and higher teacher pay.

articles.title: ‘We have become so divided’: Georgia district prepares for life after Marjorie Taylor Greene
articles.trailText: Republicans and Democrats alike look to fill congressional firebrand’s House seat when she departs in 2026
articles.summary: Marjorie Taylor Greene’s January 2026 resignation has thrust northwest Georgia’s staunchly Republican district into a fierce scramble. Voters from Ringgold to Lookout Mountain, long fatigued by her conspiratorial style, now prioritize kitchen-table concerns: skyrocketing home values, high mortgage rates, rising property taxes and broader economic strains squeezing local businesses. Internally, GOP leaders like Catoosa County chair Steven Henry decry purity tests and factionalism, while conservatives such as winery owner Charles Carroll call for low taxes, anti-corruption and a unifying candidate. Democrats quietly eye an opening amid the ensuing crowded primaries for her open House seat.

articles.title: Power surge: law changes could soon bring balcony solar to millions across US
articles.trailText: Tweaks to state laws mean many Americans will be able to benefit from small, simple plug-in solar panels
articles.summary: Small plug-in solar panels that connect to standard outlets and zip-tie to balconies are set to roll out beyond Utah—where lawmakers exempt systems up to 1.2 kW from interconnection agreements—to New York, Pennsylvania, Vermont, Maryland, New Hampshire and others in 2026. Costing $300–$1,500 with optional battery storage, these DIY installations can power appliances and wifi for individuals and small households, though they won’t suffice for larger homes or EV charging. Proponents say balcony solar delivers energy independence, affordability and modest emission reductions, unlocking access for renters and low-income residents previously barred by state utility regulations.

articles.title: Gutting of key US watchdog could pave way for grave immigration abuses, experts warn
articles.trailText: Former oversight officials alarmed by dismantling of DHS system that oversees complaints about civil rights harms
articles.summary: Experts warn DHS’s Office for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties has been gutted under the Trump administration, cut from 150 staff to nine amid 550 active civil-rights probes spanning forced sedation, pepper spraying detainees, sexual abuse and improper detentions. Fired watchdogs filed a whistleblower complaint to Congress and rights groups sued, demanding reinstatements. Without robust oversight—even previously weak—immigration enforcement may operate “with impunity,” critics say, risking mass brutality under a mass-deportation agenda. DHS insists functions continue efficiently, but advocates highlight missing public records, stalled investigations and a blank check for rights violations as detention centers proliferate nationwide.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Venezuela suspends all deportation flights after Trump airspace closure warning
articles.trailText: Venezuela responds defiantly to Trump comments about closing airspace above country, saying it doesn’t accept foreign orders or threats
articles.summary: After Trump declared Venezuelan airspace ‘closed’, Caracas denounced this ‘colonialist threat’, suspended all migrant deportation flights and vowed to defend sovereignty. The White House launched an online ‘biased media offenders’ registry. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth refuted reports he ordered ‘kill everybody’ strikes on Caribbean vessels. FDA’s stricter vaccine-approval protocol drew criticism for delaying child immunizations. Northwestern University agreed to a $75 M federal settlement restoring research funds. New Epstein-document releases may prompt charges.

articles.title: White House launches website to excoriate media for ‘biased’ stories
articles.trailText: Trump administration lists reporting it objects to in latest escalation of attacks on US journalism
articles.summary: White House launched ‘Misleading. Biased. Exposed.’ on its official site to publicly catalog outlets and journalists it says distorted Trump’s comments about six Democratic lawmakers. It lists weekly offenders—the Boston Globe, CBS News and the Independent—and an ‘Offender Hall of Shame’ led by the Washington Post, CNN, CBS and MS Now. Visitors can search a database of tagged stories (‘bias’, ‘malpractice’, ‘left wing lunacy’) and view a leaderboard ranking top offenders. The page also calls out AP, NYT, WSJ, Politico and Axios, marking an escalation in Trump’s lawsuits, settlements and personal attacks on major news organizations and female reporters.

articles.title: Pete Hegseth denies he gave orders to ‘kill everybody’ on alleged ‘narco-boat’
articles.trailText: Defense secretary called reports about his role in strike as ‘fake news’ intended to discredit US military
articles.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has denied Washington Post reports that he ordered a September missile strike in the Caribbean to “kill everybody” aboard a suspected narco-boat, calling those allegations “fabricated” and “fake news.” The strike, led by SEAL Team 6, left over 80 dead across 22 vessels; two survivors were allegedly killed in a follow-up strike. Bipartisan Senate Armed Services leaders have launched oversight to probe the operation’s legality, amid internal Defense Department objections and disputes over the Trump administration’s narco-terrorist framing.

articles.title: Experts say strict new FDA protocol for vaccine approval is ‘dangerous and irresponsible’
articles.trailText: Lead FDA vaccine regulator announced new approval process after claiming Covid vaccine had killed 10 children
articles.summary: On Nov 29, 2025, FDA vaccine chief Dr Vinay Prasad issued an internal memo claiming at least ten children died from Covid vaccines, attributing deaths to myocarditis, and rolled out far stricter approval protocols—mandating larger safety studies, curbs on simultaneous shots, and tighter rules for pregnant women. Backed by Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., his plan drew sharp rebuke: Dr Paul Offit and ex-FDA head Dr Peter Marks faulted its political tone and lack of peer-reviewed evidence, while Dr Kathryn Edwards stressed that causality requires thorough autopsy data. Public health experts warn the measures could stall vaccine development and upend established CDC schedules.

articles.title: Bread, diapers and hope: how Trinity church feeds New York’s hungry
articles.trailText: US families queue for groceries, hot meals and baby supplies as demand at Trinity’s Compassion Market soars
articles.summary: Trinity Church’s Compassion Market in Lower Manhattan now serves over 1,000 New Yorkers twice weekly—families queue in 44°F cold for groceries, hot meals, diapers and baby bundles—as rising food prices, Trump’s tariffs and a SNAP benefit pause during the government shutdown fuel hunger. Demand jumped to 250 visitors within the first hour and 200+ parents daily seeking formula. Trinity offers non-cook kits for unhoused clients, client-choice grocery shopping, daily meals, clothing and winter gear, has spent $3.3m to provide 5m meals in 2025 and fast-tracked $400k in grants to partner charities across NYC.

articles.title: As Epstein files release looms, questions abound on what happens next: ‘Possibilities are endless’
articles.trailText: People implicated in the late sex offender’s crimes could face criminal charges or, at the least, social ostracism
articles.summary: By Dec. 19 the DOJ must release congressionally mandated Jeffrey Epstein files, expected to name powerful figures and reveal why prosecutions stalled despite victims’ reports. Trump reversed months of opposition to sign the bill, yet denies wrongdoing and his administration may invoke carve-outs for ongoing probes or classify sensitive material. Attorney-General Pam Bondi has tasked a New York prosecutor with investigating Clinton, Hoffman and others, fueling concerns redactions will protect allies. Experts warn federal sex-abuse claims carry no time limit, so some names could face charges; others risk severe ostracism. Victim advocates demand a 9/11-style independent commission to map Epstein’s network, pinpoint systemic failures and enforce accountability.

articles.title: They tried to overturn the 2020 US election. Now, they hold power in Trump’s Washington
articles.trailText: Those who tried to overturn the 2020 election now occupy key federal roles, shaping rules and sowing doubt for 2026
articles.summary: President Trump’s 2024 administration has placed prominent 2020 election deniers—Harmeet Dhillon at DOJ Civil Rights, Heather Honey at DHS election integrity and Kurt Olsen as a special investigator—in key federal roles. They have pressed states for extensive voter data, pushed citizenship-verification voting rules, expanded controversial database screening to purge rolls and weakened CISA’s election security, straining trust with secretaries of state. Coupled with mass clemencies for January 6 defendants and pardons for fake electors, these moves embed denialism in policy and aim to erode confidence and set the stage to challenge 2026 election results, countered only by courts’ decentralized safeguards.

articles.title: Trump’s hate-filled rant ignores facts on immigrant crime and economic benefits
articles.trailText: In the wake of the deadly Washington DC shooting, Trump claimed immigrants are ‘destroying everything America stands for’. Here’s what the data shows
articles.summary: In response to a Washington DC shooting by an Afghan national, President Trump launched a sweeping anti-immigrant tirade, vowing to block migration from “third world” nations, overhaul asylum and green-card processes, and intensify deportations. He blamed immigrants for crime and economic decline, despite data showing immigrants are 60% less likely to be incarcerated than US-born citizens and that rising immigration since 1980 has coincided with a 60% drop in overall crime. In 2023, undocumented households contributed $89.8 bn in taxes, held $299 bn in spending power and over $6.6 trn in housing wealth.

articles.title: JD Vance, Trump Jr, DeSantis? Possible Republican contenders for 2028 run
articles.trailText: Next nominee faces enormous task of leading a party that has been entirely reoriented around Trump
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s quips about a 2028 run, despite likely constitutional ineligibility, underscore his continuing sway over a GOP realigned around him. The next Republican nominee must navigate a post-Trump landscape. Vice-President JD Vance, 41, emerges as the leading ‘America First’ populist heir; Secretary of State Marco Rubio, 54, is now Trump’s trusted hawkish ally on Venezuela; Donald Trump Jr., 47, wields his family name and combative brand; Ted Cruz retains sway with libertarian-evangelical conservatives; and Ron DeSantis, term-limited in 2026, courts a disciplined, policy-driven base. Other contenders to watch include Marjorie Taylor Greene, Kristi Noem, RFK Jr., Sarah Huckabee Sanders, Glenn Youngkin, Brian Kemp, Tim Scott, Nikki Haley and Spencer Cox.

articles.title: What is an autopen and why can’t Trump stop talking about it?
articles.trailText: The first autopen was patented in the 1800s and has been used by many American presidents
articles.summary: An autopen is a robotic signature device patented in 1803 and long used by American presidents from Thomas Jefferson to Barack Obama (including signing bills overseas). A 2005 DOJ memo says presidents can autopen-sign laws. On Friday, Trump vowed to reverse Biden’s autopen-signed orders, claiming without proof that “92%” are invalid because aides operated it unapproved. A GOP oversight report cited no evidence, branded a sham by Democrats. Trump repeatedly uses the claim to allege Biden’s cognitive decline. While successors can rescind predecessor directives, legal scholars say pardons remain intact.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president goes after Biden executive orders with baseless autopen claims
articles.trailText: Trump claims without evidence Biden did not sign off on orders himself in latest attack on predecessor – key US politics stories from Friday at a glance
articles.summary: President Trump announced plans to revoke most of his predecessor’s executive orders, alleging without evidence that Biden used an autopen to forge his signature—a device long employed by presidents, including Trump himself. He also vowed to halt migration from “third world countries,” end federal benefits for noncitizens and accelerate removals following a DC shooting. Leaks show far-right ideology among Project 2025 applicants. His order to keep a Michigan coal plant open has cost taxpayers $113 million. Separately, a college freshman was deported, and Americans express economic unease.

articles.title: Trump to pardon ex-Honduras leader serving drug trafficking sentence in US
articles.trailText: Hernández was convicted in 2024 of accepting millions in bribes to protect cocaine shipments
articles.summary: Donald Trump announced on Truth Social he will grant a full pardon to former Honduran president Juan Orlando Hernández, serving a 45-year US sentence after his 2024 conviction for accepting millions in bribes to protect cocaine shipments. Trump called the verdict unfair despite his own administration’s hard-line drug policies, including designating cartels as terrorist organizations and authorizing lethal airstrikes. The pardon announcement accompanied his endorsement of Tito Asfura in Sunday’s tight Honduran election, which the OAS and Washington are closely monitoring amid concerns of disputed results.

articles.title: DC to put national guard on joint patrols with local police after shootings
articles.trailText: Move marks shift in how the guard are used in the US capital, days after two members were shot
articles.summary: Washington DC will pair 2,000 National Guard troops, deployed under Trump’s “Safe and Beautiful Task Force,” with local police for high-visibility joint patrols after two Guard members were shot, an internal email obtained by the Washington Post shows. Pending final approval, the shift—contrasting the Guard’s crime-reduction focus since August—remains “fluid,” per officials. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced 500 additional Guardsmen. Suspect Rahmanullah Lakanwal faces first-degree murder charges after 20-year-old Specialist Sarah Beckstrom’s death; wounded colleague Andrew Wolfe is critical. West Virginia observed flags at half-staff and honored the fallen in a statewide moment of silence.

articles.title: Trump says he plans to cancel most of Biden’s executive orders
articles.trailText: Trump baselessly claims his predecessor didn’t sign off on directives himself due to use of autopen machine
articles.summary: Trump announced plans to rescind most of Joe Biden’s executive orders, alleging without evidence that “radical left” aides used an autopen to forge about 92% of Biden’s signatures and invalidating them. He threatened perjury charges if Biden denied the scheme. Republicans, including the Oversight Project and committee chair James Comer, endorsed Trump’s move, while Democrats denounced it as a sham. A GOP report cited Biden’s cognitive decline but offered no proof of unauthorized autopen use. Legal experts warn nullifying past orders sets a dangerous precedent.

articles.title: Native American actor says she was detained by ICE officers who said tribal ID ‘looked fake’
articles.trailText: Elaine Miles of Northern Exposure was stopped by four masked men in Seattle while walking to bus stop
articles.summary: A Native American actor Elaine Miles was detained by four masked ICE officers in Seattle who claimed her Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla ID “looked fake” and refused to verify it despite her requests to call the tribal enrollment office. Previously targeted familial relatives and broader accounts highlight racial profiling of Indigenous peoples under current immigration enforcement, says attorney Gabriel Galanda. The incident, coinciding with ICE arrests at Redmond’s Bear Creek Village, prompted city council to disable license-plate readers. Miles, known from Northern Exposure and The Last of Us, says she now fears venturing out alone.

articles.title: Leaked files show far-right influences among Project 2025 applicants
articles.trailText: Applicants reportedly cited Nazi theorists and other extremists as inspiration for Trump administration roles
articles.summary: Hacked Heritage Foundation files obtained by DDOSecrets expose 13,726 applications to its Project 2025 Presidential Administration Academy, revealing far-right influences among candidates. Applicants cited Nazi jurist Carl Schmitt, antisemitic men-only Old Glory Club members, nativist conspiracies, white nationalist Jared Taylor, and El Salvador’s authoritarian president Nayib Bukele as inspirations. Several have secured Trump administration posts, including a GSA deputy counsel. Southern Poverty Law Center analysts warn this reflects Project 2025’s reactionary agenda and the Republican party’s fusion with extremist networks peddling authoritarian, anti-democratic rhetoric.

articles.title: Chicago’s faith leaders on front lines of resistance against ICE crackdown
articles.trailText: Religious leaders’ ‘powerful prophetic and moral compass’ comes to fore amid ICE arrests, teargas and violence
articles.summary: Since October, ICE and DHS have arrested 800 people in Chicago, deploying teargas and violence in residential raids. In response, Black, Muslim, Indigenous and other clergy, led by Rev. Ciera Bates-Chamberlain (Live Free Illinois), Rev. David Black (First Presbyterian) and Rami Nashashibi (Inner-City Muslim Action Network), have formed an interfaith coalition, Faith Over Fear, staging weekly Friday gatherings at the Broadview processing facility to pray, blockade vans, deliver rituals and offer sanctuary. They’ve filed a First Amendment lawsuit to access detainees for spiritual care, organized Know Your Rights trainings, food distribution and rapid responders, mobilizing congregations in moral resistance to the Trump administration’s militarized immigration policy.

articles.title: Fewer one night stands, more AI lovers: the data behind generation Z’s sex lives
articles.trailText: Shaped by lockdown and two Trump presidencies, gen Z are grappling with a lot in love, dating and the bedroom
articles.summary: Gen Z Americans (13–28) are the queerest cohort (24% LGBTQ+) yet experiencing a “sex recession,” with men particularly affected (33% vs 20% of women report no partnered sex). Gen Z women are more likely queer and partnered. A notable gendered political split (56% of men backed Trump vs 58% of women backed Harris) dampens cross-party dating. Following conservative policy shifts, 20% of women fear sex post-Roe reversal and 44% of LGBTQ+ 18–24 hide their identity. Most favor traditional monogamy; casual hookups and first-date sex decline, while AI companions and advice gain traction.

articles.title: Trump order to keep Michigan power plant open costs taxpayers $113m
articles.trailText: Critics say JH Campbell coal-fired plant in western Michigan is expensive and emits high levels of toxic pollution
articles.summary: Since May the Trump administration has ordered Consumers Energy to keep the 63-year-old JH Campbell coal plant in western Michigan online, extending its life by 90 days and adding about $113 million in costs for ratepayers across the nine-state MISO grid. Critics, including Earthjustice and Michigan AG Dana Nessel, call the move expensive, polluting and illegal, noting the plant emits high levels of CO₂, SO₂ and particulates, leaks heavy metals into water, and wasn’t needed during peak demand this summer. Consumers Energy says the order guarantees cost recovery, while state data shows surplus capacity. Closure would save $600 million by 2040.

articles.title: First Thing: Trump says he will ‘permanently pause’ migration from ‘third world countries’ after national guard shooting
articles.trailText: President’s remarks followed the death of Sarah Beckstrom, one of the two guard members shot. Plus, Palestinian-American 16-year-old released after nine months in Israeli jail
articles.summary: In his social media post after the fatal shooting of guard member Sarah Beckstrom and wounding of Andrew Wolfe, President Trump vows to ‘permanently pause migration from all third-world countries’, end federal benefits to noncitizens, and expel ‘non-net-assets’, targeting suspects like Rahmanullah Lakanwal, the Afghan asylum-seeker charged. His plan faces legal hurdles. The newsletter also reports US regulators probing banks over Epstein ties, the Hong Kong tower block fire that killed 128, and the release of a Palestinian-American teen after nine months in Israeli detention.

articles.title: National guard soldier Sarah Beckstrom has died after Washington DC shooting – Trump
articles.trailText: One other member of the guards, Andrew Wolfe, is still ‘fighting for his life’, according to the president
