articles.summary: President Trump announced that National Guard soldier Sarah Beckstrom, 20, from West Virginia, has died after a targeted shooting near the White House; Staff Sgt. Andrew Wolfe, 24, remains ‘fighting for his life.’ Prosecutors upgraded charges against Afghan national Rahmanullah Lakanwal, 29—admitted under a 2021 resettlement program after serving in CIA-backed anti-terror units—to first-degree murder and may seek the death penalty. The FBI is probing motives and treating the attack as terrorism, as Trump criticizes Biden’s vetting and vows to pause migration and deploy 500 additional troops to DC.

articles.title: From Fugee to felon: how Pras ‘betrayed his country’
articles.trailText: Ex-member of the hip-hop group was convicted of money laundering and campaign finance violations after funneling money from a rich Malaysian
articles.summary: Pras ‘Pras’ Michél, founding Fugees member known for minor 90s hip-hop success, was convicted on 10 counts of money laundering and campaign-finance violations for funneling over $21m in stolen 1MDB funds from Malaysian financier Jho Low into US political campaigns, notably Obama’s 2012 run and a pro-Obama super PAC. He set up shell companies, tampered with witnesses, and later attempted covert lobbying including extradition deals. He was sentenced to 14 years in federal prison.

articles.title: Before Charlie Kirk was killed on their campus, students felt happy there. They want that again
articles.trailText: Many knew little about the polarizing figure before Utah Valley University was thrust into the national spotlight
articles.summary: On 10 Sept 2025, 31-year-old conservative commentator Charlie Kirk was shot on stage at Utah Valley University, transforming its once lively 46,000-student campus into a tense scene cordoned off with fences and heavy security. Students—many unfamiliar with Kirk’s work—felt stunned, divided and yearning to reclaim UVU’s pre-attack spirit of unity and diversity. First-year students describe the aftermath as eerie, with national vigils and political debates framing Kirk as martyr or bigot. Protests have halted plans for a Kirk memorial amid concerns over his rhetoric. UVU community leaders and a memorial committee now weigh how to honor resilience rather than the tragedy.

articles.title: Alabama priest leaves clergy after woman alleges ‘private companionship’ beginning when she was 17
articles.trailText: Robert Sullivan’s self-imposed removal comes after accusations he provided financial support in exchange for arrangement which included sex
articles.summary: Robert Sullivan, a 61-year-old Roman Catholic priest in Birmingham, Alabama, voluntarily left the clergy after Heather Jones alleged he provided her financial support—hundreds of thousands of dollars—in exchange for “private companionship,” including sex, beginning at age 17. Jones, now 33, backed her complaint with payment records, emails and a legal agreement. Bishop Steven Raica announced Sullivan’s laicization, confirmed no diocesan funds were used and referred the case to the Vatican. Though no civil charges emerged—Alabama’s consent age is 16—the case spotlights clerical power over vulnerable minors.

articles.title: Newsom, AOC, Harris? Potential Democratic contenders for 2028 run
articles.trailText: Would-be contenders include governors, senators, members of Congress and the former vice-president
articles.summary: After Democrats’ 2024 defeat to Trump, the 2028 nomination race is wide open. Potential contenders include California Gov. Gavin Newsom (high-profile Trump critic touring early states, new podcast); former VP and 2024 nominee Kamala Harris (fundraising network, core Democratic support); ex–Transportation Sec. Pete Buttigieg (technocratic brand, Iowa town halls); Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (youth mobilizer, progressive icon); Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro (bipartisan appeal); Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear (red-state Democrat) and Arizona Sen. Ruben Gallego (working-class outreach). Others on the watch list include governors JB Pritzker and Gretchen Whitmer, senator Cory Booker and ex-cabinet official Gina Raimondo, underscoring room for surprises.

articles.title: Trump says he will ‘permanently pause’ migration from ‘third world countries’ after national guard shooting
articles.trailText: In a social media post sent late on Thanksgiving, US president said he would ‘end all federal benefits and subsidies to noncitizens’ following Washington DC shooting
articles.summary: After a Washington DC shooting in which two National Guard members were wounded and one later died, President Trump announced a “permanent pause” on migration from “third world countries,” promising to end all federal benefits to noncitizens and admit only those deemed a “net asset.” He ordered visa suspensions for Afghan passport holders, broader asylum and green-card reviews, and moves to revoke temporary protected status for Venezuela, Haiti, Somalia and Afghanistan, while boosting Guard troop deployments in the capital.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: FBI expands Washington shooting investigation as president says one victim has died
articles.trailText: Trump announced the death of national guard member Sarah Beckstrom, as his administration pledged to re-examine entry of Afghan refugees. Key US politics stories from Thursday at a glance
articles.summary: FBI agents widened their probe into Wednesday’s Washington DC shooting, executing search warrants at multiple properties, including a Washington state home linked to Afghan national Rahmanullah Lakanwal—a former CIA-backed unit member who entered the US in 2021 under Operation Allies Welcome—seizing phones, laptops and iPads, and interviewing relatives. President Trump announced the death of 20-year-old National Guard member Sarah Beckstrom and said colleague Andrew Wolfe remains critical. In reaction, Trump called for re-examination of all Afghan refugees admitted during the Biden administration, as FBI Director Kash Patel detailed the investigation’s progress.

articles.title: Trump officials announce sweeping immigration reviews after national guard shooting
articles.trailText: Donald Trump signaled after attack that refugee and asylum cases would be scrutinized
articles.summary: After a fatal shooting of two National Guard members near the White House by Afghan national Rahmanullah Lakanwal—an Operation Allies Welcome entrant granted asylum this year—the Trump administration ordered sweeping visa and asylum case reviews. DHS and USCIS have indefinitely suspended processing Afghan claims and will re-examine every green card and asylum approval “from every country of concern.” USCIS will treat applicants from Trump’s 19-country travel ban as having “significant negative factors.” Trump cast the attack as vetting failures and directed re-examinations, troop reinforcements in DC, and possible removals of non-beneficial aliens.

articles.title: Suspect in Washington DC national guard shooting had ties to CIA, agency confirms
articles.trailText: Rahmanullah Lakanwal, 29, worked with agency-backed military units during US war in Afghanistan
articles.summary: Rahmanullah Lakanwal, 29, a former member of CIA-backed Afghan partner forces evacuated under Operation Allies Welcome in 2021 and granted asylum in April, is accused of ambushing two West Virginia National Guard recruits at a DC bus stop on Nov. 27 with a .357 revolver, killing Pvt. Sarah Beckstrom, 20, and critically wounding Pvt. Andrew Wolfe, 24. Arrested and hospitalized, he faces assault-with-intent and firearms charges, with murder counts possible. The FBI treats it as terrorism, executing warrants in Washington and San Diego. USCIS has halted Afghan immigration applications pending vetting reviews, DHS is broadening asylum case re-examinations, and former President Trump deployed 500 additional Guard troops while demanding stricter Afghan entry screening.

articles.title: For Trump, there’s Columbus Day and Victory Day, but no World Aids Day
articles.trailText: Administration said ‘awareness is not a strategy’, but here is a short list of orders the president has signed to do just that
articles.summary: President Trump’s administration dropped World AIDS Day, declaring “awareness is not a strategy,” even as he��s signed proclamations for numerous other commemorations: anti-communism week; National Energy Dominance Month; Leif Erikson Day; Columbus Day; National Manufacturing Day; Overdose Prevention Week; Cancer Control Month; Made in America Week; and milestone anniversaries (Bunker Hill’s 250th, Victory Day, Cape Henry’s 418th). His orders emphasize energy production, border security, “America First” manufacturing, and ideological battles, sidelining HIV/AIDS recognition despite also marking mental health and autism awareness.

articles.title: Robert AM Stern, architect dubbed ‘King of Central Park West’, dies aged 86
articles.trailText: Stern, credited with designing 15 Central Park West, sought to design buildings that invoked pre-war splendor
articles.summary: Robert AM Stern, the ‘King of Central Park West’, died aged 86. Renowned for blending pre-war aesthetics with modern luxury, Stern’s hand-drawn design of 15 Central Park West (2008) became New York’s highest-priced new condominium, grossing $2 billion and housing billionaires like Lloyd Blankfein, Steve Jobs, Bono and Denzel Washington. Rejecting modernist glass towers, he championed ‘traditional modern’ architecture with limestone façades, copper-domed lobbies and classic apartment layouts. Stern led a 300-strong firm, served as Yale architecture dean, authored definitive volumes on NYC architecture and created landmark projects from Disney resorts to the George W. Bush Center and Philadelphia’s Comcast Center.

articles.title: US midwest and north brace for storm as nearly 82m people travel for holidays
articles.trailText: Several flights are delayed and parts of Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin and Michigan could see six to 10 inches of snow
articles.summary: A potent winter storm is set to hit Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin and Michigan with 6–10 inches of snow from Friday afternoon through Saturday evening, prompting a winter storm watch and warnings of hazardous travel. Over 800 flight delays on Thursday—part of 6,630 tracked Wednesday—underscore strains on airports recovering from staffing issues post–government shutdown. Temperatures will plunge across the Northeast and eastern US, reaching Texas by the weekend, while southern states stay mostly warm apart from a storm near the Mississippi River valley. NOAA expects rain in New England and snow in the Pacific Northwest. AAA forecasts roughly 82 million travelers.

articles.title: Washington DC national guard shooting: what we know so far
articles.trailText: On Wednesday, Rahmanullah Lakanwal shot troop members Sarah Beckstrom and Andrew Wolfe
articles.summary: At 2:15 pm Wednesday, 29-year-old Rahmanullah Lakanwal allegedly launched an ambush-style attack two blocks from the White House, shooting newly sworn National Guard members Sarah Beckstrom, 20, who later died, and Andrew Wolfe, 24. Lakanwal, a former CIA partner-force member resettled from Afghanistan in 2021, was shot and arrested; motives remain unclear. He drove cross-country from Washington state alone. Charged with assault with intent to kill and firearms offenses, charges may be upgraded if death confirmed. Trump’s administration ordered 500 more guards and launched immigration vetting reviews.

articles.title: US will no longer commemorate World Aids Day, reports say
articles.trailText: State department has told employees and grant recipients to not publicly promote or make event on 1 December
articles.summary: In a departure from a practice dating to 1988, the State Department under President Trump has instructed staff and PEPFAR grantees not to use US funds or public channels to mark World AIDS Day on December 1, though they may still cite HIV/AIDS programs in other contexts and attend events. Spokesperson Tommy Pigott framed the move as replacing commemorative messaging with direct foreign-aid engagement. The shift follows administration cuts to global HIV programs and cancellation of HIV prevention funding, raising questions about continued PEPFAR reporting to Congress.

articles.title: Florida professor may have solved mystery of Peru’s Band of Holes
articles.trailText: Charles Stanish surmised indentations were rudimentary market place and later adapted as accounting and storage system
articles.summary: Florida archaeologist Charles Stanish of USF, with Dr. Jacob Bongers, used drones for high-resolution aerial mapping and microbotanical sediment analysis to resolve Peru’s Band of Holes mystery. Their study of over 5,200 shallow pits in Pisco Valley shows pre-Inca communities carved a rudimentary marketplace later adapted by the Inca as a khipu-like accounting and storage system for crops. Fossilized maize, native reeds and a pre-Inca carbon date confirm human activity. Further excavations are planned and researchers urge Peruvian authorities to protect this culturally vital site.

articles.title: ICE detains Texas father as son’s health declines: ‘Don’t forget about me’
articles.trailText: Maher Tarabishi was arrested at a routine visit despite decades in the US, leaving his son with Pompe disease
articles.summary: Maher Tarabishi, 62, a US resident and sole caretaker of his 30-year-old son Wael, who has Pompe disease, was unexpectedly detained during his routine ICE check-in in Dallas. Despite no criminal record and multiple timely asylum appointments, ICE labeled him a “terrorist alien” linked to the PLO. Tarabishi’s detention at a remote Texas facility has hindered his son’s urgent medical care amid serious infections, prompting family-led appeals and criticism of expanded Trump-era immigration arrests of non-criminal detainees. His family scrambled to locate him after days without contact, finding he’d been transferred three hours away and decrying what they call racist targeting.

articles.title: Trump says US should ‘re-examine’ all Afghan refugees after suspect named in national guard shooting | First Thing
articles.trailText: President called the shooting in Washington an ‘act of terror’. Plus, Hong Kong fire death toll rises to 65
articles.summary: First Thing briefing reports Trump’s call to re-examine all Afghan refugees after suspect Rahmanullah Lakanwal, 29, is accused of shooting two National Guard members in DC; Hong Kong’s tower-blaze death toll hits 65 amid allegations of negligent construction; US group urges sanctions on mechanical-lubricant chemicals to cripple Russia’s war machine; Georgia dismisses last Trump racketeering case; US immigration detains Karoline Leavitt’s nephew’s mother; new asthma injection shows promise; Trump warns Japan to avoid China dispute; global female prison population surges; pro-Trump X accounts proliferate in Asia; Australia likely to miss its 2035 emissions target.

articles.title: US navy accused of cover-up over dangerous plutonium in San Francisco
articles.trailText: Advocates allege navy knew levels of airborne plutonium at Hunters Point shipyard were high before it alerted officials
articles.summary: Public health advocates accuse the US Navy of withholding November 2024 air-monitoring results that showed plutonium-239 levels twice the federal action threshold at the 866-acre Hunters Point Naval Shipyard near San Francisco’s redeveloping residential area. This former nuclear weapons testing camp, designated a Superfund site, has a history of safety breaches and alleged falsification of strontium-90 data. After almost a year, the Navy alerted the city when officials published a bulletin on October 30, sparking litigation and EPA oversight over the cover-up and insufficient cleanup. Critics warn that 2,000 grams of deadly Pu-239 and other toxins threaten residents and demand full transparency and stricter remediation standards.

articles.title: Wild turkeys off the menu in Maine after ‘forever chemicals’ found in birds
articles.trailText: Contamination of wildlife with Pfas, which can increase risk of cancer, a growing problem in US
articles.summary: Maine’s department of inland fisheries and wildlife has warned hunters not to eat wild turkey and deer in four zones southwest of Augusta after detecting high levels of PFAS “forever chemicals”—linked to cancer, birth defects, kidney disease and immune issues—in muscle tissue. Similar do-not-eat advisories have been issued this year in Wisconsin, Michigan and New Mexico near former military firefighting-foam sites. PFAS persist for centuries, contaminating wildlife globally. Experts urge phasing out PFAS in products, enacting federal drinking-water standards, protecting source waters and boosting public education.

articles.title: National guard shooting will likely make Trump crack down even harder
articles.trailText: The attack makes the troops’ Washington DC exit less likely and offers a convenient data point for rightwing narratives
articles.summary: After two West Virginia National Guardsmen were shot near DC’s Farragut West Metro, Trump leveraged the attack to intensify anti-immigrant rhetoric, alleging the Afghan-born suspect entered under Biden and scapegoating Somali migrants in Minnesota. He ordered a review of Afghan nationals’ status and promised harsher ICE crackdowns. Trump also extended and militarized the DC Guard—adding 500 troops amid complaints they’re reduced to cleaning parks. Critics warn this fuels authoritarian policing and risks escalating violence in the capital.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president orders more troops to Washington DC after shooting of national guard members
articles.trailText: Two national guard members from West Virginia were critically wounded in attack near White House
articles.summary: After two West Virginia National Guard troops were critically wounded near the White House in a “targeted” shooting by a 29-year-old Afghan suspect, President Trump ordered 500 additional guardsmen to Washington, filed an emergency motion to extend their deployment under the Home Rule Act, and denounced the attack as an “act of terror” tied to Biden’s Afghan policy. Elsewhere, Georgia’s racketeering case against Trump was dismissed; calls mounted to fire his Ukraine envoy over a leaked Kremlin call; he insulted a New York Times reporter; threatened Venezuela’s Maduro; and moved to end TPS for 340,000 Haitian migrants.

articles.title: Two national guard members in critical condition after Washington DC shooting
articles.trailText: Suspect in custody after two West Virginia guard members shot in ‘targeted’ incident, Washington mayor says
articles.summary: Two West Virginia National Guard soldiers guarding near the White House were shot in a targeted attack and remain in critical condition. The FBI and DHS named Rahmanullah Lakanwal, an Afghan national admitted under the Operation Allies Welcome program, as the suspect in custody after being wounded. The incident near Farragut West station is under federal investigation as an assault on officers. Former President Trump, citing DHS, blamed the Biden-era Afghan admission policy and requested 500 more troops amid a legal dispute over Guard deployments set to end Dec. 11. The area was locked down and multiple agencies are coordinating the probe.

articles.title: Shock and dismay after national guard troops shot near White House
articles.trailText: Amid a frenetic scene, some residents said Trump’s militarization of the capital had much to answer for
articles.summary: Two Washington National Guard troops were shot near Farragut Square outside Farragut North station; authorities later identified an Afghan man as the suspect. The attack unfolded amid President Trump’s controversial deployment of federal forces to curb crime in DC, prompting shock and dismay among residents and figures like mayoral candidate Gary Goodweather, who blamed the militarization for inviting violence. Defense secretary Pete Hegseth has ordered 500 more guards, while FBI director Kash Patel vowed a full investigation and praised the troops as “heroes.”

articles.title: California prosecutors’ office used AI to file inaccurate motion in criminal case
articles.trailText: Filing contained errors known as ‘hallucinations’, with attorneys arguing prosecutors’ office used AI in other cases
articles.summary: California’s Nevada County DA admitted using generative AI in a court motion that included fabricated citations, which was withdrawn after discovery. Defense attorneys in Kyle Kjoller’s case and Civil Rights Corps flagged similar “hallucinations” across other filings and sought sanctions and appeals—denied at both the appellate and Supreme Court levels so far. A coalition of scholars and advocates filed a brief supporting Kjoller. DA Jesse Wilson insists only one AI-assisted filing occurred and attributes other errors to human oversight, instituting citation checks and AI policies. This marks the first U.S. prosecutor AI filing.

articles.title: Georgia prosecutor confirms final criminal case against Trump is ‘over’
articles.trailText: State prosecutor dismisses charges against US president and others in election interference case
articles.summary: Georgia prosecutor Pete Skandalakis has dismissed the 2020 racketeering indictment against Donald Trump and 18 co-defendants, ending the state’s only remaining election-interference case. Fulton County Judge Scott McAfee’s one-page order followed the disqualification of DA Fani Willis over an alleged conflict. Indicted in August 2023 under Georgia’s RICO law for plotting to overturn Joe Biden’s narrow Georgia win, Trump had pleaded not guilty; four others pleaded guilty before the case collapsed. Trump and allies decried “political persecution.” This closure comes after Special Counsel Jack Smith dropped federal election-related charges and Trump enjoyed presidential immunity.

articles.title: Trump officials halt protected status for Haitians in US
articles.trailText: Homeland security secretary Kristi Noem says allowing Haitians to remain is ‘contrary to US national interest’
articles.summary: DHS secretary Kristi Noem announced the termination of Temporary Protected Status for roughly 340,000 Haitian migrants effective February 3, arguing Haiti no longer faces the “extraordinary and temporary” conditions that justify TPS. The move, amid worsening gang violence, political turmoil and UN estimates of over 1.4 million displaced and 6 million needing aid, deems continued stay “contrary to US national interest” due to Haiti’s weak governance. It follows legal challenges halting earlier end dates and reversals of Biden-era extensions, underscoring Trump’s broader immigration crackdown.

articles.title: ‘Living an American nightmare’: LA hearing details lasting trauma of ICE raids
articles.trailText: Southern California residents shared disastrous effects of Trump’s immigration crackdown at a congressional hearing
articles.summary: At a Los Angeles congressional oversight hearing, residents and leaders detailed trauma from Trump-era ICE raids across southern California, which ensnared undocumented immigrants and U.S. citizens like Andrea Velez—charged with assault, detained without due process and forced to pay for water. Democrats, led by Reps. Robert Garcia and Jasmine Crockett, cited civil rights violations, racial profiling and “American nightmare” conditions. LA Mayor Karen Bass denounced the raids as federal overreach. Garcia unveiled a dashboard tracking alleged misconduct. DHS assistant secretary Tricia McLaughlin accused Democrats of smears, claiming a 1150% surge in attacks on officers amid immigration enforcement. The hearing underscored lasting community fear and calls for accountability.

articles.title: Trump calls New York Times reporter ‘ugly’ in latest insult to female journalist
articles.trailText: In a Truth Social post, the president lashed out at journalist Katie Rogers after an article questioned whether he was slowing down
articles.summary: In a Truth Social post, former President Donald Trump attacked New York Times reporter Katie Rogers as “ugly inside and out” after a Times story suggesting he was showing signs of fatigue and age in his 80th year, amid questions over his health following an undisclosed MRI. Times spokesperson Charlie Stadtlander defended the paper’s fact-based reporting and condemned the personal insults. The episode follows Trump’s history of disparaging female journalists—calling Bloomberg’s Catherine Lucey “piggy,” ABC’s Mary Bruce “terrible,” and dismissing Megyn Kelly on gendered grounds—raising fresh concerns over press freedom and gender bias.

articles.title: Hegseth reportedly plans to cut support to US scouts group for being ‘genderless’
articles.trailText: Scouting America decries accusations by defense secretary that the organization is attacking ‘boy-friendly spaces’
articles.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth reportedly plans to cut century-old military support to Scouting America—formerly the Boy Scouts—for admitting girls and lacking “masculine values,” accusing it of attacking “boy-friendly spaces.” In a draft memo to Congress, he proposes withholding medical and logistical aid for the National Jamboree and banning troop meetings on military bases, claiming the partnership diverts resources from national security. Scouting America, surprised and disappointed, insists its nonpartisan tradition and crucial role in officer recruitment—where Eagle Scouts receive academy and enlistment benefits—will continue despite the threat.

articles.title: ‘Traitor’: US representatives call for Trump envoy Witkoff to be fired after leaked Kremlin call
articles.trailText: Republicans and Democrats warn Witkoff ‘cannot be trusted’ after reportedly advising officials on peace plan
articles.summary: A leaked October call reveals Trump special envoy Steve Witkoff advising Putin aide Yuri Ushakov to demand Donetsk—and possibly other Ukrainian land—in any peace deal and to frame negotiations optimistically. Nebraska Republican Don Bacon and Democrat Ted Lieu called for Witkoff’s firing, branding him a traitor; Pennsylvania’s Brian Fitzpatrick decried secret side talks. Trump defended Witkoff as a dealmaker, while envoy Richard Grenell demanded the anonymous leaker’s dismissal. The 28-point proposal cedes Donetsk, Luhansk, Crimea, and freezes lines in Kherson and Zaporizhzhia as a buffer zone.

articles.title: Noem made decision to continue deportation flights to El Salvador, justice department says
articles.trailText: Justice department maintains that Trump administration didn’t violate judge’s order to return flights to US
articles.summary: In a Tuesday court filing, the Department of Justice asserted DHS Secretary Kristi Noem lawfully ordered continuation of March deportation flights of roughly 250 alleged Venezuelan gang members to El Salvador’s Cecot prison after consulting legal advice with DOJ principals, despite US District Judge James Boasberg’s oral directive and subsequent restraining order to return planes. The DOJ maintains the written order did not mandate return of detainees removed before issuance and that the oral instruction wasn’t binding. The filing accompanies Boasberg’s resumed inquiry into Trump-era use of the 18th-century Alien Enemies Act. The nationals were repatriated to Venezuela in July.

articles.title: John Kerry urges Australia to take ‘hard-nosed’ approach with world’s biggest fossil fuel-producing countries at Cop31
articles.trailText: Exclusive : Former US secretary of state calls for more demanding steps from Australia as it takes over presidency of next year’s UN climate summit
articles.summary: Ahead of hosting COP31, Australia’s climate minister Chris Bowen is urged by former US secretary of state John Kerry to convene the top 25 greenhouse emitters and demand a detailed fossil-fuel phaseout roadmap. Kerry advocates “hard-nosed” pressure on major producers—China, US, Russia, India, EU—and isolating holdouts like Saudi Arabia and a Trump-era US. Drawing on his COP28 deal with Saudi oil minister Abdulaziz, he stresses Australia must prepare early, propose concrete options and muster public backing by framing clean energy as a voting issue.

articles.title: President of George Soros’ non-profit says it would take legal action to fight Trump’s attacks
articles.trailText: Binaifer Nowrojee, Open Society Foundations president, said the organization would ‘go to court if need be’
articles.summary: At COP30 in Brazil, OSF president Binaifer Nowrojee vows legal action to defend the foundation’s constitutional rights amid Trump administration threats and DOJ/IRS probes. She underscores OSF’s commitment to free speech, peaceful protest and autonomy of its grantees—highlighting that frontline environmental and civil society activists face far graver risks. OSF faces rightwing scrutiny including a Capital Research Center report on climate grantees and GOP demands for documents over alleged antifa ties. Nowrojee praised Amazon-based climate talks for amplifying Indigenous and Afro-descendant voices and criticized the US absence from global climate policy.

articles.title: Who leaked Witkoff’s call advising Kremlin on how to get Trump on side?
articles.trailText: Bloomberg publishes extraordinary transcripts of secret discussions, but their provenance remains unclear
articles.summary: Bloomberg published transcripts of two secret calls—between Trump aide Steve Witkoff and Kremlin aide Yuri Ushakov, and Ushakov and Kirill Dmitriev—revealing how Witkoff coached Russia on winning Trump’s favor. The audio source is undisclosed; Bloomberg omitted bylines to protect it. Ushakov partly confirmed the recordings, noting some were on encrypted channels, others on WhatsApp. Intelligence experts suggest potential leakers include Russian factions, Ukraine, U.S. agencies (CIA or NSA) or European services alarmed by Witkoff’s stance. The raw audio’s release is surprising: it risks alerting interceptors and shutting down an intelligence pipeline. Motives range from discrediting Witkoff to internal Kremlin power plays, but the leak’s origin remains a mystery.

articles.title: Mother of Karoline Leavitt’s nephew detained by US immigration agents
articles.trailText: Bruna Ferreira, who has a child with the White House press secretary’s brother, is now in custody at an ICE facility
articles.summary: Bruna Ferreira, mother of White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt’s nephew and former partner of Leavitt’s brother Michael, was detained by ICE in Revere, MA on Nov 12. A Brazil native who arrived at age 6 under DACA protection, she’s now in removal proceedings at a Louisiana ICE facility. Agents arrested her without ID while she drove to pick up her 11-year-old son in New Hampshire. DHS labels her a “criminal illegal alien” with a past battery arrest and expired B2 visa; her family has raised funds for her defense as she seeks US citizenship.

articles.title: Trump envoy Witkoff reportedly advised Kremlin official on Ukraine peace deal | First Thing
articles.trailText: Witkoff also offered tactical guidance on how Putin should raise subject with Trump, audio recording suggests. Plus, the female pilots on Ukraine’s frontline
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s special envoy Steve Witkoff told Kremlin aide Yuri Ushakov in an Oct 14 call that a Ukraine peace deal requires Russia to control Donetsk and consider land swaps, and advised him to frame discussions optimistically to win Trump’s favor. Recordings show tactical guidance on how Putin should broach the topic with Trump. Meanwhile, Americans in Ukraine’s war effort decry Trump’s plan as backstabbing and a foreign policy failure. The newsletter also details a DOJ memo reframing Caribbean boat strikes as collective self-defense, a hike in non-resident US park fees under an “America-first” policy, and other global briefs.

articles.title: US police involved in fatal incidents use victims privacy law to hide their identity
articles.trailText: In dozen of cases officers have used Marsy’s Law, which gives victims of crime anonymity, to shield their names
articles.summary: Police departments in at least 12 states have used Marsy’s Law���meant to keep crime victims anonymous—to block public naming of officers involved in fatal shootings and violent encounters. In Ohio, officer Connor Grubb invoked it after fatally shooting Ta’Kiya Young and her unborn daughter, a tactic later overturned by the state supreme court. Similar anonymity claims arose in Florida (Jayden Baez killing) and the Dakotas. Critics say this practice erodes accountability, violates due process and hinders civilian oversight.

articles.title: Rightwing influencers spin anti-Muslim rage in Michigan for social media reach
articles.trailText: In Dearborn, provocateurs have held anti-Islam rallies, attempted to burn the Qur’an and rile residents for clickbait
articles.summary: Far-right influencers including Cam Higby, Jake Lang and Turning Point USA allies staged an anti-Islam rally in Dearborn, Michigan—home to 55% Arab-American residents—attempting to burn the Qur’an, smacking it with bacon and heckling city council members. Local leaders dismiss it as a clickbait stunt to monetize anti-Muslim hate via social media views and campaign donations. Mayor Abdullah Hammoud and CAIR-Michigan urged residents to ignore provocateurs exploiting Islamophobia for profit, warning Republican silence equals complicity.

articles.title: Trump push for new congressional maps meets resistance – from both parties
articles.trailText: White House pressure campaign has not found willing participants in all states – including Republican-led ones
articles.summary: Trump’s unprecedented mid-decade redistricting push is stalling across GOP and Dem states amid legal and political backlash. After Texas drew five new GOP seats that a federal court blocked, California approved five Dem-friendly districts in response. Red state lawmakers in Kansas, Missouri, Indiana, Nebraska and New Hampshire, citing process integrity, lawsuit risk and “dummymander” losses, defy White House pressure and MAGA threats. Democrats in Maryland, Illinois and elsewhere watch and resist. The Supreme Court’s pending review and high state thresholds leave the fate of Trump’s gambit uncertain.

articles.title: Texas man, 95, sets record as oldest bus driver: ‘I don’t have no desire to quit’
articles.trailText: Raymond Hager says he enjoys driving too much and struggles to sit at home to think about retiring
articles.summary: At 95, Wichita Falls bus driver Raymond Hager set a Guinness-certified world record as the oldest active bus driver. A former farmer and crop-duster pilot who joined municipal routes in 1998, Hager credits his lifelong love of driving and passenger interaction for shunning retirement. He maintains monthly health clearances, has safely transported thousands of riders, and received a “Raymond Hager Day” proclamation on his birthday. City officials praise him as proof that many Americans extend careers amid rising living costs, while he insists he has “no desire to quit.”

articles.title: Trump once again steps up attacks on TV networks as he threatens to revoke licenses
articles.trailText: Trump has suggested on at least 28 occasions over past eight years that a TV network’s license be revoked – even though it doesn’t work that way
articles.summary: President Trump, responding to ABC correspondent Mary Bruce’s aggressive questions about Jamal Khashoggi’s murder and the Epstein scandal, threatened to have ABC’s broadcast license revoked. It marks at least the 28th time in eight years he’s demanded TV networks lose licenses over “fake news.” He misunderstands FCC authority, which regulates local station licenses, not national networks. FCC Democrat Anna M. Gomez called his threats “hollow,” noting no affiliates face imminent renewal reviews.

articles.title: Trump envoy Witkoff reportedly advised Kremlin official on Ukraine peace deal
articles.trailText: US envoy also offered tactical guidance on how Putin should raise the subject with Trump, audio recording suggests
articles.summary: US envoy Steve Witkoff privately told Kremlin aide Yuri Ushakov that any Ukraine peace deal requires Russia’s control of Donetsk and a possible land swap, while advising optimistic framing and tactics for Putin to pitch the plan to Trump, including scheduling a call before President Zelenskyy’s White House visit. The leaked Oct. 14 call sheds light on the origins of Trump’s controversial 28-point proposal, mirroring Gaza ceasefire drafting and underscoring US and Russian pressure on Ukraine to accept territorial concessions as war’s basis.

articles.title: Minnesotans gear up to fight Trump ending Somalis’ temporary protected status
articles.trailText: Though president’s order is legally questionable, advocates worry community could be targeted for immigration raids
articles.summary: In late November 2025, Trump announced on Truth Social he would immediately terminate temporary protected status for Somalis in Minnesota, alleging widespread fraud and money laundering. Community advocates, elected officials including AG Keith Ellison, Gov. Tim Walz and Rep. Ilhan Omar, call the move racist, legally questionable and vow to sue. They warn it risks work permit loss, deportations and targeted raids, arguing TPS decisions must reflect conditions in Somalia and apply nationwide. DHS is reviewing Somali TPS due to expire in March; local groups held solidarity potlucks and mobilizations. Residents say it distracts from affordability and other crises, while organizers emphasize community resilience.

articles.title: US triples national park fee for non-residents, amid ‘new’ fee for Americans
articles.trailText: Interior department, which has defunded conservation organizations, claims fee hike is for conservation
articles.summary: Starting in 2026, the Interior Department will more than triple entrance fees for international visitors at 11 most-visited national parks, offering either a $250 annual pass or $100 per person plus standard fees. U.S. residents will pay the unchanged $80 America the Beautiful annual pass and gain 10 resident-only fee-free days, including July 3–5 (250th Independence anniversary), Sept. 17, Oct. 27 and Flag Day. Commemorative annual and military passes featuring George Washington and Donald Trump were unveiled. Secretary Doug Burgum touted the hikes as conservation funding, despite recent staff cuts, conservation defunding, logging expansions and offshore drilling proposals under his leadership.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Pete Hegseth increases administration’s attacks on senator Mark Kelly
articles.trailText: Trump’s defense secretary orders US Navy secretary to investigate ‘potentially unlawful comments’ made by Kelly – key US politics stories from 25 November 2025
articles.summary: Pete Hegseth, the US defense secretary, has directed Navy Sec. John Phelan to probe Sen. Mark Kelly’s comments urging service members to refuse unlawful orders, citing potential violations and demanding a brief by Dec. 10. This follows the Pentagon’s investigation into Kelly and Trump’s “seditious” allegations as Kelly accuses the president of weaponizing the FBI. Other developments: experts say Trump’s pardons may cover 2020 voter fraud; envoy Steve Witkoff to Moscow on Ukraine; anti-fascist terror labels criticized; 70% of Latinos now disapprove of Trump; ICE raids, a $5m tax settlement, BBC-Trump row, and new CDC deputy also made news.

articles.title: US justice department memo about boat strikes diverges from Trump narrative
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Officials frame strikes as self-defense against violence, without naming aggressor, while Trump claims they are to stop US overdose deaths
articles.summary: Classified DOJ Office of Legal Counsel memo contends Trump administration’s Caribbean boat strikes against drug cartels are lawful collective self-defense on behalf of allies like Mexico and Colombia, premised on unverified claims that cartels wage armed violence funded by cocaine proceeds. This legal framing, invoking the law of armed conflict to bypass murder statutes and congressional approval, contrasts with Trump���s public portrayal as anti-overdose action. Critics note scant evidence cartels constitute an armed enemy or sought US military aid. It coincides with an expanded campaign featuring the USS Gerald Ford and Hegseth’s threats against lawmakers questioning orders.

articles.title: Pete Hegseth orders US navy to investigate Mark Kelly’s comments
articles.trailText: Lawmakers who urged military personnel to refuse illegal orders say federal agents want to question them
articles.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has ordered the secretary of the US Navy to probe Arizona Senator Mark Kelly’s recent video urging troops and intelligence officers to refuse unlawful orders, a move following a Pentagon investigation into potential breaches of military law. The video, also featuring five fellow Democratic lawmakers, provoked President Trump’s accusation of “seditious behavior” and an FBI inquiry—reports say agents have sought interviews via House and Senate sergeants at arms. Kelly and colleagues denounce the inquiry as intimidation, vowing to uphold their constitutional oath.

articles.title: Officials find source of leak in Olympic pipeline two weeks after first report
articles.trailText: Fuel from the pipeline, operated by BP, was first spotted in a ditch near an Everett, Washington, blueberry farm
articles.summary: Investigators found the leak in a 20-inch segment of BP’s Olympic pipeline two weeks after fuel was first spotted near Everett, Washington. The 16-inch line has been restarted; repairs on the 20-inch section are pending. States of emergency in Washington and Oregon, declared by Governors Ferguson and Kotek, waived driving limits to ship fuel, including jet fuel to Sea-Tac, while major carriers Alaska and Delta deployed extra trucking and added refueling stops to mitigate holiday travel disruptions. BP excavated over 200 feet of pipe overnight, now pinpointing repairs amid growing scrutiny after multiple past spills and a $3.8m fine.

articles.title: Gobble-degook: Trump talks turkey and trashes another presidential tradition
articles.trailText: The US president made jokes at the annual turkey pardoning ceremony. It went as well as you would expect
articles.summary: At the White House Thanksgiving turkey pardon, President Trump turned the 80-year ritual into a political roast, lampooning opponents, trashing the lawn for Mar-a-Lago–style slabs and a ‘presidential walk of fame,’ and bungling jokes. He pardoned Gobble while mocking a “missing” Waddle, called Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker “a big, fat slob,” riffed on Hunter Biden, border security and AI, and watched his scattered gags fall flat amid sycophantic laughter—more cringe than cheer.

articles.title: Louisiana official who called Covid-19 vaccines ‘dangerous’ given key CDC post
articles.trailText: Ralph Abraham appointed deputy director as RFK Jr continues to reshape US federal health leadership
articles.summary: Ralph Abraham, Louisiana’s surgeon general since 2024 who halted mass COVID vaccination and labeled vaccines “dangerous,” has quietly been listed as principal deputy director of the CDC under HHS secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. HHS records show his appointment effective this week, elevating a vocal vaccine skeptic amid an agency leadership void. With no permanent CDC director after Susan Monarez’s summer ouster and acting director Jim O’Neill in place, Abraham’s push to scrap “blanket government mandates,” insist on doctor-patient vaccine decisions and ties to the late COVID-victim congressman Luke Letlow have alarmed health experts as RFK Jr reshapes federal vaccine policy.

articles.title: Trump may have inadvertently issued mass pardon for 2020 voter fraud, experts say
articles.trailText: Pardons of Giuliani and others who took part in fake elector scheme were largely symbolic, but could have a big effect
articles.summary: Legal experts warn Trump’s November pardon of Giuliani and other fake-elector participants may unintentionally shield any US citizen accused of 2020 voter fraud. Defendants like Matthew Laiss—charged for voting in both Pennsylvania and Florida—argue their motions to dismiss should succeed under the pardon’s broad terms covering “conduct relating to … voting … or advocacy … for any slate of presidential electors.” Observers say the ambiguous, expert-undrafted language could bar federal prosecutions of double voters and pressured election officials. While state charges remain available, courts now face a wave of litigation testing the pardon’s unprecedented scope.

articles.title: Woman behind Slender Man stabbing fled facility ‘because of me’, friend says
articles.trailText: Chad ‘Charley’ Mecca says Morgan Geyser ran away out of fear that the two would no longer be able to visit each other
articles.summary: Morgan Geyser, who pleaded guilty to attempted first-degree murder for the 2014 Slender Man–inspired stabbing of classmate Payton Leutner, escaped her Madison group home in November after removing her court-mandated tracker. She fled with friend Chad “Charley” Mecca—detained alongside her near Chicago—and says she ran for fear of losing visitation privileges. Geyser has waived extradition and faces re-institutionalization in Wisconsin; Mecca faces loitering charges in Posen, Illinois. Geyser was first sent to a psychiatric facility in 2018 and moved to the group home this March.

articles.title: Campbell’s Soup executive called its products food for ‘poor people’, lawsuit alleges
articles.trailText: Executive Martin Bally put on leave after alleged remarks were purportedly recorded and attributed to him in lawsuit
articles.summary: Campbell’s Soup VP of IT Martin Bally was placed on leave after a former security analyst, Robert Garza, secretly recorded him calling the company’s products “shit for poor people,” disparaging Indian employees, and claiming “bioengineered meat.” Garza says he raised these concerns in November 2024, was fired in January in retaliation, and has filed a wrongful termination suit alleging racial hostility and lack of HR follow-up. Campbell’s is investigating, denies use of bioengineered meat, and insists its soups use 100% USDA-approved chicken. Bally has not responded.

articles.title: Mark Kelly: call for troops to disobey illegal orders is ‘non-controversial’
articles.trailText: Senator Mark Kelly hits back at Trump administration and says his comments
articles.summary: Arizona Sen. Mark Kelly said urging military personnel to refuse illegal orders is "non-controversial," responding to Pentagon misconduct allegations. He defended service members' oath to the Constitution after Trump labeled him and five fellow Democrats' advice "seditious" and punishable by death, republishing calls to "hang them." The Pentagon has opened an investigation, and the FBI plans interviews. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth decried the video as "reckless," while the Manual for Courts-Martial affirms that service members need not follow patently illegal orders. Republicans like Rep. Don Bacon noted quoting that law is "dumb" to prosecute.

articles.title: Food influencer known as ‘dine-and-dash diva’ arrested in Brooklyn
articles.trailText: Pei Chung allegedly ate at multiple fancy restaurants around New York City and then skipped out on paying
articles.summary: Pei Chung, 34, a self-styled NYC “dine-and-dash diva” influencer, was arrested in Brooklyn on theft-of-services charges and held on $4,500 bail. Allegedly banned by seven upscale eateries, Chung repeatedly skipped bills—ordering $15 foie gras, $52 lamb, $28 bucatini and $19 mousse at Michelin-starred Francie (twice), $150 at Peter Luger—even offering kitchen scissors instead of cash. At Mole, after a $149 tab she refused to pay, staff called police. Facing eviction from a $3,350/month Williamsburg apartment and prior warrants for no-shows, Chung’s arrest underscores the growing power of Instagram-driven dining trends.

articles.title: Republican Jim Justice to pay $5m in back taxes following government lawsuit
articles.trailText: Lawsuit filed in West Virginia claimed Justice and his wife received notice of the funds due since 2009 but didn’t pay
articles.summary: Senator Jim Justice and wife Cathy agreed to settle a 16-year IRS tax lawsuit by paying roughly $5.2 million plus interest, after federal prosecutors sued for unpaid assessments dating back to 2009. The settlement, pending court approval, follows October IRS liens exceeding $8 million and a $1.4 million West Virginia state lien on the family’s Greenbrier resort. Once West Virginia’s wealthiest resident by Forbes, Justice’s net worth has plunged below zero amid over $1 billion of debt, which he blames on complex finances and political motives.

articles.title: JD Vance exploited a brawl to paint Cincinnati as crime-ridden. The fallout has divided the city
articles.trailText: National spotlight, after video of violent fight went viral, has led residents to question just how safe their city is or isn’t – and who is responsible for sparking the debate
articles.summary: After a July downtown brawl—widely shared online showing a Black man striking a white woman—Vice President JD Vance called for mass imprisonment, fueling right-wing media outrage and national debate over Cincinnati’s safety. Viral reposts by Elon Musk and Fox amplified racialized crime claims, prompting a town hall by Vivek Ramaswamy and an appearance on The Ingraham Angle. Though violent incidents fell from 283 to 253 in the first nine months and local elections re-elected Democrats, the police chief’s paid leave, yard-sign campaigns, business owners’ security worries, the October killing of an FC Cincinnati fan and recent Fountain Square shootings have split residents along racial and partisan lines.

articles.title: Meth worth $10.3m hidden in lettuce shipment seized at US-Mexico border
articles.trailText: CBP press release calls seized drugs and lettuce ‘a salad unfit for this year’s Thanksgiving table’
articles.summary: At the Pharr International Bridge on the Texas-Mexico border, CBP officers seized 1,153 lb of methamphetamine valued at $10.3 million hidden among lettuce in a commercial truck. CBP called it “a salad unfit for this year’s Thanksgiving table.” The 500 packages of meth were uncovered using advanced inspection tools. This follows similar seizures: 4,587 lb disguised as watermelon at Otay Mesa ($5 million), 2,500 lb among celery in Georgia ($3.2 million), plus prior finds in squash, jalapeño paste, green beans, sugar, flour and candy. CBP vows to adapt tactics as cartels evolve.

articles.title: Anti-fascist groups named as US terror threats ‘barely exist’, experts say
articles.trailText: Designation of groups from Italy, Germany and Greece labelled ‘ridiculous’ as experts say no active threat posed
articles.summary: US State Department designated four small European anti-fascist groups—Germany’s Antifa Ost, Italy’s International Revolutionary Front, and Greece’s Armed Proletarian Justice and Revolutionary Class Self Defense—as foreign terrorist organizations. Experts like Heidi Beirich and Tom Lord call the move “ridiculous,” noting these loosely organized, mostly defunct protest collectives pose no direct threat to Americans. Critics argue the listing aims to intimidate leftists and shift focus from rising far-right terrorism, while primarily enforcing financial sanctions rather than addressing genuine US security risks.

articles.title: US judge throws out criminal cases against James Comey and Letitia James | First Thing
articles.trailText: Judge says interim US attorney for eastern district of Virginia had ‘no lawful authority’ to indict former FBI director and New York attorney general. Plus, where did all the color go from the movies?
articles.summary: A federal judge has thrown out the criminal cases against former FBI director James Comey and New York attorney general Letitia James, ruling that interim US attorney Lindsey Halligan was unlawfully appointed and lacked authority to bring indictments for lying to Congress and mortgage fraud. In other news, Russia launched missile and drone strikes on Kyiv as US-brokered peace talks began in Abu Dhabi; Venezuela accuses the US of fabricating “narco-terrorism” charges; and briefs cover Taiwan tensions, cancelled Myanmar asylum, a $63m Covid-relief fraud sentence, film darkness trends, a last-minute Cop30 deal and a Thai woman’s narrow escape from cremation.

articles.title: The full list of US universities at risk of losing state department funding over DEI support
articles.trailText: State department proposes excluding 38 institutions from Diplomacy Lab partnership including Harvard and Yale
articles.summary: The US State Department has proposed suspending 38 universities, including Harvard, Yale, Stanford and Duke, from its Diplomacy Lab research partnership over their diversity, equity and inclusion hiring policies. Effective Jan 1, the draft list would remove these institutions and admit 10 new schools; targeted schools span elite private and public campuses, while Columbia, MIT, Michigan, Penn, Virginia and Texas-Austin, which altered hiring to remove DEI criteria, remain. Some affected campuses, like Oakland and St Catherine, report no funding disruptions. Internal memos cite a shift to “merit-based” hiring requirements aligning with the Trump administration’s anti-DEI agenda, though the state department has not officially confirmed final exclusions.

articles.title: Majority of Latino voters disapprove of Trump, Pew study finds
articles.trailText: Research shows 70% disapprove of job US president – who won backing of nearly half of Latino voters in 2024 – is doing
articles.summary: According to a Pew Research Center report, 70% of Latino adults disapprove of Trump’s job performance, 65% disapprove of his immigration approach, and 61% say his economic policies have worsened conditions. After winning 48% of the Latino vote in 2024 (up from 28% in 2016), support has fallen amid tariffs, social spending cuts and aggressive immigration raids. Democrats regained Latino backing in recent gubernatorial races. While 81% of Latino Trump voters still approve, 78% overall say his policies harm their community, and 52% fear deportation under his administration. For the first time in nearly two decades, most Hispanics report their situation has worsened under his administration.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: James Comey, Letitia James welcome judge’s decision to toss criminal cases
articles.trailText: Federal judge calls justice department’s actions ‘unlawful exercises of executive power’ because prosecutor was unlawfully appointed
articles.summary: Federal judge Cameron McGowan Currie vacated criminal indictments against ex–FBI director James Comey and NY attorney general Letitia James after finding that interim US attorney Lindsey Halligan—appointed by Trump—lacked any lawful authority to bring charges. Currie called all actions stemming from Halligan’s defective appointment “unlawful exercises of executive power” and dismissed the cases without prejudice. Although refiled prosecutions remain theoretically possible, Comey’s statute of limitations on the 2018 false-statement charge expired on September 30, 2025. Both defendants hailed the ruling as a vindication against politically motivated targeting.

articles.title: US justice department renews request to unseal Epstein grand jury materials
articles.trailText: DoJ argues that congressional action last week to release the Epstein files permits unsealing of court records
articles.summary: The Justice Department, via US Attorney Jay Clayton, has asked a Manhattan federal court to unseal about 70 grand jury pages from the Jeffrey Epstein 2019 sex-trafficking probe, arguing Congress’s recent 30-day mandate overrides secrecy rules. Last week’s law cleared release of investigative files, Clayton says, but Judge Richard Berman previously denied a Trump-era petition citing privacy risks to victims and the transcripts’ limited new information. A parallel bid to free Ghislaine Maxwell testimony was also rejected. Clayton’s request follows his assignment to probe Epstein’s ties to Democrats and high-profile prosecutorial shifts.

articles.title: Maga world heads left spinning by Trump’s warm welcome for Mamdani
articles.trailText: Members of rightwing base disorientated by cordial Oval Office meeting – but not all Trump supporters downcast
articles.summary: Trump’s Oval Office meeting with newly elected NYC mayor Zohran Mamdani—once derided as a “communist lunatic”—has roiled his MAGA base. Far-right figures like Laura Loomer, Elise Stefanik and Inna Vernikov denounced the “Marxist jihadist,” warning of GOP electoral fallout, while pro-Trump Steve Bannon praised Trump’s tactical restraint, predicting Mamdani’s policies will ultimately “crater the city.” Even Democrats such as Jumaane Williams and Bill de Blasio voiced surprise at the warmth on display, underscoring the political unpredictability ahead of 2026.

articles.title: US judge throws out criminal cases against James Comey and Letitia James
articles.trailText: Judge says interim US attorney for eastern district of Virginia had ‘no lawful authority’ to indict former FBI director and New York attorney general
articles.summary: A federal judge has thrown out the criminal cases against former FBI director James Comey and New York attorney general Letitia James, ruling that Lindsey Halligan’s September appointment as interim US attorney in Virginia was unlawful. Judge Cameron McGowan Currie found Halligan had “no lawful authority” to indict Comey on lying-to-Congress charges or James on mortgage fraud allegations. The dismissals, entered without prejudice, void all actions stemming from her defective appointment and likely bar a retrial in Comey’s case due to the expired statute of limitations, underscoring limits on executive power.

articles.title: Former Phoenix news anchor sentenced to 10 years for $63m fraud in Covid relief scheme
articles.trailText: Stephanie Hockridge and her husband falsified details to obtain PPP loans guaranteed by US small business agency
articles.summary: Former Phoenix ABC15 anchor Stephanie Hockridge was sentenced to 10 years after her June conviction for orchestrating a $63 million Paycheck Protection Program fraud with husband Nathan Reis. They co-founded Blueacorn in April 2020 to process SBA-backed PPP loans, fabricating payroll records, tax forms and bank statements to secure funds and charging borrowers kickbacks. The couple ran a “VIPPP” service that coached clients on submitting false applications and recruited referral agents to inflate lender fees. A 2022 congressional report found Blueacorn handled over $1 billion in PPP funds, issuing nearly three times more loans in 2021 than JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America combined.

articles.title: Family speaks out after stepbrother emerges as suspect in death of Florida teen on cruise
articles.trailText: Anna Kepner, 18, from Titusville, was found dead of asphyxiation under a bed on a Carnival cruise ship
articles.summary: Anna Kepner, 18, a Titusville, Florida, cheerleader, was found dead of mechanical asphyxiation under a bed wrapped in life vests aboard the Carnival Horizon cruise ship on Nov. 8. Miami-Dade’s examiner ruled it a homicide by bar hold; no drugs, alcohol, or sexual assault were detected. Investigators and the FBI have questioned her 16-year-old stepbrother, who is now a suspect but claims no memory of the incident. Her grandparents fear they’ve lost two grandchildren as the family awaits further developments.

articles.title: North Dakota supreme court revives state’s abortion ban
articles.trailText: Decision once again makes it a felony for doctors to perform procedure except in medical emergencies or some cases of rape or incest
articles.summary: North Dakota’s Supreme Court reinstated its near-total abortion ban, reviving felony penalties for physicians who perform abortions outside narrow exceptions for medical emergencies defined by vague ‘reasonable medical judgment’ criteria or rape and incest under six weeks’ gestation. The decision reverses a lower court’s injunction, with only three of five justices finding fatal vagueness but lacking the supermajority to invalidate the law. Doctors face up to five years in prison and $10,000 fines for violations. Advocates warn the ban’s ambiguity endangers patients and providers, and marks North Dakota among 13 states prohibiting most abortions.

articles.title: Pentagon investigating US senator over call for troops to refuse illegal orders
articles.trailText: Investigation of Mark Kelly after Trump accused Democrats in video of ‘seditious behavior, punishable by death’
articles.summary: Pentagon investigators are probing Senator Mark Kelly, a retired Navy captain and former astronaut, under UCMJ rules after he joined fellow ex-service Democrats in a video advising troops to refuse unlawful orders. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth branded the video “despicable,” warning Kelly could be recalled to active duty or court-martialed. Kelly called the inquiry intimidation, citing his combat and NASA record. Legal experts note military law allows rejecting patently illegal commands. Donald Trump labeled the call “seditious, punishable by death,” triggering fierce Democratic backlash against Pentagon politicization.

articles.title: Trump administration cancels temporary asylum for Myanmar nationals living in US
articles.trailText: Homeland security claims country being ruled by military dictatorship ‘no longer continues to meet conditions’ for Temporary Protected Status
articles.summary: In November 2025 the Trump administration’s Department of Homeland Security terminated Temporary Protected Status for about 10,000 Myanmar nationals in the US, claiming Burma’s conditions have improved. The rule, effective in 60 days, ends an 18-month humanitarian designation first granted in May 2021 under Biden and renewed in 2022 and 2024. Critics highlight Myanmar’s ongoing military dictatorship and executions of dissidents and warn of mass deportations and family separations. This move follows similar TPS withdrawals for Afghanistan, Venezuela and others, travel bans on multiple countries, and faces lawsuits by the ACLU and the U.S. Committee for Refugees and Immigrants.

articles.title: Trump hints support for fringe theory that Venezuela rigged 2020 election
articles.trailText: President’s comment implies hostility to Venezuela may be based on unfounded election-rigging conspiracy theory
articles.summary: President Donald Trump on Truth Social appeared to endorse a long-debunked theory that Venezuela’s leadership controls global voting machines and flipped votes to cost him the 2020 election—a claim U.S. courts rejected and central to Fox News’s $787 million Dominion settlement. He reposted a Lara Logan podcast featuring ex-CIA officer Gary Berntsen and exile Martin Rodil—both interviewed by the DOJ—and urged supporters to mobilize on “ELECTION FRAUD!!” Meanwhile, his administration has dispatched naval assets to the region and designated the Cartel de los Soles as a foreign terrorist organization. National security experts argue the election-rigging narrative resonates more as a casus belli with MAGA loyalists than traditional narcoterrorism claims, while insiders warn conspiracy peddlers may be exploiting White House access.

articles.title: Authorities search for man swept into ocean at California state park where two others died
articles.trailText: Three people were pulled into the water and one remained missing, with search efforts hindered by ‘high winds and unsafe water conditions’
articles.summary: Search teams from Monterey County SAR, California State Parks and the US Coast Guard are combing Garrapata State Park’s Soberanes Point near Big Sur for a man in his 30s, wearing a white turban and black clothes, swept into the ocean Saturday afternoon. Two women in the group self-rescued, but a Coast Guard helicopter’s potential sighting was lost amid high winds and dangerous surf. Searches resume Monday. A week earlier, a 7-year-old girl and her father died at nearby Garrapata Beach. Officials warn of deadly coastal conditions and urge visitors to stay off rocks and out of the water.

articles.title: US woman behind Slender Man stabbing caught after escaping from group home
articles.trailText: Morgan Geyser reportedly located at truck stop after reportedly cutting off monitoring bracelet
articles.summary: Morgan Geyser, 23, the Wisconsin woman who admitted stabbing classmate Payton Leutner 19 times in 2014 to serve the fictional Slender Man, escaped her Madison group home this weekend by removing a court-ordered ankle monitor. Authorities issued an alert Saturday after corrections staff detected a malfunction but only informed police 12 hours later. Geyser, traveling with a 42-year-old acquaintance who gave police a false name, was arrested Sunday at a truck stop in Posen, Illinois, after officers responded to a loitering complaint. Both were detained; the friend faces obstructing identification charges. Geyser, previously committed to a psychiatric institute, now risks being sent back pending a court hearing.

articles.title: Church employee in Texas allegedly posed as ICE agent to extort woman
articles.trailText: Man arrested in Houston is alleged to have used fake ID to demand $400 from woman who had given him massage
articles.summary: In Houston, 58-year-old Donald Doolittle, safety director at Gateway Community Church in Webster, allegedly impersonated an ICE agent to extort $500 via Zelle from a temporary-visa massage therapist. He showed a fake “ICE” ID, demanded cash after she refused card payment, threatened deportation and ordered her to delete their messages. The victim later reported the incident; surveillance footage confirmed her account. Doolittle now faces charges for impersonating a public servant. The case highlights growing ICE Cyber Crimes Unit warnings of scammers posing as federal agents to demand payments or deploy ransomware.

articles.title: Deadly airstrikes and a military buildup: how the US pressure campaign against Venezuela has unfolded in the Caribbean
articles.trailText: US has used claims of a ‘war on drugs’ to justify its attacks, which have resulted in 83 deaths that the UN has called extrajudicial executions
articles.summary: Since August, the Trump administration has deployed its largest Caribbean force since 1989—12,700 troops, the USS Gerald R. Ford, Iwo Jima Amphibious Group and upgraded bases in Puerto Rico, Honduras, Aruba and Curaçao—under a “war on drugs” to pressure Nicolás Maduro. It has struck 22 vessels alleged to carry cocaine or fentanyl, killing 83 people in operations the UN labels extrajudicial executions despite no evidence. Officials placed a $50m bounty on Maduro, designated his “Cartel de los Soles” a terrorist group, and airlines canceled flights after the FAA warned of heightened risk.

articles.title: Epstein survivors fighting for document release find themselves caught in party war
articles.trailText: Doubts emerge on whether Democrats or Republicans can be trusted on the issue and if either truly serves the purpose of preventing exploitation of women
articles.summary: Survivors of Jeffrey Epstein’s sex-trafficking network have driven a push for Congress to release unclassified DOJ files on Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell—securing bipartisan approval and a reluctant presidential signature. At a Capitol rally, more than a dozen women held childhood photos, recounted ages of first abuse and decried partisan exploitation of their trauma. Some, like Haley Robson, question both parties’ motives, while Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene cites the issue to justify her exit. Legal experts, including Wendy Murphy, emphasize abuse transcends party lines. As the documents’ release nears, survivors such as Rina Oh insist their quest remains strictly apolitical.

articles.title: As Epstein questions linger, Trump falls back into familiar habit: lashing out at female reporters
articles.trailText: He called one a ‘piggy’ after being questioned about the files, and reacted furiously to another during a meeting with the Saudi crown prince
articles.summary: Donald Trump, facing scrutiny over his ties to Jeffrey Epstein, has lashed out at female journalists, calling one a “piggy” and threatening to revoke ABC’s license after they pressed him about the released files. His aggressive responses peaked during a meeting with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman—criticized by Congress for alleged complicity in Jamal Khashoggi’s murder—where Trump accused an ABC reporter of “terrible attitude” and “fake news.” This surge in hostility follows a rare GOP revolt that forced him to U-turn on releasing Epstein documents. Observers note he reserves harsher attacks for women, especially on Epstein, than for male questioners.

articles.title: US senator criticises Republicans’ silence on Trump’s violent threats against Democrats | First Thing
articles.trailText: Mark Kelly, a veteran targeted by Trump over military comments, says he is ‘not going to be intimidated’. Plus, DNA reveals stone age teenager as chewer of 10,500-year-old ‘gum’
articles.summary: Senator Mark Kelly, a former Navy pilot and one of six Democratic ex-servicemembers who released a video affirming troops’ duty to refuse illegal orders, urged GOP colleagues to denounce President Trump’s social-media posts labeling their actions “seditious behavior, punishable by death” and repost praising calls to “HANG THEM, GEORGE WASHINGTON WOULD.” Speaking on CBS’s Face the Nation, Kelly criticized Republicans for their silence after Trump’s violent threats, contrasting it with their earlier demands that Democrats moderate language after the fatal shooting of conservative activist Charlie Kirk, warning that the president’s rhetoric fuels real risks to lawmakers.

articles.title: Trump DoJ’s focus on Maga goals harms other investigations, experts warn
articles.trailText: Exodus of lawyers under Trump weakens department’s capacity in civil rights, national security and other areas
articles.summary: Since Trump took office, DOJ shed about 5,500 staff through firings, quits and deferred resignations as AG Pam Bondi ousted anti-Trump attorneys. Trump pardoned or commuted over 1,500 MAGA allies convicted in the Capitol attack and steered resources toward hardline immigration and other party priorities. The civil rights division lost 70% of its 600-member team; the voting section fell below half its lawyers; public integrity dropped from 30 to 2. In the Eastern District of Virginia, veterans resigned after Trump’s push to prosecute Comey, undermining gang, terror and white-collar probes. Former prosecutors warn these purges erode expertise in national security, corruption and civil rights enforcement, risking public safety and impartial rule of law.

articles.title: Doctors respond to ‘data-free’ decision over menopause hormone therapy: ‘It’s not true’
articles.trailText: Physicians say FDA panel conflated two issues and made baseless claims about unproven health benefits
articles.summary: FDA commissioner Marty Makary removed long-standing black-box warnings on menopause hormone therapy without the usual advisory process, citing broad benefits like reduced heart disease, dementia and mortality. Experts warn the decision conflates low-risk local estrogen with systemic treatments, lacks robust randomized data, and overstates protective effects in asymptomatic women. Critics describe the closed roundtable as “data-free,” fear “harmful,” confusing messages, and warn this precedent could politicize future drug labeling decisions.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Democrats say they won’t be intimidated by president’s threats
articles.trailText: Democratic senators condemn Trump after he suggests ‘seditious behaviour’ be punishable ‘by death’. Key US politics stories from Sunday 23 November
articles.summary: President Trump on social media accused six Democratic lawmakers of “seditious behavior punishable by death,” prompting Arizona Sen. Mark Kelly to reject intimidation and urge Republican leaders to condemn the threats. Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar called the remarks “dangerous.” At a glance: NYC mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani reaffirmed his view of Trump as a “fascist”; a new X transparency tool shows many top MAGA influencers operate abroad; the federal “Doge” efficiency office quietly dissolved. Other headlines: an Epstein survivor blasts Trump’s file-release battle, and ICE detained a U.S. teen during lunch.

articles.title: US senator slams Republicans’ silence on Trump’s violent threats to Democrats
articles.trailText: Mark Kelly, a veteran and Democrat targeted by Trump over military comments, says he is ‘not going to be intimidated’
articles.summary: Arizona Senator Mark Kelly, a former Navy officer, blasted congressional Republicans for silence over Donald Trump’s violent threats against him and five Democratic colleagues after they urged service members to disobey illegal orders. Trump labeled their stance “seditious behavior” and called for their execution, prompting condemnations from House Democratic leaders Hakeem Jeffries, Katherine Clark and Pete Aguilar. Senators Amy Klobuchar and JD Vance also weighed in, with Klobuchar calling Trump’s posts “dangerous” and Vance deeming Congress’s advice to defy the president “illegal.” Kelly vowed not to be intimidated.

articles.title: Mamdani reiterates Trump is a ‘fascist’ just days after cordial meeting
articles.trailText: New York mayor-elect reaffirms past criticisms of president after agreeing to work with him on cost-of-living concerns
articles.summary: Newly elected NYC mayor Zohran Mamdani reaffirmed on NBC’s Meet the Press that Donald Trump remains a “fascist” and “despot” despite their unexpectedly cordial Oval Office meeting, where they agreed to address housing, food prices and other cost-of-living issues. Mamdani cited New York’s role as a “light in political darkness” and taunted Trump to “turn the volume up.” The mayor-elect defended retaining police commissioner Jessica Tisch, drawing praise from NEC director Kevin Hassett, while acknowledging ideological disagreements even as both vowed to deliver tangible progress for the city.

articles.title: ICE detained teenaged US citizen during school lunch break, family says
articles.trailText: Christian Jimenez, Oregon high school senior, faces possible obstruction charges after traffic stop by immigration agents
articles.summary: During an off-campus lunch break on Friday, 17-year-old US citizen Christian Jimenez, a McMinnville High School senior, was stopped by ICE agents while driving his father’s car, his window shattered and he was detained despite asserting his citizenship. Held at a Portland facility from around 12:30pm until 7pm, he was released but now faces alleged interference or obstruction charges. Superintendent Kourtney Ferrua emphasized school safety protocols—off-campus students require approved pick-up—and criticized unauthorized entry. Advocates say ICE detained four US citizens near Portland this week, part of six arrests across McMinnville, Dundee and Newberg.

articles.title: Many prominent Maga personalities on X are based outside US, new tool reveals
articles.trailText: Users posing as rightwing Americans are operating internationally, per the platform’s transparency feature
articles.summary: X’s new “About this account” feature shows that many top MAGA influencers claiming to be American are actually based abroad – in Eastern Europe, Russia, Nigeria, India, Thailand and South Asia. High-profile accounts like MAGANationX (400k followers) operate from Eastern Europe, IvankaNews (1m) from Nigeria, Dark Maga (15k) from Thailand, MAGA Scope (51k) in Nigeria and MAGA Beacon in South Asia. Users and Reddit contributors exposed these foreign actors, bolstering Democratic concerns over bot-driven misinformation worsened under owner Elon Musk and X’s AI, Grok.

articles.title: ‘That doesn’t exist’: Doge reportedly quietly disbanded ahead of schedule
articles.trailText: Statement by Trump administration confirms longstanding suspicions that Musk-led agency is on its way out
articles.summary: Trump’s “department of government efficiency” (Doge), launched by executive order on his first day and headed by Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy, was quietly dissolved eight months early, OPM director Scott Kupor confirmed to Reuters. After invading federal agencies, firing 200k workers and claiming billions in savings without transparent accounting, staff reportedly packed up in June amid Trump-Musk feuding. OPM has absorbed Doge’s functions; prominent members—Amy Gleason, CTO Zachary Terrell, Rachel Riley and Joe Gebbia—have moved into other administration roles.

articles.title: ‘I used to call him on Father’s Day’: Oakland shattered by football coach’s killing
articles.trailText: In a city where football is more than a sport, the gun death of John Beam has provoked an outpouring of emotion
articles.summary: Oakland mourns the targeted killing of beloved football coach John Beam, 66, shot at Laney College Nov. 13 and dying next day. Suspect Cedric Irving Jr., 27, charged with murder and held without bail; motive undisclosed. Over 45 years at Skyline High and Laney, Beam mentored thousands of underprivileged youth, securing college scholarships and NFL paths, becoming a father figure to generations. Shrines, student chants and planned alumni events underscore his community impact. His death highlights persistent school gun violence and spurs calls for safety reforms and memorial honors. Skyline students recently staged walkouts amid recurring school shootings, amplifying grief and demands for protection.

articles.title: How cult leader ‘Commander Butcher’ plotted to sow mayhem across US
articles.trailText: Guilty plea by far-right activist lays bare plans for bombings, school shootings and Santas handing out poisoned candies
articles.summary: Michail Chkhikvishvili, a 23-year-old Georgian neo-Nazi known as ��Commander Butcher,” pleaded guilty in Brooklyn federal court to leading the Maniac Murder Cult and soliciting bombings, school shootings and racially motivated poison-Santa attacks in New York. He distributed manuals (“Haters Handbook”) on bombs, poisons and arson, inspired a livestreamed school shooting, and coordinated with other extremist cells. Prosecutors say his accelerationist Satanist-Nazism ideology targeted minorities, Jewish schools and public spaces. Facing up to 18 years, Chkhikvishvili’s plea underscores growing domestic terror threats and online radicalization’s reach. Experts warn of youth-focused militant networks.

articles.title: Epstein survivor condemns Trump for calling file release fight a ‘hoax’
articles.trailText: Danielle Bensky, who was abused by Jeffrey Epstein, says president was ‘incredibly disrespectful’ in recent comments
articles.summary: Danielle Bensky, an Epstein survivor, criticizes President Trump for calling the fight to release Epstein files a “hoax” after he signed the transparency bill but used his Truth Social post to attack Democrats. Bensky says his comments disrespected victims and overshadowed survivors’ decades-long campaign.
