She recounts her abuse, highlights other survivors’ activism, and urges full disclosure of files to hold facilitators accountable, citing Prince Andrew’s sanction as precedent and calling for systemic change. The Justice Department has 30 days to publish the remaining files. Bensky, a choreographer, urges renaming honors and removing abuser-linked symbols, pushing broader cultural reforms.

articles.title: ‘Eating Indigenously’: award-winning chef celebrates Native American cuisine in new cookbook
articles.trailText: James Beard-winning chef Sean Sherman’s cookbook Turtle Island pushes readers to view food systems through an Indigenous lens
articles.summary: James Beard–winning Oglala Lakota chef Sean Sherman draws on Pine Ridge Reservation memories—from pounding bison wasná to harvesting Thíŋpsiŋla—for Turtle Island: Foods and Traditions of the Indigenous Peoples of North America (Nov. 11). Co-authored by Tlingit journalist Kate Nelson and Kristin Donnelly, the 13-chapter cookbook blends history, travelogues and recipes—nixtamalized corn, herb-wrapped salads, seal tartare—spanning Great Plains bison restoration to Arctic Inuit harvesting. Rejecting colonial staples (dairy, wheat, sugar), Sherman advocates Indigenous food sovereignty to address health disparities, while his NATIFS non-profit and Meals for Native Institutions program scale local food systems in tribal communities.

articles.title: Brand-new activists are discovering political movements – and each other: ‘You feel the camaraderie’
articles.trailText: Organizers are breaking down barriers and creating clever campaigns to welcome people new to protesting
articles.summary: New activists from diverse backgrounds, many first-time protesters, are joining bridge and overpass demonstrations, No Kings rallies and grassroots groups. Organizers like NH Bridge Brigade, Indivisible, NorCal Resist, Casa and Stand Up for Science deploy honk-for-democracy actions, film screenings, flower-pressing workshops, digital fandom campaigns, humor-driven flyers and listening-first tactics to lower barriers, build solidarity and mobilize millions. By blending pop culture, workshops, virtual events, art partnerships and the “3.5%” rule, they forge intersectional, coordinated campaigns for democracy, racial and environmental justice, LGBTQ+ rights, science advocacy and immigrant protection, uniting new activists against authoritarian overreach.

articles.title: Trump’s former ‘drone guy’ Dan Driscoll is the unlikely point man for the Ukraine peace deal
articles.trailText: The army secretary has little in his résumé to suggest he can end the war between Russia and Ukraine
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s US army secretary Dan Driscoll, a former investment banker and ex-drone advocate in his late 30s, has been tapped as Trump’s point man for a 28-point US peace plan to end the Ukraine–Russia war. With no diplomatic pedigree beyond a Yale friendship with JD Vance, Driscoll delivered the plan to Volodymyr Zelenskyy—widely criticized in Kyiv and Europe as favoring Moscow—and is set to discuss it in Russia and with NATO allies. His rapid ascent reflects internal trust in his performance overseeing the Army budget, National Guard deployments, ATF duties and Ukraine’s drone prowess as a bargaining asset.

articles.title: Charlotte activists met the immigration crackdown with ‘bless your heart’ resistance
articles.trailText: ICE and CBP’s North Carolina operation faced an early-warning system run by thousands of volunteers
articles.summary: Activists in Charlotte, NC, organized a grassroots “bless-your-heart” resistance to a CBP/ICE crackdown dubbed “Operation Charlotte’s Web.” Thousands of volunteers from Siembra NC and Indivisible tracked agent movements via an early-warning network, patrolling neighborhoods, honking horns, and documenting license plates. Their strategy forced CBP’s hasty withdrawal and exposed contradictory federal statements. Sheriff McFadden, elected on noncooperation, and local officials issued muted support, constrained by NC’s razor-thin partisan split and the new Criminal Illegal Alien Act. Activists liken their effort to Charlotte’s Revolutionary-era “hornet’s nest.”

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Marjorie Taylor Greene is gone, but Trump wonders for how long
articles.trailText: The ultra-loyal Maga star announced her departure in typical shocking fashion, but president says he would love to see her back in politics – key US politics stories from 22 November 2025
articles.summary: Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene abruptly resigned from the House days after her pension vested, citing a fallout with Donald Trump, who nevertheless said he’d “love” to see her return to politics despite acknowledging the challenge. Progressives like Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez slammed her record on Medicaid and ACA cuts, while GOP dissenter Thomas Massie lamented her exit. The move underscores Trump’s grip on Republicans, forcing loyalty or exile. Also covered: a Missouri gerrymandering repeal campaign, a court blocking Trump’s fast-track deportation expansion, veterans’ criticism of politicizing the military and the end of Somali migrants’ protected status in Minnesota.

articles.title: Tatiana Schlossberg, granddaughter of JFK, announces terminal cancer diagnosis
articles.trailText: Journalist, daughter of Caroline Kennedy and Edwin Schlossberg, reveals she has acute myeloid leukemia
articles.summary: Tatiana Schlossberg, 35-year-old environmental journalist and JFK’s granddaughter, revealed in a New Yorker essay that she has acute myeloid leukemia and a prognosis of less than a year. Diagnosed shortly after giving birth in May 2024, she critiques cousin Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s tenure as HHS secretary for slashing nearly $500 million in mRNA vaccine research, cutting billions from the NIH, and adopting anti-vaccine stances that she says undermine cancer care. Undergoing treatment at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia, she focuses on cherishing memories with her two young children.

articles.title: Stepbrother investigated in death of Florida high schooler on cruise ship
articles.trailText: Anna Kepner, 18, from Titusville, was found dead of asphyxiation under a bed on a Carnival cruise ship
articles.summary: Anna Kepner, 18, was found dead under a bed wrapped in a blanket aboard the Carnival Horizon on Nov. 8; preliminary findings cite asphyxiation from a bar hold and neck bruises. Investigators have named her 16-year-old stepbrother, who shared her stateroom and was allowed to drink in international waters, as a suspect. The FBI, aided by Carnival Cruise Line, is probing the case. The family court hearing revealed the boy’s involvement and prompted a postponed custody dispute. Anna was memorialized in Titusville; her mother learned of her death via Google.

articles.title: ‘This is not right’: grassroots campaign aims to repeal Missouri Republicans’ gerrymandering
articles.trailText: A new congressional map was abruptly passed by Republicans in mid-September – but voters have a chance to rebuke politicians and stop it from going into effect
articles.summary: Retired teacher’s aide Jill Imbler and fellow volunteers are leading a citizens veto campaign to suspend and refer to voters a new congressional map abruptly passed by Missouri Republicans in September at Donald Trump’s request. They need 106,000 valid signatures from six of eight districts by Dec. 11 to pause the law ahead of a 2026 referendum. Having collected over 200,000 signatures, they face GOP counter-efforts to invalidate petitions and block the vote, including lawsuits and RNC-funded pressure. Observers see the outcome as a bellwether in the mid-decade redistricting battle influencing control of the U.S. House.

articles.title: Politicians shocked by Marjorie Taylor Greene’s surprise resignation announcement
articles.trailText: Some Republicans offered congresswoman plaudits, but AOC was scathing in her dismissal of her frequent sparring partner
articles.summary: Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-GA) stunned colleagues with a surprise resignation effective Jan 5, blaming her public fallout with Trump—over the Jeffrey Epstein files, foreign war funding, cost-of-living and healthcare debates—and vowing not to be a “battered wife.” Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez accused her of timing the exit to secure her pension, rebuked her votes cutting Medicaid and ACA credits, and disputed her stock trades. GOP ally Thomas Massie praised her honesty; Trump branded her a “traitor” over low poll numbers but later said he’d back a return. Parkland survivor David Hogg and ex-Rep. Barbara Comstock also weighed in.

articles.title: Santa Monica’s shine has dimmed – can a bold reset revive the beach city’s fortunes?
articles.trailText: Years of hollowed out shops, safety worries and stalled leadership have left the famed coastal city searching for a way back
articles.summary: Santa Monica has plunged into crisis after years of rising petty crime, empty shops, dwindling services and budget shortfalls. Its famed beach, Third Street Promenade and Santa Monica Place now see low footfall amid online shopping, tech-driven housing costs and pandemic fallout. Stalled governance, slow permitting, high labor costs and homelessness-fueled disorder deter retailers; vacancies hit one in six storefronts and 35% of offices. City manager Oliver Chi's 'realignment' plan calls for more policing, faster permits, eased outdoor-dining rules, digital billboards and street art to revive revenue, but execution and structural reform remain uncertain.

articles.title: What will a ban on most US hemp products mean?
articles.trailText: Ban forbids all products that contain more than 0.4 milligrams of THC per package – a trace amount present in most CBD products
articles.summary: Senator Mitch McConnell added a clause to the spending bill that will ban, after 12 months, any hemp product with over 0.4 mg THC per package—effectively outlawing most CBD goods. The US hemp industry, generating $28 billion revenue and employing 300,000, faces potential state-level exemptions or a total federal prohibition. Companies are planning for scenarios ranging from state autonomy to supply chain shutdowns. Interstate shipping would be prohibited, forcing companies to restructure distribution. Industry groups and lawmakers like Maxwell Frost and Tina Smith are now opposing the ban, advocating for new federal hemp regulations to preserve market stability.

articles.title: New Orleans braces for Trump’s immigration crackdown: ‘We have rights’
articles.trailText: As many as 250 federal agents are expected to descend on the city imminently – despite falling crime
articles.summary: Amid a 20% drop in violent crime, New Orleans braces for Operation Swamp Sweep: around 250 CBP and ICE agents will deploy Dec. 1 under Trump’s mass deportation plan aiming for 5,000 arrests across southeast Louisiana and Mississippi. Led by Border Patrol commander Gregory Bovino, the crackdown echoes tactics in Los Angeles, Chicago and Charlotte that sparked protests and legal challenges over aggressive arrests and use of force. Residents share ICE sighting alerts, coordinate escorts for children, and attend Unión Migrante’s Know Your Rights workshops. Mayor-elect Helena Moreno warns of racial profiling and due‐process violations, while Gov. Jeff Landry endorses federal action and has backed state laws punishing local noncooperation. NOPD pledges limited collaboration but will not join deportation raids.

articles.title: Chomsky had deeper ties with Epstein than previously known, documents reveal
articles.trailText: The philosopher and the sex trafficker were in contact long after Epstein was convicted of soliciting prostitution from a minor, documents reveal
articles.summary: Emails released by House Republicans reveal Noam Chomsky maintained regular contact with convicted sex trafficker Jeffrey Epstein years after his 2008 conviction, praising their ‘in-depth discussions,’ receiving $270k via an Epstein-linked account, and writing a laudatory, undated support letter highlighting Epstein’s financial expertise and connections. Correspondence also covers music, vacations and offers of accommodation in New York and New Mexico. MIT affirmed no direct gifts. The disclosures intensify scrutiny of academic ties to Epstein amid broader calls for more file releases.

articles.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene could have led the anti-Trump resistance but the mob boss got his way
articles.trailText: The Maga star won on the Epstein files and could have founded a Republican resistance movement but is instead the latest dissenter to head for the exit
articles.summary: After winning her fight to force the release of the Jeffrey Epstein files, Greene—once a fervent Trump ally—shocked colleagues by abruptly resigning from the House, a move Trump hailed as “great news” amid GOP defections on filibuster, courts and redistricting. Poised to potentially lead a Republican anti-Trump resistance like Cheney or Kinzinger, she bowed out under fear of Trump’s “mob boss” tactics—he labeled her “wacky” and threatened a primary—and likened herself to a “battered wife.” Speculation now surrounds a possible independent 2028 bid.

articles.title: Ignorance is bliss: rightwing media largely keeps quiet on Trump-Epstein saga
articles.trailText: Fox News and other conservative networks have mostly avoided covering the president’s ties to the sex trafficker
articles.summary: After House Democrats released emails suggesting Trump knew of Epstein’s victims, Fox News and other conservative outlets initially ignored the story, depriving viewers of allegations that Trump spent hours at Epstein’s home. After GOP infighting – including Reps. Massie and Greene preparing to defy Trump by voting for release – Fox pivoted, portraying his eventual U-turn as a strategic victory. Hosts Laura Ingraham and Jesse Watters framed Democrats as opportunistic, downplayed Trump’s authority to release documents, then quickly reverted to sparse coverage, focusing on Miss Universe instead.

articles.title: ‘Horribly wrong’: US veterans condemn Trump’s politicization of military
articles.trailText: Experts infuriated by president accusing Democrats of ‘sedition’ for urging soldiers to refuse illegal orders
articles.summary: Veterans condemned President Trump’s comments labeling Democratic lawmakers’ call for troops to refuse illegal orders as “sedition, punishable by death,” warning his rhetoric politicizes the military and endangers service members. Retired JAG officers criticized his broad misuse of sedition and treason charges, cited the recent Venezuela boat strikes as potentially unlawful, and stressed that refusal is only justified for manifestly criminal orders. Experts also voiced alarm over politicization of military lawyers following Defense Department firings, urging senior leaders to reaffirm their constitutional neutrality and protect troop morale.

articles.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene to resign from Congress in January amid fallout with Trump
articles.trailText: Decision by Georgia Republican and leading Maga figure to give up House seat comes after dramatic break with Trump, lately over the Epstein files bill
articles.summary: Georgia congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene will resign Jan 5, 2026 after a public fallout with Donald Trump spurred by her vote to release Jeffrey Epstein files and her criticism of his stances on Israel, Obamacare subsidies, skilled visas and AI regulation. Once a leading MAGA figure, Greene accused GOP leaders of sidelining America First priorities, faced personal threats after Trump labeled her a traitor, and will narrow Speaker Mike Johnson’s razor-thin majority. In a four-page statement she decried the “political industrial complex,” pledged to return to grassroots activism and hinted at rebuilding conservative politics outside Congress.

articles.title: Trump calls Marjorie Taylor Greene resignation ‘great news for the country’
articles.trailText: President says ‘I think she should be happy’ while Democratic colleague praises her for stance on Epstein files
articles.summary: Marjorie Taylor Greene, Georgia Republican long allied with Donald Trump, announced her resignation effective Jan. 5, 2026, after a public falling-out over her dissent from Trump’s stance. He had withdrawn his endorsement and called her exit “great news for the country,” declining to say if she’d notified him. Greene cited “death threats, lawfare and slander” after losing Trump’s support. Democrats Jasmine Crockett and Ro Khanna praised her role in unsealing Epstein files and speculated about a 2028 run. GOP strategist Shermichael Singleton and Steve Bannon called her departure a shock, while Georgia Democrats are already gearing up for her seat race.

articles.title: From staunch Trump ally to ‘traitor’: key takeaways of Marjorie Taylor Greene’s career
articles.trailText: The Georgia representative said on Friday she was resigning from office effective January 2026
articles.summary: Georgia congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene, known for her far-right stance and conspiracy theories, shocked GOP allies and Democrats alike by announcing her resignation effective January 2026. After launching her public career in 2017 on the site American Truth Seekers, she won GA-14 in 2020 as an unapologetic Trump loyalist, wielding extremist rhetoric and QAnon-tinged claims. Over the past year Greene broke with Trump on Israel’s Gaza war and the Jeffrey Epstein file release, drawing a rare public rebuke from the former president and capping a tumultuous five-year rise-and-fall in national politics.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president meets Mamdani at White House and it was … nice?
articles.trailText: Trump told the press he’s ‘very confident that [Mamdani] can do a very good job’ in surprisingly cordial meeting
articles.summary: President Trump and NYC mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani held an unusually cordial Oval Office meeting, praising his Democratic-socialist upset and agreeing on housing and affordability reforms. Separately, Marjorie Taylor Greene plans to resign in January; Volodymyr Zelenskyy warns Ukraine faces an impossible choice as Trump demands a US-backed peace plan ceding territory; immigration arrests spiked during the government shutdown; October’s CPI report was canceled; RFK Jr. pushed the CDC to revisit the vaccine-autism link; Democrats decried Prince Andrew’s Epstein silence; and other developments include scrutiny of Swiss gold gifts to Trump, Eric Swalwell’s California gubernatorial bid, a DOJ suit over in-state tuition for undocumented students, recruitment of “deportation judges,” and data showing the least-diverse US government in decades.

articles.title: US justice department recruiting legal experts to serve as ‘deportation’ judges
articles.trailText: Trump officials have been purging immigration judges whose philosophies are different, largely in sanctuary cities
articles.summary: The Justice Department is recruiting legal professionals as so-called 'deportation judges'—officially classified as immigration judges—to enforce the Trump administration’s immigration crackdown. Homeland Security Sec. Kristi Noem touted DOJ ads inviting applicants to 'define America for generations,' offering salaries of $159,951–$207,500 plus city cash incentives. This follows purges of immigration judges in sanctuary cities (New York, San Francisco, Chicago, Boston) whose rulings or philosophies conflicted with administration priorities. After EOIR eased requirements in August, the DOJ has also tapped military lawyers to fill temporary judge roles amid a surging removal docket.

articles.title: I ❤ NY: Queens recognises Queens as Trump gives Mamdani warm reception
articles.trailText: No fists, no fire – the president and the mayor-elect met in Washington, and things went bewilderingly, bizarrely well
articles.summary: At their Nov 21 Oval Office meeting, President Donald Trump and incoming New York City mayor Zohran Mamdani, despite trading insults—Trump’s “100% Communist lunatic” and Mamdani’s “fascist despot”—displayed an unexpectedly cordial rapport. Trump praised Mamdani’s policy plans, pledged federal support for affordability and safety, and acknowledged shared ideas on cost of living. Mamdani, the first Muslim mayor and a democratic socialist, emphasized cooperation on housing and budgets. Earlier he threatened to cut federal funding if Mamdani won, yet now pledged assistance. Their public warmth and mutual admiration signaled a break from partisan norms.

articles.title: Trump and Mamdani form an unlikely alliance at White House meeting
articles.trailText: ‘We agreed a lot more than I would have thought,’ the US president said of his first face-to-face meeting with the New York mayor-elect
articles.summary: At a surprise Oval Office sit-down, President Trump and NYC mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani—once labeled a “communist lunatic” by Trump—agreed to collaborate on housing, food prices and cost-of-living relief, with Trump even interjecting to shield Mamdani from aggressive press questions. Trump praised Mamdani’s victory and pledged federal aid for crime reduction and housing. The democratic socialist focused on rent freezes, utilities and universal childcare after prep calls with Hochul, Schumer, Jeffries and Sharpton.

articles.title: ‘I’ll stick up for you’: key moments from the cordial Trump-Mamdani meeting
articles.trailText: The president hosted the mayor-elect at the White House – and seemed enamoured of his fellow New Yorker
articles.summary: At their cordial Oval Office meeting, Trump lauded NYC mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani’s surprise victory, noting shared New York roots and pledging cooperation: “The better he does, the happier I am.” Dismissing GOP attacks, Trump defended Mamdani under conservative fire (“I’ll stick up for you”), and even vowed to live in the city under his administration. The pair focused on an affordability agenda—rent freezes, cheaper utilities, bus service—and agreed to collaborate on housing and cost-of-living relief for New Yorkers.

articles.title: Group of Epstein abuse survivors say they have received death threats
articles.trailText: In a signed statement, 28 victims say they are bracing for blame for their abuse and threats of harm
articles.summary: A coalition of 28 Jeffrey Epstein abuse survivors – 18 named and 10 Jane Does – have publicly warned of death threats and intimidation as they await DOJ-file disclosures mandated by a newly signed law. In their statement “What we’re bracing for,” they call on federal and state law enforcement to investigate threats and protect them from anticipated victim-blaming, incomplete disclosures, and divide-and-conquer tactics. High-profile survivors like Anouska De Georgiou and the late Virginia Giuffre have faced similar harassment. They denounce recent efforts, including by Megyn Kelly, to downplay abuse of victims over 18.

articles.title: World’s oldest known pygmy hippo turns 52: ‘Anyone who meets her falls in love’
articles.trailText: Hannah Shirley, born in November 1973, was celebrated with Hungry Hungry Hippos-themed party
articles.summary: Hannah Shirley, born November 1973, is the world’s oldest known pygmy hippo at 52, celebrated at San Diego Humane Society’s Ramona Wildlife Center with a Hungry Hungry Hippos–themed party featuring colored balls and gifts. Rescued from an Escondido backyard in 2002, she resides in a 13,000-sq-ft habitat with pond, pool, spa-style back rubs, sprinkler showers and specialized meals. Exceeding her species’ typical 25–30-year lifespan, she embodies resilience. Fewer than 2,000 pygmy hippos remain in the wild, mostly in Liberia. As shy nocturnal forest dwellers with rounder heads, longer necks and single incisors, pygmy hippos eluded western science until 1840.

articles.title: Senator whose wife was shot fears for safety after Trump sedition accusation
articles.trailText: President called behavior of Mark Kelly, whose wife Gabby Giffords survived assassination bid, ‘punishable by death’
articles.summary: Arizona Senator Mark Kelly, whose wife Gabby Giffords survived a 2011 assassination attempt, warns of heightened threats after Donald Trump accused him and fellow ex-military Democrats of “seditious behavior punishable by death” on Truth Social. The charge followed their video urging U.S. service members to refuse illegal orders under the Manual for Courts-Martial. Under military law sedition carries death; civilians face up to 20-year sentences. Kelly cautioned that Trump’s incendiary language risks fueling the rising tide of political violence.

articles.title: Democrats investigating Epstein decry Andrew ‘silence’ over interview request
articles.trailText: Mountbatten-Windsor ‘continues to hide’, US lawmakers say, after deadline they set to receive response passes
articles.summary: House oversight Democrats Robert Garcia and Suhas Subramanyam criticized Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor’s refusal to testify in their Jeffrey Epstein inquiry after ignoring a deposition request. Citing estate documents and survivor Virginia Giuffre’s testimony, they warned his silence raises serious questions but lack subpoena power. Republican chair James Comer has not issued a subpoena, and Mountbatten-Windsor could avoid penalties by remaining abroad. They also pressed Attorney General Pam Bondi to fully implement the new Epstein Files Transparency Act and release unredacted records despite political interference.

articles.title: Tens of thousands of people were detained and deported during US government shutdown
articles.trailText: As most government business halted during the shutdown, immigration agents continued their raids
articles.summary: Released first since September, ICE data show that during the Oct 1–Nov 15 shutdown, ICE arrested ~54,000 and deported ~56,000 people, driving detention to a record 65,000. More than 21,000 detainees had no criminal record—surpassing those with convictions or pending charges—contradicting DHS claims of targeting the “worst of the worst.” Leaked emails reveal orders to arrest 3,000 daily, including “collaterals,” while border agents were reassigned inland. Surging budgets, deputized local agencies and private contractors expanded interior raids in major cities, catching undocumented migrants—and even some citizens—despite most federal services halting.

articles.title: New Mexico now offers free childcare for all. Here’s how parents and teachers made it happen
articles.trailText: From marches and petitions to a constitutional amendment, a years-long campaign led to New Mexico becoming the first state in the US to offer universal childcare
articles.summary: Beginning in 2018, largely immigrant women childcare workers organized marches, petitions and lobbying through Olé, New Mexico Voices for Children, Catholic charities and lawmakers to improve early‐childhood educator pay and expand access. They secured a 2022 voter-approved constitutional amendment tapping the state’s land grant permanent fund—ratified by Congress and signed by President Biden—to launch free childcare up to 400% of poverty in 2023. As of November 1, 2025, New Mexico offers universal free childcare, incentivizing providers to pay entry-level staff $18/hour. Advocates now push for a living wage, workforce growth and legal protections post-administration.

articles.title: US Representative Eric Swalwell announces run for California governor
articles.trailText: The seven-term Democrat is known for his pugnacious and persistent opposition to Donald Trump
articles.summary: Seven-term Democratic US Representative Eric Swalwell has formally launched a campaign for California governor during a Jimmy Kimmel Live appearance, pitching himself as an affordability champion and anti-Trump fighter. A former Alameda County prosecutor and House intelligence committee member who served as an impeachment manager, Swalwell emphasizes cutting costs, raising wages and defending democratic norms. His entry intensifies a crowded field that includes Tom Steyer, Katie Porter, Antonio Villaraigosa, Xavier Becerra and Betty Yee on the Democratic side, alongside Republicans Chad Bianco and Steve Hilton. The state’s acute housing, budget and homelessness crises loom large.

articles.title: The FBI spied on a Signal group chat of immigration activists, records reveal
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Agency accessed private conversations of New York ‘courtwatch’ group that was observing public hearings
articles.summary: Documents obtained by Property of the People reveal that in late August 2025 the FBI secretly spied on a private Signal group chat of New York immigration ‘courtwatch’ activists—who legally and nonviolently monitor public hearings at three federal courts—and quoted instructions on filming officers and navigating courthouse access. The bureau branded members “anarchist violent extremists” without evidence, distributing the report with the NYPD nationwide. It coincides with ICE’s renewed courthouse arrests, spurring courtwatchers to document alleged due-process violations. City officials and transparency non-profits likened the surveillance to J. Edgar Hoover–era spying on activists. Surveillance methods remain unclear, and advocates warn it chills free-speech.

articles.title: Health of double amputee detained in Georgia ICE jail worsens
articles.trailText: Rodney Taylor says detention ‘draining on my body’ as Democratic senator Raphael Warnock lends support to case
articles.summary: Rodney Taylor, a 46-year-old Liberian-born double amputee missing three fingers, has endured worsening health—bone spurs, high blood pressure, prosthetic leg breakdowns and resulting injuries—during nearly a year’s ICE detention at Georgia’s Stewart center. Diagnosed with severe back pain and chronic wounds from chafing, he faces limited family visits under strict new rules. Senator Raphael Warnock has urged Homeland Security to review Taylor’s case, citing his 40 years of community service and local endorsements. A habeas petition for bond remains undecided while the administration resists release despite Taylor’s pending green card and decades-old, pardoned conviction.

articles.title: Trump’s DoJ investigating unfounded claims Venezuela helped steal 2020 election
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Discredited election-rigging conspiracy theory could strengthen Trump’s military action against Maduro
articles.summary: Under Trump’s Justice Department, federal investigators in Puerto Rico and Tampa are probing unfounded claims that Venezuela rigged the 2020 US election, promoted by ex-CIA officer Gary Berntsen and Venezuelan consultant Martin Rodil. They’ve briefed US attorney W. Stephen Muldrow and the Panex taskforce on alleged links between Maduro’s regime, Smartmatic and Dominion voting machines. Despite 2023 Delaware court rulings and multimillion-dollar defamation settlements, the revived conspiracy could bolster Trump’s narrative of a “rigged” election and justify military pressure on Venezuela.

articles.title: Jimmy Kimmel accuses Trump of trying to get him fired and tells him: ‘Quiet, piggy’
articles.trailText: ‘You’ve done this before,’ comedian told president, who ranted about Kimmel online and demanded his firing
articles.summary: After Trump again demanded on Truth Social that ABC fire Jimmy Kimmel for having 'no talent' and 'poor ratings,' Kimmel used his late-night monologue to mock the president’s repeated firing threats—from September’s brief suspension under Nexstar and Sinclair pressure through an ongoing FCC power review—and quip 'quiet, piggy.' He ridiculed Trump’s tenacity, joked about making bagels for his kids, suggested they both resign together, and noted Trump’s similar campaign against Seth Meyers.

articles.title: World awaits fresh Epstein cache – but could Trump officials block full release?
articles.trailText: Experts say files certain to contain revelations but warn disclosures could still leave critical questions unanswered
articles.summary: A newly enacted law mandates that Trump’s DOJ, within 30 days, disclose its full investigative files on Jeffrey Epstein—ranging from surveillance videos and photographs to memos and witness interviews—promising revelations about his powerful associates. But experts and victims’ attorneys warn that DOJ could exploit “ongoing investigation” exemptions and redaction loopholes to withhold or sanitize politically sensitive names, particularly amid Trump‐directed probes of figures like Bill Clinton and Reid Hoffman. Though the law bars redactions based solely on reputational harm, critics argue it still allows broad withholdings. Victims say decades of delay—and powerful social, political and financial networks—have long shielded Epstein’s enablers from accountability.

articles.title: US men indicted for alleged coup plot to kill and rape people on Haitian island
articles.trailText: Texans planned to utilize unhoused US people to take over Gonâve and fulfill ‘rape fantasies’, justice department says
articles.summary: According to a DOJ indictment, 21-year-old Gavin Rivers Weisenburg and 20-year-old Tanner Christopher Thomas plotted from August 2024 to July 2025 to invade Haiti’s Gonâve Island, recruit unhoused Washington, D.C., residents, kill all men, and enslave women and children for sexual abuse. They studied Haitian Creole, bought arms, and Thomas joined the U.S. Air Force for military skills. Charged with federal conspiracy to murder, maim or kidnap abroad—punishable by life—and child pornography, they face up to 30 years in prison. The case involves the FBI, Air Force OSI, and local police.

articles.title: Swiss gold and Rolex gifts to Trump arouse ‘disgust’ in Europe
articles.trailText: Billionaires gave desk clock and engraved gold bar weeks before Trump slashed tariffs on imports from Switzerland
articles.summary: A group of Swiss billionaires—including Rolex chief Jean-Frédéric Dufour and gold refiner Marwan Shakarchi—presented Donald Trump with a bespoke gold Rolex desk clock and a $130,000 engraved gold bar reflecting his presidencies, weeks before he cut Swiss tariffs from 39% to 15%. European politicians—from Italian MEP Pasquale Tridico’s 'disgust' to Swiss Green leader Lisa Mazzone’s corruption claims—blasted the gifts as personalised foreign policy. Swiss commentators called the lobbying 'undignified', while Economy Minister Guy Parmelin and a White House spokesperson denied any quid pro quo, citing US economic benefits.

articles.title: Trump has assembled least diverse US government this century, study shows
articles.trailText: President has chosen white men for key posts at expense of women and people of colour, Brookings Institution finds
articles.summary: Brookings study finds Trump’s second term has the least diverse 21st-century US government: 90% of Senate-confirmed appointees in his first 300 days are white, with women at just 16%, down from 50% under Biden and 23% in Trump’s first term. Diversity-abolishing executive orders and firings of prominent Black officials underlie an anti-DEI agenda. Senate rule changes enabled 216 confirmations vs. Biden’s 140, accelerating to 118 in the last 100 days. Diplomatic posts plunged (31 vs. Bush’s 133), while domestic legal (14) and energy (16, 13 recent) appointments surged, signaling a strategic shift.

articles.title: First Thing: Outrage after Trump accuses Democrats of ‘seditious behavior, punishable by death’
articles.trailText: US president roundly decried for Truth Social post after lawmakers told military personnel to refuse illegal orders. Plus, Superman comic found in attic becomes most expensive ever sold
articles.summary: Trump sparked outrage by accusing six Democratic lawmakers—veterans and intel alumni—of “seditious behavior punishable by death” after they urged troops to refuse illegal orders. Meanwhile, the FBI spied on an immigrants’ rights Signal chat, Zelenskyy agreed to negotiate a US-Russia peace draft with Trump, Gaza relief donations plunged post-ceasefire, a CDC site echoed debunked vaccine-autism claims, a Frida Kahlo self-portrait fetched $54.7 m, a mother-baby fentanyl rehab pilot showed better outcomes, white nationalist Nick Fuentes exposed GOP infighting, Cop30 draft omitted a fossil fuel phase-out, and Musk’s AI Grok made boastful, bizarre claims.

articles.title: A groundswell of activism takes hold in the US: ‘We are a bridge to the future’
articles.trailText: Everyday people from blue and red states alike are leading actions such as protests, boycotts and mutual aid
articles.summary: Since Trump’s 2024 reelection, grassroots activists in red and blue states have organized decentralized protests, mutual-aid networks and boycotts to resist ICE raids, LGBTQ+ rollbacks and corporate cuts to diversity. In Chicago, “migra watches” of up to 400 volunteers chase ICE from immigrant neighborhoods, while in Florida, Indivisible’s “No Kings” rallies drew over 7 million nationwide. Boycotts of Tesla, Target and Disney erased billions in market value. Progressive groups report surging Run for Something candidacies. Twenty-three Democratic attorneys general have filed lawsuits halting Trump’s policies. Organizers warn that sustaining power requires long-term local infrastructure and inclusive outreach.

articles.title: ‘Toxic’: California ex-police chief tells of colleagues’ racist harassment campaign
articles.trailText: Shawny Williams, who tried to reform Vallejo police department, says threats to his safety led him to resign
articles.summary: Shawny Williams, Vallejo’s first Black chief, resigned in 2022 after enduring sustained racist remarks, anonymous threats (including a screeching “quit today” Halloween card) and hostility from officers and the VPOA. In a deposition for the federal civil-rights suit by Deyana Jenkins (tased in 2019) over the Willie McCoy killing, Williams described city manager Mike Malone’s refusal to act on his safety concerns, retaliation after he disciplined Jarrett Tonn for the 2020 killing of unarmed protester Sean Monterrosa (later reinstated and promoted), and a culture of entrenched violence and resistance to reform.

articles.title: US veteran considers civil lawsuit after he was arrested and injured at anti-ICE protest
articles.trailText: Dana Briggs, 70, had charges dropped after being accused of assaulting an agent during a protest at an Illinois ICE facility
articles.summary: Air Force veteran Dana Briggs, 70, had felony assault charges dropped after being knocked over by masked ICE agents during a protest at Broadview, Illinois. Magistrate Judge Gabriel A. Fuentes dismissed the case after reviewing body-worn camera footage that undermined government allegations he assaulted an officer while expanding a safety perimeter. Briggs, who suffered cuts and wrist injuries, is now considering a civil lawsuit. His prosecution—one of eight veteran cases from “Operation Midway Blitz”—drew national criticism, and the DOJ cited ongoing case reviews.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president says Democrats should be arrested for ‘seditious behavior’, drawing outrage
articles.trailText: After Trump logged on and chose violence, Democratic leaders condemned his ‘disgusting and dangerous death threats’
articles.summary: President Trump used Truth Social to accuse a group of Democratic lawmakers of seditious behavior—’punishable by death’—and called for their arrest after they urged troops to defy illegal orders. House Democrats led by Jeffries, Clark and Aguilar condemned his rhetoric, alerted Capitol security and demanded a retraction, which the White House later partly walked back. In related news, Zelenskiy plans to discuss a US-Russia peace proposal with Trump; the administration announced new offshore drilling; the CDC vaccine page was altered to echo RFK Jr.; and a judge blocked troop deployments to DC.

articles.title: White House press secretary defends Trump’s ‘piggy’ insult
articles.trailText: Karoline Leavitt says president ‘calls out fake news when he sees it’ after remark to reporter draws severe condemnation
articles.summary: White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt defended President Trump’s ‘piggy’ jibe at Bloomberg’s Catherine Lucey, asserting he ‘calls out fake news’ and grants unprecedented media access. The barb, delivered aboard Air Force One during a question on Jeffrey Epstein files, sparked widespread condemnation from journalists including CNN’s Jake Tapper and ex-Fox anchor Gretchen Carlson. Trump also labeled ABC’s Mary Bruce ‘a terrible reporter’ over Khashoggi and Epstein inquiries. The Society of Professional Journalists decried this pattern of hostility, especially toward women, as an attack on press freedom.

articles.title: Mahmoud Khalil sues Trump officials over ‘collusion’ with anti-Palestinian groups
articles.trailText: Activist detained by ICE condemns ‘smear and harassment campaign’ and demands release of key communications
articles.summary: Palestinian activist Mahmoud Khalil has filed suit against the Trump administration demanding release of internal communications with anti-Palestinian groups he alleges colluded to smear and orchestrate his March arrest and prolonged ICE detention. These groups, including Betar USA, Documenting Jew Hatred on Campus, Canary Mission and Columbia Alumni for Israel, shared dossiers with agencies like DHS, ICE, State and DOJ. Represented by the Center for Constitutional Rights, Khalil seeks records of all communications, accusing officials of coordinating a smear campaign to chill Palestinian speech. Previously released in June after three months, he also pursues $20m in damages.

articles.title: White House announces new oil and gas drilling off California and Florida
articles.trailText: But Sunshine state Republicans might oppose drilling off state’s famous beaches that keep tourism dollars coming in
articles.summary: The Trump administration on Thursday unveiled plans to resume offshore oil and gas leasing off California and Florida coasts, marking first federal auctions in nearly 30 years. Interior’s 2026–31 draft schedule outlines up to 34 sales—including six off California, two in the eastern Gulf of Mexico (banned since 1995) and 21 in Alaska, including virgin territory. Framed as a boost to energy independence and jobs, the proposal clashes with California Gov. Gavin Newsom’s “dead on arrival” warning and Florida Republicans (Sen. Rick Scott, AG Ashley Moody) defending beaches and tourism.

articles.title: CDC website altered to reflect RFK Jr’s belief in link between vaccines and autism
articles.trailText: Public health and autism specialists roundly condemn alteration to the ‘vaccine safety’ webpage
articles.summary: CDC’s vaccine safety webpage was altered under HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to reflect his view that vaccines may cause autism, replacing the unequivocal statement “vaccines do not cause autism” with language calling that claim “not evidence-based” and asserting ignored studies support a link. An asterisk notes a retention agreement with Senator Bill Cassidy. No new research is cited; HHS says it’s launching an autism causes assessment. Public health experts, former CDC officials, the Autism Science Foundation and leading pediatricians condemned the change as ideologically driven, bypassing scientific review, undermining immunization safety and CDC credibility.

articles.title: Congressman Ro Khanna warns officials not to impede Epstein files release: ‘They will be prosecuted’
articles.trailText: California lawmaker says names of anyone involved in Epstein’s crimes must come to light, Democrat or Republican
articles.summary: Democratic Rep. Ro Khanna led enactment of the Epstein Files Transparency Act requiring DOJ to release Jeffrey Epstein documents within 30 days, warning career officials they face contempt or criminal prosecution if they impede disclosure. Partnering with GOP Rep. Thomas Massie and securing enough discharge petition signatures to bypass Speaker Mike Johnson’s blockade, the bill passed unanimously, overturning Trump’s “Democrat hoax” claim. Khanna credits survivors’ pressure, supports subpoenaing ex-royal Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, and promises future House majorities will hold noncompliant officials—Democrat or Republican—accountable.

articles.title: Bay Area’s poverty soared, data shows, as California’s top earners saw windfalls
articles.trailText: Poverty rate jumped from 12.2% to 16.3% in 2023 in state, Tipping Point Community report finds
articles.summary: In 2023 the Bay Area’s poverty rate jumped from 12.2% to 16.3%, leaving 1.02 million residents below the threshold and another 12.5% (≈790,000) near poverty. From 2016 to 2023 incomes rose 34% while living costs climbed 46%. After falling from 18.7% in 2011 to 10.8% in 2021, the region’s poverty rate reverted to 2016 levels, roughly 2% above pre-pandemic. Half of Bay Area poor families include a full-time earner. Racial disparities widened: whites 9.3%→10.6%, Blacks 15.8%→22.1%, Latinos 20.3%→26%, Asians 9.6%→14.1%. Meanwhile, Silicon Valley’s top 0.1% hold over 70% of local wealth.

articles.title: Tears and solemnity at Cheney funeral – but no memorial for those killed in Iraq
articles.trailText: Great and good pay tribute in Washington but honouring of former vice-president was an exercise in omission
articles.summary: At Washington National Cathedral, bipartisan figures from Bill Kristol and Chris Wallace to James Carville, Anthony Fauci and Rachel Maddow gathered to mourn the 46th vice-president, Dick Cheney. Ex-presidents and Joe Biden attended, but Donald Trump and JD Vance were excluded. Eulogies from George W. Bush and daughter Liz Cheney praised his loyalty, service and defense of the Constitution, while sidestepping his role in authorizing the Iraq invasion, vast surveillance under the Patriot Act and “enhanced interrogation.” The ceremony’s grand solemnity paralleled the omission of the hundreds of thousands killed in the Iraq war, underscoring the funeral’s complex legacy.

articles.title: Justice department investigates handling of Adam Schiff’s mortgage fraud case
articles.trailText: Inquiry centers on whether two Trump allies influenced Schiff investigation as prosecutors struggle to build case
articles.summary: The Justice Department’s Office of the Deputy Attorney General, led by Todd Blanche, is probing whether two Trump-aligned officials improperly steered the Maryland grand jury probe into Sen. Adam Schiff’s alleged mortgage fraud. A subpoena to FHFA associate and GOP candidate Christine Bish demands her communications with FHFA chief Bill Pulte’s circle, weaponization committee head Ed Martin’s aides, financial expert Robert Bowes, and consultant Scott Strauss. Bish says prosecutors focused on possible collusion with Pulte or Martin. This offshoot inquiry could preempt Schiff’s defense or, if misconduct is found, derail weak charges that Schiff, AG Letitia James, Fed governor Lisa Cook, and Rep. Eric Swalwell all deny.

articles.title: Pelosi calls Trump ‘the biggest con job in American history’ in reply to climate comment
articles.trailText: US speaker emerita criticizes Trump’s anti-climate stance and his remarks to the UN general assembly
articles.summary: Speaker emerita Nancy Pelosi branded Donald Trump 'the biggest con job in American history' at a press conference responding to his UN claim that the climate crisis is 'the greatest con job ever.' Convened by Senate Democrats after the Trump administration skipped COP30 in Belém—its first US absence since leaving the Paris accord—she spoke alongside climate hawk Senator Sheldon Whitehouse, who denounced Trump's fossil fuel ties and dark money influence, and House leader Hakeem Jeffries, who warned the US ceded global leadership to China. New polling shows two-thirds of voters favor ambitious climate action. Pelosi, retiring at term's end, recalled attending the 1992 Rio summit alongside Al Gore.

articles.title: Outrage after Trump accuses Democrats of ‘seditious behavior, punishable by death’
articles.trailText: US president roundly decried for Truth Social post after lawmakers told military personnel to refuse illegal orders
articles.summary: After six Democratic veterans—Senators Elissa Slotkin and Mark Kelly and Representatives Maggie Goodlander, Chris Deluzio, Chrissy Houlahan and Jason Crow—released a video urging service members to refuse illegal orders, Donald Trump took to Truth Social to denounce them as “traitors” committing “seditious behavior, punishable by death,” and called for their arrest. House and Senate Democratic leaders including Jeffries, Clark, Aguilar and Schumer condemned Trump’s threats, coordinated Capitol Police security and demanded he delete his posts. Speaker Mike Johnson defended Trump’s sedition claim as a critique of “dangerous” disobedience, while White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt denied any intent to execute lawmakers.

articles.title: Republicans warn Bondi not to bury Epstein files after law’s passage
articles.trailText: Senators push the attorney general to release Epstein records within 30 days, fearing delays or sweeping redactions
articles.summary: Republican senators, days after Trump signed the bipartisan Epstein Files Transparency Act, pressed Florida AG Pam Bondi to comply with its 30-day mandate for public release of DOJ records on Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell in searchable format. They warned against stalling or heavy redactions under claims of active investigations or minor protections, citing past administration secrecy and the 2008 non-prosecution deal. While Lisa Murkowski and Thom Tillis demand transparency, John Kennedy and Eric Schmitt express confidence documents will emerge after Thanksgiving; the FBI holds over 300 GB of data.

articles.title: Documents reveal Gerald Ford’s effort to block report on CIA assassination plots
articles.trailText: Release of documents comes amid conjecture Trump may have authorized the agency to assassinate Venezuelan president
articles.summary: Declassified 1975 memos show President Gerald Ford’s White House sought to block the Senate’s Church committee report exposing CIA assassination attempts against Fidel Castro, Patrice Lumumba and Gen René Schneider. A secret options paper urged Chief of Staff Dick Cheney to oppose publication, warning of national harm. Despite CIA director William Colby and Henry Kissinger’s objections, the report deemed assassination incompatible with US principles, prompting Ford to ban such operations. Now released amid Trump-era Maduro hit speculations, analysts warn that Church’s oversight ethic has eroded as legal memos eye Venezuela strikes.

articles.title: Connie Chan, progressive San Francisco lawmaker, enters race to succeed Pelosi
articles.trailText: San Francisco supervisor, 47, highlighting work on affordability for working families in US House run
articles.summary: Connie Chan, 47, a progressive San Francisco supervisor and labor ally, has launched her campaign to succeed Nancy Pelosi in the city’s US House seat, pitching “local neighborhoods versus outside money” and championing real affordable housing and cost relief for working families. Born in Hong Kong, she immigrated at 13, won her board seat in 2020 and was reelected in 2024 with Pelosi’s endorsement. If elected, Chan would be the first Asian American representing SF. Her main rivals are state senator Scott Wiener and tech-funded Saikat Chakrabarti; Pelosi remains neutral.

articles.title: Donald Trump and JD Vance snubbed for Dick Cheney’s funeral
articles.trailText: Joe Biden and George W Bush attend Republican’s service, while Barack Obama and Bill Clinton are notable absentees
articles.summary: Former vice-president Dick Cheney’s Nov. 20 funeral at Washington’s National Cathedral left out Donald Trump and JD Vance. Instead, Bush delivered a eulogy praising Cheney’s loyalty, while attendees included Presidents Joe Biden and Kamala Harris, former VPs Pence, Gore, Quayle, Speaker Pelosi and Chief Justice Roberts. Absent were Barack Obama and Bill Clinton; commentator Rachel Maddow appeared. Exclusion of Trump stemmed from his feud with Cheney’s daughter Liz, co-chair of the Jan. 6 committee. In her remarks, Liz honored her father’s defense-first legacy, praised his constitutional fidelity over party, and noted his influence on her decision to hold Trump accountable.

articles.title: After ICE took students’ parents, these teachers began rising at dawn to keep watch: ‘We said, hell no’
articles.trailText: With students terrified and arrests rising, educators in San Diego are scanning streets, sharing alerts and defending the right to feel safe
articles.summary: At dawn in southern San Diego, three members of the Association of Raza Educators began patrolling school zones in unmarked cars to spot undercover ICE agents, using walkie-talkies, social media and megaphones to alert families. This grassroots response follows a rise in arrests of immigrant parents near campuses after federal “sensitive location” protections were rescinded. Teachers Marysol Duran, Juan Orozco and Aremi Lopez scan for tinted windows and partitions, then broadcast sightings to deter detentions. Alongside know-your-rights workshops and student-led activism, these patrols aim to uphold the community’s right to free public education amid escalating fear.

articles.title: ‘Golden crime scene’: Elizabeth Warren calls for inquiry into Trump’s ballroom funding
articles.trailText: The top Democrat on the Senate banking committee says private funding for Trump’s ballroom poses serious corruption concerns
articles.summary: Senator Elizabeth Warren urged the next DOJ to probe private donations funding President Trump’s new White House ballroom, warning it could be “a golden crime scene.” Top Democratic lawmakers Warren and Rep. Robert Garcia introduced the Stop Ballroom Bribery Act to ban conflicted gifts, mandate disclosures, and impose lobbying “cooling-off” periods. Critics note tech giants, defense contractors and telecom firms contributing to the $300m project hold government contracts that risk undue influence. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt defended private funding, while ethics experts warn of pay-to-play schemes. JP Morgan CEO Jamie Dimon declined to donate citing reputational and legal risks.

articles.title: ‘I lose my liberty in that moment’: Charlotte shuts down as citizens and noncitizens alike face ICE arrests
articles.trailText: As federal agents descend in North Carolina, businesses close as even an after-school program is targeted
articles.summary: After-border patrol agents descended on Charlotte in “Operation Charlotte’s Web” last weekend, ICE and CBP ramped up citywide immigration arrests—250+ statewide. East Charlotte’s immigrant-oriented Central Avenue businesses, led by Manolo’s Bakery, shuttered in solidarity as protests rallied outside. Agents detained U.S. citizens like Puerto Rican native Gerardo Ortiz, instilling fear across communities; even an after-school program and a church event were targeted. School absenteeism tripled, halal lamb deliveries stalled, and local officials, from county commissioners to police, condemned the raids. Advocates say the tactics—named “surge”—discriminate, spark legal limbo and sow widespread anxiety.

articles.title: First Thing: US and Russian officials draft plan to end Ukraine war based on capitulation from Kyiv
articles.trailText: The plan, which is likely to be viewed as ‘surrender’ by Kyiv, is facing pushback from the EU. Plus, Trump signs bill to compel release of more Epstein documents
articles.summary: US and Russian envoys, including Trump aide Steve Witkoff and Kremlin adviser Kirill Dmitriev, have secretly drafted a peace plan requiring Ukraine to cede eastern territory, halve its army and curb US military aid—terms Kyiv would view as capitulation and which the EU is already pushing back on. The informal backchannel’s White House support remains unclear. The proposal surfaced as Russian strikes killed at least 25 in Ternopil. Separately, Trump signed a bill mandating DOJ release all Epstein files and sparked outrage calling a reporter “piggy.”

articles.title: Trump officials reveal plan to roll back regulations in Endangered Species Act
articles.trailText: Experts fear plan, one of many attempts Trump’s made to dismantle wildlife protection, will speed up extinction crisis
articles.summary: The Trump administration’s Dept of Interior, Fish and Wildlife Service and NOAA Fisheries unveiled rules to roll back key Endangered Species Act safeguards: weighing economic impacts over habitat designations, narrowing “critical habitat” to areas species currently occupy, rescinding the threatened-species blanket rule and excluding climate impacts. New listings could wait years for tailored protections amid staffing cuts. Conservationists warn this blueprint accelerates extinctions of wolverines, monarchs and manatees. Though similar first-term rollbacks were reversed under Biden, a 30-day comment period opens Friday amid strong public opposition.

articles.title: Larry Ellison discussed axing CNN hosts with White House in takeover bid talks
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Senior officials indicated favorability toward Paramount Skydance acquiring Warner Bros Discovery
articles.summary: Senior White House officials privately favor Paramount Skydance, backed by Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison, as the preferred bidder for Warner Bros Discovery. Ellison discussed potential CNN lineup changes—dropping hosts Erin Burnett and Brianna Keilar and airing 60 Minutes segments—during calls with White House contacts aligned with Trump’s preferences. The push highlights behind-the-scenes lobbying leveraging Ellison’s relationships to clear regulatory hurdles, with former DOJ antitrust officials and FCC chair signaling minimal review. Trump’s favorable stance follows Paramount’s $16m settlement over a 60 Minutes interview with Kamala Harris. Competitors Netflix and Comcast remain interested, but Paramount prepares a bid by the November 20 deadline.

articles.title: In Tennessee, Democrats hope a ‘coalition of the pissed off’ will flip a red district
articles.trailText: With a platform focused on cost of living, Aftyn Behn wants to turn the US House seat blue for the first time since 1983
articles.summary: In Tennessee’s 7th congressional district, Democrats have tapped progressive state rep Aftyn Behn—running on a cost-of-living, anti-PAC platform—to challenge Republican army veteran Matt Van Epps in a December 2 special election. Once a 21-point GOP stronghold, polls show Van Epps’ lead has shrunk to single digits amid inflation, housing and grocery burdens. Behn, backed by the DNC and Kamala Harris, vows to build a “coalition of the pissed off,” reject corporate PAC cash, oppose projects like Musk’s tunnel, and highlight looming Medicaid cuts and Trump’s tariffs hurting local residents.

articles.title: Trump signs bill to compel release of more Epstein documents
articles.trailText: President attacks Democrats in post on Truth Social after US lawmakers swiftly move bill through Congress
articles.summary: On Nov. 19, President Trump signed a bipartisan bill mandating the Justice Department to release all unclassified files from its Jeffrey Epstein investigation within 30 days—including flight logs, plea deals, financial and travel records, communications, detention and death reports—while allowing redaction of victim identities and sensitive active-case details. The move marks Trump’s reversal after years of resistance and labeling the issue a “hoax.” He hailed the measure on Truth Social, suggesting it could expose Democrats’ ties to Epstein and barring any withholding for embarrassment or political sensitivity.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: 30-day countdown to release Epstein files begins after president signs bill
articles.trailText: Action follows months of resistance from the president and his political allies that fractured his Maga base
articles.summary: President Donald Trump has signed legislation, overwhelmingly approved by Congress, directing the DOJ to publish unclassified 'Epstein files' within 30 days, ending months of his resistance that split his MAGA base. The law mandates release of investigations into Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, flight logs, financial networks, immunity deals, internal communications, detention and death records, and entities tied to trafficking—subject to redactions for victim identities, active probes and child abuse depictions. Trump, who previously branded the release a 'hoax,' said 'we have nothing to hide' after reversing course when House passage was certain.

articles.title: ‘Nobel prize for fiction’: judge excoriates colleague in Texas redistricting case
articles.trailText: Jerry Smith condemns opinion written by Jeffrey Brown and mentions Soros name 17 times in 104-page dissent
articles.summary: Reagan appointee Judge Jerry Smith issued a scathing 104-page dissent condemning Trump appointee Judge Jeffrey Brown’s decision striking down Texas’s congressional map as discriminatory. Smith accused Brown of writing ‘fiction’ before he could respond, invoking George Soros (17 mentions), his son Alex and Gov. Gavin Newsom for allegedly influencing redistricting via Soros-funded groups. He derided an expert as a ‘Soros operative’ but praised opposing lawyers’ integrity. Texas AG Ken Paxton plans to appeal to the Supreme Court, backed by federal AG Pam Bondi, while legal scholars warn Smith’s personal attacks could undermine his arguments.

articles.title: Full grand jury didn’t see final Comey indictment, prosecutors admit
articles.trailText: Concession by federal lawyers adds to mounting challenges in effort to prosecute the former FBI director
articles.summary: At a Nov 19 hearing, federal prosecutors admitted lead prosecutor Lindsey Halligan never presented the final two-count indictment against former FBI director James Comey to a full grand jury, showing it only to the foreperson and one juror. Comey’s lawyers argue this procedural lapse nullifies the charges—making a false statement to Congress and obstructing a proceeding—while prosecutors claim the counts duplicate those originally approved and any error is harmless. Legal experts call it a “fatal flaw,” and a magistrate judge has ordered grand jury materials turned over, pending appeal.

articles.title: ‘Unforgivable’: Trump’s ‘piggy’ insult is stoking more outrage than usual
articles.trailText: The clip of the US president on Air Force One last Friday has taken off without much help from the media itself
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s ‘quiet, piggy’ barb at AP reporter Catherine Lucey on Air Force One—when she pressed him on releasing Jeffrey Epstein files��has gone viral online days later. Following a similar outburst at ABC’s Mary Bruce about Jamal Khashoggi, it highlights a pattern of female-targeted media attacks amid Trump’s political setbacks. The Society of Professional Journalists condemned the remark; the White House defended it. Democrats and activists are using pig imagery on social media to counter the insult and challenge Trump’s media stranglehold.

articles.title: Saudi Arabia releases US retiree jailed over critical tweets
articles.trailText: Saad Almadi’s family thanks Trump and state department as announcement comes after meeting with crown prince
articles.summary: Saudi Arabia has agreed to release US-Saudi dual citizen Saad Almadi, 75, five months early, allowing him to return to Florida after a 30-year exit ban and a prior 19-year prison sentence for critical tweets. His family credits President Trump, the State Department, Dr. Sebastian Gorka, the National Security Council and nonprofits like the James Foley Fund and Hostages America. The decision followed Mohammed bin Salman’s White House meeting with Trump and growing US pressure. Almadi, a retired engineer arrested in 2021 for tweets urging Lebanese citizenship and praising a street renaming after Jamal Khashoggi, now awaits departure.

articles.title: Did you lose your home in the Los Angeles wildfires? We’d like to hear how you’re spending the holidays
articles.trailText: We would like to speak to people who were displaced in the destructive January wildfires and learn how they’re preparing for upcoming holiday season
articles.summary: January’s Pacific Palisades fire, the most destructive in Los Angeles history, killed 12 people and razed over 6,800 structures. East LA’s Eaton fire in Altadena claimed 19 lives, leaving many still displaced. We’re seeking first-person accounts of how wildfire survivors are preparing for the upcoming holidays: where they’ll stay, how traditions have changed, and what emotional and practical challenges they face. Share your experiences of loss, resilience and community support as you rebuild this season. Interested contributors should contact editors to share quotes, photos or videos detailing holiday plans and recovery journey.

articles.title: Is Trump’s remarkable run of fealty coming to an end?
articles.trailText: As Trump has flailed around looking for someone to shout at, it’s the media, his familiar old foe, which has drawn the sharpest attacks
articles.summary: After nine years during which Donald Trump’s base endured impeachments, felony convictions, a Capitol insurrection and countless controversies, cracks are appearing in his GOP loyalty. His push to block release of Jeffrey Epstein files prompted up to 100 House Republicans to defy him, forcing an embarrassing U-turn. Similar insubordination on gerrymandering and filibuster reforms has provoked Trump’s pettiness and insults. Frustrated, he has lashed out at the media—branding ABC “crappy” and demanding their licences, threatening lawsuits against CNN and CBS, even smearing female reporters. As Republicans grow wary, can an embattled press stand firm?

articles.title: FBI worker says he was wrongfully terminated for having Pride flag at desk
articles.trailText: David Maltinsky, a 16-year veteran, says in lawsuit agency retaliated against him for engaging in protected speech
articles.summary: David Maltinsky, a 16-year FBI intelligence specialist, sued the FBI, naming Director Kash Patel, DOJ and AG Pam Bondi, claiming he was unlawfully fired for displaying a Pride flag at his desk—an act previously approved by supervisors and recognized as part of bureau diversity initiatives. Dismissed three weeks before graduating from Quantico, Maltinsky alleges First Amendment retaliation and seeks reinstatement. His complaint cites Patel’s October 1 termination letter condemning “political signage,” and lawyers argue it reflects a broader purge of dissenting and marginalized federal employees. FBI and DOJ declined comment.

articles.title: Will Trump sign the Epstein bill and when could the files be released?
articles.trailText: The bill passed by a passed a significant milestone in Congress and now awaits the US president’s signature
articles.summary: Congress overwhelmingly passed the Epstein Files Transparency Act 427–1 in the House, with unanimous Senate approval by expedited unanimous consent. The bill compels the DOJ to release all unclassified materials on Jeffrey Epstein, who died awaiting sex-trafficking trial in 2019. The vote followed Trump’s weekend U-turn calling prior delays a 'Democrat hoax' and ended White House attempts to flip Reps. Lauren Boebert and Nancy Mace. President Trump pledged to sign though he could veto—action Congress could override. Only Rep. Clay Higgins opposed. Observers warn Trump-ordered DOJ probes into figures in Epstein’s emails may delay or redact disclosures.

articles.title: Trump officials announce $1bn loan to restart Three Mile Island nuclear plant
articles.trailText: Facility that was site of worst nuclear disaster in US history will provide power for Microsoft datacenters
articles.summary: The Trump administration approved a $1bn DOE loan to Constellation Energy to restart the shut 835MW Three Mile Island reactor by 2027, under a 20-year power purchase with Microsoft’s AI datacenters. Energy Secretary Chris Wright said the project will secure reliable, carbon‐free power, strengthen the mid‐Atlantic grid, lower costs and create 600+ jobs. Constellation must complete NRC and water permits, refuel and upgrade cooling towers. Critics warn of unresolved radioactive waste storage. The facility, site of the 1979 meltdown, could power ~800,000 homes.

articles.title: House Republicans’ attempt to censure Democrat over texts with Epstein fails
articles.trailText: Measure that would have formally reprimanded Stacey Plaskett over real-time texts during 2019 hearing collapses
articles.summary: House Republicans failed 209-214 to censure Democratic delegate Stacey Plaskett over real-time 2019 hearing texts with Jeffrey Epstein after three GOP defectors sided with Democrats. Immediately after, Democrats withdrew their own censure of Republican Rep. Cory Mills amid allegations of stolen valor, financial misconduct and domestic abuse, fueling claims of backroom deals. Rep. Lauren Boebert and Anna Paulina Luna publicly confronted leadership. Documents show Epstein text-coaching and complimenting Plaskett during a hearing. Plaskett, nonvoting USVI delegate, cited public input and her anti–sexual assault record in response. Critics like Kat Cammack and Nancy Mace pledge further ethics actions; Mills denies wrongdoing.

articles.title: Jessica Tisch will remain New York police commissioner under Mamdani
articles.trailText: Mayor-elect said head of city’s police department will stay at her post when he takes office
articles.summary: Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani will retain Jessica Tisch as NYC police commissioner when he assumes office Jan 1, praising her tenure that saw historic crime drops – fewest shootings, nearly 20% murder decrease, and 4,800+ illegal guns removed in 2025. Tisch, first appointed by Eric Adams, has 18 years in public service and agreed after talks despite policy differences. Both aim to lower crime, curb corruption, and support officers. The move has backing from Gov. Hochul and AG James, and Mamdani ordered no NYPD assistance to ICE.

articles.title: Billionaire environmental activist Tom Steyer announces run for California governor
articles.trailText: Steyer, who ran to be Democratic presidential nominee in 2020, joins crowded field seeking to replace Gavin Newsom
articles.summary: Tom Steyer, the 68-year-old billionaire environmental activist and former 2020 Democratic presidential candidate, will join a crowded race to replace term-limited Gov. Gavin Newsom, centering his campaign on California’s affordability crisis and vowing to make corporations pay their fair share. He faces Democrats Katie Porter, Xavier Becerra, Antonio Villaraigosa and Betty Yee, plus expected entry by Eric Swalwell, while Republicans Chad Bianco and Steve Hilton also compete. Steyer, a major Democratic donor who founded NextGen America, points to past victories raising tobacco taxes, closing corporate loopholes and spending $12 million on redistricting, and proposes cutting utility costs, building one million homes in four years, offering free preschool and community college, and banning corporate PAC money in state elections.

articles.title: January 6 rioter who was pardoned by Trump arrested for child sexual abuse
articles.trailText: Andrew Paul Johnson, 44, faces multiple charges in Florida and has pleaded not guilty to the crimes, authorities say
articles.summary: Andrew Paul Johnson, 44, a January 6 rioter pardoned by Trump in 2025, was arrested in August in Tennessee and extradited to Florida on multiple child sexual abuse charges, including lewd and lascivious molestation of a child under 12 and between 12 and 16, exhibition and transmission of harmful material to minors. A probable-cause affidavit alleges he molested an 11-year-old boy three times from April to October 2024, groomed him via Discord messages and coerced him with false promises of $10 million as a pardoned “j6er.” Held in Hernando County jail, Johnson pleads not guilty.

articles.title: Senate agrees to pass Epstein files bill after near-unanimous House vote
articles.trailText: Legislation would next go to Trump who indicated he would sign bill after he and his allies backed down from opposition
articles.summary: The Senate granted unanimous consent to pass the House-approved 427–1 bill to compel release of Jeffrey Epstein investigative files, automatically sending it to President Trump, who dropped his opposition and pledged to sign. Advocates, survivors and Democrats like Schumer hailed the measure as overdue transparency. Republicans including Speaker Mike Johnson and Judiciary Chair Jim Jordan reluctantly backed it after months of intra-party conflict and criticism over victim protections. Clay Higgins cast the lone House no vote. Any Senate amendments would return to the House, potentially delaying enactment.

articles.title: Senate agrees to pass Epstein files bill after near-unanimous House vote | First Thing
articles.trailText: The bill’s support in the House and Senate is a rare moment of bipartisan agreement. Plus, Trump shrugs off Khashoggi murder during Saudi prince’s visit
articles.summary: Senate swiftly approved bipartisan legislation after the House’s 427–1 vote to release all FBI and DOJ files on Jeffrey Epstein, automatically forwarded to President Trump. The rare consensus underscores lingering political fallout from the sex offender’s network and conspiracy theories among Trump’s base. Meanwhile, President Trump shrugged off Saudi Crown Prince MBS’s alleged role in Jamal Khashoggi’s 2018 killing during a White House visit, approved potential F-35 sales, and discussed Israeli normalization. Other briefs include a Lancet review on ultra-processed foods’ health risks, far-right graft allegations, and COP30 fossil fuel phase-out calls.

articles.title: State department to cut 38 universities from research program over DEI policies
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Trump administration proposal would exclude elite schools that use diversity, equity and inclusion hiring practices
articles.summary: State Department memo recommends excluding 38 institutions (including Harvard, Yale, Stanford, Johns Hopkins, Duke, USC and several UC campuses) from the Diplomacy Lab research partnership effective Jan 1, 2026, citing “open DEI hiring practices” or DEI objectives for candidate pools. A color-coded spreadsheet evaluated 75 universities, marking red those with clear DEI policies and green those with merit-based hiring. Proposed replacements include Liberty University, Brigham Young and multiple Missouri and Texas schools. The move follows Trump’s campaign to deem diversity programs illegal and limit federal grants to strictly merit-based hiring.

articles.title: Welcome to Trump’s America! A place where people can’t afford to call an ambulance | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: How are people expected to handle increased health insurance costs when everything else in life has become more expensive? I think the answer is: they’re not, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: In "Trump’s America," Arwa Mahdawi skewers the US health insurance industry’s profit-driven model, likening insurers to rent-seekers who deny claims while lobbying politicians. Though Americans pay the most for healthcare in the developed world, outcomes lag. Families like hers pay $750 monthly premiums plus $500 ER fees; 24% skip ambulances over cost fears. Next year, 154 million employer-insured face 6–7% premium hikes, while ACA marketplace plans jump 26% as subsidies expire. A solo freelancer’s $470 plan would now cost $900 with a $4,000 deductible. Soaring expenses amid stagnant wages leave many unable to afford care.

articles.title: Nearly all immigrants detained in Trump Chicago raid had no criminal conviction
articles.trailText: Data sharply contradicts officials’ portrayal of immigration sweeps as effort to fight ‘worst of the worst’ criminals
articles.summary: Federal court records show 97% of the 614 immigrants arrested in the Trump administration’s “Operation Midway Blitz” in Chicago had no criminal convictions. Of the 16 with records, 10 faced assault or domestic violence charges, one had enticement of a minor and kidnapping conviction, two DUI and one labeled a “foreign criminal.” Most detainees were deemed low safety but flight risks. Submitted in Castañon Nava v. DHS, the data mirrors California sweeps where two-thirds had no convictions. DHS counters that 64% of ICE arrests involve criminal convictions or pending charges, vs. 94% under Biden, with non-criminal detainees now 36% of custody.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Bill to release Epstein files approved by Senate and House
articles.trailText: Donald Trump pivoted at the weekend to signal his support for the bill and says he will sign the measure when it reaches his desk – key US politics stories from Tuesday 18 November
articles.summary: Under bipartisan momentum, the Senate unanimously approved—and the House had earlier passed 427-1—a bill mandating the release of the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein’s investigative files, a measure President Trump signaled he will sign despite earlier resistance. Other developments include Trump’s downplay of the Khashoggi killing during Saudi Crown Prince bin Salman’s visit, a federal judge blocking Texas congressional maps as racially gerrymandered, criticism over Trump’s “piggy” jibe at a Bloomberg reporter, reassignment of Education Department powers, and expanded federal immigration sweeps in North Carolina.

articles.title: Trump officials wrongly deport trans woman in violation of court order
articles.trailText: Officials admit ‘inadvertent removal’ after court ruled Britania Uriostegui Rios should not be sent to Mexico
articles.summary: Britania Uriostegui Rios, a transgender lawful permanent resident with a felony assault conviction, was inadvertently deported to Mexico in November by the Trump administration despite a March court order barring her removal to face likely torture. Deportation officials bused her from Texas to Tijuana; ICE admits the error and plans to facilitate her voluntary US reentry while seeking an alternative deportation destination. Uriostegui Rios is suing for release from custody. The case echoes the earlier wrongful removal of Kilmar Ábrego García, highlighting systemic failures under the administration’s immigration enforcement.

articles.title: New York Times cuts ties with Larry Summers over Epstein emails
articles.trailText: Publication said it will not renew former treasury secretary’s contract in latest fallout after release of emails
articles.summary: The New York Times has opted not to renew its contract with former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers after newly released emails revealed his ongoing correspondence with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein through July 2019. The exchanges portrayed a friendly rapport — Epstein described himself as Summers’ “wing man”— even after Epstein’s 2008 conviction. In response to pressure from lawmakers and clients, the Times announced the end of Summers’ one-year Opinion contributor deal. Several think tanks and advisory roles likewise severed ties. Summers, citing remorse, said he’d scale back public commitments to “rebuild trust” while maintaining teaching duties.

articles.title: Man charged with murder of Oakland football coach ordered to stay in jail without bail
articles.trailText: Cedric Irving Jr charged over death of ‘legend’ John Beam, who was shot and killed on Laney College campus last week
