articles.summary: Cedric Irving Jr., 27, appeared in Alameda County court charged with murder and firearm use in the shooting death of beloved Laney College football coach John Beam, who was fatally shot in the head at the field house. Beam, a fixture at Laney since 2004 and featured on Netflix's Last Chance U, mentored players who reached the NFL. Irving, with no prior record, remains jailed without bail ahead of a December 16 plea hearing, facing up to 50 years to life plus enhancements. Authorities called the killing targeted; no motive disclosed. The case highlights rising campus gun violence in Oakland.

articles.title: Trump shrugs off Khashoggi murder during Saudi prince’s White House visit
articles.trailText: Trump elevates Saudi Arabia to major non-Nato ally after claiming Mohammed bin Salman ‘knew nothing’ about murder of journalist
articles.summary: At a White House ceremony with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman—first since the 2018 murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi—President Donald Trump dismissed Khashoggi as “controversial” and insisted the prince “knew nothing” of the killing. He elevated Saudi Arabia to major non-NATO ally, announced potential $1 trillion in Saudi investment in AI and US industry, and pledged sale of “top of the line” F-35 jets despite Israeli and intelligence concerns. The two also discussed Saudi normalization with Israel linked to a two-state solution. Critics flagged Trump’s ties to the Saudi-interested Trump Organization.

articles.title: Man pours liquid on woman and sets her on fire on Chicago subway
articles.trailText: Victim was hospitalized in critical condition and suspect taken into custody following incident on city’s train system
articles.summary: At about 9:25 pm Monday on the CTA Blue Line near Clark/Lake, a 45-year-old man poured an unknown fluid on a 26-year-old woman and ignited her. The victim stumbled off the train; flames were extinguished by responders before police arrived. She was hospitalized at Stroger Hospital with severe burns and remains in critical condition. The suspect fled but was later taken into custody. Trains resumed service at 1:30 am. Witnesses reported her hyperventilating and medics performing CPR amid a major responder turnout. Police classified the case as aggravated arson and assault, echoing a fatal 2024 New York subway attack.

articles.title: ‘Please release the records’: Epstein survivors urge Congress over DoJ files
articles.trailText: Survivors were joined by lawmakers including Marjorie Taylor Greene before House vote on releasing Epstein files
articles.summary: Outside the Capitol, Jeffrey Epstein survivors and bipartisan lawmakers—including Ro Khanna, Thomas Massie and Marjorie Taylor Greene—urged Congress to release Department of Justice files on Epstein’s sex-trafficking case, hours before the House nearly unanimously passed a bill to force disclosure. Survivors like Haley Robson and Wendy Avis denounced political obstruction and addressed President Trump, who had resisted release but reversed position days earlier. Advocates pushed the Senate to approve the measure, as renewed scrutiny follows leaked estate emails alleging Trump’s knowledge of Epstein’s abuse, which Trump and the White House deny.

articles.title: Trump and Mr Bone Saw stage love-in as Saudi’s $1tn wipes the bloody slate clean
articles.trailText: In the Oval Office the US president dismissed the murder of the columnist Jamal Khashoggi, saying: ‘things happen’
articles.summary: In a lavish Oval Office reception, President Trump and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman pledged $1 trn in U.S. investments, sealed major arms deals including F-15 and F-35 sales despite allies’ objections, and struck a new ‘golden era’ of bilateral ties. Trump publicly dismissed U.S. intelligence on Jamal Khashoggi’s 2018 murder—calling it ‘things happen’—and defended the crown prince. The visit highlighted deep economic and security bonds, driven by Saudi investments in Trump-linked ventures, and prompted a lone appeal from Khashoggi’s widow for justice and the return of her husband’s body.

articles.title: Judge rejects ‘racially gerrymandered’ maps in Texas that gave Republicans extra districts
articles.trailText: Federal judge instructed state to use older maps, with Republicans likely to appeal decision
articles.summary: A federal judges panel led by Judge Jeffrey Brown issued a preliminary injunction blocking Texas’s mid-decade 2025 congressional maps—five new GOP seats—as likely racially gerrymandered. Plaintiffs including LULAC showed lawmakers targeted majority-nonwhite “coalition districts” after a Justice Department letter by Harmeet Dhillon reframed redistricting around race under Trump administration pressure. The court ordered use of the 2021 maps for the 2026 midterms. Texas Republicans plan to appeal, mirroring national GOP efforts to reshape districts for partisan advantage.

articles.title: US perpetrators must face ‘same consequences’ as Epstein’s UK associates, congressman says
articles.trailText: Thomas Massie urged accountability amid House vote and renewed calls for former prince Andrew to testify
articles.summary: Rep. Thomas Massie (R-Ky.), flanked by survivors and Rep. Ro Khanna (D-Calif.), pressed for US perpetrators tied to Jeffrey Epstein to face “the same kind of consequences” as Prince Andrew and ex-ambassador Peter Mandelson in the UK. They led a bipartisan push for a House vote to fully release Justice Dept. files; the bill passed after GOP softening from Trump. Khanna urged Andrew to testify at the House oversight inquiry following his title-stripping by King Charles, while Dem. Rep. Suhas Subramanyam warned Andrew won’t evade scrutiny as more documents emerge.

articles.title: Texas governor Abbott designates Cair and Muslim Brotherhood terrorist groups
articles.trailText: Greg Abbott’s move heightens the clash with Muslim groups and usurps federal authority
articles.summary: Texas Gov. Greg Abbott unilaterally designated the Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR) and the Muslim Brotherhood as “foreign terrorist organizations,” barring them from acquiring Texas real property and authorizing state AG lawsuits against affiliates. The move sharpens Abbott’s clash with Muslim communities and oversteps federal authority—only the U.S. Secretary of State can list terrorist groups—and carries no federal immigration, asset-freeze or material-support penalties. Abbott, eyeing reelection, accused them of backing terrorism, while CAIR called it anti-Muslim political posturing. This follows state probes of Epic City, a planned Muslim development Abbott brands a “sharia compound.”

articles.title: Trump faces criticism for referring to female Bloomberg reporter as ‘piggy’
articles.trailText: Critics accuse the US president of trying to ‘shut women journalists up’ with ‘demeaning language’
articles.summary: Donald Trump dubbed Bloomberg’s White House correspondent Catherine Lucey “piggy” during a Nov. 14 Air Force One gaggle when she pressed him on the Jeffrey Epstein file release, prompting outrage from CNN’s Jake Tapper, ex-Fox anchor Gretchen Carlson and other press advocates. Critics point to Trump’s pattern of gendered insults against women journalists, citing past attacks on Alicia Machado and April Ryan. A Bloomberg spokesperson defended Lucey’s question as vital public service, while a White House official blamed her conduct without evidence. The International Women’s Media Foundation warned such language chills press freedom.

articles.title: Surgeons reattach 10-year-old girl’s hand nearly lost in Florida shark attack
articles.trailText: Leah Lendel was bitten by a bull shark as she was snorkeling with her family from a beach in Boca Grande
articles.summary: Ten-year-old Leah Lendel’s right hand was nearly severed by a 9ft bull shark while snorkeling off Boca Grande, Florida. Construction workers applied a tourniquet and wrapped the wound until first responders arrived. Airlifted to Tampa General Hospital, surgeons spent six hours reattaching her hand—harvesting leg arteries and repairing tendons. Leah moved two fingers within 24 hours and has regained sensation, now undergoing intensive therapy and even knitting Barbie outfits. A GoFundMe for medical bills neared $60,000. Shark attacks remain rare: 47 unprovoked bites globally in 2024, 14 in Florida.

articles.title: Mass federal immigration sweeps expand to North Carolina’s capital city
articles.trailText: Raleigh’s mayor says border patrol and ICE are in city as state’s Democratic governor criticizes federal operations
articles.summary: Federal authorities extended mass immigration sweeps to Raleigh after arresting over 100 people in Charlotte, prompting Mayor Janet Cowell to confirm CBP and ICE presence but decline local police participation in arrests. Gov. Josh Stein, critical of the “Charlotte’s Web” operation, urged residents to document abuses and decried targeting based on skin color. DHS reported 130+ arrests in Charlotte, including 44 of its “worst of the worst,” amid viral footage of agents breaking car windows. Raleigh’s crime rate has fallen, Cowell noted. Meanwhile, in Tennessee, a judge temporarily blocked Gov. Bill Lee’s deployment of the National Guard in support of Trump’s crackdown pending appeal.

articles.title: Workers at US landscape company sue Trump ally over human-trafficking raid
articles.trailText: Employees at the Utah company Rubicon are filing a lawsuit against former state attorney general Sean Reyes
articles.summary: Employees of Rubicon, a Utah landscaping firm, filed a federal suit against ex-Attorney General Sean Reyes and his office, alleging they orchestrated a politically motivated, televised human-trafficking raid in Nov. 2023 using false affidavits. Workers say the bogus charges—later dismissed by a judge—crushed business, halving contracts, triggering four layoff rounds, salary cuts and loss of bonuses. The lawsuit contends Reyes, a Trump ally with Operation Underground Railroad ties under audit, aimed to inflate trafficking claims for political gain. Plaintiffs seek compensation and a record correction to restore trust after alleged reputational and financial harm.

articles.title: Can mountain lions make a comeback in the US north-east? One group hopes so
articles.trailText: Reintroducing the apex predator would control deer populations, maintaining healthy ecosystems and bolstering biodiversity, rewilding group says
articles.summary: Last summer an unconfirmed mountain lion photograph in South Burlington, Vermont, sparked renewed interest in restoring the apex predator, extinct in New England since 1881. Mighty Earth’s Bring Catamounts Home affiliate reports a 12-to-1 pro-reintroduction survey response and highlights suitable habitats from New York to Michigan, backed by trail-cam and viral video sightings. Reintroducing catamounts could regulate booming deer populations, enhance biodiversity, cut Lyme disease and deer-vehicle collisions. Its “catamount conversations” engage Vermonters on coexistence and livestock concerns. State-led recovery studies could proceed without federal approval, laying groundwork for broader rewilding of wolves, elk and bison.

articles.title: First Thing: ‘They have total impunity’ – West Bank settler violence rises after Gaza ceasefire
articles.trailText: UN logs 260 attacks in October alone, its highest monthly tally. Plus, protests in North Carolina’s Charlotte after aggressive immigration arrests
articles.summary: West Bank settler violence surges as Palestinian olive harvest faces daily raids, with UN logging a record 260 attacks in October amid the Gaza ceasefire. The UN Security Council backed Trump’s Gaza peace proposals—with China and Russia abstaining. In Charlotte, protests flare after federal immigration arrests of 130+ people. Congress readies a vote to release new Epstein documents following Trump’s sudden reversal. Elsewhere, Poland’s PM blames Russia for a railway sabotage, Nestlé faces infant formula sugar claims, a judge finds misconduct in Comey charges, Bangladesh’s ex-PM is sentenced to death, and rare ginkgo-toothed beaked whales thrill scientists.

articles.title: Trump says US will sell F-35 stealth jets to Saudis as Prince Mohammed visits
articles.trailText: Kingdom’s de facto ruler to arrive on first White House trip since killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi in 2018
articles.summary: On his first White House visit by Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman since the CIA-linked 2018 Jamal Khashoggi killing, President Trump is set to sell Lockheed Martin F-35 stealth jets to Riyadh. Costing $80–110 million each, the deal would be the first F-35 transfer to a Middle Eastern state beyond Israel and part of wider arms and $billions AI-infrastructure pacts to cement a US-Saudi alliance against Iran. Melania Trump will host a state dinner. Khashoggi’s widow called the trip painful, while pro-Israel Republicans warn it could erode Israel’s qualitative military edge.

articles.title: Florida workers with criminal records trapped by temp agencies, report finds
articles.trailText: Former prisoners feel ‘disposable’ after being driven to accept jobs that often pay lower wages and have no benefits
articles.summary: New report from non-profit Beyond the Bars finds Florida workers with criminal records are channeled into temp agencies paying $3–$6.50 less per hour, costing $7K–$13K annually, with no benefits. Over 70% of ex-prisoners use temp firms within three years; 57% fail to find minimum-wage full-time jobs within a year. Temp agencies profit from placement fees, assume liabilities, and circumvent insurance hikes by shuttering operations. Surveys reveal widespread wage theft, injuries, self-paid healthcare and retaliation. Advocates demand probation reform, stricter temp agency regulations, training programs and union access.

articles.title: Death threats and accusations: the professor targeted by the US far right
articles.trailText: Mark Bray has become one of the highest-profile people caught up in Donald Trump’s efforts to target Antifa
articles.summary: Rutgers professor Mark Bray, author of 'Antifa: The Anti-Fascist Handbook', faced death threats and accusations after Trump’s administration targeted the decentralized Antifa movement—designating it a domestic terrorist organization and planning foreign designations. Branded a “domestic terrorist professor” by right-wing influencers, Bray’s flight to Spain with his family was cancelled in a politically motivated move. Under threat, he now teaches remotely abroad. U.S. agents interrogated him over donations to an anti-fascist legal fund. Bray calls the campaign a top-down effort to suppress dissent using a nebulous “bogeyman.”

articles.title: ‘Deeply ashamed’ Larry Summers steps back from public life over Epstein links
articles.trailText: Former treasury secretary steps away to ‘rebuild trust’ after severe backlash but will continue teaching Harvard classes
articles.summary: Harvard professor and ex-Treasury secretary Larry Summers, reeling from emails with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein who called himself his “wing man,” has announced he’ll step back from public commitments while still teaching at Harvard to “rebuild trust.” He expressed deep regret, relinquished a senior fellowship at the Center for American Progress, and faces bipartisan calls—from Senator Elizabeth Warren to think tanks and institutions—to cut all ties. A Trump-ordered DOJ inquiry has begun, and Summers remains on various boards despite mounting criticism over his judgment and past ties to Epstein.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: in a U-turn, president tells Republicans to vote to release Epstein files
articles.trailText: Donald Trump says ‘we have nothing to hide’ as Maga suspicions grow over files – key US politics stories from Monday 17 November at a glance
articles.summary: President Donald Trump unexpectedly urged House Republicans to vote to release FBI and DoJ files on Jeffrey Epstein, insisting ‘we have nothing to hide’ and dismissing Democratic allegations as a ‘hoax’. This U-turn follows GOP releases of 20,000+ pages and comes ahead of a likely vote this week. Other developments: UN Security Council backed Trump’s Gaza peace initiative; US to label Venezuela’s Cartel de los Soles a terrorist group; a judge found government misconduct in the Comey case; SCOTUS agreed to hear challenges to the asylum metering policy; and federal raids in Charlotte netted 81 immigrants.

articles.title: Why are US border agents in Charlotte, and are they allowed to operate there?
articles.trailText: Border patrol is at the center of the immigration crackdown in North Carolina – what does US law say about their presence?
articles.summary: In Operation Charlotte’s Web, CBP’s hard-line chief Greg Bovino deployed border patrol agents to Charlotte, conducting raids near churches, apartments and stores that netted over 100 arrests and sparked protests. Under a 1946 law, agents can operate warrantlessly within 100 miles of any international land border or coastline, enjoying broader search and checkpoint powers; beyond that zone—as Charlotte lies—they must meet the same constitutional standards as local police, requiring reasonable suspicion or probable cause. Critics argue aggressive tactics familiar in Los Angeles and Chicago risk civil-rights violations, while DHS insists nationwide jurisdiction is essential to curb evasion at all entry points.

articles.title: Child among seven dead after atmospheric river storm drenches California
articles.trailText: Lingering thunderstorms pose risk of mudslides in areas around Los Angeles recently ravaged by wildfires
articles.summary: An atmospheric river storm swept California last week, killing at least seven people, including a seven-year-old girl and her father swept into 20ft waves on a state beach, a 71-year-old motorist in Sutter County, and four migrants whose boat capsized off San Diego. San Francisco to southern California saw record November rainfall—downtown Los Angeles surpassed its 1985 mark, coastal Santa Barbara received over 4 inches, and the Sierra Nevada drew more than a foot of snow. Lingering thunderstorms threaten mudslides in recently burned LA areas, with rain through Tuesday and another storm due Thursday. Scientists warn warming oceans are intensifying such moisture flows, heightening flood risks.

articles.title: Trump has ‘blurred’ line between military and politics, ex-officers warn
articles.trailText: Former leaders’ report cautions against politicizing armed forces as national guard deployments raise tensions in US
articles.summary: Six former service secretaries and retired four-star officers issued The Perils of Politicizing the US Military, warning that the Trump administration’s use of National Guard troops for protest control and immigration enforcement—and the firing of senior commanders and advisers under Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth—has muddied the military’s apolitical role, undermined morale, recruitment and public trust. Citing deployments in Portland, Washington DC and Chicago, the report urges Congress to require clear justification, post-action reviews and legislative approval for domestic troop movements and high-level personnel changes.

articles.title: Acting Fema head resigns after furor over handling of deadly Texas flooding
articles.trailText: Trump administration official confirms David Richardson will depart agency after six months in role
articles.summary: David Richardson, who led FEMA as acting administrator for six months, abruptly resigned after facing backlash over a slow response to deadly Texas flash floods and a gaffe claiming ignorance of hurricane season. His departure, the second top FEMA exit since May, comes amid President Trump’s drive to slash the agency. DHS will appoint FEMA chief of staff Karen Evans on December 1 to implement a sweeping White House–mandated overhaul.

articles.title: Protests in Charlotte as aggressive immigration arrests continue
articles.trailText: North Carolina governor says immigration crackdown ‘stoking fear’ as officials say at least 130 people detained
articles.summary: Federal ICE and CBP agents conducted “Charlotte’s Web” arrests over the weekend in Charlotte, detaining 130+ people—including some US citizens—sparking protests and warnings from Gov. Josh Stein and Mayor Vi Lyles that the paramilitary raids stoke fear and racial profiling. Local Muslim-American groups cautioned residents at mosques, while GOP leaders praised enforcement amid sanctuary policy conflicts. DHS asserts many arrestees had criminal records but provided no conviction data. Business owners reported closures as communities grapple with xenophobia claims and legal challenges to sanctuary laws.

articles.title: What are the Jeffrey Epstein files, and will more be released?
articles.trailText: President reverses course and calls for House vote to force release of further documents – what might they reveal?
articles.summary: Congress has released over 20,000 emails and other materials from federal Epstein probes, revealing communications with powerful figures including Donald Trump. After resisting, Trump now urges a House vote to compel DOJ to unseal further files. DOJ says it holds 300+GB of data—flight logs, images, videos, grand jury transcripts—much sealed to protect 1,000+ victims. No evidence of a “client list” or blackmail scheme was found. Republicans are divided; Democrats cite Trump’s reversal as hypocrisy. Pending releases could clarify Epstein’s finances, associates and unresolved questions on his 2019 jailhouse death.

articles.title: Trump signals he may soon meet with political adversary Zohran Mamdani
articles.trailText: US president said ‘we���ll work something out’ in reference to meeting with the New York City mayor-elect
articles.summary: Donald Trump signaled he may meet with new NYC mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani in Washington, saying “we’ll work something out” despite trading sharp words. Mamdani confirmed reaching out to the White House to tackle the city’s affordability crisis for 8.5 million residents. During the campaign Trump called him a “communist lunatic,” threatened to strip his citizenship and pull federal funds. Mamdani says he’ll still collaborate if it lowers New Yorkers’ cost of living. He’ll be sworn in as the 111th mayor on Jan 1.

articles.title: Former prince Andrew accused of ‘hiding’ from US House’s Epstein inquiry
articles.trailText: Suhas Subramanyam, a member of the oversight panel, had asked Mountbatten-Windsor to sit for deposition
articles.summary: House oversight panelist Suhas Subramanyam accused Prince Andrew of evading a deposition request in the US investigation into Jeffrey Epstein’s case. Democrats asked Mountbatten-Windsor to testify about his ties to Epstein after documents showed extended contact; he hasn’t responded. With Republicans controlling the House, Subramanyam admits he can’t subpoena the foreign royal but vows to pursue leads from associates and evidence from 20,000+ emails. Triggered by a bipartisan petition and Trump’s late support, the House vote this week on forcing release of Epstein-related government files is expected to pass narrowly but faces an uncertain Senate fate.

articles.title: New international student enrollments in US plunge this year, data shows
articles.trailText: Enrollment fell 17%, the largest drop in a decade aside from the pandemic, amid Trump’s immigration crackdown
articles.summary: IIE data shows new international student enrollments in US colleges fell 17% in 2025/26 — the steepest decline in a decade outside COVID — amid Trump’s aggressive immigration crackdown. Visa delays and denials topped concerns for 96% of institutions; 67% said students felt unwelcome, 64% cited the broader political environment. Over half of colleges reported drops, 27% deemed them substantial. Nafsa warns this jeopardizes the $42.9 billion annual contribution and 355,000 jobs supported by 1.2 million international students, urging proactive policy to retain global talent.

articles.title: Top Democrat accuses Trump of ‘panicking’ after U-turn on Epstein files vote
articles.trailText: US president says he backs efforts to release documents related to late sex offender because ‘we have nothing to hide’
articles.summary: President Trump reversed course, urging House Republicans to vote to release DOJ files on Jeffrey Epstein, declaring “we have nothing to hide” after facing bipartisan pressure and a looming vote to force disclosure. Top Democrat Robert Garcia accused Trump of panicking and obstructing justice, while survivors and bipartisan lawmakers led by Thomas Massie and Ro Khanna rallied for transparency via the Epstein Files Transparency Act. The House is set to vote this week amid GOP fractures, as advocates demand full disclosure from Epstein’s estate and FBI records.

articles.title: US judge finds evidence of ‘government misconduct’ in federal case against Comey
articles.trailText: Judge ruled DoJ engaged in ‘profound investigative missteps’ on way to indicting the former FBI director
articles.summary: Magistrate Judge William Fitzpatrick found the DOJ engaged in a “disturbing pattern of profound investigative missteps” in charging former FBI Director James Comey with lying to Congress in 2020. He ordered prosecutors to turn over all grand jury materials, citing misstatements of law, use of potentially privileged communications, transcript irregularities and an “indict first, investigate later” approach under prosecutor Lindsey Halligan—appointed days earlier with no prior experience. Comey, who pleaded not guilty, argues the case is a vindictive prosecution tied to Trump and challenges Halligan’s appointment and the indictment’s legality.

articles.title: Trump’s reversal with call to release Epstein files reveals inability to control Maga allies
articles.trailText: President attempts to save face politically after pressuring Republicans to back off their pushes to release files
articles.summary: Trump abruptly reversed course and urged House Republicans to release Jeffrey Epstein files after failing to stop a vote driven by his MAGA base. Despite last week’s pressure on GOP lawmakers like Lauren Boebert and Nancy Mace, enough members forced a vote to compel the Justice Department to disclose sealed documents, though Senate approval still requires 13 Republicans to join all Democrats. Partial leaks include messages implicating Trump, Steve Bannon and figures such as Larry Summers and Michael Wolff. The rebellion peaked when Marjorie Taylor Greene broke ranks, prompting Trump to brand her a “traitor” and reveal his waning control over hard-right allies.

articles.title: US will label supposed Venezuelan drug cartel ‘headed by Maduro’ as terrorist organization
articles.trailText: Experts believe decision is designed to pressure Venezuela’s leader into stepping down with threat of military force
articles.summary: US to designate alleged Venezuelan cartel 'Cartel de los Soles', purportedly led by Nicolás Maduro, as foreign terrorist organization, effective November 24, announced by Secretary of State Marco Rubio. Move seeks to pressure Maduro via sanctions and military threat. Trump gave mixed messages, hinting at Maduro talks and not ruling out US troops or strikes in Mexico to halt trafficking. The US deployed the USS Gerald R. Ford carrier, 15,000 personnel, and offered $50m reward for Maduro’s arrest. Experts call the 'Cartel de los Soles' a symbolic label for military-backed smuggling, not a structured cartel.

articles.title: First Thing: Trump tells Republicans to vote to release Epstein files, in reversal of previous stance
articles.trailText: The US president says he backs lawmakers’ efforts to release the files before an expected House vote this week. Plus: is there a dark side to gratitude?
articles.summary: President Donald Trump has urged House Republicans on his Truth Social platform to vote to release Department of Justice files related to the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, reversing his earlier resistance. Citing Speaker Mike Johnson’s view that the vote would quash allegations tying Trump to Epstein, he stated “we have nothing to hide.” The unexpected U-turn aims to neutralise MAGA suspicions of elite cover-ups. Despite softening on Epstein, Trump nonetheless doubled down on attacks against Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, who has called for the files’ release and hopes for reconciliation.

articles.title: Charlotte, North Carolina reels as 81 people arrested in immigration raids
articles.trailText: Thriving business districts in North Carolina city now at a ‘standstill’ after at least 81 were arrested over the weekend
articles.summary: Federal CBP agents conducted Operation Charlotte’s Web over the weekend, arresting at least 81 people across immigrant neighborhoods and business districts in Charlotte, NC, halting operations at Manolo’s Bakery and other local shops. Social media footage captured agents chasing and detaining individuals—including a US citizen and a 16-year-old worker—spurring protests and widespread fear among Latino residents. State leaders and the incoming city council member condemned the unprecedented border-patrol presence, while Mecklenburg County’s sheriff refused cooperation. Advocacy groups called it the largest single-day immigrant arrest in state history, organizing hotlines, legal trainings, and community patrols as businesses and families brace for continued raids.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Another Republican challenges Trump over Epstein files
articles.trailText: Thomas Massie has criticized Trump for ordering attorney general Pam Bondi to examine Democrats with ties to Epstein – key US politics stories from 16 November at a glance
articles.summary: Republican congressman Thomas Massie and Democrat Ro Khanna reignited a bipartisan push to unseal all government files on Jeffrey Epstein, as Massie accused Trump’s order for AG Pam Bondi to probe Democrats with Epstein ties of being a ‘smokescreen’ to stall disclosure. Georgia GOP congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene, labeled a ‘traitor’ by Trump, called his comments hurtful yet signaled a willingness to reconcile. Meanwhile, 17 transgender Air Force veterans sued over denied pensions; US Southern Command sank an alleged drug boat, killing three; Charlotte saw increased border-patrol arrests; and the White House prioritized reshoring rare-earth mining.

articles.title: Trump’s investigation into Epstein ties to political foes may be ‘smokescreen’, Republican says
articles.trailText: Thomas Massie says move could be Trump’s ‘last-ditch effort’ to keep Epstein files from becoming public
articles.summary: Republican Rep. Thomas Massie and Democrat Ro Khanna accuse Trump of using a fresh DOJ probe into Democratic ties to Jeffrey Epstein as a ‘smokescreen’ to block full public release of federal files on the late sex offender. Massie warns opening new investigations shields documents under active inquiry and urges over 100 House Republicans to vote for disclosure before an upcoming floor vote, or risk being labeled as protecting pedophiles. Khanna emphasizes justice for survivors, and Senate leaders signal likely gridlock despite Speaker Johnson’s call to “take this weapon” away from Democrats. Epstein died in 2019; Ghislaine Maxwell is imprisoned.

articles.title: Dozens reportedly arrested in Charlotte, North Carolina, amid immigration crackdown
articles.trailText: Trump administration has made Democratic-led city its latest target despite fierce objections from local leaders
articles.summary: Federal agents under “Operation Charlotte’s Web” arrested 81 people in Charlotte on Nov. 16, targeting alleged “criminal illegal aliens” near churches, apartments and businesses over five hours, CBP said. The Trump administration’s crackdown sparked closures and fear in the 950,000-resident city, with Latino families skipping work, school and medical appointments. Mayor Vi Lyles, county commission chair Mark Jerrell and school board chair Stephanie Sneed decried the raids as unnecessary and harmful. Activists handed out whistles to alert residents of ICE presence. Advocacy groups like Siembra NC and Camino report legal and emotional distress, noting past single-day arrests never exceeded 30 in North Carolina.

articles.title: Trans air force members sue Trump administration over denied pension
articles.trailText: Complaint slams government’s actions as ‘unlawful and invalid’ after air force revoked early retirement benefits
articles.summary: Seventeen transgender Air Force members sued the Trump administration in federal court after the Air Force revoked their early retirement orders—and with them $1–2 million in lifetime pension and TRICARE benefits—despite 15–18 years of service. Named plaintiffs include Logan Ireland and Ashley Davis; advocacy group GLAD Law labels the rescission “unlawful and invalid” under official retirement rules. The suit seeks reinstatement of retirement orders, corrected military records, damages and attorneys’ fees. It follows broader Pentagon efforts to exclude and discharge transgender troops and comes after a judge blocked the administration’s military-service ban.

articles.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene says Trump’s remarks hurtful but hopes they can make up
articles.trailText: Congresswoman, a longtime Trump ally, pushes back against president’s remarks labeling her a traitor and a lunatic
articles.summary: Georgia congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene criticized ex-president Donald Trump’s recent labeling of her as a “traitor” and “lunatic” as “hurtful” and dangerous for inciting threats against her. In her first post-endorsement withdrawal interview, she defended her MAGA record, demanded full release of Jeffrey Epstein files, and urged transparency for survivors. She acknowledged past toxic rhetoric, apologized, called for an end to infighting, and outlined policy disagreements on inflation and immigration. A practicing Christian, she said she hopes to reconcile with Trump through forgiveness.

articles.title: The banality of evil: how Epstein’s powerful friends normalised him
articles.trailText: Long after his conviction for sexual offences, businessmen, academics, journalists, politicians and royals sought his ear
articles.summary: Emails released by Congress detail how Jeffrey Epstein, even after his 2008 sex-crimes conviction, remained normalized and sought after by elites���from politicians and royalty to Silicon Valley figures and academics. Between 2009 and 2019, Epstein advised Steve Bannon, Larry Summers, Lawrence Krauss and others on politics, scandal management and introductions, while royals like Prince Andrew and backers including Arianna Huffington and Peter Thiel maintained contact. The exchanges reveal a system where wealth and influence insulated Epstein from accountability, exposing power’s indifference to his crimes.

articles.title: A puppy and unlimited toilet paper? Legal experts say Ghislaine Maxwell’s alleged prison life is uncommon
articles.trailText: Maxwell is serving a 20-year sentence for her role in Jeffrey Epstein’s sex-trafficking of teen girls – and her treatment is prompting speculation
articles.summary: Ghislaine Maxwell’s transfer to low-security FPC Bryan this summer has drawn scrutiny over alleged perks: unlimited toilet paper, custom meals, private visiting area stocked with snacks and even temporary access to a puppy. A Nov. 9 letter from Rep. Jamie Raskin, citing whistleblowers, demands answers on whether the Trump administration orchestrated special treatment or a commutation bid. Legal experts call such privileges “uncommon,” suggesting a quid pro quo for information. The Bureau of Prisons says it investigates misconduct, while Maxwell denies seeking clemency.

articles.title: Scrutiny grows over LA fire origins after bombshell report: ‘Our Pearl Harbor moment’
articles.trailText: Reports that fire crews were ordered to leave original site of blaze prompt tough questions for city and LAFD leaders
articles.summary: Reports reveal that LAFD battalion chief ordered crews to abandon the 8-acre Lachman fire despite visible smoldering, days before it reignited as the deadly Palisades fire, killing 12 and destroying 6,800+ structures. Questions swirl over missing details in the 70-page after-action report and delayed internal awareness. Mayor Karen Bass has tasked interim chief Ronnie Villanueva (soon to be Jamie Moore) with an independent probe, backed by critics like Zev Yaroslavsky calling it a “Pearl Harbor moment,” urging reforms in pre-deployment, interagency coordination and communications. A suspect faces federal arson charges.

articles.title: It’s all gravy: Thanksgiving air traffic to be normal after US government reopens
articles.trailText: Experts say air traffic controllers quickly returning to work, with promise of full back pay, and even $10,000 bonus
articles.summary: After a 35-day shutdown ended Nov. 16, essential air traffic controllers began returning to duty with 70% back pay due within 48 hours and a $10,000 bonus (with TSA staff similarly rewarded). Flight cancellations dropped from 7% to 3.5%, delays shrank, and staffing triggers fell from 81 to 4, prompting the FAA to freeze additional cuts at 6% at 40 major airports. Experts say Thanksgiving travel should proceed normally, though controller shortages (3,800 below target) and pilot duty limits—compounded by weather—could still pose risks. Full back pay is set within a week, but rebuilding controller ranks may take years.

articles.title: ‘I was just going to school’: legacy of New Orleans’ other desegregation pioneers
articles.trailText: Leona Tate has built a center at the former school she and her two six-year-old friends braved angry crowds to attend – the same day as Ruby Bridges’ better-known experience
articles.summary: In November 1960, six-year-olds Gail Etienne, Leona Tate and Tessie Prevost—escorted by federal marshals—integrated McDonogh 19 in New Orleans amid hostile crowds, isolation and makeshift classrooms. Though their story was eclipsed by Ruby Bridges, the trio forged a lifelong bond. Decades later Tate bought and restored the storm-damaged school as the TEP Center, a museum, community space and senior housing complex honoring civil-rights pioneers. In 2022 they formed New Orleans Four LLC to correct history and ensure their sacrifice educates future generations.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Marjorie Taylor Greene raises fears for her safety as row with Donald Trump escalates
articles.trailText: President’s one-time ally says she has been contacted by private security firms after denunciation by president. Key US politics stories from Saturday 15 November at a glance
articles.summary: Marjorie Taylor Greene says private security firms warned her she faces threats after Donald Trump withdrew his endorsement amid clashes over Israel aid, the government shutdown and release of Epstein files, prompting mutual denunciations and a brewing primary challenge. Separately, newly disclosed texts show Steve Bannon advising Jeffrey Epstein on legal strategy, ICE agents raided a Charlotte church, Democratic minister Justin Douglas enters the midterms to mobilize white Christian voters, the Justice Department updated online pardon signatures, Trump threatened tariffs on Thailand, and NYC mayor-elect Mamdani tapped Lina Khan for his transition team.

articles.title: Alice Wong, ‘luminary’ writer and disability rights activist, dies aged 51
articles.trailText: Daughter of immigrants advocated for people with disabilities to have full autonomy over their lives
articles.summary: Alice Wong, a writer and disability rights luminary, died at 51 in San Francisco from an infection. Born to Hong Kong immigrants with muscular dystrophy, Wong used a powered wheelchair and breathing device, describing herself as a “disabled cyborg.” She chronicled her experiences of ableism, queer and immigrant discrimination in her 2022 memoir Year of the Tiger. In 2014 she founded the Disability Visibility Project to collect and publish disabled people’s stories, culminating in anthologies Disability Visibility and Disability Intimacy. A 2024 MacArthur Fellow, she championed autonomy and self-advocacy to resist systemic ableism in marginalized disabled communities.

articles.title: Federal immigration officers begin sweep in Charlotte, North Carolina
articles.trailText: Local reports say targets include church parishioners doing yard work and workers hanging Christmas lights
articles.summary: Federal immigration agents launched a sweep in Charlotte, N.C., targeting predominantly Latino residents. Masked officers arrested a churchgoer doing yard work without showing ID or asking questions, while Christmas-light installers were briefly questioned. Honduran-born U.S. citizen Willy Aceituno says agents forced him from his car and broke his window before accepting his documents. DHS framed the operation as public-safety enforcement, but Mayor Vi Lyles, Gov. Josh Stein, local council members and nonprofits condemned it as fear-mongering and a rights violation. Mecklenburg GOP chair Kyle Kirby defended the raids as border security. The action follows similar sweeps in major U.S. cities.

articles.title: Suspect arrested in shooting death of beloved Oakland football coach
articles.trailText: Cedric Irving Jr, 27, is alumnus of high school where John Beam taught before gaining fame on Netflix’s Last Change U
articles.summary: Police arrested 27-year-old Cedric Irving Jr., a Skyline High alumnus, at San Leandro BART station before dawn for the targeted killing of John Beam, the 66-year-old Oakland football coach fatally shot Thursday at Laney College’s field house. Beam, who gained national recognition on Netflix’s Last Chance U, had warned campus officials a day earlier about security lapses and urged reinstatement of armed guards. Oakland acting police chief James Beere said Beam and Irving were acquainted but not close, and that the suspect came to campus “for a specific reason.” Beam, who won 15 Oakland Athletic League titles at Skyline and led Laney’s program before becoming athletic director, died the following day, prompting tributes across scholastic and pro sports communities.

articles.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene says she’s had ‘warnings for my safety’ after posts by Trump
articles.trailText: One-time Maga loyalist diverges from Trump on issues including Epstein, so US president has withdrawn support
articles.summary: After Donald Trump withdrew his endorsement, Marjorie Taylor Greene says private security firms have warned her about threats fueled by the former president’s rhetoric. Greene accuses Trump of radicalizing paid trolls and likens her fears to those of Epstein victims as she presses for full release of Jeffrey Epstein documents. Her break with Trump spans disagreements over Israel aid, government shutdowns and cost-of-living votes. Trump labels her a “ranting lunatic” and vows to support a primary challenger if one emerges.

articles.title: Salt Lake City declines to charge anti-child-trafficking activist with sexual assault
articles.trailText: District attorney cites ‘insufficient admissible evidence’ against Tim Ballard in connection with allegations
articles.summary: Salt Lake City DA Sim Gill announced no charges will be filed against anti-child-trafficking activist Tim Ballard, founder of Operation Underground Railroad and the subject of the film Sound of Freedom, citing insufficient admissible evidence in two sexual assault lawsuits. Plaintiffs allege Ballard used a “couples ruse” to coerce female staff during rescue missions; one suit was dismissed with appeal pending, the other remains active. Ballard, who resigned amid the allegations, denies wrongdoing and seeks action against false accusers.

articles.title: ‘Trump is inconsistent with Christian principles’: why the Democratic party is seeing a rise of white clergy candidates
articles.trailText: From Texas and Iowa to Arkansas, faith leaders are wading into politics to counter the rise of Christian nationalism
articles.summary: Across Texas, Iowa, Arkansas and Pennsylvania, around 30 white Christian clergy—pastors, seminary students and other faith leaders—are running as Democrats in the 2026 midterms to counter Christian nationalism and reconnect the party with white working-class churchgoers. Figures like former Liberty grad Justin Douglas in PA’s 10th, Texas state rep James Talarico, Iowa pastor-senator Sarah Trone Garriott and Arkansas pastor Robb Ryerse challenge GOP incumbents, arguing Trump’s faith rhetoric is sacrilegious and manipulative. Progressive group Vote Common Good supports these candidates in navigating partisan divides and mobilizing faith-based voters.

articles.title: Questions arise over strikingly similar signatures by Trump on recent pardons
articles.trailText: Seemingly identical signatures appeared on clemency orders, which White House blamed on technical error
articles.summary: Online commenters flagged identical versions of Trump’s signature on seven pardons granted Nov. 7—including Darryl Strawberry, Glen Casada and Michael McMahon—leading the DOJ to replace them on its website. Officials cited a “technical error” and staffing issues for uploading one signature repeatedly, while the White House accused media of ignoring Biden’s autopen pardons. Handwriting experts note no two genuine signatures match exactly, though legal scholars say autopen use doesn’t invalidate clemency. The saga fuels Republicans’ bid to undermine Biden’s autopen, even as Trump issues further controversial pardons, such as to Capitol rioter Dan Wilson.

articles.title: Mamdani’s appointment of Lina Khan a warning to private equity, experts say
articles.trailText: Ex-FTC chair was among first to go after practice of folding local firms into larger ones leading to higher prices
articles.summary: Mamdani’s pick of Lina Khan, former FTC chair known for challenging private equity roll-ups in healthcare and tech, signals NYC’s intent to curb rent hikes and monopolies. Experts say Khan’s track record—suits against US Anesthesia Partners, scrutiny of mobile home park investors and big-tech mergers—may deter aggressive PE tactics in housing and health. Though advisory-only, she could push municipal disclosure rules on clinic acquisitions and strengthen public hospitals to counter PE-backed firms. Observers view the appointment as a populist shift among younger Democrats challenging Wall Street’s grip on local markets.

articles.title: Turmoil and tensions at FDA after dramatic exit of top drug regulator
articles.trailText: Scramble to find replacement for George Tidmarsh shines light on dysfunction at US regulatory agency
articles.summary: After George Tidmarsh’s sudden November resignation amid retaliation allegations and clashes over a new "Commissioner’s National Priority Voucher" rapid-approval program, the FDA’s CDER director post remains vacant. HHS approached oncology veteran Richard Pazdur, who declined, exposing deep rifts between CDER and CBER chiefs—particularly Vinay Prasad—and sparking a desperate internal search. Experts warn such repeated upheavals—from Prasad’s brief July firing and return—threaten the FDA’s stability, predictability and credibility in drug review, fueling industry unease and public distrust.

articles.title: Steve Bannon advised Jeffrey Epstein for years on how to rehab his reputation, texts show
articles.trailText: Pair devised responses to public outrage about Epstein’s criminal history, his treatment by the justice system and his friendships with powerful people
articles.summary: Between June 2018 and June 2019 hundreds of text messages between ex-White House strategist Steve Bannon and convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein reveal Bannon crafting PR and legal strategies to deflect scrutiny of Epstein’s underage sex trafficking, lenient plea deal and powerful connections. They discussed framing the scandal as a “sophisticated op,” coordinating media intercepts, hiring crisis communications, producing a documentary, attacking victims, and shaping narratives in outlets from Fox News to Zero Hedge. These exchanges also intersected with efforts to bolster Trump’s populist agenda and influence Kavanaugh’s confirmation hearings.

articles.title: Epstein survivor pushes for release of files in wake of new emails: ‘It will bring us closure’
articles.trailText: Marina Lacerda, 37, recounts the abuse she experienced and what inspired her to speak publicly amid new revelations
articles.summary: Marina Lacerda, once known as “Minor Victim-1,” woke to news House Republicans released thousands of Epstein documents and urged President Trump—implicated in new emails—to free all files. A key 2019 witness, Lacerda recounts being groomed at 14, raped until 17, coerced into recruiting other teens and threatened over her immigration status while Epstein boasted of owning governments. Inspired by Virginia Giuffre’s legacy, she waived anonymity to demand full transparency, closure and accountability, decrying the political stalemate that stalls survivors and shields influential enablers.

articles.title: Trump says he will take legal action against BBC, despite its apology
articles.trailText: US president says he will sue the corporation for ��anywhere between a billion and $5bn’
articles.summary: Donald Trump announced he will sue the BBC for $1 billion to $5 billion despite its apology over a misleading 12-second edit of his January 6 “Save America” speech on Panorama. The row led to the resignations of BBC director-general Tim Davie and news chief Deborah Turness. The BBC, which has agreed not to rebroadcast the episode, rejected Trump’s damage claims, citing lack of UK harm. Trump plans to call UK PM Keir Starmer and pursue compensation.

articles.title: Trump ends support for Marjorie Taylor Greene amid growing Epstein feud
articles.trailText: President turns on ‘Wacky Marjorie’ after representative criticizes effort to block release of key Epstein documents
articles.summary: Donald Trump announced he was withdrawing his endorsement of Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.) on Truth Social, branding her ��Wacky Marjorie” and later a “disgrace,” after she called his effort to block Jeffrey Epstein files “insanely the wrong direction.” He pledged to back a primary challenger. Greene, once a staunch ally, has split with Trump on healthcare, rising costs, Ukraine aid, Gaza, sided with Democrats on subsidies and transparency and criticized party leaders during this week’s government shutdown.

articles.title: Epstein was texting US House member during 2019 hearing with Michael Cohen
articles.trailText: Newly revealed documents show sex offender messaged lawmaker, and may have influenced their questioning
articles.summary: Newly released documents from Jeffrey Epstein’s estate reveal he texted a member of Congress—most likely US Virgin Islands delegate Stacey Plaskett—during the February 2019 House oversight hearing with Michael Cohen. By matching message timestamps to hearing footage, transcripts suggest real-time coordination: Epstein prompted “RONA” about Rhona Graff and even commented on the rep’s chewing. Plaskett’s questions on Trump associates Allen Weisselberg and Graff echoed these texts. Part of 20,000+ pages disclosed this week, the messages and accompanying emails have Democrats arguing Trump may have known more about Epstein’s network, reigniting investigations into his ties.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Pam Bondi announces investigation into Trump’s adversaries’ ties to Jeffrey Epstein
articles.trailText: US attorney general names Jay Clayton as lead investigator, hours after direction from US president – key US politics stories from 14 November 2025
articles.summary: US attorney general Pam Bondi tapped former SEC chair Jay Clayton to probe Donald Trump’s political rivals and their ties to Jeffrey Epstein after a direct presidential order, reversing a July DOJ–FBI finding that no further inquiries were warranted. Trump has ramped up pressure on GOP lawmakers to block full Epstein file disclosures and called for investigations into Democrats including Bill Clinton, Larry Summers and Reid Hoffman. He also threatened a BBC lawsuit, cut food import tariffs, struck a Swiss tariff deal, backed U.S. military plans for a divided Gaza, and saw Georgia prosecutors revive the last criminal case against him.

articles.title: Coach featured in Netflix’s Last Chance U dies after Oakland campus shooting
articles.trailText: Mayor Barbara Lee calls John Beam ‘a man who dedicated himself to building up the young people of this city’
articles.summary: John Beam, longtime director of athletics at Oakland’s Laney College and former Last Chance U coach, died after being shot in a targeted attack on campus. Police arrested a known acquaintance, lifted the lockdown and said the motive was specific. Beam, who coached since 2004 and mentored multiple NFL players, retired from coaching in 2024. Mayor Barbara Lee and community leaders mourned and called for action against rising campus gun violence—his was the second Oakland school shooting in two days and part of a nationwide surge.

articles.title: California: powerful ‘atmospheric river’ storm prompts evacuation warnings
articles.trailText: Los Angeles, Santa Barbara and Ventura counties prepare for deluge and possible landslides this weekend
articles.summary: A powerful atmospheric river storm is sweeping into Southern California Friday through Sunday, dumping 2–6+ inches of rain in Los Angeles, Ventura and Santa Barbara counties. Areas scarred by recent wildfires face elevated flood and debris‐flow risks, prompting evacuation warnings around burn zones. Forecasters predict heavy river and creek flows, localized tornado‐capable thunderstorms, road closures and damage to infrastructure. The second surge Saturday night is expected to bring the most intense rainfall. Already, Tyler the Creator postponed his Dodgers Stadium gig and parks like Knott’s Berry Farm closed. While the rain will replenish reservoirs, it also threatens mudslides and flash floods.

articles.title: South Carolina executes man by firing squad, in state’s third such killing in year
articles.trailText: Stephen Bryant, 44, convicted over 2004 murder, was shot dead despite growing backlash against ‘barbaric’ method
articles.summary: South Carolina executed 44-year-old death-row inmate Stephen Bryant by firing squad���its third gunfire execution in 2025 and seventh killing since reinstating capital punishment after a 13-year hiatus. Bryant, convicted of the 2004 torture murder of Willard “TJ” Tietjen, saw appeals over fetal-alcohol–induced brain damage and childhood abuse rejected. Under state law, inmates choose between firing squad, electrocution or lethal injection; rights groups condemn gunfire as “barbaric” amid broader US concerns over botched executions and painful methods. SC now rivals Utah in modern-era shooting executions.

articles.title: Trump reverses course and cuts tariffs on US food imports
articles.trailText: Order exempting coffee, beef, bananas and other items comes as White House fights off concerns about rising costs
articles.summary: President Donald Trump issued an executive order cutting and exempting 10% tariffs on food imports—including beef, tomatoes, coffee and bananas—effective retroactively from Thursday, marking a reversal of his earlier insistence that tariffs weren’t fueling inflation. The move, intended to address voter concerns about rising grocery costs spotlighted in recent Virginia, New Jersey and NYC elections, follows new bilateral tariff agreements with Switzerland and framework deals with Argentina, Ecuador, Guatemala and El Salvador. White House officials cite advances in reciprocal trade talks; Democrats in Congress argue the administration’s own trade war has driven up prices.

articles.title: Judge to approve $7bn settlement with OxyContin maker that requires Sackler family members to pay victims
articles.trailText: Deal would also require multibillionaire family to give up ownership of the Connecticut-based firm
articles.summary: US bankruptcy judge Sean Lane said he will approve a $7bn settlement in Purdue Pharma’s Chapter 11 case, requiring Sackler family members to pay up to $7bn, give up ownership and fund opioid victims, replacing a Supreme Court-rejected deal. The agreement—part of roughly $50bn in national opioid litigation—could close Purdue’s six-year bankruptcy saga over claims tied to 900,000 overdose deaths. Attorneys for states, cities, tribes and victims broadly backed the plan, which converts Purdue into non-profit Knoa Pharma focused on overdose reversal and addiction treatment. Critics say Purdue should have faced criminal charges, but stakeholders argue the settlement maximizes value for victims.

articles.title: Trump accused of caving to big business after deal to cut Swiss tariffs to 15%
articles.trailText: Rolex denies ‘any negotiation’ with US although luxury watchmaker entertained Trump and gave him gold clock
articles.summary: President Trump agreed to cut US tariffs on Swiss and Liechtenstein goods from 39% to 15% under a non-binding MOU after Swiss firms’ lobbying, aligning US rates with the EU. In exchange, Switzerland will slash duties on US industrial, fish, seafood and agricultural products, and open duty-free quotas for beef (500t), bison (1,000t) and poultry (1,500t). Critics, including Senator Elizabeth Warren, say the pact favors big business over American families, while the White House calls such claims “asinine.” Rolex denies negotiating tariffs despite gifting Trump a golden clock. Implementation details and timing remain unsettled; Swiss investors plan $200 bn US projects by 2028.

articles.title: Bondi announces investigation into Epstein ties to Trump’s Democratic adversaries
articles.trailText: Move diverges from July memo negating need for further inquiries, and comes amid intense Trump campaign to block files
articles.summary: Pam Bondi has appointed former SEC chair Jay Clayton to probe ties between Trump’s Democratic rivals and Jeffrey Epstein, diverging from a July DOJ-FBI memo that found no basis for further inquiries. The move follows Trump’s push to shift blame onto Democrats—naming Bill Clinton, Larry Summers and Reid Hoffman—and intense White House lobbying of Republicans ahead of a House vote on a discharge petition by Massie and Khanna to release all Epstein files within 30 days. Key GOP figures, including Lauren Boebert and Nancy Mace, resisted pressure; Mace, a survivor of sexual abuse, refused to backtrack. Newly released emails imply Trump knew of Epstein’s misconduct, though the administration claims they’re cherry-picked. Even if the House approves the petition, it still faces an uncertain path through the Senate and requires the president’s signature.

articles.title: Jeffrey Epstein and Larry Summers’s exchanges depict relationship as confidants, emails reveal
articles.trailText: The child sex offender and the former US treasury secretary shared personal views about politics and relationships
articles.summary: Republican legislators this week released a tranche of some 20,000 emails from Epstein’s estate, including 2013–19 exchanges between convicted child sex trafficker Jeffrey Epstein and former US Treasury Secretary Larry Summers. The correspondence shows them as close confidants sharing candid views on politics, relationships and women—Summers lamented Harvard’s admissions stance and made sexist remarks in 2017, praised violence over sexual harassment—continuing contact until months before Epstein’s 2019 arrest. The disclosure intensifies scrutiny of Summers’s judgment, Harvard’s ties to Epstein’s $9m donations and Trump’s call for a DOJ and FBI probe.

articles.title: Georgia prosecutor to take over last remaining criminal case against Trump
articles.trailText: Pete Skandalakis appointed himself to take over 2020 election interference case from district attorney Fani Willis
articles.summary: Georgia prosecutor council head Pete Skandalakis has appointed himself to revive and lead the sole remaining criminal case against Donald Trump, replacing disqualified Fulton County DA Fani Willis in the 2020 election interference indictment under Georgia’s anti-racketeering statute. Trump and 18 co-defendants, including Mark Meadows and Rudy Giuliani, were indicted in August 2023 for allegedly scheming to overturn Joe Biden’s narrow 2020 victory by pressuring Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger. After Willis’s removal over a conflict of interest, Skandalakis, unable to find a conflict-free prosecutor, took over to prevent case dismissal. A pretrial status hearing is set for December 1.

articles.title: First Thing: Jeffrey Epstein advised Steve Bannon during 2018 pro-Trump media campaign
articles.trailText: Text messages released by US House show convicted sex offender coaching Maga influencer on political messaging. Plus, readers’ favourite photo booth moments 100 years after its invention
articles.summary: Released US House text messages show convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein coached former Trump strategist Steve Bannon during an August 2018 pro-Trump media drive, advising on TV appearances and messaging; other Epstein emails detail discussions about underage girls as Congress weighs a vote to publish more files. Separately, analysis of UN and OECD data reveals China, Saudi Arabia and UAE are top climate-loan recipients, while Russia’s latest missile barrage hits multiple Kyiv districts, injuring civilians. In other news, the BBC apologised to Trump over Panorama editing, and the DOJ joined GOP litigation challenging California’s new congressional map.

articles.title: Epstein sought to restore his reputation after guilty plea, documents reveal
articles.trailText: Documents include emails depicting coordinated effort to influence online search results and journalists
articles.summary: Documents released by GOP oversight members detail Jeffrey Epstein’s post-2008 image restoration: beginning Dec 2010, he paid SEO specialist Al Seckel to deploy bots pushing Daily Beast and HuffPost articles off Google page one and alter his Wikipedia entry. Correspondence reveals pitches to publicists R. Couri Hay and Osborne & Partners to secure favorable Newsweek and business-press coverage, brand him as a science philanthropist, host annual events, avoid Prince Andrew-linked tabloids, and clean toxic search terms. In mid-2011, he even enlisted Peggy Siegal to approach Arianna Huffington on Virginia Giuffre allegations. Payments, fee disputes and warnings of volatility highlight the operation’s sustained, fee-driven PR campaign.

articles.title: National parks facing ‘nightmare’ under Trump, warns ex-director of service
articles.trailText: Jonathan Jarvis, who led the agency from 2009 to 2017, laid out the dire consequences of not closing parks in shutdown
articles.summary: Former NPS director Jonathan Jarvis warns US national parks are entering a 'nightmare' under the Trump administration, citing the longest federal shutdown that left sites open without staff. With Yellowstone, Yosemite and Joshua Tree facing fires, vandalism, bear jams and trash build-up, Jarvis accuses ideologues in the Interior Department of letting parks 'go down in flames' as 'cash cows' ripe for privatization. He decries a 24% staff reduction, hundreds of layoffs, no permanent director, halted conservation work and heightened risks to visitors and wildlife. Jarvis urges Congress intervention, volunteer clean-ups and public 'raising hell' to defend parks.

articles.title: Texas professors arrested at campus protest sue university, alleging retaliation
articles.trailText: Ben Wright and Rosemary Admiral say UTD severely restricted campus access after arrests at peaceful protest
articles.summary: History professors Ben Wright and Rosemary Admiral have sued the University of Texas at Dallas, the UT System, ex-president Richard Benson, current president Prabhas Moghe, Gov. Greg Abbott and AG Ken Paxton, alleging they were unlawfully arrested without probable cause at a peaceful May 1, 2024 pro-Palestine protest and then subjected to vague, retaliatory campus-access restrictions. Their 29-page complaint cites First and Fourth Amendment violations amid a Texas and federal crackdown on campus free speech, details severe emotional trauma, delayed non-indictment and a chilling effect on faculty and student dissent.

articles.title: Justice department allegedly investigating debunked 2020 Georgia election fraud claims
articles.trailText: Claim, by election deniers, would signal latest step by DoJ in moving away from protecting Americans’ voting rights
articles.summary: Georgia election denial figures have claimed the Department of Justice is investigating debunked 2020 fraud allegations, signaling a repurposing of the DOJ’s Voting Section under Trump appointees from protecting civil rights to validating partisan conspiracies. At an October state legislature hearing, consultant Mark Davis said a DOJ investigator contacted him about “felony residency violations.” An unverified August letter from DOJ attorney Ed Martin demanded 148,000 Fulton County absentee ballots. Meanwhile, DOJ civil rights attorneys have sued seven states for full voter registration lists and sought unredacted VRLs from 30 others, raising concerns of mass purges and restricted poll access ahead of midterms.

articles.title: Antisemitism watchdog slams ADL’s ‘hyperbolic and aggressive’ response to Mamdani win
articles.trailText: Head of Nexus Project says ADL’s plan to ‘monitor’ mayor-elect for antisemitism deepens divisions and plays into far-right agenda
articles.summary: Jonathan Jacoby, director of the antisemitism watchdog Nexus Project, lambasts the ADL’s “hyperbolic and aggressive” plan to monitor New York mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani for antisemitism, warning it deepens divisions and empowers the far right. In an open letter, Nexus also criticizes the Conference of Presidents and Stop Antisemitism for counterproductive attacks. The ADL’s “Mamdani Monitor” and citywide tipline target concerns over Mamdani’s past associations and pro-Palestinian stances, prompting Jewish groups to accuse the ADL of racist, Islamophobic tactics. Jacoby urges refocusing on white nationalism, rebuilding coalitions, and confronting real threats to democracy.

articles.title: Jeffrey Epstein advised Steve Bannon during 2018 pro-Trump media campaign
articles.trailText: Text messages released by US House show convicted sex offender coaching Maga influencer on political messaging
articles.summary: Text messages from August 17–23, 2018 released by the House oversight committee reveal convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein privately coaching former Trump strategist Steve Bannon on pro-Trump media strategy. Epstein critiqued Bannon’s TV appearances, staging and tone, drafted talking points on tax cuts, immigration and security clearances, and monitored breaking scandals—reacting to David Pecker’s immunity and Michael Cohen developments. The correspondence also logs covert meeting logistics and discussions of MAGA figures. These exchanges shed light on Epstein’s behind-the-scenes influence and Bannon’s post-White House efforts to revive and defend Trump’s agenda.

articles.title: Detained in US for speech, a UK commentator speaks out: ‘They don’t want people like us to go to America’
articles.trailText: Sami Hamdi was detained after a pro-Israel group released a video purportedly showing him praising the 7 October 2023 Hamas attacks on Israel
articles.summary: British commentator Sami Hamdi was detained by ICE at San Francisco airport on Oct 26 after a pro-Israel group released an edited video alleging he praised Hamas’s Oct 7 attacks. Held in harsh detention, he was denied medical care and kept in the dark as his visa was abruptly revoked without notice. He departed voluntarily on Nov 14 under a promise to reapply, condemning the action as a free-speech attack on pro-Palestinian advocates and exposing systemic injustices in US immigration detention.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president faces potentially damaging congressional vote over releasing Epstein files
articles.trailText: Attempts to persuade two female members of Congress to withdraw backing for petition appear to have failed – key US politics stories from Thursday 13 November at a glance
articles.summary: Trump struggled to persuade Republicans Lauren Boebert and Nancy Mace to withdraw support from a discharge petition forcing a congressional vote on releasing Jeffrey Epstein files, risking alienation of his MAGA base after House Democrats published emails suggesting he knew of Epstein’s underage sex trafficking. The White House enlisted Pam Bondi and FBI director Kash Patel but backfired. The digest also covers the DOJ suit to block California’s new map, a BBC apology, Comey and AG James challenge Trump-era indictments, an investigation into Rep. Eric Swalwell, Trump’s planned pardon of Joe Lewis, AI ads’ rise and Sen. Fetterman’s hospitalization.

articles.title: Florida kills man on death row in state’s 16th execution this year
articles.trailText: Bryan Frederick Jennings, convicted over rape and murder of young girl in 1979, given three-drug lethal injection
articles.summary: Florida carried out its 16th execution of 2025 on Nov. 13 when Bryan Frederick Jennings, convicted of the 1979 rape and drowning murder of six-year-old Rebecca Kunash, died by three-drug lethal injection at 6:20 p.m. Jennings offered no final words. Corrections officials reported no complications. Governor Ron DeSantis, who has now authorized more executions in a single year than any Florida governor since 1976, has two more scheduled before year-end to, he says, bring justice to victims’ families.

articles.title: US justice department joins lawsuit to block California’s new electoral map
articles.trailText: Move escalates legal battle over a redistricting effort designed to help Democrats flip House seats in 2026
articles.summary: The US Justice Department, led by AG Pam Bondi, has intervened in a federal lawsuit by California Republicans aimed at blocking Prop 50, Gov. Gavin Newsom’s new congressional map designed to help Democrats flip up to five GOP seats in the 2026 House elections. Prop 50, approved by 65% of voters, suspends districts drawn by an independent commission. Plaintiffs, represented by the Dhillon Law Group (with Harmeet Dhillon recused), allege the map illegally uses race to favor Hispanic voters. DOJ civil‐rights chief Jesus Osete and former AG Eric Holder have publicly clashed over the challenge.

articles.title: Donald Trump pardons UK billionaire and former Tottenham owner Joe Lewis
articles.trailText: Joe Lewis was fined $5m and given three years probation by New York judge over ‘brazen’ insider trading scheme
articles.summary: Donald Trump granted a full pardon to British billionaire Joe Lewis, overturning his 2024 conviction for a ‘brazen’ insider-trading scheme that resulted in a $5 million personal fine, $44 million corporate penalty and three years’ probation but no jail time. The 88-year-old former Tottenham Hotspur owner pleaded guilty after prosecutors detailed tip-offs to friends, employees and a romantic partner. He also owns a major stake in pub operator Mitchells & Butlers and transferred Tottenham’s control to a family trust in 2022. Lewis sought the pardon to obtain medical treatment and visit family in the US.

articles.title: Democrat Eric Swalwell faces federal criminal inquiry for alleged mortgage fraud
articles.trailText: Latest target of Trump’s retribution campaign says ‘only thing I am surprised about is that it took him this long’
articles.summary: Rep. Eric Swalwell has been referred for a federal criminal investigation into alleged mortgage and tax fraud, the latest move in Donald Trump’s retribution campaign against critics. The Federal Housing Finance Agency director urged the Justice Department to probe Swalwell’s refinancing of millions in loans after he declared a Washington residence as primary. Swalwell, the only member still suing Trump, said he’s surprised it took this long, joining Letitia James, Lisa Cook and Adam Schiff as targets of Trump-led legal pressure.

articles.title: Emails reveal Jeffrey Epstein and associate discussed ‘girls’ and travel
articles.trailText: Revealed: disclosure comes at same time US justice department downplaying possibility that other men involved in Epstein’s abuse
articles.summary: An email released Nov 12 under the House oversight probe shows a July 23, 2010 exchange where Jeffrey Epstein asks an associate “what is your schedule?”, and the associate references “the other girl” by name and invites Epstein to Ibiza to meet “Tigrane” with eight top girls, plus Jean-Luc Brunel. The associate requests travel arrangements from Ibiza to Paris. Brunel was later arrested in December 2020 for alleged sexual crimes and died by suicide in prison in February 2022. These disclosures emerged as the Trump DOJ publicly asserted no evidence of additional co-conspirators, and White House spokespeople dismissed the emails as irrelevant.

articles.title: Chicago daycare worker freed after judge rules ICE arrest unlawful
articles.trailText: Diana Santillana Galeano’s detention sparked outrage after agents dragged her from a daycare
articles.summary: Diana Santillana Galeano, a Chicago daycare worker arrested without a bond hearing under ICE’s Operation Midway Blitz, was freed from an Indiana detention center after a federal judge ruled her mandatory detention unlawful and ordered a bond hearing by November 18. Judge Jeremy Daniel criticized indefinite custody and required a status report by November 20. Galeano thanked advocates, vowed to return to her students, and her lawyers called the ruling vital for hundreds facing similar detention. Agents were filmed dragging her from the Rayito de Sol daycare, prompting lawmakers’ outrage over ICE tactics.

articles.title: People held in ‘decrepit’ California ICE facility sue over ‘inhumane’ conditions
articles.trailText: Lawsuit against US government alleges ‘life-threatening’ medical neglect and says residents frequently go hungry
articles.summary: Seven people detained at California City, ICE’s largest West Coast facility opened in August in a former state prison, have filed a federal class-action accusing the US government of unconstitutional, inhumane conditions. The suit alleges life-threatening medical neglect—denial of cancer treatment, insulin and disability accommodations—frequent hunger, subzero cells infested with sewage and insects, and extreme cold. Lawyers say residents endure punitive segregation, restricted lawyer and family access, and staff abuse. DHS and private operator CoreCivic deny all claims.

articles.title: Oklahoma inmate’s life spared moments before scheduled lethal injection
articles.trailText: Republican Kevin Stitt commuted Tremane Wood’s death sentence to life in prison for 2002 murder of Ronnie Wipf
articles.summary: Oklahoma inmate’s execution halted minutes before lethal injection after Gov. Kevin Stitt commuted Tremane Wood’s 2002 felony murder sentence to life without parole, marking Stitt’s second clemency in nearly seven years. Wood, 46, convicted in the stabbing death of 19-year-old migrant Ronnie Wipf, has served over 20 years at McAlester penitentiary. His brother, Zjaiton (“Jake”) Wood, admitted killing Wipf and died by suicide in 2019. The rare parole board recommendation followed a Supreme Court refusal to stay the execution. Critics decry the last-minute reprieve as “mental torture,” while supporters hail a chance at redemption.

articles.title: Pennsylvania senator John Fetterman suffers face injury in fall outside home
articles.trailText: Senator released humorous health update after he was released from hospital, suggesting he was doing well
articles.summary: Pennsylvania Sen. John Fetterman was hospitalized after ventricular fibrillation triggered light-headedness and a fall outside his Pittsburgh home, causing minor facial injuries. He joked about his appearance while under routine observation and thanked EMTs and hospital staff. This episode follows his May 2022 stroke from atrial fibrillation—leaving auditory-processing challenges— a February 2023 light-headedness scare, and a six-week stay at Walter Reed for depression. Since joining the Senate in 2023, he’s missed 21% of roll-call votes and drew criticism as the lone Democrat voting for a GOP-led funding resolution.

articles.title: Tenured professor sues University of Kentucky for banning him from law school over comments on Israel
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Ramsi Woodcock, who calls for an ‘end’ to Israel and military intervention against it, says the university violated his first amendment rights
articles.summary: In a federal lawsuit, tenured University of Kentucky law professor Ramsi Woodcock challenges his reassignment and ban from campus after July comments calling Israel a “colonization project” and urging war and dismantlement of the state. He argues the public university violated his First Amendment and due process rights by applying the IHRA antisemitism definition and Title VI protections to punish his off-campus speech—marking the first suit to contest IHRA’s constitutionality in a public school. The university maintains it acted to protect community safety, while Woodcock, backed by CAIR, insists his calls for Israel’s end are protected, not antisemitic, speech.

articles.title: Blurred lines: how Michael Wolff aspired to be part of elite circles he wrote about
articles.trailText: The writer who features prominently in newly released Jeffrey Epstein emails has achieved extraordinary access but faced questions about his journalistic ethics
articles.summary: Since 2003 Michael Wolff has courted the powerful to secure scoops – from brokering a failed $50m bid for New York magazine alongside Weinstein, Zuckerman and Epstein, to embedding with Trump insiders for Fire and Fury. Newly released emails show him trading PR strategy with Epstein in 2015, warning about Trump’s ties and advising how to spin accusations. Critics say this blurs journalism’s boundaries. Wolff admits he chases narrative access over fact-checking, treating himself as a writer outside traditional ethics.

articles.title: Rejecting generative AI in healthcare won’t protect patients – it will harm them | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: The combination of dedicated clinicians, empowered patients and artificial intelligence will lead to safer, higher-quality and more accessible care, says Dr Robert Pearl
articles.summary: Dr. Robert Pearl argues that opposing generative AI in US healthcare perpetuates preventable deaths—400,000 annual misdiagnoses and 250,000 medical errors—and fails chronic disease monitoring. He asserts genAI can offer real-time patient guidance, flag early warning signs for clinicians, and deliver 24/7 mental health support, augmenting rather than replacing doctors. A synergy of dedicated clinicians, informed patients, and genAI promises safer, higher-quality, more accessible care, whereas rejecting AI risks worsening today’s systemic failures.

articles.title: Forty-two days: how the US shutdown unfolded in key moments
articles.trailText: Week by week, key moments from the 43-day shutdown that disrupted flights, food benefits and federal work
articles.summary: In September Senate Democrats hoisted expiring healthcare subsidies onto the funding bill, triggering a 43-day shutdown from Oct 1 to Nov 12.
