About 67,000 federal employees were furloughed and 730,000 worked unpaid, courts operated under the Antideficiency Act, SNAP benefits froze for 42 million Americans and airlines cancelled or delayed thousands of flights. Key disruptions included a 95% DOE furlough, an 80% workforce cut at a nuclear agency and a 10% FAA flight reduction. Mid-shutdown Democratic election gains spurred pressure until seven moderate Dems and one independent broke a deadlock, passing funding through Jan 2026 without guaranteed ACA tax credits.

articles.title: Trump faces prospect of congressional vote on releasing Epstein files
articles.trailText: President’s attempts to press two female members of Congress to withdraw backing for vote appear to have failed
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s efforts to secure GOP Reps Lauren Boebert and Nancy Mace withdrawing their names from a discharge petition to release Jeffrey Epstein’s files failed. Emails released by Democrats suggest Trump knew about Epstein’s underage trafficking. Boebert resisted after White House persuasion and threats; Mace, citing her personal sexual abuse, refused. With 218 signatures reached—including other Republican rebels and newly sworn Democrat Adelita Grijalva—the forced House vote threatens to divide Trump’s base and expose alleged concealment before likely facing Senate defeat or veto.

articles.title: Epstein emails: key takeaways from 20,000 pages of newly released files
articles.trailText: Convicted sex offender said Trump ‘knew about the girls’ and called president a ‘maniac’
articles.summary: Democrats released three of over 20,000 newly disclosed emails from Jeffrey Epstein’s estate to allege Donald Trump “knew about the girls,” pointing to a January 2019 note to Michael Wolff where Epstein claims Trump asked Ghislaine Maxwell to “stop.” Others depict Trump as a “dog that hasn’t barked” after spending time with victim Virginia Giuffre, and quotes calling Trump a “maniac” showing “early dementia.” In parallel, Republican lawmakers published a larger cache. Additional messages reveal Prince Andrew maintained ties through 2011, corroborate Giuffre’s photo with him, and involve Wolff’s role as Epstein’s Trump biographer. Trump dismissed the revelations on Truth Social.

articles.title: Major US broadcasters sit out Cop30 climate talks: ‘They’re missing a lot’
articles.trailText: Figures show none of US ‘big four’ – CBS, NBC, ABC and Fox – appear to have sent teams to cover summit in Belém
articles.summary: Despite nearly 4,000 media registrants at COP30 in Belém, none of the US big four broadcasters��CBS, NBC, ABC or Fox—have dedicated reporting teams on the ground. Two ABC staffers may be present but their location is unclear. A Media Matters audit found no network coverage on ABC, CBS or NBC from Nov 6–11 and just five minutes on Fox, including anti-climate narratives. Experts blame newsroom budget cuts and shifting priorities, noting this year’s lack of a US delegation and declining corporate investment in climate journalism. Meanwhile, smaller outlets like InfoAmazonia are actively reporting and hosting local journalists.

articles.title: Trump Organization sought to bring in nearly 200 workers on visas in 2025
articles.trailText: President’s family business requested at least 184 foreign workers for Mar-a-Lago, Virginia winery and two golf clubs
articles.summary: In 2025 the Trump Organization applied for at least 184 H-2A/H-2B visas—the highest total ever—for Mar-a-Lago, two golf clubs and his Virginia winery, up from 121 in 2021. Forbes data show 566 visa requests over Trump’s White House years and 2025. This surge contrasts with the administration’s stricter immigration measures (H-1B fee hike, student/journalist restrictions). Trump defended the need for specialized foreign workers amid GOP criticism. The White House and Trump Org declined to comment.

articles.title: James Comey and Letitia James to challenge validity of Trump-era charges
articles.trailText: Former FBI director and New York attorney general say the prosecutor in their cases was unlawfully appointed
articles.summary: James Comey, the former FBI director, and New York AG Letitia James will ask Judge Cameron Currie in Alexandria, Virginia to dismiss their indictments, arguing that Lindsey Halligan—Trump’s hand-picked interim US attorney—was unlawfully appointed beyond a single 120-day limit, bypassing Senate confirmation. Halligan, who alone presented evidence that led grand juries to charge Comey with false statements and obstruction and James with bank fraud and lying to a financial institution, also used Signal with auto-delete messages, raising legal concerns. The DOJ asserts her reappointments and retroactive “special attorney” title are lawful. A ruling is expected after Thursday’s hearing.

articles.title: Trump knew about Epstein’s conduct, newly released emails suggest | First Thing
articles.trailText: One email, released by Democrats on House oversight committee, says Trump ‘spent hours’ with one trafficking victim. Plus, Al Gore wonders if ‘bullying’ Trump prompted Bill Gates to backtrack on climate
articles.summary: Newly released emails from Democrats on the House oversight committee suggest Donald Trump was aware of Jeffrey Epstein’s sex trafficking, including an April 2011 note from Epstein to Ghislaine Maxwell stating Trump “spent hours” with Virginia Giuffre. Republicans retaliated by publishing over 20,000 documents, accusing Democrats of cherry-picking memos “to generate clickbait.” On Truth Social, Trump claimed the email disclosures are a diversion from the recent government shutdown. The dispute amplifies calls for full transparency around Epstein’s files and escalates partisan battles over oversight and accountability.

articles.title: Lies, damned lies and AI: the newest way to influence elections may be here to stay
articles.trailText: The use of AI-generated campaign videos – labeled or unlabeled – is likely to permeate future US elections
articles.summary: In NYC’s 2025 mayoral race, campaigns deployed AI-generated deepfake videos and robocalls to shape perceptions: Andrew Cuomo’s team shared an unlabeled video caricaturing opponent Zohran Mamdani with racist tropes, while Eric Adams used AI robocalls in multiple languages and dystopia-themed AI ads. Lawmakers like Alex Bores have introduced bills requiring AI disclaimers and swift takedowns, yet enforcement lags—penalties post-election do little to deter mislabelled or misleading content. Public Citizen’s Robert Weissman warns AI’s realism makes lies harder to counter. As 2028 nears, unlabeled AI ads are poised to remain a fixture in US elections.

articles.title: ‘MigraWatch’ trainings to ‘Whistlemania’ events: Chicagoans fight back against ICE raids
articles.trailText: Residents are organizing in response to raids across the city amid Trump’s wide-ranging ‘Operation Midway Blitz��
articles.summary: Since September’s 'Operation Midway Blitz' in Chicago, ICE and CBP raids have illegally detained about 1,300 immigrants, prompting Mayor Brandon Johnson to seek a UN investigation. Community groups like Puño’s MigraWatch have trained over 2,000 volunteers to spot ICE and assert legal rights, while Belmont Cragin United’s 'Whistlemania' events packed 17,000 emergency kits of whistles and resource guides. Local businesses—from Colibrí Café’s tear-gas encounter to Edgewater Tacos’ fundraiser by Solar Intentions—received support, and the Street Vendors Association raised $230,000 to sustain Latino vendors.

articles.title: Epstein kept close eye on Trump even after friendship soured, newly released emails reveal
articles.trailText: Documents show staff kept Epstein informed of Trump’s air travel – and Epstein kept up with news about former friend
articles.summary: House oversight’s release of 20,000 pages of emails shows Jeffrey Epstein’s team closely monitored Donald Trump’s flight schedules—coordinating arrivals and departures via pilot Larry Visoski—and tracked his public controversies well after their fallout. Redacted messages reveal heads-ups on Trump fundraisers, TSA windows, and Palm Beach airport closures, while Epstein privately branded him “borderline insane” in exchanges with Larry Summers. Epstein also received forwarded news on Roger Stone’s arrest, Michael Cohen probes and Stormy Daniels. The White House dismisses the disclosures as “hoax” and “fake narrative,” and Trump denounces them on Truth Social.

articles.title: Democrats sift through shutdown’s ashes after resistance finally breached
articles.trailText: After 42-day standoff, government is back open – and minority party won no concessions from party in power
articles.summary: After a 42-day shutdown triggered by Senate Democrats’ refusal to fund government without extending ACA tax credits and reversing Medicaid cuts, a coalition of GOP majorities and six Democrats forced a vote to reopen federal funding without any concessions. Minority leaders like Summer Lee and Hakeem Jeffries portray the stand as proof of Democratic resolve, planning to revisit health-care demands in January. Voter polls blamed Republicans more for the shutdown, helping Dems win several off-year state races despite internal dissent over constituent hardships and Missouri’s gerrymander.

articles.title: Trump signs funding bill to end longest US government shutdown
articles.trailText: President signs bill to restart federal operations after House passes measure in 222-209 vote
articles.summary: Longest shutdown ended after House passed GOP–senator deal 222-209 and Trump signed it, funding federal operations through January. Six Democrats backed it, two Republicans opposed. Deal undoes layoffs and restores services but leaves Affordable Care Act tax credit extension unresolved; Senate agreed to vote by mid-December. Shutdown furloughed 700,000 workers, halted SNAP and cut flights, sparking criticism and off-year election losses for GOP. Democratic leaders vow to press for ACA subsidies before next funding lapse. With government funding set to expire again in January, the healthcare fight is poised to continue.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: new batch of Epstein emails suggest Donald Trump ‘knew about the girls’
articles.trailText: Release of messages by Democrats on House oversight committee likely to add to pressure on White House to release Epstein files – key US politics stories from 12 November 2025 at a glance
articles.summary: House oversight Democrats released three newly disclosed Jeffrey Epstein emails implying Trump “knew about the girls” and “spent hours” with one victim, intensifying pressure to publish the full Epstein files. GOP members countered with 23,000 documents, accusing Democrats of “clickbait.��� Trump decried the effort on Truth Social, urging Congress to end the shutdown. The House approved a bill to reopen the government; Rep. Adelita Grijalva filed a petition forcing a vote on Epstein-file disclosure; Trump threatened a BBC lawsuit; urged Israel to pardon Netanyahu; and a report detailed torture of deported Venezuelans. The US Mint will mint its final penny.

articles.title: US House to vote next week on bill compelling release of Epstein files
articles.trailText: Mike Johnson announces move hours after swearing in Adelita Grijalva, Democrat whose signature triggered vote
articles.summary: House Speaker Mike Johnson announced he will bring next week to the floor a bill compelling DOJ to release government files on Jeffrey Epstein. His announcement came after Arizona Democrat Adelita Grijalva was sworn in, becoming the 218th signer on a discharge petition that automatically triggers the vote—earlier than the December deadline. Some Republicans (Bacon, Burchett, Bresnahan) may back it. Even if passed by the House, the measure faces Senate inaction and a likely Trump veto, whom he calls a “Democrat hoax.”

articles.title: Arizona’s Adelita Grijalva sworn in after seven weeks in move that triggers Epstein vote
articles.trailText: Mike Johnson, the House speaker, had prevented the representative from taking her seat after a special election
articles.summary: After a contentious seven-week standoff, Speaker Mike Johnson swore in Arizona Democrat Adelita Grijalva, filling the seat of her late father and ending the delay that deprived over 800,000 constituents of representation. Her oath provided the 218th signature on a discharge petition forcing a House vote in early December on releasing sealed DOJ files on Jeffrey Epstein. Johnson had kept the House in recess to pressure Senate Democrats, citing nonexistent rules, and AZ AG Kris Mayes sued. Grijalva decried the “abuse of power,” spoke in English and Spanish and vowed to press for transparency and accountability.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Top House Democrats vow to oppose shutdown bill after splinter group disappoints
articles.trailText: President called the agreement that passed the Senate Monday ‘a very big victory’ amid the record-breaking government shutdown
articles.summary: After a Senate splinter group joined Republicans to advance a stopgap spending bill funding government through January but excluding Affordable Care Act tax credits, President Trump hailed it as a “very big victory.” House Minority Leader Jeffries vowed Democrats will oppose the measure for failing to extend healthcare subsidies, setting up a tight vote for Speaker Johnson. Meanwhile, the USS Gerald R. Ford deployed to Latin America, the Supreme Court upheld a pause on $4 billion in SNAP funding, the FAA imposed flight cuts, and the administration pursued new offshore drilling, CFPB dismantling efforts, and a sweeping pardon spree.

articles.title: US supreme court extends Trump pause on $4bn in food aid benefits
articles.trailText: More uncertainty after justices allow temporary block on full payments for Snap, relied upon by 42 million Americans
articles.summary: After an administrative stay by the US Supreme Court, the Trump administration will continue withholding $4bn in SNAP food aid, pausing full benefit payments for 42 million Americans until Thursday midnight. The court’s extension responds to the administration’s demand that Congress reopen the government before restoring funds, despite a federal judge’s order. States that already issued November benefits must now “undo” payments or face penalties, triggering legal challenges and operational chaos. With half of November’s allotment distributed, food banks strain under rising demand ahead of Thanksgiving.

articles.title: US ethics officials removed for inquiring into improper access of mortgage files
articles.trailText: Fannie Mae officers were investigating whether Trump ally inappropriately accessed mortgage details of Letitia James, Adam Schiff and others
articles.summary: Fannie Mae ethics officers were removed after probing whether FHFA director William Pulte, a Trump ally, ordered staff to improperly access the mortgage records of Democratic officials—NY Attorney General Letitia James, Senator Adam Schiff and Fed Governor Lisa Cook. Pulte’s referrals alleging fraud are seen as thinly veiled political targeting. Fannie Mae’s team passed complaints to the inspector general’s office, which sent them to US Attorney Lindsey Halligan. Acting IG Joe Allen was ousted, chief ethics officer Suzanne Libby and a dozen investigators were fired, and general counsel Danielle McCoy resigned.

articles.title: Woman eludes police after high-speed chase from California into Mexico
articles.trailText: Alyssa Wilson, a resident at a sober living home, stole a minivan and was chased for hours until crossing the border
articles.summary: Alyssa Wilson, a resident at Diana’s House Sober Living in Thousand Oaks, stole a 2004 Toyota Sienna minivan—its keys taken from the house manager’s purse—triggering a multijurisdictional pursuit. The Ventura County Sheriff’s Office tracked the vehicle 12 miles north to Simi Valley, but Wilson refused to stop, reaching speeds up to 90 mph on the 118 and 405 freeways. She evaded spike strips and crossed into Tijuana, prompting CHP to end the chase at the US-Mexico border. Owner-operator Nicolle Walters said she’s relieved Wilson is safe and advocates for increased mental health and recovery support.

articles.title: Kansas county to pay more than $3m over police raiding local newspaper
articles.trailText: Marion county agrees to apologize over 2023 raid that led to national outcry over press freedom, said newspaper’s editor
articles.summary: Marion county will pay over $3 million and formally apologize for its August 2023 raid on the Marion County Record, a move editor Eric Meyer calls symbolic to deter future press‐freedom assaults. The settlement resolves multiple federal suits filed by the paper’s owners, employees and a former council member. Sheriff Jeff Soyez apologized to Eric and late co‐owner Joan Meyer—who died of a heart attack the day after her home was raided—and to Ruth and Ronald Herbel. Two special prosecutors found the warrants were based on an inadequate investigation and that no crime occurred; former police chief Gideon Cody resigned and faces trial for alleged interference with justice.

articles.title: Top House Democrats vow to oppose shutdown bill over healthcare funding
articles.trailText: Democrats are demanding an extension of tax credits for Affordable Care Act health plans set to expire at end of year
articles.summary: Top House Democrats vow to oppose a government-funding bill set for a Wednesday vote because it excludes renewal of Affordable Care Act premium tax credits expiring year-end. Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, the centrist New Democrat Coalition and the Progressive Caucus denounce the Senate-passed plan, warning it “guts healthcare” and sacrifices constituent wellbeing. Speaker Mike Johnson faces a narrow majority with potential GOP rebel Thomas Massie plus possible Democratic defectors Jared Golden and Marie Gluesenkamp Perez. Eight Senate Democrats plus Rand Paul backed the measure after securing a mid-December floor vote on credits. Grassroots groups pressure Senator Schumer over the compromise.

articles.title: US army gynecologist accused of secretly filming patients during exams
articles.trailText: Lawsuit alleges doctor at Fort Hood was allowed to continue working despite complaints against him for years
articles.summary: Blaine McGraw, an army major and gynecologist at Fort Hood, is accused in a Bell County civil lawsuit of groping and secretly filming dozens of women over several years, including on-base appointments. The 13-page suit alleges senior officers ignored prior complaints from his tenure at Tripler Army Medical Center in Hawaii, enabling sustained abuse. Plaintiff “Jane Doe” and at least 45 others have come forward after investigators recovered thousands of intimate images. Victims and attorney Andrew Cobos criticize the army’s indifference and plan a Tort Claims Act action to hold leadership accountable.

articles.title: California police intervene as ICE agent in plain clothes points gun at woman
articles.trailText: Agent said woman was following and filming him, but officer said he couldn’t assist if no crime was committed
articles.summary: In Santa Ana, near Fullerton, a plain-clothes ICE agent aimed his firearm at a motorist he alleged was following and filming him. A Fullerton police officer—fresh from transporting a detainee—arrived, verified no crime had occurred, and declined to assist under California’s SB 54, which bars local participation in immigration enforcement. DHS defended the agent’s actions, accusing the driver of aggression and flight, but video contradicts parts of that claim. The FBI has since urged federal officers to clearly identify themselves.

articles.title: Trump administration moves again to dismantle top US consumer watchdog
articles.trailText: Government argues funding mechanism behind Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is unlawful
articles.summary: The Trump administration filed a court motion to dismantle the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, arguing its funding mechanism via Fed profits is unlawful and will exhaust funds in early 2026. The DOJ’s Office of Legal Counsel claims the Fed’s combined earnings have been negative since 2022, barring the CFPB from additional funding. Past efforts by Trump officials to fire 90% of agency staff and shut it down spurred months of legal battles. The CFPB has returned over $21 billion to consumers since its creation. OMB Director Russell Vought vows to close the bureau within three months despite court rulings and Democratic objections that doing so is illegal and would hurt American families.

articles.title: Delta settles flight attendant lawsuit over sexual harassment and union retaliation
articles.trailText: Aryasp Nejat says he was fired after enduring ‘sexually assaultive touching’ and making pro-union posts
articles.summary: Delta Air Lines settled for an undisclosed sum a 2024 lawsuit in which flight attendant Aryasp Nejat alleged he was suspended and then fired after posting pro-union, anti-harassment messages and reporting “sexually assaultive touching” by trainer Matthew Miller during a uniform inspection. Nejat, now at another major carrier and entering law school, said the case underscores Delta’s anti-union stance over harassment rights. His suit coincides with a push by AFA-CWA, IAM and Teamsters to unionize 29,000 Delta attendants, opposed by the airline. Delta denies wrongdoing, citing litigation costs.

articles.title: Pentagon’s largest warship enters Latin American waters as US tensions with Venezuela rise
articles.trailText: USS Gerald R Ford’s arrival marks the largest US military presence in the region since the invasion of Panama in 1989
articles.summary: The US Navy’s USS Gerald R Ford carrier strike group, with 4,000 sailors, dozens of aircraft and destroyers, has entered US Southern Command waters in the Caribbean and Latin America—marking the largest US military presence since Panama 1989. Announced three weeks ago, the deployment escalates tensions with Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro, who mobilized land, sea, air, river, missile forces and militias in response. President Trump frames the buildup as part of a “war on drugs,” citing interdiction airstrikes that killed at least 76 since September. Regional leaders at the Celac summit rejected force without naming the US; Brazil’s Lula urged a political solution in Venezuela.

articles.title: Mississippi student arrested for yelling antisemitic comments at Dave Portnoy
articles.trailText: University student charged with disturbing peace after yelling and throwing coins towards Barstool Sports founder
articles.summary: Patrick McClintock, a 20-year-old mechanical engineering student at Mississippi State University, was arrested and charged with disturbing the peace after yelling antisemitic slurs and tossing coins at Barstool Sports founder Dave Portnoy outside Boardtown Pizza & Pints in Starkville. The viral video prompted police to secure an arrest warrant; McClintock later withdrew from MSU. Police emphasized that offensive words are protected but intervened when behavior threatened public safety. Portnoy, who is Jewish, released his pizza review footage alongside a response labeling McClintock a “loser” and warning of a “definitive shift” toward antisemitism in America during a CBS interview.

articles.title: Families of Camp Mystic campers and counselors file lawsuits over deaths
articles.trailText: Families allege camp leaders ignored known flood risks in ‘entirely preventable’ tragedy that killed multiple people
articles.summary: Families of 25 campers, two counselors and the camp director killed in July’s flash floods at Camp Mystic have filed multiple lawsuits alleging gross negligence by the century-old Christian camp and its owners. Lawsuits claim leaders ignored known flood risks, housed cabins in high-risk zones to save costs, lacked evacuation plans, and prioritized equipment over evacuating campers, leading to entirely preventable deaths. Plaintiffs seek over $1m in damages, accusing defendants of negligence, wrongful death and breach of duty, amid plans to partially reopen next summer.

articles.title: Man and daughter flying hurricane relief supplies to Jamaica identified as victims of crash
articles.trailText: Alexander Wurm, 53, and his daughter Serena died in Florida crash as they were flying supplies to Jamaica
articles.summary: Alexander Wurm, 53, and his 22-year-old daughter Serena died when their twin-engine Beechcraft King Air crashed into a Coral Springs neighborhood shortly after departing Fort Lauderdale Executive Airport while carrying hurricane relief supplies to Jamaica. Wurm, founder of Ignite the Fire ministry, had made multiple aid flights to communities hit by Hurricane Melissa. No one on the ground was injured. The NTSB is investigating; wreckage recovery continues and the victims’ remains have not yet been recovered.

articles.title: Utah judge approves map creating new House seat in Democratic-leaning area
articles.trailText: Decision breathes new life into Democrats’ attempts to reclaim the House in the 2026 midterm elections
articles.summary: Utah judge Dianna Gibson ruled the legislature’s GOP-drawn map “unduly favors Republicans,” invalidating it and approving a proposal by the League of Women Voters and Mormon Women for Ethical Government. The new map consolidates Democratic-leaning Salt Lake County into one district, creating a fifth seat and ending Utah’s all-Republican delegation. The decision boosts Democrats’ 2026 House flip strategy, attracts candidates like former Rep. Ben McAdams, and provokes GOP threats of impeachment and a repeal drive.

articles.title: ICE agents accused of pepper-spraying Illinois parents and their one-year-old
articles.trailText: Video shows Rafael Veraza holding his face after he and his family we reallegedly sprayed through open car window
articles.summary: In Cicero, Illinois, video shows ICE agents firing pepper spray through a family’s open car window at a Sam’s Club, injuring 25-year-old Rafael Veraza, his U.S.-citizen wife and their one-year-old daughter, Arianna, who struggled to breathe. DHS denies any deployment, blaming rioters. Veraza and activists condemn the incident as part of Trump’s “Operation Midway Blitz” in Chicago. It follows aggressive ICE tactics—from daycare detentions to parade-route sprays—now facing legal challenges and restraining orders.

articles.title: I’m an American relying on food stamps. This country has turned us into lab rats
articles.trailText: I’m one of 41 million people who need Snap to make ends meet. For weeks, the administration has turned our survival into a game: will they eat, or won’t they?
articles.summary: In this personal essay from Mapleton, Oregon (pop. 527), a SNAP beneficiary recounts waking hungry to an empty fridge while juggling canned tuna breakfasts, winter squash, hunting and foraging. During a government shutdown, officials toggled food assistance—turning recipients into ‘lab rats’ in a political experiment. With rural poverty at 22% (44% for kids), she and her cousin Alissa (24, $1,000 rent in roach-infested slum, gig work) endure AI-driven job losses, inflation and benefit cuts. She rejects shame for solidarity, condemning systemic gaslighting and exploitation.

articles.title: Pediatricians fill vaccine messaging void left by CDC amid bad flu season
articles.trailText: Doctors step up after US health department suspended its flu vaccine campaign following Trump’s election
articles.summary: The CDC suspended its “wild to mild” flu vaccine campaign after a record 280 pediatric flu deaths in 2024-25, prompting pediatricians to fill the messaging gap. Trusted by 85% of parents, they now recommend vaccination at every visit and offer nasal sprays. A drop in global virus samples complicates strain tracking. HHS’s new respiratory virus awareness campaign omits vaccine specifics. Experts warn this season could rival last year’s high severity, citing severe outbreaks in Australia and Japan. Convenience, reminders and trusted providers are vital to boost uptake.

articles.title: First Thing: Trump threatens BBC with $1bn legal action over edit of speech in documentary
articles.trailText: Two senior BBC figures have resigned. Plus, China’s CO2 emissions have been flat or falling for 18 months
articles.summary: Donald Trump has threatened to sue the BBC for at least $1bn over a Panorama documentary that spliced his January 6 speech, demanding a retraction by Friday; senior BBC executives resigned after an internal report criticized coverage. Apple and WhatsApp vow to warn users of state spyware amid Paragon and NSO’s US push; campus protests greeted Turning Point USA’s Berkeley tour; DRC land whistleblowers face violence; Japan’s PM warns a Taiwan attack could spark military deployment; Trump appeals E Jean Carroll verdict; experts warn ICJ legitimacy risk; Canada logs 5,138 measles cases; China’s CO2 emissions plateau; evolution of protein shakes.

articles.title: US firefighter detained on the job speaks out after deportation: ‘I feel betrayed’
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Border patrol arrested José Bertin Cruz-Estrada while he was battling a wildfire in Washington. He is now in Mexico, separated from his family in Oregon
articles.summary: Undocumented Oregon resident and veteran firefighter José Bertín Cruz-Estrada was arrested by Border Patrol on Aug. 27 while battling the 9,000-acre Bear Gulch wildfire in Washington, detained for two months, then quietly deported to Mexico, separating him from his 14-year-old son and family. Cruz-Estrada, who began firefighting in 2019 after returning from a 2013 drug-conspiracy-related removal, balanced a successful landscaping business and leadership roles in wildfire response. Activists, lawmakers and community members condemned the operation as a breach of practices barring immigration enforcement during emergencies, questioning why a seasoned first responder was targeted while saving lives.

articles.title: Can Donald Trump sue the BBC for $1bn and which party would win?
articles.trailText: US president has said he will bring proceedings if the documentary containing an edited speech from 6 January 2021 is not retracted
articles.summary: Donald Trump has threatened to sue the BBC for $1bn over an allegedly misleading edit of his January 6 speech, targeting Florida courts where the two-year statute of limitations still applies and the BBC’s content is accessible online. To win, Trump must prove actual malice and concrete reputational harm as a public figure. While US verdicts have topped $1bn in rare cases, experts call his demand symbolic. The BBC has issued a partial apology and may choose to settle to avoid protracted litigation.

articles.title: ‘A classic authoritarian tactic’: outrage over Trump’s pardons for friends and allies
articles.trailText: Ex-prosecutors and legal scholars say US president ‘meting out pardons for blatantly corrupt and self-serving ends’
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s unprecedented pardon spree for political and business allies has sparked accusations of pay-to-play corruption and partisan weaponization of the Justice Department. Since his return he’s granted clemency to 1,500 MAGA rioters, ex-Rep. George Santos, Binance founder Changpeng Zhao and preemptively pardoned 70+ loyalists including Giuliani and Meadows. Trump installed Ed Martin, a partisan pardon attorney who overturned vetting standards, drawing warnings from ex-prosecutors and scholars that these “authoritarian” tactics undermine the rule of law. Critics cite conflicts of interest, pardoning Zhao after Binance’s $2bn deal with the Trump family crypto firm, and label these actions a thinly veiled form of bribery.

articles.title: Outcry as TikTok livestreamer who allegedly hit and killed man asks for donations
articles.trailText: Woman requests help to support ‘mental leave’ after incident in which Darren Lucas, 59, was struck and killed
articles.summary: Social media creator known as Tea_Tyme_3, 43-year-old Zion musician Tynesha McCarty, allegedly struck and killed 59-year-old Darren Lucas while livestreaming on TikTok via a green-screen workaround that bypassed the platform's ban on in-car streaming. Days after the fatal crash in Beach Park, Illinois, she solicited donations via CashApp to fund her “mental leave,” prompting online outrage. Police confirmed no impairment suspected; no charges have been filed, and investigators are probing a recording of the collision. McCarty’s account is now private, her bios deleted, and she promotes music and publishing endeavors despite facing backlash and potential liability in Lucas’s death.

articles.title: With his threat of a $1bn lawsuit against BBC, Trump’s assault on the media goes global
articles.trailText: US president’s latest media target comes from across the pond as he continues to scrutinize coverage he does not like
articles.summary: President Trump, following $80m in settlements from US media and tech firms, has escalated his legal campaign globally by threatening a $1bn defamation suit against the BBC over a 2024 Panorama episode. His lawyers claim the documentary stitched his January 6 speech to portray incitement; two BBC executives resigned. Citing Florida law despite limited US access, Trump’s team faces jurisdictional hurdles, while experts warn litigation could open a “Pandora’s box” of his January 6 remarks.

articles.title: Protests as rightwing Charlie Kirk activist group makes final campus tour stop
articles.trailText: People shout ‘Fascists out of Berkeley’ as Turning Point USA brings message to college with history of leftwing activism
articles.summary: Turning Point USA held its final American Comeback tour event at UC Berkeley, two months after founder Charlie Kirk’s fatal shooting. The sold-out appearance featured Rob Schneider and Frank Turek alongside memorial tributes and JD Vance’s remarks on Kirk’s political impact. Hundreds of anti-fascist protesters, chanting "Fascists out of Berkeley" and waving Palestinian flags, clashed with a heavy police presence, resulting in at least three arrests for violent altercations and vandalism. Demonstrators expressed anxiety over possible gun violence after a car’s mimicked gunshots. UC Berkeley’s chapter has doubled since Kirk’s death, underscoring heightened campus tensions.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Senate passes funding package to end shutdown after Democrats break ranks
articles.trailText: Trump said he would “abide by the deal” struck by US lawmakers
articles.summary: Senate advanced a stopgap funding bill 60-40 after seven Democrats and an independent joined Republicans, averting the longest US shutdown; House vote set for Wednesday. Schumer faces resign calls from party defectors. Trump said he’d “abide by” the deal and threatened a $1 bn suit against the BBC over a documentary edit. SCOTUS declined to revisit same-sex marriage and agreed to hear a late-ballot case. Defense Sec. Hegseth claimed six killed attacking suspected narco-boats. Other developments include Trump’s criticism of air traffic controllers, Maxwell’s commutation bid, US deportation payments to Equatorial Guinea, Thai-Cambodian border tensions and partial Syria sanctions relief.

articles.title: Trump scolds air traffic controllers and blames rivals for economy in interview
articles.trailText: President put forth his vision of ‘Trump Care’ for health and insisted ‘we have the greatest economy we ever had’
articles.summary: Donald Trump, in an exclusive Fox News interview with Laura Ingraham during the protracted government shutdown, rebuked overworked air traffic controllers, pledged $10,000 bonuses despite unclear funding, and blamed Democrats and Fed chair Jerome Powell for economic woes. He touted “the greatest economy we ever had,” dismissed inflation concerns as a “con job,” and floated a 50-year mortgage plan. Trump proposed “Trump Care,” allocating subsidies into personal accounts, and attacked rivals Gavin Newsom, Chuck Schumer, and Joe Biden. He credited GOP lawmakers for breaking the shutdown stalemate, insisting MAGA’s priorities drove his agenda.

articles.title: Senate approves funding deal to end longest US government shutdown
articles.trailText: Bill, which passed 60-40 but does not include key health concession demanded by Democrats, now heads to House
articles.summary: In a 60–40 bipartisan Senate vote, seven Democrats, one independent and all Republicans approved a continuing resolution to fund most federal agencies through January 2026, ending the 40-day government shutdown. The deal, backed by Trump and Speaker Johnson, halts mass federal layoffs and guarantees back pay but omits immediate extensions of ACA premium tax credits, promising a mid-December Senate vote. Defecting Democrats face backlash and calls for Schumer’s resignation over failing to secure key healthcare concessions.

articles.title: US has sent $7.5m to Equatorial Guinea to accept noncitizen deportees
articles.trailText: Country is one of world’s most repressive and corrupt, raising concerns over rights abuses of those deported
articles.summary: The US transferred $7.5m from its Migration and Refugee Assistance emergency fund to Equatorial Guinea’s government—marking the first use of MRA money to speed third-country deportations rather than aid refugees. Critics note Equatorial Guinea’s corrupt, authoritarian regime led by Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo and son Nguema Obiang, accused of embezzlement and human trafficking complicity. In a letter to Secretary of State Rubio, Senator Jeanne Shaheen flagged risks of abuse and lack of safeguards. The transfer fits a broader Trump-era push negotiating payments or leverage with at least 58 countries to accept noncitizen deportees under expedited protocols. UN experts warn of rights violations and inadequate legal reviews.

articles.title: Angry Democrats call on Schumer to resign after eight vote to end shutdown
articles.trailText: Some lawmakers and progressive groups blame minority leader after eight senators defect
articles.summary: On Sunday, eight moderate Senate Democrats joined Republicans to pass a short-term funding measure ending the longest US government shutdown, without securing Affordable Care Act premium tax credit extensions. Progressive groups (Our Revolution, Indivisible), strategists (Rick Wilson) and House Democrats (Levin, Khanna, Tlaib) accused Minority Leader Chuck Schumer of leadership failure, demanding his immediate resignation. While Schumer publicly opposed the deal and abstained in a key procedural vote, critics argue he secretly enabled or failed to control his caucus. House and Senate leaders Jeffries and GOP counterparts remain largely silent amid rising intra-party tensions.

articles.title: UK commentator detained by ICE after Israel criticism to be released, family says
articles.trailText: Sami Hamdi’s visa was revoked in what appeared to be retaliation for criticism of Israel while touring the US
articles.summary: British commentator Sami Hamdi, detained by ICE on Oct 26 at San Francisco airport after his visa was revoked—allegedly in retaliation for criticizing Israel and comments on Hamas—will be released under a voluntary departure agreement, his family announced. The Council on American-Islamic Relations and Hamdi’s legal team say the move targeted free speech, pointing out that no criminal or security charges were filed, only a visa overstay. DHS labels him a “terrorist sympathizer” and is arranging his removal; he is expected to return home soon.

articles.title: Democratic candidate for Congress criticizes deal to end shutdown – which her mother voted to advance
articles.trailText: Stefany Shaheen omitted to mention that her mother, Jeanne Shaheen, was among party’s rebel senators who voted to approve bill
articles.summary: Stefany Shaheen, Democratic congressional candidate in New Hampshire, blasted the bipartisan deal to end the 40-day government shutdown for lacking a guaranteed vote on extending Affordable Care Act tax credits. She neglected to mention her mother, Senator Jeanne Shaheen, one of seven Democrats (plus independent Angus King) who broke ranks to advance the funding bill extending government funding until Jan 30. Jeanne Shaheen defended her vote as “the only deal on the table” to reopen the government and then negotiate health-care subsidies. Stefany’s post sparked social-media backlash accusing her of hypocrisy. Her campaign centers on protecting Medicaid and ACA coverage for millions.

articles.title: Ghislaine Maxwell eyeing commutation, whistleblower tells House Democrats
articles.trailText: Epstein associate is also receiving special treatment in prison, Democrats say, according to whistleblower
articles.summary: Ghislaine Maxwell, Epstein’s former associate serving a 20-year sentence for sex-trafficking, is reportedly preparing a commutation petition for the Trump administration, per a whistleblower to House Democrats. Rep. Jamie Raskin alleges the warden at FPC Bryan, Texas, has been helping her file clemency documents—copying, printing, mailing—and granting perks such as customized meals, private computer-equipped visits, after-hours exercise, and a service dog. Raskin has demanded answers from the White House and subpoena Todd Blanche to testify, warning against any pardon. Fellow Democrats, including Rep. Robert Garcia, urge GOP leaders to publicly oppose clemency. The White House declined comment.

articles.title: The BBC’s editing of Trump’s January 6 speech caused controversy – but what did he really say?
articles.trailText: The scandal has provided Trump another avenue to attack the media, and to relitigate his involvement in January 6
articles.summary: BBC combined two sentences 54 minutes apart in Panorama, making it look like ‘fight like hell’ and sparking the resignations of DG Tim Davie and chair Samir Shah (who called it an ‘error in judgement’). A leaked dossier to The Telegraph alleged broader bias. Trump seized on the scandal on Truth Social, threatening a $1bn lawsuit via attorney Alejandro Brito. Jan 6 committee records show only ‘peacefully and patriotically’ was scripted; Trump’s own words urged supporters to ‘fight like hell,’ march on the Capitol and pressure Pence. He later pardoned rioters and installed allies to relitigate 2020 election claims.

articles.title: ‘We need this food’: Las Vegas teens on hunger and anxiety amid Snap cuts
articles.trailText: Children may not understand politics of shutdown, but fear of future hunger can affect young brains, research reveals
articles.summary: After Halloween in downtown Las Vegas’ distressed Huntridge and Naked City neighborhoods, volunteers handed out six different shelf-stable meals—chickpea curry kits, ramen kits, milk, cereals and more—to teens fearful the government shutdown would pause November Snap benefits. Fifteen-year-old Lola and friends carried armfuls home, aware their mother Naomi’s erratic hours and under $800 monthly EBT won’t stretch without support. Research shows children as young as five sense food scarcity, triggering chronic stress responses that impair cognition, emotional regulation and brain development, with lifelong impacts on learning and behavior.

articles.title: Zohran Mamdani’s writer on crafting a historic victory speech: ‘In New York, inspiration is everywhere’
articles.trailText: The mayor-elect’s address pulled from Socialist titans, Astoria’s uncles and his rival’s father. Julian Gerson explains how the two collaborated on the ‘love letter to New York’
articles.summary: In his victory address, New York mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani, guided by campaign speechwriter Julian Gerson, fused socialist tributes—from Eugene Debs to Fiorello La Guardia—with multicultural nods to Senegalese taxi drivers and Uzbek nurses, delivered in hip-hop cadence. Gerson, a 29-year-old Brooklynite and veteran ghostwriter, spent a week drafting with Mamdani and consultant Morris Katz, weaving Arabic (“ana minkum wa ilaykum”) and rap swagger into a ‘love letter to New York.’ Drawing on memories of Obama’s Grant Park speech and local community input, he crafted a memorable, combative oration designed to mobilize diverse urban constituencies.

articles.title: US supreme court to decide if states can accept late-arriving mail ballots
articles.trailText: Case involves a challenge to a Mississippi law that allows ballots to count if they are received days after election day
articles.summary: The Supreme Court will hear Watson v. RNC, challenging Mississippi’s law that counts mail ballots received up to five business days after election day if postmarked by then. Mississippi argues ballots are ‘cast’ at postmark under longstanding precedent; the Fifth Circuit reversed a lower court, ruling federal law fixes election day and late arrivals undermine the electorate’s final choice. Sixteen states, DC, Guam and Puerto Rico have similar windows. The Court may defer Watson pending a standing dispute in Bost v. Illinois and is also considering limits to Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act. Republicans, including Trump, have pushed to end late‐ballot counting, spurring ongoing litigation.

articles.title: Floridians warned about falling iguanas as wintry weather hits eastern US
articles.trailText: Cold and snow take hold in eastern two-thirds of the US, from the Great Lakes to Florida and Texas
articles.summary: An early arctic blast sweeping eastern US from the Great Lakes to Texas is triggering record cold, heavy snow and rare hazards like freezing iguanas in Florida. The top third of Florida could see temperatures plunge below 40°F, causing limp iguanas to fall from trees and prompting safety warnings after a 2023 injury. Midwest states face thundersnow with up to 18 inches of snow and 30 mph gusts, while dry winds elevate fire risk along the Gulf coast and disrupt travel in Chicago. Meteorologists say this polar plunge will break records, fuel lake-effect snow, then retreat by Tuesday, hastening the end of the hurricane season.

articles.title: Senate Democrats who defected in shutdown vote: ‘This was the only deal’
articles.trailText: Seven Democrats and an independent face fury over support to advance funding bill amid 40-day shutdown
articles.summary: Seven Democrats—Shaheen, Hassan, Kaine, Durbin, Cortez Masto, Rosen, Fetterman—and independent Angus King joined Republicans to secure 60-vote Senate passage of a continuing resolution ending the 40-day government shutdown. The deal funds agencies through Jan. 30, 2026, halts mass firings, restores workers fired during the shutdown, guarantees back pay and bars further cuts until January. Defectors say it was the only viable option, especially to protect federal workers and ACA negotiations, but Senate and House Democratic leaders condemn the compromise for surrendering leverage on extending enhanced ACA tax credits. The measure now returns to a narrowly divided House.

articles.title: Senate advances funding bill to end longest-ever US government shutdown
articles.trailText: The amended package will still have to be passed by the House and sent to Trump for his signature, a process that could take days
articles.summary: Senate advanced a compromise funding bill to end the 40-day shutdown by a 60-40 vote, reauthorizing government funding through January 30, 2026, restoring pay for furloughed and retained federal workers and preventing further layoffs. Negotiated by GOP leader John Thune and eight moderate Democrats, it omits Affordable Care Act tax credits, prompting broad Democratic opposition. The measure must clear the Republican-led House and be signed by President Trump, with healthcare subsidies to be debated separately in December amid looming disputes in both chambers.

articles.title: Trump pardons Giuliani, Meadows and others over plot to steal 2020 election
articles.trailText: Federal clemency towards president’s close allies largely symbolic as some still face legal exposure at state level
articles.summary: President Trump on Nov. 7 issued federal pardons to 77 close allies—Rudy Giuliani, Mark Meadows, Sidney Powell, Jenna Ellis, John Eastman and others—accused of orchestrating a fake-elector scheme in battleground states to overturn the 2020 election. Announced by Pardon Attorney Ed Martin, the “full, complete and unconditional” clemencies are symbolic, applying only in federal court and leaving ongoing state prosecutions in Georgia, Arizona, Michigan, Wisconsin and Nevada intact. Several pardon recipients have faced disbarment, license suspensions and multimillion-dollar defamation judgments.

articles.title: Trump threatens BBC with $1bn legal action over edit of speech in documentary
articles.trailText: Leaked BBC report said film had ‘completely misled’ viewers by splicing two parts of January 6 speech together
articles.summary: Donald Trump has threatened the BBC with a $1bn lawsuit over its Panorama documentary that misleadingly spliced two parts of his Jan. 6 insurrection speech. He demanded a retraction by Friday or legal action would follow. The row prompted the resignations of BBC director general Tim Davie and news CEO Deborah Turness after a leaked internal report—published by the Telegraph—accused the network of bias on issues from transgender rights to Gaza coverage. Trump hailed the exposé on Truth Social, while White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt labelled the BBC “fake news.” BBC chair Samir Shah apologised for the edit.

articles.title: Hegseth says six people killed in two new US attacks on alleged drug boats
articles.trailText: US defense secretary says without providing evidence that dead from strikes in eastern Pacific were ‘narco-terrorists’
articles.summary: US forces conducted two lethal strikes on suspected drug-trafficking boats in international waters off South America, killing six people, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said, calling them “male narco-terrorists” tied to a designated terrorist group. Since early September, similar strikes have killed over 70 individuals. Washington has not released evidence of narcotics or threats. The UN rights chief and Venezuela’s government denounce the attacks as illegal extrajudicial killings, with President Nicolás Maduro accusing the Trump administration of aggression amid a wider US naval buildup in the Caribbean.

articles.title: How could Zohran Mamdani pay for his bold agenda for New York? We broke it down
articles.trailText: A look at the realities the mayor-elect will face to pay for his progressive policies – and whose support he needs
articles.summary: Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani’s progressive agenda includes free buses, universal childcare and 200,000 low-cost housing units, but he must overcome Trump administration funding cuts and secure state legislature approval—despite GOP sabotage risk and Governor Hochul’s tax-raise opposition. His team projects raising $10bn via a 7.25–11.5% corporate tax hike, a 2% surcharge on incomes over $1m and fee increases to fund childcare ($2.5–12bn), $700m for free buses and $60m for city-owned grocery stores. A rent-controlled freeze awaits Rent Guidelines Board backing. Democrats’ legislative majorities and popular support offer political pathways and likely compromise on revenues and spending.

articles.title: First Thing: Senate advances funding bill to end longest US government shutdown in history
articles.trailText: Amended package must be passed by the house and signed by the president. Plus, Volodymyr Zelenskyy on why he’s not afraid of Donald Trump
articles.summary: In US news, the Senate narrowly advanced a bipartisan funding bill 60–0 to end the longest government shutdown on record, restoring pay but omitting Democrats’ healthcare subsidy demands. In other highlights, Ukraine’s Volodymyr Zelenskyy tells the Guardian he isn’t afraid of Donald Trump; Israeli soldiers in a UK documentary allege Gaza civilians were killed without restraint; Syria’s President Ahmed al-Sharaa plans White House talks seeking sanctions relief; the BBC’s top editors resign amid bias accusations; Super Typhoon Fung-Wong devastates the Philippines; a review finds no link between prenatal paracetamol and autism or ADHD; and the viral Louvre “Fedora Man” turns out to be a 15-year-old schoolboy.

articles.title: Snap workers say Trump administration is ‘using country’s poorest as pawns’
articles.trailText: Employees providing assistance to recipients expressed fears on how lack of aid will affect those who need it most
articles.summary: In Providence, RI, AFSCME eligibility technician Stacy Smith greeted elderly and disabled SNAP clients in long lines after benefits paused Nov 1 amid the federal shutdown—the first lapse in program history. With 42 million Americans dependent on SNAP, workers warn that half-allotment cuts, court battles and a Supreme Court appeal are leaving low-income families fearing hunger—and straining maxed-out food banks. AFSCME’s Misha Dancing Waters in Wisconsin reports state offices have no clarity, holiday meal programs end, and people lack basic food security. Staff decry using the nation’s poorest as “pawns” in a political game.

articles.title: Medicaid chief’s claim $1bn is spent on healthcare for ‘illegal immigrants’ is false, say experts
articles.trailText: Mehmet Oz made claim about audits, but experts say he misidentified routine administrative errors
articles.summary: CMS head Mehmet Oz claimed on X that an audit uncovered over $1bn in federal Medicaid spending on undocumented immigrants, framing it within the HR1/ACA tax-credit fight. Experts including Georgetown’s Leo Cuello and American University’s Nina Yamanis say these were routine state administrative errors in matching-fund claims—common state-federal reviews unrelated to immigration—and that genuine eligibility checks use DHS databases. They warn Oz’s rhetoric may deter eligible immigrant families, especially Latinos, from care, worsening health outcomes and undermining public health.

articles.title: Resilience of Europe’s populist right carries warning for US Democrats
articles.trailText: As Democrats bask in electoral success the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Poland and Hungary offer a cautionary tale
articles.summary: Riding recent wins, US Democrats face a cautionary tale from east-central Europe where defeated populists repeatedly rebound. In the Czech Republic Andrej Babiš’s ANO is set to govern again alongside far-right allies; Slovakia’s Robert Fico returned in 2023; and Poland’s Law and Justice won this year’s presidency less than two years after defeat. Analysts cite polarization, economic insecurity, anti-incumbency and a clear nationalist vision to explain these comebacks. With Viktor Orbán hailed by Trump as a model and centrist parties lacking comparable zeal, Europe’s right-wing revival warns US Democrats that electoral success may not end populist resilience.

articles.title: Coffee may protect people against irregular heartbeats, study finds
articles.trailText: Trial’s findings go against common beliefs that people with atrial fibrillation should avoid caffeinated coffee
articles.summary: Does Eliminating Coffee Avoid Fibrillation (Decaf) randomized trial in 200 adults with atrial fibrillation across the US, Canada and Australia found daily caffeinated coffee drinkers had a 47% recurrence rate versus 64% for abstainers, a 17% relative risk reduction and longer delay to recurrence over six months. Published in JAMA and at AHA, it used ECGs and wearables to verify events. Limitations include untracked non-coffee caffeine, exercise and diet. UCSF’s Gregory Marcus cited coffee’s protective role, while Mount Sinai’s Johanna Contreras recommended moderation rather than prescribing caffeine for A-fib.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: eight Democrats join Republicans to advance funding bill
articles.trailText: Bill, a first step to ending the shutdown, will still need to be deliberated and passed by the Senate, and win approval in the house. Key US politics stories from 9 November at a glance
articles.summary: The Senate narrowly advanced a stopgap funding bill to end the record US government shutdown with 60 votes—almost all Republicans plus eight moderate or outgoing Democrats—even as most Democrats balk over omitted healthcare subsidies. The measure must clear both chambers to reopen federal agencies. Concurrently, airlines face mandated flight cuts of up to 10% by mid-November amid FAA orders tied to the shutdown; former President Trump floated a $2,000-per-person tariff-funded payout, promoted a false claim about Obama’s Obamacare “royalties,” and criticized the BBC over its director general’s resignation. Additional developments: Ghislaine Maxwell’s happier prison transfer, and Trump’s contentious NFL attendance.

articles.title: US Senate vote marks step towards ending federal shutdown
articles.trailText: Senators vote on advancing House-passed stopgap funding bill, suggesting end to historic 40-day shutdown in reach
articles.summary: US Senate advanced House-passed stopgap funding bill aimed at ending the record 40-day shutdown, but excludes Democrats’ demand to extend Affordable Care Act subsidies. Majority Leader John Thune plans to combine short-term spending with three full-year appropriations and hold a separate vote on health credits “later.” Senate Democrats, including Blumenthal, Luján and progressives Sanders and Warren, oppose reopening without firm subsidy guarantees. House Democrats led by Jeffries vow to fight it. Shutdown hits federal workers, travel and air traffic, risks Q4 economic contraction. If passed, it still needs House approval and the president’s signature as healthcare costs surge.

articles.title: Trump shares false claim Obama earned $40m in ‘royalties’ from Obamacare
articles.trailText: US president promoted fictional claim from satirical website that has been debunked repeatedly since 2017
articles.summary: President Donald Trump posted on Truth Social that Barack Obama has earned $40 million in annual “royalties linked to Obamacare” since 2010, citing a screenshot from the satirical site America’s Last Line of Defense. The claim, first debunked in 2017 and republished by Christopher Blair’s network (including the Dunning-Kruger-Times), alleges $2.5 million yearly payments halted by DOGE. Despite questions, a White House spokesperson refused to say if Trump knew the claim was false.

articles.title: US agriculture department tells states to ‘undo��� Snap benefits for families in need
articles.trailText: Directive comes after supreme court order allowing Trump officials to pause food aid payments amid shutdown
articles.summary: After the Supreme Court paused a lower court ruling requiring full November SNAP funding amid a 40-day government shutdown, USDA instructed states to “undo” any issued full benefits as unauthorized, threatening to withhold admin costs and recoup overpayments. The memo, sent by Deputy Undersecretary Patrick Penn, has drawn ire from governors and senators—Wisconsin’s Tony Evers, Oregon’s Tina Kotek, Massachusetts’ Maura Healey and Sen. Amy Klobuchar—who vow legal resistance, question applicability to state-funded benefits, and decry the move as cruel amid a hunger crisis.

articles.title: Trump weighs giving Americans $2,000 from tariff revenues in bid for support
articles.trailText: Congressional approval would probably be required for plan to take effect, an idea Trump has floated before
articles.summary: Donald Trump proposed a $2,000 per-person “tariff dividend” funded by the administration’s collected duties—excluding high-income recipients—to boost public backing, though bipartisan congressional approval is required. Earlier in 2025, Sen. Josh Hawley introduced a $600 tariff-rebate bill. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent favors using $195 billion in duties to reduce the $38 trillion federal debt instead. Analysts warn a $2,000 payout to 150 million adults could cost $300–513 billion, far exceeding net tariff revenues. Consumers face an average 18% effective tariff rate—the highest since 1934—as firms pass costs onto buyers. The Supreme Court has expressed skepticism about the legality of Trump’s tariffs.

articles.title: Ghislaine Maxwell reportedly ‘much happier�� after prison transfer by Trump officials
articles.trailText: Jeffrey Epstein associate, serving 20 years for sex-trafficking crimes, is now in minimum-security federal prison in Texas
articles.summary: Emails obtained by NBC News and shared with the House Judiciary Committee reveal that Ghislaine Maxwell, serving a 20-year sentence for sex-trafficking, told friends she’s “much, much happier” after a Trump administration-ordered move in August from a low-security Florida prison to the minimum-security Federal Prison Camp Bryan in Texas. In her messages, Maxwell praised clean facilities, better food, responsive staff and an orderly environment, likening it to “Alice in Wonderland.” Experts and victims criticized the transfer as unprecedented VIP treatment. Her lawyer and brother denounced the leaks as privacy breaches. The U.S. Supreme Court recently refused to hear her appeal.

articles.title: They flew to New York to help Mamdani – now they want to bring the hope to LA
articles.trailText: Activists in Los Angeles say the energy from the Hollywood strikes has been reignited by the success of the mayor-elect
articles.summary: Los Angeles-based DSA members like screenwriter Neda Davarpanah, organizer Leslie Chang and animator Paul Zappia flew to New York to canvass for mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani, drawing energy from his grassroots, policy-driven campaign. They encountered high voter enthusiasm and strong field tactics—group canvassing, direct council member engagement, call-and-response rallies—contrasting with waning momentum in local struggles. Planning to adapt these lessons back home, the 4,000-member DSA–LA chapter aims to replicate Mamdani’s organizing model in LA’s geographically sprawling city council and school board races, turning New York’s hope into California action.

articles.title: Zohran Mamdani has made the future a bit brighter | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: New York’s mayor-elect | Foxhunting | Local shops | Where’s cool? | Guardian letter writers
articles.summary: Readers draw lessons from Zohran Mamdani’s New York mayoral upset, arguing that bold, progressive solutions and an inclusive message of hope—echoing Barack Obama’s remark that “the future looks a little bit brighter”—can galvanize centre-left politics. Other letters lament that foxhunting persists illegally 252 years after its ban, blame local shoppers (not chains) for killing community shops by chasing lower prices and deliveries, cite Holger Czukay’s declaration that real “cool” is “in the pool,” and taunt the smugness of Guardian letter writers.

articles.title: US flight cancellations rise as Sean Duffy warns travel could reduce to a ‘trickle’
articles.trailText: More than 2,500 flights cancelled as transportation secretary says flight reductions could reach 20% if shutdown persists
articles.summary: FAA ordered 4% flight cuts at 40 major US airports amid the 40-day government shutdown, causing over 2,500 cancellations through Sunday. Sean Duffy warns reductions could climb to 20% if the impasse endures, potentially grounding many travelers before the holidays. With 20–40% of air traffic controllers absent and working unpaid extended shifts, safety concerns rise. Airlines offer full refunds while the controllers’ union delivered 1,600 letters urging Congress to reopen the government. Lawmakers trade blame as analysts warn broader economic fallout—from freight and shipping costs to tourism and manufacturing—if disruptions persist into Thanksgiving.

articles.title: Trump claims the national guard makes cities safer. Birmingham halved its homicide rate all on its own
articles.trailText: Local observers cite a reversal of social dynamics, a revitalized police department and violence intervention
articles.summary: Birmingham cut homicides by more than half in the first 286 days of 2025 (from 132 to 63 murders, rate down from 86.3 to ~42 per 100,000) without National Guard deployment. Officials credit a reversal of pandemic-era social dynamics, a revamped police force, a robust violence-intervention program and last year’s arrest of alleged contract killer Damien McDaniel (accused of 18 slayings). Despite the drop in killings, aggravated assaults remain flat, shootings persist amid high poverty and easy gun access, and residents still report feeling unsafe. Mayor Woodfin’s commission calls for focused deterrence, community investment and expanded support services.

articles.title: California’s drying Salton Sea harms the lungs of people living nearby, say researchers
articles.trailText: Experts suspect that dust from the sea contains endotoxic bacteria membranes caused by fertilizer runoff
articles.summary: Peer-reviewed UC Irvine research on 500 children living near the shrinking Salton Sea finds chemical-laden dust from exposed, pesticide- and fertilizer-contaminated lakebed impairs lung capacity, with closer proximity linked to wheezing and reduced forced expiratory volume. A UC Riverside study in mice shows the dust’s endotoxin-rich bacterial membranes alter lung microbiome, triggering non-allergic asthma. The findings highlight a public health crisis for low-income, largely Latino communities downwind up to 100 miles. Advocates call for nutrient-removing wetlands, masks, home air filtration and improved water management to curb toxic dust exposure.

articles.title: ‘Too far? I don’t think we’ve gone far enough!’ The founder of Peta on gruesome stunts and her bloody fight for animal rights
articles.trailText: After 45 years as chief fake blood thrower, Ingrid Newkirk is still waging war on everything from leather to cashmere. Is she still relevant?
articles.summary: Ingrid Newkirk, 76, PETA co-founder, remains agitator-in-chief after 45 years of graphic stunts—from fake-blood protests to a hair-infused scarf for Anna Wintour—to challenge animal exploitation in fashion, food and research. Drawing headlines with “I’d rather go naked” campaigns, plane-crash will gags and Holocaust analogies, she pioneered shareholding and boardroom tactics alongside theatrical direct action. With over 10 million supporters and 800 staff, her methods helped spur Gucci, H&M and others to drop fur and down, yet critics question PETA’s relevance amid climate and sustainability priorities.

articles.title: ‘Godfather of the Trump presidency’: the direct through-line from Dick Cheney to Donald Trump
articles.trailText: A proponent of the unitary executive theory, Cheney helped expand the vast presidential powers Trump enjoys today
articles.summary: Dick Cheney, vice-president under George W Bush, championed the “unitary executive theory” to vastly expand presidential power after 9/11—pre-emptive war, warrantless NSA wiretaps, Patriot Act, enemy combatant doctrine and “torture memos.” Those precedents paved the way for Donald Trump’s aggressive use of unilateral authority against immigrants, narco-traffickers and dissenters, exploiting a polarized, gridlocked Congress and recent Supreme Court rulings. Though Cheney later condemned Trump’s excesses, his institutional assault on checks and balances remains the “godfather” of the current presidency’s authoritarian reach.

articles.title: Trump’s assault on voting intensifies as midterms loom: ‘A wholesale attack on free and fair elections’
articles.trailText: The White House is manipulating voting system, from redistricting to rule changes, to affect the midterms
articles.summary: Over a year before the 2026 midterms, Trump and allies are mounting a comprehensive effort to reshape US voting: pressing redistricting beyond the decennial cycle to gerrymander additional GOP seats, pushing emergency-powers doctrines to station federal agents or military at polls, demanding purges of voter rolls, strict ID rules and an end to mail-in ballots, while DOJ abandons voting-rights defenses and DHS cuts election security. Experts warn this "wholesale attack on free and fair elections" leverages intimidation and misinformation, fueling legal challenges and community fears of disenfranchisement and authoritarian overreach.

articles.title: Trump tariffs and strict US border rules threaten flight of Canada’s ‘snowbirds’
articles.trailText: Annual migration from frigid Canadian winter to Florida sunshine could become thinner as travellers look elsewhere
articles.summary: Canada’s 'snowbirds' winter migration to Florida is thinning due to Trump’s tariffs and stricter US immigration measures. Bookings at Fort Lauderdale rentals have declined, deposits forfeited, and many older Canadians abandoning plans: only 26% plan US trips this winter, down from 41%, and just 10% of those 61+ versus 33% last year. New US rules mandate biometric data, photos on entry/exit and mandatory registration. Snowbirds’ $20.5bn spending supports US hospitality and retail; even a 10% drop risks $2.1bn lost. Meanwhile Canada’s tourism revenue rose 6% as some travelers stay home or shift to Mexico.

articles.title: Rescued California hunter thought he’d have to watch family ‘from heaven’ – and offers advice
articles.trailText: Ron Dailey, 65, survived nearly three weeks in the frosty, mountainous wilderness after taking a wrong turn
articles.summary: Ron Dailey, 65, endured 21 days stranded in the snowbound Sierra National Forest after a wrong turn damaged his truck. Rationing 900 calories into under 70 per day, melting snow for water and using a solar charger with no signal, he twice texted farewell to his family, fearing death. Building fires with flint, toilet paper and wood, he eventually hiked nearly five miles before spotting fellow hunters who rescued him on Nov. 1. Treated and released, Dailey advises always carrying extra supplies.

articles.title: How Mamdani is defying immigrant expectations by embracing his identity: ‘His boldness resonates’
articles.trailText: New York City mayor-elect refused to ‘be in the shadows’ in the face of Islamophobic attacks during his campaign
articles.summary: New York’s mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani, a Muslim Ugandan immigrant and democratic socialist, openly embraced his identity amid Islamophobic smears and smear ads during his campaign. Born in Kampala to a Muslim father and Hindu mother, he vowed “not to be in the shadows,” rejecting extremist labels. Supported by groups like the Indian American Muslim Council and CAAAV, he mobilized working-class immigrants on housing and affordability and united Jews, Muslims, Hindus and Christians. In his victory speech he quoted Eugene Debs and Jawaharlal Nehru. His parents—scholar-activist Mahmood Mamdani and filmmaker Mira Nair—embody pluralism that informs his inclusive platform.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: President suggests scrapping Obamacare as shutdown flight chaos continues
articles.trailText: Trump urged Republican senators to redirect federal money toward direct payments to individuals. Key US politics stories from 8 November at a glance
articles.summary: President Donald Trump urged Senate Republicans to redirect hundreds of billions used to subsidize Obamacare into direct payments so individuals can buy private health plans—an idea backed by Graham, Scott and Cassidy but requiring eight Democratic votes and still dependent on insurers—on the 39th day of the federal shutdown. Airlines canceled 1,460 flights on day two of mandatory cuts, raising Thanksgiving travel concerns. Meanwhile, GOP senators floated ACA repeal, Trump pressed to name Washington’s new NFL stadium after himself, global firms braced for extra steel tariffs, and controversies erupted over Olivia Rodrigo and a DHS jet purchase.

articles.title: Border patrol chief reprimanded for lying claims shots were fired at immigration officers in Chicago
articles.trailText: Gregory Bovino was called out by a judge only two days earlier for lying about being assaulted by a protester
articles.summary: Border Patrol chief Gregory Bovino, a prominent Trump administration enforcement figure, claimed in early November that agents were “shot at” during Chicago raids, citing DHS statements. Chicago police found no evidence of gunfire; one officer was only struck by a vehicle. This allegation came days after Judge Sara Ellis concluded Bovino lied about being hit by a rock before deploying tear gas in Little Village. Critics highlight a pattern of false statements amid aggressive raids that have led to over 3,000 arrests, including US citizens.

articles.title: Senate Republicans embrace Trump’s call – from his Florida golf course – to replace Obamacare
articles.trailText: Amid a historic government shutdown, some senators on Capitol Hill are working this weekend on an unpopular bill
articles.summary: Amid the longest US government shutdown—delaying SNAP for 42 M Americans, halting pay for federal workers and grounding flights—Senate Republicans Lindsey Graham, Rick Scott and Bill Cassidy seized Trump’s weekend Truth Social proposal to scrap Obamacare’s ACA subsidies and funnel billions into health savings accounts. They argue direct payments will spur competition and lower premiums, but critics warn insurers still dominate markets and preexisting-condition coverage could be gutted. Democrats like Schumer and Warren reject repeal, pressing for immediate subsidy extensions. Moderate senators debate a temporary ACA tax-credit renewal, yet no bipartisan breakthrough emerged before the recess.

articles.title: Kristi Noem reportedly tried to buy 10 engineless Spirit Airlines planes that airline didn’t own
articles.trailText: Wall Street Journal reports DHS secretary arranged purchase to expand deportation flights and for personal travel
articles.summary: According to the Wall Street Journal, DHS Secretary Kristi Noem and GOP operative Corey Lewandowski sought to buy ten Boeing 737s from Spirit Airlines (aircraft the bankrupt carrier didn’t own and which lacked engines) to expand deportation flights and for personal travel. ICE officials warned buying jets would cost far more than extending existing charters, and the purchase has been paused. Separately, Democratic appropriators questioned DHS’s sole-source $200 million Gulfstream G700 jet deal during this government shutdown. The department disputes parts of the report.

articles.title: Driver livestreams herself on TikTok as she apparently hits and kills man in Chicago
articles.trailText: TikTok video shows woman speaking into camera and reacting to a loud thud before she says ‘I just hit somebody’
articles.summary: Investigators in Zion, Illinois, are probing a newly surfaced TikTok livestream in which a 43-year-old woman (user “Tea_Tyme_3”) fatally struck 59-year-old Darren Lucas at 5:30pm. A screen recording published Friday shows the driver reacting to a loud thud—“Fuck, fuck… I just hit somebody”—before the stream cuts. Authorities say no drugs or alcohol were involved and the driver remained at the scene. A Lake County state’s attorney is reviewing the video. Reddit witnesses say she was distracted by comments and grinning at her phone, making the crash “entirely avoidable.” Lucas’s family mourns his preventable death.

articles.title: Palestinian American hails Virginia win: ‘You can be bold on the Gaza genocide and still be victorious’
articles.trailText: Democrat Sam Rasoul, a Muslim, won re-election to the state legislature despite accusations of antisemitism
articles.summary: Virginia Democrat Sam Rasoul, the longest-serving Muslim state lawmaker, won re-election with 70% of the vote in his Roanoke-area district despite antisemitism accusations after calling Israel’s assault on Gaza genocide. An American Palestinian in office since 2014, Rasoul increased his margin by over 5%, arguing voters value honesty and deep grassroots organizing. A progressive ally of New York��s Zohran Mamdani, he centers affordability, housing and utilities in his agenda. Attacked by opponents and some Democrats, Rasoul credits his principled stance on Gaza and regular constituent outreach for securing victory in a conservative-leaning region.

articles.title: Near Ohio air force base, food pantries and businesses grapple with effects of shutdown
articles.trailText: As tens of thousands of military personnel work without pay and others are furloughed, a local pantry sees its numbers increasing as restaurants are losing customers
articles.summary: Near Wright-Patterson AFB in Fairborn, Ohio — the state’s largest employer with 38,000 personnel — the federal shutdown has doubled demand at the Fairborn Fish Food Pantry from about 250 to 500 families daily, including 300 children. Some 8,100 base civilians and contractors face furloughs, straining local businesses such as Tik’s Thai Express, now serving only a handful of customers. The base generates $16 billion locally and supports 40,000 off-base jobs. With emergency food and shelter funds cut and back-pay uncertain, county authorities and the Dayton Foodbank have delivered hundreds of emergency boxes. Pantry operators warn meat supplies are unsustainable and urge political compromise.

articles.title: Democrats just won back Latinos who voted for Trump. Will they be convinced to stick around?
articles.trailText: Though Latino voters gave sweeping support to Democrats in Tuesday’s elections, they’re not a permanent coalition
articles.summary: Latino voters who backed Trump in 2024 swung decisively to Democrats in the 2025 off-year elections, delivering 68% support for Mikie Sherrill in New Jersey and 67% for Abigail Spanberger in Virginia. Exit polls show backlash against aggressive immigration enforcement—up to 70% of Latino voters in California and 77% in Virginia deemed Trump’s policies too extreme—alongside improved economic sentiment. Republicans’ assumption of lasting Latino realignment is challenged, risking GOP-drawn districts. Analysts warn Latinos remain a swing bloc sensitive to policy, turnout and community impact.

articles.title: Washington National Opera may move out of Kennedy Center due to Trump ‘takeover’
articles.trailText: Ticket sales at about 40% unsold compared with before president made himself chair of US performing arts center
articles.summary: After Donald Trump ousted the Kennedy Center’s bipartisan board in February and installed Richard Grenell as president, WNO artistic director Francesca Zambello warns donor confidence has collapsed and ticket sales have slid from 80–90% capacity to around 60%, with many patrons boycotting the venue. Under a new “net neutral” budget edict and pressure to stage cheaper, more crowd-pleasing works, WNO faces a $2–3m subsidy at risk. With affiliate agreements renewed before the takeover, the company is now scouting alternative DC theaters for its 2026–27 season, though its board maintains it hopes to remain at the Kennedy Center.

articles.title: Businesses worldwide brace for extra Trump tariffs on steel imports
articles.trailText: Commerce department expected to add about 700 more items with steel content to levy list at request of US firms
articles.summary: US firms, from Guardian Bikes to Red Gold and kitchenware makers, have petitioned the Commerce Dept to expand Trump-era steel-derivative tariffs, adding about 700 items—bicycles, baking trays, tin cans, industrial machines—to the August list of 407 products. European exporters warn this ‘expansionist’ move undercuts existing 10–25% UK and 25–50% EU agreements, potentially layering new levies on top of baseline rates.
