With nearly all past requests approved and a decision due in December, firms fear rolling global import duties will disrupt transatlantic trade.

articles.title: Maha movement helps to kill bill seeking US food-safety rollbacks
articles.trailText: Public health advocates praise rewrite of legislation backed by big-food influence operation AFIT
articles.summary: A bipartisan coalition of public health advocates, led by figures in the Maha movement, forced Senator Roger Marshall to strip pre-emption language from the Better Food Disclosure Act, defeating industry front-group Americans for Ingredient Transparency (AFIT). AFIT, funded by ConAgra, Coca-Cola, PepsiCo and others and headed by a former Trump official, had posed as grassroots Maha to kill state truth-in-labeling laws on toxic food chemicals. Opponents say its bid would have privileged weaker federal standards and undermined state protections.

articles.title: A year after devastating Trump loss, have the Democrats begun to find their way back?
articles.trailText: Party was shell-shocked after 2024 defeat but Tuesday night’s coast-to-coast romp signals brighter times ahead
articles.summary: After a crushing 2024 defeat left Democrats divided and doubting their identity, Tuesday’s coast-to-coast victories—spanning redistricting in California, governor wins by VA’s Abigail Spanberger and NJ’s Mikie Sherrill, and NY’s first Muslim mayor Zohran Mamdani—bolster a party embracing both populist disruption and pragmatic centrism. By mobilizing youth, Latinos, and disaffected Trump voters, Democrats signaled a strategic shift: no longer guardians of the old order but a combative “fire-with-fire” coalition. Yet persistent ideological rifts over boldness versus caution and the path for 2026–28 underline that unity remains their greatest test.

articles.title: ShutdownTok: federal workers detail life without pay amid government’s closure
articles.trailText: Federal employees on social media share practical tips and document lives amid longest US shutdown in history
articles.summary: Federal employees have turned to TikTok, Instagram, YouTube and Reddit to document life without pay during the longest US shutdown ever, blending dark humor with day-to-day survival tips. Courteney Bush’s “Shutdown Diaries” rates her mood B-minus while offering coping strategies; Deidre Drakes uses satire to process furlough stress; and influencers curate resource guides for SNAP pauses, budget meals and legal aid. DC creator Lola Ajayi’s viral Google doc tracks local support services, and contractor Robert Perez runs a mile a day while unpacking shutdown civics. Together, they build online communities and amplify furloughed workers’ experiences nationwide.

articles.title: Zohran Mamdani’s win shows the power of mobilizing non-voters | Ben Davis
articles.trailText: Mamdani reshaped the electorate, bringing hundreds of thousands of non-voters out to the polls, from young people to left-behind immigrant communities
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani’s NYC council victory demonstrates how mobilizing hundreds of thousands of non-voters—young people and overlooked immigrant communities—can reshape the electorate to reflect city demographics. By building a class-based, cross-racial coalition of lower-income renters and transit users, he overcame wealthy liberal and conservative voters. His campaign enlisted 100,000 volunteers—one in ten supporters—reviving politics as community action. His success comes amid a broader off-year backlash against Republican policies, underscoring the power of grassroots organizing over top-down cultural narratives. Mamdani’s model offers a blueprint for anti-establishment, democratic socialist resistance and rebuilding working-class political agency.

articles.title: World’s longest-married couple reveals key to a lasting relationship: ‘We love each other’
articles.trailText: Eleanor Gittens, 107, and Lyle Gittens, 108, of Miami met at a basketball game in 1941 and have been married for 83 years
articles.summary: Eleanor Gittens, 107, and Lyle Gittens, 108, of Miami recently became the world’s longest-married couple at 83 years, as verified by LongeviQuest using their 1942 marriage certificate and archival data. They met at a Clark Atlanta basketball game in 1941, wed on June 4, 1942 during WWII segregation, and sustained their bond through wartime letters. They built careers in New York, raised three children, and Eleanor earned a doctorate at 69. Together they are over 216 years old and credit their secret to simple love.

articles.title: Trump-Orbán meeting: US gives Hungary exemption from sanctions on Russian oil and gas
articles.trailText: US president also praises Hungarian leader’s hardline stance on immigration during friendly White House summit
articles.summary: The US granted Hungary a one-year exemption from Trump-era sanctions on Russian oil after Viktor Orbán pressed his case at a White House summit, pledging to buy $600m of US LNG and nuclear fuel. Trump praised Orbán’s hardline immigration stance, urged EU leaders to respect him and endorsed a potential Trump-Putin summit to end the Ukraine war. Orbán denounced the Biden administration as “rigged,” faces EU penalties over democracy and rule-of-law breaches, and seeks Trump’s visit to bolster his re-election bid amid Kremlin-influence concerns.

articles.title: ‘Huge victory’ in Portland as judge’s final order bars Trump from sending national guard
articles.trailText: Karin Immergut said earlier she ‘found no credible evidence’ that protests in Oregon city were out of control
articles.summary: US District Judge Karin Immergut, a Trump appointee, issued a final order barring Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and DHS Secretary Kristi Noem from deploying Oregon National Guard troops to Portland, finding no credible evidence of widespread violence at protests near the city’s ICE facility. She ruled demonstrations were “predominately peaceful,” with only isolated low-level clashes mostly between protesters and counter-protesters. The injunction follows an earlier restraining order, a lawsuit by Portland and Oregon, and testimony from law enforcement. Oregon AG Dan Rayfield called it a “huge victory,” and the administration plans to appeal.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: supreme court blocks full Snap food aid payments following White House request
articles.trailText: The high court’s order came after a federal appeals court denied the administration’s request to block an order to distribute November’s full monthly food stamp benefits – key US politics stories from 7 November 2025
articles.summary: After a federal appeals court refused to block an order requiring the Trump administration to fully fund November’s SNAP benefits amid a shutdown, the White House obtained a Supreme Court emergency stay pausing full food-stamp payments to nearly 42 million Americans. AG Pam Bondi vowed to continue fighting to advance President Trump’s agenda. Updates: SCOTUS may hear a same-sex marriage challenge; a judge barred Trump from deploying the Guard to Portland; over 100 universities staged protests; Hungary earned a one-year sanctions reprieve; and Trump threatened to boycott the G20 over South Africa’s alleged mistreatment of white farmers.

articles.title: Republicans reject Democrats’ proposal to end longest shutdown in US history
articles.trailText: Chuck Schumer offered a deal to reopen the government in exchange for a one-year healthcare subsidies extension
articles.summary: Senate Republicans rejected Chuck Schumer’s proposal to end the 38-day government shutdown by pairing a clean funding bill with a one-year extension of ACA tax credits. Leader John Thune refused, saying tax subsidies should be negotiated only after the government reopens. With the House in recess, no immediate end is in sight. The funding lapse has paused food aid payments and cut FAA capacity, canceling roughly 800 flights. Both parties face mounting pressure: Democrats buoyed by recent state wins, Republicans warned by Trump against preserving the filibuster.

articles.title: ICE facing fierce backlash after video apparently shows unconscious man clutching child during arrest
articles.trailText: Footage shows commotion inside vehicle in Massachusetts as desperate woman in passenger seat tries to awaken man
articles.summary: Viral video from Fitchburg, MA, shows ICE agents attempting to arrest Juliana Milena Ojeda-Montoya—wanted on a local assault and battery warrant—while her husband, Carlos Sebastian Zapata, collapses unconscious clutching their young child. DHS and ICE insist Zapata faked a seizure to thwart the arrest and refused medical aid; he counters that agents pushed him, struck his ribs and pressed on his neck. Occurring amid Trump’s intensified deportation campaign, the incident has sparked fierce criticism of ICE’s tactics.

articles.title: Indiana woman who was at wrong home address to clean fatally shot by resident
articles.trailText: Officers found Maria Florinda Rios Perez De Velasquez dead after she accidentally went to a wrong property
articles.summary: Authorities in Whitestown, Indiana, are reviewing charges against the homeowner who fatally shot 32-year-old Maria Florinda Rios Perez De Velasquez early Nov. 7 after she and a cleaning crew mistakenly entered his property. Officers found Perez De Velasquez—a mother of four—dead on the front porch. Police turned over their investigation Friday to Boone County prosecutor Kent Eastwood. The case centers on Indiana’s castle-doctrine law, which allows use of deadly force against perceived unlawful entry; 31 states have similar statutes.

articles.title: Students and faculty at over 100 US universities protest against Trump’s attacks
articles.trailText: Student, national and local groups across US organized day of action to condemn Trump’s assault on academic freedom
articles.summary: Students, faculty and staff at over 100 US campuses joined ‘Students Rise Up’ protests against the Trump administration’s push to tie federal funding to conservative ideology. Organized with Sunrise Movement, Campus Climate Network and unions like AAUP, participants walked out, unfurled banners and demanded affordable education, protection for trans and international students, fair faculty contracts, weapon divestment and immigrant support. Only New College of Florida accepted the administration’s ‘compact.’ Demonstrations ranged from handprint demands at Brown to a rally at Apollo Global Management, targeting billionaire donor Marc Rowan. Organizers plan May Day strikes and a 2028 general strike to defend academic freedom.

articles.title: Virginia Republican who shared violent texts from prominent Democrat loses re-election
articles.trailText: Carrie Coyner conceded defeat after igniting text scandal over Democrat imagining ‘two bullets’ in rival’s head
articles.summary: Carrie Coyner conceded after a narrow 52.5%-47.3% loss to Democrat Lindsey Dougherty in Virginia's competitive House district. Coyner had publicized 2022 texts from former colleague Jay Jones imagining "two bullets to the head" of GOP speaker Todd Gilbert, a scandal Republicans leveraged to attack Jones and governor hopeful Abigail Spanberger. Despite outcry, Jones and Spanberger still won statewide. Coyner plans to refocus on family and her law practice. Her defeat aligns with broader GOP struggles amid low Trump approval. Jones has apologized; he's tapped ex-Governor Ralph Northam to lead his AG transition.

articles.title: Cornell University settles with Trump administration to restore $250m in funds
articles.trailText: Upstate New York institution is the fifth university under government investigation to bow to White House demands
articles.summary: Cornell University agreed to a settlement with the Trump administration to lift a freeze on $250 million in federal research funds, becoming the fifth campus under Title VI scrutiny. The deal requires Cornell to share admissions data, pay $30 million, invest another $30 million in agricultural AI and robotics research, evaluate Jewish students’ campus climate, and incorporate the administration’s anti-DEI civil-rights framework in training. Amid national student and faculty protests, Education Secretary Linda McMahon hailed it as an anti-DEI victory, while President Michael Kotlikoff insisted it preserves Cornell’s independence.

articles.title: Outrage mounts in Oklahoma over plea deal for rapist: ‘That’s sketchy as hell’
articles.trailText: Jesse Butler, 18, faced 78 years in prison, but judge reduced sentence to community service and counseling
articles.summary: An Oklahoma judge granted 18-year-old Jesse Butler youthful offender status on 10 charges—including rape, strangulation and domestic assault—committed at 17, reducing a potential 78-year adult sentence to 150 hours of community service, counseling, curfew and regular check-ins under Oklahoma’s Youthful Offender Act. The plea-in-nocontest deal, overseen by Judge Susan C. Worthington and linked to local alumni ties, has spurred protests and calls for the resignation of Payne County DA Laura Thomas. Victims, who were classmates, say the punishment trivializes nearly lethal assaults and silences survivors.

articles.title: There’s nothing cooler than knowing your stuff | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Barack Obama on what’s not cool | Nick Lowe | Huey Lewis and the News | Caesar’s ‘English’ invasion | Awkward street names
articles.summary: A batch of Guardian reader letters on what’s ‘cool’: Ian Dawson Heywood invokes Barack Obama’s 2016 Rutgers address—‘ignorance is not a virtue’—to argue that not knowing isn’t ‘keeping it real.’ Susan Baillie hails singer-songwriter Nick Lowe, author of the album Jesus of Cool. David Hodgetts recalls Huey Lewis and the News’ 1986 anthem ‘Hip to Be Square.’ Martin Pilgrim corrects that Romans first invaded Iron Age Cantium (now Kent), not England or Britain. David Edwards highlights calls to rename Thamesmead’s Epstein Road.

articles.title: An Arizona town is dreading plans to turn its prison into an ICE facility: ‘It’s morally objectionable’
articles.trailText: In Marana, residents crowded into a town hall recently to learn the fate of a building that’s been closed for two years
articles.summary: Marana, AZ residents (pop. 63,700) are mobilizing against plans by Management & Training Corporation to convert a closed mid-1990s prison into an ICE detention center, financed by a $45 billion federal budget for expanded immigrant detention. At an Oct. 23 town hall, farmers, local officials and Pima County supervisor Jennifer Allen decried jailing taxpaying immigrants—71.5 percent without criminal convictions—citing family separations, depressed home values and lax oversight under existing prison zoning. MTC reacquired the facility for $15 million after its 2023 state closure; critics recall its 2015 Kingman-prison riot history and compare the move to SB1070-style enforcement in a Trump-era deportation drive.

articles.title: Trump loyalist Elise Stefanik announces run for New York governor
articles.trailText: Self-styled ‘ultra-Maga’ Republican representative has ramped up attacks on Democratic incumbent Kathy Hochul
articles.summary: Republican Rep. Elise Stefanik, a staunch “ultra-MAGA” Trump loyalist, formally launched her New York governor bid this week, securing key GOP endorsements even as progressive Zohran Mamdani won New York City’s mayoralty. Stefanik has intensified attacks on Democratic Gov. Kathy Hochul—blaming her for high taxes, rising living costs and accusing her of bending the knee to “Commie” Mamdani—in social media posts and a Fox News interview. Hochul’s campaign fired back with ads and the microsite SelloutStefanik.com, while House Democrats led by Hakeem Jeffries denounced Stefanik as Trump’s “handmaiden,” highlighting her evolution from moderate freshman to impeachment backer and election denier.

articles.title: Supreme court considering taking up case challenging legality of same-sex marriage
articles.trailText: Court could revisit issue in case brought by county clerk who refused to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples
articles.summary: The Supreme Court is weighing Davis v. Ermold, a challenge from former Kentucky clerk Kim Davis, who refused to issue same-sex marriage licenses in 2015. After a Sixth Circuit ruling denied her religious-liberty defense and upheld $100,000 in damages to plaintiffs David Ermold and David Moore, Davis asks SCOTUS to reverse that decision—and potentially Obergefell. With a 6-3 conservative bench, just four votes suffice to hear the case, which critics warn could unsettle nearly 800,000 existing same-sex unions. A cert decision may come Monday.

articles.title: Seven people hospitalized after package with ‘white powder’ opened at Joint Base Andrews
articles.trailText: Investigation ongoing after package was sent to the home of the US president’s Air Force One
articles.summary: On Nov. 7 a suspicious envelope containing unknown white powder arrived at Joint Base Andrews, Maryland – home to Air Force One. After opening the package in an Air National Guard Readiness Center building, seven personnel experienced symptoms and were briefly hospitalized at Malcolm Grow Medical Center; all have since been released. The building and an adjacent facility were evacuated and cordoned off. HAZMAT tests found no immediate threat. The scene was turned over to the Air Force Office of Special Investigations, and an investigation remains active.

articles.title: First Thing: Judge orders Trump administration to stop ‘needless suffering’ and fully fund food stamps
articles.trailText: Policy means ‘people will go hungry, food pantries will be overburdened’, says judge. Plus, Tesla shareholders approve $1tn pay package for Musk
articles.summary: US District Judge John J. McConnell Jr ordered the Trump administration to fully fund November’s Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program for 42 million low-income Americans by today, rejecting its plan to deliver half payments amid the 38-day shutdown. He warned reduced aid will cause “irreparable harm,” leaving families hungry and food banks overwhelmed. Feeding America reports one in eight people lacks enough to eat. Lawmakers remain deadlocked even as some Democrats leverage electoral wins for tougher budget terms.

articles.title: Out-of-touch Trump talks up economy among sycophants and stars in Miami
articles.trailText: President jets in to speak at ritzy American Business Forum as millions see their food aid slashed – crisis, what crisis?
articles.summary: At a $1,990-ticket American Business Forum in Miami, headlined by Trump, tycoons like Bezos mingled at an opulent, politically charged event juxtaposed against a record‐long government shutdown that slashed SNAP benefits for 42 million Americans (3 million in Florida). Guests received $50 meal cards even as advocates decried the insensitivity. Trump lauded his “economic miracle,” attacked Democrats, and shared the stage with figures from Messi and Nadal to Argentina’s Javier Milei and Saudi investment chiefs. Critics say the spectacle underscores elite detachment as half of Miami‐Dade relies on food aid; DeSantis refused emergency SNAP funding.

articles.title: Who are the contenders for Nancy Pelosi’s long-held San Francisco seat?
articles.trailText: After nearly 40 years in the Congress, the former House speaker is stepping down, reigniting interest in the race
articles.summary: Pelosi’s retirement after nearly 40 years has drawn two Democrats: Saikat Chakrabarti—39, ex-Ocasio-Cortez chief of staff—proposing universal healthcare, childcare, a ban on congressional stock trading and ending Gaza funding, backed by a 2,000-volunteer grassroots operation; and Scott Wiener—55, state senator and attorney—spotlighting housing, climate bills, a law banning masked police, and his $1 million war chest to oppose Trump’s assaults on immigrants and LGBTQ people. Christine Pelosi and supervisor Connie Chan are also mentioned as potential entrants.

articles.title: Readers on Zohran Mamdani’s victory: ‘It was a collective exhale’
articles.trailText: Hundreds from New York City, across the US and beyond share their optimism, joy and more on the mayoral election
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani, 34-year-old democratic socialist and Queens assembly member, won NYC’s mayoral race with over 50% against Andrew Cuomo and Curtis Sliwa. Guardian readers from the city, across the US and overseas described a ��collective exhale,” expressing hope for affordability, renewed political engagement and a “breath of fresh air.” Many praised his people-centric message and urged Democrats to embrace progressive change. Some cautioned he’ll face establishment resistance, safety risks and federal pushback. A minority voiced skepticism about his experience and policies, but most see his victory as inspiration for broader progressive movements.

articles.title: Deep red and swing states making election flip to Democrats indicate Trump’s plunging popularity
articles.trailText: Results in smaller districts may offer even greater insight into the US political landscape heading into the midterms
articles.summary: Democrats' 2025 off-year elections saw state and local flips in GOP bastions, from Zohran Mamdani's NY victory to local upsets. In Erie County, PA, Christina Vogel won county executive by 24 points; in VA’s 66th district, Nicole Cole ended a 36-year GOP hold. Georgia Democrats seized two public service commission seats, first statewide wins since 2006. Deep-red Mississippi flipped two senate seats, breaking the GOP supermajority. Onondaga (NY) and Luzerne (PA) shifted to Democrats. Colorado approved universal school meals; Maine rejected stricter ID laws. Trump’s approval falls to 37% as Dems build momentum for midterms.

articles.title: US strikes another alleged drug boat bringing death toll from campaign in Latin America to 70
articles.trailText: US strikes have destroyed at least 18 vessels, but Washington has yet to make public any concrete evidence that its targets posed a threat to America
articles.summary: US forces, under Trump’s campaign against Latin American drug trafficking, struck another alleged smuggling vessel in international waters, killing three, raising total deaths to at least 70 and destroying 18 boats. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth called the target a “Designated Terrorist Organization” operated boat and warned narco-terrorists of lethal US response. The strikes—criticized as extrajudicial and lacking public evidence of a threat—are backed by six Navy ships, F-35s in Puerto Rico and a carrier strike group. The Senate blocked a resolution to limit such strikes, while Venezuela’s Maduro condemns the operations amid indictments and regional tension.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: administration reduces US flights as shutdown stretches on
articles.trailText: Experts predict hundreds if not thousands of flights could be canceled at dozens of major airports
articles.summary: On day 38 of the record federal shutdown, the FAA mandated a 4% air-traffic cut in high-volume US markets by Nov 8, forcing up to 1,800 flight cancellations (≈268,000 seats) at major hubs from Atlanta to San Francisco and DC-area airports. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy said it’s ‘not about politics’ but safety. Meanwhile, the Supreme Court allowed enforcement of Trump’s trans passport sex-marker ban; a judge ordered full November SNAP funding; Nancy Pelosi announced her retirement; the administration capped prices on emerging GLP-1 weight-loss drugs; and the Senate blocked Democrats’ effort to limit his Venezuela strike authority.

articles.title: US airlines cancel flights after aviation agency directive to cut air traffic
articles.trailText: United, Southwest and Delta have announced they will be reducing flights amid continuing government shutdown
articles.summary: Facing a 37-day government shutdown and an air traffic controller shortage, the FAA has ordered a 4% reduction in flights at 40 major US airports from Friday 6 am–10 pm to preserve safety. United, Southwest and Delta will cancel thousands of flights—Delta 170 on Friday, SWA 120, United 4% through Sunday—potentially 1,800 flights and 268,000 seats, hitting hubs like Atlanta, LAX, Dallas/Fort Worth, Miami and all DC-area airports. Cuts may rise to 10% pre-Thanksgiving. Airlines vow rolling schedule updates and customer flexibility, but delays and strain on unpaid controllers mount amid bipartisan budget deadlock.

articles.title: Death toll from UPS plane crash at Louisville airport rises to 13
articles.trailText: Firm released names of the three victims on the plane and investigators confirmed plane’s left wing caught fire
articles.summary: UPS cargo plane Flight 2976 crashed after takeoff from Louisville airport when its left wing caught fire and an engine fell off, killing all 13 onboard, including Captain Richard Wartenberg, First Officer Lee Truitt and Relief Officer Captain Dana Diamond. Mayor Craig Greenberg and UPS confirmed the fatalities. NTSB investigators are probing the MD-11’s maintenance history, including weeks of repairs in San Antonio, and analyzing intact cockpit recorders. Meanwhile, Louisville airport and UPS Worldport have resumed normal operations.

articles.title: Senate blocks Democrats’ bid to check Trump power over Venezuela strikes
articles.trailText: Resolution fails 49-51 with only two Republican senators voting in favor as president increases military buildup
articles.summary: The Senate on Nov. 6 defeated a Democratic war powers resolution, 49–51, that would have forced President Trump to secure congressional approval before expanding strikes in Venezuela. Only Republicans Rand Paul and Lisa Murkowski joined Democrats; GOP moderates Susan Collins and Thom Tillis opposed it. The vote follows failed efforts to rein in boat strikes on alleged drug-trafficking vessels and comes as the administration has deployed a carrier to the Caribbean, developed options to hit land targets and sought a Justice Department memo classifying cartel boats as DTOs. Lawmakers urged clear objectives and legal limits on U.S. military action.

articles.title: US judge orders Trump administration to fully fund Snap benefits in November
articles.trailText: Ruling comes in response to a challenge to administration’s offer to only partly fund US food benefits amid shutdown
articles.summary: US District Judge John J. McConnell Jr in Rhode Island ordered the Trump administration by Friday to fully fund November Snap benefits for 42 million low-income Americans, rebuking its plan to partially pay amid the federal shutdown. McConnell warned reduced aid would cause ‘irreparable harm,’ overburden food pantries and leave people hungry, noting delays in partial payments. The ruling follows earlier orders requiring emergency payouts (initially half, later 65 percent) and comes as states like New York, Oregon and Virginia declared emergencies to cover gaps. Plaintiffs say the administration is leveraging hunger for political gain.

articles.title: US supreme court lets Trump block passport sex markers for trans and non-binary people
articles.trailText: Decision by high court’s conservative majority is Trump administration’s latest win on emergency docket
articles.summary: The Supreme Court’s conservative majority granted the Trump administration’s emergency stay allowing enforcement of a passport policy that restricts sex markers to recipients’ birth‐certificate designation—blocking transgender and non‐binary people from selecting gender‐affirming M, F or X markers—while a challenge proceeds. US Attorney General Pam Bondi hailed the decision; Justices Jackson, Sotomayor and Kagan dissented, decrying its arbitrary harm. The policy, issued via Trump’s January order, reversed a 2021 Biden change removing medical proof requirements, prompting lawsuits citing safety and identification risks.

articles.title: ICE plans to open call center to help law enforcement locate unaccompanied minors
articles.trailText: Facility, slated to open in March in Nashville, will use ‘data-enabled technology’ to track down migrant children
articles.summary: ICE will open a 24/7 call center in Nashville by March to help law enforcement locate unaccompanied migrant children using data-enabled technology, handling 6,000–7,000 calls daily and reaching full capacity by June. The RFI seeks contractors to integrate partner and migrant data and reduce call times. Critics highlight ties to private prison operator CoreCivic and tech firms like Palantir, fresh off a $30m ICE database deal, amid surging raids, revived family separation tactics and $2,500 self-deportation stipends. A DHS official disputed the report’s accuracy. The plan echoes Trump-era zero-tolerance policies and faces civil rights backlash.

articles.title: Virginia school teacher shot by six-year-old student awarded $10m in damages
articles.trailText: Abigail Zwerner alleged assistant principal ignored reports that a firearm was on school property
articles.summary: Abigail Zwerner, shot in January 2023 by a six-year-old student at Richneck Elementary in Newport News after he drew a 9mm handgun in her classroom, was awarded $10M by a jury in a negligence suit against former assistant principal Ebony Parker, who allegedly ignored multiple student warnings about the weapon. Zwerner underwent five hand surgeries. Parker, facing child abuse/neglect charges next month, argued the shooting was unforeseeable; Zwerner had sought $40M. His mother, Deja Taylor, received 21 months in prison in 2023 on federal gun-possession charges. The case could reshape accountability standards for school leaders and parents.

articles.title: In a historic career of firsts, Nancy Pelosi might be best remembered as Trump’s most formidable adversary
articles.trailText: After nearly four decades in Congress, reactions to the former House speaker’s retirement have proved emblematic of America’s partisan extremes
articles.summary: Nancy Pelosi, first female House speaker, retires after 38 years in Congress. Elected in 1987, she championed AIDS relief via the 1990 Ryan White CARE Act, led Obama’s Affordable Care Act and post-2008 recovery, and steered Biden-era climate, infrastructure and industry bills. Hailed by Democrat Hakeem Jeffries as “iconic” yet vilified by Trump as “evil,” she became his chief antagonist: from televised Oval Office clashes, eye-rolls and mock claps to overseeing his two impeachments and surviving a January 6 threat and a home break-in. Her final bid to replace Biden as nominee fractured party unity. Pelosi departs as speaker emerita, remembered for legislative wins, partisan battles and shrewd tactics, emblematic of US polarization.

articles.title: Man who threw sandwich at US federal agent found not guilty of assault
articles.trailText: Former justice department employee’s lawyers argued it was a ‘harmless gesture’ during an act of protest
articles.summary: Sean Charles Dunn, a former DOJ paralegal, was acquitted by a DC jury of misdemeanor assault after throwing a sandwich at a Customs and Border Protection agent during Trump’s law enforcement surge. Dunn’s lawyers argued the act was a harmless protest; prosecutors countered that he knowingly struck an officer at close range. The viral incident made Dunn a resistance symbol in a city pushing back on federal troops. Fired from the DOJ and briefly detained twice, Dunn—an Air Force veteran—was defended as exercising free speech when the jury delivered the not guilty verdict.

articles.title: Nancy Pelosi, a force on Capitol Hill for decades, to retire from Congress
articles.trailText: Decision marks the close of a storied 20-term congressional career for the first woman to serve as House speaker
articles.summary: Nancy Pelosi, 85, California Democrat and the first woman House speaker, announced she won’t seek re-election, closing a storied 20-term, nearly 40-year career representing San Francisco. After stepping down as leader in 2022 and serving as speaker emerita, she guided landmark legislation—from the Affordable Care Act to Biden’s climate and infrastructure bills—and counseled her party through Trump’s impeachment and post-2020 Capitol riot. Her departure triggers a high-profile generational contest for her open SF seat and cements her legacy as a trailblazer for women in US politics.

articles.title: Trump announces plan to cut cost of weight loss drugs and expand access
articles.trailText: Injectable versions of GLP-1s from Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk will see reduced prices and broader coverage
articles.summary: Trump unveiled measures cutting weight-loss drug costs and widening coverage for GLP-1 therapies, launching TrumpRx to sell injectable semaglutide and tirzepatide (Ozempic, Wegovy, Mounjaro, Zepbound) at an initial $350 monthly price, aiming to $245 in two years, with Medicare beneficiaries paying only $50 copays and state Medicaid programs eligible if they opt in. Upcoming oral GLP-1s will cost $150/month. Health secretary RFK Jr. predicted a 125m-pound national weight loss, while CMS head Oz touted budget neutrality via obesity-related savings. This follows Trump’s broader effort to tie US drug pricing to global rates.

articles.title: ‘Icon of American politics’: Democrats heap praise on retiring Nancy Pelosi
articles.trailText: Former speaker, 85, hailed as a ‘legendary’ leader who helped usher in new generation of women in politics
articles.summary: After 20 terms, first female House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, 85, announced she won’t seek re-election in 2026, capping a career marked by passage of the Affordable Care Act, championing progressive priorities, navigating the 2021 Capitol assault and advancing women’s representation from 25 to 151 seats. Hakeem Jeffries hailed her as the greatest speaker; Barack Obama and Adam Schiff lauded her transformative impact on healthcare, jobs, equality and US leadership. With her departure, Democratic contenders Saikat Chakrabarti and state senator Scott Wiener have already entered the race for her San Francisco seat.

articles.title: US House panel requests interview with Andrew in Jeffrey Epstein investigation
articles.trailText: Robert Garcia, top Democrat on House oversight panel, makes formal request in letter published Thursday
articles.summary: The US House Oversight Committee’s top Democrat, Rep. Robert Garcia, formally requested Prince Andrew Mountbatten Windsor cooperate with its Jeffrey Epstein probe by answering questions by Nov. 20. Co-signed by 13 other Democrats, the letter cites 1999-2019 travel logs, his ties to Epstein post-2008 conviction, a 2011 “we are in this together” email, and sexual assault claims by Virginia Giuffre. Though Congress can’t compel a foreign national, Garcia argues stronger oversight is needed for transparency and justice for alleged abuse survivors. The request follows Andrew being stripped of his royal title and lease on his Windsor home.

articles.title: Democrats urged to ‘hold the line’ in talks as shutdown stretches to 37th day
articles.trailText: Lawmakers could be coming closer to a deal to end the longest US government shutdown in history
articles.summary: On day 37 of the record US government shutdown, Democrats, buoyed by recent electoral wins, are urged to ‘hold the line’ in budget talks—insisting on health insurance subsidy extensions—while negotiators eye partial “minibus” funding bills to break the logjam. The Trump administration, pressing its leverage, will cut 10% of flights at 40 major airports this Friday over unpaid FAA staff, marking an unprecedented shutdown impact, and faces court orders to maintain SNAP payments amid funding confusion. Senate Democrats like Blumenthal and Sanders resist concessions; Trump’s push to end the filibuster lacks GOP support, and furloughed workers fear lost back pay.

articles.title: New York Post’s anti-Mamdani front page is a hit – with his supporters
articles.trailText: Wednesday’s ‘On your Marx, get set, Zo!’ edition of the New York Post is a hot property – with one copy selling for $355
articles.summary: After democratic socialist Zohran Mamdani’s mayoral win, the Rupert Murdoch–owned New York Post’s Nov. 5 cover “On your Marx, get set, Zo!”—depicting him with a hammer and sickle—went viral among his supporters. Print editions sold out at delis in Brooklyn’s Bed-Stuy within hours; a single copy fetched $355 on eBay, and the paper offers a $75 metal version. Fans praised the design’s “shock factor.” Meanwhile, the Post continues to oppose Mamdani’s higher-tax, free-services agenda in scathing editorials.

articles.title: Heritage Foundation leader apologizes for backing Tucker Carlson’s interview with white nationalist
articles.trailText: Kevin Roberts, whose group pushed Project 2025, had defended ex-Fox News host’s talk with Nick Fuentes
articles.summary: Heritage Foundation president Kevin Roberts apologized to staff for defending Tucker Carlson’s podcast with white nationalist Nick Fuentes, admitting he “made a mistake” after leaked town hall footage revealed broad internal outrage and blaming a now-resigned chief of staff for scripting his initial defense. Although at least five antisemitism task force members have resigned and some urge his ouster, Roberts—who has shifted the think tank toward a Trump-aligned platform and insists he won’t resign—posted on X denouncing Fuentes’s Holocaust denial and calls for Jews’ execution, pledging to recommit to confronting antisemitism despite the turmoil.

articles.title: Europeans recognize Zohran Mamdani’s supposedly radical policies as ‘normal’
articles.trailText: Critics of New York City’s mayor-elect have said his pledges of free bus service and universal childcare are unrealistic, but in Europe it’s a given
articles.summary: After his NYC mayoral win, Zohran Mamdani’s proposals—fare-free buses, universal childcare (6 weeks–5 years), one municipal grocery store per borough, rent freezes for ~1 million rent-stabilized tenants and a newborn baby basket—sparked US criticism as radical and unaffordable. Europeans, by contrast, see such programs as routine: Tallinn, Montpellier, Luxembourg and Malta run free transit; Berlin and Portugal offer free childcare; Finland’s universal baby box dates to 1949; Istanbul’s city stores and Nordic welfare schemes prefigure grocery subsidies; Berlin’s 2019 rent freeze and NYC’s own rent board precedents show feasibility. Abroad, Mamdani’s vision is “normal,” not socialist.

articles.title: Pressure on Republicans after California map vote gives Democrats critical win
articles.trailText: Focus shifts to other states where Trump is pushing for redrawn districts as parties race to seize midterm advantage
articles.summary: California voters approved a referendum adding three Democratic seats, countering Texas Republicans’ plan to boost GOP representation. With the House margin at 219-214, parties are racing to redraw districts nationwide: Republicans in North Carolina, Missouri (subject to a citizen initiative), Indiana and Florida push GOP-favored maps, while Democrats in Virginia, Utah, Ohio and others seek gains or legal remedies in New York and Wisconsin. Some Democrats in Maryland and Illinois caution against aggressive redistricting. Meanwhile, the Supreme Court’s pending decision on the Voting Rights Act could reshape minority-vote protections and shift roughly a dozen seats.

articles.title: It’s affordability, stupid: Republicans pay price for Trump’s forgotten promise
articles.trailText: Trump looks increasingly out of touch and his disapproval rating is at an all-time high – which partly explains Tuesday’s election results
articles.summary: After Republican losses in New Jersey and Virginia and a New York mayoral victory built on housing access, VP JD Vance admitted the party must refocus on affordability. Trump’s pledge to cut costs has faltered as inflation keeps grocery and housing prices high. His tariffs and AI-driven stock boom have failed to ease daily expenses, while his lavish White House spending fuels voter resentment. Democratic candidates like Zohran Mamdani seized on rent freezes, free transit and childcare, underscoring affordability as the decisive issue behind Tuesday’s results.

articles.title: What Tuesday’s elections mean for the future of abortion rights
articles.trailText: Democrats’ commanding victories have breathed new life into the reproductive health fight
articles.summary: Democrats’ decisive Nov. 2025 victories reinvigorated abortion rights protections: Virginia’s Abigail Spanberger and New Jersey’s Mikie Sherrill won governorships to shield access; Pennsylvania voters kept three liberal supreme court justices; and California’s Prop 50 redistricting boost will help congressional Democrats defend national abortion access. Despite GOP fear-mongering—claims of "abortion up until birth"—abortion-focused messaging, supported by $1.1m in final-week TV ads and $1.8m in ACLU voter-education, prevailed. However, Republicans regaining Congress in 2026 could pursue a federal abortion ban or extend Planned Parenthood defunding. With control of Virginia’s legislature, Democrats can now pursue a constitutional amendment, ensuring reproductive rights dominate next year’s state contests.

articles.title: First Thing: Still a chance to return to 1.5C climate goal, experts say
articles.trailText: As world leaders gather in Brazil for climate talks, data suggests current plans would lead to devastating heating. Plus, Zohran Mamdani, the New York mayor-elect, introduces his all-female transition team
articles.summary: There remains a slim chance to return to the 1.5°C target if governments rapidly scale up renewables and electrify transport, heating and industry, warns Climate Analytics as world leaders convene for COP30 in Belém, Brazil—current national plans risk 2.3–2.5°C of warming. At the Supreme Court, justices expressed doubts about President Trump’s use of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act to impose global tariffs. In New York, mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani unveiled an all-female transition team to advance policies such as a rent freeze, free buses, universal childcare and city-run grocery stores, though federal funding reprisals loom.

articles.title: US ends deportation protection for South Sudanese nationals
articles.trailText: South Sudanese people with temporary protected status now have 60 days to leave
articles.summary: USCIS has ended TPS for South Sudanese nationals, effective immediately, granting 60 days to depart or face deportation. Citing improved conditions, USCIS argued South Sudan no longer meets armed-conflict criteria. TPS, first authorized in 2011 after a civil war that killed 400,000 and displaced half the population, covered only about 232 people. Departing migrants using the CBP app may receive a plane ticket, $1,000 bonus and possible future legal immigration pathways. Critics warn Trump-era revocations risk returning exiles to renewed violence amid ongoing political tensions.

articles.title: Workers decry Trump officials as ‘out of control’ as longest shutdown drags on
articles.trailText: Key figures accused of harassment, bullying and attacks as US employees work without pay to keep services running
articles.summary: As the US federal shutdown surpasses 35 days—a record exceeding the first-term shutdown—around 700,000 federal employees remain furloughed and 700,000 work without pay. Workers accuse Trump officials of harassment, bullying and threats to withhold back pay, citing mass firings, budget cuts and forced retirements. Union leaders report mounting mental-health burdens and financial strain. Despite the AFGE’s call to reopen without assigning blame, Trump refuses to negotiate, echoing OMB director Vought’s aim to cast workers as “villains.”

articles.title: How Mamdani built an ‘unstoppable force’ that won over New York
articles.trailText: The mayor-elect built the greatest field operation by any political campaign in the city’s history – by getting New Yorkers to talk to eachother. Can Democrats learn from his success?
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani stunned NYC by defeating Cuomo and Sliwa with the largest volunteer field operation in city history—over 100,000 canvassers delivering a message of affordability: rent freeze, free buses, cheap groceries, free childcare. Rooted in democratic socialist DSA-backed leadership, his bottom-up campaign emphasised listening to voters, small-donor fundraising (he hit $8 m legal caps twice with 180,000 grassroots donors), and personal canvassing in working-class neighborhoods. His blend of targeted policies, viral social media, and volunteer-driven events generated record turnout, flipping the Bronx and winning 78% of youth vote. Democrats see his model as a blueprint to counter Trump.

articles.title: Ugandans view Mamdani’s NYC win as a ‘beacon of hope’ amid democratic struggle
articles.trailText: Ugandans react with joy after Kampala-born Mamdani’s victory during a trying time for democracy in east Africa
articles.summary: Uganda-born Zohran Mamdani, 34, has become New York City’s first Muslim and first south Asian mayor after defeating Cuomo and Sliwa. Ugandans at Makerere University celebrated the Kampala native’s victory as a symbol of national pride and possibility amid East Africa’s democratic backslide marked by Tanzanian election violence and Uganda’s tightening political space under President Museveni. Activists like Joseph Sendagire and Robert Kabushenga called Mamdani’s win a “beacon of hope,” urging free, fair elections and youth participation ahead of Uganda’s fraught January vote. Opposition figures including Bobi Wine and MP Joel Ssenyonyi praised the milestone as inspiration for change.

articles.title: When is a tariff not a tax? When I say so, Trump tells supreme court
articles.trailText: The fate of the US president’s signature, globe-rattling economic policy is in the hands of a court he shaped
articles.summary: At the Supreme Court on Nov. 6, Trump’s administration defended its sweeping tariffs under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, insisting they are “regulatory” measures—not taxes—despite generating billions in revenue. Lower courts ruled IEEPA does not grant the president taxing authority, a power reserved for Congress. Justices across ideological lines, including Sonia Sotomayor and Chief Justice Roberts, expressed skepticism. The challenge, led by small businesses and a coalition of a dozen states, frames the case as executive overreach and a test of who holds the constitutional power to levy taxes. A fast-tracked decision is expected.

articles.title: US to cut airline traffic by 10% at 40 airports amid shutdown, Trump transport chief says
articles.trailText: Sean Duffy says cuts at 40 locations to reduce stress on air traffic controllers will start Friday if solution not found
articles.summary: US Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy and FAA head Bryan Bedford will cut scheduled traffic by 10% at 40 major airports, likely including New York, Washington DC, Chicago, Atlanta, Los Angeles and Dallas, starting next week if the 36-day government shutdown persists. Cuts rise from 4% on Friday to 10% by midweek, hitting cargo, private and domestic passenger flights (international initially exempt). Cirium estimates 1,800 fewer flights and 268,000 seats removed. Aimed at easing fatigue among unpaid air traffic controllers, the FAA is offering bonuses and boosting recruitment amid a 3,500-controller shortfall. Further reductions may follow before the holiday travel surge.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: supreme court examines president’s global tariffs
articles.trailText: Conservative justices expressing skepticism of the strength of the Trump administration’s position
articles.summary: On Nov. 5 Supreme Court justices challenged the Trump administration’s authority under the 1977 International Emergency Economic Powers Act to impose steep global tariffs on imports from nearly every U.S. trading partner. During Wednesday’s oral arguments, Chief Justice John Roberts and other conservatives questioned whether IEEPA grants the president power akin to congressional taxing authority. With over 40 briefs filed—including by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce—a ruling invalidating the tariffs would force the White House to rethink its aggressive trade strategy.

articles.title: Armed US immigration agents drive off with toddler after arrest of father
articles.trailText: ‘Devastated’ family demands answers after one-year-old driven by armed agents from LA Home Depot parking lot
articles.summary: Masked, heavily armed federal immigration agents arrested a US-citizen father at a Los Angeles Home Depot and drove off with his one-year-old daughter still in the backseat, prompting frantic calls from agents to the child’s grandmother. The toddler, also a US citizen, was held for hours before being released to family after proving her identity. DHS claims the father brandished a hammer and a stolen pistol; advocates decry the family separation and demand clearer protocols. Relatives and immigrant-rights groups say the incident traumatized the child and underscore calls to reform enforcement practices.

articles.title: Trump’s new gold Oval Office sign draws mockery and anger
articles.trailText: Written in cursive gold script, new sign was affixed beside office’s door while shutdown jeopardizes Snap program
articles.summary: President Trump has installed a new cursive gold “Oval Office” sign beside the Oval Office door as a government shutdown cuts SNAP benefits by half. The gilded flourish drew sharp criticism: Rep. Malcolm Kenyatta slammed the display while 43 million Americans face reduced aid, Sen. Lisa Blunt Rochester urged focus on struggling families, and Rep. Jared Moskowitz quipped the sign won’t be torn down. This follows Trump’s $300 million East Wing demolition for a new ballroom amid record shutdown outrage, and prompted Gov. Gavin Newsom’s office to mock it with a “Live, laugh, LOSE” parody.

articles.title: Kentucky plane crash: death toll rises to 12 as officials investigate how engine detached
articles.trailText: NTSB agents arrive in Louisville to investigate what caused engine to fall off UPS cargo plane and left wing to catch fire
articles.summary: UPS MD-11 cargo jet bound for Honolulu crashed off airport property in Louisville on Nov. 5 after its left wing caught fire and an engine detached during takeoff, exploding into a fireball. The death toll has risen to 12, with at least 15 injured (two in critical condition) and several unaccounted. NTSB agents recovered the detached engine, cockpit voice and data recorders intact amid a half-mile debris field and plan a preliminary report within 30 days. Louisville’s airport canceled outbound flights, will keep the damaged runway closed for 10 days, and UPS temporarily halted parcel-sorting operations at its hub.

articles.title: Trump goes on posting frenzy a day after Democrats win key elections
articles.trailText: President shares more than 30 Truth Social posts in less than three hours, including series of bizarre AI-generated videos
articles.summary: Donald Trump unleashed 33 posts on Truth Social in under three hours a day after Democrats won statewide contests in New York, California, Virginia and New Jersey. His posts ranged from endorsing books by Nicole Parker, Gianno Caldwell, Barry Loudermilk, Peter Navarro and Christina Bobb (for whom he wrote the foreword) to AI-generated videos reciting his own messages on US-Japan and Xi meetings, Walmart price cuts, threats to cut Nigerian aid, Obamacare attacks and calls to end the filibuster. Grok confirmed the clips were AI; the White House auto-reply blamed a “Democrat Shutdown.” The spree—capped by a waxy re-election anniversary image—has reignited questions over his mental acuity amid Democratic victories like Zohran Mamdani’s New York mayoral win.

articles.title: Armed ICE agents in Chicago drag daycare worker out of facility and arrest her
articles.trailText: Videos show ICE agents chasing woman into daycare and appearing to slam her face against glass doors
articles.summary: At Chicago’s Rayito de Sol daycare on Nov. 5, ICE agents chased and forcibly pulled a worker inside, dragging her out—video shows agents slamming her face into glass doors then pinning her to a car, despite her saying “I have papers.” No warrant was presented, staff say. Parents and alderman condemned the “chilling” scene as children watched. Democratic Rep. Mike Quigley and city officials decried the raid. ICE denies targeting the daycare, claiming agents pursued a vehicle. The arrest coincided with a lawsuit alleging a pattern of excessive force by ICE.

articles.title: Where the vote for Mamdani was strongest in New York City
articles.trailText: Mamdani performed well citywide, drawing support from a wide range of racial, ethnic and economic groups
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani, 34-year-old democratic socialist, clinched New York City’s mayoralty with 50.4% on a historic turnout exceeding 2 million—the highest since 1969—defeating independent Andrew Cuomo and Republican Curtis Sliwa. Mamdani’s broad coalition spanned racial, ethnic and economic lines: he dominated predominantly Black precincts, won majorities in Hispanic, low- and middle-income neighborhoods, and recorded his largest margins where the median voter was under 45. Cuomo’s support remained confined to Staten Island, select Queens areas and ultra-Orthodox Brooklyn.

articles.title: Police report describes Republican Nancy Mace berating airport police and TSA agents
articles.trailText: South Carolina firebrand running for governor allegedly abused agents working without pay during shutdown
articles.summary: South Carolina GOP Rep. Nancy Mace, a 2026 gubernatorial hopeful, is under scrutiny after a Charleston County Aviation Authority report detailed her dropping an F-bomb at unpaid TSA agents and airport police—invoking Sen. Tim Scott—during last week’s shutdown escort. Mace has hired conservative lawyer Larry Klayman and plans defamation suits against American Airlines and airport authorities, alleging airport staff conspired to create false, misleading incident reports. Bipartisan state legislators, Charleston’s mayor and the Fraternal Order of Police defended staff. Once critical of Trump, Mace now campaigns as an immigration and culture-war warrior in a tight GOP primary.

articles.title: Disturbing dash-cam footage shows LA police fatally striking skateboarder
articles.trailText: Gerardo ‘Jerry’ Estrada, 30, was hit head-on by weaving car with sirens on that had drifted from correct side of street
articles.summary: LAPD dash-cam footage from Sept. 19 shows officers with sirens weaving off course on crowded Figueroa Street and fatally striking skateboarder Gerardo “Jerry” Estrada, 30. Responding to a felony-warrant perimeter call near a neighborhood carnival, the cruiser drifted into the center lane where Estrada, heading home from work, was hit and pronounced dead at the scene. Video captures officers chatting before the crash, bystanders’ urgent shouts, and immediate panic. Estrada’s family, mourning his loss and emphasizing his film-media passion and Wurstküche job, demands accountability. LAPD says aid was rendered and an investigation into speed and officer conduct is ongoing.

articles.title: Trump voters for Mamdani and a new left coalition: the biggest surprises from New York’s election
articles.trailText: Political analyst Michael Lange, a born and raised New Yorker who predicted Zohran Mamdani would win, discusses election night’s trends and surprises
articles.summary: Political analyst Michael Lange’s block-by-block forecast accurately predicted Zohran Mamdani’s mayoral victory in NYC by mapping a “commie corridor” of progressive strongholds from Park Slope to Astoria versus a “capitalist corridor” in Manhattan’s affluent enclaves. Mamdani expanded his base by adding 500k votes among young renters, Black, Hispanic, Muslim and south Asian working-class voters—some of whom backed Trump in 2024. Turnout hit a record 2.3M. Cuomo held wealthy white and Orthodox Jewish neighborhoods via conservative-leaning independents. Republican Curtis Sliwa collapsed citywide. Lange credits the multiracial left coalition and localized turnout for Mamdani’s win and sees similar corridors shaping future races.

articles.title: What does Prop 50’s passage mean for California, Gavin Newsom and the US?
articles.trailText: Residents overwhelmingly backed the redistricting measure Democrats say is critical to protecting democracy
articles.summary: In a 63.8%-36.2% special election win, California voters passed Prop 50, suspending the independent redistricting commission until after 2030 and giving the legislature authority to redraw congressional districts mid-decade. The new map is designed to add five Democratic seats, putting GOP incumbents Darrell Issa, Doug LaMalfa, Ken Calvert, David Valadao and Kevin Kiley at risk. State Republicans have sued to block the plan, alleging partisan gerrymandering, while Democrats say it will help protect their majority in the 2026 midterms and boost Gov. Gavin Newsom’s national profile.

articles.title: Republicans file lawsuit challenging California’s redistricting measure
articles.trailText: Prop 50, passed by voters yesterday, allows legislature to redraw congressional maps to benefit Democrats in House
articles.summary: Republicans in California, led by assembly member David Tangipa, 18 voters and the state GOP, filed a federal suit Wednesday in the Central District to block Prop 50—a voter-approved measure granting the legislature mid-decade authority to redraw congressional maps, poised to help Democrats flip up to five seats. Plaintiffs argue the new districts were drawn to enhance Latino voting power, violating equal-protection and racial-gerrymandering rules, and seek a temporary injunction. Represented by Dhillon Law Group, they frame it as a partisan, race-based plan—California’s response to GOP gerrymanders in Texas. Democrats, including Gov. Newsom’s office, dismiss the challenge, citing PPIC analysis and confidence in surviving Supreme Court scrutiny amid looming Voting Rights Act litigation.

articles.title: Zohran Mamdani announces all-female transition team as he prepares for New York mayoralty
articles.trailText: Team includes Lina Khan, the FTC commissioner under Biden, and other Democratic former city officials
articles.summary: NYC mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani unveiled an all-female transition team to prepare for his January 1 inauguration, naming Elana Leopold as executive director alongside co-chairs Maria Torres-Springer, Lina Khan, Grace Bonilla and Melanie Hartzog. The 34-year-old democratic socialist, the city’s first Muslim, South Asian and Africa-born mayor, said his team will build an administration capable of delivering on his progressive agenda��rent freezes, free bus service, universal childcare and city-run grocery stores funded by higher taxes on corporations and the wealthy. Mamdani faces potential federal funding cuts from Donald Trump and Islamophobic attacks but vowed to unite New Yorkers and begin work immediately.

articles.title: Minneapolis mayor Jacob Frey fends off progressive challengers to win third term
articles.trailText: The ranked-choice election went into a second round of tabulations, putting him ahead of state senator Omar Fateh
articles.summary: Incumbent mayor Jacob Frey won a third term after Minneapolis’s ranked-choice count entered a second round, outpacing progressive state senator Omar Fateh. Fifteen candidates ran; Fateh, attorney Jazz Hampton and minister DeWayne Davis formed a loose alliance, but only Frey secured enough second‐round votes to cross 50%. Backed by business-friendly establishment groups, Frey has clashed with a socialist-tinged council over policing, homelessness and immigration enforcement. Fateh’s platform—$20 minimum wage, rent stabilization and police alternatives—drew DSA and union support but fell short against the moderate Frey.

articles.title: US supreme court justices express skepticism over legality of Trump tariffs
articles.trailText: Justices grill administration over imposition of steep duties as Sotomayor says: ‘I just don’t understand this argument’
articles.summary: During oral arguments before the conservative-majority Supreme Court, justices questioned whether the 1977 IEEPA grants Trump authority to impose global tariffs (a power reserved for Congress). Chief Justice Roberts and liberal justices Sotomayor and Jackson expressed doubt that regulatory powers include taxes. Attorneys argued that tariffs effectively tax Americans and that Congress never delegated such authority. The decision, due by July 2026, could reshape executive emergency trade powers and Trump’s economic strategy.

articles.title: Which of our warnings came true in the first year after Trump’s second election?
articles.trailText: From military-level force in cities to tens of thousands of federal workers fired by the Trump administration, effects have been felt at every level
articles.summary: In his first year post-reelection, Trump reversed many policies: deployed military/national guard in cities (LA, DC, Portland, Chicago), suppressed campus protests and deported activists, fired tens of thousands of federal workers; executed record ICE raids and mass deportations; reversed Biden-era abortion protections (dropped EMTALA guidance, FDA scrutiny of mifepristone); weakened LGBTQ+ and environmental safeguards (ESA/NEPA rollbacks, drilling leases); reshaped courts via shadow docket; intimidated media; eased gun restrictions; and pursued erratic foreign policy (trade wars, Israel–Gaza ceasefires, NATO funding, failed Ukraine peace talks).

articles.title: New York parties for Zohran Mamdani: ‘The first time we’ve had hope in so long’
articles.trailText: In the bodegas, bars and clubs of Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, the mood was joyous – it was an emotional night
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani’s upset win over establishment figures Andrew Cuomo and Curtis Sliwa sparked jubilant, tearful DSA watch parties across Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and beyond on election night. Supporters—ranging from long-time activists and bartenders to recent volunteers—danced to ’90s anthems, chanted “DSA!” and toasted New York’s first Muslim and youngest mayor in over a century. His victory on an affordability and democratic-socialist platform is hailed as proof that progressive policies resonate citywide, offering many voters their first genuine hope for transformative change.

articles.title: Trump allies erupt over Mamdani win: ‘On your Marx, get set, Zo!’
articles.trailText: Captured on the New York Post cover, Maga allies respond to Democrats’ election sweep with accusations and fury
articles.summary: Rightwing MAGA figures erupted over socialist-democrat Zohran Mamdani's decisive NYC mayoral victory, winning over 50% of the vote. The Murdoch-owned New York Post depicted Mamdani in communist imagery under the taunt "On your Marx, get set, Zo!". Fox's Sean Hannity warned of a New York exodus, tying the "Mamdani effect" to property decline and questioning Mamdani's Muslim faith. Steve Bannon condemned GOP hopes for a socialist fail-watch, while Steve Miller, Jack Posobiec and Laura Loomer spouted anti-immigrant and Islamophobic claims. George Santos attacked rival Curtis Sliwa. Only billionaire Bill Ackman offered a conciliatory "how can I help?".

articles.title: Liberal politicians outside US hail Zohran Mamdani victory in New York
articles.trailText: Opposition figures in India and Uganda and progressives in UK and France applaud Democrat’s election as mayor
articles.summary: New York’s 34-year-old mayor Zohran Mamdani, born in Uganda to Indian parents, has drawn praise from liberal figures worldwide as a blueprint against right-wing populism. India’s Abhishek Manu Singhvi hailed his Nehru-quoted, youth-led victory; Uganda’s Joel Ssenyonyi called it ‘a big encouragement’. In Europe, Sadiq Khan, Luke Charters, Jeremy Corbyn and Manon Aubry lauded his grassroots strategy and concrete pledges—rent freeze, free buses, public daycare—while Mamdani, a vocal critic of genocide in Gaza and antisemitism, won up to one-third of Jewish votes despite Trump’s last-minute “Jew hater” smear.

articles.title: Democrats celebrate while Republicans stew over Mamdani’s historic win and others
articles.trailText: Obama said ‘the future looks a little bit brighter’ while the House speaker lied about New York mayor-elect’s policies
articles.summary: Democrats celebrated a wave of election victories—highlighted by Zohran Mamdani’s historic New York mayoral win—as a referendum on Trump’s policies, with Obama calling the future brighter, Warren crediting bold reforms like universal childcare and Murphy lauding a stand for working families. Some GOP officials evoked 'Escape from New York' tropes and jihadist fears. Republicans reacted by attributing the outcome to immigrant voters and the federal shutdown, with Miller, Trump and Jayapal debating blame, while Abbott, Scott and Johnson denounced Mamdani as a socialist threat, vowing to campaign against his “radical” agenda nationwide.

articles.title: Death of beloved neighborhood cat sparks outrage against robotaxis in San Francisco
articles.trailText: KitKat, affectionately known as ‘mayor of 16th Street’, was struck and killed by a Waymo in the city’s Mission District
articles.summary: KitKat, the Mission District’s beloved “mayor of 16th Street,” was killed when a Waymo autonomous vehicle struck him. The incident has ignited local outrage, inspiring protests—some disabling or setting fire to robotaxis—and prompted SF Supervisor Jackie Fielder to propose legislation letting counties ban or restrict AV operations. Rally speakers cited job displacement, loss of local control and an $8 million Cruise settlement for a pedestrian dragged by an AV. Waymo expressed sympathy, pledged an animal rights donation and defended its safety record. KitKat’s owners launched a memecoin to fund veterinary and animal welfare causes.

articles.title: Democrats set historic records on election night. Here are six of the firsts they accomplished
articles.trailText: From Virginia’s first female governor to New York’s first Muslim mayor, Tuesday’s elections secured trailblazing wins
articles.summary: Democrats secured six historic firsts in Tuesday’s elections: Abigail Spanberger, a former CIA operative, became Virginia’s first female governor; Ghazala Hashmi emerged as the first Muslim American woman elected to statewide office as Virginia lieutenant governor; Zohran Mamdani was elected New York City’s first Muslim mayor; Mary Sheffield won Detroit’s mayoralty by a record 77% to become its first female mayor; Somerville, Massachusetts, became the first US municipality to vote to divest from Israel via a non-binding ballot; and California approved Proposition 50, marking the first state-level initiative to block mid-cycle partisan redistricting.

articles.title: The full transcript of Zohran Mamdani’s victory speech after being elected NYC mayor
articles.trailText: Mayor-elect centered affordability and the working people of the city in his speech while emphasizing: ‘Hope is alive’
articles.summary: After defeating a political dynasty, NYC’s mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani delivered a hopeful victory speech emphasizing affordability and working-class power. Addressing Yemeni bodega owners, Senegalese taxi drivers and Uzbek nurses, the democratic socialist pledged to freeze rents for 2 million tenants, make buses fast and free, expand childcare universally, hire thousands of teachers, cut bureaucratic waste, and upgrade NYCHA. He promised a community safety department, police-justice balance, and a stop to antisemitism and Islamophobia. With union backing, he vowed to tackle corruption, protect immigrant and labor rights, challenge big-money interests, and fight Trump-style misinformation, ushering in a new era of competence and compassion.

articles.title: Zohran Mamdani elected New York City mayor | First Thing
articles.trailText: Democratic socialist’s campaign was fueled by small-dollar donations and tens of thousands of volunteers. Plus, Dick Cheney dies aged 84
articles.summary: Democratic socialist Zohran Mamdani, 34, wins 50.4% to become NYC’s 111th and first Muslim mayor, defeating Andrew Cuomo (41.6%) and Curtis Sliwa (7.1%) on small-dollar donations and grassroots volunteers; his platform includes a rent freeze for 2m renters, $30 minimum wage, free buses, universal childcare, affordable housing and higher taxes on top earners. Ex-VP Dick Cheney dies at 84, noted for directing the Iraq invasion; Palestinian author Nasser Abu Srour reports torture in Israeli prisons; U.N. warns Sudan conflict is spiralling; U.S. court halts a 40-year prisoner’s deportation; Norway’s sovereign fund opposes Musk’s $1tn Tesla pay.

articles.title: Surge in antisemitism investigations at US universities after October 7 attacks, data shows
articles.trailText: A report shared exclusively with the Guardian documents how a civil rights law has become a tool to impose ideological priorities on US schools
articles.summary: Data from MESA and AAUP show a surge in US Department of Education Title VI investigations into antisemitism on campuses after Oct 7, 2023—more in late 2023 than the prior two decades. At least 126 inquiries against 89 universities since 2004, with 39 new probes in 2024 and 38 by September 2025, eclipsing other discrimination cases. Critics argue Title VI has been repurposed to curb pro-Palestinian speech, driven by pro-Israel activists filing 78% of complaints. Investigations have led to funding freezes, settlements expanding beyond antisemitism, and raised concerns about due process and academic freedom.

articles.title: California man who survived 20 days in snowy wilderness says it was walk or die
articles.trailText: Ron Dailey, who got lost on hunting trip in Sierra national forest, resolved to walk to safety after his food ran out
articles.summary: Ron Dailey, a hunter from Selma, CA, went missing in Fresno County’s Sierra National Forest on October 13 after his pickup truck broke down above 10,000 ft during a sudden snowstorm. Stranded with two weeks’ provisions, he sheltered in his truck until food ran out, then leaned on his Christian faith and embarked on a treacherous trek. Limping and breathing hard in thin mountain air, he walked about 12 miles before fellow hunters found him on November 1. Authorities recovered his truck the next day, astonished he survived 20 days in subzero conditions.

articles.title: Share your views on the New York mayoral election results
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear what people make of Zohran Mamdani’s win of the New York City mayoral election
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani has been elected the 111th mayor of New York City, defeating former governor Andrew Cuomo and Republican Curtis Sliwa. As the city’s first Muslim mayor, his win marks a historic milestone. Voters cited affordable housing, public safety and economic recovery as top concerns. Mamdani’s progressive platform pledges to tackle income inequality, expand social services and improve public transit. What do New Yorkers hope he will prioritize first, and how do they interpret the broader significance of his victory?

articles.title: Democrats have racked up election wins across America – but they would do well not to misread the results
articles.trailText: Zohran Mamdani’s victory in New York and gubernatorial wins in Virginia and New Jersey have given Democrats a night better than they dared hope for
articles.summary: On Nov 5, Democrats notched a string of high-profile wins—Zohran Mamdani unseated Trump-endorsed Andrew Cuomo in New York, Mikie Sherrill and Abigail Spanberger captured New Jersey and Virginia governorships by double digits, Democrats redrew California congressional maps, held Pennsylvania supreme court seats and flipped 13 seats in Virginia’s legislature. While these results signal voter rejection of Trump’s record, analysts warn they reflect weak GOP fields and local dynamics, not a permanent tide shift. With party approval near 30%, Democrats must balance centrist and progressive wings and avoid complacency ahead of 2026 and 2028.

articles.title: Prop 50: Californians pass redistricting measure that helps Democrats flip up to five House seats
articles.trailText: Approval of measure could determine if Republicans keep full control of government in next year’s midterm elections
articles.summary: California voters approved Proposition 50, a redistricting measure championed by Gov. Gavin Newsom that overrides the independent commission to adopt legislature-drawn maps aimed at helping Democrats flip up to five Republican-held US House seats in deep-blue California. Passed with unprecedented turnout and nearly $170 million in funding, Prop 50 is framed as a counter to GOP gerrymanders—particularly in Texas—and could prove decisive in next year’s midterms by shaping a narrow Democratic majority. Opponents, including Rep. Kevin Kiley and ex-Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, decry its partisan nature. The new maps apply through 2030.

articles.title: ‘Time for a new era’: hope swells in New York as Zohran Mamdani makes history
articles.trailText: Supporters and high-profile New York Democrats gathered in Brooklyn to celebrate New York’s first Muslim mayor
articles.summary: At a Brooklyn Paramount Theatre election night party, democratic socialist Zohran Mamdani was elected New York City’s first Muslim mayor, defeating Andrew Cuomo and Curtis Sliwa with over 50% of the vote. Hundreds of jubilant supporters—including AOC, Jumaane Williams, Brad Lander, Letitia James and Cynthia Nixon—cheered his historic victory. Mamdani’s campaign emphasized hope, unity and a working-class mandate. Volunteers described “life-changing” energy. In his address he vowed universal childcare, rent freezes, fast free buses, and to confront Donald Trump, declaring a new era of inclusive, democratic socialist governance in NYC.

articles.title: ‘Turn the volume up’: Mamdani invokes Trump in fiery speech laying out plan of action
articles.trailText: As New York City’s mayor-elect reiterated his policies, the president posted ‘And so it begins!’ on his social media
articles.summary: New York City mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani, the city’s first Muslim mayor, used his victory speech to directly challenge Donald Trump’s politics of division and cronyism. After defeating Andrew Cuomo by eight points, Mamdani vowed to make NYC a “light in a moment of political darkness” by holding landlords accountable, dismantling corruption favoring the billionaire class, expanding labor protections and backing unions. He framed the city as a haven for immigrants, trans people, Black women and single mothers, then told Trump—whom he knew was “watching”—to “turn the volume up.” Trump replied on Truth Social with “…AND SO IT BEGINS!” and urged ending the filibuster and tightening voting laws.

articles.title: Nobody likes a sore loser – but Cuomo declines to bow out gracefully
articles.trailText: Despondency reigned at the Ziegfeld Ballroom – and then the beaten candidate found it hard to praise the victor
articles.summary: At his election-night party in the Ziegfeld Ballroom, former governor Andrew Cuomo lost to progressive newcomer Zohran Mamdani with 50% of the vote but refused to concede graciously. As dismayed supporters watched, Cuomo cast his defeat as a contest over the Democratic Party’s future, warning of dangerous radicalism, criticizing Mamdani’s alleged antisemitism and threats to the NYPD, and misrepresenting his platform. The tense, free-bar event ended with boos and jeers, underscoring Cuomo’s controversial, confrontational exit from New York politics.

articles.title: US government shutdown enters 36th day to become longest in history
articles.trailText: Shutdown beats record set during Trump’s first term as succession of Senate votes fails to yield breakthrough
articles.summary: On Nov. 4, the US shutdown entered its 36th day, surpassing the 2018–19 record, after Senate votes on GOP funding bills failed amid Democratic insistence on extending expiring ACA tax credits. Last night’s Democratic wins in New Jersey and Virginia governors’ races, the retention of liberal justices in Pennsylvania and new California maps have empowered party leaders. Republicans blame the impasse and propose ending the Senate filibuster. Over 700,000 furloughed workers, millions facing higher premiums and a potential $14 bn GDP hit underscore the stakes.

articles.title: At least seven dead and 11 injured after UPS plane crashes near a Kentucky airport
articles.trailText: Aircraft erupted into fireball after takeoff at Louisville international airport, and officials say fatalities could rise
articles.summary: A UPS McDonnell Douglas MD-11 freighter (34 years old) bound for Honolulu crashed seconds after takeoff from Louisville Muhammad Ali International Airport at about 5:15 pm ET, erupting in a fireball that ignited a recycling center and auto parts shop. Three crew members were aboard and now feared among at least seven confirmed dead, with 11 ground injuries. Flights were canceled, and shelter-in-place orders extended north to the Ohio River. Governor Andy Beshear says fatalities may rise; the NTSB leads the probe with FAA support. Mayor Craig Greenberg urges residents to report debris and avoid the active scene.

articles.title: Democrat Abigail Spanberger elected governor of Virginia
articles.trailText: Former congresswoman beats Republican Winsome Earle-Sears to become Virginia’s first female governor
articles.summary: Former CIA officer and three-term congresswoman Abigail Spanberger defeated Republican Winsome Earle-Sears 57%–43% to become Virginia’s first female governor as Democrats swept state races. Ghazala Hashmi won lieutenant governor, becoming the first Muslim woman elected statewide, and Jay Jones unseated GOP attorney general Jason Miyares despite a campaign controversy. Democrats are poised to expand their House of Delegates majority. Spanberger, succeeding term-limited Glenn Youngkin, campaigned on bipartisanship, healthcare, cost-of-living relief and pledged to defend federal workers and steer redistricting ahead of 2026.

articles.title: Democrat Mikie Sherrill elected governor of New Jersey
articles.trailText: Sherrill defeated Republican Jack Ciattarelli in race that suggests Democratic resilience amid Trump’s second term
articles.summary: Democratic congresswoman Mikie Sherrill, a moderate ex-prosecutor and Navy helicopter pilot, was elected New Jersey’s 57th governor, defeating Republican Jack Ciattarelli in a race seen as a test of Democratic resilience under President Trump’s second term. Sherrill’s win follows a competitive primary pitting moderates against progressives. Affordability topped voter concerns amid culture war debates on gender identity, immigration and same-sex marriage. The contest, marred by record leaks and debate smackdowns, offers a preview of the 2026 midterms.

articles.title: Historic first for Spanberger after considered campaign against Trump
articles.trailText: Democrat becomes first female governor in Virginia’s history and placed focus on living costs and public service
articles.summary: Abigail Spanberger, ex-CIA case officer and former US representative, was elected Virginia’s first female governor, focusing her successful campaign on cost-of-living relief, infrastructure, education and protecting democracy.
