A centrist Blue Dog Democrat known for bipartisan work on rural broadband, drug trafficking and veterans’ issues, she contrasted Trump-era policies by targeting them rather than Trump himself. Her public service narrative, from Postal Inspection Service to undercover CIA work, boosted her appeal. She defeated Republican Winsome Earle-Sears, fending off attacks on her civil rights and trans sports stances by emphasizing local control.

articles.title: Zohran Mamdani faces a daunting task: making New York affordable
articles.trailText: The democratic socialist promised free childcare, fast buses and a rent freeze – can he deliver before New Yorkers lose patience?
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani, 34-year-old democratic socialist, captured New York’s mayoralty with pledges to freeze rent, deliver free childcare and overhaul transit—funded by raising corporate taxes and a 2% levy on the ultra-wealthy. His insurgent, social-media-savvy campaign mobilized nearly 100,000 volunteers, drove record early voting and reinvigorated progressives nationwide. Now Mamdani must translate lofty promises into policy amid a resistant state legislature, Gov. Kathy Hochul’s opposition, potential federal funding threats from Donald Trump and New York’s notoriously complex governance. Success hinges on negotiating power, maintaining public patience and turning campaign momentum into concrete affordability reforms.

articles.title: Pennsylvania keeps three liberal justices, preserving swing-state court control
articles.trailText: Democrats maintain 5-2 majority as three judges win 10-year terms in a key swing-state court
articles.summary: Three liberal justices—Christine Donohue, Kevin Dougherty and David Wecht—secured 10-year retention on the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, preserving Democrats’ 5-2 majority. The court, pivotal on abortion and voting-rights rulings and known for striking down the 2018 gerrymandered map, saw unprecedented spending—over $15m—in this low-turnout retention contest. A complete ouster could have produced a split bench and uncertain interim appointments by Gov. Josh Shapiro. National figures, from Trump urging “no” votes to Obama and DNC chair Ken Martin backing retention, underscored the stakes in this key battleground state.

articles.title: Who is Zohran Mamdani, New York’s Democratic socialist new mayor?
articles.trailText: Charismatic and relatable, the 34-year old energized voters – and provided a blueprint for other progressives to follow
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani, 34-year-old democratic socialist, becomes New York’s first Muslim and South Asian mayor after a grassroots, social-media driven campaign focusing on economic justice, rent freezes, wealth taxes, universal childcare, fare-free buses and a $30 minimum wage. Born in Uganda to Indian parents and raised in NYC, the former assemblyman and community organizer energized diverse, young and first-time voters with multilingual outreach and viral moments like coining “halalflation.” His upset over establishment-backed Andrew Cuomo signals progressive momentum amid Republican Islamophobic attacks; he aims to address inequality amid Trump-era threats and will shape national Democratic debates.

articles.title: Zohran Mamdani elected mayor of New York on winning night for Democrats
articles.trailText: Democratic socialist, 34, becomes city’s first Muslim mayor as Democrats triumph in several other key races
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani, 34, a Queens state assembly member and democratic socialist, was elected New York City’s 111th mayor, becoming the first Muslim and South Asian to hold the office and the youngest in over a century. He won with over 50% of the vote, defeating Andrew Cuomo (40%) and Curtis Sliwa (7%) on a platform of rent freezes, affordable housing, a $30 minimum wage, free buses and wealth taxes. His grassroots, small-donor campaign, backed by Sanders, Ocasio-Cortez, Nadler, James, Hochul and Jeffries, capped a national night of Democratic wins despite age- and faith-based attacks and Islamophobic smears.

articles.title: Live NYC mayoral election results: Zohran Mamdani defeats Andrew Cuomo
articles.trailText: Check here for results as they come in, as leftwing Democrat wins race to become city’s next mayor
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani, a 34-year-old Queens assemblyman and democratic socialist, won NYC’s mayoral race, defeating independent Andrew Cuomo and Republican Curtis Sliwa. He led polls by 5–25 points after his primary win. Early voting saw over 732,000 ballots—65% of 2021 turnout. Mamdani, city’s first Muslim mayor, ran on rent freezes, free childcare expansion and fare-free buses, mobilizing young, working-class and communities of color. Cuomo’s late independent bid was overshadowed by past scandals; Sliwa’s outsider crime-fighter campaign failed to break through.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: US election day is an early referendum of president as government shutdown drags on
articles.trailText: Decisive races in New York City, Virginia and New Jersey in US government shutdown’s 35th day – key US politics stories from 4 November 2025 at a glance
articles.summary: US voters returned to polls in the first election of Donald Trump’s second term as a referendum on his popularity and Democrats’ rebound. Key contests include New York City’s mayoral race, New Jersey’s governorship and Virginia’s win by Abigail Spanberger. Californians vote on Prop 50, which could add five Democratic congressional seats via redistricting. The 35-day government shutdown persists after a 14th Senate funding-vote defeat and airspace-closure warnings. House Democrat Jamie Raskin accuses the DOJ of an Epstein inquiry cover-up. Ex-VP Dick Cheney dies at 84. Mexico’s president denies US troop plans; Liz Cheney falls amid Trump’s DOJ pressure.

articles.title: A cultural revolution? Trump’s America feels oddly familiar to those watching from China
articles.trailText: Demands of absolute loyalty and attacks on institutions have raised memories of Mao-style chaos from US watchers in China
articles.summary: Chinese observers say Trump’s second term mirrors Mao-style purges: absolute loyalty tests, media attacks, “Doge” bureaucracy raids and campus censorship. Ex-Shanghai comedian Vickie Wang feels US speech lines shift like in China, while exiled critic Deng Haiyan was doxxed over a tweet. Peking University’s Zhang Qianfan calls it a US “cultural revolution.” Government stakes in rare-earth startups and university self-censorship deepen fears of authoritarian drift despite court checks and press refusals to sign Pentagon rules.

articles.title: Trump administration warns shutdown could force US airspace closures
articles.trailText: Transport secretary says 35-day shutdown is causing severe air traffic controller shortages and warns of ‘mass chaos’
articles.summary: Transport Sec. Sean Duffy warns that the 35-day federal shutdown has left 2,000–3,000 air traffic controllers and 50,000 TSA officers unpaid, triggering severe shortages at 35 FAA facilities and nearly half of the 30 busiest US airports. He cautioned that if Congress fails to resolve its healthcare tax-credit dispute—Democrats insist on extending credits to prevent 2026 premium hikes—mass flight cancellations, widespread delays, and partial airspace closures could follow. Security waits reached 1–5 hours at LaGuardia, JFK, San Diego, and Houston, and Tuesday’s flight delays totaled 2,565. Reagan National briefly halted operations after a bomb threat.

articles.title: US Senate rejects funding package for 14th time with shutdown in 35th day
articles.trailText: But talks between factions are under way as Democrats and Republicans try to bring standoff to a close
articles.summary: The US federal shutdown reached a record-equalling 35th day after the Senate rejected for the 14th time a GOP House–passed funding bill. Democrats and Republicans are holding behind-the-scenes talks to avert surpassing the 35-day closure under Trump’s first term in 2018, amid furloughs and service disruptions—including cuts to SNAP, now at 50% capacity for 42 million Americans via emergency funds. President Trump threatened to withhold benefits until Democrats back the package and urged GOP senators to abolish the filibuster. Centrist lawmakers are negotiating a broader funding roadmap, including expiring ACA subsidies, while the White House demands an initial vote to reopen government.

articles.title: House Democrat accuses Trump’s DoJ of ‘gigantic cover-up’ over shut Epstein inquiry
articles.trailText: Jamie Raskin in letter questions why justice department abruptly ended investigation into Epstein co-conspirators
articles.summary: In a letter to AG Pam Bondi, Rep. Jamie Raskin (D-MD) accuses the Trump DOJ of abruptly ending a long-running FBI/SDNY probe into Jeffrey Epstein’s alleged co-conspirators, calling it a “shameful and gigantic cover-up.” Raskin notes nearly 50 survivors identified around 20 powerful figures aiding Epstein’s sex-trafficking ring and detailed its sophisticated structure and financing, yet the inquiry ceased in January 2025 after files moved to DOJ HQ. He demands records of post-transfer investigative steps and challenges DOJ/FBI claims that no evidence exists against uncharged third parties.

articles.title: Liz Cheney wanted to follow her father’s legacy. Instead, Trump ended her career
articles.trailText: Republicans ousted her after she dogged Trump for January 6, but the Cheneys’ influence lingers in his administration
articles.summary: Wyoming Rep. Liz Cheney, scion of Dick Cheney’s neoconservative legacy, initially backed Trump despite his Iraq repudiation but broke with him after the Jan. 6 insurrection—impeaching him and serving on the House committee investigating the riot. Republicans stripped her of leadership in May 2021 and she lost her 2022 primary to pro-Trump challengers. Though her father’s hawkish influence endures—Trump has ordered bombing raids on Iran and naval deployments off Venezuela—Cheney remains excluded, later receiving Biden’s Presidential Citizens Medal and a pre-emptive pardon after Trump threatened prosecution.

articles.title: Dick Cheney created the ground for Trump’s excesses, despite their differences
articles.trailText: The ironies of Cheney’s parting of ways with Donald Trump and modern day Republicans are numerous
articles.summary: Before his death, Dick Cheney, architect of the Bush administration’s assertive presidency and early ‘war on terror’—from the USA Patriot Act, Guantánamo and Iraq invasion to installing right-wing justices—became estranged from the modern GOP he helped shape. Deeply alarmed by Trump’s threats to democracy, he broke with Republicans, endorsing Democrat Kamala Harris, joining Liz Cheney on the Capitol steps after January 6. His legacy of seizing executive power and expanding counterterror measures laid the groundwork for the very presidential excesses he later decried.

articles.title: Maine’s largest healthcare system informed still-living patients of their own deaths
articles.trailText: More than 500 people received letters from MaineHealth expressing condolences and providing estate instructions
articles.summary: MaineHealth mailed condolence and estate-instruction letters to 531 living patients due to a computer glitch on October 20. Though none were flagged deceased in their records, recipients were told how to settle their estates, prompting shock and calls to verify their status. MaineHealth apologized, sent formal apologies, and resolved the system fault. One patient, worried about a pending bill, confirmed her well-being with staff, who quipped: “I’m glad to hear you’re still alive.” The incident follows a $25 million jury verdict against a MaineHealth subsidiary in October.

articles.title: Dick Cheney’s role in ‘war on terror’ may have paved way for Trumpism
articles.trailText: Former US vice-president a key figure in expanding White House’s power and ‘corrupting the intelligence-policy relationship’ to sell Iraq war
articles.summary: Dick Cheney, Bush’s vice-president (2001–09), seized on 9/11 to expand executive power—eroding intelligence independence, sidestepping international law, enforcing the Patriot Act, and overseeing CIA black-site torture. He personally browbeat CIA analysts at Langley, corrupting the intelligence-policy relationship to justify the 2003 Iraq invasion and lauded “enhanced interrogation��� despite no evidence of thwarted attacks. His precedents at Guantánamo and warrantless surveillance paved the way for Trump-era ICE tactics and branding dissent as “terrorism.” Unapologetic, he championed unfettered presidential authority, laying foundations for executive overreach and Trumpism.

articles.title: Dick Cheney obituary
articles.trailText: US vice-president who served under George W Bush and pushed hard for the invasion of Iraq
articles.summary: Dick Cheney, who died aged 84, was vice-president under George W Bush. Exercising unprecedented influence, he led the neo-conservative push for the 2003 Iraq invasion and backing "enhanced interrogation" post-9/11. As head of key policy hawks including Rumsfeld and Wolfowitz, Cheney drove decisions on Afghanistan and Iraq despite thin intelligence. Before that, he served as Nixon’s youngest White House chief of staff, Reagan-era defense secretary and was Halliburton CEO, profiting billions amid controversial Iraq contracts. After leaving office, he denounced Trump’s election denial, backing Democrats in 2024. Survived by wife Lynne and daughters Liz and Mary.

articles.title: Michelle Obama’s book details how the media’s fixation on her arms was used to ‘otherize’ her
articles.trailText: The Look, a new photo book, aims to offer insight into how the former first lady used fashion as a tool for visibility and representation
articles.summary: Michelle Obama’s new photo book, The Look, explores how media fixation on her bare arms—highlighted by her sleeveless Michael Kors inaugural portrait—was weaponized to otherize the first Black First Lady. Featuring insights from stylist Meredith Koop and designers, plus a Farah Jasmine Griffin foreword, it shows how Obama leveraged fashion—choosing Jason Wu over Oscar de la Renta, championing Black, Asian and Latina talent, and embracing high-low labels—to shape her public identity, resist “angry Black woman” tropes, invite inclusivity and underscore substance alongside style during her White House tenure.

articles.title: Prop 50: Californians vote on redistricting to counter redrawn Texas maps
articles.trailText: Ballot measure would let legislature redraw congressional districts to carve out five more Democratic seats
articles.summary: California’s Prop 50 asks voters to scrap the independent redistricting commission and hand mapmaking to the legislature to carve out five additional Democratic seats—directly countering Texas’s pro-GOP gerrymander. Championed by Governor Gavin Newsom, Barack Obama and leading Democrats as a defense of democratic norms, the measure leads in polls (57–62% support) and outpaces opponents in fundraising. Amid ICE raids, federal election observers in five counties and Trump’s false rigging claims, Prop 50 serves as a high-stakes bid to shape the 2026 House majority. Elections close at 8 pm; early returns showed 29% of mail ballots returned, and campaign spending by pro-Prop 50 groups far exceeds opposition.

articles.title: Dick Cheney, vice-president and giant of Republican politics, dies aged 84
articles.trailText: Cheney, who served under presidents from Nixon to George W Bush, will be remembered for controversial role after 9/11
articles.summary: Dick Cheney, 84, died Monday. A longtime Republican power broker, Cheney served Nixon, Ford, Reagan and George H.W. Bush as House member, White House chief of staff and defense secretary before becoming George W. Bush’s powerful vice-president. He steered post-9/11 policy with Donald Rumsfeld—launching the Afghanistan war—and championed the 2003 Iraq invasion on flawed WMD/al-Qaida claims later discredited. Cheney defended detainee torture, survived multiple heart attacks, a 2012 transplant and a hunting accident. His daughter Liz was censured for criticizing Trump, and in 2024 Cheney backed Democrat Kamala Harris, calling Trump an existential threat.

articles.title: Pennsylvania artist sorry for including Nazi camp arch on school parade float
articles.trailText: ‘I made a mistake,’ says artist who included cloned archway on Halloween float for a Catholic school
articles.summary: Pennsylvania artist Galen Shelly apologized after his Halloween parade float for Hanover’s St Joseph’s Catholic school inadvertently featured a replica of Auschwitz’s Arbeit Macht Frei gate. Shelly said a delayed shipment led him to source a cemetery arch online without realizing its Nazi origins. The Diocese of Harrisburg’s Bishop Timothy Senior condemned the “profoundly offensive” imagery, apologized to Jewish communities and vowed to tighten approval processes. School leaders also apologized for failing to review the float, calling for education and reflection.

articles.title: Dick Cheney remains divisive in death, drawing tributes and condemnation
articles.trailText: Leaders from Bush to Barrasso paid tribute to the former vice-president, whose career drew praise and controversy
articles.summary: Dick Cheney died at 84, prompting high-profile tributes and fierce condemnation. Former president George W. Bush lauded him as “a calm and steady presence” and “among the finest public servants” of his generation. Senators John Barrasso, Joni Ernst, Jon Husted and Majority Leader John Thune praised his leadership in Congress, Defense and the vice presidency. Governors Mike DeWine and Abigail Spanberger offered condolences. Critics—from activists Omar Suleiman and Hasan Piker to Alex Jones and George Santos���denounced his role in the Iraq War, torture programs and neocon agenda, underscoring his enduring divisiveness.

articles.title: Listeria outbreak in pasta meals linked to six deaths across 18 US states
articles.trailText: Listeria found in pasta sold by Trader Joe’s, Kroger and others as CDC urges people to check fridges and seek care if ill
articles.summary: Six people have died and 25 hospitalized in an ongoing listeria monocytogenes outbreak linked to precooked pasta meals sold at Kroger, Trader Joe’s, Albertsons, Sprouts and Walmart across 18 states, including one pregnancy-associated fetal loss. The CDC traced contamination to Nate’s Fine Foods products and has issued recalls of various linguine, farfalle, Alfredo and deli pasta salads. Consumers—especially seniors, pregnant women and immunocompromised—should check refrigerators, sanitize surfaces and seek medical care if symptomatic.

articles.title: Judge considers Democratic challenge to Trump troop deployment in Memphis
articles.trailText: City government declines to raise objection in court but state leaders and ACLU seek to block deployment of troops
articles.summary: Democratic officials, led by Shelby County Mayor Lee Harris and state representatives, sued over President Trump’s September deployment of the National Guard to Memphis, arguing it exceeds state militia authority without legislative approval and lacks required civil unrest. Backed by the ACLU, they challenge Tennessee’s redefinition of the guard as an 'army' exempt from militia limits and say deployment is political overreach. As part of the Memphis Safe Task Force, troops have aided in 1,500+ arrests; Memphis Mayor Paul Young declined to join, instead seeking to shape troop operations despite doubts about effectiveness.

articles.title: Could a win on California’s Prop 50 aid Gavin Newsom’s presidential hopes?
articles.trailText: The ballot measure win would be a significant political gain for the Golden state governor eyeing the White House
articles.summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom, positioning himself for a 2028 presidential run, has cast Proposition 50—a ballot measure to suspend the state’s independent redistricting commission and allow the legislature to redraw congressional districts for five additional Democratic seats—as a national “fight fire with fire” response to GOP gerrymanders. Inspired by Texas Democrats’ summer walkout, Prop 50 has drawn endorsements from Barack Obama, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and millions in small-dollar donations. If approved, it could boost Democrats’ odds of regaining the House by 10–15%, elevate Newsom’s profile as an anti-Trump leader and reshape his image beyond California’s liberal enclave.

articles.title: How Trump is weaponizing the DoJ to ‘bully, prosecute, punish and silence’ his foes
articles.trailText: President’s pressure on the department to prosecute his enemies is hurting US law and violating policies, say experts
articles.summary: Donald Trump is pressuring the DOJ to prosecute his political enemies using weak evidence and installed loyalists to file charges against James Comey, New York AG Letitia James and others. Over 100 ex-DOJ officials and multiple bipartisan amicus briefs argue these prosecutions violate departmental policies and the Constitution’s due process clause. Interim U.S. attorney Lindsey Halligan and MAGA lawyer Ed Martin have spearheaded these cases. Critics say Trump’s overt involvement and retaliation-driven agenda break DOJ tradition, threaten rule of law and may prompt dismissals before trial. Congressional Democrats liken it to Nixonian revenge and foresee lasting damage to the justice system.

articles.title: Trump administration to fund just half of food stamp benefits | First Thing
articles.trailText: Department of Agriculture using contingency funds to keep benefits going amid government shutdown. Plus, economists warn $70tn in inherited wealth over next decade will widen inequality
articles.summary: With congressional Republicans and Democrats deadlocked in a 35-day shutdown, USDA’s SNAP funding officially ran out Saturday, prompting the Department of Agriculture to deploy contingency reserves to finance only 50% of benefits for nearly 42 million recipients. This marks the first partial cut in SNAP’s 60-year history after President Trump threatened a full suspension—blocked by a federal judge. Food banks nationwide report surges and long lines as recipients scramble amid legal debate over executive impoundment versus Congressional appropriation authority, leaving low-income families facing heightened food insecurity.

articles.title: New York City voters head to polls for closely watched mayoral election
articles.trailText: Race has gained national attention with Trump threatening to pull federal funds from the city if Zohran Mamdani wins
articles.summary: New York City voters on Nov. 4 face a three-way mayoral race: Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani, a 34-year-old democratic socialist assemblyman leading by double digits on affordability; former Gov. Andrew Cuomo, ousted in June’s primary now running as an independent; and Republican Curtis Sliwa, founder of the Guardian Angels. Early voting has shattered records with over 735,000 ballots cast. National figures including former President Donald Trump have weighed in, with Trump urging support for Cuomo and threatening to withhold federal funds if Mamdani wins, labeling him a communist. Polls close at 9 pm ET.

articles.title: What to expect as voters test Trump’s sway and party power from New York to California
articles.trailText: Off-year elections, including Zohran Mamdani’s high-profile New York race, could reshape the political map
articles.summary: Off-year elections on Nov. 4 will test Trump’s sway and reshape the political map. In New York City, democratic socialist Zohran Mamdani—who upset Cuomo in the primary—could become mayor despite Cuomo’s independent bid. California voters may approve Prop 50 to redraw congressional maps and lock in up to five Democratic seats. New Jersey and Virginia are choosing successors to term-limited governors Phil Murphy and Glenn Youngkin in tight races between Mikie Sherrill and Jack Ciattarelli in NJ, and Abigail Spanberger and Winsome Earle-Sears in VA. Battles over legislative control, Virginia’s attorney general race, Pennsylvania supreme court retention and Minneapolis’s mayoral contest add further intrigue.

articles.title: The trouble with US veterans benefits isn’t ‘rampant’ fraud – it’s bureaucratic roadblocks, advocates say
articles.trailText: Veterans groups say recent Washington Post stories on VA disability payments paint a misleading picture. The paper stands by its reporting
articles.summary: The Washington Post’s year-long investigation claimed “rampant” VA disability fraud, citing 30 convictions and soaring payouts. Veterans groups, former VA officials and legal experts counter that the reporting overlooks genuine service-related injuries, mental health tolls and onerous documentation requirements that delay or deny rightful claims. They argue that prosecutions demonstrate an effective fraud deterrent and that cost spikes stem from prolonged Iraq/Afghanistan deployments, aging veterans and complex multi-symptom conditions. Bipartisan lawmakers and the VA have condemned the series as misleading and warn it may fuel proposals to slash benefits. The Post defends its data-driven findings; advocates call for streamlined, veteran-friendly reforms instead.

articles.title: Democrats fight to rebuild in key state races on election day
articles.trailText: With polls showing signs of recovery after a popularity slump, Tuesday’s results will test whether the party can regain voters’ trust
articles.summary: One year after Trump’s return to the White House, Tuesday’s off-year contests in New York, New Jersey and Virginia—and California’s Prop 50 vote—will test whether Democrats can rebound from historic lows and capitalize on improving economic ratings. In NYC, socialist Zohran Mamdani leads a three-way race by 25 points; in New Jersey, Congresswoman Mikie Sherrill and Republican Jack Ciattarelli are in a dead heat; and in Virginia, Abigail Spanberger holds a double-digit advantage. Voter concerns center on affordability, public safety and education as parties fight for narratives ahead of 2026.

articles.title: Family speaks out after death of man deported by ICE in vegetative state
articles.trailText: Randall Alberto Gamboa Esquivel’s family alleges negligence and inhumane treatment
articles.summary: Randall Alberto Gamboa Esquivel, a 52-year-old Costa Rican national, was detained by ICE in Texas in February after allegedly reentering the US illegally. His family lost contact in June, later learning he’d been diagnosed with unspecified psychosis, hospitalized, and flown home in September in a vegetative state. He died in Costa Rica on October 26. Relatives and human rights advocates accuse ICE of negligence and inhumane treatment; the Trump administration defends his care. In Costa Rica, former president Óscar Arias has called for transparency as the family demands answers.

articles.title: ‘They take the money and go’: why not everyone is mourning the end of USAID
articles.trailText: The long read: When Donald Trump set about dismantling USAID, many around the world were shocked. But on the ground in Sierra Leone, the latest betrayal was not unexpected
articles.summary: After Trump’s appointee Jeremy Lewin vowed to dismantle USAID—decrying a “global humanitarian complex��� that breeds dependency—experts warned cuts could cost millions of lives. On the ground in Sierra Leone, vendors, electricians and health workers voiced resignation, not panic, accustomed to erratic aid flows and dizzyingly byzantine funding. Deputy medical officer Mustapha Kabba admits he can’t track US grants funnelled through NGOs. Long-time observer David Kpakiwa, who’s seen Peace Corps volunteers, war interventions and Ebola responses come and go, laments “they take the money and go” and urges reform that learns from past failures without abandoning the vulnerable.

articles.title: Senate Republicans strike down Democratic proposal to fully fund Snap
articles.trailText: Democratic leaders decry ‘unbelievably cruel’ move, saying ‘Trump is using food as a weapon’ during shutdown
articles.summary: Senate Republicans blocked a unanimous‐consent resolution by Democrats to fully fund November SNAP benefits for 42 million recipients during the shutdown. GOP Whip John Barrasso called it a political stunt and insisted benefits hinge on reopening the government. The administration will tap $4.65 billion in USDA contingency funds—covering just half of the $8 billion monthly need. Democrats led by Schumer and Merkley decried the move as “unbelievably cruel,” accusing Trump of weaponizing hunger amid a potential record‐long shutdown.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president endorses and threatens on eve of New York City mayoral election
articles.trailText: Trump backs Cuomo on Truth Social post on election eve as Mamdani hits back – key US politics stories from 3 November
articles.summary: On the eve of the NYC mayoral vote, Trump endorsed independent Andrew Cuomo over socialist Zohran Mamdani on Truth Social, warning he’ll withhold most federal funding if Mamdani wins. Mamdani retorted that Trump’s pick serves his interests, not New Yorkers’. Meanwhile, the administration is halving November SNAP benefits for 42m recipients amid legal battles, a federal judge barred deploying the National Guard in Portland, and CBS aired an edited 60 Minutes interview in which Trump later feigned ignorance about pardoning Binance’s Changpeng Zhao. Plus brief updates on Nigeria, the royal family, a DC protester, an FDA resignation and billionaire wealth gains.

articles.title: Trump threatens to cut funds if ‘communist’ Mamdani wins mayoral election
articles.trailText: President backs Cuomo in election eve Truth Social post as Mamdani hits back at Trump’s ‘threat – it is not the law’
articles.summary: On the eve of New York’s mayoral election, former president Donald Trump warned on Truth Social that he would withhold federal funding from NYC if the “communist” candidate Zohran Mamdani wins, despite Congress controlling appropriations and impoundment bans. The administration has already blocked $18bn for a tunnel project and contested congestion-pricing funds; a judge ordered reversal of a $34m counterterrorism cut. Trump backed independent Andrew Cuomo over Mamdani, urging Republicans to follow suit. Mamdani denounced the threat as unlawful political coercion and leads polls by about 7 points.

articles.title: Two courts urge ICE to halt deportation of man wrongfully imprisoned for more than 40 years
articles.trailText: Legal resident ‘Subu’ Vedam being held in short-term center after getting murder conviction overturned earlier this year
articles.summary: Two courts—an immigration judge and a Pennsylvania federal judge—have stayed the deportation of 64-year-old legal permanent resident Subramanyam “Subu” Vedam, who spent 43 years incarcerated for a murder conviction overturned this year. Currently held at an ICE center in Louisiana, Vedam faces deportation over a 1983 no-contest plea for LSD delivery. His lawyers argue his wrongful imprisonment, community ties since infancy, and pursuit of citizenship outweigh the decades-old drug offense, while DHS insists the vacated murder ruling doesn’t nullify the drug conviction. The Board of Immigration Appeals’ review is pending.

articles.title: LA erupts in celebration after Dodgers clinch second World Series victory
articles.trailText: Throngs of people took to the streets, and Dodger Stadium, to mark team’s nail-biting win against Toronto Blue Jays
articles.summary: After edging the Toronto Blue Jays in a seven-game World Series, the Dodgers secured LA’s first consecutive championship in 25 years. Overnight fans set off flares downtown, then tens of thousands lined a Monday morning parade route, cheering as players rode a double-decker bus beneath homemade signs and Dodger flags. At a ticketed rally in Dodger Stadium—pumped by DJ Mustard and Ice Cube in a vintage Cadillac—Shohei Ohtani predicted a three-peat and MVP Yoshinobu Yamamoto vowed “losing is not an option.” Owner Mark Walter drew mixed cheers and boos over his private-prison ties and silence on ICE raids.

articles.title: Americans ‘dumbfounded by cruelty’ of Trump officials slashing Snap benefits
articles.trailText: Those among the 42 million enrolled in the program worry that cutoff of the benefit will send their lives into a tailspin
articles.summary: During the ongoing federal shutdown, the Trump administration announced a 50% cut to SNAP benefits for 42 million enrollees—an unprecedented move in the program’s 60-year history. A federal judge blocked a full suspension, but USDA claims funds are exhausted despite states’ lawsuits. Callouts from beneficiaries—housebound retiree Taras Stratelak in California, hospitalized Wisconsin resident Betty Standridge, Missouri veteran Donna Lynn and West Virginian Zachariah Kushner—warn they’ll skip fresh produce, eggs and even medications. An NBC poll finds 52% blame Trump for the shutdown. Many fear this partial halt is a prelude to dismantling SNAP, lamenting "cruelty" and vowing to hold Trump allies accountable.

articles.title: Mississippi woman fatally shoots monkey escaped from overturned truck
articles.trailText: Jessica Bond Ferguson said her 16-year-old told her about animal in the yard and she shot it to ‘protect her children���
articles.summary: After a truck carrying rhesus macaques overturned near Heidelberg, Mississippi, on Oct. 28, homeowner Jessica Bond Ferguson fatally shot one monkey in her yard on Nov. 2 after her son spotted it about 60 ft away. She said she fired to protect her five children amid warnings the animals might carry disease, though Tulane University later clarified the primates weren’t theirs and were pathogen-free. The Jasper County sheriff’s office recovered the carcass; three other monkeys remain at large. Wildlife officials say macaques are aggressive and continue trapping escaped research primates from scattered “live animals” crates.

articles.title: Trump approval rating falls to second-term low of 37%
articles.trailText: New CNN/SSRS survey shows decline in president’s popularity as 68% of respondents say things going badly
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s approval rating has fallen to a second-term low of 37%, with 63% disapproval in a CNN/SSRS survey of 1,245 adults conducted Oct 27–30. 68% say things are going “pretty/very badly” in the US. Economy and cost of living top concerns (47%), followed by the state of democracy (26%) and immigration (10%). 61% say his policies worsened the economy; 56% say his foreign policy hurt US global standing. 61% think he’s overstepped presidential powers. If midterm elections were held today, 41% would vote to oppose Trump, 21% to support him and 38% wouldn’t send a message about him.

articles.title: New York mayoral candidates campaign across city in final push before election
articles.trailText: Zohran Mamdani walked across Brooklyn Bridge while Andrew Cuomo headed to the Bronx
articles.summary: Frontrunner Zohran Mamdani, 34, emphasized affordability during a sunrise Brooklyn Bridge walk with AG Letitia James, Comptroller Brad Lander and supporters before canvassing in Queens. Ex-Governor Andrew Cuomo, now an independent after losing the June primary, held Spanish-language radio interviews and borough stops. Republican Curtis Sliwa lags in third. Early voting shattered records with over 735,000 ballots. National spotlight intensified when Trump labeled Mamdani a "communist" and backed Cuomo; Mamdani retorted "Trump endorses Cuomo." The ideological clash over experience, donors and vision peaks as polling stations open Tuesday.

articles.title: Trump administration will provide half of usual funds to Snap recipients in November
articles.trailText: Contingency funds will keep benefits going for nearly 42 million people in the food assistance program, says Trump
articles.summary: Amid a record 34-day federal shutdown, the USDA will use contingency funds to deliver 50% of November SNAP benefits to nearly 42 million recipients after Judge John McConnell ordered emergency funding in a Rhode Island case. The Trump administration had argued contingency cash is limited to disasters, but the court deemed that “arbitrary.” Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent seeks legal guidance to resume full payments. Meanwhile, states declare emergencies and convert stadiums and food banks to distribution sites, reporting long lines. SNAP’s federal cost hits about $8 billion monthly, and delayed relief has forced some states to front limited funds.

articles.title: Trump feels ‘very badly’ for British royal family after Prince Andrew was stripped of titles
articles.trailText: King Charles stripped his brother of his titles over relationship with Jeffrey Epstein, a former friend of Trump’s
articles.summary: Trump said he feels “very badly” for the royal family after King Charles stripped Prince Andrew of his titles and forced him to leave the Royal Lodge over his ties to Jeffrey Epstein and sexual assault claims by Virginia Giuffre. The disgraced ex-duke, now Andrew Mountbatten Windsor, denies underage abuse despite settling a £12m suit. UK defense secretary John Healey will remove his final naval honor, and a US lawmaker urged him to testify before a congressional inquiry amid renewed scrutiny following Giuffre’s posthumous memoir and DOJ’s confirmation no secret client list exists.

articles.title: The ground is swallowing homes in this Native village in Alaska. Residents have no choice but to move
articles.trailText: The climate crisis is causing the permafrost to melt in Alaska, forcing the village of Nunapitchuk to relocate
articles.summary: Nunapitchuk, a Yup’ik village in SW Alaska, is sinking as permafrost melts into “Alaskan quicksand,” tilting and flooding homes. With Alaska warming nearly four times faster than the global average, 750 residents voted in 2023 to relocate 3 miles uphill—a $230 m project they’ve funded with under $3 m. Federal assistance is piecemeal across 20+ agencies despite Biden’s $560 m tribal climate relocation initiative (partially frozen by the Trump administration) and GAO calls for centralized coordination. Meanwhile, erosion, mold outbreaks, asthma rates above 15%, overcrowding, sewage leaks and cultural erosion threaten health and heritage. Former tribal administrator Morris Alexie will address the crisis at COP 30.

articles.title: Two girls injured in fall from ferris wheel at Louisiana fairground
articles.trailText: Pair were thrown to the ground after the bucket in which they were seated flipped over
articles.summary: At the Harvest Festival fair in New Roads, Louisiana, two girls under 13 were thrown from a Ferris wheel bucket that flipped nearly 90° and hospitalized by helicopter with non–life-threatening injuries. Authorities suspect mechanical failure; the Louisiana state fire marshal cleared other rides after inspection. The incident follows a Kansas City roller-coaster seatbelt scare and a Zipper ride cable snap in Los Angeles, underscoring growing safety concerns and ongoing investigations into carnival and theme-park attractions.

articles.title: ‘In this ’til the end’: Maine Senate hopeful Graham Platner on refusing to quit amid furor over ‘Nazi’ tattoo
articles.trailText: Platner’s populist campaign faces backlash over past comments and a contentious tattoo
articles.summary: Graham Platner, a 41-year-old oysterman, Marine veteran and political newcomer, has surged as a populist Democrat in Maine’s U.S. Senate race, raising over $3 million and drawing thousands to rallies. He pledges to upend the ‘establishment’ by prioritizing working-class issues, slashing foreign military spending and bipartisanship on Wall Street reform. But Platner faces intense scrutiny after resurfaced racist, sexist and homophobic online posts and a chest tattoo resembling a Nazi emblem prompted staff resignations and demands for accountability. He has apologized, cited PTSD from combat, and covered the tattoo, while key backers—including Bernie Sanders, Sen. Ruben Gallego and DNC Chair Ken Martin—have stood by him. Polls still show him leading, as rivals like Gov. Janet Mills and Jordan Wood press him on character versus change.

articles.title: CBS News heavily edits Trump 60 Minutes interview, cutting boast network ‘paid me a lotta money’
articles.trailText: Trump said Paramount’s sale to David and Larry Ellison was ‘greatest thing that’s happened in a long time’ for free press
articles.summary: On Sunday’s 60 Minutes, CBS broadcast 28 of 90 minutes from Trump’s first sit-down in five years with Norah O’Donnell, later publishing a full transcript and a 73-minute online version. Trump last year sued CBS for editing a vice-president Harris interview, settling for $16m and securing future transcripts. Un-aired clips feature Trump boasting '60 Minutes paid me a lotta money,' praising Paramount’s sale to David and Larry Ellison and new editor-in-chief Bari Weiss, while CBS edited out his election-fraud and DC crime claims.

articles.title: Trump says he doesn’t know who crypto tycoon is despite having pardoned him
articles.trailText: Billionaire Changpeng Zhao pleaded guilty to enabling money laundering before president freed him last month
articles.summary: After pardoning Binance founder Changpeng Zhao for money-laundering convictions, Trump told CBS's 60 Minutes he “doesn't know who he is” and can't recall meeting him. Zhao, who pleaded guilty in 2023 to failing to report suspicious transactions involving Hamas and al-Qaida, served four months in prison, paid a $50m fine and kept his Binance stake. The White House framed the pardon as undoing Biden’s “war on cryptocurrency.” Zhao pledged to help make America “the Capital of Crypto.” Binance has ties to World Liberty Financial, owned by Trump’s family. The episode coincides with GOP probes of Biden-era autopen pardons.

articles.title: First Thing: Top 10 US billionaires’ wealth grew by $698bn in past year
articles.trailText: Oxfam says Trump policies risk driving inequality to new heights while noting Democrats have also exacerbated wealth gap. Plus, why Salman Rushdie’s therapist has called him a ‘badass’
articles.summary: Oxfam America reports that the combined net worth of the top 10 US billionaires jumped by $698 billion over the past year, warning that Trump administration tax cuts—dubbed the “one big, beautiful bill”—alongside past policies from both parties, threaten to deepen America’s wealth divide. Federal Reserve data (1989–2022) show the top 1% of households amassed 101 times more wealth than the median household (an $8.35 million gain per top‐tier household versus $83,000 for the average), and 987 times the assets of the bottom quintile.

articles.title: One way to redefine the first lady role: demolish Melania’s office to build a folly
articles.trailText: The president’s wife is reported to have ‘privately raised concerns about’ the destruction of the White House East Wing. If so, they were ignored
articles.summary: President Trump ordered demolition of the White House East Wing—traditional office for first ladies—to build a $300m ballroom, effectively ending Melania Trump���s D.C. base. In her second term she’s spent under two weeks at the residence, staffed a handful of aides versus 20+ predecessors, and prioritized personal privacy and lucrative deals like a $40m Amazon documentary. Though she launched Be Best, backed the Take It Down Act and discussed AI education, her low-profile approach breaks from the activist legacy of Roosevelt, Carter and Obama, underscoring a diminished, atypical role for the first lady.

articles.title: Top 10 US billionaires’ collective wealth grew by $698bn in past year – report
articles.trailText: Oxfam warns Trump policies risk driving inequality to new heights – but Democrats have also exacerbated wealth gap
articles.summary: Oxfam America reports the top 10 US billionaires saw a $698bn wealth surge in the past year, highlighting both Trump-era and prior bipartisan policies that widened inequality. Federal Reserve data (1989–2022) show the top 1% gained 101 times more than median households ($8.35m vs $83,000), while over 40% of Americans—nearly half of children—are low-income. Among OECD’s 10 largest economies, the US ranks worst in relative poverty, second-worst in child poverty and infant mortality, and second-lowest in life expectancy. The report urges reforms: campaign finance/antitrust measures, wealth/corporate taxes, stronger safety nets, and union protections.

articles.title: Trump says Maduro’s days are numbered but ‘doubts’ US will go to war with Venezuela
articles.trailText: President’s remarks, made during CBS interview released on Sunday, come as the US amasses military units in Caribbean
articles.summary: On CBS’s 60 Minutes, President Trump downplayed prospects of a US war with Venezuela—despite military units massing in the Caribbean and strikes on alleged drug vessels that killed at least 65—saying “I doubt it,” but predicted Nicolás Maduro’s “days as president were numbered.” Maduro calls US drug‐trafficking claims a pretext for regime change to seize oil. Trump also claimed Russia, China, North Korea and Pakistan perform secret underground nuclear tests and said the US will test weapons “like other countries,” though Energy Secretary Chris Wright insisted tests would be non-nuclear system checks.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Republicans insist Trump is ‘desperate’ to resolve shutdown as Snap payments end
articles.trailText: Mike Johnson claims ‘big-hearted’ president wants to reopen government; FBI fires official amid Patel’s outrage over stories about jet use – key US politics stories from Sunday 2 November
articles.summary: Republicans, led by House speaker Mike Johnson, portray Trump as “big-hearted” yet desperate to end the 33-day shutdown—even as SNAP benefits for up to 42m low-income Americans have halted and Trump funds a $300m Mar-a-Lago ballroom. Two federal judges ordered the release of $5bn to resume food aid. In other news: FBI director Kash Patel fired Steven Palmer over improper jet use; a US military strike killed three aboard an alleged drug vessel in the Caribbean; ICE raids in Chicago muted Día de los Muertos festivities; California voters eye a redistricting measure to curb Trump’s influence.

articles.title: Louisiana: Alexandria diocese files for bankruptcy over clergy abuse claims
articles.trailText: More than 40 Roman Catholic dioceses have filed chapter 11 claims, 28 of which had obvious indicators of abuse fallout
articles.summary: The Diocese of Alexandria filed for Chapter 11 in early November, becoming the 41st US Catholic institution to seek federal bankruptcy amid clergy abuse claims. According to Penn State, 28 others ended in settlements tied to abuse fallout. Bishop Robert W. Marshall cited pending sexual‐abuse claims exceeding diocesan resources and said bankruptcy would allow fair compensation for victims and continuation of ministries. Alexandria follows the New Orleans archdiocese’s 2020 reorganization, where survivors recently approved a nearly unanimous $230 million settlement—despite bondholder litigation alleging securities fraud—and secured release of clergy abuse files and strengthened child‐protection measures.

articles.title: FBI fires top official amid Kash Patel’s outrage over reports of agency jet use
articles.trailText: Patel reportedly became furious after revelation he flew to visit girlfriend as agency fires official who oversees fleet
articles.summary: After press reports that FBI Director Kash Patel flew a government jet to see his partner, singer Alexis Wilkins, perform at a wrestling event, the bureau fired Steven Palmer, head of its Critical Incident Response Group. Palmer, with 27 years’ tenure and responsible for major security threats and the agency’s jet fleet, was the third unit leader dismissed under Patel since February. Flight logs, initially public then blocked, revealed Patel’s trip. Patel defended the flight on X, slammed “fake news,” and noted he reimbursed personal travel per rules, reigniting scrutiny of his jet use.

articles.title: Republicans argue ‘big-hearted president’ Trump is keen to end shutdown
articles.trailText: House speaker says president has ‘tried everything he can’ even while Trump delays food benefits to millions
articles.summary: Top Republicans portray Trump as 'big-hearted president' eager to end 33-day shutdown amid mounting pain for Americans, yet he delays SNAP benefits even after court orders and continues extravagant White House ballroom spending. Johnson says Trump wants reopening; courts order $5bn contingency funds for 42m SNAP beneficiaries by Wednesday, but administration dithers awaiting legal clarifications. Trump pushes ending Senate filibuster instead. Democrats accuse him of 'weaponising hunger'. Polls stake Republicans blame 52% to 42%. Senate Democrats hold firm, tie reopening to ACA tax credits; only 3 Dems break ranks. Meanwhile, FAA controllers unpaid, causing airport delays; Duffy warns worsening delays.

articles.title: Obama calls Mamdani and offers to be ‘sounding board’ if he wins mayoral race
articles.trailText: Former president also praises Mamdani’s campaign against rivals Andrew Cuomo and Curtis Sliwa
articles.summary: Former President Barack Obama called NYC mayoral frontrunner Zohran Mamdani to offer himself as a “sounding board” should he win Tuesday’s election, praising his challenge to independent Andrew Cuomo and Republican Curtis Sliwa. Mamdani, a Uganda-born assembly member and democratic socialist, leads an Atlas poll with 40% (vs. 34% Cuomo, 24% Sliwa), boasts endorsements from Kamala Harris and Kathy Hochul, and is backed by small donors. His platform—taxing the wealthy, raising the corporate rate, freezing rents and expanding subsidized housing—has rattled financiers and invites GOP attacks over his socialism and Israel criticism. Reuters.

articles.title: Pall of ICE spoils weekend celebrations in Chicago: ‘I think people are just scared’
articles.trailText: Despite Illinois governor’s plea to let families celebrate Halloween and Día de los Muertos, agents used pepper spray and continued to arrest people
articles.summary: Since September, ICE raids around Chicago have cast a pall over Pilsen and Little Village’s Halloween and Día de los Muertos festivities. Despite Gov. Pritzker’s plea to pause enforcement, federal agents pepper-sprayed crowds on Oct. 25 and arrested alleged suspects near a middle school in Evanston on Oct. 31. Families say fear has emptied streets previously alive with trick-or-treaters, vendors and marigold-lined altars. Parents like Cecilia Romero and Marco DeSantiago describe a somber mood as children miss out on traditions. Community organizers pressed on with reduced-attendance altars and processions, determined to uphold cultural rituals amid heightened immigration enforcement.

articles.title: John F Kennedy grandson says Julia Fox’s bloody Jackie Halloween costume ‘disgusting’
articles.trailText: Jack Schlossberg says dangerous to evoke grandfather’s assassination; Fox says it’s a statement of Jackie’s ‘bravery’
articles.summary: Political writer Jack Schlossberg, JFK’s grandson, denounced Julia Fox’s Halloween costume—blood-spattered replica of Jackie Kennedy’s pink 1963 suit—as “disgusting, desperate and dangerous,” warning it glorifies political violence. Fox defended her look as an homage to Jackie’s “extraordinary bravery,” citing the first lady’s refusal to change her stained suit after the assassination to “expose brutality.” Presented at an Oct 30 New York party, the outfit reignited debate over taste, trauma and political violence amid a climate of high-profile threats, sparking mixed reactions online. TikTok users labeled it “disrespectful,” and Fox took to Instagram to defend its symbolism.

articles.title: California set to approve Prop 50 as voters signal displeasure with Trump
articles.trailText: Voters set to accept new maps to help Democrats counter Republican gerrymandering – and check president’s power
articles.summary: Proposition 50, the Election Rigging Response Act, would temporarily replace California’s independent congressional map with new districts designed to win five extra Democratic seats. Driven by a response to Texas’s mid-decade gerrymander and galvanized by anti-Trump sentiment, Gov. Gavin Newsom and national Democrats—including Barack Obama and AOC—back the measure. Republicans, badly outraised, decry a “Gavinmander” and warn of disenfranchisement. Early returns and polling show Prop 50 leading by over 20 points, potentially boosting Democrats’ House-majority odds by 10–15%. Voting ends Nov. 4.

articles.title: Abigail Spanberger presents herself as bulwark against chaos and cruelty
articles.trailText: Democratic candidate for governor of Virginia is betting that the antidote to Trumpism is unflashy competence and a focus on cost of living
articles.summary: Abigail Spanberger, a former CIA officer and three-term congresswoman, is running for Virginia governor on a message of steady, bipartisan competence and warding off chaos from Washington. At a Norfolk rally with Barack Obama, she highlighted cost-of-living concerns—housing, energy, healthcare—and advocated for laid-off federal workers, criticizing rival Winsome Earle-Sears for indifference to government shutdown victims. Spanberger downplays direct Trump references, instead touting her record as Congress’s most bipartisan member and cross-aisle bill passage under Trump and Biden. She aims to become Virginia's first female governor, positioning herself as a moderate bulwark against cultural extremes and economic recklessness.

articles.title: Hiking with the wildlife author who studies Yosemite’s high peaks: ‘These animals are equal to us’
articles.trailText: Inspired by childhood encyclopedias and Jane Goodall, Beth Pratt writes about the more than 150 species in the national park – and transports readers to a rarefied world
articles.summary: Conservationist Beth Pratt spent a decade observing over 150 species in Yosemite’s high country. Her new book, Yosemite Wildlife: The Wonder of Animal Life in California’s Sierra Nevada (the first in 100 years to focus solely on park fauna), blends intimate stories, research and Robb Hirsch’s photography in chapter-length profiles of mammals, reptiles, amphibians and insects—from feisty pikas and marmots fending off coyotes to high-altitude butterflies and century-dormant fairy shrimp. Inspired by childhood encyclopedias and Jane Goodall, Pratt’s work, part field notebook, part manifesto, underscores wildlife’s fragile margins amid climate threats, invites wonder and supports Yosemite Conservancy.

articles.title: Trump policies spur economic anxiety in US Republican heartland: ‘Tariffs are affecting everything’
articles.trailText: Rural US towns reel as policies like tariffs cause global manufacturing companies to reconsider major investment projects
articles.summary: Rural Republican strongholds like Jeffersonville, Ohio, greeted a $3.5bn LG-Honda EV battery plant with hope but worry as Trump-era tariffs and the end of clean-vehicle credits under Biden’s Inflation Reduction Act prompt multinationals to reevaluate investments. ICE raids on Korean workers and paused projects threaten 2,200 promised jobs, slowing construction and rescinding overtime in local parts suppliers. Similar concerns hit Toyota in Kentucky, Stellantis layoffs in the Midwest, and Roche investment plans in Indiana. With rural factory employment at stake, rising economic anxiety is eroding Trump’s support, even among former backers.

articles.title: The luxury gap: Trump builds his palace as Americans face going hungry
articles.trailText: Schmoozing the super-rich to fund a $300m ballroom while cutting food aid for those on low incomes threw the president’s architectural folly into sharp relief
articles.summary: At a lavish gold-accented dinner on October 15, Donald Trump entertained 130 major donors, CEOs and tech titans at the White House to finance his $300 million ballroom—built amid a government shutdown threatening food aid for 42 million SNAP recipients and furlough pay for federal workers. Democrats, led by Kamala Harris, decry “weaponising hunger” while Trump, who earned $1.8 billion last year, unilaterally demolished the East Wing and fired federal review commissions. Polls show 56 percent oppose the project, highlighting stark inequality.

articles.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene tells Bill Maher she believes extraterrestrials are demons
articles.trailText: Georgia Republican lawmaker also claims she didn’t know Rothschild family, of her ‘space laser’ theory, was Jewish
articles.summary: On HBO’s Real Time with Bill Maher, Georgia GOP Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, a self-described Bible-believing Christian, asserted she believes demons might be extraterrestrial fallen angels. During a panel on UFO theories and “demons,” she agreed aliens could be “fallen angels” from heaven. Greene also revisited her 2018 “space laser” conspiracy blaming the Rothschilds for California wildfires, claiming she didn’t know the family was Jewish and hadn’t meant any antisemitic implication. Her remarks underscored ideological distance with both her GOP colleagues and newfound cross-aisle admirers, who had praised her occasional breaks with party lines on healthcare, Gaza, the federal shutdown, and Epstein document handling.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president threatens military action in Nigeria over alleged killings of Christians
articles.trailText: President says he has instructed the newly named department of war to “prepare for possible action” in the West African country.
articles.summary: President Trump escalated his 'America First' foreign policy by labeling Nigeria a 'country of particular concern' for Christian persecution and ordering his newly named Department of War to prepare for 'fast, vicious and sweet' military action and halt all aid if violence continues. In domestic news, Sen. JD Vance doubled down on urging his Hindu wife’s conversion to Christianity; Halloween immigration raids in Chicago and LA persisted under Trump’s crackdown; Barack Obama stumped for Democrat Abigail Spanberger in Virginia; FAA warned of flight delays as a partial government shutdown depleted air traffic controllers.

articles.title: As Barack Obama stumps for other Democrats, the party gets to see what it lost
articles.trailText: The wit and wisdom of the superstar ex-US president make him the best candidate – too bad he can’t run
articles.summary: Former President Barack Obama has returned to active politics—making 25 public appearances in six months—to stump for Democratic candidates in New Jersey and Virginia. In Norfolk, he delivered a sharp, humor-laced critique of President Trump’s ‘daily lawlessness,’ from politicizing the Justice Department and deploying ICE in unmarked vans to promoting quack medicine and lavish spending on the White House. Obama’s wit and charisma rekindled memories of his own star power, underlining the void at the Democratic helm and reminding voters that the party’s best 2028 contender cannot run.

articles.title: Obama criticizes Trump and Republican policy in stump speech for Abigail Spanberger
articles.trailText: Former US president headlines event for Democratic candidate for Virginia governor, who leads in polls
articles.summary: At a Norfolk rally on Nov 1, Barack Obama campaigned for Democratic Virginia gubernatorial candidate Abigail Spanberger, warning that Republican policies follow a “downward trajectory.” Spanberger leads GOP Lt. Gov. Winsome Earle-Sears by 14 points (55%–41%) in a YouGov survey. Obama also stumped in Newark for Rep. Mikie Sherrill (51%–42% over Jack Ciattarelli), decrying ICE raids, national guard deployments and rising costs. He praised Spanberger’s bipartisan record, policy plans to cut healthcare, housing and energy expenses, and noted she could be Virginia’s first female governor.

articles.title: JD Vance repeats comments he wants wife Usha to convert to Christianity
articles.trailText: US vice-president announces to 10,000 attenders of Turning Point USA that he prefers wife, who is Hindu, to be Christian
articles.summary: At a Turning Point USA event before 10,000 backers, VP JD Vance reiterated that while he respects his Hindu wife Usha’s free will, he hopes she will one day convert to Christianity. He said they now raise their children in a Christian school; their eight-year-old has taken first communion, and he aligned his policy views with Catholic social teaching after his 2019 baptism. Usha Vance, who maintains her Hindu identity and shares both faiths’ traditions with their kids, has no plans to convert. The Hindu American Foundation criticized Vance’s remarks as undermining religious pluralism, and Vance condemned online attacks as anti-Christian bigotry.

articles.title: Trump policies loom large over New Jersey’s unpredictable governor’s race
articles.trailText: Race between Democrat Mikie Sherrill and Republican Jack Ciattarelli is drawing attention as preview of 2026 midterms
articles.summary: In New Jersey’s off-year gubernatorial contest, Democrat Rep. Mikie Sherrill, a former Navy pilot and prosecutor, faces Republican ex-lawmaker Jack Ciattarelli, backed by Donald Trump. With early voting underway, polls show Sherrill leading by single digits in a state that has flipped governor’s offices regularly and narrowed its 2024 presidential margin to 5.9 points. Both campaigns blend local issues—cost of living, healthcare, taxes—with Trump’s influence: Sherrill links Ciattarelli to “MAGA,” while he ties her to outgoing Gov. Phil Murphy. National figures from Obama to Ramaswamy have campaigned. Turnout is deemed decisive and seen as a bellwether for the 2026 midterms.

articles.title: California is voting on redistricting. An election skeptic runs the process in one county
articles.trailText: Clint Curtis is overseeing a 4 November ballot that could add five Democratic seats and reshape US politics
articles.summary: Clint Curtis, a former congressional candidate and prominent election skeptic, was appointed Shasta County’s election official in early 2025. Tasked with overseeing a November vote on suspending California’s independent redistricting commission to reshape five new Democratic US House seats, Curtis has implemented transparency measures—live-streamed processing, reduced drop boxes and new observers—but also hired activists and excluded a local media outlet, prompting censure threats. The measure aims to offset Texas’s partisan gerrymander and could alter US House balance. Critics warn his lack of experience and ties to denialist networks may sow distrust in a county long targeted by election-fraud conspiracies.

articles.title: Missing Louisiana girl, 13, rescued from box in Pennsylvania basement
articles.trailText: Police say Ki-Shawn Crumity, 26, met girl through Snapchat, and charged him with human trafficking and sexual assault
articles.summary: Thirteen-year-old Louisiana resident vanished October 20 after connecting with 26-year-old Ki-Shawn Crumity via Snapchat. Pittsburgh police rescued her from a sheet-covered box in Crumity’s Brighton Park basement, finding evidence of repeated sexual assault and cannabis-infused edibles used for grooming. Crumity faces human trafficking, sexual assault, unlawful contact with a minor and corruption of a child charges; he’s jailed without bail. Investigators also arrested Ronald Smith in Georgia and Alvin Hanson in New Orleans on kidnapping and contributing-to-delinquency counts. Louisiana Attorney General Liz Murrill warns against social media dangers as agencies across multiple states probe the case and expect further arrests.

articles.title: Trump’s immigration raids continue through Halloween in Chicago and Los Angeles
articles.trailText: In Chicago suburb, protesters confront ICE agents, whom Evanston mayor says ‘assaulted’ residents
articles.summary: Trump’s administration persisted with Halloween immigration raids in Chicago and Los Angeles. In Chicago, ICE, backed by deployed troops, made multiple arrests and clashed with protesters in the city and Evanston suburb, where video showed agents pinning residents, prompting assault accusations from Mayor Daniel Biss. In L.A., ICE officers donned horror‐themed masks during enforcement, eliciting a “Happy Halloween” DHS quip. Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker’s call for a holiday pause was rebuffed by Homeland Sec. Kristi Noem. These actions follow months of National Guard deployments in Democratic cities; D.C.’s Navy Yard saw five teenagers arrested.

articles.title: Daca recipients in Texas await judge’s ruling that could upend their lives
articles.trailText: People brought to US as children have built lives and are raising families – but could lose their ability to work legally
articles.summary: Texas may strip Daca work permits for 86,000 Dreamers after US district judge Andrew Hanen weighs competing federal proposals. Created in 2012, the program shields more than 500,000 childhood arrivals from deportation and grants two-year work permits renewable in Texas. A Trump-era plan seeks to bar new Texas applications and revoke existing permits, following a GOP-led suit that convinced the Fifth Circuit Daca is unlawful in Texas. Recipients, who pay $830m in state/local taxes and account for $2.1bn in Social Security and Medicare contributions nationally, fear losing jobs, homes and uprooting families.

articles.title: DeSantis accused of playing politics as Florida shatters executions record
articles.trailText: The state has killed 15 people this year with two more scheduled this month as death penalty in decline across US
articles.summary: Governor Ron DeSantis has overseen 15 executions in Florida this year—two more are scheduled—shattering the post-1976 record of eight. Death penalty opponents and groups like DPIC and Amnesty International accuse DeSantis of using lethal injections as political theater ahead of a potential 2028 presidential bid, lament the secrecy around his motives, and warn that accelerated schedules strain defenders and affect mental health. Florida now accounts for nearly 40% of US executions in 2025. A 2023 law cutting jury unanimity to eight out of 12 has expedited death sentences, despite 30 exonerations from death row.

articles.title: What the New York mayor’s race will reveal about the Democratic party
articles.trailText: The political differences between the two main candidates could have major implications for next year’s midterms
articles.summary: New York’s mayoral contest pits democratic socialist Zohran Mamdani—34, grassroots-powered, promising rent freezes, free childcare and transit—against Andrew Cuomo, former governor turned independent with ultra-rich donor support. The increasingly bitter race, marked by alleged racism, Islamophobic smears and an AI-generated ad scandal, finds Mamdani leading by double digits after defeating Cuomo in the primary. A clear progressive victory would force Senate and House leaders to adopt bold affordability and inequality policies ahead of 2026 midterms, while a Cuomo comeback could validate centrist, establishment strategies despite party unpopularity.

articles.title: US food banks rush to stock supplies amid the Snap lapse: ‘We’re going to garner all the resources we can’
articles.trailText: Food insecurity for millions of Americans is set to spike, with Trump officials saying Snap benefits will cease as the government shutdown enters its second month
articles.summary: As the federal shutdown stretches into its second month, the Trump administration says SNAP benefits for 42 million Americans will run out November 1—the program’s first lapse in its 50-year history. Food banks from Community Space in Los Angeles to Food Bank for NYC and Second Harvest Heartland in Minneapolis are racing to stock dry goods, refrigerated salads and protein amid surging demand from unemployed federal workers and families. Though two judges have blocked the cutoff, appeals loom. State emergency funding—$65 million in New York, $4 million in Minnesota and contingency draws in Atlanta—offers relief, but agencies warn they cannot match SNAP’s scale.

articles.title: Labor activist takes on Teamsters leader allying with Trump: ‘He doesn’t represent the workers’
articles.trailText: Richard Hooker Jr is running to replace Trump ally Sean O’Brien as president of the Teamsters International union
articles.summary: Richard Hooker Jr., secretary-treasurer of Teamsters Local 623 and the first Black head of that local, is challenging President Sean O’Brien in the 2026 election. Hooker accuses O’Brien—who once denounced Trump but then praised him at the 2024 RNC—of betraying 1.3 million members by skipping the union’s first presidential endorsement since 2000 and shifting donations toward Republicans. A former UPS handler, Hooker pledges to re-affiliate with the AFL-CIO, restore robust member protections, and end alleged intimidation tactics under O’Brien’s leadership.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Friday rulings hamper administration on food stamps, voting access
articles.trailText: President Trump received a trio of legal setbacks Friday– key US politics stories from 31 October at a glance
articles.summary: Three federal judges on Oct. 31 blocked key Trump policies: in Rhode Island and Massachusetts, courts ordered use of contingency funds to keep SNAP food stamps flowing to low-income Americans, and in DC a judge struck down the president’s proof-of-citizenship voter-registration directive as unconstitutional. Meanwhile, the DOJ subpoenaed 2020 election records from Georgia’s Fulton County; actor Harrison Ford publicly denounced Trump’s climate stance; adviser Stephen Miller intensified visa and refugee restrictions; and Kristi Noem refused Illinois’ request to pause Halloween immigration enforcement. Trump also urged filibuster repeal, and a poll found 56% disapprove of his White House East Wing overhaul.

articles.title: Trump administration blocked from suspending Snap benefits for millions of Americans
articles.trailText: One judge issued temporary restraining order while another judge ruled the government must continue to fund program that helps low-income households
articles.summary: Two federal judges in Rhode Island (Judge McConnell) and Massachusetts (Judge Talwani) issued back-to-back rulings blocking the Trump administration’s planned suspension of SNAP benefits amid the government shutdown. They ordered USDA to tap $5.25 billion contingency funds (and potentially $23 billion reserves) to sustain November food stamp payments for 42 million low-income Americans. Plaintiffs—US cities, NGOs, a union, 22 states, DC, and governors—argued the suspension was unlawful. The administration, citing lack of authority until a spending bill passes, plans appeals. Trump vowed to comply if courts clarify funding authority, while states deploy emergency aid.

articles.title: Maine mother whose daughter died of leukemia wins $25m in wrongful death suit
articles.trailText: Verdict delivered in favor of Lyndsey Sutherland over death of daughter ‘Jazzy’ after doctors failed to identify condition
articles.summary: A Maine civil jury has awarded Lyndsey Sutherland $25m after her 15-year-old daughter Jasmine ��Jazzy” Vincent died in 2021, misdiagnosed with pneumonia and gynecomastia before fatal acute lymphoblastic leukemia-induced cardiac arrest. The award comprises $10m for wrongful death and $15m for pain and suffering; Maine’s $750,000 statutory cap may trigger an appeal. Sutherland sued Mid Coast Medical Group for negligence; defense attorneys cited honest mistakes and shared provider responsibility, while jurors underscored accountability for misdiagnoses.

articles.title: Trump justice department seeks 2020 election records from Georgia county
articles.trailText: Request to Fulton county underscores determination to revive president’s falsehoods about election he lost
articles.summary: In late October, DOJ Civil Rights Division chief Harmeet Dhillon demanded Fulton County’s 2020 election records—voter rolls, chain-of-custody logs, ballot images, security seals and scanner paperwork—echoing subpoenas by Georgia’s GOP-led board. Despite prior exoneration, the board reopened probes and sought federal help. Citing the Civil Rights Act, NVRA and HAVA, Dhillon gave 15 days to comply, alleging ongoing transparency obstructions. Critics like law professor Justin Levitt contend the DOJ cited statutes broadly without a specific basis, calling it a fishing expedition. The request joins broader DOJ demands across 40 states and follows White House and DHS hires of 2020 election deniers.

articles.title: Senate declines to halt plan to kill off half-million barred owls by Fish and Wildlife Service
articles.trailText: Northern spotted owls are being squeezed out by the westward migration of the larger barred owls
articles.summary: On Oct. 31, the Senate voted 25–72 to reject Sen. John Kennedy’s resolution under the Congressional Review Act to block the US Fish and Wildlife Service’s plan to cull up to 450,000 invasive barred owls in Pacific Northwest old-growth forests. Barred owls—slightly larger and more adaptable than imperiled northern spotted owls—have displaced their cousin amid habitat loss. Under the controversial strategy, licensed “removal specialists” will identify and shoot barred owls, sparking an ethical debate among conservationists, animal welfare groups, some Republicans and the logging industry. Oregon’s senators back the decade-long research-based plan.

articles.title: UK newspaper editor calls Bill de Blasio fake interview blunder ‘humiliating’
articles.trailText: A Times associate editor reportedly addressed situation in an email to staff, saying: ‘We should have been on our guard’
articles.summary: In an internal email, Times associate editor Ian Brunskill termed the misattributed Bill de Blasio interview ‘humiliating’, faulting reporters for failing basic source checks and warning of ‘serious damage’ to the Murdoch-owned paper. He urged staff to verify identities, question plausibility and cross-check information, citing another recent AI-generated fake royal case study. The error occurred when reporter Bevan Hurley attributed critical quotes of Zohran Mamdani to the former NYC mayor, later revealed to be Long Island wine importer Bill DeBlasio. The paper retracted the article after public outcry.

articles.title: Democratic representative urges former prince Andrew to testify over Epstein
articles.trailText: Ro Khanna, member of the House oversight panel, said Mountbatten Windsor should provide information
articles.summary: California Democrat Ro Khanna, a member of the House oversight committee, urged the former Prince Andrew to testify in the GOP-led inquiry into government handling of the Jeffrey Epstein case. He echoed UK trade minister Chris Bryant’s call for Andrew—stripped of royal titles—to comply with demands for information on alleged abuse with Epstein. Lacking subpoena power, Khanna and GOP Rep. Thomas Massie have filed a bill and discharge petition (213 Dems, 4 GOP) to force document release; Speaker Mike Johnson has blocked a vote amid the shutdown.

articles.title: US electricity bills increased by 11% in Trump’s second term, data shows
articles.trailText: New analysis prompts letter to Trump from Elizabeth Warren: ‘Your administration has no answers for families hit by high energy costs’
articles.summary: Democratic senators Elizabeth Warren, Ed Markey and Jeff Merkley warn that average US electricity prices rose 11% nationally since President Donald Trump’s second term began, contradicting his pledge to halve energy costs by 2026. A Climate Power analysis of US EIA data attributes the rise to Trump’s policies boosting expensive coal, rolling back wind and solar projects that could have powered 12m homes, eliminating or reducing clean energy funding and low-income aid, and imposing inconsistent tariffs that hike transmission material costs. They note 150,000 clean energy jobs lost or stalled and urge the administration to restore project funding, reverse fossil fuel mandates and secure energy-bill assistance before winter.

articles.title: There is opposition to Trump – and it’s growing | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Linda Rabben and her friends realise that they can’t wait for the Democratic party to save them from tyranny
articles.summary: Linda Rabben refutes claims that there is no opposition to Trump, citing an estimated 7 million participants in 2,700 No Kings demonstrations on 18 October and hundreds of thousands of daily protests against the administration’s lawless actions. In northeast Baltimore, 60 neighbors wave signs to honking motorists, while thousands of Americans fund legal advocacy groups pursuing hundreds of lawsuits challenging the regime’s illegal measures. Rabben argues this rapidly growing mass-opposition proves citizens can’t wait for the Democratic Party—they must save democracy themselves.

articles.title: Tucker Carlson’s interview with far-right antisemite Nick Fuentes divides conservatives
articles.trailText: Heritage Foundation defended former Fox News host, others slammed him for platforming white supremacist
articles.summary: Conservatives split over Tucker Carlson’s decision to host antisemite Nick Fuentes, who attacked ‘Christian Zionists�� like Ted Cruz and George W. Bush. Heritage Foundation president Kevin Roberts defended Carlson and condemned ‘cancel culture,’ arguing conservatives need not reflexively back Israel. Senators such as Cruz and groups like the Republican Jewish Coalition blasted the interview as mainstreaming hatred, warning antisemitism poses an ‘existential crisis’ for the GOP. Democrats led by Chuck Schumer also decried the move, while conservative media criticized Carlson for failing to challenge Fuentes’s praise of Hitler and conspiratorial claims.

articles.title: Trump calls on Republicans to abolish the Senate filibuster rule
articles.trailText: Calling Democrats ‘stone cold crazy’, president says ‘nuclear option’ is necessary to end government shutdown
articles.summary: Donald Trump urged Republicans to abolish the Senate filibuster—invoking the “nuclear option” to end the 30-day government shutdown amid a standoff with Democrats. He blasted Democrats as “stone cold crazy” on Truth Social and demanded a simple-majority vote to scrap the 60-vote threshold. Senate GOP leader John Thune and senators John Curtis and Thom Tillis oppose weakening the rule, while Tommy Tuberville has signaled conditional support. With 53 Republicans, Trump lacks guaranteed backing. House Speaker Mike Johnson warned of the filibuster’s safeguards but stopped short of outright rejection.

articles.title: Kennedy Center ticket sales fall to lowest in years after Trump’s takeover
articles.trailText: About 43% of tickets for typical productions remained unsold this fall as people pledge to boycott the institution
articles.summary: Following Donald Trump’s self-appointment as board chair and trustee overhaul in February, Kennedy Center ticket sales across its Opera House, Concert Hall and Eisenhower Theater plunged. A Washington Post analysis of Sept. 3–Oct. 19 data shows just 57% of seats sold or comped this fall—down from 93% in 2024 and 80% in 2023—leaving 43% unsold.
