The slump reflects patron and performer boycotts, a downturn in DC tourism tied to National Guard deployments, and a $1.6 million (36%) drop in subscription revenue; productions including Hamilton saw cancellations.

articles.title: What is the filibuster and why does Trump want to get rid of it?
articles.trailText: US president suggested ending the filibuster to conclude the federal government shutdown. Here is what to know
articles.summary: President Trump urged invoking the “nuclear option” to abolish the Senate filibuster and break a month-long government shutdown, arguing Republicans, with 53 seats, could reopen the federal government without Democratic votes or concessions on rising Affordable Care Act subsidies. The filibuster allows any 41-member minority to block legislation, historically used to defend and derail policies—from Jim Crow segregation and civil-rights bills to border wall funding. Critics note it lacks constitutional standing, emerged in WWI, and can itself be ended by majority vote. Democrats previously eyed filibuster repeal under Biden, while centrists still defend it as a check against majority overreach.

articles.title: Illinois advocates sue over ‘torturous’ conditions at Chicago-area ICE facility
articles.trailText: Agents allegedly denied people held at Broadview private calls with attorneys and blocked lawmakers and journalists
articles.summary: ACLU of Illinois and MacArthur Justice Center sued ICE, CBP and DHS over alleged inhumane conditions at the Broadview facility near Chicago. They claim detainees are denied private attorney calls, blocked from meeting lawmakers, faith leaders and journalists, coerced into signing away rights, and deprived of food, medical care and basic necessities—violating Fifth Amendment due process and First Amendment counsel access. They seek court orders to improve conditions. DHS denies the allegations amid protests and related lawsuits over use of force.

articles.title: Kristi Noem denies request to halt immigration crackdown for Halloween
articles.trailText: Illinois governor had asked for pause after border patrol agents reportedly used teargas to disrupt Halloween parade
articles.summary: DHS Secretary Kristi Noem has rejected Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker’s request to pause federal immigration raids during Halloween after reports that CBP agents used teargas at a children’s parade in northwest Chicago. Pritzker argued that aggressive enforcement endangered residents and traumatized trick-or-treaters, calling for a temporary halt. Noem refused, defending continued operations to “keep communities safe,” lamenting threats against ICE officers and condemning the governor’s plea as “shameful.” Pritzker fired back on social media, mocking Noem’s law enforcement–themed costumes and decrying policies that risk “tear gassing children trick-or-treating.”

articles.title: CDC employees on chaos of being fired, rehired and fired again: ‘stuck in limbo’
articles.trailText: Americans’ health in jeopardy as agency plunged into tumult and inefficiency even after court ruled firings illegal
articles.summary: Multiple rounds of illegal reduction-in-force notices have left about a quarter of CDC staff fired, reinstated and fired again—sometimes by email—creating chaos and eroding key public-health functions. From ethics and IRB oversight to the MMWR journal, HR, library and Washington office, critical units were eliminated despite legal injunctions. Union lawsuits allege 1,300 layoffs—including HR staff cuts—were wrongly processed. Employees like Aryn Backus face administrative limbo amid ongoing litigation. Staffers have endured harassment and a gun attack at CDC HQ, and claims of coding errors fail to allay fears that vital research and policy work is decimated.

articles.title: They were teacher and student in exile. Now this Democrat and Republican face off in Ohio
articles.trailText: Bhuwan Pyakurel and Kamal Subedi’s story charts a Bhutanese refugee community’s rise – and its growing political divide
articles.summary: Bhuwan Pyakurel, the first Bhutanese refugee elected to US office as a Reynoldsburg, Ohio Democratic councilman, faces off on Nov. 4 against his former refugee camp teacher, Kamal Subedi, now a Republican candidate. Their contest splits the 8,000-strong local Bhutanese community and ignites global diaspora debates on Facebook and WhatsApp over GOP policies leading to refugee deportations. Pyakurel decries Subedi’s party’s record as betrayal; Subedi says participation can reshape Republican narratives.

articles.title: First Thing: US to limit refugee numbers to 7,500 with priority for white South Africans
articles.trailText: US refugee groups say move ‘lowers our moral standing.’ Plus, unionized Starbucks workers to vote on strikes over pay and conditions
articles.summary: The Trump administration will cap US refugee admissions at 7,500 for 2025, down from 125,000 under Biden, prioritizing white South Africans amid disputed land expropriation claims. Advocacy groups decry the move as undermining moral standing. Meanwhile, ICE faces a federal probe after two shootings in southern California. Hurricane Melissa has killed at least 49 in the Caribbean as relief efforts intensify. Unionized Starbucks workers are voting on potential strikes over pay and conditions, highlighting a median employee salary of $14,674 versus CEO Brian Niccol’s $97.8m pay.

articles.title: How Stephen Miller is turning the US state department into an ‘anti-immigration machine’
articles.trailText: Miller is one of the most powerful officials in Trump���s White House, illustrating how it has sought to overcome a ‘deep state’ of professional diplomats
articles.summary: Stephen Miller, Trump’s homeland security adviser, has transformed the State Department’s visa and refugee processes into an ‘anti-immigration machine’ via daily “Stephen Miller calls” convening conservative diplomats, pressing for mass deportations (even to third countries), visa revocations (targeting Gaza war protesters and critics of conservative figures), caps on refugees and bans on nationals from 19 countries, and prioritizing white South African applicants. Installed allies—often from the Ben Franklin Fellowship—in key consular and PRM posts to override career diplomats, drawing criticism for politicization and racial bias.

articles.title: The ex-CIA scientist brothers perfecting Halloween
articles.trailText: Jeff and Brian Park spent 40 years working in secret at a CIA lab – but science is just one part of their lives
articles.summary: On Crowley Place in Alexandria, VA, Jeff (78) and Brian Park (75)—ex-CIA technical services scientists with 40-year careers sabotaging Russian weapon systems, engineering bubble-memory spy cameras, drones and night-vision beacons for Special Ops—transform their adjacent front yards each Halloween into a six-week, CIA-inspired animatronic spectacle. Since 1977 they’ve used rescued electronics, radar, sonar, VR rigs, sound systems and smoke machines to build interactive skeletons, robots, creatures and a miniature railway. Thousands visit as the Parks, who retired in 2014, still apply covert tech to delight and spook kids.

articles.title: More than half of Americans disapprove of Trump demolishing East Wing – poll
articles.trailText: Survey, in which one-third respondents voted for the president, found 56% disagree with move
articles.summary: An ABC News/Washington Post/Ipsos poll conducted Oct 24–28 finds 56% of Americans disapprove of President Trump’s demolition of the White House East Wing to build a $300 m, 90,000-sq-ft ballroom, with 28% approval. Respondents—mostly white—split roughly one-third each as 2024 Trump voters, Harris voters, and others. Built in 1902 under Theodore Roosevelt and expanded by FDR in 1942, the East Wing housed the first lady’s staff and a secret war-era bunker. Trump had promised no demolition, claiming personal and private funding. Similar Yahoo/YouGov data show 61% opposition. Critics, including ex-official Elaine Kamarck, decry the project as an “abomination.”

articles.title: Radio Free Asia suspends news operations amid cuts and US government shutdown
articles.trailText: RFA will begin closing overseas bureaus, as well as laying off and paying severance to staff members, with the hope that it could return in the future
articles.summary: Facing the US government shutdown and Trump administration budget cuts to government-funded broadcasters, Radio Free Asia announced it will suspend all news content production for the first time in its 29-year history. To conserve limited resources and preserve the option to resume operations, RFA will close overseas bureaus, lay off staff and pay severance—most employees have been on unpaid leave since March. Known for reporting on China’s Uyghur crackdown, Myanmar’s coup aftermath and North Korean defectors, its closure drew criticism from rights groups and former US envoy Nicholas Burns. In contrast, sister outlet RFE/Radio Liberty remains online using reserves.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Four Senate Republicans join Democrats to reject global tariffs
articles.trailText: Despite the rare opposition in the Senate, the House is unlikely to take any similar action – key US politics stories from Thursday 30 October at a glance
articles.summary: Senate Republicans Susan Collins, Mitch McConnell, Rand Paul and Lisa Murkowski joined Democrats in a 51-47 vote to nullify President Trump’s global tariffs on over 100 nations, the third bipartisan rebuke this week; the House, under GOP rules, won't vote on similar resolutions. The administration will cap refugee admissions at 7,500, prioritizing white South Africans; New York freed $65m for food banks amid a looming shutdown; Trump and Xi reached a rare-earths agreement; Trump ordered the Pentagon to resume nuclear tests; the Senate postponed surgeon general nominee Casey Means’s hearing. Briefs: Halloween ICE raids, secret detentions, a California ICE shooting, Prince Andrew’s titles stripped, and candy prices rising.

articles.title: Trump ally Stephen Miller at heart of FBI agent purge, new book reveals
articles.trailText: Miller urged firings of those who had investigated president to satisfy Trump’s desire for revenge, Injustice authors write
articles.summary: In Injustice: How Politics and Fear Vanquished America’s Justice Department, Carol Leonnig and Aaron Davis reveal that Stephen Miller, Trump’s deputy chief of staff, spearheaded a campaign—backed by DOJ enforcer Emil Bove—to purge FBI agents who probed the January 6 insurrection and Mar-a-Lago classified documents. Miller leaned on Bove to force acting FBI director Brian Driscoll to hand over names for firing. Driscoll refused, citing bureau protocol and supplied only ID numbers. The clash led to senior departures and an FBI Agents Association lawsuit to block politically driven dismissals.

articles.title: California: officials investigate after second shooting by ICE agents in a week
articles.trailText: Shooting at vehicle in Ontario comes as Trump officials attempt to step up deportation operations across US
articles.summary: ICE agents opened fire Thursday during a vehicle stop in Ontario, California, marking the second regional shooting by the agency in a week. DHS says officers ordered a non-target driver to leave; when his car reversed toward them, a frightened agent fired defensive shots. The suspect fled, abandoning the vehicle. Last week, agents shot TikTok creator Carlitos Ricardo Parias in Los Angeles; in Phoenix on Wednesday, an ICE officer also discharged at a fleeing vehicle. These incidents coincide with the Trump administration’s push to expand deportations, leadership overhauls at ICE and growing concerns over facility deaths and community fear of raids.

articles.title: Will the real De Blasio please stand up? A lesson from a UK newspaper’s gaffe
articles.trailText: The Times thought they were interviewing ex-NYC mayor Bill de Blasio. They were actually talking to a wine importer
articles.summary: UK’s Times mistakenly published quotes allegedly from ex-NYC mayor Bill de Blasio attacking mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani. De Blasio swiftly denied the remarks, demanding retraction. The paper had in fact interviewed Bill DeBlasio, a Long Island wine importer, who used ChatGPT to fashion faux-political commentary. The Times apologized and removed the story. The gaffe underscores lapses in source verification: the reporter relied on an unverified email address and accepted AI-generated responses as genuine mayoral statements, highlighting risks of digital impersonation and the need for stringent vetting in modern journalism.

articles.title: New Orleans sexual abuse victims approve $230m Catholic church settlement
articles.trailText: Victims to receive payments based on severity and effects of abuse perpetrated by members of clergy
articles.summary: Victims of child sexual abuse by New Orleans clergy approved a $230m bankruptcy settlement by 99.63% of the hundreds voting, endorsing a plan that allocates payments based on abuse severity and effects, mandates disclosure of clergy abuse files and stronger safeguards. Survivors’ attorneys initially opposed over a $50m guarantee tied to property sales but backed an amended deal. The plan faces confirmation hearings in mid-November. The archdiocese filed in 2020 after Louisiana lifted long-blocked abuse suits, spent $50m on legal fees, and was embroiled in scandal over priest Lawrence Hecker’s decades-long shielding.

articles.title: ‘You got some pants on, officer?’: video from Detroit virtual court hearing goes viral
articles.trailText: Police officer introduced himself to virtual courtroom and inadvertently revealed himself not to be wearing trousers
articles.summary: During a virtual hearing in Detroit’s 36th district court on Monday, Officer Matthew Jackson introduced himself to Judge Sean Perkins without trousers, prompting Perkins’ quip, “You got some pants on, officer?” After Jackson acknowledged he wasn’t wearing pants and repositioned his camera, defense attorney TaTaNisha Reed told ABC7 she was “trying to figure out” if she’d seen correctly, especially from a police officer. Proceedings continued in a drag-racing case. Chief Judge William McConico called Jackson “very professional,” while Detroit Police Chief Todd Bettison issued an apology, underscoring departmental standards for dignified court appearances and promising disciplinary action.

articles.title: US Senate votes to reject Trump’s global tariffs on more than 100 countries
articles.trailText: Vote passes 51-47 in latest bipartisan effort to challenge tariffs, but House is unlikely to take any similar action
articles.summary: The US Senate voted 51-47 to nullify President Trump’s executive-order “reciprocal” tariffs on over 100 countries, with four Republicans (Collins, McConnell, Paul, Murkowski) joining all Democrats. It marked the third bipartisan tariff rebuke this week after resolutions against Brazil and Canada duties. Such GOP dissent is rare in Trump’s second term. The vote coincides with Trump’s Asia trip, where he agreed with China to reduce tariffs and boost soybean purchases. Despite Senate approval, House rules block similar measures from reaching the floor. Democrats view the symbolic challenge as a lever to influence Trump’s trade stance, says Sen. Kaine.

articles.title: Teacher tells court she thought she had died after six-year-old shot her in Virginia school
articles.trailText: Abby Zwerner is suing former assistant principal for $40m, saying she failed to act after reports that child had gun
articles.summary: Abby Zwerner, a former first-grade teacher at Richneck Elementary in Newport News, Virginia, testified in her $40m civil suit against ex-assistant principal Ebony Parker, claiming Parker ignored warnings before a six-year-old student shot Zwerner in the hand and chest in January 2023. Zwerner underwent six surgeries, retains a bullet near her heart, and lost full use of her left hand. She describes believing she’d died, struggles with everyday tasks, retrained as a cosmetologist but remains unable to work. Parker faces an upcoming felony neglect trial; the shooter’s mother was jailed for child neglect and weapons charges.

articles.title: Thieves steal more than 1,000 items from Oakland museum in ‘brazen’ heist
articles.trailText: Artifacts such as Native American baskets, ivory carvings and daguerreotypes taken in early morning burglary
articles.summary: On 15 October at 3:30am, burglars broke into the Oakland Museum of California’s off-site storage and stole more than 1,000 items – Native American baskets, ivory carvings, daguerreotypes and laptops – from a collection exceeding 2 million objects. Discovered the next morning, the audacious heist prompted an FBI art crime team and Oakland PD investigation. CEO Lori Fogarty called it a brazen act robbing California’s cultural heritage. With no staff on site, officials believe it was opportunistic. The theft drew comparisons as Paris’s Louvre heist arrests made headlines.

articles.title: New York declares state of emergency to award food banks $65m amid shutdown
articles.trailText: Oregon and Virginia also issued emergency declarations to fund food assistance as shutdown imperils Snap benefits
articles.summary: Governor Kathy Hochul declared a state of emergency in New York to unlock $65 million for food banks as federal SNAP funding—about $650 million/month for NY and $8 billion nationwide—faces lapse on Nov. 1 amid the shutdown. Oregon’s Democratic governor Tina Kotek and Virginia’s Republican Glenn Youngkin made similar pledges: $5 million and surplus reserves, respectively. Meanwhile Louisiana, New Mexico and Vermont announced support. Twenty-one Democratic governors urged the USDA to tap contingency funds, and a coalition of states sued the administration to restore November benefits.

articles.title: US will limit number of refugees to 7,500 and give priority to white South Africans
articles.trailText: Low number represents a dramatic drop after US previously allowed in hundreds of thousands of people fleeing war and persecution
articles.summary: The Trump administration will cap refugee admissions at 7,500 for FY2026—a collapse from Biden’s 125,000 ceiling���and primarily reserve slots for white South African Afrikaners. A Federal Register notice justified it as ‘humanitarian or in the national interest’ yet gave no rationale. The move drew sharp rebuke from IRAP, Global Refuge’s CEO and the American Immigration Council, who decry its politicization of US humanitarian policy, moral erosion and exclusion of vetted refugees. It mirrors Trump’s cuts (18,000 in FY2020, 15,000 in FY2021) and follows his order against South Africa’s land reforms.

articles.title: US climate activists condemn 18-month jail term for nonviolent art museum protester
articles.trailText: ‘It’s hard to fathom how a peaceful protester can receive more prison time than many of the insurrectionists,’ said one researcher, of Timothy Martin’s sentence
articles.summary: Climate activists condemned an 18-month federal sentence for Timothy Martin, 55, who in April 2023 smeared washable paint on the glass covering Edgar Degas’s Little Dancer at the National Gallery of Art in a nonviolent climate protest. Convicted of conspiracy and injury to a federal exhibit, he’ll serve 12 more months plus probation, community service and $4,250 restitution—a term critics say exceeds many January 6 insurrection sentences. Joanna Smith got 60 days on a reduced plea. Activists warn the ruling chills free speech and signals a broader crackdown on environmental protests.

articles.title: Senate postpones hearing for Trump’s surgeon general pick after she goes into labor
articles.trailText: Casey Means, a leading Maha figure with an inactive medical license, is Trump’s second pick for the role
articles.summary: Senate postponed its hearing for Trump’s surgeon general nominee Dr. Casey Means after she went into labor with her first child. Means, a Stanford-trained physician with an inactive medical license turned wellness influencer and author of Good Energy, was slated to be the first nominee to appear virtually before the Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee. Trump’s second pick follows Dr. Janette Nesheiwat’s withdrawal amid credential scrutiny. A leader in the “Make America Healthy Again” movement and ally of HHS chief Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Means champions holistic nutrition, psychedelics for mental health, reduced pesticide use and cutting chronic drug prescriptions.

articles.title: Share how the ongoing US government shutdown could affect your access to food or health insurance
articles.trailText: We’re interested to hear how the looming pause of Snap benefits, as well as rising insurance costs due to a loss of subsidies, could affect Americans
articles.summary: As the US government shutdown enters week five, over 40 million low-income Americans will see Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits suspended on November 1. The USDA says it lacks legal authority to tap a $5 billion contingency fund, a stance the Trump administration defends as Democrats and 24 states sue to keep aid flowing. Meanwhile, insurers are poised to raise premiums as ACA subsidy payments lapse, prompting Senate Democrats to demand a short-term funding deal include a $350 billion extension for enhanced subsidies—an offer Republicans refuse to discuss until the shutdown ends.

articles.title: Xi-Trump meeting: America has discovered that bullies can be bullied back
articles.trailText: Outcome appears closer to truce than durable peace but outline of broader diplomatic relationship is visible
articles.summary: In Busan, Trump and Xi sealed a one-year truce in the US–China trade war: US tariffs average cut from 55% to 45%, 20% soya bean levies halved, China defers rare-earth export restrictions, resumes US soybean purchases and curbs fentanyl-precursor exports. Both leaders agreed reciprocal visits. The deal restores much of the pre-war status quo with scant detail, tests each side’s leverage and pauses a broader geopolitical rivalry. Observers warn its fragility and note China gains time to dominate future technologies while the US grapples with inflation and supply-chain vulnerabilities.

articles.title: First Thing: Trump says rare earths deal and tariff cut agreed with China
articles.trailText: Overall US tariffs on Chinese goods will be lowered to 47% after talks. Plus: the far right loses support in Dutch election
articles.summary: In talks in South Korea, Trump said the US and China agreed to suspend rare-earth export curbs and cut his 20% ‘fentanyl tariff’ to 10%, lowering tariffs to 47% and securing Chinese soybean purchases; Taiwan wasn’t discussed. He also ordered the Pentagon to resume nuclear-weapons testing. A Guardian probe found ICE detaining people in secretive cells in breach of policy. Sudan’s RSF killed hundreds in an El Fasher hospital. The Dutch far right lost ground. Five arrests were made in the Louvre robbery. US political violence surged 40%. Jamtara scam hubs were profiled. Hurricane Melissa devastated Jamaica and hit Cuba.

articles.title: Illinois governor calls on Trump officials to halt ICE raids for Halloween
articles.trailText: JB Pritzker urges suspension of immigration crackdown to let children ‘spend Halloween weekend without fear’
articles.summary: Illinois governor JB Pritzker urged the Trump administration to pause ICE and CBP raids in his state over Halloween weekend (Oct. 30–Nov. 1) to let children “spend Halloween weekend without fear.” In a letter to DHS Secretary Kristi Noem and ICE and CBP chiefs, he decried federal actions as unconstitutional and traumatizing, citing reports of border patrol agents using tear gas at a children’s parade in Chicago’s Irving Park. His appeal followed a 7th Circuit ruling blocking a lower court order requiring a senior border patrol official to report daily on immigration sweeps. DHS Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin dismissed the claims as false.

articles.title: Halloween candy prices rising, spooked by Trump’s tariffs and climate change
articles.trailText: Prices to spike by 10.8% this year, with some chocolatey treats seeing upticks of at least 20%, analysis shows
articles.summary: Halloween candy prices are set to rise 10.8% this year, with chocolate treats climbing at least 20%, driven by cocoa shortages from climate-related crop damage in West Africa and Trump-era tariffs (21% on Ivory Coast imports, 15% on Ecuador). Cocoa costs tripled from $2,300/ton in 2020 to over $6,000 now. Manufacturers like Hershey’s warn of a $100 m tariff toll and are experimenting with shrinkflation by reducing cocoa content. Despite higher costs, strong consumer demand fuels a record $13.1 bn in Halloween spending.

articles.title: The ‘Mamdani of Minneapolis’ is banking on a grassroots campaign to unseat the Democratic mayor
articles.trailText: Omar Fateh, a democratic socialist, hopes to defeat Jacob Frey by focusing on affordability, wages and public safety
articles.summary: Omar Fateh, a 35-year-old Somali American state senator and democratic socialist dubbed “Mamdani of Minneapolis,” is mounting a grassroots bid to unseat two-term mayor Jacob Frey in the November 4 ranked-choice election. Running on $20/hr minimum wage, rent stabilization and public safety reforms via police alternatives, Fateh’s DSA-backed campaign gained momentum despite the Minneapolis DFL’s revoked endorsement. He leads a progressive alliance of top challengers and highlights Frey’s unmet promises on homelessness, policing and affordability. Facing threats over race and religion, Fateh leverages door-knocking and coalition support to energize voters seeking a more left-leaning mayor.

articles.title: Revealed: ICE violates its own policy by holding people in secretive rooms for days or weeks
articles.trailText: Guardian analysis finds ICE increasingly keeps people in holding rooms with little oversight, as some facilities see a 600% rise in detention length
articles.summary: US immigration officials have increasingly held detainees in small ICE holding rooms—concrete, no‐bed spaces meant for under 12 hours—for days or weeks, violating prior policy and latest three‐day waiver. A Guardian analysis of book‐in data found 170 sites nationwide, with average stays rising over 600% post‐June memo and instances of months‐long detention. Lacking standard audits, medical care or attorney contact, these secret facilities raise abuse and due process concerns. Lawsuits and congress members have been blocked from inspections; ICE declined comment.

articles.title: Wife of British commentator ‘abducted by ICE’ speaks out: ‘We��re being kept in the dark’
articles.trailText: Soumaya Hamdi says she has barely spoken to Sami Hamdi since he was taken over his pro-Palestinian advocacy
articles.summary: British commentator Sami Hamdi, detained by ICE at San Francisco airport over pro-Palestinian remarks, has had only a 30-second call with his wife Soumaya, who learned of his transfer to McFarland detention center via rumors. His visa was revoked ahead of a November deportation hearing amid unverified clips alleging praise for Hamas’s October 7 attacks. Hamdi’s family and UK-based lawyers decry the detention as an “abduction,” unconstitutional censorship and a threat to free speech, with CAIR lawyers now seeking his release. Soumaya says their three children, including a ten-month-old, are deeply distressed.

articles.title: Five key takeaways from Donald Trump’s meeting with Xi Jinping
articles.trailText: From tariffs to rare earths, Chinese and US presidents ‘make outstanding group of decisions’ at crunch trade talks
articles.summary: After under two hours in Busan, Trump rated his meeting with Xi a ‘12/10’, saying both sides reached basic consensus on major trade issues. China agreed to suspend its rare-earth export ban under a one-year renewable deal, while the US cut fentanyl-related tariffs from 20% to 10% pending Chinese enforcement and lifted reciprocal duties. The ’phase one’ agreement investigation remains open. They set reciprocal state visits for spring, discussed broader chip sales (excluding Nvidia’s Blackwell B30A), pledged joint Ukraine efforts and global cooperation, but Taiwan went unmentioned.

articles.title: Extremists exploit political ‘trigger events’ to recruit people online, says study
articles.trailText: NYU report monitored social feeds and found groups call for retaliatory action after politically motivated violent events
articles.summary: An NYU Stern report monitoring social media from March to June 2025 (extended after Charlie Kirk’s assassination) finds that far-right, far-left, Islamist and emergent “nihilistic violent” extremists systematically exploit high-profile “trigger events” to recruit, justify ideologies and call for retaliatory violence. The US saw 520 terrorism plots or acts, 96 deaths and 329 injuries in H1 2025 (up 40% year-over-year). Extremists use mainstream platforms to spread moderated propaganda, funnel recruits to private networks, leverage memes and memorials in a feedback loop. The report urges clearer platform threat policies, rapid reporting mechanisms and legislative standards for platform-law enforcement cooperation.

articles.title: Trump directs Pentagon to match Russia and China in nuclear weapons testing
articles.trailText: US president makes threat after Russian nuclear-powered weapons tests and shortly before meeting with Chinese leader
articles.summary: Donald Trump ordered the Pentagon to begin nuclear weapons testing “on an equal basis” with Russia and China, posting on Truth Social ahead of his Korea meeting with Xi. The US hasn’t conducted a full test since 1992 and relies on simulations and trials, while Russia and China paused tests after the 1990s. Beijing urged non-proliferation compliance, and Putin’s claims of testing a nuclear-powered missile and torpedo heighten tensions. Trump repeated a false claim that the US has the most warheads. Nevada congresswoman Dina Titus vowed legislation to block new tests.

articles.title: Trump-Xi meeting: US president says rare earths deal and tariff cut agreed
articles.trailText: Donald Trump hails ‘amazing’ trade talks with Chinese counterpart, with ‘no roadblock at all on rare earth’
articles.summary: At a surprise meeting in Busan, South Korea, Donald Trump and Xi Jinping hailed “amazing” talks, agreeing to a one-year deal lifting Chinese rare earth export curbs and cutting Trump’s fentanyl tariff from 20% to 10% (bringing overall US duties on Chinese goods from 57% to 47%). China offered reciprocal export-control suspensions and resumed US soybean purchases. The leaders will cooperate on curbing fentanyl production and seek progress on Ukraine. Taiwan, Russian oil imports and China’s nuclear testing were not addressed. Trump plans to visit China in April.

articles.title: National guard deployment in Washington DC extended until February
articles.trailText: Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth gives approval for troops to remain in US capital past November end, CNN reports
articles.summary: Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth extended the DC National Guard deployment through February, keeping about 2,400 troops at roughly $1 million per day. DC officials have sued, calling the presence an illegal “military occupation,” after a California judge ruled a similar LA deployment unlawful. The extension marks a further escalation of Trump’s tactic of sending federal forces to Democratic cities—already deployed to Chicago and threatened for San Francisco, Portland and New York. Meanwhile, a Pentagon memo from Maj Gen Ronald Burkett orders “quick reaction” riot-control forces (500 guards per state, 23,500 total) with monthly readiness reports.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president’s effort to sue his own DoJ is ‘absurd’ and ‘frivolous’, expert says
articles.trailText: The two justice department officials with power to sign off on the claims are Trump appointees and allies
articles.summary: President Trump has asked two DOJ appointees to approve $230m in damages for the Russia-2016 probe and Mar-a-Lago documents search—a move experts label “absurd” and “frivolous,” and House Democrats call “blatantly illegal.” He also fired all six members of the Commission of Fine Arts overseeing his White House ballroom and planned “Arc de Trump.” The Pentagon ordered 23,500 state guard troops into crowd-control quick reaction forces. Obamacare premiums are set to rise 26% in 2026. Senate Democrats demand donor disclosures for Trump’s $300m ballroom. Toyota denies a $10bn US investment pledge, the Fed cut rates amid the shutdown, and students and activists face legal battles.

articles.title: US woman who ‘rescued’ four chickens found guilty of trespassing and conspiracy
articles.trailText: Zoe Rosenberg, 23, of San Francisco Bay Area does not deny taking animals, saying she was removing them from cruelty
articles.summary: Zoe Rosenberg, 23-year-old DxE activist from the San Francisco Bay Area, was convicted in Sonoma County on misdemeanor trespass (2 counts), vehicle tampering (1) and felony conspiracy charges for removing four chickens from Petaluma Poultry in June 2023. Posing as workers, Rosenberg and associates took the birds, claiming a rescue from cruelty at a Perdue Farms supplier. Prosecutors dismissed her motive; her legal team plans to appeal. She faces over five years in prison. Critics decry spending six weeks and hundreds of thousands in public funds protecting a multibillion-dollar poultry firm from a $25 animal rescue. The trial, held in agriculture-driven Sonoma County, follows a DxE co-founder’s conviction two years earlier for farm protests.

articles.title: Trump’s ‘absurd’ DoJ compensation bid would be rejected if he were anyone else, experts say
articles.trailText: President’s effort to win $230m in damages from Mar-a-Lago and Russia investigations criticized as ‘frivolous’
articles.summary: Trump’s bid for $230m from the Justice Department under the Federal Tort Claims Act, covering alleged abuses in the Russia investigation and Mar-a-Lago search, has been labeled frivolous and would likely be rejected if filed by anyone else. He seeks over $115m in compensatory and punitive damages, despite FTCA prohibiting punitive awards, and $15m in legal costs. Neither claim has been answered; DOJ has six months to settle or deny before suit. Experts note the demand dwarfs typical $52k settlements, and leverage lies with Trump-appointed DOJ officials, raising corruption and ethics concerns. House Democrats denounce it as illegal and unconstitutional.

articles.title: Trump’s blithe dismissal of climate science
articles.trailText: The devastating consequences of ignoring the climate crisis
articles.summary: Through misstatements in his 2015 book Crippled America and at a Trump Tower press conference, Donald Trump has repeatedly dismissed human-driven climate change—falsely citing 19th-century tornado and hurricane records and rejecting scientific consensus. As president he withdrew the US from the Paris Agreement, cut renewable energy support, championed fossil fuels and published misleading climate reports. With no US delegation at COP30 and intensifying storms linked to ocean warming, his anti-science stance threatens to derail global mitigation efforts and risk catastrophic environmental and economic fallout.

articles.title: Democratic contender for Congress indicted over Chicago ICE protests
articles.trailText: Progressive Palestinian American candidate Kat Abughazaleh, 26, decries ‘gross attempt at silencing dissent’
articles.summary: Progressive Palestinian American Kat Abughazaleh, 26, who’s challenging for Illinois’s 9th congressional district, was federally indicted over September protests outside a Chicago-area ICE facility. The charges allege she and five others conspired to forcibly impede a federal agent—banging on, etching “pig” into, and damaging the agent’s vehicle—while blocking its movement. Abughazaleh faces counts of conspiracy to obstruct and assaulting an officer. She denounces the indictment as a politically motivated attempt to suppress First Amendment dissent amid expanded Trump-era immigration raids criticized by local leaders and civil rights groups, and vows to fight the “unjust” charges.”}   (Wait extra quote?) Let's correct trailing punctuation. It duplicates quote. Should end without extra quote. Let's fix. Let's present cleaned up. Let's re-output. Let's ensure double quotes and punctuation correct. We'll provide final. Let's adjust last sentence: ... and vows to fight the “unjust” charges. So right after charges. End. No extra quote. We'll send that. End.  (Now final).

articles.title: Two Russians sentenced to 25 years for plot to kill Iranian dissident in US
articles.trailText: Mobsters Rafat Amirov and Polad Omarov plotted to assassinate Masih Alinejad at her New York home
articles.summary: Rafat Amirov and Polad Omarov, Russian mobsters convicted of murder-for-hire and racketeering for an Iran-backed assassination attempt on Iranian American dissident and women’s rights advocate Masih Alinejad, received 25-year federal sentences in Manhattan. Prosecutors say Iran paid $500,000 and the hitman received $30,000. Alinejad, who moved through safe houses since the 2022 attempt, urged a harsh term as a deterrent. Four alleged Iranian co-conspirators remain at large in Tehran. Defense pleas for leniency, invoking literary and mental-health arguments, were rejected.

articles.title: DeSantis urges Florida universities to stop hiring foreign visa workers
articles.trailText: Governor tells universities to end use of H-1B visas, though legal experts say states lack authority over federal program
articles.summary: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis has directed the state Board of Governors to cease hiring international employees under the H-1B visa program, claiming it displaces qualified U.S. workers. Nearly 400 foreign nationals currently work at Florida’s public universities under H-1B visas, part of over 7,200 holders statewide. Legal experts say states lack authority to override federal visa regulations. DeSantis’s move follows Trump’s steep H-1B fee hike and assertion of “systematic abuse,” sparking debate over the program’s role in science and engineering faculties at UF, USF and FSU.

articles.title: Met museum sued by family over allegedly Nazi-looted Van Gogh painting
articles.trailText: New York museum under fire from heirs of Jewish couple allegedly forced to surrender artwork upon fleeing to US
articles.summary: Heirs of Jewish collectors Hedwig and Frederick Stern have sued the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Basil & Elise Goulandris Foundation in Manhattan federal court, seeking return and damages for Van Gogh’s 1889 oil painting Olive Picking. The Sterns bought it in 1935 but were forced to flee Munich in 1936, with the Nazis declaring it German cultural property and selling it via a Nazi-appointed trustee. The Met acquired it in 1956, sold it in 1972 to Greek collectors now displaying it in Athens; heirs allege the museum “knew or should have known” it was Nazi-looted. A prior California claim was dismissed.

articles.title: US could lose between $7bn and $14bn during shutdown, budget office says
articles.trailText: Federal agency also estimates country’s GDP will reduce by one to two percentage points over shrinking demand
articles.summary: A Congressional Budget Office report warns the four-week US government shutdown will cost $7bn in lost GDP by end-2026, rising to $11bn after six weeks and $14bn after eight, while knocking 1–2 percentage points off Q4 2025 growth. CBO attributes losses to delayed federal spending, reduced services and weaker private demand. SNAP benefits remain intact so far, but longer closures pose risks. Amid the stalemate over Senate funding bills, 11,000 air traffic controllers missed pay and over two dozen states sued over suspended food stamps.

articles.title: US military to reduce number of troops in Romania as start of European drawdown
articles.trailText: Army says 2nd Infantry Brigade combat team of 101st Airborne to redeploy to Kentucky ‘without replacement’
articles.summary: The US Army announced it will redeploy the 2nd Infantry Brigade Combat Team of the 101st Airborne from Romania to Kentucky without replacement, cutting US troop levels from about 1,700 to roughly 1,000 at Mihail Kogălniceanu airbase. Framed as a ‘force posture adjustment’ to rebalance toward the Indo-Pacific, the decision—first formal EU drawdown under the Trump administration—drew rare GOP lawmakers’ criticism for weakening NATO’s eastern deterrence. Romania’s defence ministry called the move expected as allies assume greater defence roles, leaving 3,500 NATO troops in country.

articles.title: Lab monkeys on loose after Mississippi crash were disease-free, university says
articles.trailText: Three monkeys remain at large and are being searched for, officials said after initially reporting they were infectious
articles.summary: Tulane University confirmed that a convoy of rhesus monkeys overturned on Interstate 59 near Heidelberg, Mississippi, after a transport truck crash on Oct. 29 were disease-free despite initial sheriff’s reports of herpes and other infections. The wooden crates labeled “live animals” were strewn as video captured the 16 lb primates fleeing into tall grass. Tulane’s National Biomedical Research Center in New Orleans said the animals had no exposure to pathogens. Authorities killed several and now search for three remaining at-large monkeys roughly 100 miles from Jackson; the crash’s cause remains under investigation. They originated at Tulane’s New Orleans facility, which regularly supplies primates to research labs.

articles.title: Revealed: Pentagon orders states’ national guards to form ‘quick reaction forces’ for ‘crowd control’
articles.trailText: Pentagon memo details plan to train over 20,000 national guard members across the US to carry out Trump’s order on subduing civil unrest
articles.summary: An internal Pentagon memo signed Oct. 8 orders nationwide creation of 500-member state National Guard quick reaction forces—23,500 troops total—trained in riot-control tactics (batons, shields, Tasers, pepper spray) and de-escalation. Citing Trump’s Aug. executive order on civil disturbances, each state and territory gets 100 crowd-control kits and must report progress monthly; forces must be operational by Jan. 2026. A parallel directive expands DC’s Guard with a 50-person military police battalion ready in 90 days, full strength by 2027. Critics warn this normalizes a permanent militarized police to suppress protests or elections; advocates filed a Supreme Court brief. The White House defends deployments, citing crime drops in Memphis and DC.

articles.title: Senate Democrats demand list of donors to $300m Trump ballroom
articles.trailText: Letter warns White House of ‘blatant corruption’ risk from contributing companies with business before government
articles.summary: Senate Democrats led by Adam Schiff have demanded full disclosure of donors funding Donald Trump’s $300m White House ballroom renovation, warning that contributions from major tech firms (Apple, Amazon, Meta, Microsoft, Google), defense contractors (Booz Allen Hamilton, Lockheed Martin, Palantir) and telecoms (T-Mobile, Comcast), as well as billionaire Trump backers, create corruption risks. In a letter to chief of staff Susie Wiles, senators including Padilla, Sanders and Duckworth request by Nov 5 a complete breakdown of donations—amounts, dates, conditions, ties to federal contracts, regulatory or litigation issues—and records of any ethics guidance, safeguards or communications with donors to assess potential influence peddling.

articles.title: UK newspaper apologizes for fake De Blasio interview criticizing Mamdani
articles.trailText: The Times deletes article after its reporter was duped by impostor pretending to be former New York mayor
articles.summary: The Times UK apologized and deleted a fabricated interview with former NYC mayor Bill de Blasio, whose mock quotes attacking mayoral frontrunner Zohran Mamdani—including criticism of his $7bn-plus cost estimates—were the work of an impostor. After De Blasio publicly denounced the “entirely false” statements and lambasted the breach of ethics, the paper removed the piece. The New York Post briefly ran the bogus remarks before updating. Cuomo’s campaign echoed the false narrative, while Mamdani endures a heated, often hateful, final stretch stoked by voices like Sid Rosenberg, Steve Bannon and Megyn Kelly.

articles.title: Search under way in California after jail accidentally releases murder suspect
articles.trailText: After staff realized suspect had been freed, officers began search and confirmed he was ‘no longer in the area’
articles.summary: In Martinez, northern California, jail staff accidentally released 20-year-old Isaiah Jamon Andrews on Oct. 22. He’d been held on local charges, a Sacramento juvenile warrant and an out-of-state homicide warrant for an Oct. 15 shooting in Seattle’s Northgate neighborhood that killed a 20-year-old man in a hotel parking lot. Upon discovering the error, Contra Costa sheriff’s deputies and the US Marshals Service launched a manhunt, confirmed he’d left the area, and alerted Seattle PD and other agencies as extradition efforts to King County continue.

articles.title: Pro-Palestinian students threaten to sue US university amid antisemitism definition controversy
articles.trailText: Exclusive: George Mason University accused of censorship by citing IHRA definition to order anti-Israel post’s removal
articles.summary: Students for Justice in Palestine (SJP) at George Mason University (GMU) has threatened a federal lawsuit after GMU invoked the IHRA antisemitism definition, adopted this year, to remove an SJP video labeling Israel a “genocidal Zionist state,” calling the US “the belly of the beast” and linking Palestinian liberation to Indigenous struggles. GMU claimed the language implied all Jews were genocidal or controlled other nations, stoking community alarm. SJP, represented by Palestine Legal, argues the move violates First Amendment protections for political speech and could mark the first direct judicial test of the IHRA definition’s constitutionality in a public university.

articles.title: All operational US liquefied natural gas terminals have violated pollution limits, says report
articles.trailText: Analysis of public records comes as Trump administration aims to fast-track approval of new LNG export terminals
articles.summary: An Environmental Integrity Project analysis finds all seven US LNG export terminals—three in Louisiana, two in Texas and one each in Maryland and Georgia—breached federal pollution limits under the Clean Air Act at least once between October 2022 and July 2025. Five also violated the Clean Water Act via illegal discharges of bacteria, zinc and oil or missed monitoring reports. Sabine Pass and Calcasieu Pass logged noncompliance every quarter since 2022; Texas’s Freeport LNG faced the highest fines after its 2022 explosion. Yet it’s fast-tracking new capacity: four terminals are under construction and 28 more proposed, raising concerns over higher gas prices and increased greenhouse-gas emissions.

articles.title: Obamacare insurance prices will jump up 26% next year, report predicts
articles.trailText: Enhanced subsidies keeping premiums affordable for millions will expire, threatening to more than double what households pay out of pocket
articles.summary: Analysis by the Kaiser Family Foundation predicts a 26% average spike in Affordable Care Act marketplace premiums next year, with healthcare.gov plans rising 30% and state exchanges up 17%. Enhanced subsidies that have capped out-of-pocket costs for a record 24 million enrollees expire at year’s end, potentially driving monthly payments up 114% if Congress fails to extend them. The increase comes amid a prolonged government shutdown, as Senate Democrats press for subsidy extensions in funding talks while Republicans refuse to negotiate until reopening the government. CBO projects expiration could leave 4 million more Americans uninsured by 2034.

articles.title: Trump fires federal arts board in charge of reviewing White House ballroom and ‘Arc de Trump’
articles.trailText: White House says it will appoint new Commission of Fine Arts members ‘more aligned with … America First Policies’
articles.summary: President Trump dismissed all six members of the independent Commission of Fine Arts, the century-old federal agency that advises on design and aesthetics of public memorials and buildings, including his planned White House ballroom and the proposed Arc de Trump near Arlington Memorial Bridge. A White House official said replacements ‘‘more aligned with America First policies’’ will be named, though no appointees have been announced. His $300 million ballroom project and triumphal-arch design face disapproval from nearly two-thirds of Americans, according to a Yahoo/YouGov poll.

articles.title: Revealed: Israel demanded Google and Amazon use secret ‘wink’ to sidestep legal orders
articles.trailText: The tech giants agreed to extraordinary terms to clinch a lucrative contract with the Israeli government, documents show
articles.summary: In their $1.2 bn 2021 Project Nimbus contract, Google and Amazon accepted Israel’s “winking mechanism”: secret signals hidden in payments—1,000-9,999 shekels tied to dialing codes—sent within 24 hours when forced to hand over Israeli data under gag orders. Israeli officials also imposed no-suspend clauses, barring the companies from restricting or withdrawing any cloud services even amid human-rights or legal pressures over surveillance in Gaza and the West Bank. Leaked documents show these stringent controls aimed to prevent foreign judicial overreach and shareholder activism. Experts warn the code risks breaching US secrecy laws despite its ingenuity. Both firms deny evading legal obligations.

articles.title: Record-breaking Hurricane Melissa hits Jamaica and heads for Cuba | First Thing
articles.trailText: Parish of St Elizabeth ‘under water’ after Jamaica’s ‘storm of the century’. Plus, Trump and Xi to meet for first time since 2019
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa, Jamaica’s most intense storm since records began in 1851, made landfall as a category 5, submerging St Elizabeth, triggering landslides, cutting power to 530,000 and housing 15,000 in shelters; it’s now a category 3 barreling into Cuba. Meanwhile, Israeli airstrikes in Gaza killed at least 104, including 35 children, threatening a fragile US-brokered ceasefire. Donald Trump and Xi Jinping will meet at APEC in Seoul—their first encounter since 2019���to negotiate trade, rare earths and semiconductor controls. Quick hits: Indonesia’s planned capital risks becoming a ghost town, Tanzania votes amid opposition bans, a mercenary’s Dubai detention sparks coup fears, US top 0.1% carbon emissions dwarf poorest 10%, and a Finnish forest preschool experiment explores nature’s health benefits.

articles.title: JD Vance did nothing as Trump cuts cost his Ohio home town millions. Will it reshape the city council?
articles.trailText: Two progressives are running for seats on Middletown’s non-partisan, yet Republican-leaning, council in next month’s election
articles.summary: Vice-president JD Vance, a Middletown native, declined to help fund the high school marching band’s inaugural trip and did not intervene when Trump’s Education Department rescinded a $5.6 million school grant. In response, two progressives—pastor Scotty Robertson and nursing assistant Larri Silas—are challenging two Republican-held seats on the non-partisan, GOP-leaning city council. They argue that Vance’s and Trump’s policies disproportionately harm working-class families in a city with 29% child poverty. A progressive victory would signal local backlash and offer a preview of wider electoral shifts.

articles.title: Trump and Xi talks could end months of global economic chaos
articles.trailText: High on agenda for the leaders of the US and China will be rare earths and tariffs, with a chance of a relationship reset
articles.summary: At APEC in Seoul, Trump and Xi will meet for the first time since 2019 to reset the US-China trade war, focusing on rare earths and tariff rollbacks. China, which controls 70% of rare earth mining, tightened exports after US chip restrictions, prompting Trump’s threat of 100% tariffs. Preliminary talks in Kuala Lumpur suggest a one-year deferral of rare-earth curbs in exchange for freezing semiconductor export controls. The leaders may also address Taiwan, fentanyl, TikTok and paused tariffs due by 10 November, while Trump signs a rare-earth pact with Japan to diversify supply.

articles.title: Court to reconsider ruling that allowed Trump to send troops to Portland
articles.trailText: President remains barred from deploying national guard as appeals court agrees to ‘en banc’ rehearing of case
articles.summary: An en banc Ninth Circuit panel will rehear whether Trump can deploy National Guard in Portland after vacating a three-judge panel’s decision in his favor. Two temporary restraining orders from Judge Karin Immergut bar federalizing Oregon guard forces and any Guard deployment statewide; a separate stay partly allowed Trump to command 200 Guard members. The dispute stems from federal claims of threats at an ICE facility and Oregon’s contention that local authorities control protests. AG Dan Rayfield says the ruling upholds constitutional limits on presidential military power in US cities.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: senators pass measure that would scrap Brazil tariffs in rare fightback against trade war
articles.trailText: Bipartisan measure would terminate sweeping tariffs on coffee, beef and other products – key US politics stories from 28 October at a glance
articles.summary: In a rare bipartisan rebuke of President Trump’s trade war, the Senate voted 52–48 to overturn his national-emergency tariffs on Brazilian imports—coffee, beef and more—though the measure faces certain House gridlock and a likely veto. Other top developments: a federal judge ordered Chicago’s border-patrol chief to report daily on immigration raids; Trump-appointed acting US attorney Bill Essayli was disqualified from cases; the 28-day government shutdown threatens food aid; ICE leadership will be overhauled to intensify deportations; 24 states sued over SNAP suspensions; and House Republicans revived Biden autopen claims.

articles.title: Border patrol leader told to go to court every weekday to report on Chicago enforcement
articles.trailText: Federal judge gives orders to Gregory Bovino in exceptional bid to impose oversight over Trump officials’ raids in city
articles.summary: Federal judge Sara Ellis has ordered Border Patrol official Gregory Bovino—leader of the Trump administration’s “Operation Midway Blitz” crackdown in Chicago (3,000+ arrests since September)—to appear in federal court each weekday to report on enforcement incidents after agents deployed chemical irritants and riot-control weapons against residents, including children in Halloween costumes. The order follows repeated violations of court limits on tear gas, pepper balls and smoke grenades. Ellis also mandated that Bovino personally obtain a body camera and complete training by Friday to ensure agents enforce immigration laws constitutionally.

articles.title: US Senate passes bill with Republican support to block Trump tariffs on Brazil
articles.trailText: Republicans break ranks as vote passes 52-48 in rare bipartisan rebuke of US president’s trade policies
articles.summary: Senate approved 52-48 resolution to terminate Trump’s 50% tariffs on Brazilian imports such as coffee and beef, with GOP senators Murkowski, Collins, Paul, Tillis, and McConnell joining all Democrats. Authored by Tim Kaine, it would overturn Trump’s national emergency declaration but faces a hostile House and a certain presidential veto. Supporters argue the levies are a tax on US consumers and an abuse of emergency powers. The vote underscores GOP unease over Trump’s trade war as the Supreme Court weighs his tariff authority.

articles.title: Air traffic controllers receive $0 paychecks as government shutdown stretches
articles.trailText: Nearly 11,000 air traffic controllers, deemed essential workers, did not receive wages for two weeks of work
articles.summary: Essential air traffic controllers and TSA employees missed their first paycheck after a four-week government shutdown: nearly 11,000 controllers received $0 for two weeks of work. Transportation Sec. Sean Duffy warned repeated missed pay could devastate staff who've planned for this but now face mounting expenses. FlightAware reported 3,000+ US flight delays, 132 cancellations, amid staffing shortages in Chicago, Dallas, Nashville. NATCA President Nick Daniels highlighted controllers juggling focus with fears of affording medicine. Airlines including United, Delta, JetBlue are donating meals; some controllers resort to Uber Eats or waitressing to bridge gaps.

articles.title: Potentially diseased lab monkey on the loose after truck crash in Mississippi
articles.trailText: Several rhesus monkeys escaped after the interstate crash, but all but one were reportedly ‘destroyed’ by late Tuesday
articles.summary: A Jasper County sheriff’s office spokeswoman said a truck transporting rhesus monkeys from Tulane National Biomedical Research Center overturned on Interstate 59 in Mississippi Tuesday afternoon, freeing a group of animals potentially infected with hepatitis C and Covid-19. The monkeys, about 40 lbs each and described as aggressive, escaped when local crews responded. Authorities say all but one were destroyed by late Tuesday as a public health precaution, and the search continues for the final animal. Tulane disputes federal infection claims, stating the primates belong to another entity and pose no known biohazard, and is sending experts to assist.

articles.title: US military kills 14 in attacks on vessels in the Pacific, according to Hegseth
articles.trailText: US says one person survived latest strikes, having killed 51 people in attacks on at least 13 vessels in recent weeks
articles.summary: Defense Sec. Pete Hegseth announced US naval strikes in the eastern Pacific sank or destroyed four suspected drug-trafficking boats in international waters, killing 14 crew and rescuing one survivor handed to Mexico. These operations—part of a broader Trump-era campaign blamed for 51 deaths across 13 vessels since September—now extend beyond the Caribbean into western hemispheric routes. Hegseth likened narco-traffickers to “terrorists” and justified the strikes under Trump’s Article II powers, prompting legal debate and criticism from Republican Rand Paul. Meanwhile, the deployment of the USS Gerald Ford carrier strike group signals an imminent shift to land targets in Venezuela.

articles.title: Shutdown stretches into 28th day as Senate again fails to pass spending legislation
articles.trailText: As funding for food aid program is about to be exhausted, Congress fails for 13th time to advance Republican bill
articles.summary: At 28 days, the US shutdown deepens as Senate Democrats for the 13th time blocked a Republican continuing resolution through 21 November, citing missing healthcare funding and unchecked Trump budget cuts. Meanwhile, SNAP benefits face expiration on 1 November and over two dozen states have sued the USDA. AFGE president Everett Kelley urges a clean resolution with full back pay; Democrats led by Chuck Schumer hold out over rising ACA premiums, while GOP leader John Thune presses for bipartisan support.

articles.title: DC police officer says he was ordered to omit agent shooting at a driver in traffic stop report
articles.trailText: MPD officer said in court he was told by ‘team leader’ not to disclose details of a federal agent firing at a man in his car
articles.summary: MPD officer Jason Sterling testified that his “team leader” ordered him to omit from his incident report that an HSI agent fired three shots at Phillip Brown during a DC traffic stop. Sterling and colleague Divonnie Powell described Brown’s SUV maneuvers but didn’t mention the shooting, which left Brown unhurt but facing a felonious fleeing charge later dismissed for lack of probable cause. Brown spent four days in jail, received a coerced plea offer before seeing bodycam footage, and was freed when a judge dropped charges. MPD and US Attorney will independently probe, while DHS insists the agent fired defensively.

articles.title: Texas sues Tylenol makers alleging deceptive marketing to pregnant people
articles.trailText: Lawsuit comes after Trump’s baseless claims that acetaminophen can cause autism and ADHD in children
articles.summary: Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton sued Johnson & Johnson and Kenvue, the 2023 J&J spinoff, in Texas state court alleging deceptive marketing of Tylenol to pregnant people by failing to warn of potential autism and ADHD risks in children, and fraudulent transfer of liabilities to Kenvue. This first state-level action follows former President Trump’s unsubstantiated claims about acetaminophen risks. Tylenol makers and medical groups have defended its safety during pregnancy. Republican Sen. John Cornyn, facing a primary challenge from Paxton, dismissed the suit as a ploy to enrich trial lawyers.

articles.title: Two dozen states sue White House over food stamps suspension amid shutdown
articles.trailText: Federal food assistance benefits for low-income families set to expire on 1 November due to government shutdown
articles.summary: Coalition of 26 states—led by New York, California and Massachusetts—sued the Trump administration for halting SNAP food-stamp benefits on November 1 amid the government shutdown. They ask a federal judge to compel USDA to draw on its $6 billion emergency reserve to fund the $8 billion-a-month program serving 42 million low-income Americans. Plaintiffs cite law mandating continuous aid, challenge an agency memo limiting reserves to disasters and note a removed USDA plan endorsing multi-year funds. They seek a Friday ruling, warning food banks of overwhelming demand. The administration refuses, posting a partisan banner blaming Democrats.

articles.title: Gavin Newsom tells Prop 50 supporters to ‘stop donating’ after war chest swells
articles.trailText: California governor launched redistricting effort to counter Texas’s gerrymander and has out-raised opposition
articles.summary: Gavin Newsom emailed supporters that he'd hit fundraising goals and they can stop donating to Proposition 50, his bid to counter Texas’s gerrymander. The campaign raised $38 m from 1.2 m small-dollar donors in 10 weeks plus nearly $15 m from a Democratic super PAC, $10 m from a George Soros-funded group, $4 m from a teachers’ union and $12 m from Tom Steyer, leaving $37 m on hand. With polls at 57–62% and opponents cash-strapped at $2.3 m, the focus turns to final voter mobilization and aiding other states’ redistricting fights.

articles.title: Some of the earliest written notes in western musical history discovered in Pennsylvania
articles.trailText: Ninth-century manuscript for Easter services remained ‘out of sight’ for years in hands of private collector
articles.summary: Researchers in Pennsylvania have identified a ninth-century Latin sacramentary leaf—overlooked in a private collection—as bearing neumatic markings above “alleluia,” among the earliest Western musical notations. Discovered and authenticated by historian Nathan Raab, the German-made vellum for Easter services (circa 850–900) shows pitch inflections guiding singers. Predating or rivaling the Laon Gradual and St Gall Cantatorium, this $80,000 fragment illuminates the dawn of modern Western music notation.

articles.title: Trump demanded trans issues be excluded from sex education. 11 states complied
articles.trailText: Sixteen other states have sued the White House over the program, saying it’s trampling on Congress’s authority
articles.summary: Eleven Republican-led states—Alaska, Georgia, Iowa, Kentucky, Mississippi, North Carolina, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, West Virginia and Wyoming—and two territories (US Virgin Islands, Northern Mariana Islands) have stripped gender identity and transgender references from the $75 m Personal Responsibility Education Program under threat of losing federal funding. Sixteen Democratic-led states plus DC sued, claiming HHS exceeded Congress’s authority; a federal judge blocked cuts, calling the new grant conditions “pretextual.” Prep, which funds teen sex education on healthy relationships and STI prevention, faces criticism that banning trans content harms vulnerable youth.

articles.title: Bill Gates says climate crisis won’t cause ‘humanity’s demise’ in call to shift focus to ‘improving lives’
articles.trailText: Billionaire’s statement comes a day after UN said humanity missed 1.5C climate target and warned of devastation
articles.summary: On his Gates Notes blog, Bill Gates rejected a “doomsday view” of climate change, asserting it won’t cause humanity’s demise, and called for a “strategic pivot” from near-term emissions targets to a focus on improving lives by combating poverty and disease in vulnerable populations. He urged that the metric of progress should shift from temperature to welfare ahead of COP30 in Belém. His stance contrasts with a UN report that the 1.5°C limit has been missed and António Guterres’s warning of devastating tipping points in the Amazon, Greenland and Antarctica without urgent emissions cuts.

articles.title: US citizens on the threat of being racially profiled by ICE: ‘I carry my passport card at all times’
articles.trailText: Trump’s immigration crackdown is upending the daily routines of US citizens and permanent residents of color
articles.summary: After a 5–4 Supreme Court ruling upholding LA-area ICE “roving” patrols despite allegations of Fourth Amendment violations, US citizens and permanent residents of color report reshaping daily life to avoid racial profiling. Surveyed individuals describe sleeping with passports, carrying birth certificates to soccer practice, limiting outings, and grocery shopping for relatives. Many keep proof of status on them at all times and have created phone trees, location-tracking networks, and legal contingency plans. Some recall post-9/11 discrimination. Distrust of law enforcement is high, and families avoid reporting crimes. A minority voice defiance—publicly embracing Latinidad and organizing protests—amid pervasive fear of “papers please” stops.

articles.title: TikTok threat offering bounty on Pam Bondi leads to federal charges, FBI says
articles.trailText: Tyler Avalos allegedly posted a video with crosshairs over Bondi’s face and a $45,000 reward for her death, FBI says
articles.summary: Federal authorities charged Minnesota resident Tyler Maxon Avalos after he allegedly posted a TikTok video showing crosshairs on US Attorney General Pam Bondi’s face, offering a $45,000 dead-or-alive reward. The FBI traced the Oct. 9 post—captioned “*cough cough* when they don’t serve us then what?”—to Avalos, whose profile featured anarchy symbols and anarchist literature links. Facing federal charges filed Oct. 16, he has a multi-state record including stalking and domestic assault and was released under GPS monitoring, curfew, travel and firearm bans. His attorney denies guilt.

articles.title: Director of Nevada council addressing impaired driving issues charged with DUI
articles.trailText: Arrest of criminal justice council’s Linsey LaMontagne comes as 277 people have died on Nevada roads in 2025
articles.summary: Linsey LaMontagne, director of the Clark County Criminal Justice Coordinating Council (CJCC), which advises on DUI arrests around Las Vegas, was charged with DUI and reckless driving after a trooper stopped her last April for erratic, swerving driving. She admitted to having “two shots of Tito’s vodka” at a casino, pleaded not guilty and awaits adjudication before any county employment action. Her arrest comes as Nevada has recorded 277 traffic fatalities in 2025, largely tied to impairment and speeding.

articles.title: Trump administration will revamp ICE leadership in quest to intensify deportations
articles.trailText: Government intends to reassign multiple directors of field offices as it falls well short of its targets on immigration
articles.summary: The Trump administration plans to replace at least a dozen of ICE's 25 field office directors, many with US border patrol officials, to accelerate deportations after falling short of Stephen Miller's 3,000-daily arrests target, averaging 1,178 per day, and its goal of 1 million removals in year one. The shake-up follows White House frustration with ICE's pace and criticism of border patrol's aggressive urban raids in LA and Chicago. DHS says it is one team focused on results.

articles.title: First Thing: Humanity has missed 1.5C climate target, says UN head
articles.trailText: Exclusive: ‘Devastating consequences’ now inevitable but emissions cuts still vital, says António Guterres in sole interview before Cop30. Plus, lonely and unwell people are turning to AI chatbots for health advice
articles.summary: UN Secretary-General António Guterres warns humanity has irrevocably missed the Paris 1.5°C target, urging COP30 delegates in Belém to slash emissions before Amazon, Arctic and ocean tipping points trigger ‘devastating consequences.’ Simultaneously, Hurricane Melissa, Jamaica’s strongest recorded storm, nears as a category 5, threatening catastrophic flooding and landslides. Senator Elizabeth Warren demands probes into bankers, including Jes Staley, over Jeffrey Epstein ties. Corporate America braces for change as Amazon readies 30,000 layoffs amid an AI-driven reorganisation, and lonely patients increasingly rely on chatbots for medical advice.

articles.title: Haitians helped boost Springfield’s economy – now they’re fleeing in fear of Trump
articles.trailText: Ohio city’s economic fortunes spiral and local businesses suffer as Haitians leave due to administration’s anti-immigrant rhetoric and policies
articles.summary: In Springfield, Ohio, a boom of over 15,000 Haitian immigrants since 2017 fueled manufacturing job growth, new housing projects and businesses like Adasa Latin Market. After the Trump administration ended Haitian humanitarian parole and TPS in June, thousands fled, shrinking the labor force, depressing job fills and erasing a projected 3.5% income tax boost. Unemployment rose, municipal revenues flattened and a $4.25 million budget gap emerged. Local firms struggle to replace reliable immigrant workers while remaining Haitians face revoked status and layoffs, compounding economic and social strains in this Midwestern city.

articles.title: Atlanta journalist says he ‘won’t be the only’ one deported by Trump officials
articles.trailText: Emmy award-winner Mario Guevara warns administration ‘has the power’ after he was arrested and sent to El Salvador
articles.summary: Emmy award-winning Atlanta journalist Mario Guevara, deported Oct. 3 under the Trump administration’s second-term ICE crackdown, warns he “won’t be the only” immigrant reporter expelled. Arrested livestreaming a June “No Kings Day” protest—targeted after speaking Spanish—Guevara, who held a work permit and has US citizen children, saw federal authorities revive his 2012 refused asylum case. From El Salvador, he denounced officials’ view of media as “enemies,” cited British commentator Sami Hamdi’s visa revocation, and urged colleagues to guard themselves amid escalating retaliation and legal uncertainty. He recounted a 20-minute goodbye call, his fully paid home and pending green card bid, lamenting how quickly the administration upended his American dream.

articles.title: Trump and Xi talks: what will be on the agenda when US president meets China’s leader?
articles.trailText: Talks on Thursday will centre on tariffs as Trump seeks to end a bruising trade war with Beijing, while Taiwan and Russia are also likely to be discussed
articles.summary: Donald Trump will meet Xi Jinping on Thursday at the Apec summit in South Korea, his first face-to-face since returning to the White House. The two are expected to address a looming 100% US tariff threat in retaliation to China’s rare-earth export curbs, seek progress on US soybean purchases and fentanyl supply-chain crackdowns, and build on preliminary Kuala Lumpur economic talks. Broader discussions will target Russia’s war in Ukraine and Beijing’s oil imports, Taiwan security and Washington’s weapons sales, and the case of jailed Hong Kong tycoon Jimmy Lai.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president floats a third term as Democrats vow ‘no way in hell’
articles.trailText: President has not definitively ruled out seeking to extend time in office. Key US politics stories from Monday 27 October at a glance
articles.summary: Donald Trump aboard Air Force One in Asia declined to rule out an unconstitutional third term, saying “I would love to do it” despite the two-term limit and dismissing a VP-run workaround as “too cute.” Democrats, led by Rep. Rashida Tlaib, vowed “no way in hell.” In brief: Trump condemns Russia’s new nuclear cruise missile test; federal cuts hampered Alaska storm warnings; IMF forecasts US debt at 143% of GDP by 2030; administration seeks Supreme Court approval to fire the US Copyright Office head; over 13,000 attend pro-Democratic NYC rally; Biden warns of “dark days” under Trump; CDC layoffs threaten future vaccine guidance; Transportation Secretary moves to strip California of funds over non-citizen driver’s licenses.

articles.title: New Yorkers sue state elections board as battle over House maps intensifies
articles.trailText: Lawsuit alleges congressional map illegally dilutes voting power of Black and Latino residents of Staten Island
articles.summary: A group of Staten Island residents, represented by Elias Law Group, sued New York’s Board of Elections challenging the 11th congressional district map, claiming it violates the Voting Rights Act by diluting Black and Latino voting power. The suit argues the district’s boundaries fail to reflect recent demographic growth and confine minority communities in a safely Republican seat held by Nicole Malliotakis. Filed amid a partisan redistricting war fueled by Trump’s call for mid-decade map changes, plaintiffs seek relief within constraints of New York’s anti-gerrymandering commission-approved process, potentially forcing adjustments ahead of 2028.

articles.title: A third term for Trump would be unconstitutional. Here’s why
articles.trailText: The 22nd amendment states no person shall be elected president more than twice – but Trump allies could challenge it or seek a loophole
articles.summary: Despite Trump’s hints and Trump Organization selling “Trump 2028” caps, the US Constitution’s 22nd Amendment bars any person from being elected president more than twice. Legal experts, including Quinnipiac’s Wayne Unger, say any third‐term bid would be struck down. Amending the amendment requires two‐thirds majorities in Congress and ratification by 38 states, an unlikely feat given narrow Republican margins. Proposals include three non‐consecutive terms or exploiting the electoral versus succession distinction by running as vice‐president or serving as House Speaker to trigger succession. However, the 12th and 22nd Amendments and judicial precedent would likely block these loopholes. Any attempt to seek a third term faces formidable constitutional and political hurdles.

articles.title: Republican Indiana governor calls special session to redraw congressional maps
articles.trailText: GOP-led state is latest that Trump administration has put pressure on to undertake redistricting to favor Republicans
articles.summary: Indiana Governor Mike Braun called a special legislative session to redraw the state’s congressional map mid‐decade under pressure from the Trump administration’s push to increase Republican seats ahead of 2026. Currently sending seven Republicans and two Democrats to Congress, Braun framed the session as protecting Hoosiers��� fair representation, warning of consequences for defying Washington. Democrats, led by the National Democratic Redistricting Committee, decry the move as gerrymandered and reflecting Trump-linked threats — including vice-presidential trips and funding cuts. Meanwhile, House minority leader Hakeem Jeffries heads to Illinois to negotiate new maps with Black lawmakers concerned about preserving minority districts.

articles.title: Leader of top federal worker union calls for end of US government shutdown
articles.trailText: Hundreds of thousands of employees remain unpaid as second-longest US shutdown stretches into fourth week
articles.summary: Everett Kelley, head of the American Federation of Government Employees—which represents over 800,000 federal and DC workers from TSA agents to VA staff���urges lawmakers to end the four-week, second-longest US shutdown by passing a clean continuing resolution. With hundreds of thousands of employees missing paychecks and lining up at food banks, he demands immediate full back pay and normal legislative debate. The stalemate sees Senate Democrats blocking GOP bills to press ACA subsidy extensions, while Republicans insist they’ve offered clean funding. Kelley warns the SNAP program for 42 million Americans could run out by Nov. 1.

articles.title: Biden decries ‘dark days’ under Trump and urges Americans to stay positive
articles.trailText: Former US president on Sunday addressed Trump’s agenda while being honored at Kennedy Institute in Boston
articles.summary: Former president Joe Biden, 82, in his first public address since radiation therapy for prostate cancer, accepted the Kennedy Institute’s Lifetime Achievement Award in Boston and denounced what he called “dark days” under Donald Trump’s tenure. He warned of free-speech assaults and executive overreach amid one of the longest government shutdowns, advocated for the founding balance of executive, legislative and judicial powers and praised federal employees, universities, comedians and Republicans who defy Trump. Urging Americans not to “check out,” he predicted the nation would “keep the faith” and emerge “stronger, wiser and more resilient.”

articles.title: Lawsuits against banks with Epstein ties may shed new light on financier’s crimes
articles.trailText: Experts say claim banks enabled Epstein will be difficult to prove but other outcomes could provide solace to victims
articles.summary: Amid stalled congressional promises and unreleased DOJ files, two anonymous lawsuits target Bank of America and BNY Mellon for allegedly funding and legitimizing Jeffrey Epstein’s international sex trafficking, failing to flag suspicious transactions despite awareness of abuse. Led by veteran plaintiff attorneys Sigrid McCawley and Brad Edwards, the complaints argue that institutional profits fueled trafficking networks. While legal analysts doubt proof of causation, they foresee swift settlements and significant PR fallout. Crucially, discovery may unseal secret records, providing survivors with long-sought evidence. Plaintiffs aim to hold banks accountable, deter financial enablers of trafficking, and achieve what political branches have so far failed to deliver: justice and transparency.
