articles.title: Trump ‘would love’ unconstitutional third term but rules out running for VP
articles.trailText: Presidents are constitutionally limited to two elected terms but some had suggested unorthodox gambit to stay in office
articles.summary: While aboard Air Force One en route to Tokyo, President Donald Trump dismissed proposals to circumvent the 22nd Amendment by running as vice-president in 2028 to secure an informal third term, calling the idea “too cute” and unlikely to win public approval. He reiterated that the Constitution bars a third elected term yet admitted he “would love” one, citing his strong approval ratings. Trump praised Republicans like JD Vance and Marco Rubio as capable successors. On his five-day Asia tour ahead of APEC and ASEAN summits, he touted new Southeast Asia trade and critical minerals pacts and anticipates a truce-like deal with Xi Jinping.

articles.title: Ex-Los Angeles police officer charged in 2015 shooting death of unarmed man
articles.trailText: Clifford Proctor pleaded not guilty in death of unhoused man Brendan Glenn after grand jury indictment unsealed
articles.summary: In a grand jury indictment unsealed Friday, former LAPD officer Clifford Proctor, 60, pleaded not guilty to second-degree murder for the May 2015 shooting of unarmed homeless man Brendan Glenn, 29, in Venice. Both Black, Glenn was shot twice in the back during a struggle outside Bank of Venice after an altercation with a bouncer; LAPD video contradicted Proctor’s claim Glenn reached for a holster. The charges follow a use-of-force review by then-DA George Gascón; incoming DA Nathan Hochman will decide on prosecution. Proctor resigned in 2017, remains jailed; next hearing Nov. 3.

articles.title: Trump cuts probably hindered warning process for Alaska storm that displaced hundreds, experts say
articles.trailText: Reductions in weather balloon launches could have degraded forecasts that residents depend on to prepare
articles.summary: Experts warn Trump administration cuts to weather balloon launches and National Weather Service staffing likely degraded forecasts for Typhoon Halong’s remnants, complicating warnings before the Oct. 12 storm in Alaska’s Yukon-Kuskokwim delta. Floodwaters displaced over 1,500 Yup’ik residents, airlifted by the Alaska National Guard to Anchorage shelters, with Governor Dunleavy estimating an 18-month recovery. Trump delayed a federal disaster declaration by nearly a week and has proposed phasing out FEMA, while also cutting EPA flood-protection grants and Native-owned radio funding, further undermining resilience in remote communities.

articles.title: US and China agree ‘framework’ for trade deal ahead of Xi-Trump meeting | First Thing
articles.trailText: US treasury secretary anticipates tariff truce with China will be extended, and that Beijing will revive substantial purchases of US soybeans. Plus, is Wikipedia’s Jimmy Wales the last decent tech baron?
articles.summary: On Oct 27, 2025, US treasury secretary Scott Bessent announced a framework trade deal with China at the ASEAN summit—suspending planned 100% tariffs from Nov 1 and advancing a TikTok sale ahead of the Xi–Trump summit. Trump also hinted at truce talks with Brazil and threatened 10% tariffs on Canada over an Ontario ad. Other highlights: Rand Paul decried US strikes off Venezuela killing ~40; Category 5 Hurricane Melissa forced Jamaican evacuations; USDA paused food benefits for 41 m amid the shutdown; plus briefs on Argentina’s midterms, a WWII plane recovery, Wikipedia’s Jimmy Wales vs. AI, Klamath River restoration and AI tools for authors.

articles.title: Threat to US vaccines as CDC staff supporting key advisory panel laid off
articles.trailText: Critics say scientists ‘held hostage’ by RFK Jr as changes mean vaccine development and guidance in peril
articles.summary: CDC layoffs eliminated the staff who manage logistics, data review and compliance for the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP), postponing its October meeting indefinitely. Without working groups for flu, RSV, HPV and other diseases—most inactive for months—the US risks failing to update routine vaccine recommendations for over half of children in 2026 and to endorse new vaccines. The shakeup follows health secretary RFK Jr’s unprecedented replacement of independent ACIP advisers with his own, including anti-vaccine activists. Experts warn missing expertise, HR and ethics oversight imperil the vaccine program’s future.

articles.title: ‘Our work has only just begun’: Mamdani, Sanders and AOC rally the faithful ahead of NYC mayoral election
articles.trailText: Thousands pack Forest Hills stadium on Sunday night, voicing their excitement and hope for change
articles.summary: At a “NYC Is Not For Sale” rally in Forest Hills, Queens, on Oct. 27, some 13,000 supporters—especially energized Gen Z—gathered to back Democratic mayoral hopeful Zohran Mamdani alongside Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Sen. Bernie Sanders. Speakers emphasized unity, affordability, public transit safety and LGBTQ rights; religious leaders and Comptroller Brad Lander endorsed Mamdani. Barrage for “Tax the Rich” greeted Gov. Hochul while Sanders warned of billionaire influence. Mamdani, after ridiculing Andrew Cuomo, rallied volunteers with a phone‐light salute and declared “Our work has only just begun” ahead of the Nov. 4 election.

articles.title: Republican senator calls Trump’s military airstrikes ‘extrajudicial killings’
articles.trailText: Rand Paul’s comments come days after president claimed US lawmakers wouldn’t take issue with Venezuelan strikes
articles.summary: Kentucky Republican Senator Rand Paul denounced the Trump administration’s eight military strikes on boats off Venezuela—killing about 40 alleged drug traffickers—as “extrajudicial killings.” Paul told Fox News that Congress received no names, evidence or arms intel and likened the operations to China and Iran’s summary executions. He joined a failed war powers resolution with Tim Kaine and Adam Schiff to block the strikes, contrasting other GOP senators who supported the offensive. Trump says he needs no congressional approval and vows to “kill” drug smugglers.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: administration accused of attack on free speech after British journalist detained
articles.trailText: Homeland security said Hamdi’s visa had been revoked amid claims the move was apparent retaliation for his criticism of Israel. Key US politics stories from Sunday 26 October at a glance
articles.summary: On 26 October the Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR) accused the Trump administration of free speech abuse after ICE detained British journalist Sami Hamdi at San Francisco airport, revoking his visa and moving to deport him for criticizing Israel's Gaza campaign. A new book excerpt claims Trump called Mike Pence a "wimp" in a Jan. 6 phone call. In other news, Gavin Newsom is weighing a 2028 presidential bid post-2026 midterms; Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent says a US-China deal on TikTok's sale is finalized; experts warn Trump's order to pay troops during a shutdown sets a dangerous precedent.

articles.title: US and China agree ‘framework’ for trade deal ahead of Xi-Trump meeting
articles.trailText: US treasury secretary anticipates tariff truce with China will be extended, and that China will revive substantial purchases of US soybeans
articles.summary: On the sidelines of the ASEAN summit in Malaysia, US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent announced that Washington and Beijing have struck a framework agreement pausing planned 100% tariffs on Chinese imports and postponing export controls on rare earth minerals for a year. The deal, which also paves the way for finalizing TikTok’s US sale and reviving China’s US soybean purchases, will undergo internal approvals in both countries. It boosts the prospect of extending the current tariff truce beyond Nov 1 and reduces the risk of a wider global trade war, while parallel talks began on easing US-Brazil tariffs.

articles.title: US Boeing workers continue midwest strike after rejecting latest contract offer
articles.trailText: Nearly three-month strike includes 3,200 machinists at plants where military aircraft and weapons are developed
articles.summary: About 3,200 machinists at Boeing’s Mascoutah, IL, and St. Louis and St. Charles, MO plants developing military aircraft and weapons have voted 51%–49% to reject a five-year contract offer and continue a nearly three-month strike. The deal, similar to prior proposals, cuts the ratification bonus but adds a $3,000 share grant, a $1,000 retention bonus, and improved fourth-year top-scale wage growth. Union leaders demand higher retirement contributions and a $12,000 ratification bonus. Boeing, representing its Defense, Space & Security arm (over one-third of revenue), said it’s prepared to execute contingency plans ahead of Q3 earnings.

articles.title: ICE detains British journalist after criticism of Israel on US tour
articles.trailText: Trump ally Laura Loomer took credit for Sami Hamdi’s detainment in move denounced as ‘affront to free speech’
articles.summary: ICE detained British Muslim political commentator Sami Hamdi at San Francisco International Airport after revoking his visa amid his US speaking tour criticizing Israel’s Gaza campaign, CAIR says. CAIR denounced the arrest as retaliation and an assault on free speech and is petitioning for his release. DHS press secretary Tricia McLaughlin cited visa revocation for undermining US national security. Trump ally Laura Loomer, known for Islamophobic conspiracy theories, claimed credit for pressuring authorities. Hamdi’s case follows other deportations of pro-Palestinian voices despite a federal judge’s ruling deeming the policy unconstitutional.

articles.title: US airports report over 20 air traffic controller shortage incidents in one day
articles.trailText: Transportation secretary says figure is ‘one of the highest we’ve seen’ since 1 October as shutdown drags on
articles.summary: On Saturday 26 October, the FAA recorded 22 “triggers” for air traffic controller shortages—the highest since 1 October—leading to a ground stop at LAX and regional delays. FlightAware reported over 5,300 US delays Saturday and 2,500 more by midday Sunday, with staffing shortfalls at six major hubs, including Chicago and Newark. Some 13,000 controllers and 50,000 TSA officers are working unpaid amid a 3,500-controller deficit, forcing mandatory overtime and second jobs. Training at the FAA Academy is paused, raising long-term safety concerns. Industry leaders urge Congress to reopen the government immediately.

articles.title: One killed and six injured after shooting at Pennsylvania’s Lincoln University
articles.trailText: One armed person detained as historically Black college shooting comes amid rising violence at homecoming events
articles.summary: At least one person was killed and six injured in a shooting at Lincoln University in Pennsylvania during homecoming tailgating on Oct 26. The late-evening attack unfolded around 9:30pm outside the International Cultural Center. A suspect with a firearm was detained, and investigators are exploring if additional shooters were involved, though no ongoing threat is believed. The Chester County DA, state police and FBI are leading the probe, urging witnesses to submit video. The incident mirrors rising gun violence at recent homecoming events nationwide.

articles.title: Gavin Newsom confirms he is considering 2028 presidential run
articles.trailText: Democratic California governor and high-profile Trump critic plans to make decision after 2026 midterms
articles.summary: California governor Gavin Newsom said he’ll decide on a 2028 presidential bid after the 2026 midterms, noting term limits end his governorship in January 2027. A high-profile Trump critic, he’s championed a ballot measure to offset Republican redistricting and clashed with Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy, who’s threatened to withhold up to $160 million in federal funds over a fatal crash. A CBS poll shows 72% of Democrats and 48% of all voters want Newsom to run.

articles.title: Trump told Pence ‘you’ll go down as a wimp’ in January 6 phone call, book says
articles.trailText: Book cites Pence’s notes from call with Trump, who called vice-president a ‘wimp’ if he certified Biden’s 2020 victory
articles.summary: Retribution by ABC News’s Jonathan Karl cites Mike Pence’s notes from his Jan. 6, 2021 call with Donald Trump, who shamed Pence as a “wimp” if he certified Joe Biden’s victory and urged him to refuse. Pence countered they’d sworn to uphold the Constitution, saying “it takes courage to uphold the law.” Those notes became key evidence after Trump supporters stormed the Capitol. After winning in 2024, Trump pardoned the rioters. The excerpt also cites Steve Bannon’s talk of a plan to extend Trump’s presidency beyond two terms.

articles.title: ‘Islamophobia is endemic,’ Mamdani says of Republicans’ push to deport him
articles.trailText: Two House Republicans push justice department to investigate Zohran Mamdani’s path to US citizenship
articles.summary: Two US House Republicans, Randy Fine and Andy Ogles, have urged the Justice Department to launch a broad investigation into New York City mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani’s naturalization—Fine calling for a review of all citizenships in the past 30 years to root out an “enemy within,” and Ogles alleging communist ties via Mamdani’s Democratic Socialists of America membership. Mamdani, a dual US-Ugandan citizen, decries the probes as racist, anti-Muslim cruelty amid economic and political crises, and condemns Islamophobia normalized by figures like Andrew Cuomo.

articles.title: Americans brace for food stamps to run out: ‘The greatest hunger catastrophe since the Great Depression’
articles.trailText: Nearly 42 million people in danger as federal government shutdown continues and Snap funding to end 1 November
articles.summary: With federal funding for SNAP set to expire Nov. 1 amid a government shutdown, nearly 42 million low-income Americans—including working parents, seniors and people with disabilities—could lose roughly $187 a month in benefits. Advocates warn of “the greatest hunger catastrophe since the Great Depression” after Congress slashed $187 billion from SNAP in Trump’s One Big Beautiful Bill. The USDA has paused payments, prompting over 200 Democrats to urge use of contingency funds. Politicians trade blame: Democrats demand ACA subsidy extensions in funding bills, while Republicans fault them for blocking reopening.

articles.title: A Hawaiian princess bequeathed her inheritance to her people. The schools they set up are being sued
articles.trailText: Lawsuit against Kamehameha schools by Students for Fair Admissions, a neoconservative non-profit, alleges discrimination against non-Hawaiians
articles.summary: Students for Fair Admissions, led by Edward Blum, sued Kamehameha Schools in Honolulu federal court, challenging its race-based admissions that favor Native Hawaiian ancestry. Founded by Princess Bernice Pauahi Bishop’s 1884 bequest—landholding 9% of Hawaii—the system spans three K–12 campuses and 30 preschools, educates 5,400 students, and holds a $15bn endowment while subsidizing 92% of costs. Critics see the suit as part of a conservative campaign against affirmative action; alumni and trustees vow to defend Pauahi’s mission to uplift Native Hawaiians through culture-centered education.

articles.title: Jewish New York’s reckoning with Zohran Mamdani: ‘He’s become a vehicle for our tensions’
articles.trailText: A tour of the mayoral hopeful’s Jewish outreach reveals an electorate fractured over Israel and grappling with his historic candidacy in radically different ways
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani, a 34-year-old Democratic socialist and prominent US Palestine advocate, is navigating a fractured Jewish electorate in NYC. Against the backdrop of Gaza’s humanitarian crisis and evolving Jewish debates over Israel, polls show 43% of Jewish New Yorkers backing him (67% under 44). Conservative rabbis led by Elliot Cosgrove denounce him as a threat, while the Jewish left and younger voters embrace his anti-hate and affordability agenda. Through private synagogue meet-and-greets, Mamdani addresses antisemitism and economic issues, forcing intra-Jewish reckonings over Zionism, two-state reality and communal identity ahead of November’s vote.

articles.title: Can Democrats harness the energy of the No Kings protests to fight Trump?
articles.trailText: Millions took to US streets to oppose authoritarianism as Democrats acknowledge ‘People want to see us fighting’
articles.summary: Last weekend’s No Kings protests mobilised an estimated 7 million participants in 2,700 peaceful US rallies against Trump’s alleged authoritarianism, following earlier Hands Off! and June No Kings events. Attendance by senators Murphy, Schumer, Booker, Warren, Sanders and others contrasted with many absent Democrats, underscoring party inertia. Surveys show 62% of Americans rate the country off course and 56% view Trump as a dangerous dictator. Indivisible and grassroots leaders urge Democrats to convert mass energy into policy leverage and voter mobilisation. Tea Party parallels stress building a durable, big-tent movement to win midterms.

articles.title: Gun violence prevention groups disqualified from grants built around their work
articles.trailText: Trump administration altering program that was a lifeline for pioneering non-profits helping reduce gun violence
articles.summary: In September, the DOJ’s Community Based Violence Intervention and Prevention Initiative (CVIPI), launched under Biden in 2022 with over $300 million awarded to 120+ non-profits, was revised to bar those same groups—such as Hope Hustlers and Newark Community Street Team—from applying. Only city, county and tribal governments are now eligible, and the focus has shifted from “comprehensive, community-based prevention” to “supporting law enforcement.” Critics say this follows $800 million in Trump-era OJP cuts that gutted street outreach and hospital bedside visits. Democracy Forward sued, calling the changes “shameful,” and the case is on appeal.

articles.title: Trump oversees Thailand-Cambodia ceasefire signing as Asia tour gets under way
articles.trailText: Trump has begun a five-day trip to Malaysia, Japan and South Korea, his first visit to the region since taking office in January
articles.summary: On day one of his five-day Asia tour—his first since taking office—President Trump oversaw the signing of an expanded Thailand–Cambodia ceasefire in Kuala Lumpur, halting their worst border clash in years. The deal mandates heavy-weapons withdrawal, landmine clearance and the release of 18 Cambodian soldiers, earning Trump a Nobel nomination. Ahead of the ASEAN summit, he also secured trade frameworks: a US-Malaysia minerals deal with a 19% tariff, a Vietnam tariff cap of 0–20%, and talks with Brazil. He signals a high-stakes meeting with Xi Jinping on tariffs, Taiwan and Hong Kong.

articles.title: Trump’s move to pay troops amid shutdown sets dangerous precedent, experts warn
articles.trailText: Experts see move as Trump’s latest attempt to shift power of the purse away from Congress and into executive branch
articles.summary: By ordering military pay during the October shutdown, Trump bypassed Congress’s appropriation power, repurposing $8bn in Defense Dept R&D funds and accepting a $130m private donation. Legal experts from AEI and CAP warn the move violates the Antideficiency Act and lacks congressional authorization, risking executive overreach. While troop pay is popular, critics fear it sets precedent for funding future executive priorities: domestic deployments to policy initiatives, undermining Congress’s power of the purse. Challenges face standing hurdles and unlikely prosecutions. Appropriators, GOP and Dems worry the usurpation damages trust and complicates future budget agreements.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: President raises tariffs on Canada as he attends Asean summit with Carney
articles.trailText: Donald Trump makes announcement in response to anti-tariff ad sponsored by Ontario government. Key US politics stories from Saturday 25 October at a glance
articles.summary: Donald Trump raised US tariffs on Canada by 10% in retaliation for an Ontario government anti-tariff ad, prompting Ontario to suspend its campaign; he’s attending an ASEAN summit in Malaysia alongside Canadian PM Mark Carney but won’t meet him. On a broader Asia tour, Trump said he’s open to meeting Kim Jong-un. Meanwhile, HHS chief RFK Jr plans to reverse decades-old nutrition advice to promote saturated fats, a major Trump donor (Timothy Mellon) covered $130m to pay troops during the shutdown, Hispanic approval of Trump has halved, and the White House ramps up military pressure on Venezuela amid US health funding cuts.

articles.title: Texas officers heroically rescue baby pinned under car after overturn crash
articles.trailText: Fort Worth police share video of extraordinary effort by officers and motorists to pull car off baby and give CPR
articles.summary: Fort Worth officers Sgt R Nichols and Officer E Bounds saved an infant pinned under an overturned car after a crash on I-30, using bodycam footage showing them and bystanders lifting the vehicle to free the baby. Initially unresponsive, responders detected a pulse, administered chest compressions with fingers, and restored breathing as the child began crying. The mother and baby are stable, expected to fully recover. The department highlighted the incident’s severity, Texas’s child restraint laws, and praised the “little angel” rescue as exemplifying protect and serve, lauding both officers and motorists for their bravery and swift action.

articles.title: Trump raises tariffs on Canada by 10% in retaliation for anti-tariff TV ad
articles.trailText: Move is response to ad sponsored by Ontario that referenced Ronald Reagan’s support for free trade
articles.summary: Trump announced he will boost US tariffs on Canada by 10% after Ontario aired an anti-tariff TV ad citing Ronald Reagan’s 1987 free-trade remarks, accusing the province of misrepresentation and calling the advert a “fraud.” Ontario Premier Doug Ford agreed to suspend the campaign as Prime Minister Mark Carney seeks to revive negotiations. While most Canadian exports are exempt under USMCA, the US already applies 35% tariffs on non-USMCA goods and 50% on steel and aluminium. The Reagan Foundation and Canadian Chamber warn of legal and economic fallout. Carney is ready to resume talks but Trump won’t meet him at the ASEAN summit.

articles.title: Hispanics’ support of Trump plunges since he started second term
articles.trailText: Notable majority feel the country is headed in the wrong direction, and only 27% approve of his job performance
articles.summary: An October AP-NORC poll finds Trump’s favorability among Hispanic adults plunged from 44% pre-second term to 25%, while those saying the country’s headed the wrong way rose from 63% in March to 73%. Approval of his overall performance fell from 41% to 27%. Concern over his handling of the economy and immigration—particularly hardline enforcement—drives declines. Support among Hispanic Republicans dropped from 83% to 65%, with sharper drops among those under 45 and men. Many cite financial stress and immigration as top issues.

articles.title: Honduran immigrant dies while fleeing ICE, bringing raids death toll to three
articles.trailText: Jose Castro Rivera, 24, was killed Thursday morning after running on to a highway and being struck
articles.summary: Jose Castro Rivera, 24, was killed after running onto I-264 near Norfolk, Virginia, while fleeing a targeted, intelligence-based ICE enforcement operation—bringing to three the known deaths during the Trump administration’s expanded mass deportation raids. A DHS official said agents stopped a vehicle and detained other passengers; state police say they weren’t involved and the crash is under investigation. Previous fatalities include Guatemalan Roberto Carlos Montoya Valdés in Monrovia and Mexican farmworker Jaime Alanís García in Ventura County. Non-criminal detainees now outnumber those charged with crimes, and ICE custody has seen over 20 deaths this year, the highest since 2004.

articles.title: Trump backer Timothy Mellon identified as donor of $130m for US troop pay during government shutdown
articles.trailText: Reclusive Republican donor is descendant of gilded aged industrialist and former treasury secretary Andrew Mellon
articles.summary: Reclusive billionaire Timothy Mellon, heir to industrialist and ex-Treasury secretary Andrew Mellon, has been revealed as the anonymous donor who contributed $130 m to cover pay and benefits for 1.3 m active-duty US troops during the four-week federal shutdown. Using the Pentagon’s gift-acceptance authority, the funds offset roughly $100 per service member, though critics warn it may breach the Antideficiency Act. An ardent anti-tax Trump backer, Mellon poured over $165 m into Republican campaigns in 2024 and has a reported net worth between $700 m and $4 bn.

articles.title: One year after a historic dam removal, teens inspire river restoration worldwide: ‘It turns out you can win’
articles.trailText: The Klamath River began rebounding almost immediately. Now, Indigenous youth are leading the next chapter of the recovery, inspiring tribes from Brazil to China
articles.summary: One year after removal of four dams from the Klamath River—the largest dam‐removal project in US history—28 Indigenous teens completed the first full 310-mile descent from headwaters to ocean, marking a rebirth of biodiversity as coho and Chinook salmon returned upstream, native plants re-established and wildlife flourished. Organized by Ríos to Rivers’ Paddle Tribal Waters program, the expedition united tribal youth from the US, China, Brazil, New Zealand and Chile, forging global alliances to replicate dam-removal successes, advocate at COP30 against dams as clean energy and champion Indigenous-led river restoration worldwide.

articles.title: How ‘screw Trump’ messaging may help California’s Proposition 50 prevail
articles.trailText: Republican opposition to the effort to give House Democrats more safe seats may be no match for the fact that Californians really don’t like Trump
articles.summary: Proposition 50 seeks to pause California’s independent redistricting commission until 2031 so Democrats can carve five extra seats, countering GOP gerrymanders in Texas under Trump. Governor Gavin Newsom brands it a way to “screw Trump” and rally Californians’ anti-Trump and anti-Texas sentiment. Backed by Obama, Ocasio-Cortez and heavy fundraising ($138m vs $82m), polls show yes rising into the low 60s%, driven by high-propensity Democratic mail-in voters. Opponents including Schwarzenegger, McCarthy and Steve Hilton warn of undermining fair maps but struggle with a complex message. Late polling and fundraising edges suggest Prop 50 is poised for a decisive win.

articles.title: ‘I am not done’: Kamala Harris says she may run for president again
articles.trailText: In a BBC interview, former vice-president says she isn’t done with politics and could ‘possibly’ be the next president
articles.summary: Speaking on BBC’s Sunday With Laura Kuenssberg, former vice-president Kamala Harris declared “I am not done,” suggesting a potential 2028 presidential bid despite trailing in polls behind figures like Dwayne Johnson. She dismissed pollsters, recalled her electoral comebacks, and labeled Donald Trump a “tyrant” weaponizing the DOJ—citing ABC’s suspension of Jimmy Kimmel and corporate “capitulations.” Promoting her memoir 107 Days, she blamed her abbreviated 2024 campaign for defeat while urging acknowledgment of a UN inquiry’s Gaza genocide finding. The White House retorted that Americans “don’t care” about her “absurd lies.”

articles.title: ‘Society needs monsters’: why are Americans so obsessed with the idea of serial killers?
articles.trailText: Experts note an 80% drop-off since US serial killing peaked in the 1970s – but that hasn’t stopped a surge of interest
articles.summary: Despite rumors of the “Rainey Street Ripper” in Austin, a Texas State University and police review of 189 drownings at Lady Bird Lake found no pattern of serial homicide, attributing deaths to alcohol, drugs and bar proximity. Experts note an 80% decline in US serial killers since the 1970s thanks to DNA profiling, cameras, ride-share apps and public awareness. Yet Netflix documentaries and true-crime media keep fascination alive, even as sudden mass shootings now eclipse traditional serial murder. Journalist Rachel Corbett argues “society needs monsters” to define moral boundaries.

articles.title: Pennsylvania city divided over Trump as it reels from economic whiplash
articles.trailText: As Trump’s tariffs and funding cuts suspend projects in Erie, some residents view the changes as a necessary evil
articles.summary: In Erie, Pennsylvania, Trump’s tariffs and funding cuts halted a planned $300 million plastic-to-fuel plant by freezing a crucial Department of Energy loan, derailing hundreds of construction and operational jobs. Costs for local redevelopment rose 37 percent, starving projects in the city’s poorest zip code. Second Harvest lost $1 million in federal aid as food demand spiked 43 percent. Farmers and manufacturers report export barriers and higher import costs, though some firms see 15 percent sales gains from tax breaks. Residents remain divided—staunch supporters credit tariffs and immigration curbs for protecting jobs, while opponents blame these macro policies for Erie’s stalled growth.

articles.title: RFK Jr to urge Americans to eat more saturated fats, alarming health experts
articles.trailText: Guidance from health and human services secretary contradicts decades of dietary recommendations
articles.summary: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. plans to encourage higher saturated fat intake in new dietary guidelines, contradicting decades of advice and alarming experts. AHA's Cheryl Anderson warns more saturated fat raises cholesterol and cardiovascular risk, while UCSF's Ronald Krauss says it's "neutral" if replaced with unsaturated fats but harmful if swapped for sugars. Both advocate shifting from nutrient cutoffs to food-based guidance. Critics fear rushed policy changes could boost saturated fat in school lunches and military rations, elevating heart disease risk.

articles.title: The racism and Islamophobia behind many of the attacks on Zohran Mamdani
articles.trailText: Critics of the Democratic nominee for NYC mayor have called him everything from ‘jihadist candidate’ to ‘terrorist sympathizer’
articles.summary: Since securing the Democratic nomination for New York City mayor, Muslim candidate Zohran Mamdani has endured a torrent of racist and Islamophobic attacks. Former governor Andrew Cuomo labelled him a “terrorist sympathizer,” joked about 9/11, and ran a deleted AI-generated ad linking him to crime. Mayor Eric Adams called him a communist; Donald Trump vowed to obstruct his tenure; Republican Rep. Elise Stefanik dubbed him a “jihadist candidate”; hundreds of rabbis accused him of endangering Jews. Despite billionaire-funded smear campaigns, Mamdani’s grassroots surge, clear values and composed rebuttals have turned bias into momentum.

articles.title: ‘A problematic species’: California to allow hunting of ‘very aggressive’ swans
articles.trailText: Officials say move essential to protect wetlands and native waterfowl but some groups call decision ‘inhumane’
articles.summary: California’s new AB 764, effective Jan 1, allows year-round hunting of invasive mute swans to protect wetlands—90–95% of which are already lost—and native waterfowl. Wildlife officials say swans uproot and overconsume aquatic vegetation, alter habitat, aggressively chase off other birds and can injure people. Authored by Republican Jeff Gonzalez and backed by CDFW, California Waterfowl Association, American Bird Conservancy and others, the law lets licensed hunters or landowners (with permission) kill swans without a license. Opponents like Friends of Animals label the policy inhumane; mute swans aren’t covered by the federal Migratory Bird Treaty Act.

articles.title: Federal workers squeezed as shutdown drags on: ‘I can’t believe we’re not going to get paid’
articles.trailText: Anxiety and economic stress among federal employees as Republicans and Democrats remain deadlocked on bill
articles.summary: Federal employees face escalating furloughs, unpaid paychecks, and deepening financial stress as the federal government shutdown enters its fourth week. Republicans and Democrats remain deadlocked over a budget deal that includes healthcare subsidies, risking coverage for 15 million Americans. Union leaders report desperation, debt burdens, and emergency childcare crises. The Trump administration’s threats to withhold backpay and cut Democratic priorities, alongside rhetoric likening OMB director Vought to “Darth Vader,” fuel uncertainty. EPA workforce furloughs stall Great Lakes protections amid attrition, while Speaker Johnson demands Democrats reopen the government. House members remain on paid recess while frontline workers go unpaid.

articles.title: Trump says he is open to meeting Kim Jong-un as he embarks on whirlwind Asia tour
articles.trailText: Trip will see him take part in high-stakes trade talks with Chinese leader Xi Jinping – but he also raised prospect of meeting North Korean leader
articles.summary: Trump embarks on first Asia trip since taking office, visiting Malaysia for an ASEAN summit to sign trade deals and peace accords; refuels in Qatar to discuss a Gaza ceasefire; proceeds to Tokyo to meet Japan’s new PM Takaichi on defense and investment; then to Seoul for the APEC summit, where he’s open to a side meeting with Kim Jong-un and will seek high-stakes trade talks with Xi Jinping aimed at averting 100% tariffs set for Nov 1. Talks may cover limited tariff relief, US soy and Boeing purchases, Taiwan, Russia sanctions and Jimmy Lai’s case.

articles.title: Why is Trump, the self-proclaimed ‘president of peace’, aiming to topple the Venezuelan regime?
articles.trailText: Marco Rubio has pushed for a tough approach to Venezuela, while the president reportedly only cares about the oil
articles.summary: Under Trump's 'America First' foreign policy, the US has launched eight strikes killing 38 people on Venezuelan narco-trafficking boats, deployed B-52 bombers and special forces offshore, and authorized CIA missions aimed at ousting Nicolás Maduro—designated a 'narco-terrorist' with a $50 m bounty. Driven by Marco Rubio's 'tough' narco-terror narrative over pragmatic oil deals, policy eases some sanctions for Chevron while escalating legal and regional stability risks. Critics warn of an unprecedented military-law enforcement fusion, Monroe Doctrine echoes, and Rubio's 2028 ambitions shaping Latin America posture. Some experts dispute their legality under the Patriot Act and question Venezuela’s actual weight as a drug source.

articles.title: What is the White House East Wing and why has it been torn down in Trump’s renovation plans?
articles.trailText: President Donald Trump is adding a $300m ballroom to the White House – but that plan has come at the cost of the historic East Wing
articles.summary: President Donald Trump has torn down the White House’s East Wing—originally built by Theodore and Franklin Roosevelt to house first lady offices and conceal a wartime bunker—to build a privately funded, $300 m, 90 000 sq ft ballroom seating 999 guests, styled after Mar-a-Lago. Despite vows to preserve existing structures, demolition proceeded without National Capital Planning Commission approval, provoking ire from historians, the National Trust for Historic Preservation and figures like David Frum. Major tech and defense corporations are among donors; completion is slated before Trump’s term ends in January 2029.

articles.title: At least four people shot near Howard University, Washington DC police say
articles.trailText: Police say one person in critical condition and one person in serious condition but no details on suspect or suspects
articles.summary: Four people were shot on the 600 block of Howard Place near Howard University at 8:23 pm during homecoming celebrations, police said. One victim is in critical condition and another is serious; seven people were treated for injuries, four from gunshots. Authorities secured the scene, closed nearby roads, and reported no suspect information. Homecoming events, including a Greek step show, began Friday and continue through Sunday.

articles.title: Ex-60 Minutes producer Bill Owens says bosses discouraged him from covering Gaza and Trump
articles.trailText: Show’s leader, who resigned in April, says he was also pressured to apologize for edit of Kamala Harris interview
articles.summary: Former 60 Minutes executive producer Bill Owens says Paramount bosses discouraged further Gaza segments after pro-Israel backlash and urged him to curb Trump coverage, and pressured an apology over a Kamala Harris edit. Owens refused, citing journalistic integrity, and resigned in April amid concerns about corporate censorship tied to a Skydance merger and FCC approval. At Colby College he accepted an Elijah Lovejoy award, warned against apathy and cowardice, urged protecting 60 Minutes journalists—including warning new chief Bari Weiss—and hinted at plans to re-enter journalism.

articles.title: Portland judge rejects Trump request to allow national guard deployment
articles.trailText: Karin Immergut to decide by Monday whether to lift her order blocking federalized troops from patrolling city
articles.summary: Federal judge Karin Immergut in Portland on Friday refused the Trump administration’s request to immediately lift her order barring federalized National Guard troops from patrolling the city, deferring a decision until Monday. Immergut had issued two temporary restraining orders—first blocking 200 Oregon guard members as beyond presidential authority and then barring all reinforcements after a perceived attempt to evade the initial order. Although a Ninth Circuit panel lifted the first injunction, the second remains in effect and a stay extends both orders for several days. Parallel challenges are pending in Washington DC and Chicago over similar deployments.

articles.title: US places sanctions on Colombian president over alleged failure to stop cartels
articles.trailText: Treasury accuses Gustavo Petro of ‘allowing drug cartels to flourish’ as president attacks Trump’s ‘oppressive regime’
articles.summary: Washington has imposed sanctions on Colombian President Gustavo Petro, accusing him of permitting drug cartels to thrive. The measures, announced by Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and backed by the Trump administration, freeze US assets and bar transactions. Petro, whose visa was revoked in September after pro-Palestinian protests, counters that his government has seized record cocaine volumes and calls the sanctions “oppression.” His wife, son Nicolás (under pending corruption charges) and Interior Minister Armando Benedetti are also sanctioned. This rare action against a sitting head of state aligns Petro with leaders from Russia, Venezuela and North Korea.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Pentagon announces it is deploying US aircraft carrier to the Caribbean
articles.trailText: USS Gerald Ford carrier and other warships will head to coast of Venezuela. Key US politics stories from Friday 24 October at a glance
articles.summary: On 24 October the Pentagon announced deployment of the nuclear-powered USS Gerald Ford carrier strike group to the Caribbean off Venezuela, beefing up F-35 jets and surveillance aircraft to escalate Trump’s campaign against drug cartels with potential land strikes. Other key US political updates: a US-Canada trade spat over a Reagan tariff ad; appeals court unanimously rejects administration’s bid to delay veterans’ benefits rulings; White House East Wing razed for Trump’s gilded ballroom; Zelenskyy urges continued US support for Ukraine; Virginia Democrats pursue redistricting; DOJ to dispatch election monitors; and expanded facial-recognition screening at borders.

articles.title: Tennessee man’s heart still active nearly two minutes after execution, lawyer says
articles.trailText: Allegation raises further questions about death of Byron Black in execution lawyer says was ‘100% botched’
articles.summary: Byron Black, 69, showed nearly two minutes of cardiac activity after being pronounced dead in his August lethal injection, his attorney said, citing EKG records. Witnesses described him breathing, groaning and lifting his head as staff struggled for 10 minutes to find a vein and blood oozed at the injection site. Under Tennessee protocol, additional pentobarbital should have been given if he remained alive, yet officials closed the curtain, possibly breaching witness rights. His legal team is now challenging the state’s pentobarbital procedures as cruel and unusual, seeking execution-team testimony.

articles.title: Pentagon deploys top aircraft carrier as Trump militarisation of Caribbean ratchets up
articles.trailText: Use of USS Gerald Ford along with fighter jets comes as president plots strikes against alleged cartels on land
articles.summary: In late October 2025 the Pentagon redirected the USS Gerald Ford carrier strike group—including stealth F/A-18 Super Hornets and surveillance aircraft—from the Mediterranean to the Venezuelan coast, marking a sharp escalation in Donald Trump’s anti-cartel campaign. Officials say the deployment expands U.S. capability from targeting suspected drug-smuggling boats to striking land-based cartel and air-defense sites, backed by CIA intelligence. Trump confirmed “the land is next,” while Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro denounced a “fabricated war.” The administration’s legal rationale hinges on designating cartel vessels as terrorist assets in a “non-international armed conflict,” despite scant public evidence.

articles.title: US and Canada spar over ad of Reagan denouncing tariffs that led to derailed trade talks
articles.trailText: Ontario premier says he plans to run ad featuring speech that sparked Trump’s ire again during World Series but campaign will end Monday
articles.summary: After Trump suspended trade talks following Ontario’s airing of a 1987 Reagan speech denouncing tariffs, Premier Doug Ford reran the ad during the World Series but agreed to end the campaign Monday after consulting Prime Minister Mark Carney. Ford said the public-domain clip aimed to spark debate on tariffs’ impact on workers. The Reagan Foundation and US Secretary of State Rubio criticized the ad as misleading. The spat unfolds ahead of the USMCA review cutoff and a Supreme Court hearing on presidential tariff powers; Carney pledges to shore up Canada’s economy and await resumed negotiations.

articles.title: East Wing of White House reduced to rubble as part of Trump’s ballroom construction
articles.trailText: Despite president’s promise to preserve it, the eastern section of the building is now completely destroyed
articles.summary: Trump’s administration has demolished the White House East Wing to make way for a $300 million gilded ballroom, despite his July pledge to preserve existing structures. Satellite images show the eastern section in rubble. Plans haven’t been filed with the National Capital Planning Commission, sparking legal challenges from historic‐preservation groups and a Virginia couple seeking a restraining order. Senior officials say Trump will likely name it the “Donald J. Trump Ballroom.” Funded privately by Trump and major donors including Apple, Amazon, Meta, Microsoft, Google, Lockheed Martin, Palantir and T-Mobile.

articles.title: US airstrike on ‘drug boat’ kills six as aircraft carrier sent to South America
articles.trailText: Pete Hegseth claims six ‘narco-terrorists’ killed in Caribbean as US military conducts 10th strike
articles.summary: On Friday, Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth announced the US military’s 10th strike in international Caribbean waters, hitting a suspected Tren de Aragua ‘drug boat’ at night and killing all six onboard without US casualties, sharing video footage. Pentagon spokesman Sean Parnell also ordered the USS Gerald R Ford carrier strike group to South America to bolster narcotics detection and disruption. Since September, the administration has launched 10 such strikes, killing at least 43 people, relying on CIA-sourced intelligence and Article II self-defense claims, which legal experts, human rights groups and regional governments, including Colombia’s, argue may breach international law.

articles.title: Hakeem Jeffries endorses Zohran Mamdani for New York City mayor
articles.trailText: US House minority leader ends four-month standoff over backing for Democratic nominee
articles.summary: Hakeem Jeffries, US House minority leader, endorsed Zohran Mamdani for New York City mayor Friday, ending a four-month standoff just before early voting. Facing pressure from congressional progressives and scrutiny over Mamdani’s democratic socialist rhetoric and past Israel comments, Jeffries praised his affordability agenda and inclusive leadership. Mamdani, who upset Andrew Cuomo in June, leads polls ahead of the Nov. 4 contest against Cuomo and Republican Curtis Sliwa. Key Democrats from Governor Kathy Hochul to Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez support him; Senate leader Chuck Schumer remains the last major holdout. Two Brooklyn meetings mediated by Al Sharpton and Mamdani’s pledge to retain NYPD commissioner Jessica Tisch clinched the endorsement.

articles.title: Virginia Democrats aim to redraw maps to help party gain seats in Congress
articles.trailText: State becomes second to attempt to redistrict to benefit Democrats in response to Republicans’ efforts to gain seats
articles.summary: Speaker Don Scott has called a special session to propose mid-cycle redistricting aimed at flipping two or three additional U.S. House seats, shifting Virginia’s current 6-5 Democratic majority. If successful, they’d need a constitutional amendment—requiring approval in two successive legislatures and a voter referendum—to dissolve the 16-member bipartisan commission created in 2020. This countergerrymandering effort mirrors California’s Prop 50 fight and responds to recent GOP map-making gains in Texas, North Carolina and Missouri.

articles.title: Letitia James pleads not guilty in Virginia mortgage fraud case
articles.trailText: New York attorney general appears in court in Virginia in case brought after Trump called for her prosecution
articles.summary: Before Judge Jamar Walker in Virginia federal court, New York AG Letitia James pleaded not guilty to bank fraud and false statements, accused of falsely claiming her Norfolk home as a secondary residence to secure favorable mortgage terms. Brought by Trump-appointed US attorney Lindsey Halligan over career prosecutors' objections, the indictment alleges she misled lenders despite minimal rental profit and family occupants. James plans to move to dismiss for improper appointment. Defense calls the case political retribution amid broader DOJ pressure for Trump-targeted prosecutions.

articles.title: Daniel Lurie: the millionaire mayor who got Trump to back off (for now)
articles.trailText: San Francisco’s mayor, along with Silicon Valley leaders, managed to stop the president’s law enforcement surge
articles.summary: San Francisco’s new mayor, Daniel Lurie, persuaded Donald Trump to pause a planned weekend federal immigration enforcement surge after Trump called him “very nicely” and received endorsements from Silicon Valley figures like Marc Benioff and Jensen Huang. Since taking office in January, the Levi Strauss heir has overseen a 45% drop in homicides and a 40% fall in robberies, added police officers and attracted downtown investments. Lurie, who avoids personal attacks on Trump and focuses on public safety, stresses partnership with federal authorities and vows to protect immigrant communities amid remaining uncertainty over potential deployments.

articles.title: A storied Los Angeles high school band had fallen on hard times. Then along came Mr J
articles.trailText: Inglewood’s program had been chain-sawed by financial challenges and the pandemic, but Joseph Jauregui built it back up – and his students are winning scholarships
articles.summary: Inglewood High’s marching band, once decimated by budget cuts, leadership turnover and pandemic restrictions, has been reborn under director Joseph “Mr J�� Jauregui. Hired in 2021 to rebuild a program of just eight students, he secured new instruments, uniforms and community backing to grow the ensemble to over 120 performers. Embracing a spirited HBCU-style show, the band has played NFL halftime, a Snoop Dogg event and DC’s Independence Day parade. Students like sophomore trombonist Joan Rosas report better grades, college scholarships and renewed motivation.

articles.title: Officers in California fire on truck they say tried to back into Coast Guard base
articles.trailText: Incident occurred after ICE agents arriving at Alameda base were met by hundreds of protesters
articles.summary: Late Thursday evening at Alameda Coast Guard Base in California, Coast Guard security personnel fired live rounds at a U-Haul truck that refused verbal orders and attempted to reverse into the base’s entrance. No Coast Guard personnel were hurt; two men, including the suspected driver, were treated for gunshot wounds. The FBI is leading the investigation. Earlier that day, hundreds of protesters clashed with law enforcement after CBP agents arrived, opposing a planned immigration-enforcement ‘surge’ of over 100 federal agents. President Trump later announced he would cancel the deployment following talks with local leaders.

articles.title: Democratic senators call on education department to stop ICE raids by schools
articles.trailText: Cory Booker, Ed Markey and others urge Linda McMahon to step in amid violent crackdowns near Chicago schools
articles.summary: Nine Democratic senators, including Cory Booker and Ed Markey, urged Education Secretary Linda McMahon to press DHS chief Kristi Noem to reinstate a pre-2025 policy barring ICE from conducting raids near schools. They cited violent operations in Chicago—where agents detained a 16-year-old US citizen and deployed tear gas near campuses—arguing federal immigration enforcement is endangering children’s safety. The lawmakers demand clear, common-sense buffers (at least 1,000 feet) around educational sites and called on McMahon to coordinate with DHS to curb aggressive, ‘inflammatory’ ICE tactics in and around schools.

articles.title: Surprise sanctions look to have ended Trump and Putin’s Groundhog Day | Pjotr Sauer
articles.trailText: His patience exhausted, the US president has taken action that could bite, but is unlikely to alter Moscow’s course in Ukraine
articles.summary: Breaking his usual post-call detente with Moscow, President Trump announced surprise sanctions on two of Russia’s largest oil producers and some three dozen subsidiaries after stalled talks over Ukraine between Secretary of State Rubio and Foreign Minister Lavrov led him to cancel a planned summit in Budapest. The swift measures, which caught both Kremlin and Trump advisers off guard, aim to pressure Russia’s energy revenues but are unlikely to alter Putin’s war strategy, as Moscow insists a ceasefire must address Ukraine’s full concessions on Donbas and sovereignty.

articles.title: First Thing: Trump backs down on sending federal troops to San Francisco
articles.trailText: Protesters flood streets in show of resistance. Plus, our architecture critic on Trump’s bulletproof ballroom bling
articles.summary: President Trump has scrapped a plan to deploy over 100 CBP and federal agents to the Coast Guard base in Alameda after mass protests and a plea from SF Mayor Daniel Lurie. He also halted all trade talks with Canada over an Ontario ad critical of his tariffs and imposed new US sanctions on Russian oil giants, prompting Putin to warn of economic pain. Other briefs: a Florida man pleads not guilty in the Palisades fire case, Ireland’s presidential vote, NBA players arrested in a gambling probe, expanded ANWR drilling, and Trump’s gilded bulletproof ballroom design.

articles.title: San Francisco Bay Area mobilizes amid threats of Trump immigration crackdown: ‘We’re ready’
articles.trailText: As president backs down on his federal ‘surge’, volunteers and demonstrators remain prepared to respond
articles.summary: In the San Francisco Bay Area, local leaders, volunteers and demonstrators mobilized for a feared Trump-ordered immigration enforcement surge that was called off hours before by the president after talks with tech CEOs. Community groups in Oakland’s Fruitvale and San Francisco’s Mission deployed patrols to monitor ICE and CBP activity, assist undocumented workers and schoolchildren, and share legal-rights information. Officials condemned tech billionaires like Salesforce’s Marc Benioff. Nonprofits such as Homey, Bay Resistance and the California Collaborative for Immigrant Justice coordinate rapid-response networks, transportation services and outreach to reassure residents and prepare for any federal action.

articles.title: US student handcuffed after AI system apparently mistook bag of chips for gun
articles.trailText: Baltimore county high schools have gun detection system that alerts police if it sees what it deems suspicious
articles.summary: Baltimore County’s new AI-powered gun-detection cameras at Kenwood High misidentified a student’s bag of Doritos as a firearm on Monday night, triggering a police response that left 16-year-old Taki Allen handcuffed and searched before officers confirmed there was no weapon. The school district apologized in a letter, offering counseling to students involved and highlighting concerns over AI accuracy and student safety in automated surveillance systems.

articles.title: ‘He didn’t deserve that’: widow speaks out after husband’s violent death at ICE facility
articles.trailText: Stephany Gauffeny says her husband, Miguel García-Hernández, had his ‘arms restrained to the bed and handcuffs on his feet’ as he lay dying in the hospital
articles.summary: Miguel García-Hernández, a 31-year-old undocumented migrant married to US citizen Stephany Gauffeny, was shot on Sept. 24 while shackled inside an ICE van in Dallas and died Sept. 29, five days before their third child’s birth; his arms remained restrained in the hospital. Gauffeny, caring for a newborn, an autistic daughter and two stepchildren, blames rising anti-immigration violence, has received hateful messages and faces mortgage and funeral-expense struggles supported by GoFundMe. García-Hernández had applied for Biden’s “Keeping Families Together” waiver to legalize his status, blocked by a federal judge.

articles.title: Widow of man shot at Texas ICE facility questions whether political violence is to blame
articles.trailText: Stephany Gauffeny speaks out after her husband, Miguel García-Hernández, was shot at an ICE center and later died
articles.summary: Stephany Gauffeny, widow of Miguel García-Hernández, questions whether the surge in anti-immigrant rhetoric under the Trump administration contributed to his death after a lone gunman opened fire on an ICE facility in Dallas, scrawling “ANTI-ICE” on a bullet casing. García-Hernández, 31, undocumented since age 14, was shot in a shackled detainee van and died weeks later; two other detainees were also wounded, one fatally. Three days after his death she gave birth to their son, Miles. She criticizes officials for scant information, is weighing legal action, and laments her husband’s thwarted plans to legalize his status and launch a painting business.

articles.title: Georgia election board member accepted anonymous donations linked to ‘election integrity’ movement
articles.trailText: Exclusive: funds are being raised for Janice Johnston, vice-chair of the state election board, for her defense in lawsuit over open-records laws
articles.summary: Republican Georgia SEB vice-chair Janice Johnston is accepting $29,300 in anonymous GiveSendGo donations (including $10,000) raised by GOP first vice-chair Salleigh Grubbs to fund her defense against an American Oversight Open Records Act lawsuit accusing her of withholding private-email correspondence. Grubbs, who co-authored proposed indemnification rules benefiting SEB members, has ties to the “election integrity” movement. Ethics experts warn these contributions pose blatant conflicts as SEB members handling related cases receive funds, while Georgia’s attorney general refuses to defend Johnston.

articles.title: From scapegoats to city hall: how New York Muslims built power and shaped Zohran Mamdani
articles.trailText: Muslim New Yorkers have steadily become a political force amid post-9/11 Islamophobic sentiment. Mamdani is their most accomplished expression
articles.summary: After post-9/11 Islamophobia and mass arrests, NYC Muslims (~1m population, 350k registered, 12% turnout in 2021) organized via the 2013 Muslim Democratic Club and elected trailblazers like Robert Jackson and Shahana Hanif. Their 34-year-old DSA-aligned champion Zohran Mamdani, now a state assembly member, leads the mayoral primary with broad-based small-donor support ($16.8m, avg $98) and an affordable-city platform. Muslim turnout jumped 60% this primary, marking this community’s emergence as a potent left-leaning force reshaping city politics.

articles.title: Trump says all Canada trade talks ‘terminated’ over ad criticising tariffs
articles.trailText: US president accuses Canada of ‘egregious behaviour’ after release of ad featuring Ronald Reagan criticising tariffs
articles.summary: Donald Trump announced via Truth Social the immediate termination of all trade negotiations with Canada after Ontario ran a US TV ad quoting Ronald Reagan saying “trade barriers hurt every American worker” to criticise US tariffs. Trump labelled the ad “FAKE” interference with pending Supreme Court hearings. US Secretary of State Marco Rubio confirmed the suspension. The Reagan Foundation alleges misuse of Reagan��s 1987 speech and is exploring legal action. PM Mark Carney expressed disappointment, Ottawa seeks to renegotiate USMCA, diversify exports amid tit-for-tat tariffs.

articles.title: Man charged over deadly Palisades fire pleads not guilty in Los Angeles court
articles.trailText: Jonathan Rinderknecht, 29, accused of starting devastating fire that destroyed more than 6,800 structures
articles.summary: Florida resident Jonathan Rinderknecht, 29, pleaded not guilty in Los Angeles federal court to three arson counts tied to the January Palisades fire that killed 12 and razed over 6,800 structures. Authorities say he ignited the Lachman fire after a midnight Uber shift on Jan 1, which smoldered underground before Santa Ana winds fanned it into a deadly blaze Jan 7. Prosecutors cite his 911 calls, geolocation data placing him within 30 feet of the ignition point, and ChatGPT logs with arson queries and AI-generated burn imagery. Held without bond, his trial is set for Dec 16; defense attorney Steven Haney notes Rinderknecht’s clean record, lack of mental-health history and questions why the original fire wasn’t fully suppressed by firefighters.

articles.title: Alabama executes man on death row by controversial nitrogen gas method
articles.trailText: Anthony Boyd, 54, says ‘I didn’t kill anybody’ as Justice Sonya Sotomayor writes excoriating dissenting opinion
articles.summary: Alabama executed Anthony Boyd, 54, by nitrogen hypoxia—its eighth use—despite his protests of innocence. The Supreme Court’s six conservative justices refused his stay while Sotomayor, Kagan and Jackson dissented, warning of prolonged suffocation. Previous nitrogen executions saw convulsions, tremors and extended breathing. Boyd, sentenced in 1995 for kidnapping and burning victim Gregory Huguley, argued the method violated the Eighth Amendment. A federal judge acknowledged the panic of oxygen deprivation but upheld the procedure. Alabama and Florida permit non-unanimous jury death sentences, a factor in Boyd’s 10–2 verdict.

articles.title: Trump in Asia: five key questions as US president prepares for diplomatic tour
articles.trailText: Donald Trump will travel to Malaysia, Japan and South Korea for the Apec and Asean summits. Will he meet Xi Jinping, and what tariff deals might be secured?
articles.summary: Trump begins his tour at the ASEAN summit in Malaysia, eyeing mediation in the Thailand–Cambodia border clash, before meeting Japan’s new PM Sanae Takaichi. In South Korea’s Apec forum he’s set to meet Xi Jinping to discuss rolling back 100% tariffs, Chinese soya imports, fentanyl controls, rare-earth exports and Taiwan, as extra duties loom. He’ll push for reciprocal tariff relief with Vietnam and Thailand, seek a $350bn South Korean investment deal after an ICE raid, but a fresh Kim summit seems unlikely.

articles.title: Trump backs down on sending federal troops to San Francisco for immigration crackdown
articles.trailText: Protesters flood streets in show of resistance, as president calls off deployment after speaking with city’s mayor and Silicon Valley leaders
articles.summary: President Trump canceled plans to send 100+ CBP and other federal agents to the Alameda Coast Guard base for an immigration enforcement "surge" in San Francisco after a call with Mayor Daniel Lurie and Silicon Valley CEOs. The deployment had ignited mass protests, condemnation from Gov. Gavin Newsom and clashes near the base with flash-bang grenades. Lurie and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem confirmed the call-off, but it's unclear if other Bay Area cities like Oakland remain targeted. Local leaders say they will continue to mobilize legal aid, rapid-response networks and demonstrations amid ongoing uncertainty over federal actions.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Trump scraps plan to send federal troops to San Francisco Bay Area
articles.trailText: President says San Francisco mayor and Silicon Valley leaders asked him to give the city ��a chance’ – key US politics stories from Thursday 23 October at a glance
articles.summary: Donald Trump scrapped plans to deploy over 100 federal agents from Customs and Border Protection to the San Francisco Bay Area’s Alameda Coast Guard base for immigration enforcement after discussions with SF Mayor Daniel Lurie and Silicon Valley CEOs Marc Benioff and Jensen Huang. Other developments: major tech and defense firms are funding Trump’s $300m White House ballroom; a new book details infighting over ‘unqualified’ cabinet picks; House Democrats accuse him of a $230m taxpayer scheme; Trump pardons Binance’s founder; voters blame tariffs for rising costs; Colombia denounces US strikes; the Senate stalls pay for federal workers; and a lawsuit accuses Melania Trump’s meme coin architects of fraud as NBA stars face gambling probes.

articles.title: White House approves increased oil and gas drilling in Alaska’s national wildlife refuge
articles.trailText: National Petroleum Reserve lease sales and permitting for road through Izembek wildlife refuge were also approved
articles.summary: Trump administration reopens 1.56 m acres of ANWR coastal plain for oil and gas drilling, reverses Biden’s 2024 protections, and schedules National Petroleum Reserve-Alaska lease sale—the first since 2019. Permits reissued for the 211-mile Ambler Road through Izembek refuge threaten 200 k migratory birds and subsistence use by 37 tribes and 39 villages. Proponents cite access to a $7 bn copper deposit and other minerals; Interior Sec. Doug Burgum hails energy independence and jobs. Conservationists from Alaska Wilderness League, Earthjustice and Sierra Club warn of irreversible ecological and cultural damage.

articles.title: Trump says tech chiefs convinced him to call off troop ‘surge’ to San Francisco
articles.trailText: President specifically lauds Nvidia and Salesforce CEOs and says they told him ‘the future of San Francisco is great’
articles.summary: President Trump said he will call off a planned federal troop “surge” in San Francisco after pressure from Silicon Valley executives, notably Nvidia’s Jensen Huang and Salesforce’s Marc Benioff, who assured him “the future of San Francisco is great.” Trump had announced sending more than 100 federal agents for immigration and crime enforcement after Benioff’s initial endorsement sparked backlash and retraction. Critics warn this episode underscores the outsized influence of unaccountable tech CEOs over national policy, sidelining public input.

articles.title: US court rejects Trump officials’ effort to delay rulings on veterans benefits
articles.trailText: Unanimous ruling calls administration’s push to halt reviews of veterans’ disability appeals an “extreme request”
articles.summary: A Veterans Claims Court panel unanimously rejected VA Secretary Doug Collins’ bid to pause decisions on nearly all disability appeals during the government shutdown. In a 9-0 ruling led by Trump appointee Chief Judge Michael Allen, judges deemed the request “extreme” and unjustified. Veterans groups warned the move would indefinitely delay claims—some pending for decades over Agent Orange and burn-pit exposure. The court, which handles about 15,000 cases annually with a 222-day median resolution, will proceed with its reviews.

articles.title: Trump plans land strikes against alleged drug traffickers from Venezuela
articles.trailText: President says he ‘may go to the Congress and tell them … but I can’t imagine they’d have any problem with it’
articles.summary: Donald Trump said his administration may soon launch land-based strikes against alleged Venezuelan drug traffickers. Trump said “The land is going to be next” and is confident Congress would not object, potentially seeking formal approval after nine maritime attacks that killed at least 37 people. He and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth classify cartels as terrorists. Trump denied deploying B-1 bombers near Venezuela amid speculation anti-narcotics missions mask efforts to oust President Nicolás Maduro. Critics, including Democrat Sen. Mark Kelly, warn that bombing and talk of regime change risk American lives and mirror past failed interventions.

articles.title: US Senate fails to pass bill to pay federal essential workers and troops through shutdown
articles.trailText: ‘Shutdown fairness act’, introduced by Ron Johnson, Republican senator from Wisconsin, failed in a 54-45 vote
articles.summary: On day 23 of the US government shutdown, the Senate failed 54-45 to advance Sen. Ron Johnson’s “Shutdown Fairness Act,” which would guarantee pay for essential federal workers and troops during funding gaps. Democrats led by Schumer opposed it as a tool for Trump, though three Democrats—Fetterman, Ossoff and Warnock—voted yes. The shutdown has furloughed 700,000 workers and forced hundreds of thousands to work unpaid. Trump authorized the Defense Department to use R&D funds for troop pay. Democratic counter-bills from Peters and Van Hollen never reached a vote.

articles.title: Eric Adams to endorse Andrew Cuomo in New York City mayoral race
articles.trailText: Adams revealed decision in a New York Times interview a month after calling Cuomo a ‘snake and a liar’
articles.summary: NYC Mayor Eric Adams will endorse former Governor Andrew Cuomo in the upcoming mayoral race, reversing his previous criticism that labelled Cuomo a “snake and a liar.” Adams, who ended his own campaign after lagging in polls and saw corruption charges dropped, told the New York Times he’ll campaign alongside Cuomo in Black and Brown neighborhoods to address gentrification-driven rent hikes. His move counters democratic socialist Zohran Mamdani’s rise, was confirmed courtside at a Knicks opener, and has been rejected by both Mamdani and GOP candidate Curtis Sliwa.

articles.title: Illinois warns immigration officers tampering with license plates is illegal
articles.trailText: Hotline introduced to report on agents’ vehicles after one said plates were changed every day in video
articles.summary: Illinois officials launched a “Plate Watch” hotline after a viral video showed an ICE officer claiming to change Illinois plates daily. Secretary of State Alexi Giannoulias warned that swapping or altering license plates on Illinois-registered vehicles violates state law, carrying fines, jail time and plate suspension or revocation. The measure underscores no one is above the law. Illinois requires front and rear plates; out-of-state vehicles must display proper state licensing. The move follows calls for body cameras on ICE in Chicago and broader legislation and state bans to ensure agents visibly identify themselves.

articles.title: Top House Democrats accuse Trump of illegal scheme to pilfer $230m in taxpayer money
articles.trailText: Lawmakers say Trump as president would decide whether Trump as claimant be paid for investigations into Trump as defendant
articles.summary: Top House Democrats Jamie Raskin and Robert Garcia say President Trump is pursuing an illegal, secretive $230 million payout from taxpayers via a confidential DoJ administrative restitution process tied to investigations into him. In a Thursday letter they demand he abandon what they call an unconstitutional plan that could evade disclosure until year-end. Democracy Forward has filed a records request for related DoJ documents. Trump has insisted he alone decides if the government “owes him a lot” for probes like the Mar-a-Lago search. A DOJ spokesperson says all officials follow career ethics guidance.

articles.title: Most voters in swing House districts fault Trump trade moves for high prices
articles.trailText: New survey by Democrats also finds many are unhappy with signature Republican tax bill and healthcare cuts
articles.summary: An Oct. 2–6 DCCC poll of 1,000 likely voters in 61 swing House districts finds 61% blame Trump’s tariffs—averaging 58% on Chinese imports—for driving up consumer prices, and 52% oppose the GOP’s One Big Beautiful Bill Act (implementing his tax package, funding immigration enforcement and shrinking Medicaid). Though Trump won these seats by 4 points in 2024, Democrats lead the generic midterm ballot 47%–43%. After the recent shutdown, 43% fault Trump and Republicans. Rising costs and healthcare cuts boost voter discontent ahead of 2026.

articles.title: DC man who played Darth Vader theme at national guard troops sues over arrest
articles.trailText: Sam O’Hara was arrested after a guard member allegedly complained about his blasting Star Wars song at troops
articles.summary: Sam O’Hara, a DC resident, has filed a federal lawsuit alleging First and Fourth Amendment violations after being handcuffed for playing Star Wars’ ‘Imperial March’ while trailing Ohio National Guard troops in an anti-Trump deployment protest. Represented by the ACLU, O’Hara names four officers, one guard member and the District of Columbia, accusing them of false arrest, false imprisonment and battery under DC law. He seeks a ruling that his peaceful, TikTok-documented protest was protected speech and compensatory damages. His suit echoes recent humor-driven protests, from inflatable frog marches to a giraffe-suited comedian suing ICE.

articles.title: Top US prosecutor’s use of text message auto-delete could be illegal, watchdog groups warn
articles.trailText: Lindsey Halligan, who brought cases against James Comey and Letitia James, allegedly violated records-retention laws
articles.summary: Interim US Attorney Lindsey Halligan used Signal with an eight-hour auto-delete setting when discussing her criminal case against New York AG Letitia James with Lawfare reporter Anna Bower—actions watchdogs say may breach the Federal Records Act and DOJ retention policies. American Oversight has filed a FOIA request for her messages, and CREW urged a DOJ Inspector General probe. Federal law requires preserving official communications. Halligan, a Trump appointee who also indicted former FBI Director James Comey, faces allegations of record-destruction amid broader politicization concerns at the DOJ.

articles.title: Melania Trump’s meme coin architects accused of pump-and-dump fraud in lawsuit
articles.trailText: First lady not named in suit in which investors allege Meteora platform created crypto they knew would plummet
articles.summary: Investors filed suit in Manhattan federal court accusing Meteora exchange executives of orchestrating a pump-and-dump of the $MELANIA meme coin launched Jan. 19 alongside $TRUMP. Plaintiffs allege insiders inflated $MELANIA’s price from cents to $13.73 before dumping shares, crashing it back to about $0.10. $TRUMP peaked at $45.47 and now trades near $5.79. Melania Trump isn’t named as culpable; her brand was allegedly used as window dressing. These claims augment ongoing crypto lawsuits as the Trump family reportedly earned over $1bn in crypto profits last year.

articles.title: Marine heatwave over Pacific Ocean could lead to flooding in north-west
articles.trailText: Severe ‘blob’ or marine heatwave can lead to increased inundation and wintery weather in eastern North America
articles.summary: Scientists warn a ‘blob’ marine heatwave in the north-west/central Pacific—August temperatures 2.5 °C above preindustrial—could heighten flood risk in the US Pacific north-west, fuel storms and influence eastern North American winter weather, while driving harmful algal blooms and marine species migrations. Coined by UW climatologist Nick Bond, such ocean heat anomalies have grown more frequent and severe over the past decade (2014–16 event reached +3 °C, halting shellfish fisheries). Though linked in media to a snowy Chicago, experts say its inland impact is secondary amid other climate drivers and limited historical data.

articles.title: New book details infighting behind Trump’s ‘obviously unqualified’ cabinet picks
articles.trailText: Retribution, by Jonathan Karl, describes backroom squabbling over Kristi Noem and Sean Duffy appointments
articles.summary: Jonathan Karl’s Retribution reveals Trump’s chaotic cabinet selections, spotlighting his pick of South Dakota Gov. Kristi Noem as homeland security secretary at campaign manager Corey Lewandowski’s request despite no vetting or relevant experience—spark­ing alarm from allies like Steve Bannon and later criticism over spending, immigration overreach and so-called “authoritarian cosplay.” The book also details ex-Rep. Sean Duffy’s appointment as transportation secretary (and acting NASA admin) despite no policy background, as Trump rebuffed rivals, spurned Emil Michael and overlooked a decade-old slight unearthed by Howard Lutnick’s sabotage attempt.

articles.title: Four members of Illinois politician’s family killed in helicopter crash
articles.trailText: Darren Bailey’s son, daughter-in-law and two grandchildren all killed in accident in Montana
articles.summary: Darren Bailey, a former Illinois state senator and 2026 gubernatorial candidate, is grieving the deaths of his son, Zachary, daughter-in-law Kelsey and grandchildren Vada Rose (12) and Samuel (7), who died in a helicopter crash in Montana. Their 10-year-old son Finn survived. A campaign statement on X Thursday said Darren and Cindy are heartbroken, leaning on faith and family. Authorities have yet to release crash location, helicopter type or cause. Bailey, who lost to Democrat JB Pritzker in 2022, is mounting a second bid on a conservative platform.

articles.title: Donors for Trump’s $300m White House ballroom include Google, Apple and Palantir
articles.trailText: Work under way to demolish entire East Wing as president upped cost of new structure from $200m to $300m
articles.summary: Tech giants Apple, Amazon, Meta, Microsoft and Google; defense contractors Booz Allen Hamilton, Lockheed Martin and Palantir; and donors Miriam Adelson, Stephen Schwarzman, Harold Hamm, the Winklevoss twins and Howard Lutnick are financing former President Trump’s 90,000 sq ft White House ballroom, cost now $300 million vs $200 million initially. East Wing demolition began without public notice or review, bypassing the shutdown National Capital Planning Commission. Trump insists it’s “100%” donor-funded, hosting select contributors at a White House dinner. House Democrats and preservation groups decry the secretive process and legal review lapses; the administration promises post-demolition plan filings and cites digital archival efforts by the Historical Association.

articles.title: Revealed: police across US spread false rumors about Venezuelan gang threats
articles.trailText: Claim that Tren de Aragua planned to attack officers was widely shared – only for FBI to later acknowledge it was mistaken, internal files show
articles.summary: An unverified rumor that Venezuela’s Tren de Aragua gang ordered members to attack US police spread rapidly after a July 2024 Albuquerque police bulletin. Shared by CBP, DHS, the Texas governor, GOP lawmakers and conservative media, it bolstered hard-line immigration and border security stances. Internal FBI files months later labeled the threat inaccurate and primarily defensive. Experts say TdA has no clear US hierarchy. The episode spurred deportations, lethal strikes on suspect vessels and illustrates how thinly sourced intelligence can drive policy and fear.

articles.title: First Thing: US imposes sanctions on Russian oil over Putin’s ‘refusal’ to end war in Ukraine
articles.trailText: The Trump administration hardens its stance against the Kremlin. Plus, the final New York City mayoral debate gets heated
articles.summary: The US imposed sanctions on Rosneft and Lukoil—Russia’s two largest oil firms—to penalize Putin’s refusal to end the Ukraine war. As the first Russian energy sanctions under Trump since January, they target oil tax revenues that supply about a quarter of Moscow’s budget, aiming to strangle financing for the Kremlin’s war machine and force an immediate ceasefire. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said “now is the time to stop the killing.” Nonetheless, analysts at the Council on Foreign Relations warn the Kremlin has been adept at evading such restrictions.

articles.title: Trump’s ballroom blitz sparks chorus of disgust: ‘The perfect symbol’
articles.trailText: Obama once joked about what a gaudy Trump White House would look like – the president seems bent on proving him right
articles.summary: Donald Trump has demolished the White House’s East Wing façade to build a $250 million, 90,000 sq ft gilded ballroom—echoing Mar-a-Lago decor and funded by undisclosed private donations—to host up to 999 guests. Critics from White House alumni and historians denounce the wrecking crew’s rubble as “the perfect symbol” of his second term’s norm-busting excess, echoing Obama’s 2011 satire of a casino-style presidency. Trump proceeded without National Capital Planning Commission approval, while the National Trust warns the ballroom will overwhelm the 55,000 sq ft residence.

articles.title: US military kills five people in strikes on alleged drug-trafficking boats in Pacific
articles.trailText: Latest strikes were off coast of Colombia, while seven previous attacks in Caribbean killed at least 32
