articles.summary: Founded in 2022 by Desmond Carter in Leimert Park, LA, Mental Health Is Real Wealth convenes bi-monthly gatherings of 15 Black men aged 19 to 60+ to foster vulnerability, mutual support and cultural understanding. Sparked by Carter’s best friend’s suicide, the group counters a CDC-reported 25.3% rise in Black male suicides and the third leading cause of death among young Black males. Psychologist Lance Lenford links pandemic-driven isolation, identity crises and fatherhood pressures; the American Psychological Association cites systemic racism, economic and healthcare disparities. Facilitators Wayne Bennett and Carter break generational trauma, destigmatize therapy and build culturally competent safe spaces.

articles.title: Vermont Republican lawmaker resigns over racist and antisemitic group chat
articles.trailText: State senator Samuel Douglass, 26, and wife, Brianna, both made comments in Young Republicans Telegram group
articles.summary: Vermont state senator Sam Douglass, 26, resigned after racist, antisemitic and homophobic remarks in a leaked Young Republicans Telegram chat that also included his wife, Brianna. The comments, ranging from mocking an “obese Indian woman” to calling someone a “fat stinky Jew,” prompted Governor Phil Scott and Senate Minority Leader Scott Beck to demand his ouster and led to the New York Young Republicans’ charter revocation. Douglass apologized, effective Oct. 20, citing family safety, outreach to Jewish and BIPOC friends, and GOP infighting. Ohio Senator JD Vance labeled the exchanges “offensive jokes.”

articles.title: Disgraced former congressman George Santos released from prison in New Jersey
articles.trailText: Trump commuted Santos’s seven-year sentence for fraud and identity theft after he had served less than three months
articles.summary: Disgraced ex-Congressman George Santos was released from a New Jersey federal prison on Oct. 18 after President Trump commuted his seven-year sentence for wire fraud and aggravated identity theft, served under three months. Santos’s lawyer credited appeals from Trump plus GOP allies—Marjorie Taylor Greene, Lauren Boebert, Anna Paulina Luna, Matt Gaetz—and Justice Dept. officials. Convicted in August 2024, Santos had pleaded for clemency, citing harsh prison conditions. His release reignites debate over presidential pardon powers amid protests against perceived authoritarianism. Critics from both parties decry corruption; Democrats Hakeem Jeffries and Robert Zimmerman slammed the commutation; GOP’s Adam Kinzinger called it “corruption.”

articles.title: US tells airlines to disregard ‘X’ sex markers on passports and input ‘M’ or ‘F’
articles.trailText: Customs and Border Protection implemented rule this week, sending Americans with ‘X’ marker into panic
articles.summary: US Customs and Border Protection this week instructed airlines to override ‘X’ gender markers on US passports, requiring agents to register travelers as ‘M’ or ‘F’, triggering panic among nonbinary citizens. Although courts have upheld the 2022 ‘X’ option’s validity after Trump’s attempted ban, CBP, TSA and DHS have provided no clarity on implementation, raising fears of boarding denials and invasive body scans. Affected travelers like scientist July Pilowsky report increased scrutiny; advocates from Lambda Legal and the Chosen Family Law Center warn the opaque policy may hamper queer and trans mobility and spur further legal challenges.

articles.title: Why do so many gen Z women across the US identify as ‘leftist’?
articles.trailText: Generation Z women represent the most leftwing demographic in modern US history: ‘There’s definitely a gender divide’
articles.summary: Gen Z women have emerged as the most leftwing cohort in US history, rejecting “liberal” or Democratic labels as too centrist and beholden to billionaire influence. Shaped by climate crisis, debt, job insecurity and threats to reproductive and trans rights, they view politics as self-defense rather than negotiation. Polls show a stark gender gap: only 26% of Gen Z women approve of Trump versus 47% of men. Social media algorithms and culture-war distractions fuel right-leaning attitudes among young men, while women prioritize economic inequality, healthcare, and authoritarianism, seeing both parties as a closed, corporate-funded duopoly.

articles.title: US Senate poised to approve industry lobbyist to lead chemical safety at EPA
articles.trailText: If Douglas Troutman is confirmed, the top four toxics office at the environmental agency will be held by ex-lobbyists
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s nominee to head EPA’s Office of Chemical Safety and Pollution Prevention, Douglas Troutman, a former chief lobbyist for the American Cleaning Institute and current EPA adviser, faces Senate confirmation. If approved, the top four toxics posts will be held by ex-industry lobbyists. Environmental groups warn Troutman’s record—pushing loopholes in the 2016 TSCA rewrite, seeking to repeal California’s Cleaning Product Right to Know Act, and aligning with industry on PFAS and asbestos deregulation—signals a rollback of chemical safeguards. Alongside Nancy Beck, Lynn Ann Dekleva, and Kyle Kunkler, all with trade group backgrounds, Troutman’s confirmation heightens reliance on state laws to protect public health.

articles.title: Biggest US labor unions fuel No Kings protests against Trump: ‘You need a voice to have freedom’
articles.trailText: With more than 2,700 events planned across the US, one organizer, James Phipps, 75, says: ‘Protest is all I’ve done all my life’
articles.summary: On October 18, more than 2,700 No Kings events, anchored by SEIU and AFT, will protest Trump’s Medicaid cuts, expiring health insurance subsidies and ICE raids. Organizer James Phipps, 75, a civil-rights veteran and cancer survivor, links today’s immigrant raids to Jim Crow oppression and stresses health care access. AFT head Randi Weingarten argues union power in workplaces and democracy grants freedom, while SEIU VP Jaime Contreras condemns shutdowns protecting billionaires and equates questioning Trump with patriotism.

articles.title: US podcaster who helped convict ‘Queen of the Con’ disappointed at short sentence
articles.trailText: Johnathan Walton, who was a victim of Marianne ‘Mair’ Smyth, had helped UK authorities track her down
articles.summary: US podcaster Johnathan Walton, a former victim of con artist Marianne ‘Mair’ Smyth, criticized her four-year sentence after UK authorities convicted her of defrauding Northern Irish mortgage clients of over $155,000. Walton’s investigative podcast and book exposed Smyth’s history—from impersonating Jennifer Aniston to founding a fake church and bilking investors—which led to tips on her Maine location. Trial testimony cited £72,570 lost by one buyer and £43,000 from other victims. Despite prior pleas in California and transatlantic pursuit, Walton says the light sentence underestimates Smyth’s danger.

articles.title: Trump says he has commuted sentence of George Santos in federal fraud case
articles.trailText: Former Republican US representative walks free after being sentenced in April to more than seven years in prison for deceiving donors and stealing identities of 11 people
articles.summary: Donald Trump commuted the 87-month sentence of ex-Rep. George Santos, convicted last year of wire fraud and aggravated identity theft, leading to Santos’ immediate release from FCI Fairton. Santos, whose short-lived career was marred by fabrications and misuse of campaign funds, had pleaded guilty and been expelled from Congress. Trump, moved by a Long Island newspaper letter and urged by GOP allies like Marjorie Taylor Greene, announced the clemency on Truth Social. The move, part of Trump’s broader pattern of granting pardons to loyalists while prosecuting critics, reignites debate over political influence in presidential clemency.

articles.title: At least 15 detained after protesters and police clash outside Chicago Ice center
articles.trailText: Officers reportedly tackled and dragged several people after authorities told demonstrators to stay in ‘protest zones’
articles.summary: At least 15 protesters aged 23–44 were arrested Friday outside the Broadview ICE detention center in suburban Chicago after Illinois state police cleared a roadway, tackling and dragging demonstrators who advanced on the facility around 8 a.m. Despite directives to stay in designated ‘free speech zones’ and a 6 p.m. curfew, activists—including congressional candidate Kat Abughazaleh—clashed with officers in helmets and batons amid chants of “Who do you protect?” Charges range from resisting to obstruction. The clash, part of recurring protests met with teargas and less-lethal rounds, follows a federal court order requiring ICE agents to wear body cameras.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Trump cools on Tomahawk deal for Ukraine and commutes Santos sentence
articles.trailText: US president said ‘we need Tomahawks and a lot of other things’ as he meets Zelenskyy; fraud sentence of disgraced serial fabulist Santos commuted – key US politics stories from Friday 17 October at a glance
articles.summary: At a White House meeting with Zelenskyy, Trump downplayed Ukraine’s request for Tomahawk cruise missiles—citing US future needs and echoing Putin’s warning they’d harm US-Russia ties—and floated a possible summit in Hungary. He also commuted ex-Rep. George Santos’s 7-year fraud sentence. Other Friday highlights: ex-adviser John Bolton pleaded not guilty to mishandling classified files; leaked Fox News filings reveal staff feared the network was aiding Trump; New York Young Republicans chapter was suspended over racist chats; Trump claimed Maduro offered major concessions; GOP released a deepfake Schumer ad; DOJ asked SCOTUS to allow National Guard deployment in Illinois.

articles.title: Trump officials ask supreme court to permit national guard in Illinois
articles.trailText: Justice department submits emergency filing as Trump pushes to expand use of military in Democratic-led cities
articles.summary: The Trump administration filed an emergency request with the US Supreme Court to lift a lower court injunction blocking deployment of several hundred National Guard troops to Illinois, citing repeated threats and assaults on federal agents in Chicago and at the Broadview ICE facility. DOJ solicitor general John Sauer argues troops are needed to protect federal property. Meanwhile, Judge Sara Ellis ordered ICE officers to use body cameras and wear visible IDs, and Chicago and Illinois have sued, winning a temporary block from a Biden-appointed judge amid local protests and legal pushback.

articles.title: Breathtaking, unsettling, healing: how US artist Kara Walker transformed a Confederate monument
articles.trailText: The sweeping exhibition Monuments, which features 19 contemporary artists, opens in LA on 23 October
articles.summary: Monuments, a sweeping exhibition opening 23 October in Los Angeles, assembles 19 contemporary artists alongside decommissioned Confederate statues to confront US white supremacy. At its heart, Kara Walker’s Unmanned Drone reconfigures Charlottesville’s removed Stonewall Jackson equestrian statue—chopped, distorted and reassembled into a flailing hybrid symbolizing the horror of racist iconography. Most works appear at MOCA, with Walker’s piece in The Brick. Spanning pristine and vandalized relics, photo, film and sculpture by Black artists, Monuments reframes these objects as catalysts for reckoning and healing.

articles.title: Los Angeles agrees to pay $828m to settle more sexual abuse claims
articles.trailText: Deal comes after county in April agreed to pay $4bn to settle historical claims – largest such settlement in US history
articles.summary: Los Angeles County has tentatively agreed to pay $828m to settle over 400 new sexual-abuse claims against juvenile-facility employees, pending board approval, adding to an April-approved $4bn deal for 11,000 claimants dating back to 1959. With 2,500 unresolved cases and more expected, officials say each claim’s credibility will be reviewed and fraudulent filings denied amid probes that some plaintiffs were paid to sue. Awards will vary by abuse severity. The DTLA law firm faces extra scrutiny and possible state bar referrals. New safeguards, including a child-abuse hotline, are slated to launch by year’s end as officials warn runaway payouts jeopardize county services and advocate statute-of-limitations reform.

articles.title: Billionaire Marc Benioff apologizes for saying troops should be deployed to San Francisco
articles.trailText: Salesforce CEO faced intensifying backlash after saying national guard will make California city safer
articles.summary: Salesforce CEO and Time owner Marc Benioff retracted his support for deploying National Guard troops to San Francisco, apologizing after intense local backlash. He said his initial pro-Trump comments—in response to safety fears around Dreamforce—stemmed from “an abundance of caution” but, after consulting city officials and residents, concluded federal intervention isn’t needed. His remarks, which contradicted longstanding legal limits on domestic troop use and departed from his previous liberal advocacy on wealth inequality and homelessness, drew criticism as California leaders touted falling crime rates and rejected federal involvement.

articles.title: Epstein trial would have been ‘crapshoot’, plea-deal prosecutor tells Congress
articles.trailText: Ex-Trump labor secretary Alex Acosta, in September testimony to lawmakers, defends not taking case to trial
articles.summary: Former federal prosecutor Alex Acosta told the House oversight committee that prosecuting Jeffrey Epstein in 2008 was a “crapshoot�� due to uncooperative, inconsistent victim testimony and evidentiary hurdles. To guarantee prison time, Acosta negotiated a non-prosecution agreement requiring Epstein’s registration as a sex offender and a 13-month sentence, later marred by his work-release. He defended turning the case to Florida state authorities, cited victims’ MySpace histories and prior records as cross-examination risks, and denied any role by Donald Trump. The transcript’s release coincides with scrutiny of Florida AG Pam Bondi’s withheld files, Rep. Garcia’s subpoenas and unanswered questions over Epstein’s accountability.

articles.title: Key US nuclear agency to send 80% of workforce home as shutdown drags on
articles.trailText: About 1,400 staff at NNSA, which manages America’s nuclear weapons stockpile, to be furloughed on Monday
articles.summary: NNSA will furlough 80% (1,400) of its staff from Monday after exhausting carryover funds amid the 17-day shutdown, the longest full funding lapse in US history. Only 375 “essential” employees will perform critical safety operations: monitoring nuclear materials, maintaining warhead systems, securing naval reactor safety and continuing non-proliferation work. The Office of Secure Transportation stays funded through Oct 27. House Armed Services Chair Mike Rogers and Energy Secretary Chris Wright warn that paused research, stockpile maintenance and global security programs threaten national deterrence, a standoff Speaker Mike Johnson blames on Senate Democrats.

articles.title: Alaska governor asks Trump for federal aid after typhoon displaces 1,500 people
articles.trailText: Lawmakers urge president to allow for repair of housing and utilities after Typhoon Halong devastates villages
articles.summary: Alaska Gov. Mike Dunleavy has requested a major disaster declaration from President Trump after Typhoon Halong displaced 1,500 people in southwest villages, prompting air evacuations to Anchorage. Senators Murkowski and Sullivan and Rep. Begich back the appeal for federal resources to repair housing, utilities and infrastructure before winter. The storm’s record surge destroyed dozens of homes in Kipnuk and Kwigillingok, left remote communities uninhabitable, killed one, left two missing and underscored cuts to tribal resilience grants.

articles.title: Republicans use deepfake video of Chuck Schumer in new attack ad
articles.trailText: It is not the party’s first foray into the dystopian territory, with Trump having posted AI videos of his own
articles.summary: On Oct. 17, the National Republican Senatorial Committee released an AI-generated deepfake of Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer roboticly repeating his real quote “every day gets better for us” about the government shutdown, complete with a tiny “AI” disclaimer. Led by Sen. Tim Scott’s NRSC, the ad accuses Democrats of treating Americans’ livelihoods like a game and “loving” the standoff. NRSC communications director Joanna Rodriguez defended the use of AI, marking a new escalation after Trump’s Truth Social deepfakes and the 2023 RNC’s apocalyptic Biden AI ad.

articles.title: Man who fought for Hamas in October 7 attack fled to US and lived in Louisiana, FBI alleges
articles.trailText: According to complaint, Mahmoud Amin Ya’qub al-Muhtadi participated in attack on Israel, then applied for US visa
articles.summary: FBI alleges Louisiana resident Mahmoud Amin Ya’qub al-Muhtadi fought alongside a Gaza-based Hamas-aligned paramilitary cell on Oct. 7, 2023, crossing into southern Israel during the attack that killed nearly 1,200 people and spurred mass kidnappings. He denied terrorist involvement on his US visa application and fraudulently entered the US in September 2024, first settling in Tulsa then Lafayette. Identified by Joint Task Force October 7 and the FBI, his unsealed complaint charges him with visa fraud and conspiracy to support a foreign terrorist organization. He was arrested after coordinated cooperation from seven Israeli security agencies.

articles.title: US has seized survivors of attack on alleged narco-sub in Caribbean
articles.trailText: In the six attacks on similar vessels launched by Trump, this is the first where any survivors have been reported
articles.summary: US forces have captured survivors from a strike on a suspected drug-smuggling semi-submersible in Caribbean waters off Venezuela, marking the first survivors among six strikes since early September under President Trump. Trump publicly described the target as a “narco-sub” ferrying large cocaine loads. The attacks, invoking post-9/11 legal authority, have killed at least 28 crew. Human Rights Watch calls the operations extrajudicial, violating international law. Detainees now face unclear status—prisoners of war or criminal suspects. Criticism grows on Capitol Hill over lack of oversight amid a US military buildup and covert actions in Venezuela.

articles.title: Faculty at Texas university fear entire liberal arts departments will be slashed
articles.trailText: University of Texas at Austin faculty fear changes from new taskforce that could restructure humanities programs
articles.summary: At UT Austin, faculty fear a secret committee studying liberal-arts restructuring—targeting African/African diaspora, Mexican American/Latina/o, and women’s and gender studies—may lead to department cuts. A parallel 18-member core-curriculum taskforce, lacking representation from these fields, and a new state law dissolving faculty senates have concentrated power in administrators. Provost William Inboden’s National Affairs essay decries “identity-studies,” conservative reports accuse these disciplines of “grade inflation,” and students have begun protesting.

articles.title: Ex-Trump adviser John Bolton pleads not guilty to sharing classified information
articles.trailText: Ex-national security adviser surrendered to authorities and made court appearance as he faces 18-count indictment
articles.summary: Former National Security Adviser John Bolton pleaded not guilty to an 18-count indictment accusing him of mishandling classified information via personal email, storing top secret documents at home, and sharing diary-style notes with relatives lacking security clearances. Career prosecutors in Maryland say his notes were hacked by Iran and willfully aggregated, triggering Espionage Act charges after a Biden DOJ reopening of the probe. Bolton’s team decries political retaliation.

articles.title: No Kings: what to know about the anti-Trump protests attracting millions
articles.trailText: More than 2,700 US rallies are planned in all 50 states as protesters call for limits on presidential power
articles.summary: Millions are expected to join over 2,700 “No Kings” rallies across all 50 US states on October 18, staged by a coalition of 200+ left-leaning groups (Indivisible, ACLU, SEIU, AFL-CIO, HRC, MoveOn, etc.) protesting Trump’s “authoritarian” overreach—federal forces in cities, deportations, gerrymandering and third-term ambitions. Echoing June’s demonstrations, participants will wear yellow to signal unity and pro-democracy solidarity with Ukraine and Hong Kong. Organizers aim for the largest single-day protest in US history, invoking the “3.5% rule” that sustained nonviolent resistance can topple regimes. Safety plans include marshals and “know-your-rights” materials amid concerns over harassment or militarized crackdowns.

articles.title: California Democrat to run for congressional seat held by Nancy Pelosi
articles.trailText: Scott Wiener, the California state senator, will reportedly announce his candidacy in the coming weeks
articles.summary: Scott Wiener, 55, a Harvard-educated California state senator and current Senate Budget Committee chair, is set to run for Nancy Pelosi’s San Francisco congressional seat once she retires. Wiener, who has raised $1 million via an exploratory committee, is known for spearheading housing density, LGBTQ+ rights, tech regulation and climate action in Sacramento. Pelosi, 85, hasn’t confirmed a bid for a 21st term, focusing instead on Prop 50 to redraw districts. Progressive Saikat Chakrabarti, 39, former AOC chief of staff, has already launched his campaign, reflecting wider calls among young Democrats for generational change.

articles.title: Young Republicans New York chapter suspended after racist chats leaked
articles.trailText: Group suspended following unanimous vote after Politico documented racist and antisemitic chats from members
articles.summary: After Politico’s Tuesday report on 2,900 pages of leaked racist and antisemitic Telegram chats, the New York Republican State Committee unanimously suspended authorization of its Young Republicans chapter. Chats by members, including current chair Bobby Walker and ex-chair Peter Giunta, featured racial slurs, admiration for Hitler and jokes about rape and gas chambers. The scandal prompted the Kansas chapter’s disbandment, resignations, firings and removal from campaigns. High-profile Republicans and conservative influencers publicly condemned the extremist content, warning it threatened the GOP’s broader reputation. NY GOP chair Ed Cox signaled possible future reorganization under new leadership during a forthcoming virtual committee meeting.

articles.title: Mahmoud Khalil can freely travel within US, federal judge rules
articles.trailText: Palestinian activist can speak across country at events while pushing back on Trump’s attempts to deport him
articles.summary: Federal magistrate judge Michael Hammer has lifted travel restrictions on Mahmoud Khalil, a Palestinian activist and US permanent resident facing Trump administration deportation efforts, allowing him to travel nationwide beyond New York, New Jersey, DC, Louisiana and Michigan. Khalil, detained by ICE on March 8 after pro-Palestinian protests at Columbia University, argued via counsel Alina Das that First Amendment interests require in-person participation at rallies and events to speak on public issues. The government opposed, citing telephonic attendance and security and misrepresentation concerns. Hammer found no flight risk or release violations, but ordered Khalil to notify ICE of travel plans while litigation continues.

articles.title: Mississippi residents sue UK-owned biomass firm granted permit for more emissions
articles.trailText: Nearby residents say they have had health concerns due to air pollution from Drax Biomass facility
articles.summary: Residents of Gloster, MS, a predominantly Black low-income town, sued Drax Biomass after the Mississippi environmental permit board reversed an April denial and granted the UK-owned wood pellet plant a major source emissions permit. Plaintiffs allege years of hazardous air pollution—dust, volatile organic compounds and other chemicals—have caused headaches, respiratory illness and raised cancer risks. Drax, facing past fines for excessive emissions and inaccurate biomass sourcing data, supplies pellets to its North Yorkshire power station under UK renewables subsidies. The lawsuit and advocacy from 85 organizations demand accountability and cleaner air, while Drax asserts it will support community well-being.

articles.title: In Alaska, where overdose deaths are rising again, Narcan and community are a lifeline
articles.trailText: Overdoses have been declining nationally since August 2023, but Alaska is far behind in that progress
articles.summary: Amid resurging overdose fatalities in Alaska—where rates peaked at 68/100k in Anchorage and 51/100k in Mat-Su—community networks and widespread Narcan access are frontline defences. In rural Mat-Su borough, Shane Shelton’s “Dog House” and encampment residents like Oscar administer naloxone and rescue breaths repeatedly, reflecting a harm-reduction ethos against fentanyl’s lethal volatility. Indigenous Alaskans, overrepresented among the homeless and overdose victims, confront historical trauma even as tribal, military and state groups mobilize naloxone kit builds. While cleanup initiatives threaten these lifesaving micro-communities, expanding recovery beds, mobile crisis units modelled on Portugal’s decriminalization approach, and local nonprofits like True North aim to balance public order with support.

articles.title: Trump’s retribution campaign: who has the president targeted so far besides John Bolton?
articles.trailText: The former national security adviser is not the first person the president has retaliated against – he’s gone after James Comey, Letitia James and a host of others
articles.summary: Trump’s retribution campaign has escalated with DOJ charges against former NSA adviser John Bolton, following indictments of ex-FBI director James Comey and NY AG Letitia James. He’s pressed for investigations into Fed governor Lisa Cook over alleged mortgage fraud, revoked security clearances and Secret Service details for figures like Gen. Mark Milley and ex-CIA chief John Brennan, and targeted special counsel Jack Smith and Sen. Adam Schiff. Instruments include memos directing probes, campus policy demands and removal of portraits, reflecting a broad strategy of political retaliation.

articles.title: Revealed: how a Russian fight club expanded into the US with the help of American neo-Nazis
articles.trailText: Members of white supremacist ‘active clubs’ spearheaded a US expansion of a Russian fighting group that has raised money for the Kremlin’s illegal invasion of Ukraine
articles.summary: Guardian reports that Russia’s bareknuckle street fight outfit SFC—fundraising via pay-per-view streams for the Kremlin’s invasion of Ukraine—expanded into the US this year with help from American neo-Nazi "active clubs" and Patriot Front. It has staged underground events in the US South, notably the "Slaughter Smokey Mountain" and Dallas "Rise of Violence" tournaments, featuring fighters such as Base affiliate Thomas Denton, Tennessee active club’s Thomas Grady, Patriot Front members Tristan Rettke and Andrew Lindgren, and Lone Star club leader Avery Ross Ruiz. Experts warn these fights serve as recruiting, training and fundraising hubs for violent white supremacists.

articles.title: US non-profits ‘lock arms’ amid Trump’s menacing of George Soros: ‘We will not be intimidated’
articles.trailText: Groups across climate, democracy and Palestine solidarity have been talking for months about how to band together
articles.summary: Trump has labeled George Soros and his Open Society Foundations as targets, deploying DOJ, IRS and counterterrorism tools to probe a global grant network funding democracy, voting rights, climate justice, racial justice and Palestinian solidarity. Progressive non-profits from the ACLU, Indivisible and Jewish Voice for Peace to the Sunrise Movement say baseless accusations of “leftwing terrorism” waste their resources, chill free speech and threaten First Amendment rights. They are coordinating legal defenses, mutual support and mass protests to “lock arms” against authoritarian financial intimidation.

articles.title: Reward scheme for using less power at peak times could help lower US bills
articles.trailText: With AI datacenters soaring power bills for households, a policy called ‘demand flexibility’ could help ease grid strain
articles.summary: Demand flexibility, a bipartisan policy rewarding reduced power use or solar exports at peak times, could offset a projected 20% rise in US grid demand driven by AI data centers, EVs and heat, curb 9.5% household bill hikes and avert blackouts. A Duke study finds flexibility could add 100GW capacity—equal to 30,000 wind turbines—via battery storage and backup generators. States like North Carolina have task forces; California vetoed a study bill, while Utah’s Rocky Mountain Power pays $300/kWh for home solar storage access.

articles.title: Manhattan district attorney works to curb interstate gun trafficking: ‘It’s a national issue’
articles.trailText: Alvin Bragg was appointed co-chair of Prosecutors Against Gun Violence and sets sights on addressing flow of guns
articles.summary: Manhattan DA Alvin Bragg has been appointed co-chair of Prosecutors Against Gun Violence (PAGV), joining Columbus City Attorney Zach Klein to lead a bipartisan coalition of over 50 prosecutors focused on reducing shootings and curbing interstate gun trafficking. Drawing on his Harlem upbringing and his office’s work against ghost guns—pushing legislation to ban 3D-printed firearms, urging YouTube to block build tutorials and collaborating with printer makers—Bragg aims to share trauma-informed prosecution and community intervention strategies nationwide. He will leverage partnerships with nonprofits and fellow prosecutors to address the disproportionate impact of gun violence on Black and Latino communities, even as federal grant cuts strain local violence-prevention programs.

articles.title: Ex-Trump adviser John Bolton indicted on charges of mishandling classified information
articles.trailText: Eighteen-count indictment handed down by federal grand jury in Maryland as US president calls former ally a ‘bad guy’
articles.summary: A federal grand jury in Maryland returned an 18-count Espionage Act indictment against ex-National Security Adviser John Bolton, accusing him of willfully retaining and disclosing highly classified material from daily diary entries and notes he emailed and messaged to two individuals without clearances. The charges stem from his use of personal email and group chat accounts, FBI searches of his Maryland home and DC office, and revelations tied to his 2020 memoir, The Room Where It Happened. Bolton denies wrongdoing, pledging to defend his lawful diary-keeping practice, while Trump, calling him a “bad guy,” professed no prior knowledge of the case.

articles.title: Former Trump adviser John Bolton indicted on charges of mishandling classified information | First Thing
articles.trailText: Eighteen-count indictment handed down as US president calls former ally a ‘bad guy’. Plus, director Kathryn Bigelow on AI, Andy Warhol and nuclear Armageddon
articles.summary: John Bolton, Trump’s former national security adviser-turned-critic, was indicted on 18 counts under the Espionage Act for allegedly transmitting and retaining classified information. A Maryland grand jury charged him with sharing diary entries recounting his NSC activities with two unnamed individuals. In response, Bolton vowed to defend his “lawful conduct” and spotlight Trump’s alleged abuses of power. Trump, claiming no prior knowledge of the charges, labeled Bolton a “bad guy.” This marks the third recent DOJ indictment of a prominent Trump critic.

articles.title: How Chicago succeeded in reducing drug overdose deaths
articles.trailText: The city has adopted a ‘multifactorial approach to a multifactorial problem’ and has seen a 37% reduction in deaths since the national peak of the crisis
articles.summary: Chicago cut overdose deaths by 37% since the 2023 peak via a multifactorial response: real-time drug-supply surveillance, mass spectrometry in labs, grassroots testing from Chicago Recovery Alliance, CDC’s “overdose data to action” funding, and hyper-local ambulance data. Public libraries now distribute free test strips and naloxone alongside education. Advanced spectrometers detect adulterants like medetomidine, nitazenes and xylazine, enabling alerts to clinicians and users. This coordinated citywide network of labs, libraries, first responders and community groups has allowed rapid detection, targeted outreach and harm reduction to lower fatal overdoses in Cook County.

articles.title: US cities to resist Trump’s crackdown on dissent with No Kings protests: ‘We will not be bullied’
articles.trailText: Second round of protests at more than 2,500 sites are set for Saturday, including in cities where Trump has sent troops
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s promise to crack down on dissent—deploying troops to Democratic-run cities, labeling antifa a terrorist group and expanding immigration raids—has prompted a second “No Kings” mobilization Oct. 18. Indivisible and 200+ partners, from the ACLU and SEIU to the Human Rights Campaign and MoveOn, plan rallies in over 2,500 communities aiming to surpass June’s multi-million turnout. Organizers emphasize trained safety marshals, de-escalation tactics and coordinated boycotts as tools alongside nonviolent marches, framing the day as a nationwide pushback against presidential authoritarianism in Chicago, Portland, Austin and beyond.

articles.title: Three-year-old Michigan boy saves mother’s life with quick thinking after she has seizure
articles.trailText: Cody James Williams used facial recognition to call for help as his mother suffered medical emergency
articles.summary: Authorities in Oakland County, Michigan, honored three-year-old Cody James Williams as a junior deputy after he saved his mother, Shantell Woods, from a severe epileptic seizure on October 9. Recognizing her distress, Cody used Face ID to unlock her phone, video-called a neighbor, and repeatedly urged “Help mommy!” prompting the neighbor to summon emergency services. Woods, who has faced over 20 seizures amid diabetes and hypertension, credited her son’s quick thinking with saving her life. Sheriff Michael Bouchard praised Cody and urged parents to teach kids emergency protocols.

articles.title: Experience, integrity and Trump: key takeaways from New York’s mayoral debate
articles.trailText: Zohran Mamdani and Andrew Cuomo tried to knock each other down while Curtis Sliwa took shots at both
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani (Dem front-runner), Andrew Cuomo (independent ex-governor) and Curtis Sliwa (GOP) clashed over standing up to Trump—each opposed deploying the National Guard or backing deportations—and disputed their history with him (Sliwa praised Trump years ago at a veterans parade; Mamdani never spoke to him; Cuomo denied a recent call). Cuomo attacked Mamdani’s inexperience; Mamdani highlighted his lived NYC experience and integrity. On Gaza, all urged a ceasefire while Mamdani distanced himself from Hamas. None endorsed Gov. Hochul despite her backing of Mamdani.

articles.title: Mamdani, Cuomo and Sliwa spar in New York mayoral debate
articles.trailText: The Democratic nominee and the former governor of New York clashed repeatedly, while Sliwa criticized them both
articles.summary: At the first televised New York mayoral debate, Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani, independent Andrew Cuomo—seeking a comeback after his 2021 resignation amid harassment allegations—and Republican Curtis Sliwa sparred on crime, policing reform, housing affordability, transit and national issues including a Gaza ceasefire and engagement with a Trump administration. Cuomo attacked Mamdani’s experience, Mamdani retorted on his integrity and local roots, while Sliwa criticized both. They clashed over NYPD funding, free buses and Gaza policy. A poll shows Mamdani leading at 46%.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: John Bolton vows to defend his conduct after indictment
articles.trailText: John Bolton, who served in Trump’s first administration, faces charges of mishandling and transmitting classified information. Key US politics stories from Thursday 16 October at a glance
articles.summary: Former national security adviser John Bolton is indicted on 18 counts under the Espionage Act for retaining and transmitting classified national defense information; he vows to defend his lawful conduct amid DOJ pressure and Trump’s push to pursue critics. Meanwhile, Volodymyr Zelenskyy visits the White House seeking US Tomahawk missiles as Trump signals another summit with Putin; the Senate fails its 10th vote to reopen government; Trump unveils a Washington ‘Arc de Trump’; a US admiral will retire amid Caribbean military strikes; intelligence officials warn of accelerating democratic backsliding under Trump.

articles.title: Trump files amended $15bn defamation complaint against New York Times
articles.trailText: Refiled complaint, after judge tossed initial suit last month, also targets individual reporters and book publisher
articles.summary: Donald Trump refiled a 40-page, amended $15bn defamation suit in Florida, targeting the New York Times, Penguin Random House, Suzanne Craig, Russ Buettner and White House correspondent Peter Baker (Michael Schmidt dropped). Judge Steven Merryday had dismissed the original on 19 September for Rule 8 violations—calling it overly verbose and repetitive—and gave Trump 28 days to refile. The new complaint itemizes dozens of alleged false statements about his ‘discovery’ as Apprentice host and claims of his father’s ‘fraudulent tax evasion,’ again seeking compensatory and punitive damages.

articles.title: US admiral to retire amid military strikes in Caribbean and tensions with Venezuela
articles.trailText: Alvin Holsey just took over the US southern command late last year for a position that normally lasts three years
articles.summary: Adm Alvin Holsey, head of US Southern Command since early 2025, will retire Dec. 12 after under a year in a post that normally lasts three years. His abrupt departure follows intensifying US strikes on suspected drug smugglers in the Caribbean and rising tensions with Venezuela, amid reported friction with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth over mission strategy. Hegseth praised Holsey’s 37-year career—beginning through Morehouse College’s NROTC—while Senate Armed Services ranking member Jack Reed warned the move signals instability and cautioned against unapproved intervention in Venezuela.

articles.title: Indiana University orders school paper to cease print edition and fires director of student media
articles.trailText: Editors at the Indiana Daily Student say administration’s move to control news content amounts to censorship
articles.summary: Indiana University’s administration has ordered the student-run Indiana Daily Student to halt all print news editions and fired its director of student media, Jim Rodenbush, after he resisted censoring content. Editors decry the move as unlawful censorship, and free press advocates including the Student Press Law Center and PEN America have condemned it. IU cites a shift to a digital-first model and budget deficits. University leaders insist editorial independence remains intact despite cutting print distribution.

articles.title: Trump moves to push employers on IVF coverage and lower fertility drug costs
articles.trailText: President says plans will lead to ‘many more beautiful American children’ but unclear if companies will sign up
articles.summary: The Trump administration urged US employers to offer separate fertility benefits covering IVF and infertility treatments, and cut a deal with EMD Serono to lower fertility drug costs on TrumpRx. Agencies will issue guidance on creating standalone IVF coverage, but companies aren’t required or subsidized, leaving uptake uncertain. Trump, pitching himself as the “fertilization president,” highlights pronatalist goals amid debate over embryo policy after the Alabama court ruling. Republicans stress employer flexibility. Critics note GOP ties to anti-abortion groups oppose IVF and push alternative restorative reproductive medicine lacking strong evidence.

articles.title: US ‘on a trajectory’ toward authoritarian rule, ex-officials warn
articles.trailText: A network of former intelligence and security officers says democratic decline is accelerating under Trump’s rule
articles.summary: Steady State, a network of 340 former intelligence officers, published ‘Accelerating Authoritarian Dynamics’, warning the US under President Trump’s second term is veering toward competitive authoritarianism. Using open-source indicators—pardons for Jan. 6 rioters, purges of career officials, politicization of law enforcement, deployment of troops in cities, attacks on courts and press, electoral manipulation—the report flags democratic backsliding via expanded executive powers, weakened judiciary and Congress, and erosion of civil society. Absent organized institutional or public resistance, authors warn the US risks executive consolidation akin to Hungary or Turkey, noting rising public support for a ‘strong leader’ over parliamentary democracy.

articles.title: US Senate vote to end government shutdown fails for 10th time
articles.trailText: Second vote on Pentagon funding also failed meaning process to begin military operations becomes a non-starter
articles.summary: The US Senate on Thursday failed for the tenth time to pass a short-term GOP funding bill (51-49) and separately reject Pentagon spending, guaranteeing a continuing shutdown into next week. Only three Democrats—Shaheen, Fetterman, Cortez Masto—backed defense funding. Senate GOP leader John Thune offered a fixed-date vote on ACA subsidy extensions, but progressives including Sanders and Ocasio-Cortez rejected IOUs, demanding enacted law. White House called the town hall a “clown show”, accusing Democrats of extortion. House Speaker Johnson has kept the chamber idle, and federal workers face mounting hardship; a multiweek shutdown may extend past Thanksgiving unless compromise emerges.

articles.title: Judge orders federal immigration officers in Chicago area to wear body cameras
articles.trailText: Agents also appear to have violated order banning them from using riot-control, such as tear gas, without warning
articles.summary: Judge Sara Ellis has mandated body cameras for federal immigration agents in Chicago after video evidence showed repeated use of pepper balls, smoke grenades and tear gas—actions violating her prior ban on unannounced riot-control tactics and badge requirements. Citing news footage of aggressive DHS enforcement amid a Trump administration deportation surge, Ellis railed against unrestrained force. Documented incidents include a car chase collision and tear gas fired at protesters and police, the forcible arrest of bystanders and schoolyards blanketed in gas.

articles.title: Illinois governor JB Pritzker won $1.4m gambling last year, tax filings reveal
articles.trailText: Pritzker, a billionaire, says he plans to donate winnings from playing blackjack on Las Vegas trip
articles.summary: Illinois governor JB Pritzker won a net $1.4m playing blackjack on a single Las Vegas trip last year and plans to donate all winnings to charity, his campaign says. A billionaire heir to the Hyatt hotel chain (family net worth $41.6bn; personal net ~$3.7bn), Pritzker placed his assets in a blind trust and reported over $10m in adjusted gross income in 2024. He highlighted his Chicago Poker Challenge, which funds the Holocaust Museum and civil-rights causes. A vocal critic of Donald Trump and potential 2028 Democratic contender, Pritzker is running for a third gubernatorial term in 2026.

articles.title: Who are the rightwing influencers filling Trump’s head with visions of antifa?
articles.trailText: Meet the content creators whose videos from Portland and Chicago shape the president’s distorted view of reality
articles.summary: At last week’s White House roundtable on antifa, President Trump was briefed by 11 self-styled “independent journalists”—8 of them current or former Turning Point USA affiliates—who deploy selectively edited protest footage to cast antifascists as domestic terrorists. Leading voices include video-journalist Andy Ngo, whose misleading clips and book fueled fears—and a fatal shooting—and activists like Katie Daviscourt, Nick Sortor and Julio Rosas, whose viral content on X and Fox News distorts demonstrations to justify federal crackdowns.

articles.title: Queer and trans immigrants allege forced labor and sexual assault in Ice facility: ‘I was treated worse than an animal’
articles.trailText: At the South Louisiana Ice Processing Center in Basile, detainees say they were forced into hard labor – and sexually assaulted and stalked by an assistant warden
articles.summary: At the South Louisiana ICE Processing Center in Basile, Louisiana, queer and trans detainees allege an unsanctioned work program forced them into manual labor for $1/day while an assistant warden, Manuel Reyes, stalked, harassed and sexually assaulted them. Four complaints filed under the Federal Tort Claims Act and PREA detail coerced labor, chemical exposure without protective gear, medical neglect and threats. After reporting abuse to DHS, ICE and OIG, detainees faced retaliation including solitary confinement. ACLU, RFK Human Rights and National Immigration Project have lodged civil rights complaints with DHS oversight bodies.

articles.title: Marine colonel quits after 24 years citing concern for future of US under Trump
articles.trailText: Resignation, coinciding with Hegseth’s partisan speech, was over Trump flouting constitution, Doug Krugman writes
articles.summary: Doug Krugman, a retired Marine colonel and combat veteran, resigned on Sept. 30 after 24 years, blaming President Trump’s constitutional contempt. His departure coincided with Trump and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s partisan addresses to top military leaders. In a Washington Post op-ed, Krugman cited Trump’s January 6 incitement, pardons for rioters, refusal to shelter Afghan allies, unauthorized national guard deployments and emergency power abuses. He urged service members to question illegal orders and warned that unchecked executive overreach risks collapse of the constitutional system if voters and lawmakers fail to clarify presidential limits.

articles.title: Waving his flag all over the place: Trump adds ‘Arc de Trump’ to presidential renovations
articles.trailText: In addition to a new ballroom, flagpoles, gilding the Oval Office and paving over the Rose Garden, the US president proposes an arch
articles.summary: President Donald Trump unveiled plans for a monumental “Arc de Trump” arch in Washington, to stand as a northern gateway from Virginia near Arlington Memorial Bridge, previewing 3D models for donors at a White House dinner. The proposal accompanies his $250 million privately financed White House ballroom—bulletproof glass, 1,000-seat—funded by tech and defence magnates and a $22 million YouTube settlement. It follows Oval Office gilding, new flagpoles, Rose Garden paving, and a “presidential walk of fame” omitting Biden, plus new Washington and Lincoln statues. Attendees—from Amazon and Apple to Google, Meta, Microsoft, Palantir, Lockheed Martin and Gemini’s Winklevoss twins—received Trump’s “imperial” vision.

articles.title: Arkansas man, arrested over perfume bottle police mistook for opium, seeks to restore visa
articles.trailText: Police thought bottle contained drugs and arrested Kapil Raghu, who was then taken into custody by Ice
articles.summary: Kapil Raghu, an Indian national married to a US citizen, was pulled over in Benton, Arkansas, on May 3 for a traffic violation. Police discovered a perfume bottle labeled “Opium,” mistakenly arrested him for narcotics possession. After the state crime lab confirmed it was perfume, Raghu spent three days in county jail then was detained by ICE for 30 days due to an expired B2 visa. Charges were dropped May 20, but his work visa was revoked and he now faces deportation status, barring him from working. Raghu has petitioned ICE to restore his immigration status.

articles.title: Trump’s DEI bans undermine anti-human trafficking law, lawsuit alleges
articles.trailText: Suit comes after Guardian investigation found administration rolled back efforts to combat human trafficking while Trump officials deny retreat
articles.summary: A coalition of over 50 anti-trafficking groups is suing the Trump administration, arguing two January 2025 executive orders banning DEI language in federally funded work unlawfully censor survivors and violate the Trafficking Victims Protection Act. The DOJ has barred terms such as “gender,” “race,” “ethnicity” and “fairness,” impairing efforts to combat sexual slavery and forced labor. Lawyers note 40% of US sex-trafficking survivors are Black women, many are immigrants or LGBTQ+. Guardian investigations reveal cuts to anti-trafficking programs across five federal agencies, staff purges, delayed grants and removed resources. Nonprofits report suspended survivor services and unspent DOJ funds. Trump officials deny any rollback.

articles.title: Major airlift evacuations in Alaska after remnants of typhoon decimate villages
articles.trailText: Weekend storm devastated two villages and displaced more than 1,500 people in the south-western part of the state
articles.summary: After Typhoon Halong’s remnants battered the Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta with hurricane-force winds, rain and a 6ft surge, two remote villages—Kipnuk (715) and Kwigillingok (380)—were devastated, displacing over 1,500 residents. Alaska mounted one of its largest airlifts, flying around 300 evacuees to a repurposed Anchorage arena while hundreds sheltered in schools in Bethel amid limited power and sanitation. Disaster workers from across the US have been deployed, but some locals may choose to stay. The storm killed one person and left two missing, highlighting federal mitigation cuts.

articles.title: Former Bush adviser charged with amassing top secret files
articles.trailText: Indian-American Ashley Tellis allegedly obtained US military data and passed envelopes to Chinese officials
articles.summary: Ashley J. Tellis, 64, an Indian-American academic and former Bush White House and State Department adviser, was arrested in Virginia for allegedly retaining thousands of pages of top-secret US military and diplomatic documents. FBI agents found classified materials he printed on government computers and, authorities say, covertly passed to Chinese officials. Tellis, credited with helping negotiate the US-India nuclear deal, denies the allegations and vows to contest them. His arrest has sparked political debate in India and prompted US officials to pledge vigorous prosecution of security breaches.

articles.title: Californians wary yet supportive of proposal to redraw voting maps: ‘This is a tactical measure’
articles.trailText: Proposition 50 is part of the Democratic governor Gavin Newsom’s plan to counter Texas’s gerrymandered maps
articles.summary: Prop 50, championed by Gov Gavin Newsom and California Democrats, would redraw the state’s congressional map to net up to five additional Democratic seats, directly countering Texas’s GOP-backed gerrymander. Though California already relies on an independent redistricting commission, voters are split: many reluctantly support the temporary three-cycle measure (2026–2030) as a defensive tactic against perceived election rigging, while others warn it undermines the commission’s authority and risks a partisan ‘fight fire with fire’ spiral. If passed, the commission resumes map-drawing after the 2030 census.

articles.title: A surge of visitors to Yosemite overwhelms a skeleton crew: ‘This is exactly what we warned about’
articles.trailText: As the US government shutdown enters its third week, concerns mount over how the nation’s public lands will fare
articles.summary: As the third week of the 2025 US federal government shutdown threatens to eclipse the record 35 days, Yosemite National Park is open but operating on a skeleton crew: half its workforce furloughed and maintenance, conservation and visitor-monitoring projects halted. Weekend crowds overwhelmed unmanned entry stations, spurring unauthorized camping, BASE jumping, forbidden swims and permitless Half Dome climbs. Fire crews—exempt from cuts—contained a Joshua Tree blaze. Conservation advocates warn this reliance on entrance fees (despite GAO-flagged legal issues) masks irreparable damage, heightened safety risks and further erosion of park science and education.

articles.title: Mexico president dismisses US claim of cartel bounties on immigration officials
articles.trailText: Sheinbaum says she has ‘no information’ about Trump administration claim as experts also deeply skeptical
articles.summary: Mexico President Claudia Sheinbaum denied knowledge of Trump administration claims that cartels have placed bounties on US immigration officials, saying her government has no evidence. The Department of Homeland Security alleges drug factions offered $2,000 to identify agents, $5,000–$10,000 for kidnappings and up to $50,000 for assassinations. Former cartel trafficker Margarito Flores, ex-DEA chief Mike Vigil and scholars call the allegations improbable, noting cartels avoid targeting US law enforcement to prevent heightened crackdowns. DHS has provided no corroborating proof.

articles.title: JD Vance brushes off racist texts in Republican group chat as ‘what kids do’ | First Thing
articles.trailText: Vice-president downplays messages such as ‘I love Hitler’ in chat by 24- to 35-year-olds as ‘stupid jokes’. Plus, Virginia Giuffre on her abuse at the hands of Epstein and Maxwell
articles.summary: Morning briefing: VP JD Vance downplayed racist, sexist and rape-glorifying texts exchanged by 24- to 35-year-old Young Republicans as mere ‘stupid jokes’; Israel warns it may resume Gaza strikes after Hamas returns only a few hostage bodies; Trump threatens to send federal troops to San Francisco amid disputed crime data; the Supreme Court hears Callais v. Louisiana, risking a key Voting Rights Act provision; South Korea issues a ‘code black’ travel warning for Cambodia; Britney Spears rebuts ex-husband Kevin Federline’s memoir claims; Nestlé plans 16,000 job cuts to boost growth; Virginia Giuffre details abuse by Epstein, Maxwell and Prince Andrew; a judge dismisses a youth-led climate lawsuit against Trump’s energy orders; Elliott Gould fondly recalls Diane Keaton’s early charisma.

articles.title: Ex-Catholic priest exploited family deaths to abuse disabled boy, police allege
articles.trailText: Mark Ford, extradited from Indiana to New Orleans jail, faces life in prison if convicted of sexual abuse charges
articles.summary: Mark Francis Ford, 64, a former Vincentian priest extradited from Indiana and held without bail in New Orleans on four first-degree rape counts plus charges of sexual battery, indecent behavior with a juvenile and kidnapping, is accused of exploiting a boy with a degenerative spinal condition whom he mentored via the God’s Special Children program after his family’s deaths. Authorities say Ford groomed the child from age 10 between 2004–14, showed pornography, threatened him to keep silent and assaulted him multiple times. The district attorney vows a strong prosecution in this latest case in the archdiocese’s bankruptcy-linked abuse scandal.

articles.title: Trump’s Middle East ‘peace’ pitch to Iran falls flat in Tehran and Jerusalem
articles.trailText: In a Knesset speech, Trump urged Israel to reconcile with its longtime foe Iran. Both governments dismissed the idea
articles.summary: During a Knesset address, President Trump unexpectedly urged Israel and Iran to reconcile, proposing Tehran end proxy funding, recognize Israel’s right to exist and join a US–Israel–Iran peace triangle. Israeli leaders dismissed the offer as naive given decades of enmity and Iran’s perceived existential threat. In Tehran, hardliners, still enraged by Trump’s past bombings of nuclear sites and Soleimani’s assassination, rejected dialogue. Analysts say Supreme Leader Khamenei’s faction will not compromise absent regime change, making renewed military escalation more likely than rapprochement.

articles.title: San Francisco opposes ‘authoritarian crackdown’ as Trump threatens to send troops
articles.trailText: President pushes hyperbolic claims of out-of-control crime as city leaders say no need for ‘Trump’s personal army’
articles.summary: Donald Trump threatened to deploy federal or National Guard troops to San Francisco, repeating his pattern after actions in Portland, Chicago, DC and LA, citing hyperbolic crime claims. Gov. Gavin Newsom, Mayor Daniel Lurie, state senator Scott Wiener and public defender Mano Raju have unanimously rejected any request or need for federal occupation, pointing to a 22% drop in violent crime and the lowest homicide rate in 70 years. Immigrant-rights advocates warn a militarized response would intimidate vulnerable communities amid a federal shutdown, and Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff’s support drew backlash.

articles.title: JD Vance brushes off racist texts by adults in Republican group chat as ‘what kids do’
articles.trailText: Vice-president downplays messages such as ‘I love Hitler’ in chat by 24 to 35-year-olds to ‘stupid jokes’
articles.summary: Vice-president JD Vance downplayed leaked racist, sexist and pro-Hitler messages exchanged by 24-to-35-year-olds in the Young Republican National Federation as ‘stupid jokes’ kids make, urging critics to ‘grow up’ and focus on real issues. Politico revealed the months-long Telegram chat, prompting bipartisan calls—including from GOP leaders in Vermont and New York, and California Governor Gavin Newsom—for participants to resign. Vance compared the uproar to Democratic candidate Jay Jones’s violent text jokes and warned youth that online remarks can resurface to harm families.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Court halts mass firings threatened by White House as shutdown enters third week
articles.trailText: Federal court approves temporary injunction blocking Trump administration from mass layoffs. Key US politics stories from Wednesday 15 October
articles.summary: Third week of government shutdown: federal court grants temporary injunction blocking Trump administration from mass layoffs, ruling OMB exceeded authority; unions sued over threats to fire 10,000+ workers. Supreme Court signals intent to weaken Voting Rights Act; Chinese firm gives Eric Trump crypto company preferential equipment access; Trump confirms covert CIA ops in Venezuela. Exonerated Pennsylvania man detained by ICE; Young Republicans scandal over racist chat leaks; visas stripped over Charlie Kirk posts; Pete Hegseth’s flight diverted over cracked windshield; US passport falls from world’s top 10; Boston mayor and Brown University push back on Trump’s college compact.

articles.title: Brown University rejects Trump proposal to overhaul policies for preferential funding
articles.trailText: University joins MIT in refusing invitation, saying that compact would ‘restrict academic freedom’
articles.summary: Brown University refused to sign Trump admin’s 10-page “Compact for Academic Excellence” offering preferential federal funding in exchange for policy overhauls restricting diversity, equity and inclusion programs and international enrollment. President Christina Paxson wrote that the agreement would undermine academic freedom, institutional autonomy and merit-based research funding—criticism echoed by MIT’s president and AAUP. Brown joins MIT in declining; other invitees (UVA, UT Austin, USC, Penn, Vanderbilt, Dartmouth, etc.) have yet to decide. Trump has warned of investigations; the funding link remains unclear. Brown’s move safeguards its July White House deal preserving curriculum independence.

articles.title: Trump takes credit for already dropping crime rates in press conference
articles.trailText: Flanked by Kash Patel and Pam Bondi, president claimed it was ‘most peaceful summer in the last two decades’
articles.summary: At a White House press conference flanked by FBI Dir. Kash Patel and AG Pam Bondi, President Trump claimed credit for a nearly 20% drop in violent crime this summer, citing “Operation Summer Heat,” a months-long federal crackdown logging 28,600 arrests (8,700 violent offenders), 2,200 firearms seized and 421 kg of fentanyl. He cited Memphis’s 25-year lows in robbery, burglary and larceny and record lows in murder, assault and sexual assault, despite crime declines predating his term. He threatened Boston over World Cup cooperation, defended strikes on Venezuelan drug-smuggling boats and blamed Chuck Schumer for the government shutdown, saying it advances GOP aims.

articles.title: Judge dismisses suit by young climate activists against Trump’s pro-fossil fuel policies
articles.trailText: Plaintiffs had ‘overwhelming evidence’ of climate crisis but a court injunction would be ‘unworkable’, ruling says
articles.summary: US District Judge Dana Christensen dismissed a suit by 22 youth (ages 7–25 from five states) seeking to block three of President Trump’s pro-fossil fuel executive orders—for a national energy emergency, “unleash American energy” and coal revival—ruling that, despite “overwhelming evidence” of climate harms, the court lacked authority and an injunction would be unworkable. Plaintiffs, led by Our Children’s Trust counsel Julia Olson, vow to appeal. Critics note Trump’s administration has recruited 40+ coal, oil and gas insiders while undermining renewables and climate science.

articles.title: Voting Rights Act on the line: key takeaways from supreme court hearing
articles.trailText: Majority of US justices appear sympathetic to weakening key civil rights law in Callais v Louisiana case
articles.summary: In Callais v. Louisiana, the Supreme Court probed whether Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act—barring maps that dilute minority voting power—should survive after Louisiana added a majority-Black district. Justices Kavanaugh, Roberts and Gorsuch queried NAACP lawyer Janai Nelson on race-based maps’ endpoint and cited Allen v. Milligan precedent. Louisiana’s solicitor general decried race-based redistricting as unconstitutional. Weakening Section 2 could revive 15th Amendment promises in name only, undo minority-opportunity districts and cost Democrats up to 19 House seats.

articles.title: US Capitol police investigating flag with swastika in Republican representative’s office – report
articles.trailText: Authorities reportedly looking into modified flag displayed on cubicle wall of House member Dave Taylor’s staff
articles.summary: Capitol Police are probing after a US flag altered to display a swastika was found in GOP Rep. Dave Taylor’s office in the Cannon building. The red-and-white striped swastika flag appeared behind staffer Angelo Elia during a virtual meeting, alongside a pocket constitution and congressional calendar. Taylor condemned the symbol, ordered an investigation, and suggested foul play or vandalism. The probe continues amid a federal shutdown halting police communications. The incident follows a Politico report on Young Republican leaders’ racist Telegram chat mocking the Holocaust and praising Hitler.

articles.title: ‘He may be watching’: Mamdani on Fox News speaks directly to Trump
articles.trailText: New York mayoral contender steps into lion’s den and says he is ‘ready to speak at any time’ to help lower cost of living
articles.summary: NYC mayoral frontrunner Zohran Mamdani sat for a rare Fox News interview amid right-wing criticism of his democratic-socialist agenda. He defended funding rent freezes, free buses and childcare via wealth taxes, rejecting service cuts and blaming billionaires for NYC’s affordability crisis. Citing Trump voters driven by living costs, he countered claims he’s unqualified, speaking directly to President Trump to promise independent, cost-of-living-focused leadership. Mamdani leads Quinnipiac polls with 46% versus Andrew Cuomo’s 33% and GOP Curtis Sliwa’s 15%, ahead of a key debate where crime and Gaza ceasefire stances loom.

articles.title: Pentagon reporters have now turned in their badges – but plan to keep reporting
articles.trailText: Reporters who declined to sign new set of Pentagon rules had to clear out of world’s largest military headquarters
articles.summary: Under Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s new rules, Pentagon reporters who refused to sign strict disclosure and “solicitation” guidelines returned their badges by Oct 15, ending decades of in-house coverage. Packed-up journalists worry about slower, less probing reporting, chilling effects on sources and delayed responses to breaking news. Major networks and outlets like the Guardian and Atlantic jointly refused the policy, pledging continued coverage from outside via day passes. Some correspondents vow a more aggressive approach; only One America News and the Federalist plan to stay on-site. Impact on accountability and transparency remains uncertain.

articles.title: Oregon judge extends order preventing Trump from deploying national guard
articles.trailText: Extension maintains status quo on ground and extends orders which had been set to expire this week
articles.summary: A federal judge in Oregon extended two 14-day restraining orders blocking the Trump administration from federalizing and deploying Oregon National Guard troops to Portland, after ruling the president lacks authority and his war-zone claims were untethered to facts. The orders, scheduled to expire this week, remain until a Ninth Circuit panel reviews the appeal. Judge Karin Immergut has set a non-jury trial for Oct 29 to consider a longer-term injunction amid ongoing protests outside an ICE field office.

articles.title: ‘My vote is my voice’: protesters fight for democracy as Trump casts shadow
articles.trailText: Outside the supreme court, protesters invoked the legacy of civil rights giants with a key Voting Rights Act plank at stake
articles.summary: Outside the US Supreme Court on Oct 15, a few hundred largely Black protesters rallied to defend Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, hearing arguments on Louisiana electoral maps they fear could gut the half-century-old law and reverse civil rights gains. They invoked Thurgood Marshall, John Lewis and MLK, waved signs (“My vote is my voice”, “Protect our vote”), and chanted “Power to the people.” Leaders from Black Voters Matter and the NAACP Legal Defense Fund, including Janai Nelson, framed the case as the latest civil rights struggle. Tensions ran high amid anti-Trump slogans but optimism echoed Lewis’s “good trouble” call.

articles.title: US government shutdown festers into third week after ninth failed Senate vote
articles.trailText: Democrats and Republicans accused each other of inflexibility, while federal workers face disrupted paychecks
articles.summary: In its third week after a ninth failed Senate vote, the US government shutdown continues amid partisan clashes over spending and healthcare. House minority leader Hakeem Jeffries accused GOP senators of abandoning Washington and urged extending Affordable Care Act tax credits to prevent premium hikes, while Speaker Mike Johnson warned 1.3 million service members face missed pay. The Trump administration has deployed stopgap measures—redirecting funds from its July tax and immigration bill to pay the coast guard—and laid off over 4,000 federal workers, with OMB predicting cuts could top 10,000. Senate Majority Leader John Thune remains pessimistic about a resolution.

articles.title: Pennsylvania man wrongfully imprisoned for more than 40 years faces deportation after Ice arrest
articles.trailText: Subramanyam Vedam, 64, was recently exonerated for murder after being sentenced to life in prison in 1983
articles.summary: Subramanyam “Subu” Vedam, 64, a lawful permanent resident since infancy, was exonerated for the 1980 murder conviction that kept him incarcerated over 40 years. Centre County DA dismissed charges in 2025 after new evidence surfaced, yet ICE detained him under a 1988 deportation order tied to vacated convictions. ICE calls him a “career criminal” and controlled-substance trafficker; his lawyers and family contend he lost four decades for a crime he didn’t commit and should be allowed to rebuild his life. Vedam is held at the Moshannon Valley facility as deportation proceedings loom.

articles.title: Judge temporarily blocks firings by Trump administration during shutdown
articles.trailText: Judge says White House office of management and budget took advantage of government shutdown in firing workers
articles.summary: Judge Susan Illston of the US District Court for Northern California granted a temporary injunction blocking the Trump administration’s planned furloughed-worker firings during the partial shutdown. Labor unions AFGE and AFSCME sued, alleging OMB director Russ Vought and OPM exceeded authority by using the lapse in funding to impose unprecedented reductions in force—at least 4,100 notices issued, with Vought warning cuts could top 10,000. Illston found the evidence suggests illegal, arbitrary and capricious action. No prior shutdown has seen mass federal layoffs. The restraining order remains in effect pending full review.

articles.title: Gavin Newsom again denies parole for Manson follower Patricia Krenwinkel
articles.trailText: California governor blocks 77-year-old’s parole for second time, saying she ‘poses an unreasonable danger to society’
articles.summary: Gavin Newsom has for the second time denied parole for 77-year-old Patricia Krenwinkel, a Charles Manson follower serving life for the 1969 Tate–LaBianca murders. Five months after a unanimous parole board deemed her suitable—citing her spotless disciplinary record, earned college degrees, expressed remorse and documented abuse by Manson—Newsom ruled she still poses an “unreasonable danger.” Her attorney, Keith Wattley of UnCommon Law, called the governor’s reversal political and contrary to evidence. Newsom has also vetoed parole for other Manson associates, though Leslie Van Houten won release in 2023 when a court overturned his block.

articles.title: Chinese company gives an Eric Trump crypto firm preferential access to tech
articles.trailText: SEC filings show Bitmain gave firm partially owned by Eric Trump unusually generous terms on equipment
articles.summary: SEC filings reveal that Bitmain granted American Bitcoin Corporation—of which Eric Trump holds a 7.5% stake—preferential access to over 16,000 advanced mining machines and unusually favorable financing: payment in pledged bitcoin redeemable after 24 months, compared with the six-month terms it offers other clients. Founded two months after Donald Trump’s inauguration and majority-owned by Hut 8, American Bitcoin’s cost advantage relies on these ‘sweetheart’ deals. Experts warn the extended credit and deep discounts could allow the Chinese firm to curry influence with the Trump administration, raising national security and foreign-influence concerns.

articles.title: Outcry after US strips visas from six foreigners over Charlie Kirk remarks
articles.trailText: Cancellations represent escalating government-wide campaign to suppress criticism of rightwing influencer
articles.summary: The State Department under Trump revoked visas of six foreign nationals—Argentine, South African, Mexican, Brazilian, German and Paraguayan—who posted celebratory or mocking comments about rightwing influencer Charlie Kirk’s assassination on social media. The blowback has drawn warnings from civil liberties groups (FIRE, Knight First Amendment) that the “extreme vetting” regime, expanded in March, uses broad social media surveillance to punish dissent and violates First Amendment protections. Targets include Brazilian comedian Tiago Santineli and Paraguayan talkshow host Enrique Gamarra. Critics decry the move as viewpoint-based censorship and unprecedented political speech suppression.

articles.title: US supreme court appears poised to weaken key pillar of Voting Rights Act
articles.trailText: Dispute over Louisiana district returned to justices after long legal saga – and could have far-reaching implications
articles.summary: In Louisiana v Callais, the conservative-majority US Supreme Court signaled it will narrow Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, curbing minority voters’ ability to challenge racially discriminatory redistricting. After a 2½-hour argument, swing votes probed the endpoint for race-based remedies while liberals warned a rollback would reverse decades of minority-opportunity districts upheld in Allen v Milligan. A ruling could strip plaintiffs of a key enforcement tool, reshape maps before next year’s midterms and potentially cost Democrats around a dozen House seats.

articles.title: US falls out of world’s 10 most powerful passports list for first time in 20 years
articles.trailText: Declining strength of US passport, tied with Malaysia’s at 12th, signals ‘shift in global mobility’, says index creator
articles.summary: For the first time in 20 years, the US passport slips from 7th place last year to 12th (tied with Malaysia) in the Henley Passport Index, marking a decline in American soft power. Christian Kaelin credits a shift in global mobility as open nations advance while restrictive US visa policies—only 46 nationalities enter visa-free despite Americans accessing 180 destinations—erode its standing. Brazil, China and Vietnam have rescinded or barred entry to Americans. Asian leaders—Singapore (193), South Korea (190), Japan (189)—dominate. Rising dual citizenship interest signals Americans seeking renewed travel freedom.

articles.title: Jack Smith hits back at claims that Trump prosecutions were politically motivated
articles.trailText: Former justice department special counsel said accusations were ‘ludicrous’ and criticized Trump’s DoJ in rare interview
articles.summary: In a rare University College London interview, former DOJ special counsel Jack Smith—who led the 2023 indictments of Donald Trump over efforts to overturn the 2020 election and mishandling classified documents—called claims his prosecutions were politically motivated “absolutely ludicrous.” He stressed that his independent team of veteran prosecutors had no partisan agenda, and he warned that recent Trump DOJ actions—such as dismissing the Eric Adams corruption case and charging ex-FBI director James Comey—undermine due process and risk driving career lawyers out of public service. Following his January resignation, House Republicans have requested his testimony on alleged prosecutorial bias.

articles.title: ‘This is so vile’: Young Republicans face backlash after racist chats leaked
articles.trailText: Politico documented the use of slurs, including the N-word and a homophobic term, and antisemitic comments in chats
articles.summary: Politico revealed 2,900 pages of leaked Telegram chats among Young Republican leaders filled with racist, homophobic and antisemitic slurs—referring to Black people as “monkeys” and praising Hitler. The fallout includes calls for resignations by the Young Republican National Federation, shutdown of the Kansas chapter and multiple staffers fired or losing job offers. Elected officials from Hakeem Jeffries to Kathy Hochul condemned the hate-filled messages, while JD Vance and others deflected by citing a Democratic texting scandal. The controversy threatens the group’s leadership and the GOP’s image ahead of the 2025 midterms.

articles.title: Reparations leaders ‘deeply disappointed’ as Newsom vetoes university bill
articles.trailText: Backlash as California governor rejects measure allowing preferential treatment for descendants of enslaved people
articles.summary: California Gov. Gavin Newsom vetoed Assembly Bill 7, which would have allowed colleges to give admission preference to descendants of enslaved Americans. Assemblymember Isaac Bryan and reparations advocates said AB7 targeted the Black–White wealth gap by using lineage instead of race, aiming to sidestep affirmative‐action bans. They branded the veto “unnecessary” and at odds with Newsom’s reparations legacy, including a prior task force and apology bills. Legal experts are split on the bill’s constitutionality. Supporters plan to rework the measure, leverage the new Bureau for Descendants of American Slavery, and ramp up campus organizing to secure reparative admissions policies.

articles.title: Panic as US federal workers scramble to find out if they’ve been fired: ‘I don’t have email access’
articles.trailText: Education department staff say they can’t access work emails amid the shutdown to check for layoff notices
articles.summary: During the federal shutdown, the Trump administration abruptly axed about 4,200 employees across seven agencies—though 700 CDC cuts were later reversed—sparking confusion as furloughed staff can’t access government email to confirm RIF notices. Unions sued and won an injunction against March’s forceful Education Department reductions; a hearing on fresh firings is set Wednesday. New notices hit special education programs the day before their longtime director’s funeral, cutting staff from over 4,100 at Trump’s inauguration to under 2,000. Unions warn these cuts imperil K-12, disability services and sow anxiety across other agencies awaiting further job losses.

articles.title: More than 1,500 people displaced after typhoon remnants devastate Alaska villages
articles.trailText: At least one person was killed and two were missing after weekend storm battered two Alaska Native communities
articles.summary: Typhoon Halong’s remnants battered Alaska’s Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta, killing at least one resident, leaving two missing and displacing over 1,500 across Kipnuk (pop. 715) and Kwigillingok (pop. 380). Ferocious winds, record storm surge and rain caused dozens of homes to float out to sea. Survivors were evacuated by Coast Guard or sheltered in schools and the National Guard armory in Bethel; limited power and sanitation hamper relief. Officials halted the search for two missing men after extensive drone, boat and air efforts. Authorities warn of prolonged recovery as winter approaches and communities await food, generators and rebuilding supplies.

articles.title: Florida wildlife officials discover second case of ‘zombie deer disease’ in state
articles.trailText: Experts are enforcing emergency measures to prevent the spread of the highly contagious neurodegenerative disease
articles.summary: Florida wildlife officials confirmed the state’s second chronic wasting disease (CWD) case in a collision-killed white-tailed doe in Holmes County near the Alabama border—following its first detection in June 2023.
