CWD, a fatal prion-driven neurodegenerative condition with no vaccine or cure, spreads through direct contact, environmental contamination and ticks. The Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission has established a special management zone in Holmes, Jackson and Washington counties, initiated enhanced surveillance on 90 pending samples, and mandated carcass checks. With an estimated 700,000 deer statewide and 100,000 hunted annually, experts warn unchecked CWD could trigger a domino effect on hunting participation, wildlife management funding and agricultural impacts.

articles.title: Israel reportedly pulls back from threat to slash aid entering Gaza | First Thing
articles.trailText: Rafah crossing will be allowed to open, say reports, after Hamas hands over more remains of hostages. Plus, gaffes made by world leaders when they think no one is listening
articles.summary: Israel reversed plans to cut humanitarian aid and will open Gaza's Rafah crossing after Hamas handed over additional hostages' remains, defusing the first major test of the fragile ceasefire. At the Gaza peace summit in Egypt, Indonesia’s president Prabowo Subianto was caught on a hot mic asking Donald Trump to arrange a call with his son. In US domestic news, LA county declared a state of emergency to fund rent relief for families hit by ICE raids, while the Trump administration threatened tariffs and visa restrictions to block an IMO shipping-emissions levy.

articles.title: The not-so secret language of fascist fashion
articles.trailText: Today’s rightwingers want their message to go mainstream, so it’s coming to a store near you
articles.summary: Rightwing extremists have weaponized fashion—eschewing overt symbols like swastikas for coded apparel and subtle aesthetics that blend into mainstream retail. From T-shirts and polo shirts with quiet references (“my favorite color is white,” runic fonts, the number 88) to tradwife-style dresses, these styles signal in-group identity while offering plausible deniability. Like Mussolini’s black shirts or Hugo Boss–made SS uniforms, today’s “fascion 3.0” uses online sales, TikTok, eBay and co-opted brands (e.g. Fred Perry polos) to normalize authoritarian ideas and recruit supporters. As extremist imagery becomes polished, it infiltrates everyday wardrobes—embedding radical ideology in the guise of patriotism and convenience.

articles.title: Robert De Niro urges Americans to ‘stand up and be counted’ in anti-Trump protests
articles.trailText: In video, the two-time Oscar winner also invoked the pledge of allegiance to say ‘we’re all in this together’
articles.summary: In a new video, actor Robert De Niro urges Americans to “stand up and be counted” in nationwide nonviolent “No Kings” protests against President Donald Trump’s second term, calling him a would-be tyrant—“king Donald the first”—and invoking the pledge of allegiance’s “indivisible” ideal. Organized by decentralized 50501 (50 states, 50 protests), the rallies follow June demonstrations that drew millions. The appeal comes amid Trump’s use of troops in US cities, a –8 public approval rating in a recent Morning Consult poll and a looming partial government shutdown. De Niro, 80, warns democracy cannot be taken for granted.

articles.title: Oklahoma girls’ basketball team returns championship after realizing they lost
articles.trailText: Scoreboard error gave Academy of Classical Christian Studies team the edge over Apache high school
articles.summary: After discovering a scoreboard error that had given them a 44-43 win, Academy of Classical Christian Studies girls basketball coach Brendan King reviewed tape and found they’d actually lost 43-42 to Apache High. In an unprecedented appeal to the Oklahoma Secondary School Activities Association, they surrendered their title despite rules barring post-game reversals. The association upheld their request and handed the championship plaque to Apache. Apache coach Amy Merriweather praised their integrity, saying it proved there are still good people, while Academy players called it a lesson in honesty over victory.

articles.title: ‘The worst of all time’: Trump rails against ‘super bad’ Time magazine cover
articles.trailText: Despite the glowing story, the cover earned the ire of the US president with criticism of his appearance
articles.summary: Time magazine’s 10 November cover praising Trump’s Gaza ceasefire role sparked his ire on Truth Social, calling the sun-backlit, low-angle image “super bad” and “worst of all time” for obscuring his hair. The Graeme Sloane photo’s unflattering chin prompted Gavin Newsom to mock-pixelate it, and Russia’s MFA spokeswoman Maria Zakharova condemned Time’s choice as malicious. Guardian picture editor Carly Earl defended its heroic, contemplative framing but admitted it’s unflattering. Trump, who featured on four covers last year and even urged removal of mocked-up cover displays at his golf clubs, questioned the editors’ motives. The Guardian approached Time for comment.

articles.title: US revokes six foreigners’ visas over social media comments criticizing Charlie Kirk
articles.trailText: State department says it has ‘no obligation’ to host foreign nationals who ‘celebrate heinous’ death of far-right activist
articles.summary: The US State Department has revoked visas for six foreign nationals from Argentina, Brazil, Germany, Mexico, Paraguay and South Africa after they posted on social media celebrating Charlie Kirk’s assassination. In a thread on X, officials justified removing “aliens” who “celebrated the heinous” killing of an American and warned that Trump and Secretary of State Marco Rubio will enforce immigration laws to protect US citizens. This follows broader policies vetting visitors’ public social accounts, targeting foreign students in Gaza protests, and revoking visas for a South African ambassador, Mahmoud Abbas and British duo Bob Vylan—a move civil rights groups decry as a free‐speech violation.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Administration will produce list of ‘Democrat programs’ to be closed due to shutdown
articles.trailText: Mike Johnson says he won’t negotiate with Democrats as government shutdown enters second week. Key US politics stories from 14 October 2025
articles.summary: Amid a 14-day federal shutdown, Trump’s administration will deliver a list of “Democrat programs” to be permanently closed after the Senate’s eighth failed rescue effort; 4,108 federal workers have been laid off—the first large-scale firings in a shutdown. Speaker Mike Johnson refuses bipartisan talks and has redirected Pentagon funds to cover troop pay. Elsewhere, Trump posthumously awarded Charlie Kirk the Presidential Medal of Freedom; ordered a US strike off Venezuela killing six; revoked visas of 50 Mexican officials; threatened to strip World Cup and Olympic sites from blue cities; North Carolina Republicans moved to add a GOP congressional seat; Marjorie Taylor Greene attacked fellow Republicans as “weak”; and Trump warned he could cut Argentina aid if Javier Milei loses upcoming elections.

articles.title: US Senate again rejects Republican plan to end government shutdown
articles.trailText: Eighth Senate vote fails on 49-45 tally as Congress remains deadlocked on legislation amid now two-week shutdown
articles.summary: In its eighth attempt, the Senate rejected a GOP stopgap funding bill to end the two-week federal shutdown, failing 49–45 due to unchanged votes. Republicans, led by Speaker Mike Johnson, refuse to negotiate with Democrats, defending Trump’s Pentagon reallocation to pay troops, while Dems accuse them of prioritizing an Argentina bailout over healthcare subsidies. The stalemate risks spiking ACA premiums if subsidies lapse, has furloughed 4,000+ workers and drawn criticism from moderate Republicans and senators from MD and VA.

articles.title: Trump posthumously awards Charlie Kirk the Presidential Medal of Freedom
articles.trailText: President presented award to Kirk’s widow, Erika, on what would have been the far-right commentator’s 32nd birthday
articles.summary: President Trump posthumously awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom to slain far-right commentator Charlie Kirk, shot at a Utah Valley University event in September, presenting it to his widow Erika at the White House on his 32nd birthday. Kirk, founder of Turning Point USA, mobilized young conservatives behind Trump but drew criticism for anti-LGBTQ remarks and calling the 1964 Civil Rights Act a “mistake.” The ceremony included visa revocations for six foreigners who mocked Kirk’s assassination, raising free-speech concerns. Erika Kirk praised his faith and presidential ambitions. Trump used the event to denounce “far-left” violence and justify National Guard deployments in Democratic cities.

articles.title: Trump says six were killed in US strike on another boat allegedly carrying drugs near Venezuela
articles.trailText: UN has condemned US strikes on small boats it believes to be trafficking drugs as extrajudicial executions
articles.summary: Donald Trump announced a US strike on a small boat off Venezuela, killing six male ‘narcoterrorists’ suspected of drug trafficking. Conducted in international waters at Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s order, and accompanied by video footage, it is the fifth deadly Caribbean strike since September amid a declared “non-international armed conflict” with cartels. An internal memo reclassified drug networks as non-state armed groups. The White House defends targeting Tren de Aragua to curb drug flows, but UN experts decry extrajudicial executions. Colombia’s president warns one boat held Colombians, and a Senate bid to block further strikes without approval failed.

articles.title: Trump says Hamas will be forced to disarm or ‘we will disarm them’
articles.trailText: US president says it should take place in a ‘reasonable period of time’ amid questions over group’s status
articles.summary: On Tuesday President Trump warned that Hamas must disarm within a "reasonable period" under his 20-point Gaza peace deal or face forcible, potentially violent, disarmament. Although he brokered a ceasefire, Trump allowed Hamas a limited role in security until phase two begins, contradicting his blueprint's call for the group’s complete withdrawal. The White House’s direct talks—led by envoys Jared Kushner and Steve Witkoff—and regional mediators sealed the agreement, linked to a hostage-exchange initiative. Meanwhile, Hamas released footage of executions targeting alleged collaborators, underscoring Gaza’s instability. Trump stressed a phased cleanup and reconstruction plan, promising US oversight to prevent renewed Israel-Hamas conflict.

articles.title: Newsom vetoes California bill banning cookware with Pfas, ‘forever chemicals’
articles.trailText: Governor says bill would cause sudden product shift, sparking debate among chefs, lawmakers and environmentalists
articles.summary: Gov. Gavin Newsom vetoed a bill that would ban the sale of cookware and consumer goods with intentionally added PFAS by 2030, citing concerns over a “sizable and rapid shift” in product availability and affordability. The measure, backed by environmental groups, aimed to phase out nonstick cookware, cleaning supplies, food packaging and more due to PFAS’s links to cancer, high cholesterol and reproductive issues. Celebrity chefs Thomas Keller and Rachael Ray had opposed the ban, urging education over elimination, while Sen. Ben Allen vows to refine safer alternatives. Newsom also vetoed other racial justice bills while approving related studies.

articles.title: Chicago TV producer’s arrest in Ice raid ‘alarming and horrifying’, lawyers say
articles.trailText: Attorneys for Debbie Brockman, released with no charges, deny agent’s claim she ‘threw objects’ at border patrol car
articles.summary: WGN TV producer Debbie Brockman, a US citizen, was forcibly detained by ICE agents in Chicago’s Lincoln Square during a raid, led to the ground, handcuffed and put in an unmarked van amid federal claims she threw objects at a border-patrol vehicle. Held seven hours, she was released without charges. Her attorneys say she was walking to her bus stop, not working, and was violently assaulted—battered, handcuffed and partially stripped—contradicting ICE’s account. They plan legal action, warning against unchecked federal enforcement. DHS and CBP declined comment. Brad Thomson calls the treatment “alarming and horrifying.”

articles.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene slams party and calls Republican men in Congress ‘weak’
articles.trailText: In Washington Post interview, the far-right congresswoman said GOP men are ‘afraid of strong Republican women’
articles.summary: Far-right Georgia Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene publicly brands GOP men—including Speaker Mike Johnson—as “weak” and “afraid of strong Republican women.” In a Washington Post interview, she criticizes her party’s handling of the government shutdown, demands abolishing the Senate’s 60-vote filibuster to advance a spending bill, and sides with Democrats on healthcare subsidies. Greene also presses for Justice Department transparency on Jeffrey Epstein files, denounces the marginalization of figures like Elise Stefanik, and contrasts punitive treatment of women with rewards for male loyalists.

articles.title: US supreme court rejects Alex Jones appeal over $1.4bn defamation penalty
articles.trailText: Infowars founder and conspiracy theorist had been ordered to pay because of false claims about Sandy Hook massacre
articles.summary: The US Supreme Court denied Alex Jones’s appeal, upholding a $1.4bn defamation and emotional distress judgment awarded to Sandy Hook families for false claims that the 2012 Newtown massacre was a hoax. Jones argued liability without trial and a crippling “financial death penalty” on his media reach. The court issued no explanation. Jones and Infowars’ parent company declared bankruptcy in 2022, amid findings of asset transfers to shield millions from creditors. The verdict stems from lawsuits in Connecticut and Texas. The victims’ attorney hailed the decision as accountability for threats and harassment spurred by Jones’s lies and vowed to enforce the historic verdict.

articles.title: Obama backs California’s Proposition 50 to counter Texas redistricting
articles.trailText: Former president urges support for the ballot measure Democrats say could add up to five US House seats
articles.summary: Former President Barack Obama released an ad urging California voters to back Prop 50, a November ballot measure allowing lawmakers to redraw congressional districts and potentially add up to five Democratic seats. Championed by Gov. Gavin Newsom to counter a Republican-led redistricting effort in Texas tied to Donald Trump, Prop 50 seeks independent mapmaking and a level electoral playing field. Obama warns Republicans aim to rig future elections, calls voters to return ballots immediately, and cites Emerson polling showing 51% support vs. 34% opposition, with 15% undecided.

articles.title: ‘Instability and whiplash’ as CDC slashes 1,300 jobs before reinstating half
articles.trailText: Trump administration says 700 notices were sent in error, while former top CDC officer says ‘they didn’t think through what they were doing’
articles.summary: Over 1,300 CDC staff got layoff notices as the Trump administration slashed offices, then reinstated half after public outcry, erasing entire MMWR, global health, suicide prevention teams, “disease detectives”; HR and IRB staff remain cut. Administration attributes 700 notices to errors; 600 staff remain terminated, HHS silent on documentation. Cuts hamper outbreak tracking, ethics review, congressional liaison and mental health support. Former CMO Debra Houry warns of “instability and whiplash,” diminished capacity amid measles surge, and urges Congress to oversee and back the agency.

articles.title: US airports refuse to air Kristi Noem video blaming Democrats for shutdown
articles.trailText: Airports in Phoenix, Las Vegas, Seattle and elsewhere cite laws barring partisan political content at TSA checkpoints
articles.summary: Major US airports—including Phoenix Sky Harbor, Harry Reid (Las Vegas), Seattle–Tacoma, Portland, Charlotte Douglas and Westchester County—have refused to air DHS Secretary Kristi Noem’s video blaming Democrats for the federal shutdown at TSA checkpoints. Citing the Hatch Act and state laws barring partisan political content on public assets, each authority said the PSA violated their neutral‐information policies. Noem’s footage claims Democratic “refusal” to fund the government has left TSA staff working without pay. Westchester called the video inappropriate, while DHS assistant secretary Tricia McLaughlin echoed the party-blame rhetoric. Airports urged bipartisan resolution and vowed support for unpaid employees.

articles.title: North Carolina Republicans will redraw maps to gain extra seat in Congress
articles.trailText: State is the latest in the US conducting mid-decade gerrymandering to favor one party before the midterms
articles.summary: Republican leaders in North Carolina plan an October legislative session to redraw the state’s 14 congressional districts, adding a seat to bolster GOP control ahead of the 2026 midterms. Mirroring Texas’s August move to pick up five Republican seats, and in response to California’s ballot measure to expand Democratic representation, House Speaker Destin Hall and Senate leader Phil Berger accuse Democrats and Gov. Gavin Newsom of partisan redistricting. Newsom condemned the effort on X, while North Carolina Democrats organise a rally to protest what they call election rigging.

articles.title: Democrats launch bid to fund nutrition program for low-income women and kids amid shutdown
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Congressional Democrats set to introduce bill to shore up the Women, Infants, and Children (WIC) program
articles.summary: Amid a government shutdown risking the Women, Infants, and Children (WIC) nutrition program—used by 40% of US infants and serving 6.7 million women and children monthly—House Democrats led by Reps. Bobby Scott and Suzanne Bonamici unveiled the WIC Benefits Protection Act. The bill, with about 50 Democratic co-sponsors, would amend the Child Nutrition Act to guarantee mandatory funding starting in FY2026, shielding WIC’s $7.2 billion annual budget from shutdown lapses. States are already scaling back services; the administration’s $300 million tariff patch is temporary.

articles.title: California braces as fierce storm batters fire-ravaged hillsides
articles.trailText: Evacuations ordered in about 115 Los Angeles area homes as heavy rain and wind raise fears of mudslides and flooding
articles.summary: California’s wildfire-scarred hillsides faced a rare October onslaught as a potent Pacific storm delivered heavy rain, gusty winds and risks of mudslides and flooding across Los Angeles and Santa Barbara counties. Authorities ordered about 115 homes evacuated in Pacific Palisades and Mandeville Canyon, sites of January’s deadly inferno, while flash-flood and shelter-in-place warnings hit burned zones. Downpours, hydroplaning accidents, power outages affecting over 16,000 customers and road closures including state Route 27 underscored unpredictability. The National Weather Service warned up to 4 in of rain, high winds, possible tornadoes and debris flows, with teams and helicopters on standby as snow blanketed the Sierra Nevadas.

articles.title: Mitt Romney’s sister-in-law found dead next to parking garage in California
articles.trailText: Carrie Romney either fell or jumped, and foul play did not appear to be a factor, officials said
articles.summary: Carrie Romney, 64, sister-in-law of Utah Senator and ex-Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney, was found dead Friday by a Valencia, California parking garage. Officials said she either fell or jumped and early investigation shows no foul play; the LA County medical examiner deferred cause pending toxicology tests. Mitt Romney released a statement lamenting her loss and requesting privacy. Carrie married George 'Scott' Romney in 2016; he filed for divorce in June after eight years together. Scott, 84, is a Michigan lawyer and father of GOP chair Ronna Romney McDaniel. Her body was discovered around 8:30am near the five-level garage; her car had been spotted at the scene.

articles.title: ‘I am the only one that matters’: Trump deals praise and insults at Gaza summit
articles.trailText: Self-styled world’s greatest peacemaker calls Meloni ‘beautiful’ and Erdoğan a ‘friend’, but takes jab at Iraqi and Canadian leaders
articles.summary: At Monday’s Sharm el-Sheikh Gaza summit, a tardy Trump—arriving two hours late—declared himself the world’s greatest peacemaker and alternated between flattery and barbs: praising UAE’s Sheikh Mansour (“bundles of cash”), Italy’s Meloni (“beautiful”), Turkey’s Erdoğan (“tough friend”), Egypt’s al-Sisi (“strong leader”), and Hungary’s Orbán (“only one that matters”); quipping to Canada’s PM that he’d promoted him to president; slamming Iraq’s leader over oil abundance; relegating UK’s Starmer to his shadow; lampooning Macron’s seat choice. Pakistan’s Shehbaz Sharif alone out-praised him; Iran stayed away.

articles.title: ‘It’s a big unknown’: California Democrat on Trump’s 100% tariff plan for foreign movies
articles.trailText: Laura Friedman, who spent 20 years in Hollywood before winning her House seat, says film industry needs help but president’s vague policy idea is baffling
articles.summary: Representative Laura Friedman, a former Hollywood production VP, warns that President Trump’s plan to impose a 100% tariff on films made abroad risks raising consumer prices and misunderstands why studios—driven away by pandemic slowdowns, 2023 guild strikes and LA wildfires—relocate to Georgia, New Mexico and overseas. The only House member with a film background, Friedman proposes a national film tax credit to retain jobs, support creative labor and revive California production, arguing tariffs on intellectual property are unclear and could penalize US shoots and foreign imports alike.

articles.title: China says it will ‘fight to end’ after US said it was trying to hurt world economy
articles.trailText: Commerce ministry says US is ‘threatening to intimidate’ with plans for new Trump tariffs on exports
articles.summary: China’s commerce ministry accused the US of threatening intimidation by planning new Trump-era tariffs on Chinese exports and vowed to “fight to the end” in trade talks after Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said Beijing sought to “pull everybody else down” by harming the global economy. The latest tit-for-tat measures—mutual port fees on cargo ships, rare earth export controls, and looming 100% tariffs from Nov 1—underscore record tariff levels (58% US, 33% China) paused until Nov 10. Both sides held working-level talks, clouding prospects for a Trump-Xi meeting at APEC.

articles.title: Israelis and Palestinians celebrate but key truce issues remain | First Thing
articles.trailText: UN says Gaza still needs ‘lifesaving aid’ as world leaders gather in Sharm el-Sheikh to discuss 20-point proposal. Plus, nude cyclists protest against national guard deployment
articles.summary: Hamas released the final 20 living hostages in Gaza in a prisoner swap that freed nearly 2,000 Palestinians, marking a rare moment of relief as world leaders convened in Sharm el-Sheikh to negotiate extending a limited Gaza truce into lasting peace. The ceasefire has halted a two-year Israeli offensive that killed almost 68,000, but key issues—including Hamas disarmament, Gaza governance, and reconstruction—remain unresolved. Egyptian President Sisi urged the Gaza war be the region’s last, while US President Trump proclaimed “peace at long last,” highlighting the truce’s precarious nature.

articles.title: Private equity takeover of hospitals led to rise in Medicare emergency patient deaths, says study
articles.trailText: Study found seven more deaths per 10,000 patients in private equity hospitals’ versus non-private equity hospitals
articles.summary: Study in Annals of Internal Medicine finds that private equity-owned hospitals see seven more deaths per 10,000 Medicare emergency visits compared to controls, amounting to 700 excess deaths among 1 million visits. Private equity hospitals cut ER staff by 11.6% and salaries by 18.2%, transfer 12% more high-risk patients out, and have lower staffing and pay. Experts warn cost-cutting undermines care quality, calls for policy to hold PE firms accountable have stalled amid political ties and legal protections insulating firms. This echoes prior findings of worse surgical complications, infections and nursing home mortality under private equity ownership.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: President declares ‘peace in the Middle East’ despite many barriers remaining
articles.trailText: Donald Trump has vowed to use the power of his presidency to ensure that Israel recognises it has achieved ‘all that it can by force of arms’. Key US politics stories from 13 October 2025
articles.summary: Donald Trump declared “peace in the Middle East” after brokering a Gaza ceasefire in Sharm el-Sheikh with Israel, Egypt and Hamas, culminating in the release of the last 20 hostages and 1,968 Palestinian detainees. He hailed a “new Middle East” and signaled talks on next steps—including potential Iran rapprochement—have begun, though Hamas’s disarmament and Israeli withdrawal remain unresolved. Other US political developments: media resist new Pentagon briefing rules, senators stalemate over the government shutdown, Obama criticizes corporate deals with Trump, veterans face arrests in anti-deportation protests, CDC reverses mass firings, museums close amid the shutdown, nude protests in Portland and markets edge up on easing US-China tensions.

articles.title: US news outlets refuse to sign new Pentagon rules to report only official information
articles.trailText: Defense department policy requires outlets to vow not to obtain unauthorized files and restricts access to some areas
articles.summary: Several leading outlets, including the Washington Post, New York Times, CNN, the Atlantic, the Guardian, Reuters, AP, NPR, HuffPost and Breaking Defense, refuse to sign a Pentagon policy introduced by Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth requiring press pledges not to obtain unauthorized material and restricting access unless escorted. Those organizations argue the measure infringes First Amendment protections and public's right to know. Hegseth responded on social media with dismissive emojis and mock guidance. The Pentagon says the pledge is voluntary and vital for security, while the Pentagon Press Association labels it intimidating and unconstitutional. One America News accepted; Newsmax declined.

articles.title: Obama takes aim at companies cutting deals with Trump: ‘We have capacity to take a stand’
articles.trailText: Universities, law firms and businesses that have changed course should have stood by convictions, says ex-president
articles.summary: On Marc Maron's final WTF podcast, Barack Obama criticized universities, law firms and businesses that compromised with the Trump administration—from dropping DEI targets to pledging free legal services and curbing campus antisemitism—urging them to uphold academic independence, use endowments to absorb potential federal grant losses and defend diversity hiring. He warned against moral posturing, stressed acknowledging fallibility, and highlighted integrity’s price. Citing examples like Disney’s rebranded inclusion program, he called on institutions to resist political pressure and “take a stand” for convictions rather than yield to White House demands.

articles.title: Majority of special education staff in US education department laid off – report
articles.trailText: Layoffs ‘decimating’ office responsible for protecting rights of infants, children and youth with disabilities, says worker
articles.summary: Multiple outlets (CNN, NPR and K-12 Dive) report 466 layoffs at the US Education Department amid a funding lapse that hit most staff in the Office of Special Education and Rehabilitative Services, which oversees programs for children and adults with disabilities. Employees warn cuts “decimating” safeguards for infants, children and youth with disabilities. The National Association of State Directors of Special Education and the Council for Exceptional Children warn that rolling back IDEA support will deprive students of free, appropriate public education. This follows March’s broader 1,300-job reduction under Secretary Linda McMahon.

articles.title: ‘Cavalier and aggressive’: why are border agents flooding into US cities?
articles.trailText: Border agents have become a key force in Trump’s migrant crackdown – operating far from their traditional rural range
articles.summary: Under Trump’s mass deportation push, CBP’s Border Patrol—led by hardliner Gregory Bovino—has deployed thousands of agents into urban centers far beyond the southwest border’s rural zones, invoking a 1946 law permitting warrantless searches within 100 miles of any international boundary. Agents have carried out military-style raids in Chicago—including a shooting—horse patrols in LA parks, highway stops in California’s Central Valley and checkpoints in Washington, DC. Lawyers warn they lack community-policing training, flout Fourth Amendment limits and bring a cavalier, aggressive culture into cities, triggering lawsuits over rights violations.

articles.title: Republican and Democratic senators dig in heels over government shutdown
articles.trailText: Lindsey Graham says closure won’t push him to meet Democrats’ demands on Obama-era healthcare subsidies
articles.summary: Lindsey Graham (R-SC) and Mark Kelly (D-AZ) remain entrenched as the US government shutdown nears two weeks. On Meet the Press, Graham said he’s ready to reopen the government immediately but won’t agree to restore $350 billion in Obama-era ACA subsidies, while Kelly urged genuine talks to avoid a healthcare “cliff” for millions. Senate stopgap funding bills have repeatedly failed to muster 60 votes. Meanwhile, VP JD Vance warned of deepening federal workforce cuts—over 4,000 layoffs identified—and Speaker Mike Johnson called Democrats’ subsidy demands “impossible,” blaming them for stalling resolution.

articles.title: US Smithsonian museums and National Zoo close due to government shutdown
articles.trailText: Washington DC-based institution says it’ll temporarily close museums and research centers in response to shutdown
articles.summary: Facing the 13-day government shutdown, the Smithsonian Institution has closed all 21 museums, 14 research centers and the National Zoo, pausing in-person visits while keeping digital archives online. Staff continue essential animal care at the Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute, but live cameras are off. The move halts operations funded chiefly (62%) by federal appropriations, echoing a 2019 shutdown’s $3.4m revenue loss. The closure follows White House scrutiny over exhibit content ahead of the US’s 250th anniversary, and large-scale federal furloughs affecting 750,000 workers.

articles.title: Tennessee community mourns 16 killed in munitions plant explosion
articles.trailText: Cause of explosion at Accurate Energetic Systems that leveled building is unknown but foul play not ruled out
articles.summary: In Bucksnort, TN, an early Friday blast at Accurate Energetic Systems munitions plant leveled the AES headquarters, killing 16 workers. On Sunday, some 200 residents gathered in a candlelight vigil on the Humphreys County courthouse lawn, singing hymns as Sheriff Chris Davis and Gov. Bill Lee urged community solidarity. Authorities shifted from rescue to recovery, deploying rapid DNA to identify remains amid an undetermined cause that hasn’t ruled out foul play. Local churches held intimate prayer services supported by Billy Graham Ministries, drawing standing-room-only crowds as neighbors comforted grieving families.

articles.title: Firings of hundreds of CDC employees reportedly reversed
articles.trailText: Department of Health and Human Services rescinds more than half of the 1,300 termination notices it sent, reports say
articles.summary: The Department of Health and Human Services has reversed over half of the 1,300 termination notices sent to CDC staff amid the government shutdown, reinstating hundreds of employees—including about 70 Epidemic Intelligence Service “disease detectives” and Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report editors—while roughly 600 remain laid off. Officials attribute the rescissions to a coding error and incorrect notifications. The AFGE has filed suit to block reductions across federal agencies affecting more than 4,000 workers, with a San Francisco court set to hear arguments this week. These moves add to broader turmoil at the CDC, marked by leadership upheaval, political interference and a deadly 2025 shooting at its headquarters.

articles.title: Nor’easter brings flooding to US east coast as storm sweeps away homes in Alaska
articles.trailText: Areas from the Carolinas to New England see flooding and high winds, while flooding in Alaska carries away homes
articles.summary: A slow-moving nor’easter sweeping from the Carolinas to New England triggered flooding, high winds and state of emergency declarations in New Jersey and eight New York counties, forcing Columbus Day parade cancellation and National Guard activation in Delaware. Coastal highways flooded in the Outer Banks; Charleston, Georgetown County and Myrtle Beach saw widespread inundation. Meanwhile, in western Alaska, Typhoon Halong remnants lashed remote villages Kipnuk and Kwigillingok, ripping homes off foundations and leaving up to 20 people unaccounted for. Governor Dunleavy extended disaster declarations to Yup’ik, Pribilof Island and Lower Kuskokwim districts as rescue aircraft scoured isolated boardwalk and boat-access communities.

articles.title: Why has US-China trade war restarted and how have markets reacted?
articles.trailText: Trump has threatened 100% tariffs after Beijing’s fresh curbs on rare earths, a month before deadline to agree a deal
articles.summary: China reinstated export curbs on rare earth minerals—over 90% of processed supply���citing national security, prompting President Trump to levy 100% tariffs on all US-bound Chinese goods, scuttling ongoing trade talks. This escalation follows US export controls on semiconductor equipment. Average US-China tariffs now exceed 50% and 30% respectively. A TikTok divestment deal and congressional visit had hinted at détente, but both sides have since re-escalated, and Trump canceled plans to meet Xi at APEC. Markets initially plunged, rebounded on conciliatory US rhetoric; Beijing has vowed countermeasures. Deadline for a deal looms November 10.

articles.title: The populist playbook: Democratic US Senate candidate seeks to replicate Mamdani’s success
articles.trailText: Abdul El-Sayed’s bid for Michigan senator centers on bold leftwing populism similar to the NYC mayoral candidate
articles.summary: Abdul El-Sayed, a Sanders-endorsed Democrat, is mounting a leftwing populist bid for Michigan’s 2026 US Senate primary, echoing Zohran Mamdani’s NYC playbook. Pitching Medicare for All, billionaire taxes, anti-monopoly laws and $700m in medical-debt relief, he vows a combative style—“when they go low … we take them to the mud and choke them out.” He also sharpens criticism of Israel’s Gaza campaign, labeling it “genocide.” He faces Rep. Haley Stevens and state Sen. Mallory McMorrow, risking a split in outsider-leaning voters. El-Sayed’s win could prove progressive economics electable in swing states and reshape the 2028 presidential race.

articles.title: Growing number of US veterans face arrest over Ice raid protests
articles.trailText: Veterans are facing federal charges after protesting Ice sweeps and Trump’s national guard deployments. The justice department claims the veterans were violent
articles.summary: US military veterans have increasingly been arrested, injured and prosecuted for protests against ICE raids and Trump’s expanded National Guard deployments. The Guardian found eight cases, including 70-year-old veteran Dana Briggs charged with felony assault after video showed an ICE agent knocking him down, and former Marine John Cerrone tackled and held in unsanitary conditions. Groups like Common Defense decry “state-sanctioned abuse,” while the Justice Department and White House defend ICE, citing a surge in officer assaults. In Chicago, a federal judge temporarily barred ICE from using riot-control weapons, and lawmakers such as Senator Tammy Duckworth criticized paramilitary tactics at VA facilities.

articles.title: Advocate says ex-priest charged with raping disabled child should now be put on clergy-abuser list
articles.trailText: Group says Mark Francis Ford’s work history also has several red flags, including entering a program known for treating pedophilia, though he claimed he was there due to problematic spending
articles.summary: Mark Francis Ford, a 64-year-old former Vincentian priest, is accused of raping a disabled boy he met through New Orleans’ God’s Special Children program between 2004 and 2014. Ford previously served in Dallas, Gallup and New Orleans dioceses after his 1992 ordination, disappeared from the Official Catholic Directory during stints at a Servants of the Paraclete treatment center, and laicized in 2007. Church accountability group BishopAccountability.org calls for Ford’s addition to clergy‐abuser lists. Arrested in Indiana in September on first-degree rape, kidnapping and sexual battery charges, he faces mandatory life imprisonment if convicted.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Insurrection Act on the cards, says Vance, as president touts peace in the Middle East
articles.trailText: JD Vance confirms White House seriously considering invoking 1807 insurrection act as Trump heads to Israel.
articles.summary: The Trump administration is weighing emergency powers, including invoking the 1807 Insurrection Act to deploy troops on US soil amid rising urban crime, JD Vance told NBC’s Meet the Press. As legal pushback looms, President Trump flew to Israel to herald a major Gaza peace deal, declare the war over and oversee the release of hostages. In parallel, Beijing warned of retaliation if he imposes 100% tariffs on Chinese imports by November. Officials are also mulling selling portions of the $1.6 trn student‐loan portfolio and MAGA figures back El Salvador’s Bukele in calls to impeach US judges, even as border agents surge into US cities under the migrant crackdown.

articles.title: Trump ‘looking at all options’ amid threats to invoke Insurrection Act, Vance says
articles.trailText: Vice-president calls crime ‘out of control’ in US cities as Trump faces legal battles for use of federal forces
articles.summary: On NBC’s Meet the Press, VP JD Vance confirmed that President Trump is weighing the 1807 Insurrection Act—permitting domestic deployment of national guard and military forces—to combat ‘out of control’ crime in Democratic-run cities like Chicago. Federal courts have blocked recent deployments in Illinois and Oregon, yet Trump has vowed he’d invoke the Act if necessary. Vance decried Chicago’s ‘lawlessness’ despite falling violent crime rates and hinted at prosecuting Governor JB Pritzker. Partisan clashes over the day-12 federal shutdown also escalated.

articles.title: Luigi Mangione’s lawyers seek dismissal of federal charges in healthcare CEO killing
articles.trailText: Attorneys push to drop death penalty eligibility due to legal threshold and claim Mangione was not read his rights
articles.summary: Lawyers for Luigi Mangione asked a federal judge to dismiss charges, including the sole death-penalty count, arguing it falls below the legal threshold. They also seek suppression of a gun and ammunition seized without a warrant at a Pennsylvania McDonald’s and contend he wasn’t read his Miranda rights. Mangione has pleaded not guilty to state and federal counts over the December 4 assassination of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson. Federal charges rest on a firearms-murder statute tied to “crimes of violence,” which his defense says misclassifies an alleged stalking offense. A judge already dismissed state terrorism charges. The case splits public opinion as supporters have raised over $1.3 million.

articles.title: China warns US of retaliation over Trump’s 100% tariffs threat
articles.trailText: Beijing says it will act if US president doesn’t stand down, while investors brace for trade war turmoil
articles.summary: Beijing’s commerce ministry warned it will retaliate if Donald Trump enforces his threat of 100% tariffs on Chinese imports and new controls on critical software by November 1, calling Washington’s approach irresponsible. Trump responded on Truth Social, urging calm and framing Xi’s stance as a fleeting misstep. Markets plunged—Dow futures fell nearly 900 points, wiping out about $2 trillion in US equity value—while FTSE 100 slid almost 1% and Bitcoin swung. Chinese officials emphasized that rare-earth export curbs aren’t bans, and analysts question whether Trump’s tariffs aim to escalate to de-escalate trade talks.

articles.title: Maga figures back Bukele’s call for Trump to crack down on US judges
articles.trailText: Experts say El Salvador president’s intervention comes as Trump is employing tactics used by autocrats abroad
articles.summary: El Salvador’s president Nayib Bukele urged Donald Trump to impeach “corrupt judges” in the US, a call embraced by MAGA figures including Elon Musk. Experts say this mirrors autocratic tactics used in Turkey, Hungary and Bukele’s own El Salvador to subvert judicial independence. Since returning to office, Trump, advisor Stephen Miller and former AG Pam Bondi have attacked judges like Oregon’s Karin Immergut for blocking national guard deployments. US Marshals data show record threats—562 threats against 395 federal judges—in 2025. Scholars warn such rhetoric aims to intimidate the judiciary, undermining checks on presidential power.

articles.title: Doge-ish comes to Florida: a DeSantis loyalist is going after ‘waste’ in Democratic cities
articles.trailText: Blaise Ingoglia was handpicked by the Republican Florida governor to lead an assault on municipal spending
articles.summary: Blaise Ingoglia, handpicked by Gov. DeSantis as Florida’s CFO, has launched “Doge-style” audits of Democratic cities, claiming $189m in waste. His agency dispatched armed officers to a retired couple’s home in Largo over a handwritten postcard, sparking free-speech concerns. Broward County disputes his calculations, citing unfunded state mandates. Similar audits of St. Petersburg, Orlando and several counties uncovered no major fraud—only small DEI or LGBTQ+ expenses. Critics argue the purge is politically driven, aimed at justifying property-tax reforms and bolstering DeSantis’s anti-local government agenda ahead of 2027.

articles.title: Trump officials reportedly consider selling student loan debt to private investors
articles.trailText: Experts say the move could eliminate the federal government’s power to cancel educational loans
articles.summary: Trump administration is exploring selling segments of the federal $1.6 trillion student loan portfolio—held by roughly 45 million borrowers—to private investors, reviving a first-term idea paused during Covid-19. Proponents hail it as shrinking government footprint; critics warn it would strip the Education Department’s cancellation authority, shift repayment oversight to profit-driven firms, end key borrower protections and raise legal and logistical hurdles. The plan ties to broader efforts to wind down the department and undo Biden-era forgiveness, though interest and cost-neutrality for taxpayers remain unclear.

articles.title: Chicagoans optimistic about annual marathon even amid violent Ice activity
articles.trailText: ‘We haven’t seen Ice attack any large-scale festivals directly,’ said a community leader from the Pilsen neighborhood
articles.summary: Amid Operation Midway Blitz and court blocks on ICE warrantless arrests and National Guard deployment challenges, Chicago’s annual marathon—starting and ending at Grant Park and spanning 29 neighborhoods along Lake Michigan shores—proceeds under cautious optimism. Mayor Brandon Johnson condemns federal overreach, while Pilsen-based Puño educates residents on rights, fields on-site volunteers, and asserts ICE hasn’t directly targeted mass events. Organizers, Tortugas Run Club founder David Ruiz and La Malinche café co-owner Héctor Aguirre report elevated fear among Latino runners but emphasize solidarity, community resilience and celebration despite aggressive anti-immigration actions.

articles.title: ‘Using us as political pawns’: federal workers reel over threats of firings and withheld back pay
articles.trailText: Employees express growing anxiety over their pay – and the future of their jobs – amid the US government shutdown
articles.summary: With no end to the shutdown, 750,000 Feds furloughed and hundreds of thousands working unpaid as Trump threatens to withhold back pay—despite the 2019 Fair Treatment Act—and warns of mass firings. OMB director Russell Vought announced layoffs have begun. Union leaders at the CDC, Labor Dept and TSA report anxiety and confusion over paychecks and job status, with some monitoring email daily for termination notices. Furloughed staff fear bills and childcare collapse, dreading capacity cuts under Project 2025. Unions and watchdogs demand legal back pay and clarity after a judge orders agencies to detail layoffs. Congress is urged to pass a budget.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: US troops will be paid despite shutdown, president claims
articles.trailText: Donald Trump says he has directed the defence secretary to release funds on 15 October. Key US politics stories from 11 October at a glance
articles.summary: President Donald Trump said on Truth Social he directed Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth to tap available funds to pay US troops on October 15 despite the federal shutdown that began October 1, accusing Democrats of holding national security hostage and demanding they reopen the government. Other highlights: Trump and Egypt’s al-Sisi to cochair a Gaza peace summit in Sharm El Sheikh with 20+ leaders; Democrats refuse to budge on healthcare; an appeals court barred deployment of Trump-sent Illinois National Guard troops; and MAGA allies used Charlie Kirk’s killing to brand critics the “radical left.”

articles.title: Chicago TV journalist pushed to ground and arrested during Ice raid, then later released
articles.trailText: Witnesses call arrest of video editor Debbie Brockman, a US citizen, by masked federal agents ‘absolutely horrifying’
articles.summary: During a North Side Chicago ICE raid in Lincoln Square, WGN video editor Debbie Brockman was violently wrestled to the ground by masked federal agents, handcuffed and detained in a van after allegedly throwing objects at a Border Patrol vehicle. Onlookers protested, calling agents “fascists,” and a second man was also held. Brockman, a US citizen, was released by 3pm with no charges filed. DHS cited obstruction and assault claims, while locals condemned the action as horrifying. A federal judge recently barred forceful tactics against journalists without probable cause.

articles.title: National guard troops in Illinois can remain but cannot be deployed yet, judge rules
articles.trailText: Troops can stay under federal control, as US senators Dick Durbin and Tammy Duckworth decry being barred access to Ice facility
articles.summary: An appeals court ruled that Trump’s National Guard troops in Illinois must remain under federal control but cannot be deployed to protect federal property or patrol, pausing their deployment until further hearings. Judge April Perry blocked the deployment after finding no danger of rebellion, citing Tenth and Fourteenth Amendment concerns. Meanwhile, Senators Durbin and Duckworth were barred access to a Broadview ICE facility, where a federal judge also ordered removal of an illegal perimeter fence. In Tennessee, guard troops patrol Memphis sites under Gov. Lee’s command. Similar deployments in other cities face state resistance and court blocks.

articles.title: Trump says military members will be paid despite government shutdown
articles.trailText: President claims he found a way to pay troops and directed Pentagon chief to release funds on 15 October
articles.summary: Trump declared on Truth Social he would use his commander-in-chief authority to direct defense secretary Pete Hegseth to release funds to pay over 1.3 million troops on Oct 15 despite the federal government shutdown beginning Oct 1, accusing Democrats of holding national security hostage. The shutdown has furloughed around 750,000 federal workers, although back pay is guaranteed once it ends under a 2019 law. Senate Democrats, led by Chuck Schumer, remain deadlocked over reopening legislation, while the White House has begun executing mass layoffs across agencies, prompting union challenges.

articles.title: Six people dead with multiple injured in three shootings at Mississippi homecoming weekends
articles.trailText: Four people were killed in an attack in Leland, while two were killed in Heidelberg, amid a third attack in Rolling Fork
articles.summary: Three separate homecoming shootings in Mississippi left six dead and 18 wounded. In Leland (Washington County) around midnight Friday, four people were killed and 16 injured, including four critically airlifted to Jackson, with no suspects in custody. In Heidelberg (Jasper County) a school event shooting killed two; authorities are seeking an 18-year-old suspect. In Rolling Fork (Sharkey County), two suspects were arrested after two people were wounded. State investigators are leading inquiries; local officials offered condolences but few details have been released.

articles.title: No survivors in Tennessee explosives factory blast, officials say
articles.trailText: Initial toll after explosions at plant near McEwen on Friday was believed to be 19 people but later revised to 18.
articles.summary: Authorities confirmed no survivors among the 18 workers unaccounted for after Friday’s massive blast at Accurate Energetic Systems’ 1,300-acre explosives plant near McEwen, Tennessee. Sheriff Chris Davis said DNA testing will be used to identify victims as recovery efforts replace rescue operations. The blast, felt miles away, leveled a production building at the Bucksnort facility, which manufactures ordnance for military, aerospace and demolition markets. FBI and ATF agents are investigating the cause amid complicating secondary explosions and high-security hazards. AES, which suffered a fatal ammo accident in 2014, expressed condolences to families and first responders.

articles.title: Before Trump, ‘Dreamers’ were shielded from deportation. Here’s what’s changed
articles.trailText: Until recently, Daca allowed undocumented immigrants brought to the US as children to live and work legally
articles.summary: Under Trump, DACA recipients face renewed uncertainty as the administration floats restarting initial application adjudications while simultaneously asserting the program confers no legal status and detaining about 20 known recipients. Launched in 2012, DACA shielded over 525,000 Dreamers��undocumented immigrants brought to the US as children—from deportation and granted work permits. Litigation halted initial petitions until a 5th Circuit ruling ordered resumption outside Texas. Texas Dreamers risk losing both work authorization and lawful presence. Advocates warn mixed signals erode protections, despite bipartisan support for a citizenship pathway and economic stakes.

articles.title: Joe Biden receiving radiation therapy for prostate cancer
articles.trailText: Former president was diagnosed in May with ‘aggressive form’ of cancer and was already taking hormone medication
articles.summary: In May former president Joe Biden, 82, was diagnosed with an aggressive prostate cancer that had metastasized to his bones; he’s now undergoing a five-week course of radiation therapy alongside ongoing oral hormone treatment. His office confirmed the decision, first reported by NBC, marking a new phase following his spring hormone regimen and September Mohs skin surgery. Biden, who left the White House in January after one term, remains optimistic about beating the disease as he approaches his 83rd birthday. Reuters contributed reporting.

articles.title: Democrats refuse to fold over shutdown as Republican outrage builds
articles.trailText: Party sticks to its guns on healthcare and says it’s willing to hold out – much to the delight of its progressive supporters
articles.summary: Senate Democrats led by Chuck Schumer have refused to reopen the government after a 10-day shutdown, demanding extensions of ACA premium tax credits, Medicaid cut reversals, restored PBS/NPR funding and limits on Trump-era budget rescissions. Republicans, including House Speaker Mike Johnson, have condemned Schumer’s stance as “sickening” and printed his remarks as posters, while OMB director Russ Vought has begun firing over 4,000 federal workers. Seven failed Senate votes underscore a 60-vote stalemate. Progressive groups cheer Democrats’ leverage, but Republicans insist funding must resume before negotiations. Legal challenges to layoffs loom as both sides dig in.

articles.title: ‘Reckless’ behavior and dystopian AI: disturbing picture of suspect in Pacific Palisades fire emerges
articles.trailText: Jonathan Rinderknecht, 29, allegedly used ChatGPT to create scenes of a city burning and to confide an obsession with fires
articles.summary: Uber driver Jonathan Rinderknecht, 29, is accused of igniting a small vegetation fire in Topanga State Park on New Year’s Day that smoldered then exploded into the Palisades fire, burning 23,000 acres, killing 12, destroying over 6,800 structures and causing billions in damage. Federal investigators used GPS data, video and court documents to show he poured fuel, followed and filmed responding firefighters, and used ChatGPT for dystopian fire imagery and to confess an obsession with blazes. Charged with property destruction by fire (5–20 years), he’s held in Orlando pending a 17 October hearing amid mental health concerns and flight risk.

articles.title: Trump is ‘obsessed’ with seeming pro-worker – but his actions suggest otherwise
articles.trailText: Agriculture and other sectors are suffering under the administration’s policies, adding up to a grim outlook
articles.summary: Despite championing blue-collar America, Trump’s second-term policies—forced unpaid leave for furloughed federal workers, mass RIFs and cuts via the “department of government efficiency,” plus the “big beautiful bill” tax-and-spending measures—have eroded worker conditions. Broad tariffs on inputs like steel, fertilizer and lumber raise consumer prices and trigger manufacturing job losses, while corporate exemptions (e.g., Apple) shield big business. Aggressive deportations strain agriculture, and H-2A visa wage cuts shift $2.46 bn from US laborers to landowners. With hiring frozen and long-term unemployment climbing, critics argue Trump’s rhetoric masks harmful anti-worker impacts.

articles.title: ‘Page one of the authoritarian playbook’: how Trump and allies are exploiting Kirk’s killing
articles.trailText: The president and his Maga allies have used the rightwing influencer’s killing to justify attacks on critics, experts say
articles.summary: After rightwing influencer Charlie Kirk’s killing, Trump and MAGA allies seized the event to intensify attacks on liberal critics—labeling them the “radical left” or “enemy within,” launching a RICO inquiry into George Soros, threatening ABC over Jimmy Kimmel, and indicting ex-FBI chief James Comey and NY AG Letitia James. Trump branded Antifa a “domestic terror” group and urged using federal troops in Democratic cities as “training grounds.” Legal scholars warn these tactics follow the “authoritarian playbook,” weaponizing DOJ powers, undermining civil society, and chilling dissent.

articles.title: The quiet toll of Trump’s legal immigration crackdown: ‘I’m trying to stay afloat’
articles.trailText: Immigration lawyer Kim Xavier says stricter enforcement and delays are leaving even legal immigrants in limbo and fear
articles.summary: Immigration attorney Kim Xavier warns that the Trump administration’s accelerated enforcement—such as the surprise $100,000 H-1B fee, proposed refugee cap cut from 125,000 to 7,500, expanded USCIS law-enforcement powers and tighter consular scrutiny—is generating severe delays and “soft denials” for renewals, leaving legal immigrants and their employers in limbo. Backlogs, opaque processes and truncated grace periods prevent travel or status extension, spreading pervasive uncertainty across family, tech and humanitarian pathways.

articles.title: Man will plead guilty to threatening Pride event after Charlie Kirk’s death
articles.trailText: Joshua Wayne Cole to admit in court to making online posts about shooting people at an LGBTQ+ parade in Texas
articles.summary: Texas man Joshua Wayne Cole will plead guilty to interstate threatening communications after online posts in September vowing to shoot people at the Abilene Pride parade in retaliation for the murder of conservative activist Charlie Kirk. Arrested mid-September when parade organizers alerted police to his “lock and load” and anti-LGBTQ “fairies” remarks on Facebook, Cole admitted the threats to the FBI, was jailed without bail, and faces up to five years. He signed plea papers on October 5; his hearing is set for October 16. Enhanced security and a university float withdrawal underscored organizers’ safety concerns.

articles.title: Trump completes ‘semiannual’ physical before traveling to Middle East
articles.trailText: White House had described doctor visit as ‘routine yearly checkup’ although president had annual physical in April
articles.summary: Donald Trump, 79, underwent a “semiannual physical” at Walter Reed on Oct 10 before a Middle East trip amid an Israel-Hamas ceasefire, despite an April annual check. His doctor, Sean Barbabella, reported advanced imaging and lab work, noted his cardiac age is 14 years younger than his real age and highlighted a 20-lb weight loss since 2020 and “exceptional health.” Barbabella also disclosed chronic venous insufficiency and attributed recent bruising to aspirin use and frequent handshakes. The White House has not released full results, saying the exam was standard health maintenance intended to quell rumors about the president’s wellbeing.

articles.title: White House announces federal worker layoffs as shutdown nears third week
articles.trailText: AFL-CIO fights issue in court as union leader warns of ‘devastating effects’ for Americans
articles.summary: Facing a third week of shutdown, OMB director Russell Vought initiated federal RIF notices, laying off roughly 4,000 employees across Commerce, Education, Energy, HHS, HUD, DHS and Treasury. Unions (AFGE, AFSCME, AFL-CIO) vow court battles, warning ‘devastating effects’ on vital services. Republicans blame Senate Democrats for the impasse over GOP funding; Democrats demand ACA tax-credit extensions, public media and Medicaid safeguards. Partial paychecks issued; military pay next at risk.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: layoffs for federal workers begin and president threatens China with tariffs
articles.trailText: President suggests layoffs will be ‘a lot’ and in Democrat areas as unions for federal workers take the matter to court – key US politics stories from 10 October at a glance
articles.summary: Mass layoffs of federal workers began Friday as the government shutdown drags into a third week, with White House budget director Russell Vought confirming substantial RIFs targeting Trump-critical Democrat districts; unions are suing. President Trump also threatened 100% tariffs on Chinese imports and may use visa restrictions and sanctions against supporters of the IMO net-zero framework. Meanwhile, National Guard troops patrolled Memphis despite being blocked from Chicago and awaiting a Portland court ruling, MIT rejected a policy-overhaul-for-funding proposal, and the administration slammed the Nobel committee for snubbing Trump.

articles.title: AstraZeneca makes deal with Trump to lower drug prices and avoid tariffs
articles.trailText: Company will sell some medicines at a discount to government’s Medicaid health plan in exchange for tariff relief
articles.summary: President Trump struck a tariff-for-price-cut deal with AstraZeneca, agreeing to most-favored-nation pricing for medicines sold to Medicaid—matching the lowest price among developed countries in exchange for relief from threatened US tariffs. The pact, mirroring a recent agreement with Pfizer, covers roughly 70 million low-income enrollees but excludes Medicare. Trump overstated potential savings with impossible claims of up to 1,000% cuts, prompting experts to call his math illogical and note modest Medicaid discounts yield limited consumer benefit. The administration aims to leverage tariff threats to curb America’s higher drug costs.

articles.title: Nineteen people feared dead after blast at Tennessee munitions plant
articles.trailText: Police chief calls explosion near Bucksnort, south-west of Nashville, ‘devastating’ and says ‘we have some deceased’
articles.summary: A massive explosion at Accurate Energetic Systems, a military munitions plant near Bucksnort, Tennessee, on Oct. 10 left 19 workers missing and feared dead, with confirmed fatalities though exact casualties unverified. Emergency crews, hampered by secondary blasts, scoured the rubble for survivors and evidence as sheriff Chris Davis described the site as ‘gone’ and urged residents to report debris. Homes miles away shook, with footage showing burning debris and damaged vehicles, and McEwen’s mayor called it a community tragedy. Governor Bill Lee mobilized state and federal agencies; the cause remains under investigation.

articles.title: Trump threatens 100% China tariffs as Beijing restricts rare-earth exports
articles.trailText: President accuses China of ‘very hostile’ moves and says additional tariffs could come on 1 November ‘or sooner’
articles.summary: President Donald Trump threatened 100% tariffs on Chinese imports starting November 1 to retaliate against Beijing’s expanded rare-earth export curbs critical to US industry, and announced controls on "critical software." He hinted a Xi Jinping meeting in South Korea may be canceled. The move rattled markets—S&P 500 fell 2.7%, Dow 1.9%, Nasdaq 3.6%, Nvidia down 5%—and revived trade-war risks. China supplies over 90% of processed rare earth elements for electric vehicles and aerospace and added five new export controls. Trump argues higher import taxes will boost federal revenue, though critics warn of inflationary fallout.

articles.title: The mortgage fraud case against Letitia James is ‘bupkis’, experts say
articles.trailText: ‘Are you really going to believe the attorney general of New York would commit this over $600 a year?’ says one lawyer
articles.summary: Legal experts say the indictment of NY Attorney General Letitia James for allegedly lying on a 2020 mortgage to rent her Norfolk second home is weak. Trump-appointed US attorney Lindsey Halligan pushed a grand jury despite career prosecutors finding no probable cause. Charges alleging bank fraud and false statements hinge on proving James knowingly violated a rider that may not bar rentals until a year later and includes exemptions. The $18,933 total gain—about $633 per year—underscores the low-stakes nature, boosting her selective-prosecution defense amid Trump’s public calls for her indictment. Observers call it “bupkis” and predict conviction will be an uphill battle.

articles.title: Trump officials cancel major solar project in latest hit to renewable energy
articles.trailText: Esmeralda 7 in Nevada would have produced enough energy to power 2m homes
articles.summary: The Trump administration canceled Esmeralda 7—a 6.2 GW solar-plus-storage network across 185 sq miles in southern Nevada by NextEra, Leeward, Arevia and Invenergy—after halting the project’s programmatic environmental review, imperiling power for nearly 2 M homes. Developers may reapply via individual filings. Approved under Biden, the plan paused without a final EIS. Trump’s Day One renewables moratorium, BLM chief Kathleen Sgamma’s oil-industry ties and a February order centralizing Interior vetoes, plus his Truth Social pledge to block wind and solar, underscore an administration-wide assault on clean energy.

articles.title: Letitia James criminally charged in Trump’s latest effort to punish rivals
articles.trailText: Prosecutor who sought charges was installed amid Trump frustrations with pace of investigations against rivals
articles.summary: A federal grand jury indicted New York Attorney General Letitia James on one count each of bank fraud and making false statements, alleging she misrepresented a Virginia home’s use to secure a 3 percent mortgage rate and saved $18,933. Newly installed Eastern District of Virginia U.S. Attorney Lindsey Halligan—brought in amid former President Trump’s frustrations with rival investigations—personally presented the case. James denounces the charges as baseless political retribution and is due in court Oct. 24. Democrats decry the move as Trump’s weaponization of the Justice Department amidst recent firings over other high-profile prosecutions.

articles.title: Sister Jean Dolores Schmidt, beloved Loyola University team chaplain, dies aged 106
articles.trailText: Schimdt remembered as ‘profound blessing’ after gaining attention for supporting Chicago school’s basketball team
articles.summary: Sister Jean Dolores Schmidt, 106, Loyola Chicago men's basketball chaplain, died. Born in 1919, she joined the Sisters of Charity in 1937 and became Loyola University Chicago staff in 1991, later advising the basketball team. Nicknamed “the booster shooter,” she provided spiritual guidance and game tips, gaining national fame during Loyola’s 2018 Final Four run. Her 2023 memoir Wake Up with Purpose! reflects her motto “worship, work, win.” Honors include induction into Loyola’s Athletics Hall of Fame (2017), a papal blessing at 100, and proclamations from Governor Pritzker and President Biden.

articles.title: New York Democrats rally behind Letitia James day after indictment for mortgage fraud
articles.trailText: Zohran Mamdani and Kathy Hochul among party members decrying president’s ‘weaponization’ of justice department
articles.summary: After a federal indictment by Trump-appointed prosecutor Lindsey Halligan on bank fraud and false statement charges over her 2020 Virginia home purchase, New York AG Letitia James is backed by Chuck Schumer, Kathy Hochul and Zohran Mamdani, who decry the ‘weaponization’ of the DOJ. Experts warn proving criminal intent is hard. The charges mirror James’s 2022 mortgage-fraud suit against the Trump Organization. James denies wrongdoing, pledges to challenge what she calls a vindictive, selective prosecution. She’s due in court Oct 24; trial hinges on intent vs honest error.

articles.title: This free speech group at Columbia is taking on Trump when the university won’t – and winning
articles.trailText: The Knight Institute is defending free speech at a school now synonymous with compromising on it
articles.summary: The Knight First Amendment Institute at Columbia, led by Jameel Jaffer, won a landmark federal ruling in Boston barring the Trump administration’s detention and attempted deportation of pro-Palestinian students—including green-card holder Mahmoud Khalil—as unconstitutional intimidation of free speech. The victory highlights a stark rift with Columbia’s own leadership, which settled antisemitism claims and restricted campus protests under pressure from Trump. Founded in 2016 with joint endowment funding, the Institute now spearheads high-profile First Amendment challenges, contrasting Columbia’s cautious compromise with its own defiant defense of constitutional rights.

articles.title: Virginia governor candidates trade barbs in fiery election debate
articles.trailText: Republican Winsome Earle-Sears presses Abigail Spanberger over fellow Democrat’s ‘abhorrent’ texts
articles.summary: In Virginia's sole gubernatorial debate at Norfolk State University, Democrat Abigail Spanberger, leading by four points, clashed with Republican Lt. Gov. Winsome Earle-Sears. Spanberger condemned fellow Democrat Jay Jones’s “abhorrent” violent texts but deflected on withdrawing her endorsement. Earle-Sears pressed cultural issues such as abortion and transgender locker-room access. Meanwhile in New Jersey, GOP Jack Ciattarelli plans to sue Democrat Mikie Sherrill for defamation after she blamed him for the opioid epidemic. Sherrill’s “gross” pork roll remark and release of unredacted naval records fueled further sparks.

articles.title: US retail workers and shoppers: tell us about the impact of Trump’s tariffs
articles.trailText: More than three in four store managers report more empty shelves since the Trump administration’s global tariff rollout, new poll suggests
articles.summary: Survey by warehouse-software firm GreyOrange finds 78% of US store managers reporting increased empty shelf space since the Trump administration’s global tariff rollout. Over half (51%) of managers say they’ve reduced headcount in the past six months, raising concerns about staffing levels and customer service. The article invites shoppers and frontline retail workers to share firsthand observations on product shortages, missing inventory categories, shelf replenishment delays and broader operational changes in US stores following the tariff hikes. It asks whether specific product lines—from electronics to household essentials—are disproportionately affected and how reduced staff numbers are impacting restocking times and shopper experience.

articles.title: Melania Trump says eight Ukrainian children seized by Russians have been reunited with their families
articles.trailText: First lady had pleaded for children in letter that Donald Trump delivered to Russian president at meeting in Alaska
articles.summary: After writing to Putin in August, First Lady Melania Trump announced that eight Ukrainian children, seized by Russian forces during the 2022 invasion, have been returned to their families within the past 24 hours. She said Putin responded to her letter, delivered by Donald Trump at their Alaska meeting, and established an "open channel" to address child welfare. The move follows an ICC arrest warrant accusing Putin of war crimes over child abductions. Donald Trump has criticized failure to end the Ukraine war swiftly.

articles.title: White House slams Trump’s perceived Nobel peace prize snub as ‘politics over peace’
articles.trailText: President has ‘heart of humanitarian’, spokesperson says after unsuccessful bid for prize amid Gaza ceasefire deal
articles.summary: White House communications director Steven Cheung accused the Norwegian Nobel Committee of choosing politics over peace after it awarded its 2025 Peace Prize to Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado instead of President Donald Trump, who campaigned—through a Gaza ceasefire deal and lobbying—for the honor. Special envoy Richard Grenell lamented the Nobel’s demise, while Lara Trump blamed ‘Trump Derangement Syndrome.’ The committee praised Machado’s fight against authoritarianism, implicitly critiquing Trump’s policies. Analysts foresee Trump’s personal grievance, and Russia’s Vladimir Putin decried the prize’s fading prestige.

articles.title: National guard troops seen on Memphis streets as Trump faces legal challenges
articles.trailText: Court to rule on whether president can deploy guard in Portland, Oregon, against mostly small, nightly protests
articles.summary: Federalized National Guard troops appeared in Memphis’s Pyramid area for the first time under Trump’s new domestic deployment plan, escorted by local police amid Gov. Lee’s support but no formal request from Memphis officials. Concurrently, a Ninth Circuit panel heard appeals over Trump’s authority to federalize 200 Oregon Guard soldiers for nightly protests in Portland—where demonstrators in costumes have gathered outside ICE facilities—challenging a federal judge’s temporary restraining order. Twenty states backing the administration and 24 opposing filed amicus briefs. At issue is the president’s power to override governors and use the Guard for civilian law enforcement in politically contested cities.

articles.title: Inside tech billionaire Peter Thiel’s off-the-record lectures about the antichrist
articles.trailText: The political svengali and investor has been giving lectures on ‘an evil king or tyrant … who appears in the end times’
articles.summary: Peter Thiel held four off-the-record waterfront lectures in San Francisco warning that a one-world state could be the biblical antichrist and that Armageddon will be stoked by global agencies, environmentalism and tech regulation. The PayPal and Palantir co-founder, a ‘small-o orthodox Christian’, drew on René Girard, Carl Schmitt and J.H. Newman to argue that figures from Greta Thunberg to the US government might incarnate an end-times tyrant, linking fear of existential risks and tech stagnation to his apocalyptic, politically influential worldview.

articles.title: US immigration enforcement using military hardware and tactics on civilians
articles.trailText: Agencies like Ice are way ahead of Donald Trump, who wants the military to treat cities like ‘training grounds’
articles.summary: Federal immigration agents have increasingly borrowed battlefield tactics—air assaults by helicopters, flash-bang grenades, armored vehicles and Predator drones—to execute domestic raids, notably a predawn ICE operation on a Chicago apartment complex that left homes uninhabitable and civilians zip-tied. Civil-rights groups, Democratic lawmakers and journalists wounded by chemical rounds during protests are suing for accountability, arguing these war-zone methods—echoed in Trump’s call to use U.S. cities as “training grounds”���violate constitutional rights and exceed typical police authority.

articles.title: First Thing: Hamas and Israel implement ceasefire
articles.trailText: Israeli troops begin pulling back from parts of Gaza. Plus, stories from survivors who were trapped on Everest
articles.summary: Following a two-year war that killed tens of thousands, Hamas and Israel enacted a ceasefire, with Israeli forces pulling back from Gaza and thousands of displaced Palestinians returning amid cautious relief and fear of renewed violence. Hospitals in Israel readied to receive hostages freed by Hamas, while the coalition government and Tel Aviv crowds celebrated. The deal’s turning point came during a UN sideline meeting in New York convened by the UAE and chaired by Donald Trump, who unveiled a 20-point peace plan. Elsewhere, Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado won the Nobel Peace Prize, and New York AG Letitia James was indicted in a Trump-driven bank fraud case.

articles.title: US farmers caught in Trump-China trade war – who’ll buy the soybeans?
articles.trailText: Tariffs have caused a Chinese exit from the soybean market – and midwestern farmers are waiting on a solution
articles.summary: In southern Minnesota, fifth-generation farmer Matt Purfeerst has 100,000 bushels of soybeans stranded in bins after China’s sudden exit from the $12 billion US market triggered by Trump’s tariffs. With input costs surging and prices swinging between $9 and $12 per bushel, producers await Trump’s promised relief—delayed by the government shutdown and blamed on Democratic inaction—while pressing for open trade deals, interim bailouts or expanded domestic crush outlets to avert financial collapse.

articles.title: US professors facing threats, firings and harassment over Charlie Kirk posts
articles.trailText: As many as 40 academics have been dismissed in aftermath of shooting, allegedly without due process
articles.summary: Following Charlie Kirk’s assassination, around 40 US professors have been fired, suspended or disciplined for sharing or criticizing his rhetoric without due process, creating a “climate of fear” on campuses, says the AAUP. Cases include Dr Karen Leader (Florida Atlantic) placed on leave for quoting Kirk, and Ball State’s Suzanne Swierc, fired after a private post mourning his death. Rightwing influencers like Jordan Chamberlain and LibsofTikTok amplified posts, pressuring universities. Professors such as Phillip Michael Hook won injunctive relief in lawsuits alleging First Amendment violations. Union leaders warn this wave of reprisals undermines academic freedom nationwide.

articles.title: Roman grave marker found in New Orleans yard left there by US soldier’s granddaughter
articles.trailText: Erin Scott O’Brien says grandfather Charles Paddock brought back artifact with him from second world war
articles.summary: A 1,900-year-old Roman grave marker unearthed in a New Orleans garden belonged to Sextus Congenius Verus and was brought home from Italy by WWII veteran Charles Paddock Jr. His granddaughter, Erin Scott O’Brien, inherited the inscribed marble tablet, treated it as yard art, then left it behind when she sold her house in 2018. Anthropologist Daniella Santoro and husband Aaron Lorenz recognized its Latin inscription, consulted archaeologists who linked it to a missing Civitavecchia museum piece, and handed it to the FBI art crime team for repatriation.

articles.title: US anti-fascism expert leaves country day after being blocked from flying to Spain
articles.trailText: Rutgers University professor who published book on antifa was told at gate his trip was cancelled after Trump threats
articles.summary: Rutgers University historian Mark Bray, author of Antifa: The Anti-Fascist Handbook, was blocked from boarding his family's flight to Spain at Newark Airport a day after being targeted by threats from Trump allies. He discovered his reservations canceled at the gate, which he suspects was politically motivated, before rebooking for the next day. Following online petitions, doxxing and death threats—spurred by Turning Point USA activists who labelled him a “domestic terrorist”—Bray relocated to Europe with his wife and children for safety, intending to continue teaching anti-fascism courses remotely while Rutgers affirms its commitment to campus security.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Schumer says justice department has become a ‘personal attack dog’ after Letitia James indicted
articles.trailText: New York attorney general attracted Trump’s ire after she led a civil fraud case against the president. Key US politics stories from Thursday 9 October
articles.summary: Senate Dem leader Chuck Schumer blasted the Trump administration for weaponizing the Justice Department after a Virginia grand jury indicted New York AG Letitia James on bank fraud charges linked to her civil case that fined Trump’s businesses $500 million. Schumer and Sen. Adam Schiff warned this signals a dangerous pattern of targeting political enemies.
