Other key updates include Norway’s Nobel Peace Prize concerns, National Guard deployment in Chicago for immigration enforcement, the ninth-day government shutdown, an FBI redeployment, stock-market crash warnings and a Rutgers professor’s travel ban.

articles.title: US to send 200 troops to Israel to support and monitor ceasefire deal, reports say
articles.trailText: Officials say US to establish center in Israel to help flow of humanitarian aid and logistical and security aid
articles.summary: Under the newly approved ceasefire deal, the US will deploy 200 troops to Israel to staff a civil-military coordination center run by US Central Command, facilitating humanitarian, logistical and security aid into Gaza. This intervention—part of a broader team with partner nations, NGOs and private firms—aims to monitor the pause in hostilities and support Gaza’s transition to civilian governance. Key issues persist, including Hamas disarmament, Israeli withdrawal, prisoner exchanges, massive humanitarian needs—over 2 million displaced, 67,000 killed, widespread famine—and reconstruction planning. The UN has urged opening all Gaza entry points to scale up aid amid famine, displacement and infrastructure collapse.

articles.title: Judge temporarily blocks Trump’s effort to deploy national guard in Chicago
articles.trailText: Much-anticipated judgment centers on efforts by Trump administration to use troops to aid immigration crackdown
articles.summary: US District Judge April Perry has temporarily barred the Trump administration from federalizing or deploying hundreds of National Guard troops in Chicago to aid immigration enforcement and curb crime, ruling there’s no credible threat of rebellion. Effective for two weeks, the injunction stems from Illinois’s lawsuit; Gov. J.B. Pritzker and Mayor Brandon Johnson hailed it as a vindication of state authority. The administration plans to appeal, while a separate injunction limits federal agents’ use of force and requires visible identification in northern Illinois.

articles.title: Nearly half of FBI agents in major offices reassigned to immigration enforcement
articles.trailText: Data shows stunning shift in law enforcement priorities that has raised public safety concerns
articles.summary: Data from Sen. Warner shows the Trump administration moved 45% of agents in 25 largest FBI offices to ICE-led immigration raids, shifting 23% of the bureau’s 13,000 agents from cybercrime, counterterrorism, drug trafficking, espionage, violent crime and counterintelligence. Critics warn of national security gaps, low morale and civil rights risks as untrained agents join aggressive immigration sweeps. Former FBI agent Mike German calls the realignment unprecedented, potentially purging dissenters and elevating loyalists. Ex-agent Kenneth Gray warns that sustained focus on immigration over terror and cyber threats could leave the U.S. vulnerable. The DOJ and DHS have not commented.

articles.title: Trump dreams of ‘everlasting peace’ as acolytes drop heavy hints to Nobel committee
articles.trailText: The president was coy about a peace prize for the ceasefire deal in Gaza – Marco Rubio was much less reticent
articles.summary: In a White House cabinet meeting timed ahead of the Nobel Peace Prize announcement, Trump touted his Gaza ceasefire as a historic breakthrough, promising “lasting, perhaps everlasting peace,” and celebrating an imminent release of Israeli hostages dancing in Arab streets. He lauded aides—especially Marco Rubio, who pressed the Nobel committee to reward Trump’s unique role—and announced renaming Columbus Day. Yet Middle East optimism collided with domestic strife: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem threatened troop deployments in Democratic cities, and VP JD Vance landed a discordant anti-Schumer quip.

articles.title: Alex Jones asks US supreme court to block $1.4bn defamation judgment
articles.trailText: Rightwing pundit’s request is latest in a series of appeals, both against the judgment and against sale of InfoWars
articles.summary: Rightwing conspiracist Alex Jones has petitioned the U.S. Supreme Court to stay enforcement of a $1.4 billion defamation and emotional distress verdict over his false Sandy Hook hoax claims. He seeks to block the transfer of InfoWars—bought by satirical site The Onion at bankruptcy auction for $1.75 million cash plus a $5 million victim credit. Jones, who’s apologized and now concedes the shooting’s reality, argues First Amendment protections and warns of a chilling effect on journalism. The court will consider his appeal in private on Friday.

articles.title: National guard remains in Chicago area as judge to rule on Trump deployment
articles.trailText: President attacks Chicago mayor and Illinois governor as extra troops arrive at army training site south-west of city
articles.summary: Roughly 500 National Guard troops—200 from Texas, 300 from Illinois—remain stationed at a heavily fenced army training site southwest of Chicago ahead of a judge’s ruling on the Trump administration’s deployment to protect ICE buildings and federal facilities for an initial 60 days. Illinois and Chicago officials have sued, calling the order unconstitutional, and a court hearing is under way. It follows similar Trump deployments in Los Angeles, DC and Memphis and ongoing legal challenges under the Posse Comitatus Act. Gov. Pritzker and Mayor Johnson denounce it as federal overreach while DHS doubles down on buying new ICE offices in Chicago.

articles.title: Dominion, voting firm targeted by false 2020 election claims, sold to new owner
articles.trailText: Company, which reached $787.5m defamation settlement with Fox News, becomes new entity called Liberty Vote
articles.summary: Dominion Voting Systems, best known for its role in 2020 election conspiracy claims and a $787.5 million defamation settlement with Fox News, has been sold to Scott Leiendecker, former Missouri elections director and KnowInk founder. Rebranded as Liberty Vote, the U.S.-based firm pledges to use hand-marked paper ballots, paper-based transparency, domestic staffing and development, and rigorous third-party audits to comply with President Trump’s executive order on voter-verifiable paper records. Financial terms were undisclosed. The move follows Dominion’s libel settlements with Newsmax, One America News, Sidney Powell and Rudy Giuliani and aims to rebuild trust in American elections.

articles.title: Senate still deadlocked over shutdown as Trump reiterates threat to Democrats
articles.trailText: Seventh round of votes fails to yield breakthrough while president threatens to cut funds for ‘Democrat programs’
articles.summary: Senate remains deadlocked on a seventh failed vote to end the US government shutdown as neither Democrats nor Republicans can secure the 60-vote threshold. Republicans insist on a clean continuing resolution to fund federal agencies through November 21, while Democrats demand extensions of Affordable Care Act premium tax credits, restoration of public media and Medicaid funding. President Trump reiterated threats to cut federal funds from Democratic-led states and cities, targeting “Democrat programs.” Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer praised his party’s stance as advantageous. Meanwhile, House Speaker Mike Johnson has kept lawmakers in recess, and federal workers face missed paychecks, with OMB canceling projects in Democratic jurisdictions.

articles.title: Stephen Miller said Trump has ‘plenary authority’. What does that mean?
articles.trailText: White House deputy chief of staff had an odd pause during a CNN interview when asked about the president’s power to deploy national guard troops
articles.summary: White House deputy chief of staff Stephen Miller paused during a CNN interview when asked about President Trump’s “plenary authority” to deploy federalized National Guard troops, a term meaning nearly unlimited power. The administration cites Title 10 and Article II’s Commander-in-Chief clause to justify broad military control, but experts note constraints like the War Powers Resolution, Posse Comitatus Act, Insurrection Act and Congress’s exclusive war-declaring authority. Critics warn invoking plenary power echoes autocratic overreach, as courts rejected Trump’s near-plenary claims in Newsom v. Trump and related deployment disputes.

articles.title: Truly, madly, deeply: Trump’s desire for a Nobel peace prize is driving diplomacy
articles.trailText: The US president’s fervid pursuit of the award is believed to have been a key motivator in brokering peace deals in Ukraine and Gaza
articles.summary: Trump’s return to the White House has been marked by an unprecedented, overt campaign to secure a Nobel Peace Prize, which has shaped his diplomacy. He lobbied Norway’s committee, phoned finance minister Jens Stoltenberg about the award and tariffs, and encouraged GOP allies like Brian Mast to pressure academics. The Nobel deadline drove a flurry of peace efforts: a failed Ukraine summit with Putin in Alaska, then a 20-point Gaza ceasefire plan unveiled at UNGA and a White House summit with Netanyahu. Critics note the timeline aligns with Friday’s Nobel announcement.

articles.title: Anti-abortion activists pardoned by Trump face trial for new clinic ‘invasion’
articles.trailText: Two who received presidential pardon among six activists charged with trespass and conspiracy in Pennsylvania
articles.summary: Six anti-abortion activists, including two pardoned by Donald Trump, are set to face Pennsylvania state charges of trespass and criminal conspiracy following their July “invasion” of the Delaware County Women’s Center. The group entered the abortion clinic under false pretenses to dissuade patients, refused to leave when asked and sprinkled “holy water” and salt. They waived their appearance—tantamount to pleading not guilty—though no trial date is set. Rights advocates say these “rescues” have risen after Trump curtailed enforcement of the 1994 FACE Act and pardoned nearly two dozen protestors. Clinic operators report spikes in similar invasions and threats, reflecting activists’ growing boldness.

articles.title: Texas court again pauses execution of man in ‘shaken baby’ case
articles.trailText: Robert Roberson, who has maintained innocence in death of two-year-old daughter, gets third execution date stayed
articles.summary: Texas’s highest criminal court on Oct. 9 stayed Robert Roberson’s execution—his third stay since 2016—just days before his scheduled Oct. 16 lethal injection for the 2003 shaken baby syndrome conviction in his two-year-old daughter Nikki’s death. The court sent his case back to Anderson County for a hearing under Texas’s 2013 junk science law, allowing review of new medical analyses—including a joint statement from 10 pathologists—and allegations of judicial misconduct. Bipartisan lawmakers, John Grisham and ultraconservative activists back Roberson����s innocence; AG Ken Paxton and some experts maintain he abused his daughter.

articles.title: California to become first US state to phase out ultra-processed foods from school meals
articles.trailText: New law signed by Gavin Newsom will define and ban ‘ultra-processed foods of concern’, beginning in 2029
articles.summary: California will become the first US state to phase out defined “ultra-processed foods of concern” from public school meals under a law signed by Gov. Gavin Newsom. By mid-2028 the health department must set criteria, schools begin phasing out these sugar-, salt- and additive-heavy products in July 2029, vendors face bans by 2032 and full meal bans by July 2035. Building on free meals, farm-to-school initiatives and earlier dye bans, the measure aims to curb obesity and chronic disease and ensure healthy, locally sourced meals statewide.

articles.title: More than 40 Trump administration picks tied directly to oil, gas and coal, analysis shows
articles.trailText: Report looks at White House nominees and appointees and agencies dictating energy, environment and climate policy
articles.summary: Analysis by Public Citizen and the Revolving Door Project finds that 111 Trump administration officials, including 43 directly hired from oil, gas or coal firms, and 12 tied to fossil-funded right-wing think tanks, occupy key energy and environment roles across eight agencies—including EPA, Interior and Energy. Senior appointees include Energy Secretary Chris Wright, ex-Liberty Energy CEO, and Interior Secretary Doug Burgum, a land lease holder of Continental Resources. The report warns this concentration fuels deregulatory moves—like the “one big beautiful act” opening federal lands—and underpins assaults on climate science. The White House rejects the critique.

articles.title: Alarm as CDC calls for separate MMR vaccines despite measles outbreak
articles.trailText: Concerns that three separate shots would be more costly and time-consuming, and keep kids from being vaccinated
articles.summary: HHS deputy Jim O’Neill, citing Trump, called on manufacturers to break the combined MMR shot into measles, mumps and rubella monovalent vaccines despite the worst US measles outbreak in decades. Experts from Yale, Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia and University of Saskatchewan warn splitting vaccines would increase costs, clinic visits (up to 20 for a six-month-old), lower completion rates, require new unethical placebo trials and sow confusion. CDC’s ACIP has no monovalent vaccines to recommend; past ACIP votes (1999) and decades of research found no safety or autism risks with combined MMR.

articles.title: Mocktails for Maga: why the US right is turning sober
articles.trailText: Tucker Carlson says young people are more health-conscious than older generations. Does it explain why Republicans are drinking less?
articles.summary: At Butterworth’s, a right-wing DC hangout co-owned by Raheem Kassam and frequented by Steve Bannon, bartenders have begrudgingly begun serving mocktails as MAGA staffers shun booze. A Gallup survey shows Republican drinkers plunged from 65% in 2023 to 46% in 2025—far sharper than among Democrats or independents. The trend may reflect Trump’s Diet Coke preference, Christian nationalist temperance, wellness fanaticism or economic belt-tightening. Prominent abstainers include Donald Trump, Tucker Carlson, Charlie Kirk and RFK Jr. Analysts say the shift is “statistically significant” but lack a definitive explanation.

articles.title: US west coast faults could trigger catastrophic back-to-back earthquakes, study finds
articles.trailText: Study shows high-magnitude temblor in north-west could set off another in California, causing unrivaled disaster
articles.summary: A marine‐geologist team studying deep‐sea turbidite layers finds 18 instances in the past 3,000 years where M9 ruptures on the Cascadia subduction zone triggered secondary M7.9 quakes on California’s San Andreas fault within hours. The 1700 event leveled Cowichan settlements and likely struck northern California minutes later. Simultaneous quakes could shake San Francisco, Portland, Seattle and Vancouver, spawn an 80ft tsunami across 27 countries, inflict $200bn+ damage and overwhelm response. Large events recur roughly every 200 years, while experts urge insurance, home retrofits and drop-cover-hold drills to boost coastal resilience.

articles.title: ‘You cannot undo a wrongful execution’: push to halt killing of Texas man in ‘shaken baby’ case
articles.trailText: Lawyers scramble as Robert Roberson to be first person executed under theory now widely seen as junk science
articles.summary: Texas plans to execute Robert Roberson at Huntsville next Thursday, making him the first person put to death based solely on “shaken baby syndrome,” a medical theory now widely denounced as junk science. Convicted in 2002 of shaking to death his two-year-old daughter, Roberson’s lawyers cite new expert testimony and autopsy reviews pointing to pneumonia, infection and a minor fall rather than violent shaking. Dozens of bipartisan lawmakers, SBS exonerees, the original detective and trial jurors urge a reprieve as federal and state appeals are pending. Opponents warn executing an innocent man would irreparably undermine justice.

articles.title: First Thing: Israel and Hamas agree to first phase of Gaza ceasefire plan
articles.trailText: Trump says all hostages to be released and Israel to withdraw troops to an agreed line. Plus, shutdown deadlock deepens
articles.summary: Israel and Hamas have agreed to the first phase of a Gaza ceasefire plan, pausing hostilities in the two-year war that has killed tens of thousands and destabilized the region. Donald Trump announced on Truth Social that all hostages held in Gaza will be released soon and that Israel will withdraw troops to an agreed line as the first step toward a “Strong, Durable, and Everlasting Peace.” Hamas confirmed the deal includes an exchange for up to 1,700 Palestinian prisoners within 72 hours. Key issues—Hamas disarmament and Gaza’s governance—are still unresolved.

articles.title: Pennsylvania Republicans reignite bid to unseat Maga congressman
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Republicans Against Perry are relaunching their campaign to oust Trump ally Scott Perry in 2026
articles.summary: Republicans Against Perry (RAP), a Republican grassroots group backed by WelcomePac, is relaunching efforts to unseat four-term GOP Rep. Scott Perry (PA-10) in 2026. After their 2024 push backed Democrat Janelle Stelson, who lost by under 2%, RAP will deploy electronic billboards, target furloughed federal workers amid a shutdown, and monitor closed primary results. While not yet endorsing a challenger, they eye Stelson and GOP contender Karen Dalton. Perry, a Freedom Caucus founder and January 6 figure under federal probe, faces scrutiny in the swingy Harrisburg district.

articles.title: Lauren Boebert vows to pursue ‘truth about UFOs’ as she bids for re-election
articles.trailText: Colorado Republican congresswoman kicks off fourth term run with email to potential donors: ‘They tell us we’re crazy’
articles.summary: Colorado GOP Rep. Lauren Boebert launched her fourth term House campaign by pledging to uncover the “truth about UFOs,” accusing the federal government of suppressing evidence of unidentified anomalous phenomena. In an email to donors she blasted Washington bureaucrats for dismissing sightings and demanded full disclosure. Democratic analyst Andy Boian called the move a “cry for help” amid her fundraising and voter support challenges, though her campaign says donor interest is strong. A QAnon adherent, Boebert previously pressed Congress in November 2024 on underwater alien bases and narrowly won reelection in 2022 and 2024.

articles.title: ‘The stakes are quite large’: US supreme court case could gut Voting Rights Act
articles.trailText: Court’s decision in Louisiana v Callais could limit voters from challenging racial discriminatory districts
articles.summary: The US Supreme Court will re-hear Louisiana v. Callais on October 15, a pivotal challenge to Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act—the key tool banning racial vote dilution—after white voters sued over a majority-Black congressional district stretching from Shreveport to Baton Rouge. Justices have invited briefing on whether creating that district violates the 14th or 15th Amendments. The ruling could uphold, strike down, or sharply curtail Section 2, imperiling minority-opportunity districts nationwide. Several conservative justices have already signaled deep skepticism, raising historic stakes for redistricting and civil-rights protections.

articles.title: ‘A fatal blow’: Italian producers fear effects of Trump’s ‘war against pasta’
articles.trailText: US president’s threat to impose 92% tariffs targeting major manufacturers puts family-run firms in the line of fire as well
articles.summary: Following a US Department of Commerce probe into alleged dumping, the Trump administration plans to impose up to 92% tariffs on major Italian pasta makers—including La Molisana and Garofalo—and by extension 11 other brands like Barilla and Pasta Rummo from January. The move, aimed at protecting US manufacturers and potentially encouraging onshore production, risks doubling retail prices of premium Italian pasta in America. Italy’s €4 billion export sector, its government alongside the EU, and agribusiness groups have vowed legal challenges and diplomatic efforts, warning of a 'fatal blow' to a culinary staple amid imitation brands.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: a note, a whisper and the first phase of a Gaza ceasefire deal
articles.trailText: Trump announces ‘first steps’ to ‘durable peace’; Kristi Noem compares Antifa to MS-13. Key US politics stories from 8 October at a glance
articles.summary: Marco Rubio handed Trump a note prompting his Truth Social announcement of a "first phase" Gaza ceasefire deal with Israel and Hamas—hostage releases and Israeli withdrawals brokered by Qatar, Egypt and Turkey—hailed by Trump and Republican lawmakers, though Palestinian Americans remain wary. Kristi Noem likened antifa to MS-13, Hamas, Hezbollah and ISIS. The US government shutdown deepened as senators rejected funding bills, forcing the IRS to furlough 34,000 staff and sparking airport staffing shortages. Trump called for jailing Chicago’s mayor and Illinois governor. James Comey pleaded not guilty to lying to Congress.

articles.title: Republicans praise Trump for Gaza deal as Palestinian Americans remain wary: ‘So much remains unclear’
articles.trailText: Politicians, poets and academics make posts on social media to laud the US president or share concerns
articles.summary: Republican lawmakers including Sen. Joni Ernst, Sen. Bernie Moreno and Rep. Brian Mast hailed Trump’s first-phase Gaza deal securing living hostages’ release and remains of the dead, lauding “peace through strength” and pressing for a Nobel Peace Prize. Yet Palestinian American voices – Pulitzer-winning poet Mosab Abu Toha, analyst Yousef Munayyer and scholar Shibley Telhami – cautioned the unverified terms, lack of a permanent ceasefire, unclear aid access and Israeli withdrawal, fearing a temporary pause in violence amid Gaza’s devastation. A senior Qatari official adds the deal covers Palestinian prisoner releases and aid entry.

articles.title: Man charged with starting Palisades fire that killed 12 people
articles.trailText: Jonathan Rinderknecht allegedly started blaze that destroyed over 6,800 structures in California
articles.summary: Jonathan Rinderknecht, 29, was arrested near his Florida home on federal charges of destruction of property by means of fire after investigators concluded he ignited the Lachman fire in Pacific Palisades on New Year's Day. The blaze smoldered underground for a week before flaring on January 7 amid heavy winds, killing 12 people and destroying over 6,800 structures. The ATF gathered 13,000+ evidence items, produced 300+ reports and conducted hundreds of interviews, using geolocation and digital proofs—incl. ChatGPT-generated imagery—to place him at the ignition site. He faces 5–20 years in prison; no motive has surfaced.

articles.title: A Gaza ceasefire deal could be Trump’s biggest diplomatic achievement – but the devil is in the detail
articles.trailText: The plan attempts to thread the needle between creating the conditions for a ceasefire and negotiating a lasting end to the war but hard questions remain
articles.summary: The Trump administration’s 20-point plan, endorsed by Arab states and regional powers, aims to broker a Gaza ceasefire as the president’s marquee diplomatic win. Phase one proposes exchanging Hamas-held hostages for a limited Israeli troop withdrawal, but locating captives and sequencing pullback remain fraught. Key issues—Hamas’s disarmament, Gaza’s governance and Israel’s long-term strategy—are unresolved. Netanyahu must balance right-wing coalition threats if he signs off. Trump, eyeing a Nobel Peace Prize, is pushing for a swift regional signing.

articles.title: Trump to visit Walter Reed for ‘routine yearly checkup’, the second since April
articles.trailText: Purpose of Friday checkup at US military medical center unclear for oldest man to be inaugurated president
articles.summary: President Donald Trump, 79, will visit Walter Reed for a second annual “routine” checkup since April, with specific tests yet unspecified. His April exam at Walter Reed included cognitive and cardiology assessments and deemed him “fully fit to execute presidential duties.” Since then he’s been diagnosed with chronic venous insufficiency, and a recent hand bruise—attributed to shaking hands and aspirin—sparked illness rumors. Critics have questioned his mental acuity after erratic appearances. White House says Trump may then pursue a Middle East trip to negotiate a Gaza ceasefire.

articles.title: Marco Rubio interrupts Trump with handwritten note on Gaza deal
articles.trailText: Note from secretary of state says ‘you need to approve a Truth Social post soon so you can announce deal first’
articles.summary: At a White House roundtable with conservative influencers, Secretary of State Marco Rubio intercepted President Trump with a handwritten note urging him to approve a Truth Social post announcing an imminent Gaza ceasefire deal. Trump later posted that all hostages would be released soon and Israel would withdraw to an agreed line. The note coincided with a third day of US-brokered talks at an Egyptian resort involving Qatar’s prime minister, Steve Witkoff and senior negotiators, as Trump signaled possible travel to the region.

articles.title: Senators press Mike Johnson to swear in Democrat who could force Epstein vote
articles.trailText: Mark Kelly and Ruben Gallego hold press conference at speaker’s office over his refusal to swear in Adelita Grijalva
articles.summary: Arizona Democratic senators Mark Kelly and Ruben Gallego confronted House Speaker Mike Johnson outside his office Wednesday, pressing him to administer the oath to Adelita Grijalva, who won a special election to replace her late father, Raúl M. Grijalva. Johnson refused, conditioning her swearing-in on reopening federal funding, and denied delaying her seating to block a petition—just one signature shy of forcing a vote—on releasing Jeffrey Epstein files. The stand-off, set against a partial government shutdown treating hundreds of thousands of federal workers as furloughed, coincided with a heated hallway clash between House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries and GOP Rep. Mike Lawler over one-year ACA premium tax credit extensions.

articles.title: Kristi Noem compares antifa to MS-13, Hamas, Hezbollah and the Islamic State
articles.trailText: Homeland security secretary calls loosely affiliated network of anti-fascist street activists ‘just as dangerous’
articles.summary: On Oct. 8 at a White House roundtable with conservative journalists Andy Ngo, Nick Sortor and Katie Daviscourt, Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem likened antifa’s decentralized network to MS-13, Tren de Aragua, ISIS, Hezbollah and Hamas, labeling it “just as dangerous.” She echoed President Trump’s September executive order designating antifa a “domestic terrorist organization,” while AG Pam Bondi warned of “masked terrorists.” Days earlier, Proud Boys leader Joe Biggs urged “antifa hunting,” and Trump cited unverified antifa blame for attacks on federal agents and the Charlie Kirk shooter, despite no confirmed links. Experts emphasize antifa’s lack of central command or formal structure.

articles.title: IRS to furlough nearly half its workforce due to government shutdown
articles.trailText: Move comes after White House memo suggests workers may not get back pay, despite law Trump signed in first term
articles.summary: Facing the government shutdown, the IRS will furlough about 34,000 non-exempt employees—nearly half its workforce—starting Oct. 8, leaving 39,870 staff (53.6%) on duty. Affected workers enter unpaid, non-duty status but get up to four hours to close out tasks. Acting human capital officer David Traynor’s standard furlough notice confirms no pay until funding resumes, “on the earliest date possible.” The National Treasury Employees Union, led by Doreen Greenwald, warns of service disruptions, longer wait times and delays for upcoming extension filings. A White House memo suggested furloughed staff might forgo back pay despite the 2019 Gefta.

articles.title: Last of 10 inmates who escaped from New Orleans jail captured by police
articles.trailText: Authorities say they found convicted killer Derrick Groves after a standoff at a home in south-west Atlanta
articles.summary: Derrick Groves, a four-time convicted killer serving time for a 2018 Mardi Gras double murder and linked to a 2017 manslaughter, was captured in southwest Atlanta after a standoff, ending the five-month manhunt as the last of 10 inmates who escaped from the Orleans Parish jail on May 16 by prying open a cell, crawling through a hole and scaling barbed wire. New Orleans DA Jason Williams called the escape a historic security breach; Orleans Parish Sheriff Susan Hutson, facing a tough re-election, credited multistate cooperation. Groves, the most violent escapee and grandson of police brutality victim Kim Groves, will face new prosecution.

articles.title: Texas charges eight people over links to midwife accused of illegal abortions
articles.trailText: State attorney general Ken Paxton claims ‘cabal of abortion-loving radicals’ practiced medicine without a license
articles.summary: Texas AG Ken Paxton announced the arrest of eight individuals indicted alongside midwife Maria Rojas, the first charged under Texas’ near-total abortion ban, accusing them of practicing medicine without licenses. Rojas faces charges of performing three abortions and 12 counts of unlicensed medical practice at her three Houston clinics. Paxton, calling them “abortion-loving radicals,” vows to enforce pro-life laws. Rojas’ lawyers counter that misoprostol possession and delegated tasks by assistants don’t prove illegal abortions or independent practice. The case, unfolding since Rojas’s March arrest, reflects intensifying state-level abortion bans post-Roe.

articles.title: US shutdown deadlock deepens as senators reject competing bills
articles.trailText: Proposals from both sides fail to receive enough support as no senators change their votes from recent days
articles.summary: Senate deadlocked for sixth vote on competing funding bills, no senators switching positions since shutdown began eight days ago. Democrats insist any deal include extension of ACA premium tax credits expiring year-end, while Republicans, backed by Trump, offer funding through Nov. 21 only. White House OMB said furloughed workers aren’t entitled to back pay despite a 2019 law; Speaker Mike Johnson insisted pay is statutory. Both sides stick to demands: Schumer decries GOP refusal to negotiate healthcare; Thune says tax credits can be addressed after reopening. One GOP defector backs tax-credit talks; Democrats reject GOP compromise.

articles.title: Democratic frontrunner for California governor threatens to walk out of interview
articles.trailText: Interviews grows testy when CBS reporter asks Katie Porter about 40% of voters who went for Trump, saying: ‘I’m going to call it’
articles.summary: Democratic gubernatorial frontrunner Katie Porter bristled in a CBS News interview when reporter Julia Watts pressed her on winning the roughly 40% of Californians who voted for Trump, challenging the premise that a Democrat must court Republicans in a deep-blue state. Frustrated, Porter threatened to end the exchange as ‘unnecessarily argumentative.’ Rivals on both sides seized on the clip—Democrats questioned her temperament; GOP hopeful Chad Bianco called it a tantrum. Porter leads with 17% in jungle primary polls, with 38% of voters undecided.

articles.title: Military should only be used for external threats, more than half of Americans say
articles.trailText: Survey finds 58% backing restricting armed forces to external threats amid Trump deployments to US cities
articles.summary: Reuters/Ipsos survey finds 58% of Americans believe US forces should be used only for external threats, versus 25% for wider domestic roles and 18% unsure. Support by party: Democrats 72%, Republicans 51%, others 53%. Just 37% back sending troops over a governor’s objection (70% Republicans, 13% Democrats). 83% demand military political neutrality. Results come as Trump deploys National Guard to cities like Portland, Chicago and LA, suggests using urban centers as training grounds, calls to jail Chicago��s mayor and Illinois’ governor, and sees a federal judge block his Portland deployment.

articles.title: US airport staffing shortages expected to cause more delays amid shutdown
articles.trailText: Air traffic controllers warn of escalating delays and stress as the government shutdown enters its second week
articles.summary: As the US government shutdown enters its seventh day, staffing shortages at airports and FAA control centers in cities like Nashville, Boston and Dallas are causing growing delays—two-hour waits at Nashville, 41 min at O’Hare and 30 min at DFW. Over 6,000 flights were delayed Monday. With 13,000 controllers still working without pay and 11,000 furloughed, unions warn of safety risks and mounting stress, urging Congress to reopen the government. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy and industry analysts warn of holiday travel chaos, while President Trump has said some furloughed workers might not receive customary back pay when the shutdown ends.

articles.title: Supreme court appears open to Republican challenge over Illinois mail-in ballot law
articles.trailText: Justices questioned Illinois law allowing mail-in ballots postmarked by election day to be counted for two weeks after
articles.summary: A Supreme Court panel on October 8 considered Republican Mike Bost’s challenge to an Illinois law allowing mail-in absentee ballots postmarked by Election Day to be counted up to two weeks later. Bost argues the extension unconstitutionally prolongs elections and that campaign staffing costs give him standing. Justices probed whether a federal candidate is a direct “object” of the rule and if the statistical chance of late ballots affecting results matters for standing. Lower courts dismissed Bost for lack of injury; his appeal emphasizes financial harm and broader implications amid GOP efforts, including Trump’s directives against post-Election Day mail ballots. ACLU backs his standing claim.

articles.title: Ex-FBI director James Comey pleads not guilty on lying to Congress charge
articles.trailText: Case marks significant step in Trump’s efforts to politicize the justice department and punish political enemies
articles.summary: Former FBI director James Comey pleaded not guilty to federal charges accusing him of lying to Congress in September 2020 about authorizing anonymous sources. Arraigned before Judge Michael Nachmanoff in Alexandria with his family present—including his wife, ex–SDNY prosecutor daughter Maurene, and son-in-law Troy Edwards Jr.—his trial is set for January 5, 2026. Counsel Patrick Fitzgerald plans motions to dismiss for malicious, selective prosecution and to challenge interim US attorney Lindsey Halligan’s appointment. The indictment, handed down by a Trump-installed grand jury, underscores President Trump’s broader effort to politicize the DOJ by ousting career prosecutors.

articles.title: Alabama sheriff condemned over ‘racist’ Halloween display at home
articles.trailText: Mobile county sheriff, Paul Burch, faces backlash after skeletons in sombreros and ‘ICE’ shirts spotted in his yard
articles.summary: Mobile County Sheriff Paul Burch sparked outrage with a Halloween display on his yard featuring skeletons in sombreros and ponchos being chased by skeletal figures in “ICE” T-shirts. Neighbors and Hispanic groups called it dehumanizing and racist; the sheriff’s wife claims authorship, calling it “tongue-in-cheek” and citing her Cuban heritage. Local Latino business associations stressed the region’s integrated culture. The incident follows Burch’s defense of deputies in a recent use-of-force case and taps into broader debates over immigration imagery and cultural sensitivity.

articles.title: Trump calls for jailing of Chicago mayor and Illinois governor as national guard arrives in city
articles.trailText: President accused Brandon Johnson and JB Pritzker of failing to protect Ice officers as troops deploy to Chicago
articles.summary: On Wednesday, President Trump used Truth Social to demand jailing of Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson and Illinois Governor J.B. Pritzker for “failing to protect ICE officers,” as his administration sends 200 Texas National Guard troops (plus 300 from Illinois) to the Chicago area to guard federal immigration agents—ostensibly under the Insurrection Act—despite Posse Comitatus limits. Johnson and Pritzker have sued to block the deployment, issued executive orders barring federal staging on city property and denounced the move as authoritarian. Chicago police data show homicides down 31% year-to-date, and a Reuters/Ipsos poll indicates most Americans oppose using troops domestically without an external threat.

articles.title: ‘Tennessee Three’s’ Justin Pearson launches challenge against Democratic congressman
articles.trailText: Memphis lawmaker to go up against Steve Cohen, joining wave of younger candidates calling for generational change
articles.summary: Memphis state representative Justin Pearson, 30, known as one of the “Tennessee Three” expelled and reinstated after a 2023 gun-control protest, launched a Democratic primary bid against 76-year-old Rep. Steve Cohen in Tennessee’s deep-blue 9th district. Criticizing stagnant leadership amid a 22.6% local poverty rate, Pearson’s progressive platform includes cheaper healthcare, housing affordability, tougher gun laws and generational change. Backed by Justice Democrats and David Hogg’s Leaders We Deserve (pledging $1 million), he argues it’s time to “pass the torch.”

articles.title: First Thing: National guard troops arrive in Chicago as governor decries Trump’s ‘military invasion’
articles.trailText: Illinois governor says Donald Trump is ‘taking away people’s rights’. Plus, the key stats highlighting Israel’s destruction of Gaza
articles.summary: Texas National Guard troops deployed to Chicago under Trump’s order mark a stark escalation of his immigration crackdown in the city, prompting Gov. JB Pritzker to denounce it as an unconstitutional “military invasion” aimed at stripping rights. After a federal judge refused to block the deployment despite Illinois and Chicago’s lawsuit, Pritzker vows legal action. The surge follows weeks of heightened immigration enforcement and violent clashes in suburban Broadview, where police used teargas on protesters.

articles.title: Man who became popular in Blinking White Guy gif raises over $300,000 for multiple sclerosis research
articles.trailText: Drew Scanlon, a resident of San Francisco, said the case was close to him a friend and his mother are afflicted with it
articles.summary: Drew Scanlon, whose bewildered 2013 livestream reaction birthed the “Blinking White Guy” meme, has leveraged his viral fame to raise over $300,000 for the U.S. National Multiple Sclerosis Society. A San Francisco–based Twitch producer, Scanlon annually cycles in an MS charity race and once a year tweets the meme with “THIS IS MY FACE” and a link to BlinkingGuy.com. In 2025 alone he raised $70,000. Motivated by a friend and her mother’s MS diagnoses, he views the meme as “a gift” he must pay forward.

articles.title: Democrats introduce bill to help federal workers cover childcare costs during shutdown
articles.trailText: Exclusive: employees would be reimbursed for fees paid to childcare facilities under plans initiated by Ilhan Omar
articles.summary: Democrats led by Rep. Ilhan Omar introduced the Federal Worker Childcare Protection Act of 2025 to reimburse furloughed or unpaid federal workers for childcare fees during the government shutdown. Co-sponsors include Jayapal, Lee, Meeks, Nadler and Tlaib. The bill authorizes GSA to accept documentation and issue reimbursements after the agency shuttered 100 on-site childcare centers. It comes as an EPI report finds childcare costs exceed rent in most states and amid White House false accusations blaming Democrats for the shutdown. Senate leader Schumer and AFL-CIO president Liz Shuler urged restoring pay and ending the impasse.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Texas national guard arrive in Chicago area as Donald Trump increases pressure on city
articles.trailText: Military presence comes after US district judge declined to immediately block troops from entering city – key US politics stories from 7 October at a glance
articles.summary: Texas National Guard troops deployed to Chicago after a federal judge refused to bar their entry amid Trump’s intensified immigration and protest crackdown, spurring lawsuits by Illinois and the city. In other developments, the US Supreme Court signaled a potential rollback of Colorado’s ban on conversion therapy; the White House argued furloughed federal workers aren’t guaranteed back pay; AG Pam Bondi faced Senate Democrats over Epstein files and troop deployments; Marjorie Taylor Greene expressed willingness to negotiate healthcare costs with Democrats; Trump cited “natural conflict” yet “mutual love” with Canada during PM Carney’s visit; far-right influencer Laura Loomer warned him against pardoning Ghislaine Maxwell; and CBS News staffers braced for Bari Weiss’s editorship amid continuing airport delays, Kristi Noem’s ICE facility tour, and Trump’s approval of an Alaska mining road.

articles.title: Mamdani attends Israelis for Peace vigil after his 7 October statement draws ire from Israel
articles.trailText: New York City’s mayoral candidate sits in with Brad Lander after commemorating Israeli and Palestinian victims
articles.summary: After condemning Hamas’s Oct.7 attacks and denouncing Israel’s “genocidal” Gaza offensive in a statement honoring both Israeli and Palestinian victims, NYC mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani attended Israelis for Peace’s weekly Manhattan vigil—alongside comptroller Brad Lander—marking the attacks’ second anniversary with calls for a ceasefire, hostage release and equal rights for Palestinians. His remarks, accusing Netanyahu and the US of complicity, drew harsh rebukes from Israel’s foreign ministry and conservative commentators—including Atlantic writer David Frum and Fox’s David Asman—intensifying controversy in his campaign.

articles.title: What is the Insurrection Act, and can Trump use it?
articles.trailText: President has threatened to invoke 19th-century law as a means to control mobilization of national guard troops
articles.summary: President Donald Trump has threatened to invoke the Insurrection Act of 1807—a federal law that lets the president deploy military or federalize National Guard troops domestically to quell uprisings—as Democratic-led governors and courts block his immigration enforcement plans. Experts warn that activating the Insurrection Act would allow troops to perform civilian law-enforcement duties otherwise barred by the Posse Comitatus Act, raising risks of force against protesters. The Act has been used sparingly since the 1960s civil-rights interventions and the 1992 LA riots. Courts typically defer to presidential military judgments, though some judges have imposed limits on deployments.

articles.title: Kristi Noem tours Portland Ice facility with Maga influencers in tow
articles.trailText: Oregon governor, Tina Kotek, accuses Ice of antagonizing protesters with teargas and by inviting influencers to film
articles.summary: ICE Director Kristi Noem toured the small Portland ICE facility Oct 7 flanked by conservative influencers (Benny Johnson, Nick Sortor, David Medina), underscoring Trump’s narrative of an “under siege” field office despite a handful of mostly costume-clad demonstrators. Portland police cleared streets; Noem led officers in prayer, met Police Chief Bob Day and rallied guard troops. Oregon Gov. Tina Kotek condemned ICE’s use of teargas in residential areas and harnessing MAGA influencers. A federal judge blocked attempts to federalize Oregon’s Guard, finding Trump’s claims “untethered to the facts.”

articles.title: White House says furloughed federal workers not entitled to back pay amid shutdown
articles.trailText: OMB argues an amendment to a 2019 act would not guarantee furloughed workers post-shutdown pay
articles.summary: In a draft memo obtained by Axios, OMB general counsel Mark Paoletta argues the 2019 Government Employee Fair Treatment Act doesn’t guarantee back pay for furloughed federal workers without an explicit congressional appropriation. The OMB removed GEFTA references from its shutdown guidance. President Trump said pay “depends who we’re talking about” and floated program cuts and layoffs. House Speaker Mike Johnson backs back pay but notes legal uncertainties. Democrats, including Senators Chris Van Hollen and Patty Murray, decry the reinterpretation as unlawful. Some 750,000 workers remain furloughed on day seven of the shutdown.

articles.title: Bondi spars over Epstein but stays silent on Comey: takeaways from a tense hearing
articles.trailText: The attorney general clashed with Democrats over Trump, Epstein, and the ‘weaponization’ of the justice department
articles.summary: At a Senate Judiciary hearing, AG Pam Bondi was accused by Democrats of weaponizing the DOJ to protect Trump allies, mismanaging the Epstein probe and evading questions on Comey’s indictment. She refused to discuss White House pressure on personnel decisions, denied an Epstein client list exists, defended Operation Arctic Frost as law enforcement overreach, and clashed over FBI actions against senators’ phone records. Bondi countered by attacking Democrats personally, invoking troop deployments to Chicago and pivoting to Hunter Biden criticisms.

articles.title: Six former US surgeons general warn RFK Jr is ‘endangering nation’s health’
articles.trailText: Former top doctors condemn health secretary’s vaccine, research policies, saying ideology replaced science at HHS
articles.summary: Six former US surgeons general (Adams, Carmona, Elders, Murthy, Novello, Satcher) warn in a Washington Post op-ed that HHS Secretary RFK Jr.’s “Make America Healthy Again” agenda—narrowing COVID-19 vaccine eligibility, dismissing advisory panel members, cutting mRNA research funding, reviewing vaccine recommendations and restructuring agencies—replaces science with ideology, undermines public health agency morale and talent, and threatens the nation’s health amid resurgent infectious and chronic diseases. They accuse him of misleading the public, rejecting science and putting lives at risk. Last week, psychiatric groups also urged his removal over mental-health agency changes; HHS says he’s restoring trust.

articles.title: Virginia governor’s race shaken up by ‘violent’ texts sent by ally of Democratic candidate
articles.trailText: Abigail Spanberger faces criticism for her support of fellow Democrat who speculated about Republican lawmaker getting ‘two bullets to the head’
articles.summary: A scandal erupted in Virginia’s governor’s race after private 2022 texts by Democratic attorney general hopeful Jay Jones surfaced, in which he fantasized about shooting GOP Speaker Todd Gilbert ‘two bullets to the head’ and ‘breeding little fascists.’ Republican nominee Winsome Earle-Sears, trailing Democrat Abigail Spanberger by 12 points, seized on Spanberger’s continued support for Jones—despite his apology—and demanded both drop out. Donald Trump echoed the criticism. The episode hit amid rising US political violence and has dominated campaign messaging.

articles.title: Pam Bondi and Senate Democrats spar amid Trump’s troop deployments
articles.trailText: US attorney general declined to talk about many of the administrations decisions and personally attacked senators
articles.summary: Pam Bondi, US attorney general, faced Democratic senators at a Senate judiciary hearing over her role in Donald Trump’s political prosecutions, national guard deployments to Democratic-led cities and handling of Epstein case files. Dems accused her of politicizing the Justice Department — indicting ex-FBI chief James Comey after Trump’s demands and dropping the Tom Homan probe — while she declined to discuss these actions, personally attacking senators and citing the government shutdown. Exchanges grew heated with Dick Durbin, Alex Padilla and Adam Schiff, amid GOP praise and concerns over lawmaker phone taps. Bondi has also gutted the DOJ’s public integrity unit.

articles.title: Texas national guard troops arrive in Chicago amid Trump’s crackdown
articles.trailText: Military presence comes after judge declined to block troops from entering, following lawsuit filed by city and state
articles.summary: Texas National Guard troops have deployed to Chicago under Trump’s escalated immigration crackdown after US District Judge April Perry declined to block their entry amid a lawsuit by Illinois AG Kwame Raoul and the city challenging out-of-state deployments. The move follows violent clashes in Broadview and weeks of ramped-up immigration enforcement. Mayor Brandon Johnson has barred ICE from city property; Gov. J.B. Pritzker and Sen. Dick Durbin condemn what they call unlawful militarization. It echoes Trump’s prior deployments to LA, Portland and Washington, D.C.

articles.title: Texas national guard troops head to Illinois after judge fails to block move
articles.trailText: Federal government allowed to continue Chicago deployment while it responds to Illinois lawsuit
articles.summary: After a federal judge declined to block the Trump administration’s deployment of Texas National Guard troops to Chicago, Gov. JB Pritzker and AG Kwame Raoul sued to stop the move, arguing it violates state sovereignty. The judge gave the administration until Wednesday to respond. Trump is also seeking to federalize 300 Illinois guardsmen and send 400 more from Texas. In Congress Republicans cheered the deployment while Democrats grilled AG Pam Bondi over presidential authority, with critics warning of constitutional overreach. A similar effort to send troops to Portland was blocked by an Oregon judge.

articles.title: US supreme court appears poised to overturn Colorado ban on ‘conversion therapy’
articles.trailText: Ruling in favor of Christian legal group could undermine care and rights for LGBTQ+ youth across the country
articles.summary: SCOTUS is considering overturning Colorado’s 2019 ban on licensed conversion therapy for minors in Chiles v. Salazar after the Alliance Defending Freedom argued the law unlawfully restricts speech. Counselor Kaley Chiles claims self-censorship of her faith-based counseling and seeks strict scrutiny. Conservative justices probed the statute’s scope and questioned evidence of harm, while liberal justices highlighted medical bodies’ condemnation of conversion therapy’s risks. DOJ’s Hashim Mooppan called the ban a content-based prior restraint. State SG Stevenson framed it as essential healthcare protection. A ruling for ADF could jeopardize 20+ state bans and LGBTQ+ youth rights.

articles.title: Flight delays as US air traffic controllers feel strain of government shutdown
articles.trailText: More than 6,000 US flights were delayed Monday as some airports temporarily closed amid staffing shortages
articles.summary: More than 6,000 US flights were delayed Monday across hubs including New York, Los Angeles and Denver as air traffic control facilities strained under staffing shortages during the federal shutdown. The Hollywood Burbank tower shut temporarily after higher sick call-outs. Essential controllers remain on duty unpaid; the NATCA union warns fatigue risks grow. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy deems airspace safe but warns of further closures. The shutdown, triggered by a Senate funding impasse over healthcare, also jeopardizes Essential Air Service subsidies to small communities.

articles.title: Laura Loomer warns Trump on idea of Ghislaine Maxwell pardon: ‘Do not do it’
articles.trailText: Far-right influencer’s comments on X came after president evidently left door open to pardoning the Epstein associate
articles.summary: Far-right influencer Laura Loomer publicly urged Donald Trump on X to abandon any consideration of pardoning Ghislaine Maxwell, warning such a move would be irreversible. Her comments followed Trump’s noncommittal response after the Supreme Court declined Maxwell’s appeal of her 20-year sex-trafficking conviction. House Rep. Robert Garcia praised the court’s refusal and criticized the Justice Department’s earlier transfer of Maxwell. Meanwhile AG Pam Bondi clashed with Sen. Dick Durbin over withheld Epstein files. Trump also disclosed a pardon request from Sean "Diddy" Combs, whom he called Puff Daddy, and said he is weighing his decision.

articles.title: Federal agents taunted Chicago woman to ‘do something’ before shooting her, attorney claims
articles.trailText: Officers say woman was in chase ending in ramming border patrol vehicle during Trump’s immigration crackdown
articles.summary: Chicago Sun-Times reports that Marimar Martinez, 30, was shot multiple times by a Customs and Border Protection agent in Brighton Park after a vehicle chase alleged to have boxed in a CBP truck during the Trump administration’s heightened immigration crackdown. Her attorney says body-cam video captures an agent taunting “Do something, bitch” before firing, while prosecutors contend Martinez and co-defendant Anthony Ian Santos Ruiz, 21, recklessly rammed the patrol car and that she carried a concealed handgun. Both face charges of assaulting federal officers. A judge ordered them released pending trial, and footage remains unpublished.

articles.title: Rutgers professor moving to Europe after threats over antifa accusations
articles.trailText: Mark Bray says threats intensified after a Turning Point USA petition accused him of promoting political violence
articles.summary: Rutgers history professor Mark Bray is temporarily relocating to Europe after receiving intensified threats when Turning Point USA’s Rutgers chapter launched a Change.org petition accusing him of being “a prominent leader of the antifa movement” and calling for his firing. Bray, author of Antifa: The Anti-Fascist Handbook, denies any antifa affiliation, describing himself as a historian of leftist movements. After Trump’s executive order labeling antifa as terrorists and far-right commentary, he moved classes online and plans to teach remotely. Rutgers has pledged support for his academic freedom while reviewing the petition amid campus debate over free speech.

articles.title: CDC backs updated Covid vaccines as access issues persist: ‘We still don’t have doses in hand’
articles.trailText: Delays in recommending the shots and misinformation have created obstacles for vaccine access
articles.summary: After months-long delay and misinformation, the CDC’s acting director signed off updated Covid-19 vaccine recommendations on Sept. 19 for anyone over six months under a shared decision model. The approval, pending website updates, removes combined MMR-varicella rec. Because CDC endorsement precedes VFC program inclusion, 52% of underinsured or Medicaid-enrolled children remain unable to access doses this fall, missing crucial flu season timing. Providers cite perceived low demand and outdated storage concerns, fueling a self-fulfilling stockout. Experts warn infants face high hospitalization risk and long Covid. Misinformation and equity gaps persist, with families and pediatricians still waiting for available vaccine supplies.

articles.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene open to healthcare deal with Democrats amid shutdown
articles.trailText: Republican says she is ‘disgusted’ by rising insurance premiums and may defy her party over expired tax credits
articles.summary: Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, absolutely disgusted by expiring ACA tax credits that could double premiums for her family and Georgia constituents, signaled willingness to negotiate healthcare with Democrats despite her longstanding opposition to Obamacare. A self-described MAGA loyalist since 2021, she slammed GOP peers for funding Ukraine and Gaza conflicts over U.S. needs, calling the shutdown “shameful” and “traitorous.” Insisting on barring taxpayer-funded coverage for undocumented immigrants, her stance aligns with Trump’s caveat to reopen government first.

articles.title: Rural US town outraged as only hospital forced to shut: ‘I would have died without it’
articles.trailText: Nearly 28,000 people relied on Glenn Medical center for its services, but now they will have to travel more than 30 miles for care
articles.summary: Glenn Medical Center, the sole hospital serving 28,000 residents around Willows in far-northern California, closed on September 30 after 75 years when CMS revoked its critical-access designation for failing a 35-mile distance test—recalculated via a “rural cut-through” road as 32.5 miles. Without CAH status, federal Medicare and Medicaid reimbursements drop steeply, rendering the 25-bed facility financially unsustainable. Locals now face emergency drives over 30 miles on winding rural roads, heightening risks in heart attacks, traumas and chronic-illness cases. Nearby fire crews are expanding EMS, and Congressman LaMalfa is lobbying HHS and the Rural Health Transformation Fund to restore funding. The closure spotlights challenges confronting hundreds of U.S. rural hospitals.

articles.title: Alligator Alcatraz snaps back to life after judges’ reprieve of Florida’s migrant jail
articles.trailText: The deportation hub seemed on the point of closure but has been revived as a ‘black site … people are being disappeared’
articles.summary: Alligator Alcatraz, a 3,000-bed tented ICE camp hastily built on Everglades wetlands, seemed destined for closure in late August after a federal judge ruled its construction violated environmental laws. Two Trump-appointed appeals judges stayed that injunction, backed by a $608 million FEMA reimbursement, allowing DeSantis to refill the facility. Activists report surging detainees, denied lawyer visits, secret transfers into “black-site” limbo and sudden deportations without notice. Suits by the Miccosukee Tribe and environmental groups, alongside litigation over access and due-process rights, accompany weekend vigils and protests across Florida against alleged inhumane conditions.

articles.title: First Thing: Israelis gather to mark two years since 7 October Hamas attack
articles.trailText: A rally in Tel Aviv will call for release of remaining hostages in Gaza. Plus, global renewable energy generation surpasses coal for first time
articles.summary: Israelis across the country will hold rallies on Tuesday to mark two years since Hamas’s 7 October 2023 assault, which killed about 1,200 people and seized 251 hostages. In Tel Aviv, a mass demonstration will press for the release of remaining captives, while southern kibbutzim will hold unofficial commemorations for victims. Despite Donald Trump’s call to halt strikes, Israeli air raids in Gaza have killed at least 19 people in the past 24 hours. Hope for a ceasefire has risen as Hamas and Israeli negotiators meet in Egypt.

articles.title: New Orleans couple discovers ancient Roman grave marker in their yard
articles.trailText: Discovery of 1,900-year-old headstone dedicated to Roman sailor sets off effort to repatriate item to Italy
articles.summary: In March, Tulane anthropologist Daniella Santoro and husband Aaron Lorenz unearthed a 1,900-year-old marble headstone in their New Orleans yard, bearing a Latin inscription. University of New Orleans archaeologist D. Ryan Gray, Tulane’s Susann Lusnia and Innsbruck’s Harald Stadler identified it as the tombstone of 2nd-century Roman sailor Sextus Congenius Verus and linked it to a missing artifact from Civitavecchia museum. Santoro’s team turned the slab over to the FBI art crime unit to repatriate it. Research suggests it was removed amid WWII chaos in Italy—perhaps by Allied troops or dealers—but its precise route to Louisiana remains uncertain.

articles.title: No air traffic control crew at busy LA airport amid government shutdown staffing crunch
articles.trailText: Air traffic to the Hollywood Burbank airport would be remotely managed for six hours on Monday night causing delays for travellers
articles.summary: Hollywood Burbank Airport’s control tower will be unstaffed from 4:15pm to 10pm Monday as the government shutdown forces 13,000 FAA controllers and 50,000 TSA officers to work unpaid. Southern California TRACON will manage arrivals and departures, but staffing cuts—down up to 50% in some regions—have triggered delays averaging 1h51m and peaking at 2h35m. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy warned that more sick calls could force flow reductions to maintain safety. Governor Newsom blamed President Trump, while unions urged members to avoid illegal job actions amid pay‐check anxiety.

articles.title: New California law bans loud ads on streaming services for ‘peace and quiet’
articles.trailText: Legislation was written by lawmaker whose aide had complained about ad breaks startling his newborn daughter
articles.summary: California has enacted Senate Bill 576, requiring streaming platforms including Netflix, Hulu, Amazon Prime and YouTube to ensure that commercial audio levels match the average volume of programming, ending sudden loud ads. Signed by Gov. Gavin Newsom and introduced by Sen. Tom Umberg—whose aide’s newborn daughter was jolted awake by blaring ads—the law aligns streamers with FCC broadcast regulations dating to 2010. With major services headquartered in California, SB 576 could prompt similar rules nationwide.

articles.title: Republicans post fake image of Oregon protest – using photos of South America
articles.trailText: A federal judge had blocked Trump’s request to deploy California national guard to Portland
articles.summary: After a federal judge blocked Trump’s request to deploy California National Guard troops to Portland, the Oregon Republican Party posted celebratory social media messages claiming 300 guardsmen would protect federal facilities. Accompanying the posts was a doctored image—intended to bolster Trump’s false claim that protests were ‘burning to the ground’—combining a 2008 Getty Images photo of South American police (identified by ‘Policia’ shields and Ecuadorian unit initials) with a 2017 Pexels shot of a Brazilian demonstration. When challenged by the Guardian, the party’s X account responded, “We’re not reporters, just bad memers.”

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: President mulls use of insurrection act as national guard deployment faces legal issues
articles.trailText: The president threatened the use of emergency powers after a federal judge temporarily halted national guard deployment in Portland. Key US politics stories from 6 October at a glance
articles.summary: President Trump warned he could invoke the Insurrection Act after an Oregon judge blocked National Guard deployment in Portland, even as another court green-lit troops in Illinois. The US government shutdown hit week two, prompting federal workforce cut plans. In Virginia, a federal prosecutor resisted Trump’s push to charge NY AG Letitia James; the Supreme Court refused Ghislaine Maxwell’s appeal; CBS News tapped Bari Weiss as editor-in-chief. Meanwhile, rural airport subsidy funds face expiration, Jimmy Kimmel’s popularity briefly surpassed Trump’s, and Brazil’s Lula urged tariff relief.

articles.title: US shutdown enters second week as Senate again rejects rival funding bills
articles.trailText: Competing bills fail to pass 60-vote threshold, while Trump hints at possible deal with Democrats over health subsidies
articles.summary: The US shutdown enters week two after the Senate again failed to reach 60 votes on rival funding measures—52–42 for the GOP bill and 50–45 for Democrats’. Trump hinted he’ll negotiate on ACA premium tax credits, central to the stalemate, but Republican leaders refuse talks before restoring funding. Furloughs shutter agencies, a food‐aid program nears insolvency, and the White House warns of layoffs. Speaker Johnson keeps the House in recess to pressure Senate Democrats and delay an Epstein files vote. Polls show most Americans blame Republicans.

articles.title: What to know about Trump’s national guard deployment, from rulings to protests
articles.trailText: US president has faced backlash from judges and governors for deploying troops amid escalating campaign in Portland
articles.summary: After Judge Karin Immergut barred Trump from mobilizing 200 Oregon National Guard troops—slated from California and Texas—to Portland, and granted a temporary restraining order, Illinois became the third state to sue. In Chicago, Judge April M. Perry paused a block on 400 planned Texas troops. Federalized units arrived in Portland, spurring nightly ICE facility demonstrations with about 400 protesters; federal agents used tear gas and made arrests. Governors Gavin Newsom, Tina Kotek and JB Pritzker condemned unauthorized deployments as politicized rule-of-law breaches. Judges challenged the administration’s circumvention tactics as Trump escalates troop deployments under “war zone” rhetoric in Democratic-led cities.

articles.title: Federal prosecutor resists pressure from Trump to charge Letitia James
articles.trailText: Prosecutor reportedly does not believe there is probable cause to file charges against the New York attorney general
articles.summary: Elizabeth Yusi, a career prosecutor in the eastern district of Virginia, has concluded there’s insufficient probable cause to charge New York Attorney General Letitia James with mortgage fraud, despite pressure from Trump allies. Installed US Attorney Lindsey Halligan, a Trump loyalist with no prosecutorial experience, is set to review Yusi’s findings after referrals by FHFA head William Pulte, who alleged James misrepresented her primary residence on 2023 mortgage documents. Emails and filings indicate James disclosed she did not intend to occupy the Norfolk home as her main residence. Grand jury proceedings in May faltered, and several prosecutors have been ousted amid the high‐stakes confrontation between Trump and the Justice Department.

articles.title: US skydiving instructor found dead after apparently falling without parachute
articles.trailText: Authorities say federal aviation agency to investigate incident after also rescuing instructor’s student from tree
articles.summary: A 35-year-old instructor, identified as Justin Fuller, was found dead in a wooded area near Nashville after apparently falling without a parachute during a tandem jump. His student became trapped in a tree with an open chute and was rescued by Nashville fire crews, then hospitalized in stable condition. Officials say the pair separated from their tandem rig aboard a plane; three other skydivers landed safely. The FAA and local police are investigating, and Go Skydive Nashville is cooperating fully.

articles.title: Fire engulfs home of South Carolina judge who had received death threats
articles.trailText: State’s chief justice says fire that sent three people to the hospital appeared to have been caused by an ‘explosion’
articles.summary: South Carolina judge Diane Goodstein’s Edisto Beach home was destroyed by a Saturday fire with no signs of arson or pre-fire explosion. Goodstein, 69, was walking her dogs when the blaze hospitalized her husband, ex-state senator Arnold Goodstein, and two family members. SLED investigators found no intentional cause despite reported death threats after Goodstein blocked a voter-file release to the DOJ. The incident sparks fears of politically motivated violence against judges amid a broader uptick in US political attacks.

articles.title: US supreme court declines to hear Ghislaine Maxwell’s appeal of sex-trafficking conviction
articles.trailText: Jeffrey Epstein associate was sentenced in 2022 to 20 years in prison for sex trafficking and related crimes
articles.summary: US Supreme Court declined to hear Ghislaine Maxwell’s appeal of her 2021 sex-trafficking conviction linked to Jeffrey Epstein, affirming her 20-year prison sentence. Maxwell’s legal team asserts unresolved factual and legal issues and plans to pursue clemency as her only remaining early-release option. Her appeal had invoked Epstein’s 2008 non-prosecution deal, but appellate courts ruled it non-binding. The decision, issued without comment, underscores Maxwell as the sole Epstein associate convicted amid ongoing political and survivor demands for broader accountability.

articles.title: Jimmy Kimmel more popular than Trump after show suspension, poll finds
articles.trailText: Economist and YouGov poll finds president had a 16-point deficit in terms of popularity compared with late-night host
articles.summary: In an Economist/YouGov poll of 1,656 US adults (Sept 26–29), Jimmy Kimmel posts net favorability +3 (44%/41%/15%) versus Trump’s −13 (41%/54%/5%), a 16-point lead. Kimmel was suspended by ABC on Sept 17 after criticizing the administration’s response to Charlie Kirk’s killing under FCC chair Brendan Carr’s threat, sparking protests and Disney boycotts; he was reinstated six days later and two major affiliates resumed airing his show by Sept 26. His comeback monologue, calling the suspension “anti-American” and clarifying his stance on Kirk’s death, drew 15 million YouTube views. Trump initially praised the suspension then attacked ABC online.

articles.title: Trump urges negotiators to ‘move fast’ in run-up to Gaza ceasefire talks | First Thing
articles.trailText: Discussions in Egypt expected to focus on path to peace and release of hostages, after Israel killed dozens of people in just over 24 hours. Plus, why are young Americans eating so early?
articles.summary: Arriving in Sharm el-Sheikh for Gaza ceasefire talks, negotiators will focus on phase one of Trump’s proposal—swapping the remaining 48 Hamas-held hostages for Palestinian prisoners—after the Egyptian foreign ministry endorsed the agenda. In a social media post, Trump urged participants to move swiftly as talks “advance rapidly,” even as Israeli strikes killed 63 Gazans in 24 hours. US envoy Steve Witkoff is set to join, alongside Israeli and Palestinian delegations led by Hamas deputy politburo chief Khalil al-Hayya.

articles.title: Outcry as Trump plots more roads and logging in US forests: ‘You can almost hear the chainsaws’
articles.trailText: Critics say move to axe Bill Clinton’s ‘roadless rule’ that protected key old-growth forests will be devastating to environment
articles.summary: President Trump’s administration plans to rescind Bill Clinton’s 2001 “roadless rule,” opening 58m acres of old-growth national forests to new roads, logging and drilling to boost domestic timber output by 78%. Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins calls the rule “overly restrictive,” but conservationists warn road building will fragment habitat, erode watersheds supplying 60m Americans, increase wildfire risk and release vast carbon stores. The rollback, despite 99% public opposition, reverses a decades-old consensus on protecting ecologically vital forests—threatening species from Alaska’s brown bears to Virginia’s trout.

articles.title: Judge blocks deployment of national guard to Oregon as Newsom vows to sue
articles.trailText: California governor says president ‘attacking rule of law’ as Trump-appointed judge rules twice to stop use of military
articles.summary: U.S. District Judge Karin Immergut issued a temporary restraining order through Oct. 19 halting President Trump’s deployment of California and Oregon National Guard troops to Portland, ruling there’s no evidence recent ICE protests posed threats requiring military support. The order came hours after Gov. Gavin Newsom vowed to sue, accusing the administration of attacking the rule of law. Pentagon spokesman Sean Parnell said 200 federalized CA guardsmen were reassigned to support ICE and federal property protection. Oregon AG Dan Rayfield also plans legal action, while the White House defends Trump’s authority to secure federal assets against “violent criminals.”

articles.title: US supreme court begins new term with nation’s democratic governance at stake
articles.trailText: Scrutiny on the nine justices is about to reach a new level of intensity as Trump aggressively asserts executive power
articles.summary: With a 6-3 conservative majority, the Supreme Court opens a fraught new term amid Trump’s aggressive executive-power bids. After overturning Roe v. Wade and granting broad presidential immunity, the court has ruled for the administration in roughly 20 cases, often via the shadow docket. Upcoming cases include challenges to the Voting Rights Act’s majority-Black districts (Louisiana v. Callais), transgender surgery bans, mail-in ballot rules and tariff authority—decisions legal experts warn could reshape democratic governance. Critics predict that unchecked rulings against civil liberties may prompt a judicial “civil war” as lower courts resist the high court’s expansive precedents.

articles.title: Tariffs, ‘conversion therapy’ and mail ballots: key US supreme court cases to watch this term
articles.trailText: Trump has voiced strong views on many of the issues the US high court will be tackling as justices assemble for new term
articles.summary: The Supreme Court’s new term starting October 6 will address five high-stakes disputes shaping Trump’s agenda: Chiles v Salazar (Oct 7) tests Colorado’s ban on ‘conversion therapy’ as protected speech; Bost v Illinois (Oct 8) challenges state mail-ballot rules; Louisiana v Callais (Oct 15) examines Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act and alleged racial gerrymandering; consolidated Learning Solutions v Trump and Trump v VOS Selections (Nov 5) probe the president’s tariff powers under the IEEPA; and Trump v Cook (Jan term) considers his authority to remove Fed Governor Lisa Cook amid questions of agency independence.

articles.title: Christian group ‘deceived’ supreme court about LGBTQ+ research, cited scholars say
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Experts say Alliance Defending Freedom, arguing to revive conversion therapy, ‘profoundly misrepresented’ their work in case threatening trans and queer youth
articles.summary: Alliance Defending Freedom asks the US Supreme Court to strike down Colorado’s 2019 ban on conversion therapy for minors in Chiles v Salazar, citing studies by University of Utah law professor Clifford Rosky and psychologist Lisa Diamond. Both scholars say ADF “profoundly misrepresented” their work—which documents conversion therapy’s psychological harm—to claim it supports reviving such practices. ADF also relied on discredited or ambivalent authorities, including Nicholas Cummings and Rev. D. Paul Sullins. Experts warn a ruling for ADF could weaken youth protections nationwide and embolden further attacks on trans and queer Americans.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Democrats say administration refusing shutdown talks as president repeats threat of firings
articles.trailText: Chuck Schumer says administration has ‘refused to talk with us’. Key US politics stories from 5 October at a glance
articles.summary: Facing a stalemated shutdown since Oct 1, the Trump administration warns it will mass‐layoff federal workers if talks “go absolutely nowhere,” per Kevin Hassett, while Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer says the White House has “refused to talk.” House Speaker Mike Johnson brands Democrats insincere as they demand low‐income healthcare be tied to funding. Meanwhile, Trump touted US strikes on a Venezuelan drug boat, California Gov. Newsom sued over National Guard deployments, Homeland Sec. Kristi Noem decried Chicago as a “war zone,” and Cairo‐brokered Gaza hostage talks pressed on amid intense Israeli bombardment.

articles.title: US struck another alleged drug boat off Venezuela coast, Trump says
articles.trailText: President said US would turn attention to drug trafficking happening on land during speech at navy ceremony
articles.summary: At a ceremony marking the US Navy’s 250th anniversary, President Trump announced US forces had struck another suspected drug-smuggling vessel off Venezuela’s coast, part of four Caribbean "cartel terrorist" strikes defending against Tren de Aragua shipments. He warned smugglers would shift to land trafficking next. The UN condemned the maritime strikes as extrajudicial killings. Trump decried the federal shutdown harming service members, vowed to rebuild the fleet - now smallest since WWII - and praised accelerated submarine production. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s leadership shakeup includes ending "woke" culture, adopting male-level fitness standards and using US cities for military training.

articles.title: House speaker claims Democrats aren’t serious about shutdown negotiation
articles.trailText: Mike Johnson adds Trump does not want permanent job cuts as talks between parties stalled over weekend
articles.summary: House Speaker Mike Johnson accused Senate Democrats of failing to engage in serious negotiations to end the fifth day of the federal government shutdown, arguing the House has passed a funding bill and it is now up to the Senate. He claimed Chuck Schumer fears an Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez challenge and cited President Trump’s opposition to permanent job cuts, while Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries countered that Republicans—including Trump���are lying about healthcare for undocumented immigrants. With talks stalled, no votes scheduled, and under 30% of voters backing shutdown tactics, both parties trade blame ahead of renewed discussions.

articles.title: Bad Bunny pushes back on Kristi Noem threat that immigrants stay away from Super Bowl
articles.trailText: Singer jokes on SNL that everyone was happy about his planned half-time show, ‘even Fox News’
articles.summary: Bad Bunny used SNL’s season premiere monologue to mock DHS Secretary Kristi Noem’s vow to deploy ICE at the 2026 Super Bowl, quipping “everyone’s happy about it—even Fox News.” He delivered a Spanish message praising Latinos’ enduring contributions and challenged English-speakers to learn Spanish in four months. A US citizen born in Puerto Rico, he excluded the US from his world tour amid immigration-raid fears. Noem had insisted only Americans should attend next year’s game and warned the NFL “will not be able to sleep” over his selection.

articles.title: Democrats are embracing the risky politics of a government shutdown to rein in president, activists say
articles.trailText: In ‘holding the line on healthcare’ Democrats answered the call to do something in a rare display of unity
articles.summary: Democrats in a rare show of unity have deliberately blocked Republican funding bills to force a government shutdown, leveraging a 60-vote Senate threshold to demand extension of expiring Affordable Care Act tax credits and curb President Trump’s budgetary overreach. Progressive activists and congressional leaders frame healthcare as their “north star,” while the administration readies punitive layoffs and partisan shutdown messaging. Early polls assign GOP more blame for closures. Democrats view the shutdown as their strongest leverage to protect ACA subsidies, limit executive power to rescind funding and mobilize their base ahead of critical midterm and 2026 elections.
