articles.title: Kristi Noem calls Chicago a ‘war zone’ after federal agents shoot woman
articles.trailText: Homeland security secretary takes aim at city’s mayor who has called deployment of national guard ‘unhinged’
articles.summary: In a Fox News interview, DHS Secretary Kristi Noem called Chicago “a war zone” after Border Patrol agents shot an armed US citizen accused of doxing agents, justifying Trump’s deployment of 300 Illinois National Guard troops to protect federal property. Noem blasted Mayor Brandon Johnson for “lying” to enable crime, while Governor J.B. Pritzker denounced the “un-American” intervention, saying it worsens violence and demanding the administration withdraw forces.

articles.title: Marco Rubio says Gaza war not yet over as Israel and Hamas prepare for talks
articles.trailText: Secretary of state says ‘we’ll know very quickly whether Hamas is serious or not’ about release of hostages from Gaza
articles.summary: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said Sunday the Gaza war remains ongoing even though Israel and Hamas have provisionally endorsed Donald Trump’s 20-point plan. He warned success hinges on how technical talks in Cairo proceed on the logistics of releasing roughly 48 remaining hostages—about 20 believed alive—within three days. US, Egyptian and Qatari mediators face roadblocks over prisoner exchanges, disarming Hamas and ceasefire timing. Trump cautioned Hamas risks “complete obliteration” if it stays in power. The plan’s second phase envisions Israel’s pullback and a technocratic Palestinian governance replacing Hamas. Rubio stressed urgency: “The hostage piece has to happen very, very fast.”

articles.title: ‘The president is unhinged’: Trump’s online behavior grows increasingly odd
articles.trailText: The US president’s recent behavior is strange to many, from reposting a false AI video of himself to confusing comments during press conferences
articles.summary: Since early October 2025, President Trump’s online activity has taken an erratic turn, from sharing a false AI clip of House leader Hakeem Jeffries in a sombrero to reposting an AI-generated “med bed” video depicting him promising miracle hospitals. After deleting the latter, aides offered no real explanation. Offline, he’s made confounding claims—linking Tylenol to autism, confusing Albania with Armenia, and posting gold-fixture tours amid news of a church shooting—while in a Virginia military meeting he delivered a disjointed, partisan address on Iran strikes, stairs-safety anecdotes and using “dangerous” US cities as training grounds, prompting bipartisan alarm over his fitness.

articles.title: Ohio’s sole national forest could be wiped out as Trump targets land for logging
articles.trailText: Over 80% of Wayne national forest classified as suitable for logging, drawing concern from locals
articles.summary: Trump's administration has designated over 80% of Ohio’s Wayne National Forest—one of only 154 national forests and the state’s sole federal forest—for large-scale logging by reclassifying it as “suitable for timber management” and rolling back NEPA protections. Conservationists warn clear-cut roads and lost root systems risk leaching coal-waste toxins into the Ohio River watershed, harming endangered hellbender salamanders and local drinking water, while increasing fire, landslide and flood hazards. Though timber sales can generate jobs in economically deprived Appalachian counties, critics note that road-building costs often exceed revenue and question logging public lands amid private forest abundance and $3.5 bn timber exports.

articles.title: Youth-led US climate activists widen focus to fight authoritarianism
articles.trailText: Sunrise Movement, which led calls for a Green New Deal, will organize against Trump’s attacks on universities
articles.summary: The Sunrise Movement, the youth-led climate justice group behind the Green New Deal, is broadening its mission to fight rising authoritarianism under Trump. Its new focus includes campus organizing to defend free speech and resist curriculum controls, rapid responses to troop deployments and immigration crackdowns, and training activists in nonviolent resistance. Local chapters are also tackling immigrant and labor rights, with plans for nationwide ICE opposition, support for defiant city officials, healthcare cuts resistance, and a mass student mobilization set for May 1, 2028—arguing that democratic rights are a prerequisite for bold climate action.

articles.title: How likely is it that Trump’s Gaza plan will work?
articles.trailText: The US president’s proposal is the closest negotiators have got to an end to the war – but a deal is still far off
articles.summary: Following Hamas’s partial acceptance of Trump’s 20-point Gaza ceasefire plan—hostage release, power handover to a technocratic Palestinian authority and Israeli troop withdrawal—US, Israeli and Palestinian negotiators meet in Cairo to resolve remaining disputes over disarmament, the nature of the governing body and withdrawal timetables. While Israel insists on Hamas disarmament and retains vague troop-presence plans, Hamas demands clear guarantees against re-entry. With over 67,000 Palestinian deaths and repeated peace-talk failures, cautious optimism abounds but both sides remain wary until binding language is agreed.

articles.title: Trump sets sights on liberal mega-donor George Soros: ‘a chilling message to other donors’
articles.trailText: Billionaire philanthropist makes ‘perfect cartoon villain’ as Trump attacks Democratic contributors before midterms
articles.summary: Donald Trump has publicly singled out billionaire donor George Soros for a potential Justice Department investigation into “leftwing terrorism” funding���despite no evidence—labeling him “at the top of everything.” Critics say the timing—just over a year before midterms—aims to intimidate Democratic mega-donors and chill contributions. Soros, aged 95, has donated over $32bn through the Open Society Foundations to global democracy, human rights, and civil rights groups. Conservatives long cast him as a “cartoon villain,” deploying coded antisemitic tropes.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: President authorizes sending national guard into Chicago as judge blocks Portland deployment
articles.trailText: Illinois governor JB Pritzker calls move unnecessary and ‘a manufactured performance’ – key US politics stories from 4 October at a glance
articles.summary: President Trump has authorized the Illinois National Guard’s 300-troop deployment to Chicago, citing “violent riots,” prompting Gov. JB Pritzker to deride the move as a “manufactured performance,” while a federal judge halted his planned Portland deployment, backing Gov. Tina Kotek’s argument that federal troops would inflame protests. Separately, a White House aide inadvertently revealed plans to send the 82nd Airborne to Portland; envoys, including Jared Kushner, left for Egypt to negotiate a Gaza ceasefire; Defense Sec. Pete Hegseth ousted the Navy chief of staff; a judge barred detaining immigrant minors past 18; and a former CDC official accused RFK Jr. of undermining infectious-disease policy.

articles.title: US envoys head to Egypt for Gaza ceasefire talks as Trump says ���we are very close’ to deal
articles.trailText: President says he will push to finalize agreement even as scores of Palestinians killed in latest Israeli attacks
articles.summary: Talks follow last month’s deadly Israeli airstrike on Hamas negotiators in Qatar that undermined ceasefire efforts. President Trump has dispatched envoys Jared Kushner and Steve Witkoff to Cairo to finalize technical details of a proposed hostage exchange and lasting Gaza ceasefire, following Hamas’s conditional acceptance of key elements in his 20-point plan. Egypt will host Israel and Hamas delegations to negotiate hostages-for-prisoners. Despite Trump’s demand to halt Israeli strikes, air raids killed scores of Palestinians including at least 17 in Gaza City. Netanyahu vows to recover hostages during Sukkot and disarm Hamas. Trump warns Hamas against delay, praises Erdoğan’s mediation and aims to restore Israel’s global standing.

articles.title: Trump authorizes national guard deployment to Chicago, White House says, as border patrol there shoots woman
articles.trailText: Illinois governor JB Pritzker says administration is escalating ‘aggression against Illinois citizens and residents’
articles.summary: President Trump authorized 300 Illinois National Guard troops to Chicago to protect federal officers and assets, citing “ongoing violent riots and lawlessness.” This follows border patrol agents reporting their vehicle was rammed and boxed in, then shooting and wounding a US citizen armed with a semi-automatic rifle, accused of trying to run them over and doxing agents. Governor JB Pritzker condemned it as a “manufactured performance” forced by a Pentagon ultimatum. Meanwhile, ICE’s Broadview facility faced protests and 13 arrests amid a broader immigration crackdown.

articles.title: Judge blocks Trump administration from deploying national guard to Portland
articles.trailText: US district judge agrees with Oregon assertion that deployment would likely inflame rather than calm protests in city
articles.summary: US District Judge Karin Immergut granted Oregon’s request to block President Trump’s plan to activate 200 federalized National Guard troops in Portland, ruling the deployment would inflame protests and likely violate constitutional and federal domestic troop statutes. Oregon AG Dan Rayfield and Gov. Tina Kotek, backed by 17 mayors, argued protests were peaceful, countering DOJ claims of violent “antifa” sieges. The restraining order marks a legal setback for Trump’s efforts to militarize Democratic-led cities amid nationwide civil unrest.

articles.title: Judge halts Trump administration from detaining immigrant children after they turn 18
articles.trailText: Ruling temporarily prevents transfer to adult detention centers that advocates said were planned for this weekend
articles.summary: US District Judge Rudolph Contreras issued a temporary restraining order on Oct. 4 blocking ICE from transferring unaccompanied immigrant children into adult detention after their 18th birthday, ruling it breaches a 2021 mandate to release them to the least restrictive settings. The ruling halts weekend transfer plans and intensifies legal pushback against Trump administration policies, including a $2,500 self-deportation stipend for minors, alleged family-separation coercion, fingerprinting and DNA screening delays, and data showing non-criminal migrants now form the largest detention group. Advocates warn these measures target vulnerable youth and deter asylum claims.

articles.title: US treasury considers special $1 Trump coin reading ‘fight, fight, fight’
articles.trailText: US treasurer says officials looking at drafts for country’s 250th anniversary featuring president with raised fist
articles.summary: The U.S. Treasury is reviewing draft designs for a $1 coin commemorating America’s 250th anniversary that feature Donald Trump raising a clenched fist under an American flag with the slogan “fight, fight, fight,” referencing his rallying cry after surviving a 2024 assassination attempt. Treasurer Brandon Beach shared the non-final mock-up on X, sparking debate over legal bans on living individuals’ portraits on commemorative coins. The design, enabled by 2026 semiquincentennial legislation Trump signed in 2020, would navigate longstanding coinage rules and mirror past anniversary issues whose surcharges fund federal monuments and museums.

articles.title: How Democrats are trying to bust Republican lies about healthcare for undocumented immigrants
articles.trailText: At the centre of the government shutdown is the issue of healthcare for Americans being stripped by Trump’s ‘big, beautiful bill’
articles.summary: Amid the current government shutdown triggered by funding disputes, Republicans and Trump falsely claim Democrats sought “free healthcare for undocumented immigrants,” alleging their resolution would undo the One Big Beautiful Bill Act’s cuts to immigrant health benefits. Democrats counter that federal law already prohibits Medicaid, Medicare and ACA coverage for undocumented immigrants, insisting their funding bill only restores Medicaid eligibility for lawfully present non-citizens (TPS holders, refugees and asylum seekers) and permanently extends popular ACA premium tax credits due to expire in 2025. The CBO projects those OBBBA cuts could strip coverage from 1.4 million lawfully present immigrants, while subsidy lapses risk 4 million Americans losing insurance.

articles.title: Kristi Noem warns immigrants away from Super Bowl: ‘We’ll be all over that place’
articles.trailText: Homeland security chief also excoriates NFL for selecting Bad Bunny to perform during game’s half-time break
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s DHS secretary Kristi Noem declared ICE will target noncitizens at next year’s Super Bowl, warning only law-abiding Americans should attend. Speaking to podcaster Benny Johnson, she vowed to “enforce the law” and railed against the NFL’s choice of Puerto Rican rapper Bad Bunny for halftime, claiming organizers “will not be able to sleep.” Bad Bunny, who excluded the US from his tour over raid fears, has drawn conservative ire for criticizing immigration policies. The White House said there’s no specific ICE plan for the game but reaffirmed its commitment to deport criminal noncitizens.

articles.title: White House official inadvertently reveals plans to send elite army unit to Portland
articles.trailText: Anthony Salisbury displayed chat about deployment of 82nd airborne division on cell phone while in Minnesota
articles.summary: A senior White House official, Anthony Salisbury, inadvertently exposed via Signal chats a plan to deploy the 82nd Airborne Division to Portland, Oregon. In messages viewed publicly in Minnesota, Salisbury conferred with Patrick Weaver, adviser to Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, who sought President Trump’s explicit go-ahead amid concerns about backlash over using active-duty troops. Weaver noted Hegseth preferred National Guard forces to avoid headlines. Hegseth later announced 200 guard personnel “immediately” but local reports say none are yet in place. The White House defended Salisbury, calling the leaks unclassified and criticizing reporters. This follows previous administration Signal leaks.

articles.title: Empty tollbooths, ‘devastated’ visitors: shutdown throws US national parks into limbo
articles.trailText: Some parks are closed, some are trying to function with a skeleton staff – and visitors and employees are frustrated
articles.summary: With the government shutdown underway, 9,296 of 14,500 National Park Service staff are furloughed, forcing closures at sites like Mesa Verde and Aztec Ruins while parks such as Yosemite and Grand Canyon remain open on skeleton crews with self-issued permits and no maintenance. Concession operators can operate independently, but law enforcement is stretched. Advocates warn the shutdown could cost the Park Service $1m in daily fees and local gateway communities up to $80m, leaving parks and economies in limbo.

articles.title: Small US college towns reel amid Trump immigration crackdown: ‘They need international students’
articles.trailText: From Ohio to Florida, the US government’s clampdown on students from abroad threatens rural universities and local businesses
articles.summary: Small US college towns from Oxford, Ohio, to West Lafayette, Indiana, and Champaign, Illinois, face steep declines in international enrollment—down 40% nationwide, with 150,000 fewer students—driven by Trump-era visa restrictions, enhanced screening, and fear of arrest over campus protests. Miami University’s international cohort fell from 2,895 to 750, costing about $140 million locally; Ohio, Kentucky and Iowa could each lose tens to hundreds of millions more. These students pay full tuition, sustain restaurants, housing and over 10,000 jobs; their absence threatens closures and broader economic chaos in rural communities.

articles.title: Pete Hegseth fires US navy chief of staff
articles.trailText: Jon Harrison, appointed in January, had been key to broad changes in military branch’s policy and budgeting offices
articles.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth abruptly dismissed Navy Chief of Staff Jon Harrison, who since his January appointment had driven sweeping policy and budget reforms alongside Secretary John Phelan. Harrison’s exit, confirmed by the Pentagon and first reported by Politico, follows the Senate confirmation of new Navy Undersecretary Hung Cao, after Harrison and Phelan allegedly sidelined aides meant to support Cao. The firing is the latest in Hegseth’s aggressive shake-up: he’s cut 20% of four-star officers, dismissed several top generals—including the only female admirals and Air Force Gen CQ Brown Jr—and denounced DoD “woke” initiatives in a recent address.

articles.title: OpenAI launch of video app Sora plagued by violent and racist images: ‘The guardrails are not real’
articles.trailText: Misinformation researchers say lifelike scenes could obfuscate truth and lead to fraud, bullying and intimidation
articles.summary: OpenAI’s invite-only video generator Sora 2, released October 2025 with a social feed, topped Apple’s charts before users flooded it with graphic violence and racist content—from simulated mass shootings on campuses to white-supremacist slogans and war-zone clips with AI-fabricated children. Despite terms banning harmful content and promised guardrails, Sora’s feed already features copyrighted characters in extremist contexts and fake crypto scams. Researchers warn lifelike AI videos risk deepening misinformation, fraud, bullying and intimidation, eroding public trust. OpenAI says it will refine safeguards and honor takedown requests.

articles.title: Mike Johnson hasn’t sworn in this new Democrat. Is it because she wants to release the Epstein files?
articles.trailText: Adelita Grijalva of Arizona came to Washington DC this week, but returned two days later, a little confused
articles.summary: Arizona Democrat Adelita Grijalva, elected in a special race to replace her late father, remains “representative-elect” after Speaker Mike Johnson has not administered her oath of office. Grijalva attributes the delay to her intent to sign a discharge petition—needing her signature for 218 lawmakers—to force a vote on releasing Jeffrey Epstein files, a move opposed by Johnson and Trump. With the House adjourned amid a shutdown over funding, Johnson says he’ll swear her in only once the chamber reopens, leaving her unable to serve constituents.

articles.title: ‘He wasn’t this national hero’: US college students voice concern over Charlie Kirk’s idolization
articles.trailText: Black, brown and LGBTQ+ students across the US are puzzled by all the praise the far-right commentator has received after his killing
articles.summary: Following Charlie Kirk’s assassination on September 10, Black, brown and LGBTQ+ college students nationwide have decried his hagiography, pointing to his anti-marginalized rhetoric. At HBCUs such as Howard and Tennessee State, racist threats and a “Fearless Tour” stunt sparked fear. Meanwhile, students at Texas Tech and Texas State faced expulsion or withdrawal over mocking his death, raising free-speech concerns. Legal experts warn that this backlash could justify heightened campus militarization, censorship and regressions in racial equity. Many see Kirk’s martyring as part of a broader cycle of progress followed by reactionary crackdowns on dissenting voices.

articles.title: A ‘hostile takeover’: ousted CDC official raises alarm over RFK Jr approach to infectious disease
articles.trailText: Debra Houry speaks after testifying on eight months under Kennedy, who critics say shuns science and spreads falsehoods
articles.summary: Debra Houry, the former CDC chief medical officer, told a Senate committee that HHS secretary RFK Jr. sidelined experts during deadly measles, flu and bird-flu outbreaks, met her only once in eight months and pushed unwarranted changes to childhood immunization schedules. She accuses Kennedy of ignoring science, spreading misinformation—denouncing vaccines, removing COVID-19 and MMR recommendations and proposing hepatitis B delays without data or CDC input. Houry called his tenure a “hostile takeover,” warned that 80% of veteran CDC leaders have departed and urged his resignation over eroded public-health trust and preparedness.

articles.title: Body slamming, teargas and pepper balls: viral videos show Ice using extreme force in Chicago
articles.trailText: A facility in Broadview, a mostly Black suburb, has become the site of escalation and ‘targeted attacks’ on protesters
articles.summary: In Broadview, a majority‐Black Chicago suburb, viral footage shows ICE agents deploying tear gas, pepper balls and body‐slamming protesters and journalists outside a processing facility, part of the Trump administration’s “Operation Midway Blitz.” Federal and local police have arrested advocates including congressional candidate Kat Abughazaleh and city officials. Workers at an adjacent warehouse report chemical exposure. Illinois agencies formed a unified command to protect First Amendment protests. Detainees inside the overcrowded facility describe squalid conditions. Legal observers and reporters, including CBS Chicago’s Asal Rezaei and Unraveled Press’s Steve Held, have been attacked, drawing civil rights outcry.

articles.title: Fired national security prosecutor warns colleagues in note on way out
articles.trailText: Michael Ben’Ary says he was fired based on a social media post by a January 6 conspiracy theorist
articles.summary: Michael Ben’Ary, a veteran national security prosecutor in the Eastern District of Virginia, says he was abruptly fired after pro-Trump commentator Julie Kelly, a January 6 conspiracy theorist, falsely accused him on social media of bias due to ties to Deputy AG Lisa Monaco. His exit joins politically driven ousters of interim US attorney Erik Siebert and prosecutor Troy Edwards, occurring mid-prosecution of a suspected Islamic State Afghan branch operative linked to the deadly Abbey Gate attack. Ben’Ary warns DOJ leadership prioritizes punishing perceived enemies over national security.

articles.title: How Maga cheerleaders have infiltrated the White House press corps
articles.trailText: Trump administration has transformed tone and tenor of media interactions by centering rightwing voices and reporter sycophancy
articles.summary: Trump’s second term has seen a deliberate reshaping of the White House press corps: the administration now hand-picks questioners, excluding wire services and inviting fringe MAGA reporters and influencers—Brian Glenn (Real America’s Voice), Benny Johnson, One America News and Gateway Pundit correspondents—who lob softball questions and praise. Since January these right-wing voices accounted for 41% of briefing-room calls, often used to blunt tough inquiries. Critics from Tara Setmayer to Matt Gertz warn this sycophancy echoes authoritarian playbooks to suppress accountability. Still, mainstream stalwarts like Jim Acosta and NBC’s Yamiche Alcindor continue probing with hard-hitting queries.

articles.title: ‘I’m fearful people will die’: Pennsylvania reckons with impact of Trump cuts
articles.trailText: In Johnstown, thousands live in poverty – and voters went for Trump. How are people feeling as his devastating cuts take hold?
articles.summary: In Johnstown, PA—once a steel powerhouse now marked by poverty, flooding and industrial decline—nearly half of households live below basic living costs. Residents like Ernest Hairston and Will Dill depend on Medicaid, SNAP ($6/day) and HUD grants set to be slashed under Trump’s mega‐bill imposing work requirements and $200 billion cuts to food assistance. Many low-income voters still back Trump, blaming welfare culture, while others warn that losing benefits could cost lives—analysts project 150 preventable deaths annually in the region.

articles.title: California measure brings rideshare drivers one step closer to unionizing
articles.trailText: Governor Gavin Newsom signs measure opening path to more than 800,000 drivers to bargain for wages and benefits
articles.summary: California Gov Gavin Newsom signed bipartisan legislation enabling more than 800,000 Uber and Lyft drivers to unionize as independent contractors, marking the largest private-sector collective bargaining expansion in state history. The deal, negotiated with SEIU and the rideshare companies, also cuts state-mandated accident insurance coverage from $1 million to $60,000 per person (and $300,000 per accident), a change expected to save Lyft $200 million. Drivers can now bargain over pay, benefits, deactivation rules and paid leave, though advocates want stronger data-reporting mandates.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Hamas says it has approved parts of Donald Trump’s ultimatum to end war in Gaza
articles.trailText: President says Israel must ‘stop the bombing of Gaza’ while Palestinian group says it wants further negotiations over plan – key US politics stories from 3 October at a glance
articles.summary: Hamas approved two key elements of Trump’s 20-point Gaza peace plan—hostage swap and transfer of Gaza governance to technocrats—while refusing to disarm and seeking further talks. Trump hailed this as progress and ordered Israel to halt Gaza bombings. Also: third day of government shutdown over stalled Senate funding votes; US strike killed four on alleged Venezuelan drug boat; Apple removed an ICE-tracking app under Trump pressure; Supreme Court allowed ending protected status for 300,000 Venezuelans; FBI cut ties with two extremism-tracking groups; and other briefs from paused Chicago infrastructure funds to an Arkansas man’s visa restoration bid.

articles.title: Trump administration to offer unaccompanied minors $2,500 to self-deport, memo reveals
articles.trailText: Voluntary departure has always been an option, but ‘astonishing’ decision to incentivize children to leave is new
articles.summary: The Trump administration will offer unaccompanied immigrant children aged 14 and older a one-time $2,500 'resettlement support stipend' to voluntarily self-deport, according to an HHS memo. Excluding Mexican minors, the incentive replaces typical court-supervised voluntary departure with a cash inducement that critics say breaches child protection laws and risks coercion, trafficking, and due process violations. DHS says stipends are disbursed only after a judge approves return and the child arrives home. Advocates and members of Congress denounce the policy as exploiting traumatised youth, pressuring them to abandon legal claims and reunification rights.

articles.title: Stunned Combs holds head in hands as judge unmoved by pleas for mercy
articles.trailText: Mogul appeared shocked after sentence read out to hushed courtroom but prosecutors disappointed by 50-month term
articles.summary: In a hushed Manhattan courtroom on Friday, Sean “Diddy” Combs was sentenced to 50 months in prison for two counts of transporting women for prostitution, far below the 135 months prosecutors sought and ten months under the advisory range. Convicted of coercing ‘freak-off’ encounters but acquitted of running a broader sex-trafficking conspiracy, Combs appeared stunned as Judge Arun Subramanian rejected his plea for mercy. Citing abuse, power and resources, the judge praised victims��� bravery and underscored Combs’s unchanged behavior despite apologies and claims of reform.

articles.title: Nature, books and naked bike rides: Portlanders refute Trump claims they are ‘living in hell’
articles.trailText: On the ground in the Oregon city, with rich fall colors and leafy hiking trails, things look different than on Trump’s TV
articles.summary: In Portland, Oregon, residents rebut Donald Trump’s portrayal of their city as ‘living in hell,’ showcasing verdant hiking trails, fall foliage, a thriving food scene and bookstore culture via TikTok and Instagram. Fewer than ten demonstrators faced off with a pro-Trump influencer, prompting three arrests and an impending 200-troop National Guard deployment. Locals—from Powell’s Books to Haitian eatery Kann���warn false claims threaten small businesses. Protesters plan an “Emergency Naked Bike Ride” against militarization. Veteran Amanda Cochran holds “Vets Against Militarization” signs, while chicken-costume organizer Jack Dickinson satirizes right-wing agitators, arguing Portland refuses to play their provocation game.

articles.title: US government shutdown continues as Senate funding bills again fail to pass
articles.trailText: Democratic and Republican proposals fail to cross 60-vote threshold as impasse persists and Trump plots more cuts
articles.summary: On day three of the shutdown, Senate votes on both GOP‐backed and Democratic funding bills again failed to reach the 60‐vote threshold, extending the stalemate as the Trump administration threatens further cuts and project cancellations. Republicans insist on reopening government first; Democrats demand reversal of Medicaid cuts, extension of ACA tax credits, restoration of public media funding and an end to Trump’s foreign aid rescissions. The funding lapse stalled Labor’s monthly jobs report and paused $2.1 billion in Chicago transit contracts. Senate GOP leader John Thune and House Speaker Mike Johnson refuse to negotiate, pressing to flip a handful of Democrats to pass a continuing resolution through Nov. 21.

articles.title: Trump administration freezes $2.1bn in funds for Chicago transit projects
articles.trailText: OMB director Russ Vought presented the pause as a move against diversity efforts in latest jab to Democratic-led city
articles.summary: The Trump administration has frozen $2.1bn in federal funding for Chicago transit projects – notably the 5.5-mile Red Line extension and modernization of the “L” system – citing a new DOT rule to review race-based contracting. OMB director Russ Vought framed the pause as a pushback against “diversity efforts” in the Democratic-led city amid the partial government shutdown. Vought previously halted $18bn for New York’s Hudson River tunnel and Second Avenue Subway under the same rationale. These funding delays, part of a broader political pressure campaign, face likely legal challenges.

articles.title: Hegseth says four killed in US strike on alleged drug boat off Venezuelan coast
articles.trailText: Pentagon chief says strike – fourth by US military in recent weeks – targeted boat with ‘substantial amounts’ of drugs
articles.summary: US defense secretary Pete Hegseth, acting on President Trump’s orders, announced a strike in international waters off the Venezuelan coast that killed four aboard an alleged drug-trafficking vessel carrying “substantial amounts” of narcotics. It marks the fourth such strike in recent weeks under a newly declared “non-international armed conflict” with cartels. In a confidential memo to Congress, the administration claims these narco-terrorists—designated under a novel “Designated Terrorist Organization” category—justify lethal force under Article II self-defense powers. Legal experts question the evidence linking cartel Tren de Aragua to Maduro’s government, and previous strikes killing 17 have drawn international outrage.

articles.title: Texas man faces hate-crime charges for spray painting anti-Israel graffiti on side of church
articles.trailText: Raunaq Alam and two others were arrested in connection with graffiti on wall of non-denominational church
articles.summary: Raunaq Alam (32) was arrested in March 2024 with two others for spray-painting 'Fuck Israel' on Uncommon Church’s wall, which displays an Israeli flag. Prosecutors raised damage estimates from under $200 to over $750 and added a hate-crime enhancement for targeting Jews and Israelis. A jury rejected the enhancement, convicted him of criminal mischief and fined him $10,000 without jail, but Judge Brian Bolton overrode that, sentencing Alam to 180 days behind bars. Now facing five arrests and false-statement charges, he remains free on bond with electronic monitoring. Co-defendant Afsheen Khan’s trial is set for this fall amid broader US protests and antisemitism probes.

articles.title: ‘Time for Democrats to exercise what power they have’: readers on the US shutdown
articles.trailText: Guardian readers said they agreed with the Democrats’ position – but some shared concerns about their tactics
articles.summary: After the US federal government shut down following Democrats’ refusal to back a Republican funding bill, Guardian readers largely endorse using the shutdown as leverage for ACA premium tax credit extensions, Medicaid funding restorations, and public media financing, and to block Donald Trump’s pocket rescissions. Many applaud Democrats exercising minority power to protect healthcare and Congress’s power of the purse, while others warn of job losses, convoluted strategy, unclear goals, and question whether healthcare should dominate the standoff.

articles.title: Apple removes Ice tracking apps after pressure from Trump administration
articles.trailText: Company removed IceBlock and similar immigration agent alert apps from its App Store, citing ‘safety risks’
articles.summary: Apple removed IceBlock and similar crowdsourced ICE-tracking apps from its iOS App Store, citing ‘safety risks’ after pressure from the Trump administration. Launched in April by musician-turned-entrepreneur Joshua Aaron, the Waze-style app had over 1 million users reporting Immigration and Customs Enforcement activity within a 5-mile radius. Apple flagged ‘objectionable content’ based on law enforcement feedback, though existing users can still use it. DHS Secretary Kristi Noem and AG Pam Bondi labeled it ‘obstructing justice,’ and Aaron alleges DOJ retaliation against his wife. Despite removal, users continue seeking map-based law-enforcement alerts.

articles.title: Ice protests continue in Portland amid Trump’s latest federal deployment
articles.trailText: Kristi Noem reportedly promises ‘surge’ of Ice resources to city after rightwing commentator arrested over police fight
articles.summary: Portland activists and rightwing provocateurs clashed outside a local ICE facility Thursday, coinciding with the Trump administration’s fresh deployment of federal officers and national guard troops on federal orders. Rightwing commentator Nick Sortor was arrested after a fight, then freed, spurring DHS secretary Kristi Noem to promise an ICE “surge.” A coalition of 17 Oregon mayors and AG Dan Rayfield sued to block 200 federalized guard members; a judge will hear arguments Friday. Trump’s hardline immigration measures, antifa terrorist designation, and past federal interventions in Portland, LA, DC, Chicago and Memphis underscore this latest enforcement push.

articles.title: ‘Stronger every day’: 12-year-old who survived Minneapolis school shooting returns to class
articles.trailText: Lydia Kaiser suffered a bullet wound to the head in the deadly mass shooting at Annunciation Catholic school
articles.summary: Lydia Kaiser, 12, who was shot in the head shielding a younger classmate during the August 27 mass shooting at Annunciation Catholic School in Minneapolis, has returned to class after suffering a traumatic brain injury that required skull surgery. A GoFundMe for medical and recovery costs has raised over $412,000. While she can’t yet play sports, she’s cheering on her volleyball and basketball teams and feeling ‘stronger every day’. Her father, Annunciation’s gym teacher, met with VP JD Vance to urge commonsense, bipartisan gun control. As gunfire on US school grounds surges, her community emphasizes healing, solidarity and faith.

articles.title: Trump administration will ‘enable human trafficking’ by freezing funds for survivors, groups warn
articles.trailText: Plea to Congress from 74 legal, religious and advocacy groups comes in wake of Guardian reporting on cuts to federal efforts to combat human trafficking
articles.summary: Seventy-four legal, religious and advocacy organizations (including Freedom Network USA, the Human Trafficking Legal Center and the National Advocacy Center of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd) have pressed Congress to demand the Trump administration release $88m in Justice Department funds frozen since late September that support more than 100 service providers for human trafficking survivors. A Guardian investigation revealed a rollback of federal anti-trafficking initiatives. The letter warns that stagnant funding leaves survivors without emergency housing, case management or counseling, risks re-exploitation and emboldens traffickers. DOJ maintains that appropriated money will be spent "eventually" under new administrative priorities despite bipartisan congressional backing over 25 years.

articles.title: US military under fire in Virginia, but were Trump and Hegseth shooting blanks?
articles.trailText: President and his defence chief took aim at the ‘fat generals’, but some doubted there was much substance to the swagger on show
articles.summary: At a secret Quantico briefing, President Trump and defence chief Pete Hegseth rallied roughly 800 top US officers with an anti-woke, partisan directive, denouncing ‘fat generals’, pledging to deploy troops against crime in Democrat-run cities, and banning diversity, equity and inclusion programs. They threatened purges and loyalty oaths but ultimately made no firings or policy changes. Military insiders and thinktanks called it more spectacle than substance—‘could have been an email’—warning the stunt risks politicizing the armed forces and eroding civil‐military norms.

articles.title: Journalist Mario Guevara deported to El Salvador after 100 days in Ice custody
articles.trailText: Removal comes after Emmy-winning Salvadorian reporter was arrested while covering ‘No Kings Day’ protest
articles.summary: Emmy-winning Salvadoran journalist Mario Guevara, a fixture in Atlanta media for two decades, was deported to El Salvador after 100 days in ICE custody. Arrested while livestreaming ‘No Kings Day’ protests on petty charges later dismissed, he was held under reopened deportation orders despite a valid work permit and two U.S. citizen children. His detention, among the longest for a U.S. journalist, prompted CPJ, PEN America, Reporters Without Borders, the ACLU and Free Press to file an appeals brief, warning of a chilling effect on press freedom and the right to film law enforcement as his family faces financial and emotional hardship.

articles.title: RFK Jr fires top NIH scientist weeks after she files whistleblower complaint
articles.trailText: Jeanne Marrazzo’s complaint reportedly involved the Trump administration’s hostility toward vaccines
articles.summary: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. abruptly terminated NIH immunologist Jeanne Marrazzo on Sept. 26, three weeks after she filed a whistleblower complaint accusing the Trump administration of politicizing vaccine research, undermining grants, and flouting court orders. Marrazzo, who was demoted from NIAID director in March, received no explanation for her firing. The dismissal is part of Kennedy’s broader HHS “restructuring,” targeting 10,000 job cuts and following his rollback of $500m in mRNA vaccine grants, consolidating over one-quarter of personnel losses across federal health agencies.

articles.title: Megachurch pastor and ex-Trump adviser pleads guilty to child sexual abuse
articles.trailText: Robert Morris to serve only six months in county jail after charged with five counts of lewd or indecent acts with child
articles.summary: Robert Morris, 64, founder of Texas’s 25,000-member Gateway Church and former Trump spiritual adviser, pleaded guilty in Oklahoma to five counts of lewd or indecent acts with a minor for abusing a 12-year-old girl from 1982 to 1986. Sentenced to 10 years with a plea deal of six months in county jail, he must register as a sex offender and pay $250,000 restitution. Victim Cindy Clemishire, who confronted him in court, detailed years of abuse and a 2005 bribery attempt. Morris resigned last year amid the fallout.

articles.title: Fire still burning at California Chevron refinery following explosion
articles.trailText: No injuries reported in El Segundo, site of company’s second-biggest US refinery, which supplies jet fuel for LA airport
articles.summary: An explosion on Thursday night ignited a fire at Chevron’s El Segundo refinery, second-largest US facility, which supplies 20% of California’s motor fuels and 40% of southern California jet fuel. The blaze, confined to the Isomax 7 unit, was still burning Friday with no injuries; all staff are accounted for. Cause remains unclear. Operating capacity is 290,000 barrels/day with 12.5 million-barrel storage. Officials from Gov. Newsom’s office and LA mayor’s office coordinated with fire authorities. No impact on LAX fuel supply, though local gasoline prices could climb.

articles.title: Break in 1991 Texas yoghurt shop murders sparks hope for cold cases: ‘There are other victims out there’
articles.trailText: Advances in DNA testing led to a suspect in the deaths of four girls. Can lab results now link a serial killer to other violent crimes?
articles.summary: Advances in DNA testing and ballistics databases have identified deceased serial killer Robert Eugene Brashers as the sole perpetrator in the infamous 1991 murders of four teenage girls at an Austin frozen yogurt shop. Federal legislation in 2022 spurred the cold-case review, and renewed Y-STR and NIBIN analyses matched trace DNA and a shell casing to Brashers, vindicating two men coerced into false confessions. Brashers is now linked to five more violent crimes across South Carolina, Kentucky, Missouri and Tennessee. Families praised the long-awaited closure and urged immediate uploads of cold-case evidence and rape kits to national databases.

articles.title: California governor under pressure over bill to ban cookware made with Pfas
articles.trailText: Gavin Newsom, who has vetoed environmental bills before, feeling push from industry and celebrity chefs on next steps
articles.summary: California governor Gavin Newsom faces pressure from cookware makers, celebrity chefs and the Cookware Sustainability Alliance to veto a bill, approved September 12, banning sale of PFAS-containing “forever chemical” nonstick pans. Public health advocates, including NRDC and Clean Water Action, warn PFAS are linked to cancer, immune issues and environmental persistence. Newsom, who has vetoed similar toxic-chemical measures before, must decide by October 13 as industry argues chefs need PTFE coatings and warns of cost burdens, while supporters point to safe stainless steel, ceramic and cast-iron alternatives.

articles.title: Republican bill targets migrants who re-enter US illegally with mandatory 10-year sentences
articles.trailText: Critics of new GOP act say it is a ‘mass incarceration bill’ that forces harsh penalties on migrants for a non-violent offense
articles.summary: Republicans advanced the Stop Illegal Entry Act (HR3486), imposing mandatory minimums on unauthorized re-enterers: 5 years if convicted of a crime punishable by over one year, and a 10-year minimum—matching child sex-trafficking penalties—for offenses punishable up to two years. The House passed it on 11 September, largely along party lines with limited Democratic and White House support; Senator Cruz now pushes it in the Senate. Critics call it mass incarceration, warning it could send 7,000+ migrants to prison at $440k each, jam courts, strain the Bureau of Prisons and erode due process.

articles.title: First Thing: Federal agencies blaming Democrats for shutdown in possible breach of law
articles.trailText: Actions could be a violation of legislation that prohibits federal employees from engaging in partisan political activity. Plus, how a plant-rich diet could prevent 40,000 early deaths a day globally
articles.summary: Several federal agencies and furloughed staff have blamed Democrats for the government shutdown—some by scheduling automated out-of-office emails reading "not working because Democrats caused a shutdown," others via hostile website messaging like the Treasury’s "the radical left has chosen to shut down the United States government." These actions may breach the 1939 Hatch Act, barring on-duty partisan activity. Lawmakers missed a funding deadline after Democrats sought concessions on healthcare, public media and foreign aid, which Republicans refused. Representative Jamie Raskin called the messaging a "naked violation" of the law.

articles.title: My travels through Chicago: teargas, resistance and Trump’s big immigration crackdown
articles.trailText: Donald Trump recently launched ‘Operation Midway Blitz’ in the city and threatened to send in the National Guard. The mood is febrile, with fears things could get worse
articles.summary: In early September, Trump’s ‘Operation Midway Blitz’ in Democratic Chicago targeted Broadview, a fortified ICE processing center where families like 22-year-old Milagros Pelayo and her sister braved tear gas while seeking information on their detained father amid reports of overcrowding and squalid conditions. Federal agents in fatigues repelled protesters with pepper balls, spurring community leaders—from jiu-jitsu instructor Elias Cepeda’s neighborhood patrols to congressional candidate Kat Abughazaleh—to decry what they call an authoritarian crackdown, intensified by Trump’s vow to deploy the National Guard and evocations of Charlie Kirk’s killing, fueling grassroots resistance and wider polarization.

articles.title: Tesla sued by family of California teenager killed in fiery Cybertruck crash
articles.trailText: Lawsuit alleges the design of the vehicle’s door handles is at fault for Krysta Tsukahara’s death
articles.summary: Tesla faces suit by parents of 19-year-old Krysta Tsukahara, killed after her Cybertruck struck a tree in Piedmont, CA on Nov 27, 2024, ignited and door power cut, trapping occupants. Suit in Alameda Superior Court alleges faulty flush electric door handles with no manual override prevented escape, causing her death by smoke inhalation. Cites prior entrapment incidents, ongoing NHTSA probe and eight recalls. Vehicle had high crash-test ratings. Family also sued the intoxicated driver’s estate. They argue Tesla had notice of the risk and her death was preventable.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: President hails shutdown as ‘opportunity’ to further campaign of cuts
articles.trailText: The government has already announced the cancellation of billions of dollars in federal funding for projects tied to Democrats. Key US politics stories from Thursday 2 October at a glance
articles.summary: With the US shutdown entering day two, President Trump praised it as an “unprecedented opportunity” to advance Project 2025 cuts, meeting with OMB chief Russell Vought to target agencies—already axing billions in Democrat-linked funding. He also labeled Caribbean drug cartels “unlawful combatants” under a non-international armed conflict. Meanwhile, Hamas signals it may accept—but only after revising key elements of—Trump’s Gaza ceasefire proposal. In California, Gov. Newsom vowed to slash state funding for universities endorsing Trump’s “academic compact” limiting departments, international students, and diversity policies. In Baltimore, an immigration judge denied Kilmar Ábrego García’s asylum bid. Other items: Elon Musk’s Netflix boycott push; White House’s disputed Tylenol-autism links.

articles.title: Trump officials push claim that US in ‘armed conflict’ with drug cartels
articles.trailText: Administration attempts to justify strikes on alleged Venezuelan drug boats by claiming US under ‘armed attack’
articles.summary: The Trump administration has told Congress it considers US strikes on three Caribbean vessels carrying alleged Venezuelan cartel members part of a ‘non-international armed conflict,’ labeling drug gangs as ‘non-state armed groups’ whose operations constitute an armed attack on the United States. Officials cite self-defense and drug-flow prevention to justify killing 17 people and bolstering military deployments around Puerto Rico. Critics—including lawmakers and human rights groups—question the legal basis, and intelligence assessments cast doubt on purported ties between Maduro’s government and the cartels.

articles.title: Anti-abortion groups furious as FDA approves generic abortion pill
articles.trailText: Abortion rights supporters hail win for evidence-backed medicine as Evita Solutions’ generic version of mifepristone given approval
articles.summary: FDA quietly approved Evita Solutions’ generic mifepristone, surprising anti-abortion activists who've lobbied since Roe v Wade’s 2022 overturn to curb access. Sen. Josh Hawley and Students for Life condemned the approval, citing a flawed, non-peer-reviewed report alleging serious complications despite 100+ peer-reviewed studies affirming safety. Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s promised HHS review had raised hopes for restrictions, making the approval unexpected. Abortion rights groups, including Hey Jane’s CEO Kiki Freedman, hailed expanded generic options as critical for evidence-based care amid political attacks. The HHS notes limited FDA discretion under legal mandates.

articles.title: California vows to ‘instantly’ cut funding to universities that cave to Trump ‘compact’
articles.trailText: Governor Gavin Newsom urges schools not to sign ‘radical agreement’ to cuts to departments, students and speech
articles.summary: California governor Gavin Newsom vowed to cut state funding instantly any public university that signs the Trump administration’s “Compact for Academic Excellence in Higher Education.” The deal, offered to nine campuses including USC, would require trimming departments deemed hostile to conservatives, capping international undergraduates at 15% (5% per country), imposing federal gender definitions, banning race/sex criteria in hiring and admissions, controlling endowment spending, tuition freeze, and curbing grade inflation, in exchange for federal grants. Newsom calls it a hostile takeover threatening academic freedom.

articles.title: Federal agencies blaming Democrats for shutdown in potentially illegal move
articles.trailText: Departments and staff are using out-of-office emails and websites to engage in partisan political activity
articles.summary: Furloughed federal employees across more than a dozen agencies—including Justice, Treasury, Agriculture, Education, and HHS��have been instructed to use out-of-office replies and website banners blaming Democrats for the government shutdown. Critics say this partisan messaging breaches the Hatch Act and Anti-Deficiency Act, turning taxpayer-funded sites into propaganda. NGOs like CREW and Public Citizen have lodged ethics complaints, while GAO and inspectors general face calls to probe potential legal violations. Lawmakers from both parties warn this politicization undermines trust in essential services.

articles.title: Travel, national parks and housing: what does the US government shutdown mean for everyday people?
articles.trailText: Several thousand federal employees will be furloughed or must do unpaid work. Regular people will feel it differently
articles.summary: Shutdown furloughs hundreds of thousands of federal workers (EPA 89%, HUD 71%, etc.)—essential staff (military, TSA, air traffic control, Postal Service, VA) work unpaid and get back pay; contractors excluded. Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, SNAP/WIC continue; passport/visa, FDA approvals and NIH research slow; flights operate with potential delays. National parks stay open but under-staffed; Smithsonian open to Oct 6. HUD fair-housing and Flood Insurance halt home sales; consumer protection agencies are paralyzed, raising predatory risk.

articles.title: Trump sees ‘unprecedented opportunity’ to punish Democrats as shutdown enters day two
articles.trailText: Republicans and Democrats engage in war of words as White House also uses impasse to cut government spending
articles.summary: As the US government shutdown entered its second day, former President Donald Trump dubbed it an “unprecedented opportunity” to slash Democratic agencies, announcing on Truth Social a meeting with OMB director Russell Vought—architect of Project 2025—to decide on temporary or permanent cuts. Vought immediately froze roughly $18bn in New York–area infrastructure projects over alleged “unconstitutional DEI principles” and withheld $8bn for programs in 16 Democratic-run states, sparking fierce backlash from Schumer, Jeffries, Schiff and Wyden as political retribution. While press secretary Leavitt warned of imminent layoffs—deviating from past furloughs—some Republicans expressed unease. With both chambers deadlocked and Yom Kippur halting Senate votes, no breakthrough is in sight.

articles.title: Slash and burn: Trump budget chief relishes chance to cut, fire and cancel
articles.trailText: Russ Vought, architect of rightwing Project 2025, has been waiting for his moment to pursue deep cuts to government
articles.summary: Amid the US government shutdown, OMB director Russ Vought, a key architect of Trump-aligned Project 2025, is pushing deep cuts to programs he brands “Democrat scams.” Encouraged by Trump, Vought moved to cancel $8bn in climate funding in 16 Biden-supporting states and freeze $18bn in New York infrastructure spending, targeting projects backed by Senate leader Schumer and House leader Jeffries. He’s primed for permanent cuts via impoundment, citing the 1974 Impoundment Control Act and framing civil service layoffs as “trauma.” Some GOP senators fear his aggressive use of executive power could squander Republican leverage by alienating moderate voters.

articles.title: Judge denies Kilmar Ábrego García’s bid for asylum in the US
articles.trailText: Ábrego, who was deported to El Salvador in March before being returned to the US, has 30 days to appeal ruling
articles.summary: An immigration judge in Baltimore denied Salvadoran national Kilmar Ábrego García’s asylum bid, citing no relief but granting a 30-day window to appeal. Wrongfully deported by the Trump administration to El Salvador in March, the 30-year-old returned in June facing human smuggling charges he denies. Released from Tennessee custody pending trial, he now confronts new deportation plans to Uganda and Eswatini and was re-detained by ICE at a Baltimore check-in. Living in Maryland with his U.S. wife and children since arriving as an undocumented teen fleeing gang violence, Ábrego’s lawyers seek a gag order over officials’ inflammatory MS-13 claims.

articles.title: Trump offers top universities funds if they boost conservative ideas
articles.trailText: Brown and MIT among nine schools told to back conservative views or risk losing federal support, sparking free speech fears
articles.summary: Trump's White House sent nine top universities a 10-point 'Compact for Academic Excellence' offering substantial federal grants in exchange for advancing conservative ideas. Demands include boosting conservative voices, eliminating departments that punish conservatives, banning race and sex criteria in admissions/hiring, freezing tuition for five years, capping international undergraduates at 15%, and government control over academic definitions and endowment spending. Refusal risks losing federal funding. Recipients—Brown, MIT, Vanderbilt, Dartmouth, Penn, USC, Texas-Austin, Arizona, Virginia—face critics from Newsom, Cornell Brooks and ACE's Mitchell citing threats to free speech and academic freedom. Harvard has sued, while Columbia settled, illustrating polarized responses.

articles.title: People in the US: share your views on the US government shutdown
articles.trailText: We���re interested to hear what people make of the Democrats’ refusal to vote for the Republican spending bill, and what people think the party should demand to end the shutdown
articles.summary: After Democrats blocked a Republican stopgap funding bill designed to keep the federal government running until mid-November, Washington has entered a shutdown. Instead of voting yes, Democrats presented healthcare-related demands aimed at reversing key GOP policies enacted over the past year. The Guardian is asking US readers whether they support the Democratic refusal despite the shutdown risk, what rationale underpins their stance, and which concessions—particularly regarding healthcare or other priorities—they believe Democrats should secure in exchange for approving reopening legislation. The survey form invites detailed feedback and provides links to terms of service and privacy policy.

articles.title: Focus on US mass shooters’ political beliefs undermines fight against gun violence
articles.trailText: Leaning so heavily on politics to understand mass violence fails to capture rapidly changing landscape of radicalization
articles.summary: Heavily scrutinizing mass shooters' partisan affiliations, as seen in recent cases labeled 'radical leftist' or tied to Trump yard signs, obscures the evolving drivers of US gun violence, experts warn. Research by the Institute for Countering Digital Extremism shows shooters are increasingly radicalized online—fixated on violence, conspiratorial memes and prior attackers—rather than motivated by mainstream political ideologies. Historical indicators like hate toward minorities and admiration of previous shooters still matter, but must be assessed alongside digital influences. Analysts argue that simplistic Democrat-Republican binaries impede prevention, and caution that cuts to DHS extremism programs threaten vital research into complex radicalization pathways.

articles.title: Husband of judge who blocked ‘Alligator Alcatraz’ shutdown has ties to DeSantis
articles.trailText: Barbara Lagoa’s husband, Paul Huck, is an attorney whose law firm has business with the Florida government
articles.summary: Barbara Lagoa, an 11th Circuit appeals judge, authored a 2–1 decision halting a Miami judge’s 60-day wind-down of 'Alligator Alcatraz,' Governor Ron DeSantis’s remote Everglades ICE detention camp. Lagoa’s husband, Paul Huck, is a founding partner of conservative firm Lawson Huck Gonzalez, which has won over $10 million in Florida state contracts under DeSantis—clients include ICE oversight suits and Target Pride litigation. Critics, including Democrats and immigration advocates, allege this marital connection creates a conflict of interest and demand Lagoa’s recusal. Lagoa’s office asserts no ethical breach, and the facility remains open pending appeals.

articles.title: How the White House spun ‘weak’ and ‘inconclusive’ studies to tie Tylenol to autism
articles.trailText: Experts say White House presented ‘association as causation’ and based conclusions on ‘poor quality studies’
articles.summary: Experts denounce a White House press release tying prenatal acetaminophen (Tylenol) use to autism as politically spun: weak, inconclusive and repetitively linked studies that only show association, not causation. Surgeons highlight double-linking of the same Mount Sinai, Harvard and Johns Hopkins papers, and mischaracterization of a “mechanistic” study that admits unknown pathways. Omitted is a 2.5 million-birth Swedish sibling-controlled analysis demonstrating associations vanish. Critics warn this mirrors vaccine misinformation tactics and call for rigorous, multifaceted research before claiming causality.

articles.title: Vance uses false claims to blame shutdown on Democrats as White House touts imminent layoffs | First Thing
articles.trailText: Democrats reject ‘Republican lies’ as both parties try to pin the shutdown blame on each other. Plus, Israeli naval forces board pro-Palestinian flotilla
articles.summary: Vice-President JD Vance falsely blamed Democrats for the government shutdown—accusing them of withholding funding to expand healthcare for undocumented immigrants���claims Democrats label “Republican lies,” as the White House warns of imminent layoffs. About 750,000 federal employees face furlough and essential staff like military and border agents risk working without pay, with Trump considering turning furloughs into firings. A Marist poll shows 38% would blame Republicans, 27% Democrats and 31% both. Meanwhile, Israeli naval forces boarded 13 pro-Palestinian flotilla vessels—including Greta Thunberg’s ship—75 miles off Gaza, enforcing a blockade condemned by the UN.

articles.title: Stars and stripes flags for Trump UK visit had to be changed for brighter red
articles.trailText: Switch of 66 hand-sewn flags for use along Mall and at Windsor Castle cost estimated £52,800 in public funds
articles.summary: Sixty-six hand-sewn US flags destined for the Mall and Windsor Castle during Donald Trump’s unprecedented second state visit were replaced at £52,800 public cost after the US embassy rejected supplier Flag Consultancy’s standard R01 red, demanding a brighter cherry hue. MD Nick Farley noted the new shade outshone the union flag’s red and speculated stored samples had sun-faded to russet. The episode, amid Trump’s handwritten invitation by Keir Starmer and unchallenged claims at Chequers, underscores UK indulgence and follows a £150bn US investment pledge.

articles.title: White House plays racist deepfake video of Democratic leaders on loop
articles.trailText: JD Vance said he thought the video was ‘funny’ and that the ‘sombrero memes’ would cease if government reopened
articles.summary: At the White House briefing room, the Trump administration looped two racist deepfake videos mocking Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. One video falsely depicts Schumer calling Democrats "woke pieces of shit," the other superimposes a sombrero and mustache on Jeffries, set to mariachi music. Posted on Trump's social media, the clips support a false claim that Democrats demanded ACA subsidies for unauthorized immigrants; undocumented people are ineligible. Vice-President JD Vance joked the "sombrero memes" would end if Democrats reopened the government. The fabrications echo the white supremacist "great replacement" conspiracy. Jeffries decried the depictions as racist.

articles.title: Perky Maxwell House viral ad takes on housing crisis as ‘Maxwell Apartment’
articles.trailText: Historic US company also offering ‘12-month lease’ – an annual supply – of pre-ground coffee for under $40
articles.summary: Maxwell House, marking its 133rd year, is satirizing the US housing crisis with a “Maxwell Apartment” campaign by Rethink. A video spot jokes “Maxwell Apartment” is more affordable than homeownership, echoing NAR data that first‐time buyers hit a record median age of 38 in 2024 and represent just 24% of sales, while Redfin finds under 16% of listings affordable in 2023. On Amazon, fans can “lease” a year’s supply of pre-ground Maxwell Apartment coffee for under $40 (limited stock), complete with a novelty “lease” agreement.

articles.title: Trump FCC chair to reportedly testify to Senate panel after Kimmel suspension
articles.trailText: Brendan Carr, who appeared to pressure broadcasters to take show off air, set to go before commerce committee
articles.summary: Brendan Carr, pro-Trump FCC chair, will testify before the Senate Commerce Committee—likely after November��over his role in pressuring broadcasters to suspend Jimmy Kimmel’s show. Carr urged affiliates on a conservative podcast to pull ABC’s late-night program after Kimmel’s remarks about far-right pundit Charlie Kirk, leading Nexstar and Sinclair to drop the show and ABC to suspend it. Kimmel returned a week later, logging a 10-year high among adult viewers. Critics, including committee chair Ted Cruz, condemned Carr’s “mafia”-style threats. Hearing date remains unset.

articles.title: Trump falsely claims that national guard troops are ‘in place’ in Portland
articles.trailText: On a post on social media, the president says guards had been deployed, while no members were present
articles.summary: President Trump falsely claimed on social media that 200 Oregon national guard troops had been deployed to restore “law and order” in Portland after a small ICE protest. NBC affiliate KGW confirmed no guards were on site; commanders say vetting and training require another 4–7 days. Governor Tina Kotek warns the federalization could cost taxpayers $10m, and Oregon AG Dan Rayfield sued to block the deployment, arguing Trump exceeded his authority. Trump repeats “war zone” rhetoric despite peaceful conditions.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Funding for Democratic states frozen as president uses shutdown to punish opponents
articles.trailText: The vice-president said the administration would be forced to resort to layoffs if the shutdown lasts more than a few days. Key US politics stories from Wednesday 1 October at a glance
articles.summary: Trump froze $26 bn in funding for Democratic-leaning states—including $18 bn for New York transit projects and $8 bn for green-energy in 16 states—to punish opponents during the government shutdown. VP JD Vance threatened permanent layoffs beyond the 300,000 furloughed, blamed Democrats with false claims, and refused to rule out targeted cuts. Democrats countered that Republicans are to blame for the shutdown and will press the message nationally. Other updates: Trump’s misinformation on National Guard deployment in Portland; Supreme Court paused his bid to remove Fed governor Lisa Cook; critics slammed Pete Hegseth’s military address; Democrats likened Trump to Putin over troop-training remarks.

articles.title: Vance uses false claims to pin shutdown blame on Democrats as White House warns of layoffs
articles.trailText: Vice-president falsely says Democrats calling for billions for ‘healthcare for illegal aliens’ as funding deadlock continues
articles.summary: In a rare White House briefing, VP JD Vance falsely accused Democrats—specifically Schumer and AOC—of demanding billions for healthcare for undocumented immigrants while blaming them for a funding deadlock that has shut federal departments. Press sec. Karoline Leavitt and OMB chief Russ Vought warn of imminent layoffs and pause billions in infrastructure and clean-energy grants to Democratic states. Democratic leaders Jeffries and Schumer counter that Republicans orchestrated the shutdown to advance an extreme agenda amid bitter brinkmanship and social-media attacks.

articles.title: Cleveland bakery to represent US in ‘Bread Olympics’ in France
articles.trailText: For the first time since 2017 the US will be represented in the event, by Brian Evans of On the Rise Artisanal Breads
articles.summary: On the Rise Artisan Breads in Cleveland Heights, Ohio, will be the first U.S. entrant since 2017 at France’s Mondial du Pain “Bread Olympics” Oct. 19–22 in Nantes. Led by self-taught owner Brian Evans—with junior baker Val Kertesz and coach Louis Volle, a James Beard semifinalist—the team must craft 18 breads, viennoiseries and sculptures within a 2.5-hour prep and 8.5-hour bake window, including 250 g, 55 cm baguettes. Selected by the Bread Bakers Guild of America for its technical excellence and community mission, the bakery aims to spotlight Northeast Ohio’s artisanal talent.

articles.title: Wisconsin Planned Parenthood clinics suspend abortion services amid funding crisis
articles.trailText: Planned Parenthood is struggling to navigate fallout of law that blocks them from receiving Medicaid reimbursements
articles.summary: Planned Parenthood of Wisconsin will halt abortion services on October 1 after a new federal provision bars any provider receiving over $800,000 in Medicaid reimbursements from the program for a year. By suspending abortions, the affiliate hopes to preserve Medicaid funding for cancer screenings, STI tests and contraception. It is the first Planned Parenthood affiliate to cease abortions in a state where it remains legal. At least two independent clinics and an Illinois consortium stand ready to serve Wisconsin patients, while up to 200 Planned Parenthood centers nationwide—mostly in rural, under-served areas—face potential closure without state intervention. Maine and Washington have allocated emergency funds; affiliates in Kentucky and Oregon report unsustainable losses and may soon begin charging patients.

articles.title: Democrats liken Trump to Putin after call to use US cities for military training
articles.trailText: Illinois governor JB Pritzker and others condemn president for suggesting cities be used as military training grounds
articles.summary: President Trump told military leaders at Quantico to use US cities as “training grounds” for quick reaction forces to suppress unrest, calling undocumented immigrants “the enemy within.” Illinois Governor JB Pritzker likened him to Vladimir Putin, questioned his mental health and urged the 25th Amendment’s use. California Governor Gavin Newsom and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer decried the proposal as authoritarian and a breach of the Posse Comitatus Act. The ACLU and civil rights groups warned against domestic military policing. Trump’s rhetoric drew silence from generals and sparked fears of escalating federal enforcement in Democratic-led cities.

articles.title: Federal Reserve governor will keep job for now despite Trump’s bid to remove her
articles.trailText: Supreme court defers action on request to remove Lisa Cook from post, at least until it hears oral arguments on case
articles.summary: Supreme Court has deferred ruling on DOJ’s request to pause a lower court injunction blocking President Trump’s attempt to remove Fed governor Lisa Cook, at least until oral arguments in January. Trump cited unverified pre-2022 mortgage fraud allegations as cause, marking the first-ever presidential bid to fire a Fed official. A district judge ruled those claims likely don’t meet the Federal Reserve Act’s undefined “for cause” removal standard. Cook, the first Black woman on the Fed board, denies wrongdoing and argues the move threatens central bank independence; justices’ short-term status quo helps calm markets pending a final decision expected by mid-2025.

articles.title: US government shuts down after Senate fails to advance both parties’ bills
articles.trailText: Democrats and Republicans blame each other for failure to extend funding, resulting in first shutdown in nearly seven years
articles.summary: Government shut down at midnight after the Senate rejected competing stopgap funding bills: a GOP resolution to fund operations through Nov. 21 lost 55–45, and a Democratic version extending funding to end-October with expiring ACA subsidies failed 47–53. Vice-President Vance and the Trump White House blamed Senate Democrats for “radical” demands���ACA tax-credit extensions, Medicaid restorations and public-media funding—while Democrats accused Republicans of misleading voters on healthcare. This first shutdown since 2018 will furlough 750,000–1 million federal workers, risk coverage for 20 million Americans and faces low public support in polls.

articles.title: Government shutdown leaves federal workers ‘on edge’ as Trump eyes more job cuts
articles.trailText: Employees wonder if the shutdown will leave them out of work temporarily or set stage for permanent termination
articles.summary: The first federal shutdown since 2018 has furloughed roughly 750,000 workers, straining their finances and services. Labor attorney James Kirwan and unions warn employees forced into debt face emotional harm and fear permanent job cuts after the Trump administration ordered mass layoff plans. The USPTO plans to RIF 1% of staff, and most EPA frontline workers are furloughed with recall only for emergencies. Unions sued, calling firing threats illegal, as the administration eyes cutting 300,000 federal jobs by year end.

articles.title: Economists relieved as White House withdraws controversial pick to lead Bureau of Labor Statistics
articles.trailText: Donald Trump wanted EJ Antoni to head agency, but critics said he was too partisan and ‘exceedingly unqualified’
articles.summary: After Trump fired BLS chief Erika McEntarfer over revised weak job‐growth data and accused the agency of bias, his nomination of EJ Antoni—Heritage Foundation economist and Project 2025 co-author—to lead the Bureau of Labor Statistics was withdrawn. Senators such as Susan Collins and Lisa Murkowski refused to advance an overtly partisan, unqualified candidate. Economists from AEI, AIER, Harvard and the Roosevelt Institute praised the pullback, warning Antoni’s confirmation would harm the BLS’s independent credibility. The White House lauded Antoni and vowed to nominate a replacement soon.

articles.title: Why healthcare spending was at the center of the US government shutdown battle
articles.trailText: Democrats said they won’t vote for legislation unless Republicans reversed Medicaid cuts and extended subsidies
articles.summary: A standoff over healthcare spending partly shut down the federal government after Democrats refused to back a stopgap unless Republicans reversed $793 billion in Medicaid cuts and extended ACA subsidies due to expire in 2025. Trump’s June “big, beautiful bill” imposes 80-hour work requirements, ends Covid-era premium tax credits and could leave 7.8 million more uninsured. Senate leader John Thune proposed funding through Nov. 21 with a fix for the expiring credits, keeping talks open.

articles.title: ‘A righteous fight’: Democrats hold fast on healthcare but also use shutdown to pummel Trump
articles.trailText: Republicans, however, need to peel off only a few votes to end stalemate over government funding
articles.summary: Senate Democrats refused to back a GOP plan to fund the government through mid-November, demanding reversal of Medicaid cuts, extended ACA tax credits, restored PBS/NPR funding and blocks on Trump’s back-door foreign-aid cuts. Framed as a “righteous fight” to challenge Trump’s low approval, inflation and free-speech record, the shutdown—jeopardizing federal pay and public services—could ironically strengthen him. With a 60-vote filibuster rule, Democrats risk defections as Republicans persist with funding votes and OMB signals firings, setting up a test of party unity ahead of key races.

articles.title: US national parks to remain partly open during government shutdown
articles.trailText: Hours before the shutdown, NPS staff began preparations to close down some parts of popular US public lands
articles.summary: In the hours before the US government shutdown, the National Park Service outlined a contingency plan closing gated facilities, visitor centers, and furloughing over 9,200 staff (64%), while keeping open-air areas—roads, trails, memorials—accessible. Parks may tap separate fee revenue and accept state, local, tribal or private funding (unreimbursed by NPS) to maintain restrooms, trash service, campgrounds and emergency operations. Advocates warn skeleton crews risk irreversible harm—past shutdowns saw vandalism, habitat damage, poaching and overwhelmed rescue. Autumn’s heavy visitation and wildfire season heighten danger. Budget cuts and an April order pushing parks open foreshadow strained operations and local economic losses from halted visitation.

articles.title: ‘This is their shutdown’: Democrats and Republicans blame each other as government closes down
articles.trailText: Democrats say Republicans have ‘decimated healthcare for 20m Americans’ and say they will not blink first
articles.summary: Democrats blame Trump and Republicans for first US government shutdown in nearly seven years, accusing them of 'decimating healthcare for 20 million Americans' and prioritizing benefits for undocumented immigrants. Senate minority leader Chuck Schumer vows protests and social media campaigns to shift blame to Republicans, while GOP leaders Mike Johnson and John Thune argue Democrats refuse to negotiate to protect 'illegal aliens' and pressure moderates to reopen government. Progressive figures like AOC urge standing firm on healthcare; Kamala Harris and Cory Booker also hold Republicans accountable. Unions (AFL-CIO) sue over threatened layoffs; markets tumble as S&P 500 futures dip.

articles.title: Border wall slicing through Arizona wildlife corridor begins construction: ‘A show of force for nothing’
articles.trailText: The 30ft-high wall between the US and Mexico will cut through one of the last unbroken grasslands in the west, leaving residents alarmed over the potential impact on wildlife and water use
articles.summary: In San Rafael Valley, AZ, work has begun on a 27-mile, 30-ft-high steel border wall, cutting through one of North America’s last intact grasslands. The project replaces low vehicle barriers but threatens migratory routes for endangered jaguars, ocelots, bears and mountain lions, and requires new wells tapping scarce groundwater to mix concrete. Locals and conservationists call it "a show of force for nothing," citing low illegal crossings (-90% year-over-year) and legal challenges over waivers of 30+ environmental laws. DHS and CBP defend it as essential for security; opponents warn of ecosystem fragmentation, water depletion and reduced transparency.

articles.title: ‘Meant to be a deterrent’: asylum seekers face new, higher fees in US
articles.trailText: Host of expensive, ‘impossible to fulfill’ immigration fees and requirements suddenly being imposed
articles.summary: A new Trump-backed law has saddled asylum seekers with a suite of hefty fees—$100 to file, $100 per year pending, $550 for work permits, $500+ for TPS, hundreds for child relief, and $1,000+ to appeal. Courts initially lacked payment portals, forcing some like a detained woman in Laredo to abandon valid claims. Lawyers warn these charges—imposed without clear procedures—effectively bar low-income refugees from access to justice, creating a financial filter that deters meaningful participation in U.S. immigration proceedings.

articles.title: Miami deal for Trump library next to famous Freedom Tower angers critics
articles.trailText: Advocates say reopened tower, which tells story of Miami as welcoming city for immigrants, will be tarnished
articles.summary: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis and cabinet members quietly deeded nearly three acres adjacent to Miami’s historic Freedom Tower to the Trump Presidential Library Foundation, drawing sharp criticism from immigrant advocates, local protesters and Miami Dade College trustees. Opponents warn the library’s proximity will undercut the tower’s legacy as El Refugio, a Cuban refugee processing center (1962–74), and clash with Trump’s hardline immigration record. Critics accuse DeSantis and MDC of erasing non-white history, while supporters, including Eric Trump, hail the gift as an economic boon and fitting tribute to the 45th president.

articles.title: First Thing: US government shuts down as Senate fails to advance both parties’ bills
articles.trailText: Democrats accuse Republicans of ‘risking America’s healthcare’ in spending bill. Plus, Trump says military should use US cities as training grounds
articles.summary: US government shut down after Senate failed to pass a GOP funding extension requiring 60 votes, as Democrats insisted on Medicaid restorations and ACA subsidy extensions. Non-essential federal employees furloughed; Republicans schedule fresh votes.
