Former President Trump urged using US cities like Chicago as military training grounds and encouraged aggressive tactics by immigration agents, and claimed a $500 m Harvard settlement pending. DOJ sued LA County sheriff’s dept over delayed gun permits; a judge ruled Trump’s deportations of pro-Palestinian students unconstitutional. Taiwan became top Russian naphtha buyer; Slovakia enshrined binary gender, curbing same-sex adoption; Europe loses 600 football-pitch green land daily; DOE bans "climate change" language. Alaska’s 32 Chunk wins Fat Bear Week.

articles.title: Veterans react to Hegseth’s ‘insulting’ address to generals and admirals
articles.trailText: Defense secretary’s speech touching on physical fitness and doctrine of lethality was seen as ‘egotistical’ and ‘dangerous’
articles.summary: Veterans and retired officers slammed defense secretary Pete Hegseth's hour-long, TED-talk style address to 800 generals and admirals at Quantico as egotistical, insulting, and dangerous. Critics objected to his lecturing seasoned flag officers on warrior ethos, physical fitness, DEI, and a 'return to male standards,' calling his assertions of promotion quotas for officers of color baseless. While some women vets welcomed his push for uniform fitness benchmarks, others denounced his remarks as disparaging. Hegseth's emphasis on 'doctrine of lethality' and Trump's subsequent 'enemy within' rhetoric drew alarm over politicizing senior military leadership.

articles.title: Retired US supreme court justice fears ‘democracy is not guaranteed to survive’
articles.trailText: Anthony Kennedy told NPR ‘partisanship is becoming ... more prevalent and more bitter’ in the high court’s opinions
articles.summary: Retired Justice Anthony Kennedy warns democracy isn't guaranteed, citing rising bitterness and partisanship in Supreme Court opinions, demurring on whether past rulings will hold. Speaking to NPR ahead of his memoir release, he decried antagonistic discourse. He authored Obergefell in 2015 and legalized same-sex marriage, noting the demeaning denial of adoption rights for gay parents. He contrasted fellow Justice Thomas's disregard for precedent and recalled Scalia's harsh dissent and later apology. Kennedy urges the Court toward moderation and respect as its term begins on October 6. His memoir 'Life, Law & Liberty' publishes Oct. 14.

articles.title: What does a government shutdown mean and why is this year’s more serious?
articles.trailText: The US government has shut down because Congress couldn’t reach a funding agreement. Here’s what to know about what happens next
articles.summary: Congress missed the funding deadline, triggering a partial federal shutdown that furloughs roughly 750,000 non-exempt employees while essential staff work unpaid. Republicans proposed a stopgap bill to extend funding to Nov. 21, but Democrats withheld support over demands to extend ACA subsidies, roll back Medicaid cuts and restore public media funding. The White House has threatened permanent layoffs, directing agencies via an OMB memo to prepare reduction-in-force notices. Non-essential services from national parks to food inspections will pause, while Social Security, Medicare, military and air traffic control continue. A prolonged standoff risks economic disruption and deeper political impasse.

articles.title: Global academic freedom group warns Trump is dismantling US higher education
articles.trailText: Report from Scholars at Risk counts some 40 attacks against academic freedom in the US in the first half of 2025
articles.summary: Scholars at Risk’s Free to Think report warns that the Trump administration’s 2025 return has triggered an unprecedented federal assault on US academic freedom: revoking research funding, detaining and seeking to deport foreign scholars, targeting diversity, equity and inclusion programs, and policing Gaza-related speech. SAR counted 40 US attacks in H1 2025—up from 80 in all of 2024—amid over 30 higher-ed bills, executive orders, audits of 60+ campuses, frozen grants, loan caps and new visa restrictions. Globally, it recorded 395 assaults on universities across 49 countries.

articles.title: ‘Dominant on the river’: 32 Chunk crowned champion in ‘biggest Fat Bear Week yet’
articles.trailText: Brown bear’s nearly 100,000 votes leads him to victory despite suffering for most of season with broken jaw
articles.summary: 32 Chunk, a brown bear at Katmai National Park, won this year’s record‐breaking Fat Bear Week with 96,350 public votes, outpacing runner‐up Bear 856’s 63,725 and dethroning two‐time champion 128 Grazer. Despite battling a broken jaw—likely from a mating fight—Chunk ate massive quantities of salmon to bulk up to an estimated 1,200 lbs. The annual bracket competition, which attracted over 1.5 million votes, combines weight‐gain photos, bear personalities, and live‐cam drama. Chunk’s victory follows last year’s controversies, including the on‐camera killing of Grazer’s cub and another fatal bear clash. Observers hailed his resilience and dominance as essential for hibernation survival.

articles.title: US on brink of government shutdown after Senate rejects funding plans
articles.trailText: Senate sinks Democratic and Republican plans to extend government funding beyond midnight and avert shutdown
articles.summary: Senate failed to advance either party’s stopgap funding measures before the midnight deadline, sending the US to a shutdown. Democrats blocked the GOP’s plan through Nov 21, while Republicans filibustered a Democratic bill extending ACA tax credits, Medicaid funding and public media support. Leader statements flew: GOP’s Thune blamed “far-left Democrats,” Schumer denounced partisan intransigence. Three Democrats crossed to support the GOP bill. The White House threatens mass furloughs and blamed “Democrats’ insane demands.” House GOP passed its own bill but lacks Senate votes. Polls show voters split over blame and shutdown tactics.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Shutdown a chance to ‘get rid of a lot of things we didn��t want’, says president
articles.trailText: Senate Democrats voted down a Republican bill to keep funding the government, putting it on a near certain path to a shutdown. Key US politics stories from 30 September 2025
articles.summary: After Senate Democrats rejected a GOP stopgap spending bill, a US government shutdown is all but certain after Sept 30; Trump blamed Democrats, ordered agencies via OMB memo to prepare layoffs of ‘Democrat things’, and touted shutdowns as opportunities to eliminate unwanted programs. Some agencies openly blamed the ‘radical left’ in apparent Hatch Act breaches. Concurrently, Trump endorsed Pentagon policy changes, threatened Hamas with a four-day ultimatum on Gaza, struck a $500 m Harvard settlement, announced Pfizer drug discounts, and saw a judge block his anti–pro-Palestinian student deportations.

articles.title: Zillow and Redfin accused of suppressing competition in lawsuit
articles.trailText: Federal Trade Commission alleges agreement between two firms started when Zillow paid Redfin $100m
articles.summary: The FTC has sued Zillow and Redfin for allegedly entering an illegal deal: Zillow paid Redfin $100 million to suppress competition in online rental advertising, ending contracts with partners, halting multifamily property ads for up to nine years, and syndicating Zillow listings. Redfin cut hundreds of employees, some moving to Zillow. The FTC claims this harms renters and property managers by reducing ad competition and raising costs, violating antitrust laws. Both firms deny wrongdoing and call the pact pro-consumer; the FTC seeks to unwind the agreement.

articles.title: Photos show bluff crumbling towards ocean in landslide-stricken California enclave
articles.trailText: Rancho Palos Verdes threatened by worsening landslide, with no injuries reported but trigger still unknown
articles.summary: Rancho Palos Verdes, a coastal enclave 25 miles south of Los Angeles, saw fresh bluff collapses this week, with aerial images capturing backyard land slipping toward the Pacific. City officials reported no injuries or structural damage and said the trigger remains unknown. The event differs from the Portuguese Bend Landslide Complex—an ancient slide reactivated in 1956 that has since destroyed 140 homes and, after torrential rains, shifted up to 1 ft per week—causing buckled roads, utility outages and forcing hundreds of families to evacuate.

articles.title: Federal agencies blame Democrats for looming shutdown in apparent Hatch Act violation
articles.trailText: Housing and VA departments attack ‘radical left’ despite law limiting political activities of government employees
articles.summary: Several US federal agencies, including VA and HUD, publicly blamed Democrats and the ‘radical left’ for a looming midnight shutdown, in apparent Hatch Act violations. Agencies sent identical partisan emails to employees and posted website statements faulting Democrats for blocking a continuing resolution over demands like open borders and transgender rights, spanning departments from HHS to FTC. Experts say this coordinated messaging using taxpayer-funded systems breaches Hatch Act and lobbying laws. With 750,000 workers facing furloughs or firings, FDA head Marty Makary secured an exemption, citing public safety.

articles.title: DoJ sues pro-Palestinian activists under law often used to protect abortion clinics
articles.trailText: Lawsuit from Trump’s justice department targets advocates involved in a 2024 protest at a New Jersey synagogue
articles.summary: The Trump DoJ filed a first-of-its-kind civil-rights suit under the Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances Act against two advocacy groups and six activists for a violent November 2024 pro-Palestinian protest at a West Orange, NJ synagogue selling West Bank settlements. The complaint alleges assaults on pro-Israel counterprotesters, vuvuzelas used as “weapons,” and disruption of memorial and Torah lecture services, seeking fines of $30,000–$50,000 per violation. Historically used to shield abortion clinics, the FACE Act has never before guarded houses of worship, raising legal and partisan tensions.

articles.title: Judge issues blistering opinion against Trump policy to deport pro-Palestinian students
articles.trailText: Judge rules non-citizens have the same free speech rights as US citizens under the first amendment
articles.summary: A federal judge, William G. Young, ruled the Trump administration’s policy to detain and deport non-citizen scholars for pro-Palestinian speech unconstitutional and violative of the First Amendment. Brought by the AAUP with Harvard, Rutgers, NYU chapters and MESA, plaintiffs exposed an “ideological deportation policy” stemming from two executive orders targeting “hateful ideology.” Trial testimony and documents showed reliance on Canary Mission dossiers and higher-level directives, producing a chilling effect on campuses. Arrested students—Mahmoud Khalil, Mohsen Mahdawi, Rümeysa Öztürk and Badar Khan Suri—were released pending proceedings. Young’s 161-page opinion affirmed equal speech rights for non-citizens, warned against eroding constitutional values and signaled an appeal to the Supreme Court.

articles.title: US energy department cracks down on workers’ use of climate crisis language
articles.trailText: Efficiency employees reportedly told to avoid ‘climate change’ and similar terms in their work in latest clampdown
articles.summary: In late September 2025 the DOE’s Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy was told via internal email to avoid using terms like “climate change”, “decarbonization”, “sustainable”, “emissions” and “energy transition” in all internal and public communications. Agency staffers warn this undermines DOE’s carbon-slashing mission and freezes clean energy R&D. The DOE press secretary denies any word ban, while Secretary Wright defended a disputed climate report at the UN and cut $13bn in renewables funding. Critics link the move to the Trump administration’s broader anti-climate-language campaign, which has blacklisted hundreds of terms, removed climate content from federal sites and sees the president calling the crisis a “con job.”

articles.title: Pfizer agrees to offer discounted drugs through new federal website, Trump announces
articles.trailText: President also said that company would offer medications to Medicaid at ‘most favored nation’ pricing
articles.summary: President Donald Trump announced Pfizer will offer medications at “heavily discounted prices” via a new federal portal, TrumpRx.com, and sell all drugs to Medicaid at “most favored nation” rates—linking US costs to the lowest global prices. Trump predicted a major reduction in Medicaid outlays. CEO Albert Bourla argued that foreign countries underpay for innovation, forcing Americans to subsidize drug development. The move follows Rand data showing US prices nearly three times higher than in 33 peer nations and comes as Congress debates deep Medicaid cuts that could add 16 million uninsured by 2034. The administration is courting other drugmakers for similar deals.

articles.title: Federal prosecutors urge judge to give Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs an 11-year sentence
articles.trailText: Recommendation comes ahead of sentencing after Combs was found guilty of transportation to engage in prostitution
articles.summary: Federal prosecutors have urged Judge Arun Subramanian to impose an 11-year, three-month prison term and a $500,000 fine on Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs after his July conviction on two counts of transportation to engage in prostitution. Acquitted of sex trafficking and racketeering, Combs is accused of using his fame, wealth and threats to coerce two former partners into drug-fueled sexual encounters with escorts. The US Probation Office recommended 5–7 years; his defense sought 14 months, citing rehabilitation. Victim impact letters, including from Casandra ‘Cassie’ Ventura, detail ongoing trauma and fear of retribution if Combs receives a lenient sentence.

articles.title: No more ‘woke’ in the US military: key takeaways from Pete Hegseth’s speech
articles.trailText: Pentagon chief railed against diversity and fat-shamed the troops as he directed his generals to fall in line – or quit
articles.summary: At a Quantico speech, Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth, now head of the newly renamed Department of War, declared an end to ‘wokeness,’ ditching race- and gender-based promotions, DEI offices and identity months. He fat-shamed unfit troops, ordered strict grooming (no beards, long hair) and restored ‘highest male’ physical standards for combat roles, warning women may be excluded if they cannot meet gender-neutral benchmarks. He also tightened media access rules amid security breach concerns and told dissenting commanders to quit rather than resist his ‘merit- and war-fighting’ focus.

articles.title: US federal agency website blames ‘radical left’ for looming shutdown
articles.trailText: Giant red banner appears on Department of Housing and Urban Development page after lawmakers fail to reach deal
articles.summary: After GOP and Dem leaders missed a spending-deal deadline, HUD's website splashed a giant red banner blaming the "radical left" for an imminent shutdown over a $1.5���trillion wish list, echoing Trump-era messaging. HUD spokesman Matthew Maley called it a necessary warning of "massive pain" on Americans; critics like law professor Samuel Bagenstos slammed it as propaganda by an underfunded agency. The VA used similar rhetoric internally. Partisan finger-pointing persisted as Trump posted a racist deepfake, drawing House leader Hakeem Jeffries's rebuke and refocus on cost and healthcare battles.

articles.title: Trump defends troops in US cities after Hegseth decries military DEI efforts
articles.trailText: President and defense chief delivered pair of incendiary speeches to a crowd of hundreds of generals and admirals
articles.summary: At a summit of generals and admirals, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth unveiled ten directives to purge “woke” culture, firing DEI-focused officers—disproportionately Black and female—and scrapping diversity initiatives. He mandated colorblind, merit-based promotions, equal physical standards for women, tighter grooming rules, “shark attack” training, and freer rules of engagement, backed by his lawyer-turned-navy-commander. Former President Donald Trump echoed this hardline stance in a campaign-style speech, proposing US cities like Chicago as military training grounds, endorsing forceful retaliation for insults or brick-throwing, and justifying navy sinkings of Venezuelan boats. Officers remained largely impassive.

articles.title: Second victim dies following shooting at Texas immigration facility
articles.trailText: Miguel Ángel García-Hernández, a father of four, ‘succumbed to his injuries after being removed from life support’
articles.summary: According to LULAC, 32-year-old Miguel Ángel García-Hernández, a father of four, died after being taken off life support following a Sept. 24 sniper attack on the Dallas ICE facility. A former Mexican house painter, he and his wife had just bought their first home and were expecting a fifth child. He was the second detainee killed after Norlan Guzman-Fuentes, 37; a third, Jose Andres Bordones-Molina, survived. Shooter Joshua Jahn, 29, died by suicide at the scene. Investigators, who found anti-ICE materials and attack plans, are treating it as targeted violence; no officers were hurt. The office reopens with stepped-up security.

articles.title: Louisiana governor asks for national guard deployment to New Orleans
articles.trailText: Jeff Landry’s request comes as crime trends analyst says New Orleans has had fewest murders since 1970
articles.summary: Louisiana Republican Gov. Jeff Landry has requested deployment of 1,000 National Guard troops to New Orleans, Baton Rouge and Shreveport through FY2026, citing elevated violent crime rates, staffing shortages and support for major events and disaster response. This follows President Trump’s prior troop deployments to Washington, Memphis, Los Angeles, Portland and Chicago in the name of crimefighting and immigration enforcement. Critics note New Orleans recorded just 75 homicides to date—the lowest since 1970—and sharp declines in shootings, carjackings and burglaries, calling Landry’s request unnecessary.

articles.title: Michigan church shooting suspect bore a hatred of Mormon religion, locals say
articles.trailText: Michigan suspect was a marine veteran, as was suspect in another recent shooting in North Carolina, who has been charged with murder
articles.summary: On Sep 29 in Grand Blanc Township, Michigan, 40-year-old ex-Marine Thomas Jacob Sanford stormed a LDS church, ramming his pickup into its doors then opening fire with a semi-automatic rifle, killing four congregants—including 77-year-old Navy veteran John Bond—and setting the building ablaze with gasoline before police fatally shot him. Locals say Sanford harbored a virulent hatred of Mormons, whom he branded “the antichrist” after a Utah-based breakup. His father apologized to victims’ families. Gov. Whitmer lamented Michigan’s 12th mass shooting this year. The weekend also saw a marine veteran charged in a boat attack at a North Carolina restaurant.

articles.title: Hundreds of US women charged with pregnancy-related crimes since fall of Roe
articles.trailText: Study finds prosecutors targeting low-income women mainly in US south – and figure likely to be an undercount
articles.summary: In the two years after Roe’s reversal, Pregnancy Justice documented 412 pregnancy prosecutions in 16 states—predominantly in the US South targeting low-income women. Roughly 300 cases occurred in Alabama and Oklahoma; 16 involved homicide charges, nearly 400 alleged prenatal substance use, and nine cited abortion-seeking but only one faced a criminal ban. Prosecutors repurposed child-protection laws to grant fetuses legal rights, cementing fetal personhood amid rising surveillance. With no national court database, these undercounted cases—from miscarriages and stillbirths to drug use—signal escalating punitive policing of pregnancy. Ongoing bills in 12 states risk homicide charges.

articles.title: ‘It’s hard to know what day it is’: families tell of grim Ice detention in Texas
articles.trailText: Anxiety high as parents and children tell of lack of clean water, inadequate medical care and poor food in ‘prison-like’ conditions
articles.summary: At the South Texas Family Residential Center in Dilley, Texas, ICE contractors keep immigrant parents and children in isolated, prison-style trailers behind metal fences under prolonged, court-challenged detentions far beyond legal limits. A federal court filing by outside monitors details scarce potable water—often foul, bleach-scented, bottled at unaffordable prices—monotonous meals, basic hygiene and medical neglect, one-hour-a-day schooling, invasive night checks and banned physical contact. Families report severe anxiety, weight loss, nightmares and developmental delays among detained children.

articles.title: Palestinian American denied slot at DNC competing for Georgia governor: ‘We’re trying to rebuild the coalition’
articles.trailText: Ruwa Romman is ‘running to build a movement’ and ‘restoring civic ethos of being involved in the government’
articles.summary: Palestinian-American state Rep. Ruwa Romman, 32, the first Palestinian-American and Muslim woman elected at state level in Georgia, launched her 2026 Democratic gubernatorial bid to challenge two decades of GOP rule. Born in Jordan and raised in Gwinnett County, she rose to national attention lobbying against the Biden administration’s support for Israel at last year’s DNC. Her platform centers on rebuilding a broad coalition—young progressives and disillusioned older voters—to expand Medicaid, raise Georgia’s $5.15 minimum wage, revive shuttered hospitals and bolster education. She joins a crowded May primary field including Jason Esteves, Keisha Lance Bottoms and ex-Lt. Gov. Geoff Duncan, aiming to restore civic engagement and economic growth in a state that has missed Medicaid expansion and enforces strict abortion laws.

articles.title: Trump pressure tactics in Comey case ‘chilling’ – but they could backfire, experts say
articles.trailText: Former prosecutors condemn ‘takeover of the DoJ’ but say chance of success could be tainted by president’s comments
articles.summary: Former President Trump’s public and private campaign to force ex-FBI director James Comey onto criminal charges is seen by scholars and ex-prosecutors as evidence of authoritarian interference in the Justice Department, yet risks tainting the case via selective prosecution. After Virginia US attorney Erik Siebert’s ouster for deeming the evidence weak, Trump installed untested White House aide Lindsey Halligan, who alone signed the two-page indictment. Experts warn that Truth Social posts pressuring AG Pam Bondi and grand jurors could bolster defenses of vindictive or politically-motivated charges, undermining norms of DOJ independence. Critics call the moves a dangerous break with decades of prosecutorial separation.

articles.title: Americans and US food banks brace for Trump cuts: ‘Battling hunger is no longer a priority’
articles.trailText: Looming funding cuts to the US food assistance program come as food prices continue to rise under Trump’s administration
articles.summary: Starting October 1, 2025, Trump’s One Big Beautiful Bill Act eliminates SNAP-Ed funding for food banks, marking the largest cut to US food assistance in history. The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities estimates up to 4 million Americans will lose benefits upon recertification. Rising grocery costs—up 17.8 percent since January 2022—and Trump’s tariffs and immigration-related labor shortages compound hunger risks. States face new administrative burdens as they must cofund SNAP, while food banks nationwide report surging demand, dwindling supplies and staff layoffs. Meanwhile, USDA cancelled its annual hunger survey, sparking criticism that tracking food insecurity is no longer a priority.

articles.title: Trump gutting protected status for immigrants will strain US healthcare, Democrats warn
articles.trailText: Exclusive: more than 100 members of Congress warn TPS cancellations will result in significant staff losses that US healthcare facilities will struggle to replace
articles.summary: Over 100 Democratic lawmakers, led by Elizabeth Warren, warn Trump’s plan to cancel Temporary Protected Status for immigrants from eight nations will strip work authorization from roughly 570,000 healthcare staff—including 32–40% of home-care aides, 24% of residential care and 21% of nursing facility workers. In a letter to DHS, HHS and Labor secretaries, they caution these terminations, paired with Medicaid cuts under the OBBBA bill, will worsen staffing shortages, fuel hospital and nursing home closures, spike medical errors, delayed diagnoses and patient mortality, and expose thousands to ICE arrest.

articles.title: First Thing: Trump and Netanyahu tell Hamas to accept Gaza peace plan or face consequences
articles.trailText: The Israeli PM threatens to ‘finish the job’ if Hamas does not agree. Plus, do AI ‘actors’ pose an existential threat to their human counterparts?
articles.summary: President Trump and PM Netanyahu issued Hamas a 20-point Gaza peace plan ultimatum—ceasefire, hostage-for-prisoner swap, staged Israeli withdrawal, Hamas disarmament and an international transitional government—or face full military backing from the US to “finish the job.” Separately, Trump’s meeting with congressional Democrats failed to avert a looming government shutdown over ACA subsidies and Medicaid cuts. In Michigan, a church shooter displaying a Trump sticker killed four worshippers. Hollywood’s viral AI “actor” Tilly Norwood sparks debate over AI replacing talent. The administration also unveiled $625m and 13.1m acres for coal revival.

articles.title: Utah governor calls on people to ‘stop shooting each other’ after Kirk killing
articles.trailText: Spencer Cox tells 60 Minutes he’s making plea after being unable to ‘unsee’ video of Charlie Kirk being shot
articles.summary: On 60 Minutes, Utah Gov. Spencer Cox, who repeatedly watched the video of rightwing activist Charlie Kirk’s fatal shooting by a sniper on campus, urged Americans to “stop shooting each other,” rejecting calls for a kumbaya moment but decrying political violence and warlike rhetoric. Cox, who briefed the media and informed Donald Trump of Kirk’s death, warned that framing disagreements as a war fuels further attacks like the recent firebomb at Gov. Josh Shapiro’s residence and the shootings of ex-Minnesota House Speaker Melissa Hortman and others, and said he welcomes debate despite criticism from Steve Bannon.

articles.title: US justice department sues Minnesota over sanctuary city policies
articles.trailText: State is latest to face legal threats in the course of Trump administration’s brutal deportation campaign
articles.summary: The US DOJ sued Minnesota on Sept 29 for defying federal immigration law by refusing local cooperation with ICE, alleging sanctuary policies “jeopardize public safety” and release dangerous criminals. Minneapolis, St. Paul and Hennepin County join Democratic jurisdictions like LA, NY and Colorado facing similar suits after DOJ letters to 13 states and 22 localities warning of funding cuts or prosecution. DOJ court briefs in June sought to block LA’s ordinance; a federal judge later stayed Trump’s funding ban on 34 sanctuary cities. MN officials declined comment.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: UK and French leaders back president’s peace plan for Gaza
articles.trailText: Trump and the Israeli prime minister outline their 20-point plan during meeting at White House. Key US politics stories from Monday 29 September at a glance
articles.summary: President Trump and PM Netanyahu unveiled a 20-point Gaza peace plan, urging Hamas to accept or face US-backed Israeli action; UK PM Starmer and French President Macron have endorsed it, though Hamas's stance is unknown. Domestic highlights: Trump's talks with Democrats deadlock on funding ahead of a potential shutdown; 200 National Guard troops headed to Portland; records link Michigan church shooter to a Trump sign; Iowa's largest superintendent loses license after ICE arrest. Others: Stephen Miller directs strikes on alleged Venezuelan drug boats; $625m in coal-industry aid; cannabis stocks jump after Trump's senior-focused CBD video.

articles.title: Trump talks with Democrats fail to yield breakthrough as US shutdown nears
articles.trailText: Democrats strike optimistic tone after high-stakes meeting but Republicans accuse rivals of ‘hostage-taking’
articles.summary: After an Oval Office meeting, Trump, Senate GOP and House leaders failed to break a funding stalemate with Senate minority leader Schumer and other Democrats, who won’t back the stopgap bill to extend funding past September 30 without restoring ACA subsidies, undoing Medicaid cuts and re-funding public media. GOP figures like JD Vance and Senate majority leader Thune accused Democrats of “hostage-taking” and warned of a shutdown. Schumer said Trump “understood the magnitude” of the healthcare crisis and could push GOP leaders toward bipartisan amendments before Wednesday’s midnight deadline. With a shutdown due Wednesday, Trump has yet to comment publicly.

articles.title: Louisiana issues warrant for California doctor accused of mailing abortion pills
articles.trailText: It is part of effort by anti-abortion activists and red states to target telemedicine abortion and providers across states
articles.summary: Louisiana has issued a 2024 arrest warrant for California physician Dr Remy Coeytaux, accused of mailing mifepristone and misoprostol to Louisiana resident Rosalie Markezich. She alleges her boyfriend used her email to order pills and forced her to take them despite her desire to continue her pregnancy. The warrant is part of red states’ campaign against telemedicine abortion providers in blue states with “shield laws,” and ties into a federal challenge to mifepristone access. AG Liz Murrill called the providers “criminal drug dealers.” Similar actions target Dr Margaret Carpenter in Texas and NY, with legal experts expecting Supreme Court review.

articles.title: Des Moines revokes education license of school superintendent arrested by Ice
articles.trailText: Ian Roberts was superintendent of Des Moines public schools, the largest school district in the state
articles.summary: Ian Roberts, superintendent of Des Moines public schools, was arrested by ICE on Sept 27 in a targeted enforcement operation citing a 2024 final removal order and no work authorization. ICE noted existing 2020 weapon possession charges and recovered a loaded handgun, prompting an ATF probe. On Sept 28, Iowa’s Board of Educational Examiners revoked his teaching license—effective immediately for lack of legal presence—removing his authority as superintendent and giving him until Oct 28 to appeal. The Des Moines school board placed Roberts on administrative leave and will consider next steps at a special meeting.

articles.title: US whistleblowers say they were fired for raising fair housing concerns
articles.trailText: Hud attorneys who said fighting discrimination not a Trump priority call dismissals ‘as blatant as can be’
articles.summary: Two HUD anti-discrimination attorneys, Paul Osadebe and Palmer Heenan, were fired days after blowing the whistle on the Trump administration’s alleged dismantling of Fair Housing Act enforcement. In a report to Senator Elizabeth Warren, they and colleagues said HUD deprioritized fighting segregation and cut staff for “optics.” Osadebe was placed on leave for speaking to the press; Heenan was terminated during his probation for disclosing non-public information. Warren condemned the firings as retaliation. The duo, backed by a lawsuit, vow to continue challenging what they call a “systemic attack” on fair housing rights.

articles.title: Portland braces for deployment of 200 national guard troops to city
articles.trailText: Oregon has filed a lawsuit to block Trump’s move, warning there was no ‘legal justification’ and it will escalate tensions
articles.summary: Oregon has sued to block President Trump’s plan to federalize 200 Oregon National Guard troops for deployment in Portland, arguing no legal basis exists and the move will inflame tensions. Trump cited unsubstantiated claims of ICE facilities under attack in the Democratic-run city. Gov. Tina Kotek warned there’s no insurrection or security threat. A Department of Defense memo orders troops to protect federal sites for two months. The lawsuit contends the deployment infringes state sovereignty and risks public safety. This follows similar federal force use in Los Angeles and Washington DC this year.

articles.title: Body of missing teen found in D4vd’s Tesla likely ‘dead for several weeks,’ say police
articles.trailText: Celeste Rivas Hernandez, first reported missing at age 13, found decomposing in trunk of singer’s car in Los Angeles
articles.summary: Celeste Rivas Hernandez, first reported missing at 13 in April 2024, was discovered decomposing in singer D4vd’s Tesla trunk on September 8—one day after her 15th birthday—after a foul odor prompted police attention. LAPD Capt. Scot Williams reports she likely died several weeks earlier, with the vehicle ticketed on August 27, towed September 5 and parked in Hollywood Hills for over a month. The L.A. County Medical Examiner has yet to determine cause or manner of death; the robbery-homicide unit is investigating concealment of her body. D4vd, 20, canceled his Warfield and Greek Theatre tour dates and had his rented property searched by authorities.

articles.title: Nine people dead and scores injured over weekend of mass US shootings
articles.trailText: Six separate mass shootings bring tally to 324 this year, underscoring continuing US crisis of gun violence
articles.summary: Over a single weekend in late September, six mass shootings across four states killed nine people (including one suspect) and injured at least 33, raising this year’s US total to 324 – more than one per day. Incidents included non-fatal shootings in Alexandria, LA and Raleigh, NC; a waterfront bar attack in Southport, NC (3 dead, 8 wounded); a casino shooting in Eagle Pass, TX (2 dead); a Bourbon Street brawl in New Orleans (1 bystander killed); and a church massacre in Grand Blanc, MI (4 worshippers killed, 8 wounded). Specialists cite the country’s 400 million firearms and lax state laws amid nearly 47,000 gun deaths in 2023.

articles.title: Trump administration spending $625m to revive dying coal industry
articles.trailText: White House allocating 13.1m acres of public land to coal mining, which has been on rapid decline over past 30 years
articles.summary: The Trump administration announced a $625m package and opening 13.1m acres of public land for coal to revitalize the sector amid a 30-year US coal output slide and wind and solar topped coal in 2023. Measures include $350m for plant upgrades, $175m for rural energy projects and $50m for wastewater systems. Critics warn of taxpayer waste, increased pollution, and health costs while clean power overtakes coal. The move highlights administration priorities in energy security and AI-era demand but draws ire from environmental groups citing coal’s climate and health impacts.

articles.title: Ice’s deportations of south-east Asian refugees creating ‘ripple effect’ of trauma: ‘I didn’t get to say bye to my husband’
articles.trailText: Administration’s targeting of group settled in the US after fleeing war in Vietnam creating further displacement
articles.summary: Deportations by ICE of aging south-east Asian refugees—many Hmong and Laotian war-era arrivals with decades-old convictions—have surged under the Biden administration, mirroring a Trump-era ramp-up and creating a ripple effect of trauma. Hmong refugee Wa Kong Lor, born in a Thai camp, was sent to Laos stateless, armed only with $65, leaving his wife unable to say goodbye. Advocates report over 150 deportations from Minnesota since May and are pushing state pardons to block removals. Meanwhile, grassroots groups in Vientiane scramble to provide housing, cash and care to deportees who never knew their “homeland,” warning that stripping breadwinners from low-income enclaves deepens displacement and trauma.

articles.title: Michigan car crash kills three family members from TLC’s Meet the Putmans
articles.trailText: Five other relatives were injured when vehicles crashed into each other after semi-truck driver failed to stop at sign
articles.summary: Three members of the Michigan-based TLC reality family Meet the Putmans—patriarch Bill “Papa” Putman, his wife Barb “Neenee” and daughter-in-law Megan—were killed Sept. 29 when a Florida semi-truck failed to stop at a sign and slammed into their Jeep. Five other relatives (Uncle Blake, Lulu, Alena, Noah and Gia) remain hospitalized—Noah sedated but responsive, Gia post-craniotomy with reduced brain pressure. Two truck occupants sustained minor injuries; the driver was arrested pending charges. The Putmans, whose 2017 TLC series chronicled their multigenerational Tuscola County household, have requested prayers and support.

articles.title: Mormon church shooting suspect had Trump sign outside home, records show
articles.trailText: Google Maps images show suspect who was shot dead by police had Trump sign outside his Michigan house
articles.summary: In Grand Blanc Township, Michigan, 40-year-old Thomas Jacob Sanford, a former Marine, killed four worshippers and wounded eight at a Mormon church before police shot him dead. Public records and Google Maps imagery show a blue sign reading 'Trump' on his Burton home and a family photo of him in a 'Re-elect Trump 2020' T-shirt. Sanford disparaged Mormons, rammed a pickup through the church door, opened fire, and set it ablaze. Investigators label the attack 'targeted violence' but have not confirmed a political motive. The FBI and state police continue probing his planning and affiliations.

articles.title: First Thing: At least four dead and eight injured after shooting at Mormon church in Michigan
articles.trailText: Church set ablaze on weekend when shooting attacks also took place in North Carolina, Texas and New Orleans. Plus, the secrets of Birkenstock’s enduring success
articles.summary: In Grand Blanc Township, Michigan, a 40-year-old man drove through the front door of a Mormon church on Sept. 28, opened fire on worshippers with an assault rifle, killing two people and injuring eight before police shot him dead. Hours later, firefighters found two more bodies in the church’s charred remains after the attacker set the building ablaze. Authorities say this marks the 324th mass shooting in the US this year and warn the death toll may rise as the site is cleared.

articles.title: Pastor linked to Lutheran church group also linked to neo-Confederate movement
articles.trailText: John Eidsmoe, associated with Lutheran Church Missouri Synod, has history with public defenses of Confederacy
articles.summary: John Eidsmoe, a Presbyterian pastor and retired colonel, has long defended the Confederacy before neo-Confederate groups such as the Council for Concerned Citizens—which Dylann Roof cited in his radicalization—and the League of the South. Though LCMS denies he is a pastor or member, Eidsmoe sits on the board of its Recognized Service Organization Lutherans for Life and has lectured at affiliated colleges. His enduring ties to far-right networks, including Roy Moore’s Foundation for Moral Law, have reignited scandals over extremist influence in the Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod, prompting calls for internal reckoning.

articles.title: Harris calls Trump ‘incompetent and unhinged’ and makes call to ‘fight fire with fire’
articles.trailText: President’s 2024 election rival delivers fiery remarks while accepting Congressional Black Caucus Foundation award
articles.summary: Speaking at the Congressional Black Caucus Foundation awards in Washington DC, former VP Kamala Harris condemned President Trump as an “unchecked, incompetent, unhinged” leader and urged opponents to “fight fire with fire.” She criticized his second-term policies—cutting healthcare and nutrition assistance, imposing tariffs that drove up consumer prices, slashing $500m for vaccines, deploying troops domestically—and decried institutions that “kneel before a tyrant” by settling lawsuits over free speech and discrimination. Citing Jimmy Kimmel’s reinstatement at ABC after a boycott, she lauded grassroots resistance and called on Democrats to win the 2026 midterms to restore checks and balances on a feared Trump second presidency.

articles.title: Stephen Miller takes leading role in strikes on alleged Venezuelan drug boats
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Miller’s homeland security council has played a key part in coordinating operations, sources say
articles.summary: White House deputy chief of staff Stephen Miller has spearheaded US strikes on suspected Venezuelan drug boats, channeling operations through the newly independent Homeland Security Council he leads and eclipsing Secretary of State Marco Rubio. Miller’s team controlled intelligence and strike timing, briefing top officials hours before attacks such as the 15 September hellfire strike. The Trump administration defends the operations under Article II self-defense powers and its designation of Venezuelan cartel Tren de Aragua as a terrorist organization—despite a federal appeals court ruling deportations unlawful and scant evidence of the cartel’s ties to Maduro’s government. Approvals came from the Pentagon general counsel, DOJ and White House counsel.

articles.title: At least four dead and eight injured after shooting at Mormon church in Michigan
articles.trailText: Church allegedly set ablaze by gunman on weekend when shooting attacks also took place in North Carolina, Texas and New Orleans
articles.summary: At least four killed and eight wounded when 40-year-old Iraq war veteran Thomas Jacob Sanford rammed a vehicle into a Michigan Mormon church in Grand Blanc Township, opened fire and set it ablaze; Sanford was shot dead by police and two more bodies were found in the ruins. That weekend also saw mass shootings at North Carolina waterfront bars (3 dead, 5 wounded), a Texas casino (2 dead, 5 wounded) and Bourbon Street in New Orleans (1 dead, 3 wounded), pushing the US total past 320 for 2025. A 100-agent FBI response is underway; motives remain unclear.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: more than 100,000 federal workers to quit on Tuesday in largest ever mass resignation
articles.trailText: Latest departures in Trump administration’s deferred resignation program come as Congress faces government shutdown deadline – key US politics stories from Sunday 28 September
articles.summary: On Tuesday, over 100,000 workers will resign—the largest mass departure in US history—under Trump’s deferred resignation program to enact sweeping workforce cuts. Facing a funding deadline to avert a government shutdown, White House ordered agencies to draft large-scale layoff contingency plans if talks fail. Employees cite months of ‘fear and intimidation’ for quitting. Meanwhile, Trump plans a bipartisan meeting in a final shutdown bid; a former White House lawyer says he’s using the James Comey indictment to rewrite history; NYC mayoral candidate Eric Adams drops out; and watchdogs warn of dire water and sleep shortages for children in ICE detention.

articles.title: Oregon sues to block ‘illegal’ deployment of 200 national guard troops to Portland
articles.trailText: State attorney general asks federal court to block Trump from sending troops to city based on ‘social media gossip’
articles.summary: Oregon sued in federal court to block President Trump’s order federalizing 200 Oregon National Guard troops for 60 days in Portland, arguing his portrayal of the city as “war ravaged” is “pure fiction” rooted in a single Fox News segment that misused 2020 protest footage to describe a small recent ICE demonstration. Governor Tina Kotek and Attorney General Dan Rayfield maintain there is no insurrection or public safety crisis, local law enforcement has protests under control, and Trump exceeded his authority by seizing state reservists absent a foreign invasion or mass anarchy.

articles.title: Ex-Trump lawyer says president using Comey indictment to conceal being ‘criminal’
articles.trailText: Ty Cobb, who managed Trump’s Mueller investigation response, said president is trying to ‘rewrite history’
articles.summary: Ty Cobb, Trump’s ex-White House lawyer during the Mueller probe, told CBS Face the Nation that Trump’s indictment of ex-FBI director James Comey for lying to Congress is an authoritarian, unconstitutional bid to rewrite history and shield the president’s alleged crimes—from inciting insurrection and stealing classified documents to refusing to concede. Cobb argued the Comey case is fatally flawed—the grand jury approved two counts by slim margins—and predicted its likely dismissal or acquittal. He criticized Trump’s installation of Lindsey Halligan—a personal lawyer with no prosecutorial experience known for downplaying slavery at the Smithsonian—to pursue Comey charges, and warned that any of Trump’s opponents faced similar retaliation.

articles.title: Eric Adams drops out of New York City mayoral race
articles.trailText: New York City mayor abandons faltering bid to win re-election in social media video set to strains of song My Way
articles.summary: NYC mayor Eric Adams, who was elected as a Democrat but ran for re-election as an independent after a federal corruption indictment (later dropped for his cooperation on immigration raids), abandoned his struggling bid just over a month before election day. In a social-media video set to 'My Way,' Adams blamed constant media speculation, a campaign finance board’s decision to withhold matching funds over suspicious donations, and admitted he’d lost New Yorkers’ trust despite calling the charges unjust. His withdrawal narrows the race to Democrat Zohran Mamdani, former governor Andrew Cuomo and Republican Curtis Sliwa, with Mamdani leading Cuomo by double digits.

articles.title: Illinois senator demands to meet with Ice amid clashes at immigration facility
articles.trailText: Dick Durbin renews push to talk to Trump officials as operations and protests escalate at Broadview facility
articles.summary: Senator Dick Durbin, with Rep. Delia Ramirez and other Democrats, has demanded access to the ICE detention center in Broadview, Illinois, after federal operations escalated and protesters clashed with officers. ICE has refused a congressional oversight visit, offering instead postponed meetings. Recent protests saw arrests, pepper spray and teargas, and an ICE agent allegedly fired chemical agents into a reporter’s car, prompting a criminal investigation. Governor JB Pritzker condemned federal force and urged documentation of actions. The tensions follow the Trump administration’s Midway Blitz targeting immigrants and controversies over conditions and civilian arrests.

articles.title: Trump to meet with US congressional leaders in last-ditch effort to avoid shutdown
articles.trailText: President reverses course days after scrapping meeting to discuss crisis with Hakeem Jeffries and Chuck Schumer
articles.summary: President Trump, days after canceling talks, will host a bipartisan Oval Office meeting Monday with House Speaker Mike Johnson, Senate Majority Leader John Thune and Democratic minority leaders Hakeem Jeffries and Chuck Schumer in a final effort to avert a government shutdown that would furlough scores of federal workers as early as Wednesday. The House-passed, seven-week continuing resolution faces a Senate blockade without at least eight Democratic votes, who demand extension of Affordable Care Act tax credits for over 20 million Americans. Trump’s own advisers say he may welcome a shutdown to wield executive authority, as both parties trade blame.

articles.title: EU industry fears ever-expanding list of ‘derivative’ goods subject to steel tariffs
articles.trailText: Europe braces for further damage if products containing metal, such as windows and doors, are added to rolling list
articles.summary: US proposes a rolling list of 407 “derivative” products—from windows and doors to turbines and furniture—subject to steel tariffs, adding to Trump’s 50% duties on steel imports. EU business leaders and MEP Bernd Lange warn the ad hoc expansion fuels uncertainty and extra costs, as manufacturers struggle to prove metal content and risk up to 200% penalties. BusinessEurope, Eurofer and UK trade unions call for a stable tariff framework and pledges to back domestic steel, while the UK government seeks clarification from Washington on further inclusions.

articles.title: Rudy Giuliani and Dominion settle $1.3bn defamation suit over election lies
articles.trailText: US voting machine maker sued ex-New York mayor and Trump lawyer in 2021 for repeatedly calling election rigged
articles.summary: Rudy Giuliani has confidentially settled a $1.3 billion defamation suit filed by Dominion Voting Systems in 2021 over 50+ false claims that its machines rigged the 2020 election. Filed in federal court in Washington, DC, the deal marks Dominion���s third major pretrial resolution after Fox’s $787.5 million and Newsmax’s $67 million payouts. Giuliani, Trump’s former lawyer, amplified the conspiracy on TV, radio and podcasts, then threatened to countersue on free-speech grounds. The agreement deepens his legal and financial troubles following disbarments in New York and DC, a $148 million judgment to Georgia poll workers and court-ordered asset seizures. Both sides confirmed the settlement but declined further comment.

articles.title: A Trump ally in California is fighting redistricting. Is that what his constituents want?
articles.trailText: Representative Doug LaMalfa made headlines in August after being booed and shouted down at a local town hall
articles.summary: After being heckled at his first Chico town hall in eight years over fears about immigration raids, Medicare and Medicaid cuts, tariffs and wildfire damage, seven-term GOP Rep. Doug LaMalfa—a Trump loyalist who carried 61% here in 2024—now faces California’s Prop 50 referendum. The November vote would redraw congressional districts mid-decade to add five Democratic seats. If approved, LaMalfa could lose his rural, agriculture-rich district. Democrat Audrey Denney may challenge again. Local battles over hospitals, water, housing and fire recovery intertwine with partisan debates on fair representation, prompting high-stakes campaigning ahead of the special election.

articles.title: ‘Like the Gestapo’: trailblazing immigration judge on Ice brutality and Trump’s damage to the courts
articles.trailText: Dana Leigh Marks had a long and notable tenure on the bench. Now she’s watching the Trump administration trash her institution – and raising the alarm
articles.summary: Retired immigration judge Dana Leigh Marks, celebrated for winning INS v Cardoza-Fonseca at 32 and spearheading collective bargaining and female representation on the bench, warns that the Trump administration's political interference is wrecking immigration courts. With over 100 judges dismissed, a 3.6m-case backlog, resource starvation and ICE arrests "like the Gestapo," she fears due process is under siege. Marks criticizes inserting military lawyers without asylum experience, calls for an independent judiciary separate from the DOJ, and likens current courts to canaries in a coalmine for wider threats to American legal precedent. She labels the chaos deliberate, predicting that building by disorder will ultimately collapse, and urges public outrage to revive bipartisan legislation for independent immigration courts.

articles.title: Crunch time: Democrats ready for shutdown standoff over Republican health cuts
articles.trailText: Party prepared to risk government shutdown and will not support GOP bill unless cuts to healthcare are reversed
articles.summary: Facing a Tuesday funding deadline, House and Senate Democrats refuse to back Republicans’ clean continuing resolution unless cuts to Medicaid are reversed, public media funding is restored and ACA subsidies are extended. Minority leader Hakeem Jeffries and Senate leader Chuck Schumer warn the GOP’s tax-and-spending bill threatens coverage for 10 million Medicaid beneficiaries and 20 million ACA enrollees. Republicans accuse Democrats of hypocrisy over past CRs. Lawmakers return Monday under the threat of a Trump-led shutdown, with Democrats betting a healthcare standoff will rally voters for the 2026 midterms.

articles.title: Children left short of clean water and sleep amid ‘prolonged’ detention by Ice, watchdog groups allege
articles.trailText: Legal experts speak of ‘cruel’ and harmful deprivations for families held in Texas immigration facility
articles.summary: Legal monitors’ court filing details inhumane conditions at ICE’s South Texas Family Residential Center in Dilley: children held for weeks or months—far beyond the 20-day limit—endure foul water shortages, 24/7 lights and noise causing chronic sleep deprivation, lack of paid hygiene supplies, delayed medical care (including emergency appendicitis surgery), minimal one-hour daily schooling and emotional abuse. Detainees live in “cell-like trailers,” guards call them “inmates.” Attorneys argue CoreCivic’s ICE facility violates Flores settlement standards and are seeking court enforcement to protect children’s health and rights.

articles.title: ���It’s incredibly exciting’: ancient canoe unearthed after Hurricane Ian stormed through Florida
articles.trailText: The latest find is likely from the 16th century and could have originated as far away as the Caribbean
articles.summary: In 2022, a Fort Myers resident uncovered a fragile 9-ft wooden canoe during Hurricane Ian cleanup. State archaeologists preserved the vessel, the first mahogany craft recorded in Florida, and noted iron tool marks indicating a post-contact, likely 16th-century, Spanish or Caribbean origin. Radiocarbon tests have yielded anomalously early dates—probably dating the timber’s death or affected by contaminants—so the exact construction date remains undetermined. This rare find joins over 450 ancient canoes, some 7,000 years old, highlighting Florida’s uniquely water-rich environment that fosters exceptional archaeological preservation.

articles.title: Clarence Thomas says precedent might not determine cases on upcoming supreme court docket
articles.trailText: The court is expected to weigh in on same-sex marriage next session, which it legalized in 2015
articles.summary: At a public address at Catholic University’s law school, Justice Clarence Thomas argued that Supreme Court precedent is not ‘gospel’ and should reflect sound legal tradition rather than blind adherence to flawed past decisions. He signaled willingness to revisit landmark rulings, including the 2015 Obergefell same-sex marriage decision he dissented from, and suggested overturning other substantive due process precedents on contraception and same-sex intimacy. Thomas’s remarks come ahead of a term expected to tackle Obergefell challenges alongside cases on tariffs, trans rights, campaign finance, religious freedom and capital punishment. They underscore the power of Trump’s conservative supermajority and follow a rejected Democrats’ ethics referral over his undisclosed gifts and travel.

articles.title: US set for largest mass resignation in history as Trump continues deep cuts
articles.trailText: Federal workers say they have little choice but to depart, with 100,000 leaving under deferred resignation program
articles.summary: Trump administration's deferred resignation program prompts 100,000+ federal workers to quit, part of sweeping cuts to shrink workforce by up to 275,000 via resignations, attrition, early retirements and fires amid looming government shutdown. OMB head Russell Vought’s rhetoric vilified civil servants as 'villains', fueling fear. The $14.8bn buyout, defended as saving $28bn annually, follows months of intimidation, rising job insecurity and mission erosion. Labor unions sued, alleging the plan circumvents Congress and undermines agency functions. Departing employees cite mental health strains, broken morale and a stagnant job market amid a record employment drop since WWII and 4.3% unemployment.

articles.title: The week in Trump absurdities: from Turkey’s ‘rigged elections’ to ‘your countries are going to hell’
articles.trailText: The president, in five days, has claimed Tylenol causes autism, he was sabotaged at the UN and pronounced his rivals ‘guilty as hell’
articles.summary: Over five days, President Trump launched a series of unhinged stunts and gaffes: he urged AG Pam Bondi to prosecute political foes ‘guilty as hell’ then deleted the post; at Charlie Kirk’s memorial he admitted hating opponents while dancing beside the widow; he falsely warned Tylenol causes autism and mispronounced ‘acetaminophen’; at the UN escalator stopped mid-ride, blamed ‘sabotage,’ teleprompter failed, and decried open borders; in talks with Erdoğan he mocked ‘rigged elections,’ threatened liberals, insulted Rep. Crockett’s IQ and replaced Biden’s portrait; he capped the week advocating splitting vaccines and banning Tylenol for children.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: Trump orders deployment of national guard to ‘war ravaged’ Portland
articles.trailText: Officials in Portland have pushed back against the announcement, saying there is ‘no need for military troops’ – key US politics stories from Saturday 27 September
articles.summary: President Trump ordered National Guard troops to “war ravaged” Portland, Oregon, to protect ICE facilities he claims are under siege by Antifa, prompting Governor Tina Kotek and local officials to reject any security threat or need for military forces. In related developments, Trump fired the acting US attorney in Sacramento after she warned against indiscriminate immigration raids; detainees at California’s new ICE detention center describe “hell on earth” conditions; Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth summoned hundreds of generals amid fears of firings; and the FBI arrested a Texas man accused of threatening violence at a Pride parade.

articles.title: Portland residents scoff at Trump threat to send military: ‘This is not a war zone’
articles.trailText: Claims of violence by US president contrast with reality of life in vibrant, peaceful Oregon city, residents say
articles.summary: Despite Trump calling Portland a “war zone” under siege by antifa and “domestic terrorists” to justify deploying federal troops with “full force,” downtown Portland was calm, vibrant and largely filled with civilians at coffee shops and a packed farmers’ market. Only four protesters gathered at an ICE field office next to a Tesla dealership—one in a chicken costume—denouncing racial detentions and holding signs like “Tesla Funds Fascism.” Protesters describe a months-long small but persistent action, including an organizer nicknamed “Burrito,” saying federal agents, not protesters, escalate tensions. Online, residents share images of normal life mocking Trump’s false narrative.

articles.title: Trump is flaunting his corruption. Is it changing what the US thinks of scandal?
articles.trailText: President has shouted from rooftops what his predecessors would have tried to cover up for fear of ending their careers
articles.summary: President Trump openly brags about abuses past leaders hid, from ordering DOJ probes of foes to pressing foreign governments to investigate rivals. Observers warn his brazen ‘flood the zone’ tactics desensitize Americans and earn him a veneer of authenticity, as Republicans refuse to rein him in. By tweeting demands for charges against James Comey, Adam Schiff and Letitia James, then deleting them, and pardoning January 6 rioters, Trump dismantles norms, diluting the sting of scandal. He even plans to accept a $400 m plane from Qatar as Air Force One, defying emoluments concerns.

articles.title: FBI arrest man who allegedly threatened to shoot people at Texas Pride parade
articles.trailText: Suspect Joshua Cole allegedly used a Facebook account to threaten revenge for murder of Charlie Kirk
articles.summary: On Sept. 18, FBI agents in Dallas arrested Abilene resident Joshua Cole for Facebook threats to “lock and load” and target “fairies” at the Sept. 20 Abilene Pride parade in retaliation for rightwing activist Charlie Kirk’s Sept. 10 killing. Using the “Jay Dubya” account, he posted violent anti-LGBTQ+ comments. After quitting his job, Cole was stopped by police, waived his rights, and admitted to the threats. He faces up to five years under federal law. Abilene Pride Alliance reaffirmed its security measures; the Trump administration has not commented.

articles.title: Donald Trump says he is deploying troops to Portland, Oregon
articles.trailText: Apparently misled by hyperbolic reporting from conservative outlets on a single small protest, president described peaceful city as ‘war ravaged’
articles.summary: President Trump announced on social media he is deploying federal troops to Portland, Oregon, claiming “war ravaged” streets and ICE facilities “under siege” by Antifa. Local leaders – Governor Tina Kotek, Mayor Keith Wilson and Congressional Democrats – say Portland is peaceful, with only a small protest outside an ICE office, and reject any request for troops. Videos cited by Trump were outdated or misleading, they say. Senators Jeff Merkley and Ron Wyden, Representatives Suzanne Bonamici and Maxine Dexter denounced the move as authoritarian, unnecessary and based on false reporting. No timeline or troop numbers have been provided.

articles.title: Police identify suspect in 1991 murders of four girls at Texas yogurt shop
articles.trailText: Officials name Robert Eugene Brashers in brutal deaths of Amy Ayers, Eliza Thomas and Jennifer and Sarah Harbison
articles.summary: After more than 34 years, Austin police have identified Robert Eugene Brashers—who died by suicide in 1999—as the DNA-linked suspect in the brutal 1991 slayings of Amy Ayers (13), Eliza Thomas (17) and sisters Jennifer (17) and Sarah Harbison (15) inside an I Can’t Believe It’s Yogurt shop. The girls were bound, gagged, shot execution-style, sexually assaulted and the store set ablaze. Renewed attention from an HBO docuseries prompted advanced testing that exonerated two men whose convictions were overturned in 2009. Brashers, with a history of violent crimes across multiple states, remains the focus of an ongoing investigation.

articles.title: US military brass brace for firings as Pentagon chief orders top-level meeting
articles.trailText: Pete Hegseth summons hundreds of generals and admirals to Virginia to meet and receive address on ‘warrior ethos’
articles.summary: Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth abruptly summoned hundreds of generals and admirals to Quantico for a top-level meeting on “warrior ethos” amid expectations of firings or demotions. The unprecedented gathering, ordered with little notice, will feature Hegseth’s ‘rally the troops’ address on fitness standards, defense-industrial base and deterrence. Sources say it signals a show of force under Trump’s second presidency, part of broader cuts to general officers, prompting unease among senior leaders and comparisons to historical purges.

articles.title: Belva Davis, a journalist who ‘opened doors for a generation’, dies aged 92
articles.trailText: Friends and colleagues remember the first Black woman hired as a TV reporter on the west coast for her ‘courage, integrity, grace and humanity’
articles.summary: Belva Davis, who died aged 92, was a trailblazing journalist and the first Black woman TV reporter on the US west coast. Born in Monroe, Louisiana, during Jim Crow, she moved to California, began in print and then anchored KPIX, KRON and KQED’s flagship news programs. Over five decades she covered Harvey Milk’s assassination, the AIDS crisis and major elections, earned eight regional Emmys and lifetime achievement honors, and mentored generations with courage, integrity and grace.

articles.title: Northwestern students blocked from enrollment after refusing controversial antisemitism training
articles.trailText: Students say mandatory training video is biased in favor of Israel and could inflame campus tensions over Gaza
articles.summary: At Northwestern University, at least 300 students have been blocked from registering after refusing a mandatory antisemitism training they say is biased toward Israel, inaccurate and risks inflaming campus tensions over Gaza. The hold—required by federal anti-discrimination rules and Trump’s 2020 executive order—threatens jobs, visas, stipends and health insurance. Produced by Jewish United Fund, the module equates critics of Israel with David Duke, labels the West Bank “Judea and Samaria” and includes anti-Arab content. Students argue it silences dissent and entrenches bias. Similar trainings are spreading amid federal funding threats, yet Northwestern still lost $790m in research support.

articles.title: Outrage mounts as Republicans in Congress move to protect pesticide makers from lawsuits
articles.trailText: Bayer, maker of Roundup weedkiller, founded group pushing to block cancer claim suits against pesticide makers
articles.summary: After inheriting 100,000+ Roundup cancer lawsuits, Bayer-backed Modern Ag Alliance has helped pass liability shields in Georgia and North Dakota and now targets federal measures in an appropriations rider and the upcoming farm bill to block pesticide litigation and prevent EPA label updates if not aligned with existing human health assessments. Consumer advocates—including the bipartisan Maha movement—alongside Democrats like Rep. Chellie Pingree and trial attorneys decry these “sneaky” provisions as unconstitutional, warning they strip consumers of legal recourse and obstruct new health risk warnings. Bayer argues federal certainty is needed to protect research and investments and disputes that the language precludes lawsuits, while also threatening to halt glyphosate sales if litigation persists.

articles.title: ‘Find it in your heart to seek the truth’: Epstein survivor pushes for lawmakers to release files
articles.trailText: Jess Michaels says authorities are ‘completely ignoring’ hers and dozens of other victims’ statements about Epstein’s trafficking
articles.summary: Jess Michaels, a former professional dancer raped by Jeffrey Epstein in 1990, has joined dozens of survivors demanding that Congress and the Department of Justice release decades-old investigative files. Despite President Trump’s campaign promise and the FBI’s claim to be “releasing as much as legally allowed,” DOJ officials insist no client list exists and refuse further disclosure. Survivors and GOP Rep. Thomas Massie point to documents identifying at least 20 men to whom Epstein allegedly trafficked victims, contradicting FBI counsel Kash Patel’s assertion of no credible evidence. Michaels decries systemic neglect, bipartisan frustration, and urges lawmakers to ‘find it in your heart to seek the truth.’

articles.title: Kamala Harris’s new book details her steep challenges without acknowledging her failures
articles.trailText: In 107 Days, Harris leaves little room for nuance – nor is she afflicted with a surplus of self-awareness
articles.summary: In her campaign memoir 107 Days, Kamala Harris contends that Joe Biden’s age-related decline and minimal lead doomed her second White House bid with just 107 days to campaign. She critiques her own timidity and indecision, laments selecting Minnesota governor Tim Walz—whose lackluster debate performance she recounts in detail—and admits passing on Pete Buttigieg. Harris celebrates breaking the Senate tie on the Inflation Reduction Act yet glosses over muddled stances on immigration, inflation and social safety nets, identity-politics jargon and a cultural disconnect with working-class voters.

articles.title: ‘A hot mess’: Florida open-carry gun ruling leads to chaos and confusion
articles.trailText: Florida’s attorney general recently said ‘open carry is the law of the state���. State officials and advocates aren’t so sure
articles.summary: Florida AG James Uthmeier hailed a 1st District appeals court ruling overturning the 1987 ban on open carry, prompting sheriffs to stop enforcing open‐carry prohibitions. Yet dozens of statutes still bar firearms in schools, hospitals, courthouses, polling places, bars and private property, leaving law enforcement, legislators and advocates in disarray. Democrats decry a "hot mess" that GOP lawmakers face in January to clarify policy. Gun safety groups warn of escalated risks; gun rights groups advise caution amid legal ambiguities.

articles.title: ‘Hell on earth’: immigrants held in new California detention facility beg for help
articles.trailText: Six people at a remote Ice facility in California City describe medical problems and filthy conditions, which operator CoreCivic denies
articles.summary: In California City’s new 2,560-bed ICE detention center, six migrants fighting deportation describe “hell on earth” conditions: filthy cells, malfunctioning toilets, limited hygiene and food rations, delayed or discarded medications triggering medical emergencies, threats of solitary confinement and force, and minimal outdoor time in harsh desert environs. Operated by CoreCivic without local permits, the facility opened in August 2025, boosting ICE capacity by 36% to over 500 detainees. CoreCivic asserts health and maintenance issues have been addressed; advocates and city officials allege unlawful operation, spurring protests and hunger strikes.

articles.title: Democrats race to embrace swearing and angry comebacks – but will it work?
articles.trailText: Democrats are abandoning their careful messaging in favor of gut-level rhetoric that’s unapologetically more profane as the party faces an authenticity problem
articles.summary: Facing decade-low approval and an authenticity crisis, Democrats from presidential hopefuls to state chairs are shedding polite talking points for raw, profane rhetoric and trolling tactics. Figures like Rep. Robert Garcia, Gov. Gavin Newsom and grassroots leader Lorena Gonzalez embrace swearing, viral memes and live-streamed hot takes on TikTok, Twitch and even Fox News to sound like “normal people” and counter Trump’s outrage machine. Guided by polling memos on what to say (and what to avoid), younger “fighter” Democrats wager that authentic anger and humor will energize disillusioned voters—though critics warn that emotion without action risks fueling frustration rather than change.

articles.title: New York man charged with parents’ murders after TV confession
articles.trailText: Lorenz Kraus, 53, tells WRGB in Albany he killed elderly parents as act of mercy and buried bodies in back yard
articles.summary: Lorenz Kraus, 53, confessed on WRGB in Albany that eight years after his parents vanished he suffocated and buried his father, 92-year-old Franz, and his mother, 83-year-old Theresia, in their backyard as an act of mercy. He described choking his father with his hands and using a rope on his mother before concealing their bodies. Charged with two counts of murder and illicitly concealing a corpse, Kraus pleaded not guilty and is held without bail. A 1994 Siena valedictorian with an MBA, he urged legal reform on mercy killings.

articles.title: Trump fires US attorney who told border agents to follow law on immigration raids
articles.trailText: New York Times reports Michele Beckwith’s firing came after she reminded Border Patrol to comply with courts
articles.summary: Donald Trump abruptly dismissed acting US attorney Michele Beckwith in Sacramento on July 15 after she instructed Border Patrol to honor an April federal court order barring indiscriminate detentions without reasonable suspicion. Beckwith, appointed in January, told El Centro Border Patrol chief Gregory Bovino via call and follow-up email to comply with the constitution and court rulings. Hours later her devices were disabled and she received a termination letter. Two days later agents raided a Home Depot. Beckwith has appealed. Her firing follows similar removals of federal prosecutors clashing with Trump’s agenda.

articles.title: Trump says he expects charges for other adversaries after Comey indictment
articles.trailText: President says ‘I think there’ll be others’ as justice department condemned for enacting retribution campaign
articles.summary: President Trump predicted further criminal charges against his “corrupt radical left” adversaries after DOJ indicted ex-FBI director James Comey for allegedly authorizing leaks. The two-count false-statement indictment, filed by Trump-appointed prosecutor Lindsey Halligan in Alexandria, narrowly secured grand jury approval despite earlier US attorney Erik Siebert deeming the evidence insufficient. Critics decry the move as politically motivated retribution by Trump’s Justice Department. Trump has also targeted New York AG Letitia James, Sen. Adam Schiff, former CIA chief John Brennan and ex-NSA adviser John Bolton, urging AG Pam Bondi to pursue charges against others who challenged him.

articles.title: Detainees shot in deadly attack on Ice facility in Dallas identified – reports
articles.trailText: Two men were injured and one was killed by an alleged lone shooter at an immigration detention center in Texas
articles.summary: Three ICE detainees—Mexican national Miguel Angel García-Hernandez, Venezuelan Jose Andres Bordones-Molina and Salvadoran Norlan Guzman-Fuentes—were shot at a Dallas detention center in a “targeted” attack by 29-year-old Joshua Jahn, who later died by suicide. Guzman-Fuentes was killed; García-Hernandez remains in critical condition after multiple operations, prompting a family fundraiser; Bordones-Molina was also injured. Both García-Hernandez, a house painter and father of four, and Bordones-Molina were undocumented; Guzman-Fuentes had past arrests. Jahn’s notes outlined the attack; Trump blames left-wing extremists despite no evidence.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president says he hopes ‘there will be others’ after Comey indictment
articles.trailText: ‘It’s not about revenge,’ Trump claims as lawmakers raise alarm over ‘blatant abuse’ of justice department – key US politics stories from Friday 26 September
articles.summary: Friday’s US politics roundup: President Trump denies Comey indictment is revenge, calls it justice and hopes for further prosecutions as Democrats warn of DOJ abuse. Other developments: ICE officer suspended after court assault video; immigrants without criminal records now the largest ICE detainee group; US blocks UN declaration on noncommunicable diseases; Arizona GOP lawmaker calls to execute a Democratic congresswoman; Abu Dhabi royal fund to take 15% of TikTok US; Trump jokes to Rolex about tariffs; plus updates on Gaza speech, Wounded Knee medals, frozen foreign aid, teen opioid treatment and Ryder Cup security.

articles.title: Trump jokingly asked Rolex executives if tariffs prompted US Open invite, CEO says
articles.trailText: Rolex CEO stressed US president’s remarks were made ‘in jest’ in letter to Elizabeth Warren, who had raised concerns
articles.summary: At the US Open final Swiss watchmaker Rolex invited President Trump to its VIP box, prompting Trump to quip—only half in jest—whether his 39% tariff on Swiss exports won him the invite. CEO Jean-Frédéric Dufour stressed in a letter to Sen. Elizabeth Warren that the invitation reflected sportsmanship, not tariff talks, and no trade discussions occurred. Warren decried the invite as potential corruption, while the White House dismissed her as peddling conspiracy theories. Trump received a golf sweater and gilet as thanks.

articles.title: Ice detains superintendent of Iowa’s largest school district
articles.trailText: Fellow educators express shock at detention of ‘beacon of light’ Ian Roberts as DHS claims he had ‘no work authorization’
articles.summary: The superintendent of Iowa’s largest school district, Ian Roberts, was detained by ICE on Sept 26 over a final removal order and lack of work authorization. Born in Guyana and raised in Brooklyn, the 54-year-old former Guyana Olympian—first person of color to lead Des Moines Public Schools—allegedly fled ICE officers and is held in Pottawattamie County. He has a prior weapons infraction from 2020. Board members and teacher unions, shocked by his arrest, contest DHS claims, have hired a third-party background check, and appointed an interim superintendent.

articles.title: Elon Musk and Peter Thiel mentioned in Epstein documents released by Democrats
articles.trailText: Prince Andrew and Steve Bannon also referenced in six-page batch of documents made public with redactions
articles.summary: Democrats released six redacted pages from DOJ files on Jeffrey Epstein’s investigations showing scheduled meetings: a breakfast with Steve Bannon (Feb 2019), a lunch with Peter Thiel (Nov 2017), and a potential Elon Musk trip to Epstein’s island (Dec 2014). An earlier manifest names Prince Andrew; a financial disclosure suggests payments to “Andrew” for services. The releases reignited social media attacks between Elon Musk, Trump allies and oversight committee members over selective document publicizing. Democrats are pushing House legislation, now likely to get the 218 signatures needed, to compel full release of Epstein files despite Senate and White House resistance.

articles.title: Hegseth says Wounded Knee massacre soldiers will keep Medals of Honor
articles.trailText: Historical records say the US army killed about 250 Lakota Sioux people in the 1890 massacre in South Dakota
articles.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced that 20 US soldiers who participated in the 1890 Wounded Knee massacre of about 250 Lakota Sioux will retain their Medals of Honor, rejecting calls for revocation. Hegseth—citing a review panel’s conclusion—called the awards justified, halting efforts by Democrats and Native activists who view the massacre of unarmed men, women and children as a genocidal atrocity. Critics accuse the Trump administration of sanitizing history amid wider actions reversing Confederate base renaming and rewriting museum narratives.

articles.title: LA car wash owner sues for $50m after being slammed and detained in Ice raid
articles.trailText: Rafie Ollah Shouhed, 79, a US citizen, was held for 12 hours after sustaining broken ribs and a traumatic brain injury
articles.summary: Rafie Ollah Shouhed, a 79-year-old US citizen and owner of a Van Nuys car wash, has filed a $50 million suit against DHS, CBP, ICE and Border Patrol after agents allegedly body-slammed him, causing broken ribs and a traumatic brain injury, and detained him for 12 hours despite proof of citizenship. His attorney alleges constitutional and civil rights violations amid a surge of aggressive Trump administration raids in southern California, noting video of masked agents using excessive force. Shouhed was never charged and released the same day; ICE said he impeded an operation and was arrested but released without charges.
