Participants were asked if they would change their medication habits and professional opinions on the assertion. The callout closed October 10, 2025; responses were later published, and readers can contribute to other open callouts or share stories.

articles.title: Ice targeted me for organizing, says farm worker who left US for Mexico
articles.trailText: Alfredo Juarez Zeferino spent a harrowing few months in Ice jail – and, under threat of deportation, chose to leave
articles.summary: Alfredo “Lelo” Juarez Zeferino, a 25-year-old farm-worker organizer in Washington since age eight, spent March–July 2025 detained by ICE at Tacoma’s Northwest Detention Center. Under threat of forced removal, he agreed to self-deport after enduring late meals, undercooked meat, medical neglect and a near-midnight deportation flight scraping. Back on his family’s farm in Guerrero, Mexico, he continues remote organizing with Familias Unidas por la Justicia and Community to Community, campaigns for unannounced ICE-center inspections, opposes the H-2A guest-worker program and pursues a legal path to return to the US.

articles.title: Trump officials announce highly contentious conclusions on autism | First Thing
articles.trailText: President claims Tylenol increases risk when taken by pregnant women, an assertion contradicted by research. Plus, Jimmy Kimmel will return to TV tonight after much-criticized suspension
articles.summary: The Trump administration, led by RFK Jr. and President Trump, asserted that prenatal acetaminophen (Tylenol) use raises autism risk in children and urged pregnant women to limit its use. Scientists in the US and UK swiftly rejected the claim, labelling it fearmongering unsupported by existing studies. Alison Singer of the Autism Science Foundation called the announcement premature and misleading; Durham University’s Monique Botha highlighted a 2.4m-birth Swedish study finding no link. No new data was cited, and critics warn it could undermine public health guidance.

articles.title: Pennsylvania official faces threats over post she says was misconstrued as Charlie Kirk killing celebration
articles.trailText: Misty Hunt, a local school board member, said her ‘one down, hundreds to go’ post was about gardening, not Kirk
articles.summary: Misty Hunt, a Homer-Center school board member, posted "one down, hundreds to go" about windblown milkweed seeds, but poor reception kept her gardening video from uploading. When Charlie Kirk was shot that day, many misconstrued it as celebrating his killing. After receiving threats and sparking an investigation, she stepped back from duties, abstained from votes and was removed from a committee. A packed September meeting saw supporters and critics. Hunt apologized, condemned all political violence and will wait for November’s election before deciding her political future.

articles.title: Experts alarmed as Trump pushes unproven link between Tylenol and autism
articles.trailText: Doctors call president’s warning that pregnant women should limit use of acetaminophen – also known as paracetamol – ‘highly concerning’ and ‘irresponsible’
articles.summary: After President Trump and Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. urged pregnant women to curb acetaminophen over an unproven autism risk, top obstetric and regulatory bodies—ACOG, SMFM, the UK MHRA and Australia’s TGA—called the claim baseless and irresponsible. They cited a 2024 Swedish sibling cohort study of 2.4 million births finding no causal link to autism, ADHD or intellectual disability. Tylenol’s manufacturer and leading pediatricians reaffirm its safety in pregnancy, while the FDA’s approval of leucovorin for autism treatment drew APA cautions on insufficient evidence.

articles.title: Zohran Mamdani agrees to ABC town hall after Kimmel reinstated
articles.trailText: New York mayoral candidate had withdrawn from WABC event in protest at network’s suspension of talkshow host
articles.summary: New York mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani, a Queens assembly member who clinched the Democratic nod in June, withdrew from a WABC town hall to protest Disney/ABC’s suspension of Jimmy Kimmel under FCC pressure, decrying corporate cowardice and free-speech threats. He reversed course after ABC reinstated Kimmel��s late-night show amid public backlash. With under two months until Nov. 4, Mamdani leads polls at 43% versus Cuomo’s 28%, Sliwa’s 10% and Adams’ 8%.

articles.title: White House aide sworn in as interim US attorney after Trump fired predecessor
articles.trailText: Appointment of Lindsey Halligan, who has no prosecutorial experience, alarmed current and former prosecutors
articles.summary: Lindsey Halligan, a White House aide with no prior prosecutorial experience, was sworn in as interim US attorney for Virginia’s Eastern District after Trump ousted Erik Siebert for declining to charge James Comey and NY Attorney General Letitia James. Her appointment alarmed current and former DOJ prosecutors, who fear political pressure to indict the president’s opponents irrespective of evidence. Halligan, Trump’s most junior personal lawyer and former Florida insurance attorney, oversaw the special master filing at Mar-a-Lago and now leads a 300-lawyer office handling sensitive national security cases near the Pentagon and CIA. She serves 120 days; Trump plans to nominate her for a full term.

articles.title: Eat salmon, win prizes: Fat Bear Week begins in Alaska’s Katmai national park
articles.trailText: Fattest brown bears, bulking up for hibernation, pitted against each other in online public vote – who will win?
articles.summary: Katmai National Park and Preserve launches its annual Fat Bear Week competition September 23–30, inviting the public to vote online for the fattest brown bear preparing to hibernate. Each day between 12 pm and 9 pm ET, paired bears feasting on Brooks River salmon face off in a single-elimination bracket revealed September 22. The event educates viewers on brown bears’ reliance on salmon runs to build fat reserves—vital for months of hibernation, cub rearing and male fights over prime fishing spots. Since 2014, over a million votes from 100 countries have crowned champions like last year’s 128 Grazer.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president’s attack on acetaminophen criticized by experts as ‘irresponsible’
articles.trailText: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists hits back at linking of key painkiller, known widely as Tylenol or paracetamol, to autism – key US politics stories from 22 September 2025
articles.summary: President Trump urged pregnant women to limit use of acetaminophen (Tylenol/paracetamol), claiming it increases autism risk, citing strides over two decades of research. His statement, part of a broader push for autism causes and a potential cure, was denounced by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists as irresponsible, lacking full scientific backing and oversimplifying autism’s complex factors. Experts worldwide challenge his assertion, noting robust studies contradict his claims and warn his message could confuse and alarm expectant mothers.

articles.title: What to know about Trump’s new $100,000 H-1B visa fee
articles.trailText: White House proclamation announcing new visa fees has prompted questions and confusion – here’s what to know
articles.summary: Trump’s White House has instituted a $100,000 annual fee on new H-1B visas—up from $1.7–4.5k—aiming to curb wage undercutting and offshore IT jobs by shifting costs to employers. Effective immediately, it affects roughly 730,000 H-1B holders and 550,000 dependents, especially in STEM/tech sectors where Google, Amazon and Microsoft lead. A proposed wage-weighted lottery would favor higher-paid roles. Economists warn of slower growth and brain drain; India’s government decries humanitarian impacts. Existing visas and renewals are exempt.

articles.title: Trump rails against Tylenol but autism claims not supported by science
articles.trailText: President’s announcement latest move in campaign that seeks to valorize the ‘natural’ – often at women’s expense
articles.summary: President Trump, echoing Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s unproven claims, urged pregnant women to limit acetaminophen (Tylenol) over an alleged autism risk—contrary to scientific consensus that finds no causal link and warns that untreated fever and pain pose maternal-fetal dangers. This move fits a broader Trump administration push valorizing “natural” pregnancies—undermining Covid vaccines, antidepressants and IVF while promoting pseudoscientific restorative reproductive medicine—rooted in an appeal-to-nature fallacy that could shrink women’s healthcare options, increase risks and enforce pronatalist social control.

articles.title: Trump signs order designating antifa as a ‘domestic terrorist organization’
articles.trailText: Executive order revives controversial pledge from Trump’s first presidency in wake of Charlie Kirk’s killing
articles.summary: Donald Trump signed an executive order designating antifa a “domestic terrorist organization,” reviving his 2020 pledge in response to far-right commentator Charlie Kirk’s killing. The order labels antifa as an anarchist enterprise aiming to overthrow US institutions, though no evidence links the suspect to the network. Extremism experts say there is no legal basis or framework for such a domestic designation under the First Amendment. Antifa’s decentralized, non-hierarchical structure frustrates formal labeling, but investigations could intensify.

articles.title: Trump attacks Tylenol as officials unveil highly contentious conclusions on autism
articles.trailText: President says acetaminophen – also known as paracetamol - increases risk when taken by pregnant women, assertion contradicted by research
articles.summary: At a White House briefing, President Trump and health secretary RFK Jr claimed prenatal acetaminophen raises autism risk and urged women to avoid Tylenol; they also proposed delaying MMRV and hepatitis B vaccinations and will relabel acetaminophen warnings. They announced a leucovorin trial as a possible autism treatment, labeling autism an “epidemic.” Scientists from the CDC, UK and US criticized the assertions as unsubstantiated, citing large studies refuting the acetaminophen link and warning that such rhetoric undermines public health.

articles.title: Democrats urge Trump border czar investigation over bribery allegation
articles.trailText: Tom Homan alleged to have taken $50,000 cash from undercover FBI agent in return for political favours
articles.summary: Democrats have urged treasury watchdogs to probe allegations that Trump’s border czar Tom Homan accepted a $50,000 cash bribe from an undercover FBI agent in return for immigration-related contracts, and failed to report it on his 2024 tax return. Representative Dave Min called on treasury inspectors general to examine whether Homan properly disclosed the payment tied to his consulting firm. The DOJ previously shut down a bribery inquiry, while the White House denies wrongdoing and reporters insist internal documents prove the payment. Senators Warren, Blumenthal and others demand release of video evidence and wider oversight of Homan’s decisions.

articles.title: Republican decries FCC chair’s comments on Kimmel suspension: ‘Absolutely inappropriate’
articles.trailText: Rand Paul, a Kentucky senator, also said Disney and ABC have no obligation to employ the late-night host
articles.summary: Rand Paul, R-Ky., criticized FCC Chair Brendan Carr’s threat to yank ABC licenses unless Disney punishes Jimmy Kimmel for his MAGA-critical comments, calling it “absolutely inappropriate” government interference while noting networks can enforce morals clauses. Other Republicans, including Ted Cruz and Donald Trump—who praised Carr—have voiced free-speech concerns. Ex-Disney CEO Michael Eisner and industry analysts warn Carr’s intimidation risks politicizing major media deals, such as Disney’s proposed NFL asset swap.

articles.title: Democrats silent as Republicans galvanised after Charlie Kirk memorial
articles.trailText: Democrats trod carefully in responding to event attended by nearly 100,000 that blended politics with religion
articles.summary: Nearly 100,000 people filled an Arizona stadium for Charlie Kirk’s memorial that fused Christian revival with a MAGA political rally. Trump, Stephen Miller and other Republicans cast Kirk as a martyr, vowing to defend “the West.” Kirk’s widow, Erika, won praise for forgiving her husband’s killer and will lead Turning Point USA, energizing young conservatives. Democrats remained cautious, fearing any rebuke could be exploited. Pundits on MSNBC argued the event mixed authentic religious grief with campaign-style grievance, underscoring tensions over church–state politics.

articles.title: New Jersey candidates for governor wage heated debate over Trump and political violence
articles.trailText: Mikie Sherrill and Jack Ciattarelli’s face-off reflects tense US political climate over issues including free speech
articles.summary: Mikie Sherrill and Jack Ciattarelli clashed in New Jersey's governor debate, reflecting national tensions over Trump, free speech and political violence. Both backed legislation to treat violence against politicians as hate crimes after Charlie Kirk's killing, but sparred over free-speech consistency and past votes. Sherrill, ahead by eight points, accused Ciattarelli of being a 'Trump poodle' for supporting tariffs and the "big, beautiful bill" driving up costs, while he praised Trump's energy stance and vowed to curb lawsuits. With six weeks until the Nov. 4 election, taxes, energy rates and Trump's influence loom large in this early test before midterms.

articles.title: Family of man killed in New Hampshire shooting says he sacrificed his life
articles.trailText: Robert Steven DeCesare was dining at country club in Nashua and faced the shooter to protect his wife and family
articles.summary: At the Sky Meadow Country Club in Nashua, NH, 59-year-old Robert Steven DeCesare was shot dead Saturday night shielding his wife and daughter during an attack by 23-year-old ex-employee Hunter Nadeau. DeCesare, hailed as a hero by family and club staff, was planning his daughter’s wedding when Nadeau opened fire—wounding two others—before patrons disarmed him. Authorities arrested Nadeau for second-degree murder; no hate motive has been found despite his “Free Palestine” chant.

articles.title: Hiring of military lawyers as immigration judges alarms law experts
articles.trailText: Move is high-risk and potentially unlawful amid Trump’s deportation push since military lawyers lack immigration expertise
articles.summary: The Trump administration is enlisting hundreds of active-duty and reserve Judge Advocate General officers as temporary, renewable immigration judges to expedite mass deportations amid a 3.75m-case backlog while purging experienced trial judges. Experts warn JAGs lack immigration law expertise—often receiving minimal training—and argue the appointments may violate the Posse Comitatus Act and executive rules. Critics see militarization of civilian justice, potential unlawful decisions, and increased appeals. Democratic senators and legal advocates decry risks to due process for asylum seekers and immigrants.

articles.title: Tiger fatally attacks handler at Oklahoma preserve, officials say
articles.trailText: Ryan Easley operated Growler Pines preserve, which called accident ‘painful reminder’ of ‘unpredictability’ of nature
articles.summary: At Growler Pines Tiger Preserve near Hugo, Oklahoma, operator Ryan Easley was fatally mauled by one of his tigers on Saturday, a tragedy officials called a “painful reminder” of nature’s unpredictability. Easley, who sourced big cats for ShowMe Tigers from Joe Exotic and Doc Antle and exhibited them in traveling circuses, deeply loved the animals, viewing them as beings he connected with through daily care. The preserve suspended tours and encounters. PETA’s senior director, Debbie Metzler, condemned captive big cat handling as unsafe and urged exhibitors to send animals to accredited sanctuaries. Joe Exotic, serving 21 years for animal abuse and plotting murder-for-hire, denied involvement beyond briefly hosting Easley’s tigers.

articles.title: Climate activists gather in New York for ‘Sun Day’ solar energy and anti-billionaire rallies
articles.trailText: Sun Day national action supported renewable energy, day after ‘Make Billionaires Pay’ march ahead of Climate Week
articles.summary: Hundreds of activists convened in Stuyvesant Square Park on Sept. 22 for Sun Day, a national action founded by Bill McKibben and Denis Hayes to champion solar and renewables. Press-conference remarks by McKibben, NY Lt. Gov. Antonio Delgado and Sen. Peter Welch preceded solar-panel exhibits and panel discussions. Over 500 satellite actions nationwide ranged from rooftop installations in Virginia to EV showcases in Michigan. The rallies preceded Climate Week and followed a 25,000-strong Make Billionaires Pay march. Despite Trump administration rollbacks on wind and solar, speakers touted renewables’ boom—over 90% of global capacity growth—and new bills to expand renters’ solar access.

articles.title: How the billionaire class and wealthy landlords are conspiring against Zohran Mamdani
articles.trailText: The wealthiest New Yorkers are desperate to rally support – and millions of dollars – for Andrew Cuomo to defeat the democratic socialist
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani, a 33-year-old democratic socialist and frontrunner for New York City mayor, has drawn the ire of billionaires and major landlords by pledging a rent freeze and a 2% tax hike on million-dollar earners. After failing to stop him in the Democratic primary, top real estate donors and at least two billionaires convened with ex-governor Andrew Cuomo to plot a late challenge. Hedge-fund titan Bill Ackman has also mobilized capital and urged Eric Adams to withdraw. Despite millions spent by Michael Bloomberg, Ron Lauder, John Hess and others, recent polls show Mamdani leading Cuomo by double digits.

articles.title: Scams, silence, rejection: US job seekers describe ‘depressing’ work prospects
articles.trailText: Qualified candidates struggle in a sluggish market due to Trump tariffs, AI screening and vanishing entry-level roles
articles.summary: Qualified US workers—from ex-USAID contractors to MBA graduates—report a bleak labor market marked by AI-driven filters, Trump-era tariffs and vanishing entry-level roles. Despite advanced degrees and thousands of applications, job seekers like Philip Kowalski and Taylor Napier see few interviews, rising scam calls and systemic underemployment. BLS revisions show 911,000 fewer jobs added to March 2025, just 22,000 in August and a 4.3% unemployment rate, the highest since 2021. Long-term unemployment has doubled since 2023 and involuntary part-time work is surging, tilting hiring power toward employers and fueling financial anxiety.

articles.title: Donations for Turning Point USA pour in after founder Charlie Kirk’s death
articles.trailText: Fundraising efforts ramp up to open new chapters of influential far-right group as Kirk’s widow takes over as CEO
articles.summary: After Charlie Kirk’s murder, mega-donors including Lynn Friess, Tucker Carlson and Doug Deason have pledged over $1 million to Turning Point USA, maintaining its rapid growth: $85m raised in 2024, 900 college and 1,200 high school chapters. Tax records show major support from Bradley Impact Fund, Donors Trust and Deason Foundation. TPUSA’s political arm spent tens of millions for Trump’s 2024 campaign, and received 54,000 new chapter inquiries. The board appointed Kirk’s widow Erika as CEO per his wish. Experts predict continued fundraising strength fueled by Trump ties, dark‐money vehicles and sanctification of Kirk’s legacy.

articles.title: First Thing: Trump says he ‘hates’ his opponents at Charlie Kirk memorial attended by tens of thousands
articles.trailText: The vice-president JD Vance used his speech to call Kirk a ‘martyr for the Christian faith’. Plus, a behavioral scientist shares how she stays focused
articles.summary: Donald Trump told tens of thousands at a Utah Valley University memorial for conservative activist Charlie Kirk that, unlike Kirk—who he said wanted to “know them and love them”—he “hates” his opponents. Kirk’s widow has publicly forgiven the man charged in her husband’s killing. Vice-President JD Vance honored Kirk as a “martyr for the Christian faith,” a characterization analysts see as a bid to galvanize young believers ahead of 2028. The event capped over two dozen Trump speeches celebrating Kirk’s MAGA influence.

articles.title: Robert Redford’s death renews search for suspect in murder of daughter’s boyfriend
articles.trailText: FBI announces $10,000 reward to find suspect who disappeared after Sid Wells was fatally shot in 1983
articles.summary: Robert Redford’s death has revived efforts to find Thayne Alan Smika, accused in the August 1, 1983, murder of Sid Wells, then-boyfriend of Redford’s daughter Shauna at the University of Colorado Boulder. Smika was arrested but never charged for lack of evidence, vanished in 1986, and faced a DNA-driven arrest warrant in 2010. Redford attended Wells’s funeral, funded family security early on, and personally urged prosecutors to keep the case alive. After Redford died, the FBI offered a $10,000 reward and set Smika’s bail at $5 million in this unsolved cold case.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president calls Charlie Kirk a ‘martyr’ at memorial
articles.trailText: President says ‘I hate my opponents’; Kirk’s widow forgives shooter; Murdochs could be part of TikTok deal – key US politics stories from 21 September at a glance
articles.summary: At Charlie Kirk’s Arizona memorial, Trump hailed the slain activist as a ‘martyr,’ derided opponents—‘I hate my opponents’—and hinted at a White House autism initiative. Sitting beside Musk, he blended eulogy with campaign attacks on Biden. Kirk’s widow, Erika, forgave his shooter. JD Vance teased a 2028 run. The administration will link Tylenol use in pregnancy to autism risk. Trump said Rupert and Lachlan Murdoch may join a TikTok acquisition. Other items: he tapped ex-lawyer Lindsey Halligan as US attorney in Eastern Virginia; detainees at his Angola immigration center began a hunger strike; seven states launched a Northeast health alliance.

articles.title: Vance puts Charlie Kirk’s Christian faith front and center – with an eye on 2028
articles.trailText: Vice-president was in confessional mode as he eulogized his friend in Arizona – but speech could have political utility too
articles.summary: At Charlie Kirk’s Glendale memorial, VP JD Vance delivered an unscripted eulogy spotlighting his Christian faith—invoking Jesus ten times—to galvanize Kirk’s youth and evangelical base ahead of a soft-launched 2028 presidential bid. The 41-year-old ex-Ohio senator, dubbed a “youth whisperer,” chairs RNC finance, mobilizes Turning Point USA supporters and blends Trump’s populist bombast with economic nationalism. His online war-crime tweet against Venezuelan cartel links and public scolding of Zelensky underscore a hard-edged style critics warn could eclipse Trump’s. Leading early GOP primary polls at 46%, Vance positions himself as heir to both MAGA and Kirk.

articles.title: Charlie Kirk memorial: Trump says he ‘hates’ his opponents at event attended by tens of thousands
articles.trailText: President delivers mix of eulogy and campaign speech while JD Vance calls Kirk ‘martyr for the Christian faith’
articles.summary: At a Glendale, Arizona memorial at State Farm Stadium, Trump closed a program honoring slain activist Charlie Kirk by declaring he “hates” his opponents—contrasting Kirk’s last wish to “love” dissenters—while mixing somber eulogies with campaign flair and announcing an autism initiative. Vice-President JD Vance dubbed Kirk “a martyr for the Christian faith,” and Kirk’s widow Erika forgave his accused shooter and urged love for enemies. The MAGA event drew tens of thousands under Super Bowl–level security, merged political rallying with evangelical revival, and intensified debate over political violence, free speech and retribution against Kirk’s critics.

articles.title: Erika Kirk, Charlie Kirk’s widow, says she forgives man accused of murder
articles.trailText: Wife of activist killed in Utah, allegedly by Tyler Robinson, 22, says ‘I forgive him because it was what Christ did’
articles.summary: At State Farm Stadium memorial in Glendale, AZ, Erika Kirk forgave Tyler Robinson, 22, accused of fatally shooting her husband, activist Charlie Kirk at UVU on Sept. 10. Citing Christ’s example, she said she leaves punishment to the state to avoid personal vengeance. Appointed leader of Turning Point USA, she vowed to continue Kirk’s “American Comeback” tour, preaching gospel love even for enemies. The killing, now subject to a possible death-penalty trial, has sparked partisan debate on hate speech and political violence, with prominent conservatives including Donald Trump and JD Vance using the service to criticize their political opponents.

articles.title: Charlie Kirk memorial mixes rally and revival as mourners vow to spread Maga message
articles.trailText: Emotions were raw as service began with Christian worship songs – and ended with a political speech from the president
articles.summary: Tens of thousands gathered at Glendale’s State Farm stadium for a memorial blending Christian worship and a MAGA rally, honoring far-right activist Charlie Kirk as a “prophet.” Kirk, 31, founder of Turning Point USA, was fatally shot by a lone gunman now charged with capital murder. Speakers included widow Erika Kirk, who vowed to lead the movement, Donald Trump, JD Vance and Stephen Miller, mixing personal anecdotes with fierce attacks on the left. Attendees donned red, white and blue, chanted “We are all Charlie Kirk now,” and pledged to carry on his faith-driven conservative movement.

articles.title: US must ‘universally condemn political violence’, Democratic governor Shapiro says
articles.trailText: Pennsylvania’s Josh Shapiro says US stands at ‘inflection point’ after Charlie Kirk killing and urges unity over division
articles.summary: Pennsylvania governor Josh Shapiro told NBC��s Meet the Press Americans must 'universally condemn political violence' after the killing of commentator Charlie Kirk and a York County shoot-out that killed three police officers. Warning of a national 'inflection point', he recounted his mansion’s April firebombing—allegedly by an Israel-war critic—and referenced the June murders of Minnesota House speaker Melissa Hortman and her husband by a suspect previously registered as a Republican. Shapiro distinguished protected speech from incitement, urged unity over division, criticized Benjamin Netanyahu’s Gaza war leadership, defended his 2024 ticket role from Harris memoir claims and declined to confirm a 2028 bid.

articles.title: Trump officials reportedly set to tie Tylenol to autism risk
articles.trailText: Washington Post says announcement imminent despite guidelines showing drug – known as paracetamol elsewhere – is safe for pregnant women to take
articles.summary: Trump administration is set to announce a potential link between prenatal acetaminophen (Tylenol/paracetamol) use and autism, defying guidelines that deem it safe for pregnant women. According to four anonymous sources cited by the Washington Post, health secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr and other officials will also promote investigational leucovorin therapy, based on early trials showing speech and social improvements in autistic children. Previewed by Trump at a Charlie Kirk memorial, the initiative follows federal reviews of Harvard/Mount Sinai studies and highlights internal divisions over communicating unconfirmed environmental risk factors amid claims of an ‘autism epidemic.’

articles.title: Trump drive to pursue critics puts US on path to dictatorship, Democrats warn
articles.trailText: Chuck Schumer and Chris Murphy condemn president’s call for justice department to act against perceived enemies
articles.summary: Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and Sen. Chris Murphy warn that Trump’s public push to use the Justice Department and FCC against perceived enemies—calling for probes of Sen. Adam Schiff and NY AG Letitia James, and prompting ABC to pull Jimmy Kimmel after FCC threats—risks turning the US into a dictatorship or “banana republic.” Hillary Clinton and GOP Rep. Don Bacon also decry what they see as an unprecedented assault on press freedom and rule of law in Trump’s second term.

articles.title: ‘Nothing stops reporters’: Trump talks down Pentagon restrictions on journalists
articles.trailText: DoD previously said journalists would lose passes if they did not sign ‘pledge’ not to release certain information
articles.summary: President Trump criticized Pentagon’s new press restrictions limiting reporters’ access to US military information and movement within the building, insisting “nothing stops reporters.” A memo from the Department of War, led by Pete Hegseth, requires journalists to pledge not to gather unauthorized (even unclassified) info or risk losing press passes, and confines them to designated areas. Hegseth’s measures follow a leak mishap, removal of major outlets’ offices, and have drawn condemnation from the National Press Club and Freedom of the Press Foundation as unconstitutional prior restraint.

articles.title: Trump says Rupert and Lachlan Murdoch likely part of US TikTok deal
articles.trailText: US president tells Fox News ‘a man named Lachlan is involved … that’s a very unusual name, Lachlan Murdoch’
articles.summary: President Trump told Fox News that Rupert and Lachlan Murdoch, along with Larry Ellison and Michael Dell, will likely join the US consortium buying TikTok to comply with a 2024 law barring ByteDance ownership on national security grounds. He suggested Fox Corporation, controlled by the Murdochs, would be among investors, and praised them as American patriots. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said Oracle would oversee data and a US-majority board ensures American control of TikTok’s operations. Trump also referenced legal action against the Wall Street Journal over Epstein-era claims and credited TikTok with boosting his 2024 campaign.

articles.title: Keir Starmer’s Trump card to woo the US president | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Derrick Joad decries the PM’s appeasement of Trump, while Rev Robert Titley sympathises with Starmer. Also letters from Jane Edwards and Michael Fuller
articles.summary: A series of Guardian letters critiques and defends Keir Starmer’s strategy to court Donald Trump during his UK visit. Derrick Joad warns that, by adopting Trump-style xenophobia, racism and ‘tech-bro’ policies, Starmer risks importing MAGA division into British politics. Rev Robert Titley counters that, like Churchill’s deference to Roosevelt, cultivating a powerful US leader is necessary. Jane Edwards urges direct confrontation of political ‘bullies’, while Michael Fuller quips that Carol Ann Duffy’s poetry might have been more fitting at Windsor Castle.

articles.title: Hundreds plunge in Chicago River for first official swim in nearly 100 years
articles.trailText: Group participates in previously unthinkable mile-long swim after US made key progress to clean polluted rivers
articles.summary: Hundreds of swimmers (≈300), from US locals to applicants in 13 countries, plunged into the Chicago River on an overcast Midwest morning for the first organized mile-long loop swim since 1927. Spearheaded by Doug McConnell's A Long Swim and ecologist group Friends of the Chicago River, the event met EPA fecal coliform safety standards. Once so fetid it sparked cholera outbreaks and earned the savage nickname 'bubble creek,' the revived waterway now sustains fish, beavers and public recreation. Olympian Olivia Smoliga competed among vetted participants. This milestone showcases 50 years of river cleanup under the Clean Water Act but flags threats from federal rollbacks to pollution protections.

articles.title: States rally to offset fracturing of federal healthcare agencies: ‘Diseases don’t see state lines’
articles.trailText: Changes to regulatory or information environments will help states decouple from federal health recommendations
articles.summary: Seven Northeastern jurisdictions (CT, ME, MA, NJ, NY state and NYC, PA, RI) and soon Maryland launched the Northeast Public Health Collaborative to synchronize health guidance amid federal agency shifts on COVID and MMRV vaccines. They share scientific review, bulk purchasing and align emergency preparedness, while states decouple rules: empowering pharmacists to vaccinate without prescriptions, mandating insurance coverage for ACIP-recommended shots. A West Coast alliance similarly issued winter Covid, flu and RSV guidance. Experts warn this rapid state-by-state divergence—mirroring abortion policy fractures and amplified by proposals in Florida, Idaho, Texas and West Virginia—could erode trust, deepen access gaps and fuel cross-border outbreaks.

articles.title: Virginia woman donates $150,000 Powerball prize to charity: ‘I needed to give it all away’
articles.trailText: Carrie Edwards, a widow and grandma, gave the money to dementia research, food access and aid for military families
articles.summary: Carrie Edwards, a widow and grandmother from Midlothian, Virginia, won $150,000 on the Sept. 8 Powerball by matching four numbers plus the Powerball and tripling her $50,000 base prize with a $3 ticket. She donated the $150,000 equally to the Association for Frontotemporal Degeneration (honoring her late firefighter husband's early-onset dementia battle), Shalom Farms (distributing 400,000 servings of produce annually to boost food access in Richmond) and the Navy-Marine Corps Relief Society (supporting service members and families). At a lottery news conference Edwards said, "God is blessing me, so I can bless others," hoping to inspire similar generosity.

articles.title: Tiny co-living spaces are popping up across New York. Local communities see them as ‘harbingers of gentrification’
articles.trailText: Such properties are a housing alternative for younger people, but longterm residents worry about being priced out of their homes and losing community
articles.summary: In Crown Heights, Brooklyn, Cohabs transformed the historic Kingston Lounge into 'Crown 120', a 19-bed co-living building with 74–115 sq ft rooms renting at $1,900–2,400/month. Modeled on dorms with shared kitchens, lounges and amenities like gyms and cinemas, Cohabs targets Gen Z and young professionals—many from overseas—offering flexible leases and instant community. Longtime residents and community boards view these hubs as harbingers of gentrification, erasing cultural landmarks, inflating area rents and displacing working-class households. Tenants typically stay just 11 months; critics call for stricter regulation to curb tenant abuse and preserve neighborhood heritage.

articles.title: Trump picks his former lawyer to be top prosecutor, as he pushes Bondi to investigate foes
articles.trailText: Lindsey Halligan appointed as US attorney for the eastern district of Virginia after president demands investigations of his political enemies
articles.summary: President Donald Trump publicly pressured AG Pam Bondi to appoint his former counsel Lindsey Halligan as US attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia, replacing Erik Siebert who resigned after declining to prosecute NY AG Letitia James. Trump, citing alleged unwarranted indictments and impeachments against him, urged swift action on probes into political adversaries including James and ex-FBI Director James Comey. Halligan, a Mar-a-Lago litigation attorney and ex-beauty queen, may serve interim pending Senate confirmation. The move follows Mary “Maggie” Cleary’s abrupt tap and reflects Trump’s push to weaponize federal prosecutions against foes.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: fears president will seize on Kirk’s murder for campaign of vengeance
articles.trailText: Critics worry Donald Trump will use memorial service for Charlie Kirk to turn collective grief into revenge campaign against ‘radical left’ – key US politics stories from 20 September 2025 at a glance
articles.summary: At Charlie Kirk's Arizona memorial, critics warn President Trump may exploit the event to marshal grief into a 'revenge' campaign against the 'radical left,' proposing domestic terrorism designations and tax-exempt revocations without evidence. His allies brand Democrats as extremists even as they condemn Kirk’s killing. Other updates: Trump paused $400m Taiwan weapons aid amid China trade talks; DNI Tulsi Gabbard revoked 37 CIA-related security clearances without White House notice; Trump’s vendetta against late-night hosts like Jimmy Kimmel intensifies; FBI arrests near the stadium, allegations of graft in Homan probe, military press constraints, and California’s face-cover ban for officers.

articles.title: Trump ‘border czar’ Tom Homan reportedly accepted $50,000 in cash from undercover FBI agents
articles.trailText: Alleged handoff occurred before Trump won second presidency, after which administration killed federal corruption case
articles.summary: The FBI secretly filmed former ICE director Tom Homan accepting $50,000 in cash from agents posing as contractors in September 2024—six weeks before the election—after he allegedly promised to secure border-security contracts during a prospective second Trump term. The Biden-led DOJ considered conspiracy, bribery and fraud charges but delayed to observe his performance as Trump’s border czar. Once Trump returned to office, his appointees closed the probe as baseless, calling it a ‘deep state’ attack, while Democrats, led by Sen. Adam Schiff, accused the administration of covering up graft.

articles.title: Oklahoma Republicans propose all state colleges must have Charlie Kirk statue
articles.trailText: Schools would be required to build memorial plaza and describe slain activist as civil rights leader or face fines
articles.summary: Republican lawmakers in Oklahoma introduced a bill requiring every public university to build a Charlie Kirk Memorial Plaza – including a statue and signage labeling the slain conservative activist as a “modern civil rights leader,” faith advocate and martyr – in a prominent campus spot, with designs approved by the legislature. Schools face monthly fines equal to 1% of their budget and must expel students who vandalize the memorial. Sponsored by Freedom Caucus senators Shane Jett and Dana Prieto, it has drawn MLK comparisons from allies like Cardinal Dolan and Russian church figures, and rejection from MLK’s children and campus polls showing 70% student disapproval.

articles.title: Tulsi Gabbard did not alert White House before revoking 37 security clearances
articles.trailText: Exclusive: White House only realized afterwards that clearances at the CIA and in Congress had been rescinded
articles.summary: Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard last month revoked 37 security clearances – including senior CIA deputies to Director John Ratcliffe and aides who worked on sensitive military operations, plus two Democratic congressional staffers – without notifying the White House in advance. The move left the White House blindsided, with officials noting no paper trail of presidential directives. Part of Trump’s broader effort to punish those who allegedly politicized or leaked 2016 Russia intelligence, it fueled frustration among Trump advisers and deepened ODNI-CIA tensions. Gabbard maintains she acted on presidential orders, though officials dispute if the list was shared with key White House offices beforehand.

articles.title: Man armed with gun and knife arrested at Charlie Kirk memorial service venue
articles.trailText: US Secret Service in Phoenix says man said he was law enforcement and there to provide private security
articles.summary: At State Farm Stadium outside Phoenix, 42-year-old Joshua Runkles was arrested Friday for carrying a gun and knife into a prohibited venue and impersonating law enforcement while claiming to provide private security at Charlie Kirk’s memorial service. Released on bond, he faces weapons and impersonation charges. The Secret Service and Arizona DPS are investigating his intent amid heightened SEAR Level 1 security for Sunday’s event featuring speakers like Donald Trump, JD Vance, Marco Rubio and Erika Kirk. Kirk, 31, was fatally shot Sept. 10; suspect Tyler Robinson faces aggravated murder charges.

articles.title: Pentagon demands journalists sign pledge not to gather certain information
articles.trailText: If they don’t agree to limits, including restricting movement within building, Pentagon press passes will be revoked
articles.summary: Pentagon under Trump administration's DoW chief Pete Hegseth ordered journalists to sign a pledge barring them from gathering unauthorized (even unclassified) information and restricting movement to press pens, food court and courtyard, or lose their passes. This builds on May's new limits and follows Hegseth's removal of NYT, CNN, Politico and NPR offices after a data leak. Free-press advocates call it a prior restraint and assault on independent reporting, while NPR vows to push back. The restrictions coincide with Trump's calls to punish 'negative' networks.

articles.title: How Trump is seizing on Charlie Kirk’s killing for a campaign of vengeance
articles.trailText: The Trump administration is trying to harness outrage over the rightwing activist’s killing to crush dissent, experts say
articles.summary: After rightwing activist Charlie Kirk’s 2025 killing, President Trump and top advisers have turned grief into a political weapon: threatening to label leftwing groups as domestic terrorists, revoke nonprofit tax-exempt status, and brand the Democratic Party as extremist. Using unsubstantiated claims of an organised “radical left” plot, administration figures like Stephen Miller and Pam Bondi call for sweeping probes and punishments. Critics warn this playbook mirrors authoritarian regimes, exploiting the tragedy to justify crackdowns on civil liberties, target NGOs like Indivisible, and stifle dissenting speech under the guise of preventing violence.

articles.title: Police arrest man suspected of shooting into a Sacramento ABC news station
articles.trailText: Police say the ABC10 building was occupied when shots were fired into the lobby but ‘no one was injured’
articles.summary: Anibal Hernandez Santana, 64, was arrested after shots were fired into the lobby of Sacramento ABC affiliate KXTV Friday; no injuries were reported. He faces assault with a deadly weapon, shooting into an occupied building and negligent discharge counts, plus an FBI charge for interfering with federally licensed communications after posting bail. Police linked him to a suspect vehicle and arrested him in River Park. Authorities are probing motive—unknown if targeted. The shooting followed protests over Jimmy Kimmel’s suspension; Hernandez’s X account harbored anti-Trump threats and comes amid rising media threats, including a bomb found under a Utah newsroom van last week.

articles.title: ‘The devil is not gonna win’: how Charlie Kirk became a Christian nationalist martyr
articles.trailText: The rightwing pundit’s meteoric career was in some ways a microcosm of the rise of Trump-era Christian nationalism
articles.summary: After Charlie Kirk’s killing, his widow’s rhetoric framed his death as Christian martyrdom, fueling an “accelerationist” narrative. Kirk’s evolution from a secular Tea-Party-era organizer to a Trump-era Christian nationalist paralleled Turning Point USA’s shift from free-market activism to dominionist politics. Turning Point USA, founded in 2012, morphed from a pro-market youth group into a megaphone for charismatic preachers sidelined by the evangelical establishment. Influenced by New Apostolic Reformation theology and the “seven mountains” mandate, he normalized the view that America must be an explicitly Christian nation, fueling a theocratic strain of MAGA conservatism.

articles.title: Four people arrested in Washington after alleged hate crime attack on trans woman
articles.trailText: Three teenagers and one adult arrested in Renton after an alleged attack left a 39-year-old woman hospitalized
articles.summary: Renton police have arrested four suspects, three teen boys (15, 16, 17) and 25-year-old Ramodre Edwards, in a hate crime attack on a 39-year-old transgender woman. Witness video shows the group chasing her near a transit center, hurling homophobic and transphobic slurs before violently punching, kicking and choking her, leaving the victim hospitalized with serious injuries. Two siblings, ages 15 and 17, were apprehended immediately and face assault, strangulation, great bodily harm and hate crime charges; a third teen and Edwards surrendered later. All suspects deny wrongdoing; bail and charging decisions are pending by 23 September.

articles.title: US attorney tasked with inquiring into Trump critics resigns after president says ‘I want him out’
articles.trailText: Erik Siebert leaving after his investigation finds insufficient evidence to charge New York’s attorney general Letitia James with a crime
articles.summary: Erik Siebert, nominated by Trump as US attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia, resigned after his office found insufficient evidence to charge New York AG Letitia James with wrongdoing. Trump, angered that Virginia’s Democratic senators had backed Siebert and urged on by allies like FHFA chief Bill Pulte, publicly demanded Siebert’s removal, later claiming “I fired him.” The probe into James’s alleged misrepresentation of her Virginia residence yielded no criminal basis. Siebert’s exit underscores mounting concerns over DOJ independence amid Trump’s politically charged personnel moves.

articles.title: On the street and in your feed: the joyful genius of Zohran Mamdani’s viral videos
articles.trailText: The frontrunner for New York mayor has won social media with clips that are always fun – and resolutely on-message
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani’s surge as NYC mayor frontrunner owes much to his polished TikTok and Instagram clips that marry slick, hip-hop–scored visuals with a laser focus on affordability and housing. From strolling Manhattan to marathon runs, scavenger hunts and self-aware behind-the-scenes gags, each video underlines how soaring rents and childcare costs are crushing New Yorkers—and calls viewers to action. His energetic, on-the-move style contrasts with staid rivals, driving millions of views, boosting volunteer turnout and cementing his grassroots momentum.

articles.title: Black women are being hit hard by the Trump layoffs and firings: ‘It chips away at morale and self-worth’
articles.trailText: Though they make up just over 6% of the total workforce, Black women account for more than 12% of federal workers
articles.summary: Under Trump’s sweeping cuts to federal grants and contracts, Black women – 6% of the workforce but over 12% of federal employees – have disproportionately borne layoffs, with some 300,000 exiting the labor force in two months. Historically, federal roles offered pensions, benefits and more equitable pay than the private sector. Senior policy analyst Ravon Alford and an account supervisor in DC (“Duke”) describe traumatic job losses, enduring anxiety, disrupted career and personal plans, and six-month unemployment spells. Psychologists warn such instability erodes morale, self-advocacy and psychological safety, driving many from the public sector, undermining identity, long-term planning and mental health.

articles.title: Trump’s reported pause on Taiwan weapons aid sparks fears he is using island for China trade deal
articles.trailText: It comes amid US efforts for deal after punishing trade war and hours before Trump and Xi Jinping spoke on phone
articles.summary: Trump’s reported decision to pause $400m in weapons aid—lethal munitions and autonomous drones—to Taiwan has sparked fears he’s using US support as a bargaining chip in a China trade deal. Announced hours before his call with Xi Jinping, who touted progress on trade, fentanyl and TikTok and planned a Korea summit, the move alarmed arms dealers and analysts. They warn this tactical concession could be exploited by Beijing and solidify a low-support stance, prompting Taiwan to boost defense spending toward 5% of GDP.

articles.title: MSNBC pundit ousted over Kirk talk says network agreed comments were misconstrued
articles.trailText: Matthew Dowd tells Katie Couric ex-employer concurred but ‘it didn’t matter’ and they dismissed him anyway
articles.summary: MSNBC fired senior political analyst Matthew Dowd after he suggested Charlie Kirk’s rhetoric may have fueled the Utah shooting. On Katie Couric’s podcast, Dowd said the network privately agreed his remarks were misconstrued as insensitive but refused to reverse its decision, calling it final. He argues he spoke before Kirk was confirmed as the target and accuses MSNBC of bowing to a right-wing media campaign. In a Substack post, Dowd criticized the network for yielding to a “rightwing media mob” and contrasted his ouster with colleagues’ outrage over ABC suspending Jimmy Kimmel for comments on Kirk’s death.

articles.title: Immigrant rights activists braced for crackdown as Trump threatens to target ‘leftwing’ groups
articles.trailText: Advocates advise staff and volunteers to practice caution but say they will not give up their first amendment rights
articles.summary: Following threats from the Trump administration to criminally prosecute immigrant‐rights nonprofits and activists labelled “leftwing,” groups like ICIRR are advising caution when assisting or filming ICE raids but vow to steadfastly exercise First Amendment rights. Heightened rhetoric from JD Vance and Stephen Miller, plus expanded DHS rules, has led to arrests of lawmakers and protesters in New York, Chicago and LA—some charges dropped after evidence showed false law‐enforcement claims. Drawing on experiences from 2017, organizations (Illinois Coalition, Project South, Texas Civil Rights Project) plan to continue legal aid, rapid‐response monitoring and community organizing despite an “atmosphere of fear.”

articles.title: Media giants accused of ‘cowering to threats’ as Trump tries to stamp out criticism
articles.trailText: Disney’s Bob Iger and Paramount’s David Ellison are among executives pulling the strings amid criticism that US TV networks are caving to the Trump administration
articles.summary: US TV networks ABC (Disney’s Bob Iger), CBS (Paramount Skydance’s David Ellison) and NBC (Comcast’s Brian Roberts) have faced mounting pressure from the Trump administration and FCC chair Brendan Carr—referred to as a “censor-in-chief”—to silence late-night critics. After ABC paid a $15m settlement and suspended Jimmy Kimmel’s show, and CBS shelled out $16m and axed Stephen Colbert, executives have been accused of prioritizing merger approvals over First Amendment protections. Civil liberties advocates warn this business-driven compliance of “cowering” undermines free speech amid ongoing corporate-regulatory battles.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president hikes H-1B visa cost to $100,000 a year as aide tells firms to ‘train Americans’
articles.trailText: Decision could be major blow to tech industry, but commerce secretary says ‘all of the big companies are on board’
articles.summary: President Trump signs an order raising H-1B visa fees to $100,000 annually, with Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick urging firms to “train Americans,” claiming tech giants back the hike. Trump also says he and Xi Jinping agreed on a preliminary TikTok deal, though details remain vague. A Florida judge dismisses Trump’s $15 billion defamation suit against the New York Times. Democrats block a short-term spending bill over healthcare cuts, risking a shutdown. Separately, the Virginia US attorney resigns after declining charges against AG Letitia James; the House honors Charlie Kirk in a contentious resolution; Sen. Ted Cruz likens FCC license threats to mob tactics; the president announces a lethal Caribbean anti-drug strike; and the administration appeals to the Supreme Court over passport gender-marker rules.

articles.title: Ted Cruz compares threats to ABC by FCC chair to those of mob boss
articles.trailText: Texas senator says Brendan Carr’s threats to revoke licenses amid Jimmy Kimmel suspension ‘right out of Goodfellas’
articles.summary: Ted Cruz likened FCC chair Brendan Carr’s warning to revoke ABC stations’ licenses over Jimmy Kimmel’s suspended show to ‘Goodfellas’-style mob threats, praising Kimmel’s firing but warning of First Amendment dangers if regulators police content—an approach he says could backfire on conservatives under a future Democratic administration. At the Oval Office, Trump disagreed with Cruz, calling Carr a ‘patriot’ combating alleged illegal liberal media bias, referencing NewsBusters’ analysis, and alleging networks gave him lopsided negative coverage.

articles.title: Trump announces new deadly strike on suspected drug boat in Caribbean
articles.trailText: President says US military carried out strike ‘on my orders’, killing three men he said were carrying illegal narcotics
articles.summary: On Sep 19, 2025, President Trump announced on social media that, “on my orders,” US forces under USSOUTHCOM jurisdiction carried out a lethal strike on a Caribbean vessel, killing three men he claimed were smuggling illicit narcotics for a designated terrorist organization. The White House and Defense Secretary shared video of the fiery aftermath. Trump said intelligence confirmed the boat was en route to poison Americans, but he offered no legal justification for this extrajudicial action. More details are forthcoming.

articles.title: Trump signs proclamation imposing annual $100,000 fee on H-1B visas
articles.trailText: Move deals potentially major blow to US tech industry, which relies heavily on workers from India and China
articles.summary: President Donald Trump signed a proclamation imposing a $100,000 annual fee on H-1B visas, prompting concern in the US tech sector reliant on Indian and Chinese workers. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, alongside Trump, said the levy aims to ‘train Americans’ by steering employers toward domestic graduates. Critics and immigration experts dispute the president’s authority to set such fees, warning of higher costs for startups and reduced competitiveness, while supporters like Elon Musk argue H-1Bs are essential for filling critical high-skill roles.

articles.title: Federal agents use teargas and pepper balls to break up Chicago Ice protest
articles.trailText: At least two protesters arrested as Democratic congressional candidate condemns ‘violent abuse of power’
articles.summary: Federal agents in riot gear fired pepper balls and teargas to disperse about 100 protesters, including Democratic candidates Kat Abughazaleh and Bushra Amiwala, outside ICE's Broadview Chicago facility during Operation Midway Blitz, arresting at least three. Abughazaleh and Lt. Gov. Juliana Stratton condemned what they called "violent abuse of power" as they sat cross-armed blocking SUVs. DHS reposted video accusing protesters of aiding criminals. Demonstrators chanted for Silverio Villegas González, shot dead by an ICE officer. The clashes underscore Trump's intensified immigration crackdown, which has netted nearly 550 arrests in Chicago.

articles.title: RFK Jr’s vaccine panel votes against recommending prescription for Covid vaccine, emphasizing personal choice
articles.trailText: After heated meeting, healthcare professionals and experts left deeply confused about committee’s recommendations
articles.summary: At its contentious September 19 meeting, the CDC’s Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) tied 6–6 on recommending a prescription requirement for Covid-19 vaccines; chair Martin Kulldorff cast the deciding vote against it. Instead, ACIP endorsed clinician consultation, “shared clinical decision making” and enhanced informed-consent processes amid sharp divisions and heated outbursts among members largely appointed by RFK Jr. Skepticism and procedural confusion now complicate vaccine access, insurance coverage and state mandates under his HHS tenure.

articles.title: Brett James, Grammy-winning songwriter, dies in plane crash
articles.trailText: James’ wife and stepdaughter were also killed when the Cirrus SR22T crashed in Franklin, North Carolina
articles.summary: Brett James, 57, a Grammy-winning songwriter known for Carrie Underwood’s “Jesus, Take the Wheel,” died with his wife, Melody Carole, and stepdaughter, Meryl Maxwell Wilson, when their Cirrus SR22T crashed under unknown circumstances in a wooded area near Franklin, North Carolina. The plane had departed Nashville’s John C. Tune Airport; the NTSB is investigating. Inducted into the Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame in 2020, James wrote over 500 songs recorded by artists including Faith Hill, Luke Bryan, Keith Urban, Kelly Clarkson, Meghan Trainor and Nick Jonas. Carrie Underwood and Jason Aldean publicly mourned his passing.

articles.title: Democrats reject spending bill over healthcare cuts as shutdown looms
articles.trailText: Senate blocks funding bill passed by House on near party-line vote with Jeffries saying ‘We don’t work for Trump’
articles.summary: Facing a looming shutdown, Senate Democrats blocked a GOP House–approved continuing resolution extending funding to Nov. 21 because it offered no protections for Medicaid or expiring ACA subsidies. Democrats countered with a shorter extension to October that safeguards healthcare programs, but Republicans dismissed it as “fundamentally unserious.” Only three House Democrats and one senator backed the GOP bill. Leaders Chuck Schumer and Hakeem Jeffries insist they’ll hold the line to defend healthcare, while Congress breaks for Rosh Hashanah with no resolution in sight.

articles.title: Louisiana reports five deaths from flesh-eating bacterium in coastal waters
articles.trailText: Officials say deaths from Vibrio vulnificus exceeding average amid warning over climate-linked case increase
articles.summary: Louisiana’s health department reports five deaths among 26 Vibrio vulnificus infections in 2025, far above the decade’s average of one fatality from about ten annual cases. The flesh-eating bacterium, thriving in warmer Gulf waters between May and October, infected 85% of patients via seawater-exposed wounds and 92% had underlying health conditions. Researchers link rising cases to climate-driven sea surface temperature increases. Vibrio infections carry a 20% mortality rate and can require limb amputation. The US reports 150–200 cases yearly, half in Gulf states, with Louisiana and Florida hardest hit. Officials urge public education on wound care and seafood safety.

articles.title: Man arrested by Ice dies in jail cell in Long Island, New York
articles.trailText: Officials in Nassau county confirmed death of 42-year-old man to Newsday but declined to share details
articles.summary: Authorities found a 42-year-old ICE detainee unresponsive in his East Meadow cell at Nassau County Correctional Center on Sept. 19; he became the first ICE death in Nassau custody since the county began housing over 1,400 federal detainees in February under a 50-cell partnership. Sheriff Anthony LaRocco announced a transparent probe, while NY Attorney General Letitia James’s office launched a preliminary review. So far in fiscal 2025, ICE records show 14 in-custody deaths among nearly 58,800 detainees nationwide through Sept. 7. Nassau officials say they are reimbursed $195 per person nightly; statewide immigrant bookings in county jails have sextupled compared with 2024.

articles.title: US appeals court orders deportation of Atlanta journalist detained by Ice
articles.trailText: Mario Guevara faces imminent removal from US as his attorney files emergency petition
articles.summary: An immigration appeals court has closed the case of Atlanta journalist Mario Guevara, ordering his immediate deportation despite an earlier bond release granted by an immigration judge. ACLU lawyers filed an emergency petition to block ICE’s removal, arguing Guevara—an El Salvador native held over three months at the Folkston detention center—faces retaliation for his immigration reporting. Arrested and stripped of unrelated local protest and traffic charges, he holds a work permit, has a pending green-card application and had his asylum claim administratively closed after a 2012 denial. A habeas corpus appeal is pending in federal court.

articles.title: Judge strikes down Trump’s $15bn lawsuit against the New York Times
articles.trailText: Judge gives US president 28 days to refile action after saying original filing is full of ‘vituperation and invective’
articles.summary: US District Judge Steven Merryday in Florida dismissed Donald Trump’s $15 billion defamation suit against the New York Times, Penguin and reporters Susanne Craig and Russ Buettner, finding the 85-page filing full of vituperation and invective and violative of Federal Rule 8(a) for lacking a short, plain statement of claim. He noted the pleadings were cluttered with superfluous praise and detailed evidentiary matter, and said the order did not address the allegations’ merits. Trump has 28 days to refile. His suit accused the Times of acting as a Democratic mouthpiece by falsely depicting his role on The Apprentice, inheritance via tax schemes, real-estate valuations, mafia links and money-laundering; the Times called it meritless intimidation.

articles.title: Body found in Tesla reportedly owned by singer d4vd that of missing teenager
articles.trailText: Celeste Rivas, 15, identified by Los Angeles officials after body discovered inside vehicle in Hollywood tow lot
articles.summary: Los Angeles officials identified a decomposed body found Sept. 8 inside an impounded black Tesla registered to singer David “d4vd” Anthony Burke as Celeste Rivas, 15, missing since April 2024 from Lake Elsinore. The LAPD is treating her death as a homicide, though the exact cause remains undetermined. The vehicle, towed from the upscale Bird Streets area in Hollywood Hills after being abandoned, emitted a foul odor that led to discovery. Authorities executed a search warrant at Burke’s Hollywood Hills residence; he’s cooperating, denies involvement, and has not been implicated. He subsequently canceled the rest of his U.S. tour.

articles.title: US House passes resolution to honor Charlie Kirk in vote that divided Democrats
articles.trailText: Several Democrats who opposed the measure said they condemned Kirk’s murder, but could not support his speech
articles.summary: In a bipartisan vote, the US House passed a GOP resolution introduced by Speaker Mike Johnson honoring slain conservative activist Charlie Kirk as a “courageous American patriot.” Ninety-five Democrats supported it, 58 opposed, 38 voted present and 22 did not vote. Opponents including AOC and Diana DeGette decried its omission of Kirk’s divisive Christian nationalist and anti–Civil Rights rhetoric; proponents like Jamie Raskin argued its clear condemnation of political violence justified support. The clash underscores deep polarization, amplified by FCC Chair Brendan Carr’s pressure on ABC to suspend Jimmy Kimmel, prompting Democratic calls for his resignation.

articles.title: Texas A&M University president resigns after ‘gender ideology’ controversy
articles.trailText: Mark A Welsh III steps down after student’s complaint led to firing of teacher and dismissal of dean and department head
articles.summary: Texas A&M president Mark A. Welsh III resigned less than two weeks after a student's viral complaint over "gender ideology" courses triggered the firing of an instructor and removal of a dean and department chair. A retired four-star Air Force general who led Texas A&M since 2022, Welsh offered only timing as his rationale. Chancellor Glenn Hegar and GOP Rep. Brian Harrison supported the departure. His resignation, effective Friday, caps a dispute against DEI and LGBTQ+ content in Texas higher education.

articles.title: Trump cuts threaten futures of 250,000 children of migrant farm workers: ‘We felt like crying’
articles.trailText: The Migrant Education Program opened doors for the kids of seasonal farm laborers. The Trump administration wants to axe all its funding
articles.summary: Trump’s 2026 budget would eliminate the 60-year-old Migrant Education Program (MEP), threatening support for more than 250,000 children of seasonal farm workers—including 80,000 in California. MEP provides after-school tutoring, summer enrichment, speech and debate, meals, mentoring and parent education, stabilizing disrupted schooling tied to harvest cycles. Alumni like UC San Diego freshman Regina Zarate-Garcia and Monterey County’s migrant education director credit MEP with enabling college and leadership success. The proposal follows a summer freeze of nearly $7 billion in education funds and, if enacted, could drive higher dropout rates and limit college access.

articles.title: Josh Shapiro and Pete Buttigieg respond to revelations in Kamala Harris’s book
articles.trailText: Harris’s memoir, 107 Days, includes thoughts about Pennsylvania governor and ex-transport secretary as potential running mates
articles.summary: Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro, a potential 2028 White House contender, says Kamala Harris must explain why she didn’t publicly flag President Biden’s fitness to serve after reading her memoir 107 Days. He, who narrowly lost the 2024 VP slot to Gov. Tim Walz, says he raised concerns privately but stayed silent publicly. Harris recounts hesitating to confront Biden, fearing disloyalty, and recalls pre-vetting Shapiro’s VP logistics. She also names Pete Buttigieg “ideal” had she been straight white, deeming a woman-gay ticket “too risky.” Buttigieg, surprised, argues voters focus on policy over identity.

articles.title: Trump mega-donor privately mocked his claim to have upper hand with China
articles.trailText: Liz Uihlein sent staff email with cartoon of Trump saying ‘I hold the cards’ to which Xi says ‘the cards are made in China’
articles.summary: Uline co-founder Liz Uihlein, one of Trump’s biggest backers ($143m to GOP candidates), privately sent staff a cartoon mocking his claim to hold the upper hand in China talks—Xi Jinping quips “the cards are made in China.” The April email highlights unease among major donors whose businesses rely on Chinese imports. It follows Uihlein’s prior public calls for a coherent US trade strategy and mirrors broader Republican donor skepticism of Trump’s tariff approach, even as he and Xi prepare another high-stakes call amid suspended duties.

articles.title: New York lawmakers arrested for blocking Ice access to federal building
articles.trailText: Arrests include 11 city officials who had demanded to see the conditions of an Ice intake facility on the 10th floor
articles.summary: On Sept. 18 in Manhattan, 70 demonstrators – including immigrants' rights activists, religious leaders and 11 elected officials (e.g., Comptroller Brad Lander, Public Advocate Jumaane Williams, Council member Tiffany Cabán) – blocked ICE's underground garage at 26 Federal Plaza and demanded to inspect its 10th-floor intake facility. NYPD and federal officers arrested protesters - using zip ties and duct tape - and charged officials with federal misdemeanors. Organizers decried "cruel" ICE detentions, called for abolishing the agency and passing the "New York For All" sanctuary bill. DHS labeled the action a stunt endangering personnel and detainees.

articles.title: Dozens of workers penalized after Charlie Kirk shooting, from journalists to Jimmy Kimmel
articles.trailText: Employers and officials are cracking down on comments considered ‘inappropriate’ after far-right activist was killed
articles.summary: After the murder of far-right activist Charlie Kirk at Utah Valley University on Sept. 10, dozens of US workers—from federal agents and TV hosts to academics, airline pilots, teachers and healthcare staff—have been fired, suspended or placed on leave for social media posts deemed to celebrate or mock his death. Trump-era officials and conservative activists urged employers to punish “insensitive” remarks, prompting actions by the Secret Service, FEMA, Jimmy Kimmel’s show, MSNBC, universities, airlines and others. Civil-liberties groups warn this crackdown risks chilling free speech and infringing First Amendment rights.

articles.title: Republicans try to gut protections against US military’s Pfas pollution
articles.trailText: If approved as proposed, legislation would delay ban on toxic ‘forever chemical’-laden firefighting foam
articles.summary: Republicans in the House and Senate NDAA propose measures to indefinitely delay next-year ban on PFAS-containing firefighting foam, cut cleanup funding by $200 m, lift a moratorium on incineration, and repeal bans on PFAS in military consumer goods. Despite five years of PFAS restrictions, closed-door amendments passed 14–13 along party lines. Critics warn the actions push the 2024 phase-out to 2028, worsen contamination at 630 bases polluting water, and expose service members to bioaccumulative “forever chemicals” linked to cancer, kidney and immune disorders. Amendments to preserve foam and PFAS-free procurement face GOP pushback citing consumer consistency.

articles.title: Revealed: US law enforcement claimed emojis could signal Tren de Aragua affiliation
articles.trailText: Claims are ‘an unsophisticated, uneducated approach that demonstrates a lack of knowledge’, says one professor
articles.summary: In internal 2024-25 briefings obtained by Property of the People and reviewed by the Guardian, the FBI, CBP, Army North and NYPD flagged emojis—trains, swords, ninjas, alien faces, strawberries and hand gestures—as secret codes signaling affiliation with Tren de Aragua, a Venezuelan gang President Trump cited to justify immigration and military actions. Scholars and attorneys call these warnings “unsophisticated,” “uneducated” and “baseless,” warn they could trigger false positives, wrongful detentions and deportations, and argue there’s no evidence the decentralized gang uses such iconography.

articles.title: A US neo-Nazi fight club is using Charlie Kirk’s killing to recruit new members
articles.trailText: ‘Active clubs’ are capitalizing on assassination of far-right commentator to entice recruits with promises of vengeance
articles.summary: US-based “active clubs”—neo-Nazi MMA groups led by Rob Rundo—are exploiting Charlie Kirk’s assassination to recruit white men with promises of vengeance, racist camaraderie and anti-left narratives. Training in local gyms and parks, these loose cells tout violence in Telegram posts, paint Kirk’s killing as proof of “anti-White” oppression, and even marched alongside Patriot Front at a Huntington Beach vigil. Authorities deem them a top domestic terror threat; chapters now span 27 countries. They’ve also launched youth wings modeled on the Hitler Youth.

articles.title: ‘Angry and disappointed’: Kamala Harris critical of Joe Biden in new book
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Democratic candidate lays bare tensions with then president during 2024 election campaign
articles.summary: In her memoir 107 Days, Kamala Harris recounts feeling “angry and disappointed” when President Biden urged her—hours before her high-stakes debate with Trump—to worry that his brother��s Philadelphia power brokers were withholding support. She criticizes Biden’s self-focus on past debate stumbles, his faltering debate prep, and his muted leadership on Roe v. Wade’s overturn. Harris describes growing campaign tensions: being sidelined, the zero-sum view that her success dimmed his, and advisers urging her to distance from an embattled Biden, who ultimately withdrew and endorsed her. She also rebuffs Trump’s racist jabs about her heritage.

articles.title: DC Democrat challenges long-serving House delegate amid age concerns
articles.trailText: Council member Robert White says ‘we need our strongest fighters’ as he bids to take on Eleanor Holmes Norton, 88
articles.summary: Robert White, an at-large DC council member, announced he will challenge 88-year-old Eleanor Holmes Norton in next year’s race for DC’s non-voting House delegate, citing the need for “strongest fighters” as the city faces federal intervention. Trump ordered a temporary takeover of the DC police, deploying National Guard and federal agents amid disputed crime claims, while House Republicans advance “tough on crime” bills. Former Norton aide Donna Brazile urged her to forgo a 19th term, questioning her energy. At a recent hearing, city leaders decried federal overreach, and Norton pressed for DC statehood.

articles.title: First Thing: Fellow hosts decry Kimmel suspension as ‘blatant assault on freedom of speech’
articles.trailText: Protesters gather outside Disney HQ after decision to indefinitely suspend the popular show. Plus, California records highest national poverty rate alongside Louisiana
articles.summary: Jimmy Kimmel's indefinite suspension by ABC over his comments on Charlie Kirk has prompted late-night peers—Stephen Colbert, Jon Stewart, Seth Meyers, Jimmy Fallon and David Letterman—to decry the move as a blatant assault on freedom of speech, fueling protests outside Disney HQ and boycott calls. Donald Trump cheered the decision, warning networks critical of him could face government punishment. Also: Trump’s UK visit and Putin clash; White House bid to oust Fed governor Lisa Cook; mass strikes in France; California’s 17.7% poverty rate; a long-hidden Picasso reveal; Sunday’s Sun Day climate rally; and an underwater living experiment.

articles.title: Hundreds protest outside Disney HQ over ‘un-American’ Kimmel suspension
articles.trailText: Demonstrators condemn CEO Bob Iger and fellow executives for ‘bending the knee’ to Trump administration
articles.summary: About 200–300 protesters, spurred by the Writers Guild of America, rallied outside Disney’s Burbank headquarters to demand the reinstatement of Jimmy Kimmel Live! after Disney and ABC, led by CEO Bob Iger, suspended the show under pressure from FCC chair Brendan Carr and the Trump administration. Carrying signs decrying “corporate cowardice” and chanting ���un-American,” participants framed the suspension as a blatant attack on free speech. Parallel demonstrations in New York and Hollywood echoed WGA demands to keep up pressure on Disney until Kimmel returns, decrying this as authoritarian censorship.

articles.title: Trump suggests punishing TV networks for ‘negative’ coverage amid outrage over Kimmel suspension
articles.trailText: President says Jimmy Kimmel was ‘not a talented person’ as critics decry show’s suspension as an attack on free speech
articles.summary: On Air Force One returning from the UK, Trump praised ABC’s suspension of Jimmy Kimmel, calling the host “not talented” with poor ratings, and floated revoking network licenses over “97% negative” coverage—an unfounded claim given US networks aren’t FCC-licensed. Kimmel’s indefinite suspension for remarks on Charlie Kirk sparked protests outside Disney, boycotts, and union solidarity from WGA members and Hollywood figures like Letterman and Lindelof. Barack Obama condemned the threats as “dangerous,” while FCC chair Brendan Carr and GOP allies eyed regulatory action. Democrats decried an assault on free speech and plan subpoenas and anti-censorship legislation.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: president threatens other TV networks amid Jimmy Kimmel fallout
articles.trailText: Donald Trump suggests networks that carry critical coverage should lose licenses, amid calls for boycott of ABC owner Disney – key US politics stories from 18 September 2025
articles.summary: President Trump threatened to revoke TV network licenses for ‘negative’ coverage after ABC suspended Jimmy Kimmel, citing an unsubstantiated “97% against me” figure. He misrepresented FCC rules, which license only local stations, not national networks. His comments sparked calls to boycott Disney. Former President Obama denounced the threats as a “dangerous” free-speech assault, and FCC Commissioner Anna Gomez blasted ABC’s “shameful” capitulation. Other headlines: Kamala Harris’s VP pick regrets revealed in her memoir; Trump asks the Supreme Court to allow firing Fed governor Lisa Cook; he criticized Putin alongside UK’s Keir Starmer; Erika Kirk named Turning Point USA CEO; and legal updates on tariffs and protests.

articles.title: Alleged gunman in Pennsylvania officer shootout had been sought for stalking
articles.trailText: Matthew James Ruth, 24, killed in altercation that left three officers dead and wounded two more
articles.summary: Matthew James Ruth, 24, shot dead three detectives and wounded two officers in rural York County, Pennsylvania, while executing a domestic violence warrant at his ex-girlfriend’s home. Ruth, already charged with stalking, trespassing and prowling after allegedly loitering outside her residence and burning her truck, opened fire with an AR-15-style rifle as officers entered an unlocked door. The slain detectives—Det Sgt Cody Becker, Det Mark Baker and Det Isaiah Emenheiser—led the regional force. Authorities and Gov. Josh Shapiro decried gun violence; the two injured officers are in stable condition.

articles.title: Trump tells Britain to ‘call out the military’ to control its borders
articles.trailText: US president ends second state visit with warning that illegal migration could destroy the UK
articles.summary: During his second UK state visit hosted by King Charles, President Trump urged PM Keir Starmer to 'call out the military' to stop illegal migration after the first Channel migrant deportation under Starmer's 'one in, one out' scheme. He downplayed disagreements over London's plan to recognize Palestine—set for Friday—praised North Sea oil, scoffed at wind power, and surprised officials by saying he wants to retake Afghanistan's Bagram base to counter China. Trump also criticized Vladimir Putin, backed US pressure on Russian oil, and championed a £150bn US investment pledge alongside a new US-UK tech pact featuring Nvidia's £2bn AI commitment.

articles.title: CDC panel recommends multiple shots for measles, mumps, rubella and chickenpox instead of single vaccine
articles.trailText: Experts react with concern that increasing the number of vaccinations required will threaten children’s health
articles.summary: CDC ACIP voted to switch from the combined MMRV shot to separate MMR and varicella vaccines, citing a slightly lower febrile seizure risk but acknowledging that split dosing may reduce compliance. The change won’t affect which vaccines are free under the Vaccines for Children program, causing confusion among panel members. The meeting, reshaped by HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s appointees, drew criticism for limited vaccine expertise and low stakeholder participation. Experts noted combination vaccines improve completion rates and that measles, mumps, rubella and chickenpox caused thousands of hospitalizations annually. Public support for MMR school mandates stands at 70%, up from 63% in 2023.

articles.title: Calls grow to boycott ABC owner Disney over Jimmy Kimmel suspension
