articles.trailText: Critics say ‘authoritarianism isn’t coming – it’s already here’ amid widespread condemnation of talkshow’s suspension
articles.summary: After FCC chair Brendan Carr, appointed by Trump, complained about Jimmy Kimmel’s monologue on the killing of conservative activist Charlie Kirk, ABC indefinitely suspended Kimmel’s late-night show. Major station owners Nexstar and Sinclair also pulled episodes, citing objections and pressure while seeking FCC approvals. Labor and free speech groups, including the Working Families Party and 50501, launched viral guides urging a boycott of Disney-ABC, Nexstar and Sinclair, framing the suspension as state-sanctioned censorship. Activists rallied on social media under #BoycottDisney. Critics warn this sets an authoritarian precedent. Trump celebrated the cancellation on social media. House Democrats and PEN America condemned ABC’s decision, demanding FCC chair Carr’s resignation.

articles.title: ‘Censor-in-chief’: Trump-backed FCC chair at heart of Jimmy Kimmel storm
articles.trailText: Brendan Carr says he supports free speech – but has gone after broadcasters he deems are not operating in the ‘public interest’
articles.summary: Brendan Carr, the Trump-appointed FCC chair and self-styled free-speech advocate, has used the agency’s vague “public interest” mandate to target broadcasters he deems disloyal. After ABC indefinitely suspended Jimmy Kimmel over his remarks about the accused killer of Charlie Kirk, Carr publicly threatened investigations and license revocations, leveraging his informal chairman’s power to extract concessions. He’s pressured networks on diversity policies and mergers, prompting CBS affiliate Nexstar to pre-emptively pull Kimmel’s show. Democratic commissioners, led by Anna Gomez, have condemned his actions as government overreach and called for his resignation, warning he’s become a de facto “censor-in-chief.”

articles.title: Jury finds LA protester not guilty of assaulting border patrol agent
articles.trailText: Brayan Ramos-Brito acquitted after US immigration officials were accused in court of lying about the incident
articles.summary: Brayan Ramos-Brito, 29, was acquitted of misdemeanor assault on a Border Patrol agent during a June protest in Paramount, Los Angeles, after witness video showed an officer forcefully shoving him and no clear footage of any attack. Jurors reached the not-guilty verdict in just over an hour, exposing discrepancies in DHS reports and undermining Chief Gregory Bovino’s credibility amid cross-examination over past misconduct. The outcome is a significant setback for U.S. Attorney Bill Essayli’s office and highlights the challenges of prosecuting immigration protesters without definitive video evidence or reliable law-enforcement testimony.

articles.title: Starmer has avoided state-visit bear traps but has he changed any of Trump’s thinking?
articles.trailText: PM cannot afford for US president to walk away from Ukraine crisis and must persuade him to publicly support specific Gaza plans
articles.summary: During Trump’s second UK state visit, Starmer steered clear of public missteps and emphasized shared defence, trade and tech ties. Privately, he pressed Trump to reconsider support for Ukraine sanctions and endorse specific Gaza proposals—stopping civilian casualties, backing a Hamas-free interim government and Kushner-Blair reconstruction plan. At the press conference Trump resisted recognition of a Palestinian state and insisted on full hostage releases. He showed cautious alignment on pressing Putin by cutting Russian oil imports, offering Starmer a basis to push Europe’s accelerated sanctions.

articles.title: Judges rule against Trump administration on deporting Guatemalan children and Venezuelans
articles.trailText: Double defeat protects Venezuelans with temporary protected status and Guatemalan minors
articles.summary: Two federal courts rebuffed Trump administration efforts to deport Guatemalan unaccompanied minors and terminate temporary protected status (TPS) for Venezuelans. In DC, Judge Timothy Kelly, a Trump appointee, barred removal of 76 Guatemalan children taken from shelters in pre-dawn raids on August 31, after DOJ’s claim that parents sought their return collapsed under a Guatemalan govt report. Meanwhile, the Ninth Circuit refused to stay a decision restoring TPS for about 600,000 Venezuelans, warning of family separations, job losses and wrongful removals.

articles.title: Putin, Gaza, tariffs and Mandelson: key details from Trump-Starmer press conference
articles.trailText: The two leaders skirted around areas of potential conflict but there was still plenty of news and startling information
articles.summary: At Chequers, Trump and Starmer held a disciplined, hour-long press conference covering Ukraine, Gaza, trade, tech and defence. Trump blamed Putin for invading Ukraine but declined new sanctions, praised tariffs and vowed to try reclaiming Bagram airbase. Starmer neatly avoided Gaza civilian suffering, calling Hamas anti-two-state, defended the Online Safety Act's curb on harmful content, and highlighted Britain's commitment to 5% GDP defence spending. They noted stalled tariff cuts on UK exports, and Trump claimed not to recall Peter Mandelson while Starmer mentioned his baptism as a nod to Britain's Christian heritage.

articles.title: Trump turns fire on Putin and lauds UK in press conference with Starmer
articles.trailText: US president also advises PM to use military to stop irregular migration at conclusion of his second state visit
articles.summary: At a joint press conference in London ending his state visit, President Trump slammed Vladimir Putin for derailing a potential Russia-Ukraine truce, accusing him of high Russian casualties and saying 'he’s let me down.' He praised PM Keir Starmer, King Charles, Queen Camilla and the 'magnificent isles,' endorsed military action to curb irregular UK migration and slammed wind power as an 'expensive joke.' He disagreed briefly with Starmer over Palestinian statehood, resisted extra Russia sanctions, argued lower oil prices could force Putin's withdrawal, and critiqued Joe Biden and Jimmy Kimmel.

articles.title: Members of Congress condemn Kristi Noem over fate of migrant ‘Dreamers’
articles.trailText: Letter signed by 78 demands to know how many people protected under Daca have been arrested or deported
articles.summary: 95 members of Congress, led by Reps. Delia Ramirez and Sylvia Garcia, sent a letter to Homeland Security Sec. Kristi Noem and acting ICE director Todd Lyons condemning recent wrongful detentions and deportations of DACA recipients under Trump’s second term. They demand data on arrests, deportations and legal authority. The letter cites eight cases—including a deaf carwash worker in California, organizer Catalina “Xochitl” Santiago in Texas and a detainee sent to Florida’s “Alligator Alcatraz”—and warns of due-process violations. Signatories range from AOC to Ilhan Omar. They urge co-sponsorship of the American Dream and Promise Act 2025.

articles.title: US seeking to regain control of Afghanistan’s Bagram airbase, says Trump
articles.trailText: US president suggests he is negotiating with Taliban for American forces to once again occupy base
articles.summary: During a Chequers press conference, Trump announced negotiations with the Taliban to regain Bagram airbase, the former largest US installation in Afghanistan surrendered during the 2021 withdrawal. He emphasised its 11,800-ft heavy-concrete runway and proximity—one hour—to China’s nuclear missile facilities. He blamed Biden for abandoning US assets, alarmed allies over US-China tensions. Taliban spokesperson Zabihullah Mujahid denies Chinese occupation and signals interest in US engagement. Trump also criticised Putin for failing to swiftly end the Ukraine war despite their past rapport.

articles.title: US supreme court sets date to hear arguments on Trump’s tariffs
articles.trailText: Hearing on 5 November sets up major test of the president’s use of executive power to drive his economic agenda
articles.summary: On November 5, 2025 the US Supreme Court will hear oral arguments on the legality of President Trump’s global tariffs imposed under the 1977 International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). A federal appeals court ruled the president exceeded his authority by using an emergency statute— which makes no mention of tariffs— to levy steep duties on imports, following challenges from small businesses and toy maker Learning Resources. If upheld, average US effective tariffs could drop from 16.3% by half and trigger repayment of tens of billions collected. The fast‐tracked case, set before the court’s nine-month term, tests the limits of executive power in trade policy after 18 consecutive emergency relief approvals.

articles.title: Trump v Kimmel: simmering feud ends with comedian’s talkshow yanked off air
articles.trailText: Comedian, whose show was pulled after Charlie Kirk comment, has long been a thorn in president’s side
articles.summary: After ABC abruptly pulled Jimmy Kimmel’s late-night talk show over his claim that conservatives were politicising Charlie Kirk’s killing, President Donald Trump celebrated the cancellation as “great news for America,” branding Kimmel “ZERO talent” with ratings “worse even than Colbert.” Their long-running feud dates to 2015—Trump has skipped and mocked Kimmel appearances, while the host has repeatedly criticised his health-care repeal, national alert plan and inaction on gun violence. Kimmel shot back at the Oscars and in recent monologues, and Trump now targets NBC’s Jimmy Fallon and Seth Meyers.

articles.title: Kamala Harris tells of dismay as Tim Walz ‘fumbled’ debate answer in book
articles.trailText: Democratic 2024 presidential nominee’s memoir also reveals Minnesota governor was not first choice as running mate
articles.summary: In her memoir 107 Days, Kamala Harris recounts her mortification as running mate Tim Walz ‘fumbled’ a key VP debate answer against JD Vance, nodding along to Vance’s faux bipartisanship and bungling a Tiananmen Square timeline question by talking about biking. Harris also discloses that while staff auditioned Walz, Josh Shapiro and Mark Kelly, her first choice was Pete Buttigieg—but she deemed it too risky for a Black woman nominee. The debate ultimately had negligible polling impact.

articles.title: Erika Kirk, widow of Charlie Kirk, named new CEO of Turning Point USA
articles.trailText: Late co-founder previously expressed that he would want his wife to lead in the event of his death, organization says
articles.summary: Erika Kirk, widow of late Turning Point USA co-founder Charlie Kirk (fatally shot last week), has been named CEO and board chair of the pro-MAGA youth group. The organization says Charlie had designated her successor and framed her appointment as a test of faith and resolve to carry on his mission to “save” the country. Founded in 2012, TPUSA transformed youth politics but faced workplace discrimination claims. Erika holds political science and international relations degrees, a juris master’s, is pursuing a doctorate in Christian leadership, runs faith-based apparel Proclaim Streetwear, and is a former Miss Arizona USA and college basketball player. A memorial is set for Sept. 21 with Trump, Vance, and Rubio.

articles.title: Trump administration asks supreme court to allow firing of Fed’s Lisa Cook
articles.trailText: Request sets stage for historic test of presidential power as Trump pursues greater control of the Federal Reserve
articles.summary: The Trump administration asked the US Supreme Court for an emergency order to allow firing Fed governor Lisa Cook, citing unconfirmed mortgage-fraud claims after an appeals court blocked her removal, marking a test of presidential power over the Fed’s independence. Cook, a Biden appointee and first Black woman on the Fed board (term to 2038), denies wrongdoing; lawyers argue the president lacks removal authority. Though too late for this week’s policy meeting—where new governor Stephen Miran dissented for deeper cuts—Trump has publicly demanded interest-rate reductions, challenging Fed autonomy. District Judge Jia Cobb had ruled Trump’s allegations insufficient, prompting the DOJ’s appeal.

articles.title: House Democrats call for FCC chair to quit over Jimmy Kimmel suspension
articles.trailText: Hakeem Jeffries and five other leaders accuse Brendan Carr of ‘corrupt abuse of power’ after late-night show suspended
articles.summary: House Democratic leaders led by Hakeem Jeffries demanded FCC Chair Brendan Carr’s resignation, accusing him of abusing regulatory power to force ABC to suspend Jimmy Kimmel Live! after Kimmel’s monologue on the killing of conservative activist Charlie Kirk. Nexstar affiliate president Andrew Alford called Kimmel’s remarks “offensive and insensitive.” Carr condemned them as “truly sick,” threatened Disney/ABC with regulatory action for alleged misinformation and public-interest violations. Democrats vowed congressional probes and subpoenas, labeling the suspension and the recent cancellation of Stephen Colbert’s show as censorship and part of a corrupt pay-to-play scheme.

articles.title: Wildfire smoke will kill nearly 1.4m each year by end of century if emissions not curbed – study
articles.trailText: Separate research found that at the current rate of global heating, more than 70,000 people will die in the US by 2050
articles.summary: Researchers project that unchecked climate warming could boost annual global deaths from wildfire smoke to 1.4m by 2100—six times current levels—due to stronger, drier vegetation fueling larger blazes. In the US, fatalities may climb from 40,000 today to 71,000 by 2050, with California, New York and Texas especially vulnerable. Economic losses in America could reach $608bn/year by mid-century. Africa could see an 11-fold rise in fire-smoke mortality. Authors urge cuts in greenhouse gases, expanded fuels management and better community protection during smoke events.

articles.title: Who sat next to whom at Trump’s Windsor banquet – and what does it tell us?
articles.trailText: US president was next to Princess of Wales while Rupert Murdoch had the ear of Starmer’s chief of staff
articles.summary: At the Windsor state banquet for Donald Trump, seating revealed power plays: Trump sat centrally beside the Princess of Wales; Rupert Murdoch was placed next to Labour leader Keir Starmer’s embattled chief of staff Morgan McSweeney; Starmer shared a table with Blackstone’s Stephen Schwarzman after a £90 bn US investment pledge; Kemi Badenoch sat by AI entrepreneur Sam Altman amid his feud with Elon Musk; Queen Camilla flanked longtime confidant US Treasury official Scott Bessent; and Tiffany Trump was paired with Apple CEO Tim Cook, signaling restored warmth between Trump and Silicon Valley. The lineup, overseen by protocol, Downing Street and the White House, highlighted personal alliances shaping UK–US relations.

articles.title: ‘Sun day’: US climate activists to rally for clean energy amid Trump attacks
articles.trailText: Some 200 events are planned across the US this Sunday to celebrate growth of solar power and energy efficiency
articles.summary: US climate activists will host over 200 'Sun Day' events this Sunday, led by Bill McKibben and 350.org, to celebrate solar power and energy efficiency and counter Trump’s 150-plus anti-renewable actions since January. Showcasing installations—from Habitat for Humanity solar panels and electric school buses in Virginia to electric Ford F-150–powered concerts in New Hampshire—Sun Day replaces defensive climate marches with proactive celebrations. High-profile gatherings in Union Square feature Jane Fonda and Antonique Smith performing Here Comes the Sun; local efforts include Indigenous dances in Oregon, net-zero fire stations in New Paltz and solar home tours in DC. Organizers hope this optimistic approach will broaden the climate movement’s appeal amid regulatory rollbacks and rising US emissions.

articles.title: The Indiana town suffering under the shadow of a BP refinery: ‘They’ve had way too many accidents’
articles.trailText: Whiting residents worried after facility, which has had multiple problems, shut down temporarily after rain
articles.summary: After a 6-inch storm on August 19 flooded Whiting, Indiana, BP’s 400,000-bpd Whiting Refinery shut down, spewing oil fumes into basements and causing a 50-ft hydrocarbon sheen along Lake Michigan. The facility’s repeated breakdowns—2019 air pollution suit, 2022 fire, 2024 outage and pipeline leak—have heightened residents’ fears amid regulatory rollbacks and climate-driven extreme storms. State inspectors flagged oil-soaked grounds and failed wastewater treatment. Locals demand infrastructure upgrades, citing chronic accidents, untransparent risk disclosures and BP’s global track record, fearing further environmental and health hazards.

articles.title: ‘The dungeon’ at Louisiana’s notorious prison reopens as Ice detention center
articles.trailText: Critics condemn reopening of ‘Camp J’ unit at Angola in service of Trump’s nationwide immigration crackdown, noting its history of brutality and violence
articles.summary: Governor Jeff Landry declared a state of emergency to refurbish Angola’s former Camp J 'dungeon'—a notorious solitary unit—and rebrand it as "Camp 57" to house 400 of ICE’s "worst" detainees under Trump’s crackdown. Critics say using the largest US maximum-security prison, with a legacy of brutality, forced farm labor and racial violence on a former plantation site, blurs civil immigration detention and criminal incarceration. Detainees lack guaranteed counsel, transparency over renovations and management is murky, and ongoing lawsuits challenge abusive conditions.

articles.title: Trump cheers suspension of Jimmy Kimmel’s show after host’s Charlie Kirk comments | First Thing
articles.trailText: The two largest Hollywood unions voiced support for Kimmel. Plus, Bernie Sanders becomes first US senator to say Israel committing genocide in Gaza
articles.summary: ABC suspended Jimmy Kimmel Live! indefinitely after his monologue on Charlie Kirk’s supposed ‘murder’ and criticism of VP-elect JD Vance, following a threat by the Trump-appointed regulator. Trump applauded while WGA, SAG and Democrats defended him. Sen. Bernie Sanders called Israel’s actions in Gaza genocide, a first in the chamber; a judge ordered pro-Palestinian leader Mahmoud Khalil’s deportation amid appeals. Other briefs: Fed cut rates 25bps; Venezuela drills; French unions strike over budget cuts; Florida��s 12th execution; AI warned unregulated tech threatens publishing; Trump DOJ sued to halt Vermont climate law.

articles.title: RFK Jr’s vaccine panel appointees to set agenda despite lack of experience
articles.trailText: Some have little to no documented experience with vaccines while others have undermined their safety
articles.summary: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has replaced 17 CDC ACIP advisers with 13 Kennedy appointees—5 new plus 8 June hires—many lacking vaccine expertise or opposing established immunization science. This anti-vaccine–leaning panel will vote on MMRV, newborn hepatitis B and Covid shots despite warnings that insurance coverage and Vaccines for Children could be jeopardized. Critics warn of delays (e.g., shifting hepatitis B to age 4), narrowed Covid guidance, and unverified VAERS data misuse. Resignations of senior health leaders, >50 falsehoods noted, and looming measles outbreaks underscore the risks of politicizing vaccine policy.

articles.title: US judge orders Mahmoud Khalil deported citing ‘misrepresented facts’ on green card form
articles.trailText: Lawyers say pro-Palestinian activist remains protected from immigration enforcement while separate federal court case proceeds
articles.summary: An immigration judge in Louisiana ordered deportation of pro-Palestinian activist Mahmoud Khalil to Algeria or Syria, ruling he willfully misrepresented information on his green card application. Khalil, a legal permanent resident married to a US citizen with a US-born son, and a former Columbia student who led nationwide campus protests, was detained for three months. His lawyers plan to appeal and say a separate federal court in New Jersey has blocked any removal or detention while his civil rights case proceeds. Khalil denounced the ruling as retaliation for his free speech. Critics argue pro-Palestinian advocacy is not antisemitism.

articles.title: Trump says he plans to designate antifa as ‘major terrorist organization’
articles.trailText: It is unclear how anti-fascists, an umbrella term for far-left-leaning groups rather than a single entity, will be labeled
articles.summary: During a UK state visit, President Donald Trump announced plans to designate antifa—a decentralized umbrella of far-left anti-fascist activists—as a “major terrorist organization,” calling it a “SICK, DANGEROUS, RADICAL LEFT DISASTER.” He said he would push to investigate funders, even though antifa’s informal, nonhierarchical nature makes it ineligible for the State Department’s foreign terror list and no federal domestic terrorism statute exists amid First Amendment protections. Louisiana Senator Bill Cassidy and Texas Senator Ted Cruz previously backed similar resolutions, while ex-FBI Director Christopher Wray testified that antifa is an ideology, not an organization. The declaration came hours after ABC suspended Jimmy Kimmel Live! under FCC pressure.

articles.title: Trump news at a glance: royals roll out red carpet amid protests; Kimmel taken off air over Kirk comments
articles.trailText: Trump was kept out of reach of critics as he met Britain’s king and queen, amid furore back in US over suspension of Jimmy Kimmel Live! show – key US politics stories from 17 September 2025
articles.summary: Donald Trump's second UK state visit began with royal pomp—horse-drawn carriage, flypast and a £150bn US investment pledge by PM Keir Starmer—while London protests demanded his removal. In the US, ABC suspended Jimmy Kimmel Live! indefinitely after regulator threats over his Charlie Kirk remarks; the Federal Reserve cut rates to 4–4.25%; former CDC officials warned RFK Jr’s vaccine policies threaten public health; ex-BLS chief Erika McEntarfer decried data interference; DOJ deleted a report on far-right violence; Senate’s Bernie Sanders called Israel’s Gaza actions genocide; Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent faced dual-residence scrutiny; and Barack Obama cautioned against rising political violence.
